J3NGTrZh42DrDmMsaCM3Fw.text: This ramen place could do well in the LA area. I had the miso ramen spicy and the flavor was on point. The charsu was delicious and basically melts in your mouth Very quick service of course and a great feel to the restaurant. Definitely will stop in again when I'm in town.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen with green onion with egg added.

TBTI_0enQ87y3J55sVOYPA.text: The restaurant is pretty small and they are almost always packed. So get there right when they open if you don't want to wait. If you like thin straight noodle, get their tonkotsu ramen. One of the best bowls of ramen you'll ever find anywhere especially in Vegas. Parking is pretty sparse so it can be a gamble finding a parking spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkotsu ramen (added nori and nitamago) and takana fried rice

kkLylIY17c8fuQuT4Gvq9Q.text: We made a stop by here before we left vegas. It was insanely crowded that the servers didnt have time to write our name down for the wait. So we decided to togo our food instead. The ramen was more salty than i would like. The noodles weren't as chewy either. My friend got the cha siu bowl and it reminded me of the vietnamese thit kho.

h8gkWW8zVwSJrjXeAPw8iw.text: Seriously.... The Best Ramen I had in US! It is truly authentic and is cooked by the Japanese chef.  This place stays busy for a reason. A little hole in a wall but the place is kept clean. Ramen ranges $6-$8. hubby had fried rice and Gyoza which he gave me the thumbs up. Prepare to wait for at least 15 min. Seating in the restaurants is 30 ppl max. This is a place to come, eat and get out so I wouldn't recommend for a large group.  I am seriously in LOVE with this place!

L8smCX2mCH2j4eMJY6h7jw.text: I use to like coming here prices are good but at the end of my meal they  didn't ask me to tip they told me too the waitress barely spoke English and had the nerve to tell me to tip I had to break a 20 to give her a $1 because I think that's rude in any customer service job or server job  I'll tip when and if I want to tip

O6EUyPQk-AZQUeDhIeb63Q.text: This has become our favor spot when my bf and I try to pick a place for dinner.  The food: very good. I would suggest Spicy Tonkatsu, Black Garlic Tonkatsu and Fried rice... dont forget the flavor egg on the side The service: small place run by 2 regular servers and with a long constant long service line, they are still very attentive. The drink: they don't really have a variety of drink on their menu but no worry, kungfu tea is right next door. The price: very reasonably low The onyl thing negative about this place is you always have to wait in a long line but it also not a huge deal when it is this good.

UUGxcPC-UltckFUpAoh8wA.text: This place is yummy!!! It was a big hit with even my picky best friend!!! We will be back!

cURLCdZExHqgMaToB-oeLw.text: The best Ramen PERIOD. Beats L.A.'s Santouka & Daikokuya. Tonkotsu Ramen was excellent with creamy broth and melt in your mouth chashu.  Kimchi fried rice was nothing special and gyoza was mediocre, in fact, a bit burnt.  Nevertheless, the ramen was that delicious that the 5 star is still well deserved. Only a ~20 persons capacity, so think twice before bringing your party of 10+.  Servers were attentive.  Well worth the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RHyrJMMrCw4kJTR4v3A9AA.text: I read the term "complex tasting broth" in a review for another ramen place and I never got the term till I tried the tonkotsu shoyu ramen here. Best ramen ever! The fried rice is pretty good to but the gyoza is nothing to rave about.

3TeGNo18clOynF-Z33ePvQ.text: Get 2 things!  It's just so good!  I'd almost come to Vegas solely for the ramen here.  Every time we come to visit we rent a car just so we can come off the strip and eat here!  All their ramens are fantastic and a great deal.  The pork is extremely tender and we always get an extra rice bowl with the chiashu pork!  The reviews really speak for themselves here.  The only thing that's a problem is that the place is too small.  There's almost always a wait, but no complaints here.

JIeLuw55JIzS2LwAzMrhUw.text: Craving for some Ramen! Monta is the spot to go to. This place definitely satisfies your Ramen craving. There was a long wait since this place is very small and their was 8 of us. It was worth the wait!  I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen. It was mighty delicious! I also ordered a side of the dumplings, which a must try. You can tell they make it fresh, it's not your typical frozen prepackaged ones.

CZVfDZ3R2Pd3rENw-YcNbA.text: Best ramen place I've been to! I've gone there often enough that they started to remember my order. The food comes out almost immediately after you order and when there is wait, it's never super long.

Pt0DHB5ajkRxLG7eCYqtew.text: Small restaurant in Chinatown. Waited for 10 minutes at 5pm Friday for a table.  Good portion (not too big or small) for a decent price.  All 4 ramen options are same price $6.95 with an extra serving of ramen noodles for $1.50.  Broth is not as flavorful, but not as salty as other ramen places in Los Angeles. I didn't have to drink glasses of water afterwards.  Egg was ok. I've had better.  Pork was tender and yummy.

Mn3OvNl5tZBs_Ba5FZLEXw.text: I must say, out of all the ramen places I've tried, Monta definitely sticks out. I've had ramen from NorCal, SoCal, and New York. I don't call myself very knowledgeable but I sure as hell know what I like to eat. The best ramen place that I've tried is Ippudo, which is located in Manhattan NY. However, Monta does come close.  Monta is quite a small restaurant and it has one of those homely feels to it. One thing I didn't quite like was how stuffy it was. I went during one of the warm days, it wasn't even hot, but all they had was fans and I couldn't even feel them. So the place had pretty poor circulation and stuffy. I'd hate to see what it's like during an actual summer temperature where it hits over 100 degrees.   I had their tonkotsu ramen with corn -- definitely recommended. Their broth is rich and full of flavor. It is yummy. However, because of how rich and yummy the broth is, I don't suggest adding an egg to it. Because once you do, the egg loses its flavor and the broth overpowers it. So no point.   I would've given this place five full stars if it were not for the waitress that helped us. Oh the service was fine throughout our meal. When we first took our orders down, she offered us, "Would you like everything on one check or split checks?" We were a party of 8. Obviously, some had cash and some didn't so we would prefer the latter. So we answered with, "Split checks would be nice :)" But then she responds with, "I could do that but could you please not do 8 separate checks? It's a little bit too much."  I'M SORRY? Really, why did you even bother to offer?   I didn't feel like arguing or bothering so we just went with one check. You don't offer something then take back your offer. Or at least lay your own terms down before you finish offering. Thank you.   But hey. Food's good. :) Just that tiny bit irked me.

5_992F2dPM1v-iadJe1rtw.text: This place is excellent. We chose to order take out since we live close by and the food was still fresh and flavorful by the time we got home. The noodles are cooked well - and when ordering take out they give the option of cooking the noodles yourself at home or having them cooked in the restaurant. The tonkatsu broth is bomb - both regular and spicy. This place is highly recommended for those looking for authentic ramen in the local Vegas area.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen with pork

rhmpsdMrn6pTeqVaZaBMhg.text: Since I walk to this restaurant, a lot of people wait outside and the restaurant is very small, only can attended about 30 people, the outside of restaurant smell very strong, looks like they use a lot of flavor to mix up and attract people to go their restaurant. Once I walk in to restaurant, smell stronger when walk closer, it is open kitchen, so that you can see how they make and prepare the food, it can make people feel safe to eat and I saw almost everyone order the ramen, so that may the one reason why all flavor comes out so quickly. Once I get menu, not much food option in the menu, several ramen and fried rice to choose, I heard their ramen is good, so I order the miso ramen with thin noodles, add corn and egg on top. About 15 minutes, the server give me my ramen, this ramen looks so bright and opaque, because it have green onion and a little bit seaweed with the corn and egg on top, those makes this dish so colorful, once I smell the dish, it is fragrant and looks like very tasty. The noodles very soft and moist, when I eat that my mouthfeel is smooth and stringy, the soup is very salty for me, and the egg is cold and smooth too, when I ate a lot of soup I feel oily. The dish is not very big, so I don't feel full when I finished this dish.

SRjuM4bTYpxwaUWlt8GjTg.text: As comfort food goes, Ramen can be such a go-to meal when it's cold outside (We both sweat WAY TOO MUCH to be slurping noodles in mega hot molten lava broth in the summer)! So during the colder months, we make our way as much as possible to Monta for Ramen  It's tiny noodle shop, the counter seats ten and five table tops that seats twelve total.  It's open until late at night and it cranks out people like no one's business-prety much there's always a waiting list to get into this place!  And it is well worth it,  the Ramen is some of the best that we have had, (and that includes Japan!  Gasp! Horror! Blasphemy!) but it's True-we went to Hide Chan Ramen in Fukuoka and the broth wasn't as good as Monta's!  As we always do, there's a couple of things that we order and not much else, (it's hard to venture out when you know a dish is that good).  We start the Japanese journey with an order of the Gyoza; these pork dumplings are perfectly cooked, a crunchy charred exterior that holds in the moist juices of the pork.  Add Sujoyu, (a mixture of Vinegar and Soy Sauce) Rayu (Chili Oil) and some raw garlic, dip these little moon shaped suckers in it and pop' em in your pie hole!   After you've wet your appetite, it's time move onto the Main Event; the Ramen.  As is, we're partial to the Tonkotsu (Pork Bone) Ramen- the broth is made from simmered Pork Bone, Fat and Collagen which gives it its super rich, almost creamy soup that can easily fill you up and warm your body.  It's most definitely the most satisfying noodle soup on this planet.  And especially since this is a Kyushu dish, (Fukuoka is on the  island of Kyushu) I'm particular to the flavor.  (Japan based on its regions have different tastes and styles to the same dish).    Monta's Tonkotsu Ramen recipe is from Kurume, (not far from Fukuoka) so it's really close to my heart.  Which is why you won't see me ordering the other Ramen, (there's Shoyu, Miso and Tonkotsu-Shoyu).  One of these days, We'll get to them......  There's a couple of add ons and I would definitely go and order an extra Chashu, (Roasted Pork) these tender slices of heaven are as much as a main character as the Noodles and Broth.  Getting to the Noodles, have you ever had anything better than Ramen Noodles? They're just so unique; chewy and Monta really cooks them right.  We also get the Nitamago, (cooked egg) Takana, (Mustard Leaf) and sometimes Nori, (Seaweed) -the egg for extra protein, the Takana for the vegetable and crunch and Nori for the contrast in texture.  You can also order an extra helping of Ramen Noodles (Kaedama) if you have extra broth, but there's no way I have ever had enough room for that!!!  In the Summertime, they serve Hiyashi-Chuka (Cold Chinese Noodles). It's refreshing and cold perfect for the summer with bits of Ham, Cucumber, Bean Sprouts, Takana, Nori and Sesame Seeds over Ramen noodles in a light Soy; it's the best on a hot day!!!  I forgot to mention the Rice bowls that they serve as well; I'm not the biggest fan of these bowls but that just me- a lot of people rave about them!  I know what I like and I'm happy staying on my side of the menu if you know what I mean...The service here is excellent, the waitresses are terribly polite and the the food comes outs really fast! (They need too, cuz they have to get people in and out of there)!  Ratings (Out of Five Stars)  Food          4.75 Ambience  4 Service      4.5

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkostu Ramen

Gi8owChJuJh0-k7FeGJcpg.text: Been eating here regularly since they first opened. By far, the best ramen in Vegas. Maybe best shoyu ramen on the west coast (believe me, I've eaten a lot of ramen up and down the west coast).    Love the atmosphere... Very traditional ramenya... Small cozy seating area, bar counter searing, usual garnishes.  It's how it's suppose to be.  And yes, the waitresses really are and speak Japanese (unlike most "Japanese" places in Vegas).  4.5-stars but I guess I have to round up.

ra70rbIdajwf-AKYOUkUVg.text: Best ramen I've had in the USA.  I used to live in Japan, so I miss having the option of eating ramen. I've tried it at several places in the US, and haven't found anything close until I went to Monta.   I always order the tonkatsu ramen and request the noodles to be on the hard side, which is called 'katame'. It adds a bit of texture to the noodles and is an option you can always ask for in Japan.   This is one of the places I always stop at when I'm in Vegas.

QWOJyTf6Q94zYS3rTOUz7g.text: Monta is the best ramen in Vegas!!!!   This restaurant is located in a small plaza and it's also a small location that can sit only about 20-25 ppl.   There is usually at least an hour wait during dinner and lunch time.   They don't take reservations and won't sit you unless all parties are present.  I highly recommend coming during a weekday or early before rush hour.   But even if you had to wait, it's still worth trying for the 1st time.  The food comes out really fast and the servers are not a few feet away.   Monta is very efficient in getting you in and out.  The menu overall is very affordable and what's even better is that the ramen is delicious!     The 2 dishes you have to try are Kuro Ramen Black Garlic oil $7.95 and Takana Fried Rice $6.95.  The ramen broth is very rich from a long period of simmering and the noodles comes out chewy just like the way i like it.  If you like roasted garlic, you have to try it.  I found the flavor was even better when you add chili oil.  Eat this ramen fast because the soup gets richer and saltier the longer the soup sits.   It was a bit too salty and thicker for my liking.  But it's still a good ramen that you can't get anywhere else in this world!!!!!  You can also add additional toppings for additional fee if you are feeling adventurous.   The Takana Fried rice is the best rice i have ever had and i want to note that i'm not much of a ricer eater.  But the way they made the fried rice is out of this world.  Its served with chasu pork, mustard vegetables, green onions, eggs and white onions.  I loved the texture with the white and green onions mixed together.  They also give you a side of radish ginger for more enhanced flavoring.   Note:  1.  They do accept credit card if the bill is over $10. 2.  They don't allow you to bring drinks from another restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen black garlic oil $7.95!

TWptY91MyRYbPIyxGXOL0g.text: Food: 8/10 - Pretty good but not the best  Service : 9/10 - Waitresses were attentive and nice  Price: 7/10 - Good price considering the popularity of the place Overall: 7.5/10 - If you're in the area and craving ramen, check this place out! Not anything mind blowing but pretty good!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

anwj0SzyD6pkpVvnKQjqsA.text: I've tried a couple different ramen places around town, none can compete, there is always a line to get in, but let me tell you, this place is worth the wait! I always get the spicy tonkatsu ramen with egg and see weed, it is filled with warm and amazing flavors, I honestly think it is one of my favorite meals ever! Their broth tastes like a slice of heaven, there are no words to describe this concoction they put together, but trust me, you have to try it! Pork belly appetizer is really good as well

Kx2B3plJAP2BQ2Ywtnl29Q.text: We found this place from yelp since this restaurant had better reviews than others. But we both didn't like it. We ordered 2 different kinds of Ramen, and both were too salty and soup was not hot enough. There will always be a wait, but it's not worth it. I would not recommend this place.

VNqA4Lz9nEX0hO_8xU7NvQ.text: One of the better ramen places that will not cost an arm and a leg.  Small place but gets pack easily.  Also service is good.  After a bowl of ramen and you are not full; you can refill on ramen for like $1.50.

T-QTOGnW0xBAdizU28kPGQ.text: Coming to Monta Ramen was probably the best decision I made while in vegas. My party arrived about half an hour before the shop opened so we decided to go to the boba shop next door. By the time we had gotten our drinks there was already line in front of Monta before it opened! It is quite a small shop for the business it draws in so I can see why there would be a long wait.  I got the Tonkotsu Ramen and it was heaven on earth. The broth was so thick and satisfying. It was actually so thick that the spoon even floated on it. This is now my favorite ramen and I am so sad I can only eat it in vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xZExKgYe8Y7neG7-xgLzDA.text: We met my aunty here for ramen today because she said it was the "best ramen in Las Vegas!" We've been putting off a ramen date for a while so we finally met here here for Ramen.  We waited 45 minutes to be seated because the place itself is tiny. There's space for maybe 35 people maximum. There's space for about 3 people to wait inside and the rest have to wait outside. Today was hot and the sun was shining right on us so we tried to squeeze inside which didn't make the servers very happy.   Food was 5/5. The ramen was hands down the best ramen I have ever had. I had the spicy ramen. Everything about it was perfect.   However, the server asked us to leave when we were done eating so they could make room for others because "they're waiting." We weren't even sitting for five minutes before he asked us to. I paid for their food and tipped them for their service. If I wanted take out I would have took the food to go. The reason we go out to eat is so be able to socialize and talk.  That was extremely rude and I don't think should ever happen again. If this is their normal attitude toward customers then I'm disappointed in their staff and something should be changed.

y3sfLlAh0TdUMDQyfbrI7Q.text: This restaurant is so cozy and welcoming. all the staff there are very nice and polite. one of the best ramen restaurants I've ever been to.

FSgCoKa0Udoli_HpM7LyQA.text: Excellent food with great quantity and quality! I had their black garlic ramen and it tasted delicious but a little heavy cause of their soup broth. My friends had their tonkatsu ramen, shoyu ramen, and spicy tonkatsu ramen and were all super satisfied. Since I'm a fat ass I also had their chashu rice and pork rice and honestly everything here taste delicious at a great price!

5off2kvXf90Xl9GULYA5qw.text: We were visiting Las Vegas and decided to try the famous Monta Ramen. We got there around seven and were told it was going to be a twenty min wait but ended up waiting an hour. But the Ramen was so worth it.  I got the Tonkotsu Ramen. The broth was rich and creamy. It really carried the flavor of the pork broth through. I asked for thick noodles in my Ramen. The noodles were perfectly chewy. The toppings on the Ramen like the slices of pork were melt in your mouth good.  The only negative I would have to say were the side dishes. The kimchi fried rice lacked any kimchi flavor and tasted a little off.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The tonkotsu ramen.

cLAYSIj_Lz-qt2rOPHLIxA.text: If I was an egg I would want to grow up (or stay the same?) to be a monta egg.   The restaurant only fits like 3 1/2 people (on a good day) plus 2 tiny children which is why there's always a wait. Been here countless times, and there's always a wait and it's always worth it.  This ramen is what I compare all other ramen to. Don't think the noodles are hand made, don't care. Hot tea served in a soda can, don't care. Eggs probably don't come from cage free, free range chickens, don't care.  Sometimes when I'm eating soup somewhere else I get sad because I could be eating soup here. Their shoyu broth is so clear I can see my reflection and it shows who I am inside. Their egg, omg. 5 Stars for the egg alone.

3EgLYCxGEHORL5JhdHgHIQ.text: There are different types of broth.  2 kinds of noodles very delicious  Choose topping.  Great prices delicious place!  Not a huge fan of there fried rice.   Friendly staff.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Awesome noodles

ek67cpQ-9kjkgliPWNTAjA.text: Best Ramen bar in town. Chashu's so tender, you don't need teeth to eat it.   They're always busy and have people lining up outside. Expect to wait 10-15 mins but be patient because it's worth it.

ZUCziSC1tFscq6zSqI5q0Q.text: When we arrived 11:30 and there's a line, we knew it's gonna be good. Sat at the bar and watched their kitchen. It's very authentic. Tonkotsu stock is thick and tasty. Pork is tender belly meat lightly stewed.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. #1 with egg

XIwmM5ovarYCnD13PAlJ-w.text: One of my favorite ramen spots in Las Vegas. It's off the strip and the broth is pretty heavy but be aware the lines are long. The good thing is that it's located in a plaza with a lot of dessert options like Kung Fu Tea and Sweet Raku so you can explore a bit while waiting to get served. Add butter to your ramen for an extra kick!

w8K4mYOR7n9W7fcUZI_30w.text: This 2 star review is specifically for this location*  This place is so small! For how busy it always is, I feel like they need to invest in a bigger location. When my friends and I got here the line was out the door. 6 groups of 4 ahead of us and a full house cramped with people. The only reason we stayed and waited was because my friends were really craving ramen. If you really want Monta Ramen, try the location on Eastern and Serene (Next to EOS). That place isn't as busy as this one!  The ramen was good, portion was generous which is why I'm even giving this place 2 stars. I also ordered gyoza and it tasted like it was the frozen kind you buy from the store. I suspected that because it was still cold in the middle and because they were all stuck together. Im guessing they half assed cooking it because it was busy.   Their condiments on their table (soy sauce, chili sauce, vinegar, gyoza sauce) weren't labeled and when my friend picked up the vinegar, the lid opened and spilled it all over the table. It seemed full so I'm guessing whoever refilled it didn't close the lid properly.   Lastly, I felt rushed. I couldn't enjoy my food because I felt like the servers where just walking robots trying to get everyone in and out.   Because of all these things, I probably won't come to this location again especially if there's another location more convenient and less hectic.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

pFZHHVv-SX7xf4nQaMfMCw.text: Small but full of flavor and character! This place is a local hotspot and must visit for tourists. The broths are delicious, the noodles taste fresh the options are simple but it's my favorite way to have ramen.

XxwqnELOA5qHIAA7oVN1aw.text: Yum!! Not a great place for a big group since it's relatively small inside.  If you're planning to come here, I would definitely recommend coming before 11:30am (when it opens) and wait for it to open! There are people who line up and are seated right when they open, so if you arrive at 11:35am, you'll end up waiting about a half hour to get seated.  RAMEN is amazing! They have a special tonkotsu-shoyu ramen and it was greaaat. The broth was amazing and there was enough goodies in the ramen to make me full! They also have some rice bowls (we tried a small pork belly to share amongst the 5 of us). Even the "small" bowl was a pretty decent size. We were full!  Wait for our food wasn't too bad at all and we were in & out in about 30-45 mins. We sat at the bar and was able to watch them cook everything - fascinating!  Go-to ramen place in Vegas? DEF.

2TWiF7JX76C2pbWnkJlAkg.text: Oh wow!  This place is good.  Noodles perfectly cooked, meat tender and melts in your mouth, and broth very rich and flavorful.  Probably one of the best meals we had in Vegas.

ayBg0pqxvLRyY4ag6aFzYw.text: Best ramen I've ever had. The garlic is a little rich as a full meal but everything else is just perfect.

v97qNMyx0_VbBZXLkeQyBg.text: I found the best Ramen place in Vegas!! It's a small restaurant and after learning that the wait could be LONG, we smartly decided to go at 4pm in the afternoon.  Got seated immediately!    The ramen here were truly authentic.  I had the miso flavor.  The soup base was thick, creamy, flavorful yet not dense.  The noodles were cooked just right and not soggy at all.  The pork was a great cut of proportionally fat, meat and fat --juicy but not greasy.   Overall, I would come back again and again!

_b1D9qY0bQwt4QjyUS5CBg.text: Great ramen spot in Las Vegas! I ordered the black garlic ramen. It had great flavor but wasn't over powering. The thing noodles still had a bite to it and the pork was buttery and melts in your mouth. The egg however wasnt good - over cooked and little flavor which was disappointing since it was an extra. Other than that everything else was good.

v9-Pg00ssZWspjtRcXlkJQ.text: We arrived when they had first opened and there were already people waiting outside to get in. I was expecting something special but everything was pretty basic. I don't know if I've been spoiled living in LA where we have the best of every cuisine.  Don't get me wrong, it was good. Service was quick and fine. It doesn't feel right giving them 4 stars though, just doesn't feel 4 stars worthy. So 3 stars it will be. Everything was basic.

tIgXesd8WT1j0LdS_U44AQ.text: This place was pack before the door even open. Good thing we there early. We were able to get a table and service right away. The broth and noodles are delicious. Very flavorful and lots of add on if needed. The meat I'm the soup was very tender.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

FFVPwQbCpsJUsJz-nfrEvw.text: Ooooh kaaay. This place is off the chain!! The ramen here is by far tremendous. If you like Shin Sen Gumi, you will be blown away with Monta Ramen. I got the Tonkotsu Ramen with thin noodles. The noodles were perfectly cooked, a little chewy and a little bite, amazingly done. The broth was not salty at all, perfectly seasoned. I also got an added egg which was soft boiled and added to the creaminess texture of the soup. The service is the only knock, but understandable since the place was packed out for a Tuesday night. I will definitely be back!  This place rocks.
