Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly noodles.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen. ~$8.00 excellent.

IY9ESqD-EqZOglnOt_Vk_g.text: My favorite ramen of them all. I like the thick noodles, chewy. The tonkatsu broth is thick and flavor is amazing, the chashu pork is the best I've had soft and melt-in-your-mouth. Nitimago soft boiled egg is USUALLY perfect, occasionally over cooked but it's rare. Kimchee is good and I highly recommend the gyoza dumplings, order them the second you sit, before you look at your menu, because they take a while. The black garlic ramen is also amazing and the rice bowls with pork belly/chashu are also good but I always return to their amazing tonkatsu ramen with thick noodles, chewy, extra chashu and nitimago, my favorite ramen of all time!

SgmxCdhS-3Oqo83hJEjMTw.text: It's like 3.75 stars. Not a huge fan of ramen, unless it's remakarable place and though it was good, it wasn't anything I would want to stay in line waiting for it. It was just not comparable to ramen places in LA or NY.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy donkatsu ramen

4Sd7GAxiINTyYBODpXgizA.text: Monta has a line out the door, as expected from its tasty food and popularity. I was lucky enough to wait only 10 minutes, because the two parties before me weren't there when their names were called. The restaurant is tiny with around 10 items on their menu. They focus on ramen with two types of broth and other rice bowl dishes. Unlike their wait, the service is quick and efficient. We ordered the shoyu ramen with corn, large pork belly rice bowl and chashu bowl. The Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen had a deep and thick broth. The pork belly rice bowl was delicious! The thin and tender pieces of pork were cooked to perfection and the fatty components melted in your mouth. The juices from the pork travel down to the rice and leaving enough flavor for you to even eat the rice alone. The Mentaiko bowl was a great contrast to the ramen. However, the Mentaiko is very salty and they don't give you much.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Rice Bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu ramen with corn
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tiny restaurant with limited seating. Be prepared to wait

Fgz3W9S5T6Cd9K30DygMaQ.text: Love this place! Every time I got it's packed but it's worth the wait! Their gyoza's, fried rice, and Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen are the best!

62kRxNYszQIBiRS9yES7CQ.text: This place is small. There is a wait if you come here. The food is great and affordable. It is worth the wait. I tried the miso ramen it was a big serving. The pork belly bowl was a good portion and had was delicious. Fried rice was tasty.  I ordered to go pork belly rice bowl to take back home to LA.  Next time I'm in Vegas this will be my new fave ramen place.

vRAB30uDtCLibZx0Uvkvwg.text: It was delicious! We had to wait a bit and the guest in front of us was lying about his whole party being there to be sat. He took our seats!   The ramen I got was the spicy one. It was delicious. It was a good about of ramen. I ordered the extra ramen cause I was hungry but by the time I finished my first ramen, I was full. I forced myself to finish eating the rest cause they charge for you to take home.   The goyza was normal tasting. Nothing special.   Over all the prices were good and cheap and the food was good. They need a bigger place cause they get so much guests.   Beer was like only 2 bucks! It's like cheaper than anyplace around in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hRpEOqwrk-SJjZGhcMJICw.text: Very very solid ramen in Las Vegas! It's essentially in a strip mall, but I get the sense that this is the deal with a lot of restaurants off the strip in LV. There was a wait when I arrived (around 1pm on EDC weekend, so I anticipated this), and the place was very very small which meant waiting outside in 110+ degree heat... ramen is always worth the wait though! One thing I would suggest is to reorganize a bit so there is more room for waiting inside, and perhaps if possible find a way to keep more of the AC inside... I was happy I wasn't seated near the door because you were definitely feeling the hot air!   Anyway, the food... I ordered the miso and asked to add spicy paste - it wasn't listed as an add-on for the menu but they were happy to accomodate. The broth was rich, salty, and tasty, with a strong miso flavor which I really appreciated. Sometimes "miso" ramen just tastes like "salty" ramen lol - not the case here. The spicy sauce was a great choice, it had a nice garlicky flavor and blended well into the soup. The pork was delicious and well-cooked, but the portion wasn't as  large as I might have liked. The noodles were excellent! The miso comes with the wavy noodles and this is my personal preference, so I really enjoyed them. Very chewy and well cooked. There was also a healthy portion of menma, a delicious ajitama, and a piece of nori included. Probably should have just added more chashu for only $2.50... but I didn't think of it.   I also ordered gyoza which were not very memorable, maybe a little oily, but a nice side option if you need more food.   All around a good option if you can make the trek off-strip!

abwDfsEP0s-BXOvYlvmkAw.text: My friend and i got here around 7:30 p.m. and were lucky to grab the last two seats at the counter.   We got the Tonkotsu-shoyu ramen and it was quite good.  The egg was cooked just right, it was running and I loved how it was perfect with the soup..  The noodles had a good bounce to it , but the pork had too much fat.  I felt like my portion of the pork was small and didn't have much meat.  It had more fat than meat, which is why I lowered my rating.   However, when i come back here, I need to try their Kimchi fried rice, the table next to me ordered it  and it looked soooo good!!  It takes a while for the food to come, so if you super hungry prepare to wait.  When i left this place, i saw there was a large crowded gathered outside.  I'll make note of that the next time i'm back

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A nice hot bowl of ramen

n97ICSNoB1dXd3BWMRKz8Q.text: Always have a great experience here, good service, good food. It is a small space and there is usually a wait but it is usually pretty quick. Not recommended for large parties.

-ESOkH9OiBzGyBB6id8yeA.text: I'm always up for Ramen wherever I go. You don't really think of eating ramen when your in Vegas but there are several good places in sin city. I tried Monta when they were part of the crappy ramen festival last summer. I got a bowl but by the time I got it I did enjoy it very much. I wanted to give them another shot so I decided to hit this place up for a fresh bowl of noodles. Like most ramen houses the place is small and the night we went there was a slight wait. Gyoza ~ yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... Of course you have to get some because it just goes well with Ramen. These were pretty good with a crisp char. Kuro ~ yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... Which is tonkotsu with black mayu (garlic oil). Because its tonkotsu/hakata broth the noodes are the straight white ones. Broth was good. Not really salty. The black mayu brought out a nice garlic flavor. Good amount of kikurage and bamboo shoots. The chasu had a good equal amount of fat and meat with a good flavor to it. It didn't come with ajitama so I had planned to order one on the side but totally forgot. Would have liked to taste it to see how it compared to other places. Shoyu ~ yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... Friend ordered the shoyu. It had a great tasting broth. The noodles were the yellow chijiri type. It was slightly overcooked but it was pretty good. Service was hit and miss. Usually you get your gyoza before ramen but we got it the other way around. We also had ordered ice tea and soda but that never came. It was taken off the bill. Overall it was a decent bowl of ramen. Since this is the first ramen spot I tried in Vegas I cant compare to the other places in the city. I will stick with a 4 star for now. Eyes ~ Small place with lots of hungry peeps! Nose ~ Smells good!. Ear ~ Happy diners chatting and grubbing! Mouth ~ Ahhhh Ramen!! Tummy ~ Satisfied.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu black.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

mD6dkZ0u1I-JRhoAqptMGQ.text: A MUST WHEN IN VEGAS, BABY! Ok, I live in LA and we have many amazing ramen places. Silverlake Ramen being one of the best for me. However, it doesn't come between the love I have for Monta. I love Monta so much. It's just... so good. I can never finish a bowl of ramen at a restaurant. At Monta, watch me down the rest of the soup from the bowl.   I always order the Kuru Ramen which is the Black garlic oil ramen (just thinking about it, my god). I get it with butter, corn, egg, and nori. I skip out on the bamboo shoots because to me they don't really taste like anything. Order it with the butter and the corn, you won't regret it.

vbSmMVs9MxtkJMsmhfeFFQ.text: This place has terrible service. Everyone is so rude to you, and rushes you. My dad was outside making a phone call, but we had a table of 4. They would not let us order or sit until he came in. I understand it was busy, but he was literally outside, and the attitude they displayed was inappropriate & very rude.

SrtbNUYBZLAsikWIMJ0FuQ.text: This ramen place is pretty popular in Vegas so I thought i would check it out.   The place is pretty small, so the wait was a little long. But when we were finally able to order I got the spicy tonkatsu ramen with an added egg and seaweed.   The soup was a little buttery and heavy for my taste, but still not bad.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkatsu ramen with egg and seaweed

f6Nq4ftEEpVXENORvhzjIQ.text: The food was ok. I went in there with high expectations after seeing all the reviews. Is it the best? No but it was decent.

S0jOhAm5ahuYH71ND6IMng.text: Asked a friend where to meet for lunch and they picked out this place. It was 4 of us and it took about a hour to be seated around 11am on a weekday. Wouldn't recommend coming here during busy hours with a larger group because of limited seating.   Ordered the Special on the Spicy Ramen and it was very good but needed a bit more spice in my opinion,  also the fried rice was really good. Would come here again if they didnt have the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hour to be seated smh.

sNKz6pcwA_5QD6xHcmJXTA.text: This place is great for a cold and rainy day in Vegas (or really any day in Vegas because it was yummy). The broth is awesome and the noodles are super good. I don't have anything bad to say about this place because you can't go wrong with ramen.   The pork belly appetizer is awesome so you should definitely try that if you go.

q-MvAVD0I9u_XNGLH4lMzg.text: Here's Ramen(especially miso ramen but I was ordered Tonkotsu Shoyu) is very good!! If I'll visit Las Vagas, I would to visit again!

CZqAKTaXZBmNccpKCsRcOg.text: Judging by the constant lines and Japanese clientele, this place is legit. And because it's seemingly authentic, vegetarian ramen is a mere fantasy here. All ramen options are pork-based. While not a place for vegetarians, Monta is a great spot for a hangover cure after too much partying. The consensus from my carniovore/omnivore buddies was that the broths were tasty but a tad too salty towards the end. One friend observed a person eating rice on the side with his/her ramen, perhaps a good solution to the saltiness.  Because I didn't have a non-meat option for soup, I got two bowls of the mentaiko on rice instead. Mentaiko atop rice is nowhere near as tasty as the noodle version. Also, butter seemed to missing from the fish egg mixture. I probably won't order this again if I return. The vegetable gyozas are probably worth trying, though.  Service is pretty good for such a fast-paced dining environment; the staff really know how to manage lines and to keep things moving along without being rude or giving you the impression that you were being kicked out. I'd definitely recommend this to any person looking for a soothing soup after a night of endless drinks.

vYHuM5aZaw-aODuFs-PBSw.text: I really like this place a lot. The food is awesome, I always get the tonkatsu shuyo which has the chicken and port broth. It's a pretty good portion for the price. A side of kimchi could be a hit or miss because sometimes the they you like 2 pieces of kimchi and other times there'll be a lot. The ramen itself comes with the noodle, broth, mushroom, bamboo and two pieces of the pork slice. It's has a pretty awesome flavor. My friend and I always share the a big pork belly bowl as well. Which when you add a lot of pickled ginger, it is to die for. So when it comes to food, they're pretty awesome. But the service is a bit crappy.  They're really poor with service.  I think we saw them twice in our visit. Taking our order and giving us the check. Not that I need them to baby sit me but a water refill would be appreciated.  Also they can't use your card unless it's $10+ so bring cash when you can.

PWyC8BOt1zFedpcAhvuUpA.text: I dont understand what the Hype is all about. I was craving for ramen cause it's raining and Jinya is my go to spot. Everyone keeps talking about Monta so I tried it. Straight to the point...it's not good  Ramen was salty and charge extra to make it spicy. The fried rice had a burnt taste to it. Maybe I would've somewhat ate it if it was an after taste but No it was the taste. Menu sucks and service sucks. They said goodbye while we still eating and dropped the check.  I also ordered oolonghot tea. Came in a hot ass can that's waiting for a lawsuit and on top of it they didn't give me a hot tea cup. They gave me a regular plastic cup.  Atmosphere also sucks  After eating here I'm still craving ramen.  Never coming back here again. Just go to Jinya Ramen to avoid disappointment.

DX3a2VO86WPM8vkTB3YxMA.text: Worst ramen I've ever had. The broth is flavorless and not hot, bamboo is canned one. Why do they get 4 star review???

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_TIvd5OKw-YxVq1mst3vWw.text: Everything about this place is amazing!!! Gyoza are delicious! Black garlic ramen is amazing!!! Pork belly bowl is a must!!!! Fried rice is also a must!!!  The service is amazing!! Very polite and fast, they do not mess around!!

JPgWSfbZytmbimYD6hmkbw.text: I'll keep it short: order the kuro ramen. Thick broth with black garlic oil. Definitely a level up from the other ramen options here.

A1QcW-i8dsrtmcr6Ytf09A.text: This place has great, tasty, affordable Japanese comfort food!  After spending a ton of money for a weekend in Las Vegas this place fits the bill perfectly. The wait was a bit long since it's such a small place but it was well worth it. Both the ramen and the pork belly bowl were good sized portions for the price. Although, they were both average in the taste department.   Overall, I would recommend this place if you're looking for a cheap alternative to life on the strip.

1GdXYWGFnEPGwQ_VKZXPFQ.text: Monta Ramen, a top ramen restaurant in Vegas, provides good food, but it is not worth the long wait. Although the nitamago (soft boiled egg) had a great texture, it was bland and lacked the distant soy sauce flavor. My friend's spicy tonkotsu ramen had pork with great proportion of fat and meat; yet, the soup was not spicy by all means. I recommend going to Monta Ramen at 11:30 a.m., its opening time, in order to avoid the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen Master

3BBxya0a7cKXZcAr_DdBMw.text: This review is LONG overdue as I've been coming here since 2012 when a good friend took me with her. My favorite is the shoyu/tonkotsu ramen with extra pork and I also order the fried rice to go with it. Potstickers aren't bad either and they've got plenty of condiments to keep your food tasting great. Service is good, but fair warning; this place is ridiculously small. There's almost always a line outside so it's best to get there right when they open so you can get in and get out. It's got the reputation of being the BEST ramen in all of Las Vegas and in my opinion, it lives up to its name. Give them a try Yelpers!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hN3_5vZP9Gg2d_nGX7waAQ.text: This is my new favorite place for ramen, and it's unfortunate that Monta is located so far away. Or is it? I say it's just another good reason to visit Vegas... again. I'm not a ramen expert, but I've had my fair share of ramen throughout LA and OC (though Daikokuya in LA is up there). Everyone has their own style of ramen, coming from different regions in Japan. My favorite just happens to be tonkatsu-style ramen.  After waiting about a half hour to get seated in this hole-in-the-wall, we were slurping away. The price of $6.95 per bowl is a steal, but if you want to add extras it can easily go up to $10+. I had the tonkatsu-shoyu, and I found the broth to be perfect. Deep, rich flavor, while not too heavy or salty.   My particular bowl of ramen came with thin noodles, which were okay. I kept reaching over to steal some of my wife's shoyu bowl, which had the standard, curly-style ramen noodles. Those had a nice, al dente chew, and I just loved how it clinged onto the flavors from the broth. Of course, what did I do after I was finished with my bowl? I had to order an extra side of curly ramen noodles for $1.50. Well worth every penny.  The other part worth mentioning is the slices of pork in the ramen. I'm used to the thick, fatty slices of pork belly. At Monta, the pork is so thinly sliced that it just melts and falls apart as soon as you try to pick it up with chopsticks. It's a shame that you only get 2 slices with the bowl. Next time around, I'm ordering extra.   I can just imagine my face dripping with sweat if I'm slurping down Monta ramen in 110+ Vegas heat in the summer. I was dripping with sweat in 70 degree winter weather in November! At any rate, it's definitely worth the short drive from the Strip, the sweat, and the wait to eat at Monta ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu shoyu ramen

wNAag4Hkl8V_QkEiUZSXlQ.text: Best ramen in town, I was taken there by a Japanese friend and he knows which one is the real deal. Highly recommended and super cheap

wBKcCUF5JFipGcJiBwd9fQ.text: Their COLD RAMEN IS SUPER delicious!!!! I had it w/ yuzu sauce and it was bomb. Noodles were chewy and the toppings were proportional. The hubs and friends got spicy tonkotsu & regular tonkotsu and they said is VERY EXCELLENT. We also had gyoza which was so so good!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold ramen w Yuzu sauce

EeYJRuBfUEwIHlKRhTwtXA.text: Went here with friends and family. I'm not super into ramen, so I nabbed the regular size pork belly bowl and the gyoza. Both were fantastic, just basically perfect. The gyoza had that crispy-tender fried crust on the bottom that I never quite manage at home, and the pork belly bowl had some serious depth-- tender, tasty pork, fresh green onions & carrots on top, and the rice on the bottom was just fantastic, flavored nicely by the sauce/juices of the pork.  Like everyone else says, the wait can be seriously bad-- it's a small space, and though they do their best to move everyone through asap, the food takes time to come out (as it should!). It doesn't help that if you're there with a group, you're probably going to end up ordering extras to try once you've had anything on the menu.

W4adrxC0Ux0RSgVkQpO20A.text: This is by far one of my favorite ramen spots to go! Don't forget to get there early and line up, because it does get busy. Wish they had another location up north, that would be good!!!

cjEJZpPw4XhHn29QLCPvyw.text: I have to echo the reviews here about the spicy tonkatsu ramen. Absolutely phenomenal. Don't forget the gyoza!

8x1jCmokcaDkKIZEqEKB0w.text: This place is great!! First time here and we are most definitely coming back  #oishi kimchee fried rice, miso ramin and tonktsu shoyu ramin was all great!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ENU0EhqPAufd6x9E43M8Dw.text: This is my go to place for Ramen, proof of a legit business is always a line outside (it doesn't help that both locations are not too big).   Pork belly bowl is yummy as well as their fried rice. They have a smaller side menu than other ramen places.  Their ramen is delicious, the broth is tasty on its own, the meat is given in good proportion. The price is not too bad considering I spend less than 16 dollars for both my girlfriend and I.  The portions given for their pork belly bowl are big enough for two people (that is for the regular bowl)  Highly recommended ramen place here in Vegas.

KUQf82ZIVrLdDeizKaB_4g.text: YES PLEASE, MORE PLEASE.  Loved this cute little place. And it's CHEAP!  under $8 for a huge bowl of wholesome goodness.  It is a really small place, so keep that in mind, people were definitely waiting outside to get in.  But the food comes out fast, in fact, our dinner came out before our appetizer, which wasn't optimal but was OK.  Service was meh in my opinion which is why it was 4 stars instead of 5.  It was FREEZING in here, they have the fans on blast, way too cold for both of us.  But once they serve you the steaming goodness in a bowl it does warm up a bit, but not that much. Tip-move the fans to the kitchen to help the workers out but it was too cold for us.  I ordered my Pork Ramen w/out mushrooms and they placed the wrong bowls in front of us, my dinner companion was about to take a bite and the waitress like snagged it out from under him to swap ours around.  I couldn't even finish the whole thing. It has to be at least 3 cups of liquid, plus noodles and some very small bits of pork.  Get yours with the hard boiled egg. It's worth the other $1.50 or whatever it is they charge you, it was delicious.  Great for a cold day too!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Condiment heaven!!!!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. No mushrooms!!! Get the egg !

mjVfW9f570bVwJjMcVRgeQ.text: Very likely one of my favorite late night ramen places. Small spot located in a small strip mall type place off Spring Mt with other gems. During peak hours can be a bit of a wait, but ramen is always delish and made right in front of you in and open kitchen type setting. Great spot!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BwYTYSEQJ3shiMVNo8ZNYQ.text: 2 stars - the service was good and the gyoza was decent. If you want a scale of spicy ramen then go elsewhere.   We come from LA so we know good ramen but by no means are we snobs. We understand we have to venture out and try new things. I will say that the fact that this place has so many 4 star and above reviews is what drew me to give it a shot. I saw this highly recommended by anther elite and figured it would be credible.   We sat at the bar and immediately took our order as we were starving. High notes: the portions are excellent. That being said I would prefer a less amount of better ramen than too much mediocre ramen. We ordered fried rice on the side and gyoza in addition to a bowl of spicy tonkatsu and shoyu. The fried rice was strange and had WAY too much egg in it. It looked more like a scramble. The spicy level of the tonkatsu bowl ( they only have one level) was laughable. We can only add more of the Chile oil but that won't do anything. I will vouch   for the toppings which were premium. I like a lot of toppings but not so much that it overwhelms the noodles and base.  My shoyu broth was bland and thin. The noodles were too thick although it is advertised as medium. The base broth was not salty but lacked so much flavor. I had so much high hopes for this little hole in the wall place.   It was an underwhelming visit and we won't be back.

9h2TfeZjmV_fn98Vvk2QQQ.text: I have always loved this place! I love love love the pork belly bowl! So good! Also the Black garlic oil ramen is my favorite ramen there! Their fried rice, gyoza and cold noodles are also amazing! The prices here are very very reasonable! If you just get two bowls of ramen, you can easily spend less than $20! This place gets really busy but somehow he wait isn't so long. People there usually are in and out. So don't be scared away by long lines, it usually goes fast and it is super worth it!

XLqjVGPNihC1K2_Vhi3R_w.text: The Shoyu Ramen is excellent.  My 9 year old son devoured it and asked for more chashu.  We ordered extra for just $2.50 and 4 large pieces came and we got it grilled and added to the leftover broth.  He was so happy.  Bear in mind that this place is tiny.  There is going to be a long wait during peak dining hours.  We were a family of 4 and had to wait 30 minutes at 5:30pm on a Thursday and eventually got seated at the bar because we didn't want the kids to wait any longer for a table.  It was worth the wait.

FX_X-j45wxsu1a-iNrhiUA.text: My friends and I shared the large pork belly bowl and it was delicious! The meat was flavorful and rice was soft and fluffy. Yum!!  I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen with extra chashu pork. The noodles were thin noodles and it was cooked to my liking. It's not too soft or too hard. The chashu pork was thinly cut, very tender and super fatty. I regretted ordering extra chashu pork. The broth was thick and extremely salty. I had to down half a cup of water after eating four bites. I couldn't eat it anymore so I left the bowl as in.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu ramen.  Beware, it&#39;s  extremely salty.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly rice. It was delicious!

p431wUMb2IeOXOt5u1zuSw.text: Hands down one of the best ramen places in Vegas for their Tonkotsu shoyu ramen! Whenever we make a trip down to Vegas this is the first place we hit up!  We love their Tonkotsu shoyu ramen, the broth and noodles are perfect in every way! The broth is creamy and the Tonkotsu and shoyu flavor are equally balanced. The noodles that come with this ramen is straight skinny noodles and compliments the broth very well. It is not too al dente and not too soft, just the right consistency. Keep in mind ramen comes with wood ear mushrooms, green onions, two slices of pork, and bamboo shoots only. Additional toppings will be extra charge.  Shoyu ramen was the other we ordered and this is with chicken broth. It was good but not as good as the Tonkotsu shoyu ramen, maybe because the broth had a lighter flavor. This came with curvy noodles that was perfectly al dente, just the way I like it. We also like to order their fried rice which is quite tasty. It has eggs, pieces of pork, and onions.  Although, food is delicious just be aware that there will be a wait as this place is tiny (maybe seats up to 25 people). Parking lot is shared amongst other restuarants so finding a parking space maybe difficult.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice

h2z0a7cdJaRaCnXHgQZVuw.text: This is by far the best ramen spot in this area. I love ramen so I eat it quite often. Whenever I come to Vegas I have to come here no matter what because their ramen is just that good! I always get the black garlic ramen. It is so good! If you come here you have to get this ramen. Every time I bring my friends, they end getting it and loving it. I've tried the other ramen places in town and this is definitely better than all the others. I love how there is a Kung-Fu Tea next to it too because while you wait in line you can order boba. Or you can have it as dessert.   The only thing I hate about this place is the parking. This place is located in a plaza with other good places so it is always busy and there is never enough parking. Regardless, I love this place so much that I will suffer through the pain of finding parking just to eat here.

-Ie9KfAqIuA8W65kPxxRFQ.text: A must!  In my experience, it's hard to find a good ramen place. Monta is a small restaurant in a busy shopping area. We were lucky to find parking. The lot was full and didn't look like anyone was leaving any time soon. As you walk in there's a sign in sheet. They are very strict about having the whole party present and hearing for your name.  I ordered the tonkatsu and the pork belly bowl. SO GOOD! The noodles were thin and homemade. The broth tasted as if it was stewing for hours. The pork belly tasted delicious, as well as the rice.  The price was very affordable and the customer service was great! They were very helpful and knowledgeable about their menu. I would definitely come back here!!

sehZeaN5LUOBfeI5LCch_A.text: Although I felt a bit clostrophobic, the place is reminiscent of Ramen places in Tokyo. It"s small but clean. The service was fast. Full disclosure: I"m not a ramen fan. BUT, I had a change of heart after finishing a full bowl of their MISO RAMEN! It was delish! Oh em gee! I love it!!! Considering how big the bowl was,  the price of $7+ is CHEAP!    My hubby ordered a bowl of ramen that had a garlic based broth (sorry I forgot the name). The flavor was too strong although my husband loved it. Overall, two thumbs up for this place. Woohoo!  P.S. parking was a bit of a challenge but the Ramen would make it worth your while.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CD7cvCoTeg3iO46u_S8_KQ.text: My first time in this place and it didn't disappoint me. After reading the reviews online I knew I have to visit this noodle house. The place was packed indicative of the quality of food that they serve. Fortunately there was no long line yet so we were seated in less than 10 mins. We ordered Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen with extra Choshu pork and Nitamago, fried rice and gyoza. They were perfect. The cost of everything including drinks was fairly good, too. We're not spending that much. This will be my new must-go place when I crave for Japanese ramen.

QiwXvBo1Wxj0FBRme7VqXA.text: Can see why there's a lot of buzz about this place because their ramen is definitely on top of my list! The space is located in a plaza behind the strip, where you will also find Kung Fu Tea and a shaved snow place (forgot what it's called).  Like many ramen places, the space is small. I came here with a party of 7 on a Friday for lunch just right when it opened and our wait was about 25 minutes. It's a great place for a casual meal and more ideal for smaller parties. Our party of 7 ended up splitting up, where 3 of us sat at the counter and 4 of us sat at a table (which we were totally okay with but just a heads up for people who prefer to have a more of a catch-up session!).  For their ramen, they offer quite a few different kinds from Tonkatsu, Shoyu, Black Garlic Oil and Spicy. I was torn between their Black Garlic Oil and Spicy ramen and decided to get their Black Garlic Oil with spicy sauce on the side. Portion was decent- it's probably considered a medium bowl you would see at most noodle places. Each ramen comes with a good amount of bamboo shoots, mushrooms and green onions. Their broth had hearty, savory pork flavor (just like how all solid ramen broth should be). At first, I was worried that the black garlic oil would be too heavy and overpowering but surprisingly I thought the garlic flavor was a lovely element to their both. Noodles were thin and firm, also similar to traditional ramen places.   I also got a hot tea, which comes in a can rather than in a pot. Price wise, I can't remember the exact amount but I do remember thinking it was only a LITTLE bit more pricey than the usual places I go to. But if anyone needs a hangover fix and needs a break from all the madness that may happen on the Strip, I do suggest trying this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Ramen with Black Garlic Oil

1HJZajzNZmS7pCQZUN6KxA.text: I have been wanting to try this place for a while after seeing it on IG and how amazing it was from other people. I had attempted to go one time before, but when we got there it was a 2 hour wait and I was not in the mood for waiting it was freezing outside and that's the only place you can wait, so we ended up at another spot. Trying to park here is horrible! We had to park across the street and hope we didn't get towed. We attempted again, this time it was raining but I was determined to see what all the hype was about. So this time the wait was about an hour. It is very small so that explains the wait. We're finally inside and seated, it's so loud in there I felt I was yelling when putting in my order and I couldn't hear the waitress when she did talk to me.  Our food was at our table in no time, I want to say maybe within 10 minutes. I ended up getting the spicy ramen which was pretty good and I was full and satisfied with the serving but they do offer extra noodles. I'm glad I can say I tried it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. spicy ramen

m2LVgZwlY3BkBHACSKINUA.text: Idk what the hype is about. A little disappointed the noodles are not fresh, the egg wasn't runny and was cold. The skimped on the meat- really thin slices and only gave you 2? Everyone knows it l's etiquette to have odd numbers (3,5)? Had to pay extra for corn and the egg. Tab was 83$ for 6 bowls of ramen and 2 pork belly bowl. The pork belly tasted like a marinated beef. I just had high standards set because we had to wait 30 minutes to be seated and the reviews on yelp look appetizing.

n7vKNMzpe9v2T2xN8BWM4g.text: This place is neat! Good customer service and food came really fast! I ordered the pork belly bowl. Highly recommend it! Husband ordered the kuro ramen, and it does not disappoint! Plus, we haven't seen any Japanese ramen spot that does the garlic oil on their ramen. Love this place  will come back next time we're in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen with Black Garlic Oil!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl- candid food photo

EEtHCgUgRoabt8T_ZPj75Q.text: Yelp Challenge 21/100  Amen for Ramen!!! Drove a nice 5 hours to try this place.. the parking is spot is limited but you can park on the side of the street. Since there are alot of good restaurants here.. we got ayce kbbq..dessert places..japanese grill bbq and this. Its like heaven .  The store is semi small so bigger parties wait longer.. I like the nice wooden ramen bar for fast dine in and out.   The bowl of ramen was nice-- i ordered spicy ramen but it didnt have the kick of spicy as I expected.. yet it was flavorful.. a little salty though but maybe because we came in at around midnight. THE NOODLES...were fresh and delicious however! I like it.

SuLb7k7t1xTHnFjbVdfDcg.text: Found this on YELP while looking for something else, decided it was worth a try.  I got take put to take bavk to my hotel.  Got there at 7pm on a Sunday it was full when I arrived and had 20 people waiting when I left.   This was my first time having real Ramen and it was fantastic.  I got three different Ramen, the Pork Belly Bowl and Fried Rice.  There were four of us eating and we were stuffed.  It costs less than $40 for everything.   The service was phenomenal, they were training a ton of new people but even though I was just getting takeout they were kind to me and the person they were training.  He was training her to be efficient and was thoughtful and through in his process. I will visit again my next time in Vegas.

t7V1wnrPASukQITI0GrgHQ.text: Delicious, fast, and hot soupy ramen at an affordable price. The restaurant is a bit small, and we luckily came at a good hour as we were seated right away. I ordered the spicy tonkatsu and we started with an order of gyoza.   The gyoza was a great appetizer, it was meaty, hot and fresh and tasted just like how gyoza should taste. The ramen was not as spicy as I would have liked, but that was easily fixed with the chili powder that's placed at each table. I will say.. I think next time I will probably do without the shredded green onions.. as it was a little too overpowering. Service is friendly and fast. Will definitely be back the next time we're in town.

Jb8qaPZA87IEwMJ5cRaO8w.text: This used to be my favorite go-to spot. Service is still great considering the constant rush they seem to be working under.   However, the overall quality of the ramen has changed. The soups lack much depth in the flavors and was just simply salty. This was consistent with the Shoyu black garlic and Tonkatsu/Spicy Tonkatsu ramen that we frequently order.   Pork belly rice bowls were still delicious and a good, hearty choice if you're not feeling something soupy.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

damZcvH4rG1xq5Lz_QMqVg.text: Best broth in town!!! I love this place. I lived in Japan for three years and this spot reminds me of the ramen I had out there. Seriously the best. Busy on weekends but well worth the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monta&#39;s Tonkatsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monta&#39;s Tonkatsu Ramen

-me6I6FwXA0XPsul7br3wg.text: My favorite food is Ramen... So when my friend Vicky told me theres some awesome ramen for $7 not in japan I was skeptical. Back home in Honolulu there is an explosion of really good ramen but at a price. I always go for the basic to test the broth. So I went with the shoyu ramen... Basic and because it's just broth and noodles it has to shine with prep and care. Dam... This was excellent! They had the correct noodles cooked perfectly, nice flavorful soy broth, clear, not to salty, hot! I barely said keadama when I fresh bowl of noodles arrived after finishing the initial batch. Dam good. I'd go back and order that 100 times if I didn't want to try the rest of the menu. I did try the gyoza of course... Meh, good but nothing special. Tried the kimchee fried rice... Needs more kimchee, and I don't exactly expect really good fried rice at a ramen joint... Although back in Honolulu the best fried rice come from ramen places. The ramen is killer... Like Goma Ichi back in Honolulu my first love in ramen. Feeding 3 peeps got out of there under $35...dam good!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2Ea_6WxCrYUWX_4yXmSYPw.text: I love their ramen , it is so good!  Their broth is flavorful, and ramen is QQ.  Their fried rice is perfectly cooked and extremely flavorful. I will come back !

kypWDzjEtlft84GpCbN5lA.text: Ramen snob checking in!  I was excited to try a new ramen place while in Vegas, especially since there aren't many options where I live. I had heard the hype about Monta and had very high expectations.  I went for lunch on a Sunday and arrived right before the place opened.  There was a line, but when the doors opened, there were just enough tables for everyone who was waiting.  Service was friendly and quick.  Broth: The tonkotsu broth was relatively creamy and flavorful.  Not the best I've ever had, but it was definitely the best part of my bowl. Noodles: I wasn't impressed. I expected hand-made or at least fresh noodles; mine were either over cooked or not the freshest. Pork: Quite good. Fatty, how it's best served. Egg: Thumbs down for this barely seasoned egg.  I debated between giving 3 or 4 stars on this review. I decided on 3 due to hype and lines; if I had randomly come across this place and wandered in, I think I would've enjoyed it more due to lower expectations.  Oh well.. on to the next bowl elsewhere!

bzbedAByRtfWKS19M8cYeQ.text: I love coming to this ramen house. The noodles are always excellent. The base has a lot of flavor. I will be back again. I love it when they're topped with pork and an egg.

KVjfnGYpbvPp51avft03nw.text: If you're looking for a great bowl of ramen you've got to checkout this place. I started with a small order of pork belly. Haven't had pork belly like that before, loved it. It was served in a small bowl with rice. I ordered miso ramen with pork chashu and a boiled egg. The ramen was perfect.   I felt like I needed to rush, since there wasn't much seating. If you're looking for a place to go with a big group of friends you may have trouble getting seated. There is maybe enough room for 40 people. So grab your few closest friends and go get a table.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with pork chashu and an egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small pork belly

ATjNCFjtUISVnNFrCvwurw.text: This place is not all that. Not too many selections just plain and simple. I wish they have chicken at least because everything is pork. The place is very small and the wait is long. This will be my first and last.

k1fe9NzSsKYpe9BfYLDG-Q.text: These guys are great!  A little whole in the wall ramen place that has outstanding value and portion size.  Parking here can be really tough especially during the busy hours, but that's obviously no fault of the business.  Some of the most flavorful tonkotsu ramen with tender pork and really delicious eggs to go with it.  The noodles were delicious as well and loved adding a little spicy paste for a kick.  We'll be back!

452ivztaW0m7LFO2aBehAQ.text: Always busy! There is a reason for that! Good consistent food. All of the ramen are yummy. I like the pork belly rice because the flavors of the meat melt into the rice and into my mouth! The noodles are firm, yet able to hold the flavors of the soup. I recommend ordering extra chashu pork as the slices are thin and extra protein is good!

e3E1F3HtEi-roJYQcVoY0w.text: The wait was about 45 minutes long because this restaurant was not very large. Customers went in and out though, and they served our food very quickly. It was very well made, the noodles and soup had a distinct taste that made it really delicious. I ordered the misu ramen noodles. I also got a bowl of pork belly with rice and it was also really tender and delicious as well. The prices for the ramen and appetizers/ other dishes was worth it and the wait was pretty worth it as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0i_XAFr8SUjHLQvBPVBhTA.text: Monta Ramen.. My friend comes to Monta Ramen often.. but he took me here ..and I had high expectations of this place and they usually have a wait-list.. and I knew this place is one of the well-known ramen joint in the Chinatown area in Las Vegas..  But the food didn't seem it was cooked all the way and it was a little bit salty for me.. so I didn't finish it.. but the service was good.

SKOjbiGCn_wqe6-Cb2OhvQ.text: 'Anything you want to check out while we're at Vegas?' 'Earl of Sandwich and Monta Ramen.'  It was my first time here and I could see why he suggested coming here. The restaurant itself is very cute and homey. There was a good amount of people when we arrived. Luckily for us, they had all ordered and were receiving their order when we placed our food.  The menu is small - a couple different styles of ramen, a couple of add ins, a handful of appetizers, including fried rice. From my experience, simple is usually good. It means that they make whatever they make very well.  My extra chasiu made the broth a little fatter than I would like; however, the broth was good - not too rich or heavy, and all the toppings in the ramen was fresh. The gyoza was made to order and same with the fried rice (which somehow ended up being my favorite part).  It was so good that we came back, once more, during our 3 days Vegas getaway before returning back to the Bay.  Oh... make sure your party isn't too big. The restaurant is very cute and homey, but it gets harder to accommodate large parties. (And if you have a large party and they accommodate you, please make sure you're in and out, as a respect to the restaurant and other guests they will serve).

iApUbR-8o3_FwX5ogFjAWA.text: In my opinion, this is the best ramen place in Las Vegas. I highly recommend their bbq pork rice bowls and tonkotsu ramen bowl!! Also their prices are low!

-ZHR57cik4vmpOG_3unPiA.text: Great authentic ramen noodle spot not far from the strip. Super small establishment but big flavor. Highly recommend if you're looking for something different then what the strip has to offer

bc-KqHoPmB1zWu45LfaQFg.text: Nice little hole in the wall. Quick service, food came fast. Simple menu. Must have gyoza.

jt_L_c4EHs6btsm7RMLT8g.text: This place got high reviews and I really really want to like the place and hoping I have another favorite Japanese noodles place but  just couldn't and doesn't understand why it got high rating and always crowded. For a starter parking is really stressful since the area it is located at alway jam packed and hard to find parking space. Place is small with approx 6-8 tables and there are seatings at the counter which we ended up at. There are no other appetizer except for gyoza. We order kurt ramen black garlic oil with thick noodles, extra eggs, Miso rame & Takana fried rice. The fried rice didn't hit the marked either since it tasted a little vinegary & salty . Both noodles bowls were also very salty, I can't even tasted my garlic flavor because the salty ness over powered everything else. This place can be good since noodles texture, black mushrooms, bamboo shoots are the same as anywhere else. Glad I try it out but would never come back or recommend to friends.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Takana fried rice.... look good but tasted just ok
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso &amp; black garlic oil ramen

LYMo6YzHSaZA5LKUF8PQtw.text: I had the pork belly bowl, fried rice, and toko ramen they all tasted amazing. Definitely some of the best ramen I've had on the mainland. The service was fast and attentive. They got us in quick for a Saturday night. I definitely will be coming back. Glad I got to check this place out.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CuQCg410uQN2tuEhrIi40Q.text: Pork belly is to DIE for. I just wish that their large rice bowls came with more rice. The small and large rice bowls are literally the same size.

PPzzVYfOxhtnqMoy1gr3ZA.text: I loved the texture of the noodles. Not soggy but not hard either. The soup base was delicious and it was super affordable. Wait time can be a bit long depending on the time and day you visit. I came on a Saturday night around 9pm and waited about 30 min. Staff is also very attentive

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

IKQoIBdUQoBJvbL8BVAIrw.text: Wow. Best ramen in Vegas? Yes!  Kind of a hole in the wall so don't expect cloth napkins. But the chopsticks are plentiful and everything is clean. In fact, part of the charm is the open kitchen, separated by a half-wall from the counter and tables. Really cool thing, if you run out of noodles and still have broth you can get more fresh noodles. I'm a pretty big eater and I didn't need any extra, but I can see the appeal for someone who doesn't want to drink a bunch of broth to end their meal.

T30VhHSGwMNvlEL2oiVMRg.text: What a great find. Ramen here was awesome. Nice, rich broth and chewy noodles. Price is reasonable and service was great. On my list when I'm in town.

U__6Uiiz_fj1sT2Qt_UDYQ.text: Ah, I finally stopped by this popular ramen shop to see how it competed with the best of SoCal. Although I don't think it beats out some of my California favorites, Monta Ramen is a solid ramen shop...just be mindful of the wait.  +Let's talk about pricing first. I got the tonkatsu ramen for a pretty reasonable price ($8.50) that includes a mixture of kikurage, bamboo, green onions and two pieces of chasu. It's a bit light on the items it comes with, which is a little bit unfortunate. I added egg and extra chasu for about $3.50 more. You can get drinks here for fairly cheap. Beer is only about $3 but note that they only have Asahi/Bud. They also have a number of side dishes, some coming in different sizes like gyoza to a chasu bowl. They also have a number of different ramen types which look interesting. +Flavor-wise, I think the tonkatsu ramen was really solid. The broth had a simple but filling flavor. The chasu nearly seemed to melt in your mouth with the fat easily tearing off as you chew. Not the 'softest' chasu I ever had but comes pretty darn close. I did think adding extra chasu (which was about another 4-5 pieces) seemed a little overkill though for me personally. The noodles were pretty good although didn't stand out as anything different that you might expect. They have a variety of regular condiments for you to use from ginger to sauces.  +Staff was friendly and attentive. Loved seeing the kitchen from the bar area as in most ramen places.    +/- Seating (which I'll mention again below) is tight. There's a small bar area and a few tables. Don't expect to bring a huge group here. +/- Parking is in the same plaza as a few other popular restaurants like Raku. It didn't seem overly busy in the daytime but it's definitely a tighter space for parking to be mindful of.  +/- Note they have a $10 credit card minimum.   -Man, this place is small. I came about 11:45AM (15 minutes after opening) and it already was a 25 minute wait. Those who came right after had to wait longer for sure. Be mindful of this when you stop by and especially with the hot summer months, you might be waiting out in the hot weather.  -Again, as noted above, don't expect too many toppings on your ramen as in some other places.   All-in-all, a pretty solid spot with a good wait. Come early, eat happy!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen

rQ3Fzm6UUekvpU4Wj0WbBw.text: Waited for like an hour but totally worth it! Gyoza was good but I was surprised it ddn't come with its own special sauce. Ramen is to die for ;)

GoM9reeMzXCbGqqBueOIsQ.text: I'm from Los Angeles, so let me just start off with admitting that I've been spoiled with Lil Tokyo's extremely legit Japanese ramen....  So of course, I was a little suspicious that a ramen place in VEGAS would be up to par.... well, was I proven wrong!!!  My bowl of ramen was AMAZING! The broth was super flavorful and the noodles were chewy, just the way I like it!! :) IN addition, i got to try  the pork belly rice bowl (forget the name) but it was just PHENOMENAL. Even though I was super full, I couldn't stop stuffing myself with extra bites of it!   Although this place is small and the lines inevitable, I definitely think it was worth the wait! :)

S0Xs7RH7noSRaSBI7qNkSw.text: It amazes me how adding one vegetable (s) or without can add or miss the flavor of the delicious Monta Noodles offered.  I finally tried Miso and I thought it was amazing and actually has a better taste than Tonkatsu. Only I prefer the straight noodles served with Tonkatsu instead of curly Ramen noodles with Miso.  With my Miso, I had green onions, corn and takana mustard leaf! The taste was flavorful and decadent with a touch of spice!   The following week, I ordered my Miso with my favorite noodle along with my extra vegetable components just like my last visit but forgot to add the mustard green. I swore up and down to the chef that they gave me Tonkatsu because Miso was spicy last time.  Well, after a discussion with the chef we realized that the takana mustard leaf presented the spicy flavor to the broth, which was forgotten!   I am astonished how one element can change the flavors!   Cheers to the chef for helping me figure that out and making a fresh batch of Miso with my extra kicks.  Monta Monta....You know you wanna Monta Monta!

D72jwq3cpDw9TN2kI62peQ.text: Whenever I wanted to eat ramen in Las Vegas the best option was to stay home and cook a bag of Maruchan. Why is that you ask? Because at least then I'm already prepared to be disappointed. The ramen scene in Vegas is not that great, there are few choices of where to go and even fewer options of what type to order.  Hearing from my friends that we were planning to visit a new ramen place I got quite excited. Were we finally going to find a place worth eating ramen at after all these years? The simple answer, yes.  As soon as I walked into Monta I knew that this was going to be a place we would eat again. The decor was simplistic in nature and at the same time very enchanting. There were few seats, maybe 26 at most, but you didn't feel cramped at all. We chose to sit at the bar seating and got a great view of the chefs at work.  A first look at the menu told me that there were three different types of ramen to choose from. This may not seem like a lot but accompanying that was a decent sized list of sides that you can add for a small price. As my nickname is Miso, I decided to stay True to it and order the miso ramen. I requested no bamboo shoots or mushrooms, that come with the order at no extra cost along with some slices of pork. I also decided to add an egg to my order because egg in my opinion makes everything better.  The staff there was very upbeat and happily took our orders. They were very chatty with each other, but not in a bad way. This is the kind of staff that you know they enjoy their work. If anyone needed a refill on their drink the staff was very quick to notice and refill them without any trouble.  As the food arrived all of us looked at our food putting off the first bite in fear of being disappointed once again by another bowl of ramen, boy were we wrong. The first bite was amazing and with that we began to devour our dinner with gusto. The flavor of the miso was a little on the salty side but not so much to over power it. The noodles were prepared well and the texture was enjoyable. The egg that I had ordered did not disappoint, and the pork was a pleasure to eat. The size of the order was enough to make me content. Had I wanted more there was an option for more noodles for $2.00, which is not that bad at all.  Overall the experience at Monta was a great one. It may not be the best ramen out there, but it is for sure the best ramen you are going to find here in Vegas. The pricing is reasonable, the order came out to under $10.00, and the food did not disappoint. If you are looking for some good ramen, Monta is the place to go in town! We will most definitely be making return visits in the future!

w6gMgtJGCUdmSK1QizElKQ.text: The only other ramen joint that stands in Monta's way is Daikokuya in Los Angeles. So that says a lot about Monta :) I absolutely love the tonkatsu ramen they have! Monta practically became my go to place to get my ramen fix. I felt terrified when I heard they had health code violations but glad they quickly solved the issues and reopened! They always have had great service and decently priced items on their menu.

ypM-3FqhsGEZyTKIUUtBbg.text: Tiny hole in the wall that is located next to Raku.  It is Osaka style stringy ramen, swimming happily in a savory white Tonkotsu (Pork Bone) broth, not to be confuse with Tonkatsu (Pork Cutlet).  It is created from slow roasted pork bones. You can add sides such as corn, butter, pickled vegetables.  I asked for the roasted chastu pork, medium boiled egg and nori.  The roasted pork melts into the broth creating a symphony in your mouth and the egg was cook to perfection with the yolk still bright orange.  This is definitely a place where I will come back again but it is like a typical ramen shop.  One thing I have to add is that, they do not serve very large portions, so if you're hungry be sure to get an appetizer.  Sits 20 people, the open at 11:30am and full house by 12:30.  Service was friendly and menu is basic and simple.

aFBP1qiOy0ZOzsXpzlm4Jw.text: Im asian and all about ramen. Tried this place for the first time on a Saturday night at almost 1am. It was still crowded in there! If youre confused about what ramen is, its just noodles and broth and you get to pick your additional toppings or mix ins or whatever. This place has a chicken broth, a pork broth, or half and half. Its acually really good. It is a little salty, and I wish they had a few more choices for the additional add ins, but I would definitely go back. It is a tiny place, and they wont seat you unless the whole party is there.

2m8JJzAt3FcIhnKlpkR7HA.text: We got the miso ramen and tonkatsu ramen. Everything was salty. When u order the miso ramen itself it was plain, omly meat...had to add little things on side with an additional cost. We asked to try their hot sauce that they put in soup, the waitress gave us a little bit of the spicy sauce on the side, in the end they charged us for a $1 for that super small sauce plate. she could have warned us if it was that small, at least two teaspoon... I've had better in vegas.. I've tried ramen sora and it is way better. Only down the street not too far. *sorry for grammars*

Rsibl0f4pMUyXx-OpivBLg.text: The best ramen place in town.  It is worth the long wait outside! The price is reasonable, I don't feel like i am over paying for ramen.  The black sesame oil is delicious.

h54k9JbdG-DMKIPHqB9mAA.text: Whenever a craving for ramen hits , I usually went to togashi ramen. Since it closed been eating pho instead , not the same. While searching in yelp ran across monta noodle, with all the great reviews and the cool weather decided to give it a try .  God I wanted this to b good . I ordered the Tonkutso ramen .  Not impressed the soup was dull, the pork flavor did not jump out , kinda muddled flavors. Did not care for the noodles , don't know what type it was , but wife had the miso ramen and those noodles were the ones I'm used to eating little more rubbery bite(chewy). Even the miso ramen flavors were weak.  Also had the pork belly bowl , I liked the flavors of this dish jus wish the pork was sliced a little thicker.   The one good thing was the bill was only $21 . Service was good.         I miss togashi ramen and their mabo tofu ramen :( , well the search goes on for ramen....

TrJH-6qa-hlOT5fe-Oqy7g.text: Good Ramen.  You won't regret coming here.  I had a bowl of rich Ramen with pork and a side of Kimchi.  Very good tasting broth.  Service was very friendly and quick.  I'd come back any time.

DcBOvzcygSoBsJ0B4Qlw7g.text: Want some traditional Japanese ramen? This place will not disappoint.   Food: Excellent traditional Japanese ramen.   Price: Very reasonable   Service: Excellent prompt and courteous service.   I highly recommend this place if you know your Ramen and know what to expect from real ramen.   This will be my list of place to eat while I'm in Las Vegas.

MBtg0QxfEsbs_1GEidiKFQ.text: OMG i loved it! Best ramen Ive had in a long time! we came right before they opened and there were already some people waiting outside. I ordered the tonokatsu Ramen and it was so delicious. The broth was so rich and flavorful and the pork pieces were juicy. The addition of corn and their egg is a MUST! I will definitely be back again and again

91LHGMQjcYs4qD29ZLbC1w.text: Its nice to try out Ramen in different places .. they all have their style of perfecting it.

In83piLgnISi8HZJISvK4A.text: My favorite ramen spot her in Vegas. Their slow roasted pork is the best. Nice atmosphere. Great tasting food. Filling. Easy on the wallet.

M019kozcUEYAj99iOaR0jg.text: Went because of the helpful reviews!! Everything was delicious! If you like bacon, you'll love the pork belly bowl! Delicious! Yummy ramen and broth! The only reason why I give it 4 stars is due to the rash waitress. She didn't explain much when we asked her to clarify a few menu items. We felt kind of rushed. Other than that- amazing food! I'll go back for sure!

hnV-sls1oM8oMpf1TyWIGw.text: I went on the wrong day, it was hot and the wait was long, staff was nice though. and ramen was descent, totally Kaedama-ed it. went to Japanese Zen afterward for laters dinner which was awesome. and since found Fukumimi where i dine often.

Wn7DwsYAyYTGnM8PadHRTQ.text: I've always been on the lookout for good Japanese Ramen, and I always thought that Ichiza's ramen was the closest I'd ever get to authentic. Boy was I proven wrong, Monta's was the most amazing and flavorful ramen I've ever had in a long time.  I'm not from Japan, but I am from Hawaii so I do know what good ramen's supposed to taste like.  Despite it being a little pricey, I say I'd go back for another bowl.  The people were nice, and the atmosphere is very chill.  I ordered the Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen and added pork belly, nori, hard boiled egg, corn and butter....and damn! did that intensify the flavor. My best friend ordered the Miso ramen with pork, and Nori.  His didn't look as amazing as mine, but it was good regardless.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen with pork, nori, corn, butter, and egg

Ate24BC_rasqjmvG6uv1Gw.text: Its been years since I've tried a good Ramen Spot.. Thanks to the fellow Yelpers I got another go to spot for some great hot soup (other than Pho) for those cold/chilly nights..  I went here a couple days ago and decided to go for the suggested:  Tonkatsu - Broth was Tasty and Creamy, resembled a Miso type soup. Noodles were great. The Pork was awesome, it was extremely tender!  Shoyu - Broth was much darker than the Tonkatsu and had a slight soy sauce type flavor but a bit salty for my taste. Noodles great as well. The Pork definitely the highlight!  Pork Belly Bowl (Regular Size) - First of, I'm so glad I ordered the full size than the small. I love Yoshinoya Beef Bowls and this was a Glorified version of it! This is a 100% Must Try  Gyoza - Great Starter, just dip it in a bit of soy sauce and enjoy..

SIHNOFyyOGEIfAFbHRVizg.text: I love this place!  Whenever I want ramen this is the only place I come.  Granted its very small and there is usually a wait for a table but the food is worth it. If you're on the other side of town they're is another location it's much bigger and still had the heat same food

Vj5jwh61blpsamo2Vnno4w.text: On par with any top ramen shop, would go back.  I got spicy tonkatsu and goyza.

GF0_-cmZ6W252jqjTlExXg.text: This is my second time coming to Monta. I'm a big ramen fan. I've tried several other Ramen places in the area and like this one the most. The noodles are good, but it's the broth that made it. It is not exactly the most healthy as you're pretty much drinking some of that pork fat, but it totally gives the ramen that extra kick. I've been lucky to have come here each time to have to wait only 2-5 minutes, and only to have been seated to be thankful I escape the crowd of line suddenly waiting. The place is very small, not good for a big group, and seating is very limited. Try to eat and go so other hungry ramen eaters can enjoy!

3PCzWPi5Kwxs049lzskffQ.text: Went to try this place based on the Yelp reviews.  What a great find.  The location is tiny, but the food is wonderful.  Noodles were cook perfectly, and the broth was hot and flavorful.    I wish we had a place like this in Dallas.

0Lf1-M_GlzXjGHXKfB27rA.text: The 1b of ramen noodle shops in Vegas (see Fukumimi for 1a)!  My kindergarten aged daughter's new favorite eatery. :)  I've been coming here with my family on and off now since opening, and even though the broths and noodles are still very tasty, the quality of the soups and other items have been hit/miss over the last year or so.  Used to be that we'd always order the takana rice and gyoza, but both of those taste like microwaved foods now (even though freshly made - if you watch the kitchen).  The broths are still very tasty, but sometimes overly salty, sometimes not enough.  Hit/miss, like I said.  Stay away from the shoyu and miso version if you don't need extra sodium.  Normally I just get the tonkotsu with corn, nitamago, and takana on the side (self-add for saltiness).  If I'm there with my daughter, then I get an extra order of noodles to share - broth is usually enough for two decent sized bowls.    Seating at the counter is still the most fun - especially with young(er) kids.  But being that the restaurant is tiny (only has five 4-tops I believe and 9 or 10 counter seats), groups larger than 2 usually wait a while.    Still a great ramen place to sit down and slurp in some noodles on cool Vegas nights though!  Just stick to the basics!

RJYEnoC4lZvIqqBOjyHtdQ.text: This is my favorite ramen place ever.  I'm from Vancouver and we have a lot of great ramen places at home but Monta is my favorite and what really turned me on to ramen.  The char-siu is so tender and the noodles are prefectly cooked.  I always get gyoza to share as well.  The restaurant is very small so expect to line up but well worth the wait.  Food comes quick so the turnover moves quickly.

yWwk9a-lp6tqK_UC3i6z3Q.text: It's a very tiny place, but the food is good. The first time I went here was over the summer, which was a big mistake. There isn't really air conditioning in there (or there was, but i didn't realize it). The waitresses are wonderful though :) and if you sit at the bar stools, you can watch them prepare your ramen.

7z98uVYb936Ku4s3BSNTwg.text: For Vegas, it's fine. Had the Kuro Ramen with thick noodles, eggs, and corn. The broth wasn't as flavorful as expected and the black garlic oil didn't add too much. Thick noodles were their best characteristic. It's tough to come from LA and find similar ramen but as I said. For Vegas it's fine. On the other hand, they had this pickled fried rice that was quite tasty.

oD9Shaq-kGcxBFGjasRwaQ.text: I'm going to lobby for a bullet train or an underground mine shaft (with pulley cart included) to take me pronto to Monta Noodle House from the strip.  This place is popular with the locals and frequent Vegas visitors.  The hype is no bull and regrettably if you arrive after 5 pm, there are clusters of hungry ass people waiting for an open seat outside & inside.  And dammit, I will wait.  You cannot go wrong ordering the shoyu ramen, unless you space and not ask for extra char siu aka "juicy pork butt".  To really have a ramen equivalent of the "Calgon-take-me-away" dreaminess, get extra char siu, egg, nori, menma (marinated bamboo shoots).  Their broth has been made the traditional way.  Really good broth doesn't require lots of salt or shoyu, just enough to enhance its flavor.  I rarely finish the broth, since most places make it way too salty but I cleared my bowl here.  One tip I will mention is the ramen will come with basic garnish of  green onions.  I made the mistake of ordering it as an extra, and I got a mound of jullienne scallions which was a bit onion overkill.  Their gyoza is excellent, and compliments a bowl of ramen so don't forget that too.  On top of all that yumminess, super cute&sweet servers that are fast on their feet to clear a table so I can devour more ramen when need be.

Gi40XAc7p_MMJM7WmtWd9A.text: Tonkatsu shoyu the absolute perfection!!!!   Mmmmmmmmmm. Cannot get enough especially when weather gets chilly.........

MEGg6IjKvgiuwPiZRhnY5w.text: Really glad I found this place I'm not a local I travel a lot and I've eaten ramen from many locations this ramen was pretty good and the favors were also nice. I really enjoyed the ambiance and the great customer service. As soon as I arrived I was seated and my food was out and ready less than 5 minutes later and it taste good. I ordered a hot tea and it came in a can! Never seen that before. Really excited and will come again.

VuMOtLusbGZBKmGwyEQapg.text: They serve very good ramen noodle. The noodle is fresh, broth is salty but really flavorful. You should come early right when they are open. there is always a line since this restaurant gets really good reviews on yelp and the restaurant is tiny. Pork belly with rice is very delicious too. I love this place but wont come back again because of long wait.

rg_TbYzcikJWxUjggEUgrQ.text: The first time I reviewed Monta almost 3 years ago (wow!), it was really my first experience with ramen.  Since then, ramen places have popped up all over the valley, giving Monta competition.  And, IMHO, the competition wins.  I won't name my favorite place in this review because we're not supposed to per TOS, but my most recent visit to Monta reinforced my higher regard for my favorite place down the street.  Not that Monta is terrible, mind you.  It has plenty of avid fans, my good friend being one; she doesn't like my favorite place at all.  We came here for lunch last week because she loves her some Monta; she comes here so often that the staff knows her order.  We arrived ten minutes before they opened on a Friday morning and there were already 25 people waiting in line!  Monta staff hand out a waiting list for everyone to sign in on, so that's how I know the number.  When we got in the doors, my friend and I plus one other couple were the last to be seated, so capacity in the joint is about 29 people, if my math is correct; this includes sitting at the counter.  We ended up at the counter and that was actually a fun place to be because we got to watch the cooks at work.  We both had the shoyu ramen and I added eggs and corn to mine.  It took about 30 minutes to get our food; I should have ordered an appetizer.  I usually get edamame, but they don't offer it on the menu--weird.  This is a very small space and once it fills up, the line is steady waiting for people to hurry up and eat.  It's been a while since I've been back here and the ramen is good, but given the choice, I choose the other place.

ipl-pe4hGM4sjw42PIQcSw.text: I've studied and had my share of great and authentic Japanese ramen--it's as much an art as a science.  Not bad. Girls are really nice here--aiming to please.  The space is clean.  It was great to see that they have the popular dual broth (tonkotsu-shoyu) that is quite trendy in Japan.  It was excellent. Unfortunately the noodles are not made here--what a disappointment.  The egg was made too far in advance and thus cold and too hard.  But I didn't expect that much out here in Vegas, so it was a nice meal despite the noodles.

dqQjN5nZZNnumZLPiInu8w.text: The ramen here is pretty good. I personally got the Miso ramen and the broth was alright. You have to pay for extra toppings such as corn, egg, and butter, which I did not like. Overall, Ramen Sora is better in my opinion, but Monta is not a bad place to go for your ramen fix.

RhF8QM8rRe-f7nuwTf_f6g.text: My favorite place to go for a quick Ramen fix. Might be a long wait because eveyone likes this place but it's worth the wait. Ramen is good. Atmosphere is good. And we'll priced.

wKjplxlkMTr6btP-5_zHAw.text: My husband liked this place, & it wasn't for me.  The restaurant was really tiny,  The service was fast & the food came out quickly, but the pork was really weird that came in the ramen. The noodles were good, & so was the fried rice. But the pork made me gag, and I normally like pork.  Not what I was expecting. Neither of us would go back.

ethECIv6kdHV0y0eel9VZQ.text: What do you need to know?  best noodles in town.  Friendly staff, and always consistently satisfying. When I think of noodles, I think of Monta.

6W7bgEsMSfhA6iaCvLl__g.text: The wait time for a table was long and the flavor fell short. The broth was too salty, and tasted like thick chicken noodle soup. The noodles they use are thin noodles and half way through eating my ramen, the noodles became mushy. I also had fried rice, very disappointed ... Bland and flavorless. The one good item I had was the Sapporo (although they forgot about it and I had to remind them TWICE). I would not return for a second bowl of ramen here.

-Fn2jQ0aJy5XCFZuMyjzvQ.text: Cheap and good!  Spicy tonkatsu ramen was so delicious, I added extra noodles although I was completely stuffed. My super picky girlfriend ate two servings of the fried rice. We will definitely be back.

FJ7rD8Z1gLmOrAaWwiBbGg.text: Went here a few days ago during a weekday - it has the BEST chasu pork I've ever tasted! It literally melts in your mouth. They're thin slices, so I recommend ordering extra for your ramen.  The wait is a bit long so prepare for that. Our group of 5 got there at 2pm and we still had to wait for almost an hour to get seated. It's definitely a small, cozy place with great food, hence the wait.

uP_eK0G9j1uZLSKXaZJScw.text: They have limited selection on the menu compare to the Monta in the Henderson Area. It is also a lot smaller, staffs aren't as friendly and caring... We have gone to this place 4x and out of those 2... The first, they forgot my daughter's order. Her order finally arrived when we were nearly done with our ramen.. second time our water was never refilled ... Instead of apologizing for the lack of service, the staff told us that it was busy and she never heard us say about my daughter's order. -.- I don't know if I'll come back to this place.

q5Mtg-Mce-wcCAree7-WIw.text: 2nd time around in Vegas came for a late lunch and no wait!  So great because after the meal i would have been upset if i waited longer than 10 minutes to eat this meal  dont get me wrong it was good, but not mind blowing or something that I'd come back for. I had the tonkatsu ramen with side of gyoza   broth was good, but noodles were too thin for my liking. Plus the broth had this wierd porky taste like unclean or unorganic pork. (trust me I cook a lot and know the difference) Think pigs in a dirty straw pin taste...yee  Anyhooo it was fine to try it and $30 out the door for 2 pl wasnt bad, but the best ramen i've had is still in LA Tsujita   Gyoza was good though- home made  ok to try once but wouldnt spend my $ there again. Sorry.

Mlb8VGTAxdcPumoZFvakEg.text: Absolutely delicious. 30$ (including tip) tried the spicey tonkotsu. The chazu rice and green onion. The pork Gyoza was great and had some special fried rice.  The flavor of the soup was so good I was ready to go back for more the next day.

iPfaKK7d0CO2EAwUhKFlsQ.text: I love coming here, especially on a rainy day.  It is very small and there is usually a wait, but eating here is such a quick process.  It won't be very long.  We usually sit at the counter in which you can watch them prepare your food.  I am that white girl that asks for a fork. :( Lol.  The menu is very small, but delicious.  I usually get the Miso Ramen and kim chee fried rice.  The pork is so good, it melts in your mouth.  My mouth is watering as I write this!  The staff is always welcoming & service is good.  Only thing is I wish they had dessert.
