d3DqFnVxDGCC2oOQ6LpGaw.text: Ramen = Happy belly. Eating here reminds me of Tokyo. Good Tonkatsu Ramen makes me want to PUNCH the people that invented Top Ramen and Cup O' Noodle IN THE FACE.  In my opinion come hungry and pay for the extra toppings.

SuWYHxRG9-jK3b_kXWH_1A.text: Ordered the pork ramen, but instead got a bowl of limp and soggy noodles drenched in pork fat. Service was pretty slow for just a single bowl of ramen. Incredibly disappointed in the flavor as it tasted foul, oily, and gross. Would not recommend to anyone...!

vBt6ektmchwiz_J79t-iIw.text: One word. Disappointed. The parking was aweful. Tip: park at the side street next to it. One star is for the staff, they were quick and assertive... Short wait time, got our food as soon as it was ready, drinks were filled immediately when it goes empty. The food was not as great as I had expected. Which was a very big disappointment. It was good but mediocre on taste. The restaurant itself was ridiculously small. I was shocked how small it was. Poor hostess was trying to get tables going so she can sit more people. Since the restaurant was so small, you can smell the bathroom was close by also. Yuck! The other star is really for nothing, I was just trying to be nice... Maybe a star for how cozy the room was. Oh wait. The other star goes to how affordable it is, it's a good cheap place to have soup.

titcFl2NfmyDsSJoDTydCQ.text: I look forward to eating here,  I always have to come here everytime I'm in Vegas without fail. This is the best authentic ramen you can get in America I'm convinced. If you haven't tried it you really should you won't regret it!!    This place is always packed (cause its great) so your probably going to have to wait especially if you have a large group, but trust me it's well worth it!!

qS3ypxJXsbgVOnZ-psy5_Q.text: I have been here five weekends in a row and last weekend I didn't, only because I was out of town.  No matter...I'll be back on my ramen kick starting up again this weekend, woohoo!  I have not been able to stray away from the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen with char shu (pork), nitamago (egg) and nori (seaweed.)  I've ordered and enjoyed it every single time.  See you again this weekend Monta!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatau-shoyu ramen with egg, extra pork belly and nori.

_WMtEjr_V-Adv97_VIn39Q.text: Been here twice in the last week.  Superb broth starts an outstanding bowl of ramen. I always order extra Chasu and eggs.  Added a side of kimchi for good measure.  Fantastic meal.  Would recommend this place to all my friends and family who come to LV to visit.  My only issue is the limited space to eat and difficulty finding parking due to the cramped area it's located in.

cwbFdUMfQee47bF5FgMSMw.text: I get a craving for Monta nearly once a week...Nah who am I kidding, it's more like a daily burn. If I lived closer to their Chinatown location, I would seriously consider a 5x a week lunch adventure, transporting me back to Japan with an enveloping nostalgia of aroma, atmosphere, personality, texture and UMAMI. Oh man, the umami. The wait (and there ALWAYS is one) is WELL worth it. Whether it's 10 minutes for lunch or a 30-60 minute wait for dinner, your olfactory glands, umami super sensors and full warm belly will thank you profusely.   I am a massive fan of the basic tonkotsu, always with a nitamago (soft boiled, soy sauce-seasoned egg), with a spicy iteration thrown in the routine every so often. I am also slightly obsessed with their kimchi fried rice, on which I pile on pink pickled ginger. They should probably start charging me for the pickled ginger, as I definitely take advantage of the free-for-paying-customers-with-the-notion-it-will-be-used-sparingly jar of the condiment/dish enhancer. $2.95 Asahi on tap?? Give me a couple!   Monta is incredibly well priced, intimate in a truly authentic Japanese way, lively, wicked efficient (in the manner they move customers in and out), clean and SO CONSISTENT. I will be back, in approximately 15 minutes! Damn Spring Mountain traffic!

gwtVqLu5U-5HQOvCgYJQlA.text: I had a very bizarre experience here. When I arrived there was no host at the stand but I was told by one of the waitresses walking by to add my name to the sign in sheet. I added my name in the next available open slot, and joined the crowd of people who were standing around outside waiting to be called. 45 minutes pass and I see that a couple who had arrived after me is called in for the their table. I go inside to ask about my position and I see on the sign in sheet that they have literally skipped over my name and seated at least 12 people who had signed in after me. I'm bewildered at this point because I'm starving. So I flag down a man who appears to be a manager lurking in the back of the restaurant. He tells me that my name was skipped over because it was not written exactly within the lines on the sheet. Huh?? So you skipped me because my handwriting went over the line in my designated space? I was so utterly confused. With not so much as an apology, he tells me the only thing he can do is add me to the bottom of the list. Thankfully, a very nice couple who had witnessed the entire thing invites my fiance and I to share their four top. We were very grateful as we would have had to wait another hour just to be seated. How strange. The food was decent however, neither one of us eats pork so we ordered the chicken broth only to find out that they still add large hunks of pork within the soup even when you specifically request no pork. Also, I ordered corn and egg and received neither. The staff was very unapologetic and I found the manager to be quite rude. I'm thinking my experience may have been a fluke and I'm willing to give this place another try so I'll give two stars. Just remember to sign your name precisely within the lines of the sheet or you may risk being skipped over.

iCwUaRnD8mRjuS1O97u8ag.text: I had the spicy tonkatsu ramen, the person I went with got the kuro ramen and we split an order of gyoza. The gyoza were great, crispy on the outside and juicy on the inside. We were both impressed with our ramen, great flavor and portion. I would definitely reccomend adding the egg as it doesn't come with the base ramen order. Overall it's a great meal at a great price.

h_dgV9FGSDGE3SW4yZgbkA.text: Raman!! Raman!! Raman!! What more can I say!! Quick fix that does it right!! Place serve tonkatsu, shoyu, miso and tonkatsu/shoyu broth!! Delicious either way! Add more topping! And wow.. I was amazing with the flavor that was instantly put in my mouth! Come to this little spot for a quick japanese raman fixture! Try their pork over rice..- fatty! Goodness over rice :D!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ordered the small pork over rice, shared half with friend just to test it out..!! Goood!!!!!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu/shoyu added corn,nori,and butter :D
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chief at work!

jvpJcd1HbGP57bXJWAXYnw.text: The best ramen in Vegas!!!. I have been to Japan before and I can tell u tat their ramen is just like the one in Japan. Very reasonable price. Have been there so many time during summer. However, the place is crowded during dinner time so be ready to wait if u wanna have a dinner there.

O7KddLs05f5U16ehmm-yXw.text: Yum yum yum, I love ramen, so of course I had to have it in Vegas!  Wait was not bad at all , 5 minutes, but we came in on a Monday night before my flight out, so that may have been why. I ordered the Kuro ramen (black garlic oil ramen) and it was possibly the best Kuro ramen I have had thus far. There is a restaurant that specializes in kuro ramen near my own home, but it does not compare to Monta's.   The food came out pretty fast, which is always awesome. The garlic was incredibly flavorful and aromatic and just amazingly delicious. Chashu was also really nice and tender. My only qualm was that the broth was a little salty for my own liking. I had to add some ginger and sesame seeds to cut the saltiness a bit, but other than that it was very, very good. If I had access to Mona Ramen close to my own home, I would eat there so much it would definitely not be too good for my blood pressure.  Can't wait to come back and try their tonkatsu and miso ramen as well!

p9aPhq-APj9L7AEvFoox0g.text: Service was excellent. Food came lightning quick!  Noodles are firm..soup was tasty..pork was melt in your mouth tender.  The shop is tiny..5 tables and 10 seats at the counter.

M876cmiZv-jYxAkQNGXbbw.text: Monta Ramen is a very tiny ramen restaurant, with apparently, the best ramen in town. Now that I have tried it a few times, I would say that it is probably True. With the wait however, it just is not worth it suddenly. Especially because I am from Southern California, there are a lot more ramen places that is just as good, if not better, than Monta Ramen. But for the Las Vegas area, this has been the best place to get my ramen fix.   The broth is super fresh and clean, not filled with like oils and things like that. The meat is super soft, which just melts in your mouth. The noodles are just how I like them, RAMEN noodles.   One bowl is enough to satisfy your hunger.   Now to mention the wait - my family and I waited 50 minutes for ramen noodles. Factoring that in, it was not worth it. The waitress even let back people who "left" from the waiting list, and came back! That's not what a waiting list does, if a party leaves, they are off the list. The waitress would squeeze the party back in. That just lengthens the time I am waiting outside, especially since she did it for two 5 person parties before mine.   They have another Monta in Vegas now. Maybe that one is worth trying out.

XCWr7UFAGokg-Z46p6I2Nw.text: Just like their other location in Henderson (their 2nd location is the one where I had my first Monta experience) this ramen is pure crack.  This is hands down the best, sticky, greasy, porky, al dente, delicious ramen I've had.  Pure crack.   I now hit up Ramen, as well as In-N-Out, everytime when visiting family in Vegas...

oaE0qkfcU9nMAjgY7pMQkg.text: Awesome little gem! Great ramen and dirt cheap! I suggest u dress lightly it's hot in there! Otherwise a must in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken broth ramen!

qKfi4DKl2ok2XjCIvrg3ig.text: Funny that I liked the gyoza and the fried rice better than the ramen here. Don't get me wrong, the ramen is good, but the gyoza was so savory with a very thin wrap fried crispy on one side. The ramen noodles I ordered was the thin ones, which is what I like. I think you can order the thicker noodle if that's your preference. The pork broth was a little on the salty side and was very thick (almost sticky).

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen

ipxDpUZjVZ7HOKe3S-4gWw.text: My fiance and I visited Vegas over the Labor Day weekend.  We had the Bellagio buffet and the next day we figure we would get something light and soupy so we checked out yelp around the area for noodle soup and Monta popped up the search with very high ratings.  Located on Spring Mountain Road, this hidden gem is well tucked away in a strip mall.  It's comfort food for my fiance and I especially after the Bellagio buffet dinner on the night before.  The place was very small and there were people waiting when I got there.  They won't sit you unless all of your party are present which is nice so no one can hog up the table.  We ordered Tonkotsu ramen with extra ramen, and flavored egg, gyoza and takana fried rice.  Everything was excellent.  The takana fried rice was very different than the regular Japanese fried rice.  It has a very nice kick to the taste too.  My fiance and really enjoyed the food and would definitely come back whenever we are in town!  The place is cash only.

zbQ1G_oatUIBY_89LDXDtQ.text: Awesome noodles, their Black garlic was ok, noodles were too thin, more Angel hair than Ramen.  Their Soyu was really tasty, but my fav was their fatty pork rice bowl, that was super delish.  Overall, great place to eat for cheap of the strip..

Kqtt2-LyULyzbfSb9itVyg.text: First time trying ramen in Las Vegas and came to this highly recommended hole in the wall spot. But to my husband and my disappointment the ramen was mediocore. He had the Tonkotsu and I had Miso. We both thought it was too salty. However we shared a Kimchi fried rice and it was delicious!  We have much better ramen spots here in California.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen added egg, corn, &amp; nori

BgEaABnaZOSNL1eDr9tBqg.text: Very popular place, we showed up 30 min after opening for lunch and ended up waiting for an hour!  The place is small so it fills up quickly.   I was surprised when I asked for tea that it comes from a heated can!  Would definitely go again when I'm in town.   Place is a little small so it can get packed very quickly.

MZEC6yvFL6cSU6B75ATZVA.text: Can you believe it? This was my first Tonkotsu ramen EVER. I cannot believe I missed out on this delicious food all these years. Since I don't have anything to compare it with, I cannot really write a review about the authenticity of this dish. All I can say is that the broth was very flavorful and delicious and I definitely have to expand my ramen experience now that I know how much I like it.   I loved how this place was smaller, with a small menu, but very clean and comfortable - exactly my kind of place! Also, the servers were very friendly and helped us with the menu.  I'm very glad I had a great first ramen experience. This makes me want to go back and see how I feel about it the second time. I'm excited, already!

OwVh1bCjjH4EVlQlSvGVVQ.text: If you've read my past reviews, you'll see very quickly that I'm broke as a joke and would prefer eating closer to my home in NLV, but Monta is the ONLY place far away from home that I will eat at and drive through traffic for (OK, it's only a 20-minute drive away but the price I'm paying for gas makes it feel like a journey).  I lived in Japan for 8 years, so as far as authenticity goes, this place takes the cake (or ke-ki). The waitresses and chefs are always welcoming and courteous, and you could tell they put a lot of love and effort in every dish that is served. There are items on the menu that I haven't seen since I lived in Japan, so Monta leaves a very special, nostalgic mark in my heart. They also remember their regulars and treat them like friends. So you'd think the price would match the golden service, but NO! It's so nice and cuddly on my wallet. My wallet wants to date the face off this place. I don't know many places that fix a huge bowl of noodles that could feed two people for just $6, and still taste awesome.

xdLeqZD3P3_sokbXfTeaXQ.text: I'm not a very big fan of soup especially when it's already super hot outside in Vegas but my friend insisted I try this place. Monta is really small I had a hard time trying to find it in the beginning.   They're really quick on service that we were out there in less than 30 mins. Their ramen was really good however, I just wish it came with more meat since I'm such a carnivore. I'll definitely make sure to come here more often, most likely when the weather has cooled down though! Lol

04hkMr--Tostx-c5OFq04Q.text: Best ramen in town!  This intimate little gem was once a hidden secret. Hard to spot off the busy street, tucked away back in a tiny shopping center. Now this booming ramen shop is busier than ever, and the ramen is still top of its game.   Offering quick and cheap eats, this menu may be small, but there is nothing small about the taste. Kimchee fried rice is a must. Monta offers 4 different broths, numerous toppings as well as sides and like gyoza, fried rices, bowls, etc. Definitely one of my favs

7XfFKt9eU6OBhdb99-p88Q.text: Monta Ramen's tonkatsu ramen broth is one of the best ramen broths we have tried. You can really taste the flavor in every sip. The chasu melts in your mouth and the price is very reasonable compared to other ramen places.

CvhYgCvJCrDmOjHHR2OIpw.text: Monta is located in back of Seoul Plaza.  It is easy to drive pass this plaza looking for Monta.  Look for the plaza that says MASSAGE or OZZIES.  I got to try the Miso ramen and the tonkotsu ramen.  The default ramen does not come with an egg.  Both miso broth and tonkotsu broth was flavorful.  I liked the tonkotsu broth more.    The only other ramen place that I tried in Vegas is Anime ramen.   Monta is better than Anime.

3zHPSNUdMmzyUOX5ZNLXxA.text: I had the tonkatsu ramen and loved it. It wasn't too salty, IMO. The service was prompt and very friendly and  the bathroom was clean and nicely decorated (see photo).

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Clean bathroom, cool sink. Someone stole the artwork shown in the other bathroom photo, or it has been removed.

DmlJX99w0U6exVinmiP5eg.text: You guys are crazy. After reading these reviews i had to go try it. As i eagerly waited for my dish and the  impending orgasmic party in my mouth, i was a bit disappointed as i shoveled the black garlic noodles in my face.  Nothing happened. No heaven, no eyes rolling behind my head, no happy ending. Sorry guys. Yelp is normally pretty accurate but these reviewers are having way too much fun and i feel a little bit left out. I thought it was too starchy and salty. It was good but not 5 star great. I did like the flavored egg; it was gooey goodness.  Would i do it again? Probably not. Perhaps my expectations were too high. Perhaps the chef forgot the crack in my soup base. Service was good, ramen was good enough. Try it for yourself.  Maybe you'll get lucky and leave with a happy ending. Btw. I did like the kimchi fried rice a lot but the portion was small. Its more of an appetizer. Its pretty good, order one for yourself and don't share because you'll crave for more. I would rate this establishment 3.5 stars.

0MQu0Ltewb0eCElwtaKTiw.text: Monta Ramen is the best is Vegas. Hands down. I've searched around to see if any Vegas ramen joints are better and the answer is a resounding no.  The tonkotsu broth simply can't be beat, and the chasu pork atop the ramen is the most tender I've found. I typically add the corn and the hard-boiled egg (nitamago). If you're in the mood for more than just ramen, the kimchi fried rice and the potstickers are both excellent starters.  This place gets crowded. Like, insanely crowded. Line out the door. If you're planning to stop by for lunch, you better be waiting outside before they open at 11:30am. But even if you do have to wait for a table or a counter seat, trust me, it will be worth it.

zFX8q5aAbm58Tzj-3ZHyIA.text: Was looking for a ramen fix that hasn't been satisfied since a trip to NYC's Totto Ramen.  This place was a good fix, though incomparable to Totto.   Came here during Sunday lunch and had a 30 minute wait in the small shop that probably seats 30.  Service was fairly quick, got my food within 5 minutes of ordering.  Fried rice was really good, would definitely get again.  Got the ramen with thick noodles- thanks fellow yelpers for the recommendation.  The thick noodles are the normal size at other restaurants- nice and chewy.  Broth was good but not as creamy as other places I've been to.  Wished the pork slices were smoked like at Totto, would have added to the flavor.

b9YBAloALWcOU-t7asiwSQ.text: Good food and fast service! Ramen is cook right.place is small but Im willing to wait since we always get our food fast once we get seated.I rather come here and wait on their busy day than coming to Jinya.Monta always fills up my Ramen cravings.

8EDaI71sxzaw_pklOQhUxA.text: Visited this small restaurant based on popular review. Indeed, this restaurant is so popular that you will have to wait in the line. Another reason why you'll have to wait is that the dining room can probably fit about 30 dining guests at each time, half of the guests will need to be on the bar table. Me and my wife are lucky to get a table after about 45 minutes of wait with about 6 parties waiting in front of us for dinner (by the way, you will need to check yourself in as there are only 2 very busy waitresses). The menu was very simple - noodle, fried rice or some small variety of specialty. There are flyers if 2 today's special pasted on the wall, which we ordered - spicy tonkotsu ramen. We also ordered a mini mentaiko bowl (basically some fish eggs with sesame over small bowl of rice). I would not say it is super delicious, but it is really worth the price. The ramen was very flavorful (can be a little salty). You also have the option to add another noodle if you still feel hungry after you finish the bowl - I think most people will do since there was actually not much noodle in it. For us, the bowl of rice does the job. The rice is nothing special and almost had no flavor. I just seasoned the rice with the broth of the ramen I had. Overall, not bad, and it is definitely worth the price. But if you don't have much time in Vegas, you can safely skip this place as it is not worth that much of wait, unless you really want to save money in your trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu Page 2
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu Page 1
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mini Mentaiko Bowl

ROQLjfupCZ-MwlHf8fmTMA.text: BEST charsiu of any noodle place I've tried!! Kinda bummed I didn't order extra. Got the Tonkotsu-Shoyu and just asked for corn, but she charged me for it and I never got it.. but that's okay cause the charsiu was so good I didn't care! Have the choice of 3 different broths and either thick or thin noodle... I opted for thick and the bf got the thin with the miso broth... not a fan of miso but it was good. Mine was better.  Very small place though, not really good for large parties. And easy to miss when trying to locate... But food comes out quick! And very reasonable pricing. Love it. Should try the rest of the menu, but this small bowl of ramen is pretty filling...  If you haven't been, you must try.  Why not 5 stars? I dunno... maybe when I sample more items I will reconsider.

kFF8egx9g4z306Alb7LGvA.text: My husband and I went pretty much as soon as we found out about this place, ramen junkies that we are. The thing is, I really wish this website allowed half star ratings, because I would have rated it 3 1/2. What really brings it down in my mind are the noodles.  The atmosphere was fine and the staff are friendly. But the noodles... They are too starchy and separated, and not very fresh-tasting. Frowny face. The broth, however, was something else entirely. Our bowl of Tonketsu ramen was perfectly salty and flavorful, and the texture of the broth wasn't grainy or too fatty.  The other toppings and chashu pork were fine, but in my opinion, the chashu at Ramen Sora down the street is far superior. All in all, it certainly wasn't a bad eating experience, but I didn't enjoy my noodles very much, and man can not live on broth alone.

wLFeFqb9P0YCiItUHl34vg.text: First time going with my parents and ordered Fried rice along with Shoyu and Tonkotsu ramen and it was amazing! Nice small mom and pop shop and seemed like it's always busy so expect to wait, but it's worth it!

Eg-W0WNqSFAkRB9W0ejU0A.text: This is the best place for Ramen in all of Vegas.  It is far superior to the Sora Ramen both in taste and cleanliness/price.  Pork belly is one of the best. Sister company of Goyemon (another favorite).   Don't come here if you are in a hurry.  Waits during Sat for lunch can exceed 45mins.   They also don't take reservations and the entire place seats around 25 people max.  They should raise prices to keep the crowds away or expand into one of the neighboring suites due to high demand.  I would give 5 stars if not for the wait (which is terrible).

CnOfWIsJmkLZbQw-CAFEAw.text: This restaurant is quickly becoming my favorite place for noodles. The food is so delicious and the prices are excellent! If you're thinking about it, you should go.

DoGdz0ZBgcFQ5yySmEbFDw.text: Probably the best ramen place in Vegas and the price is right!  We Ordered one shoyu ramen, one tonkatsu ramen, and one shoyu tonkatsu ramen. Also got the pork belly bowl. All were pretty good. The kids, who are avid ramen fans couldn't decide between giving this a 3 or 4, so we agreed on a 3.5 star. My broth was a little salty - I think I'll be drinking a lot of water later!  The pork belly was very flavorful and was perfect over the bed of rice. Service was friendly and fast! It's a small place, but we lucked out cuz it wasn't that busy at about 7pm on a Tuesday. I would definitely come back when I'm craving ramen in Vegas!

gvlfkNg_cOn3zQCO5pI_8Q.text: The best ramen in Las Vegas! Simple menu selection and very friendly staff. I recommend the pork belly bowl (best dish in the house) and the spicy Tonkotsu ramen. You won't be disappointed!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-ZmvquAvPM4NdfQs_fNdRQ.text: Always a wait. Parking is bad. Crowded. Worth it.  Don't be timid and get your name on the waiting list clipboard. Wait outside because there is no room inside.  Everyone has his/her favorite ramen. I like miso. It's buttery and rich. I add seaweed (nori), extra pork, egg (nitamago) and green onion. Have a Sapporo.  Ramen is a messy food. You will need your napkin. Your nose will run. I eat close to the bowl to hide my gluttonous joy. I know that people feel uncomfortable eating it because they think people are looking at them dropping the egg and the noodles clumsily from his/her chopsticks. No one is looking. We are all eating.

atJagfQdXQ25q1uSkd1SWg.text: Went here twice while visiting Vegas. Is pretty good ramen and love the bite of the noodles. The broth is on the richer side and chaisu is tender and melts in the mouth. Doesn't have many vegetarian options. Opens at 11:30 and consistently has many customers so I would go earlier if you don't want to wait in line outside because it is a pretty small shop. However, ramen comes out really quickly.

TN1rBpK5ZHwSWwcsUcaUDg.text: Great authentic Ramen. The place is small and hot due to the open kitchen. Make sure everyone in your party is present otherwise you will not be seated. The place is a gem and worth the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Great food. The place is small so make sure everyone is present.

thmKa3xmrIoJ01ODkiaefQ.text: Authentic Japanese Ramen place. Was recommended by a sushi chef in another restaurant. I came here twice during my short visit to Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

4OwBowO0tXvyhmi3msBhdQ.text: Been here numerous times and love it every time, at least the food. Different broths all provide depth of flavor and you can always add-on other items such as mid-boiled eggs, corn, extra pork, etc. Kimchi fried rice is delicious as well: lil kick and rice is perfect. Only thing that brings this place down is the lack of space. It's really a hole in the wall and seats accordingly. Staff is helpful and the line are long, lunch lines aren't too bad but expect to wait a good while at dinner. All in all, a very good bowl of ramen.

dONPzt_Bc4Pxo4js_UImZw.text: Hella good! The team does a great job and takes care of you. Good food and good service.   -Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen  (preferred this over the straight Tonkotsu because I liked the mix of broths. A little lighter.) -Hot UCC tea in a can   I'll be back for sure when I'm in town. Thank you!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The counter
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu. I&#39;d get this again!

HY92ncOPMTjdkJdGBoSHuw.text: This is still my favorite spot for ramen. You just have to come early or later. You'll wait for a while if you come between 630p to 930p.   Items ordered: Gyoza-  Always a winner, crispy and chewy wonton wrap with tasty meat fillings. Make your own dipping sauce with condiments on table. Cold ramen with yuzu- Great noodle chew with different varieties of veggies, egg and chashu pork dressed in yuzu dressing. Very refreshing Shoyu tonkatsu- A mix of both broth and those delicious noodles. The broth makes your lips stick, yum Chashu bowl- Exactly that thinly sliced chashu on top of rice Pork belly bowl- Sweet soy sauce cooked with the pork belly until super tender.   I always recommend this place to everyone, it's a small spot that probably seats about 45 including the counter. Constantly busy and consistent with quality of their food.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza..yum
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chashu bowl

mvXSaFv2JkElpQn0zK5y4A.text: Busy all day, everyday for sure!  This is one of the very few spots i know of that can serve two people and keep the total bill under $20. Other than ramen on the menu, you can get some fried rice or fried pork to munch on. Variety is always better when theres more than one belly at the table. Seating is very limited.. we are talking about 5 tables and a bar to fit 10 people total so be prepared to wait for a table to open.  Too cheap to not come and stop by for some fast served ramen! =d

lsSt7x_1rz2Ub5B4VIulMQ.text: This place never fails me and the wife when it comes to noodles and their Takana Fried rice. Chasu is the best on Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen with Tamago wife always pairs her Takana Fried Rice with Gyosa, Chasu melts in your mouth best place to warm your tummy on cold weather.

EJ-a3Kfd3ReX88RKOkFVEg.text: Absolutely loved everything we ordered it! Bit of line up even past the meal time but the food was good.

TVP4UX-4MgjlpBdrZ8-Rgg.text: A small dining place that will never leave you disappointed. Very friendly, courteous, clean, prompt & always tasty!  Never a bad meal no matter when you come. And yes, it does actually make good leftovers, too. I've tried almost everything on the menu and have loved everything I've had!  There are not many restaurants you can go to where you can say that!  A friend brought me here two or three years ago and I've been returning regularly ever since!  I'm definitely hooked for life!!!

bnfzP3u-ofjQMbAKvGZzwg.text: Yum yum yummmmm.. place is tiny and always has a line. But it's definitely worth the wait. If you're looking for warm and cozy. This is the place for u.. Small menu, but there's something for everyone... parking isn't the greatest tho..

YaEIiXC-gTKJ8k-dXVTVcg.text: We visited here for the first time Friday and were not disappointed.  Delicious ramen and the broth is amazing!  I wish there were more seats because there is a huge wait.  Food is served hot and fast.  We will go back for sure!

ZSFqfvEa5WljusT6t0_etg.text: This was my first meal in Vegas and it was really good! Finding parking here was kinda annoying since the parking lot for this shopping center was small. We were actually surprised that we were able to be seated right away as a party of 5. When we left there was a line going outside the door, so I'd either come early or expect a wait because this place is super tiny inside (there's a few tables and then bar style seating).   Looking over the menu, I was shocked at how cheap the ramen was. But then I realized that the ramen is very basic -- broth, 2 slices of pork, green onions, ramen and bamboo shoots. If you want extras like egg, extra pork, corn, kimchi, etc. you'll have to pay extra. But even after adding toppings my food still came out to be like $10.   We started off sharing a pork belly bowl as a table. It was pretty good! As for my meal, I ordered the Miso ramen and asked for spicy paste on the side. I also opted to add the egg and corn.  After adding the spicy paste in my Miso ramen it tasted great and was full of flavor! The miso ramen also had the thick wavy noodles that I love.   Service was quick and efficient. I kind of got the vibe that they wanted us to leave quickly after paying the bill, but I can't really blame them with a line out of the door! If you're looking for an inexpensive meal that will fill you up then you should check out Monta Ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. miso ramen with added corn and egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. pork belly bowl

KPsQ0ircib-cB3wZ0dGA4w.text: For those who are familiar with Santouka, I always use it as a guide to distinguish the good from the bad.  If a place is better than Santouka, then it is worth a second visit.  If the ramen falls below the Santouka standard, then I can forget about it.  How did Monta Ramen place on this scale?  Well, Monta came out on top.  There was no wow factor for my black tonkotsu ramen, but everything was done quite nicely.  The yolk was not overcooked.  The noodle had the right amount of chew.  The broth was flavorful.  Even though the ramen was good, it was not worth the long wait.  We arrived before opening time, and waited for about 30 minutes with the long line.  This place is definitely worth returning, and hopefully the wait is shorter next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black Tonkotsu Ramen

5Ig-nTGYEgG491q7UAulnQ.text: This is a superb find by my son and we are truly grateful we found this hole in the wall kinda place but the food is superb! I just want to suggest for them to get to a new location to accommodate more people that are waiting. It's worth the wait though, don't get me wrong.

J_BnABh8v0I0kqWq_rKuQw.text: Stopped in and enjoyed this Ramen house in Las Vegas recently.   May have a bit of a wait but it is worth it.   Had a tonkatsu ramen with  a side of gyozas.   Deep, rich broth and plenty of noodles.  You can even order extra noodles when you finish your 1st order.   Gyozas loaded with plenty of filling!   Def be back next time were in Vegas!

OdL_ZROo27YZ-niO7VCCaA.text: I lived in Alhambra, CA for several years and had some of the best ramen. This place in Vegas is by far my favorite in Vegas and would be a contender for the best ramen I've had. Not too salty, incredible flavor and homemade noodles!

oLyaeYHz-qGzHmqyMg-ZbA.text: I think ninjas work here!!! The service was fast, friendly and efficient! I definitely recommend the black garlic oil. I added flavored egg and spring onion to my tonkatsu broth with wavy noodles but was disappointed by the noodle-to-broth ratio.  The broth was delicious but there was just not enough! I guess I don't mind being disappointed if the reason is not having enough. The pork in my ramen kind of tasted like uncured pork, which is definitely not my thing but I know some people love that. I did enjoy the pork belly over rice, the pork was well seasoned, but next time I would order the smaller size because the regular had a lot of rice.   Don't be fooled by the small size of this restaurant,   The service is fast and the wait is worth it! (We asked the hostess if she could flag is down while we waited in the car with our a/c on, and she was more than happy to oblige --- beat the heat!)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl!!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen: tonkatsu broth with an added kick, fragrant black garlic oil. I ordered flavored egg and shredded spring onion, too.

xxkn1WimM5blGqHpQ-dx1A.text: Love this place. I truly can't get enough. It's super tiny, which I think adds to its sheer brilliance. Cooked to order in mere minutes, the ramen is brilliant. The flavors are clear, portions massive and price is ridiculously inexpensive!! Less than $7 a bowl!  The servers are super nice and attentive and they've always got a sweet playlist going that really sets the mood. I'll be back over and over and over again.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso

MWlqRpkCfOifbc6CDQDTIQ.text: The first time I went to Monta Ramen, there was about an hour wait.  Let me just say:  ABSOLUTELY WORTH IT.  The noodles and broth are rich, creamy, savory, and delicious. I've never tasted anything so deliciously complex, and it's all contained in a bowl of something good. The service is fast and friendly. The food comes out minutes after you order it, and it's good if you're on a budget. Generous portions!  My recommendation:  Black garlic Kuro Ramen with egg, seaweed, and a side of kimchi (which is always fresh and flavorful)!  Ever since the first visit, the wait times have been constantly decreasing.   The proper method to eat at Monta Ramen is as follows:  Get in. Eat ramen. Leave. You'll love it.

Pf2pO0cccB3IdJUHNHj8wQ.text: Food was awesome every time I've been there.  The only down side is that the place is about the size of small master bedroom....so get there eary be prepared to wait.. decause it is worth it

hLRB59XJavFHUniLGmLuLw.text: OMG! The Ramen here was fantastic! I went on Saturday Night around 5:20 and it was very packed! It's a little spot, so its very cramped.. but the wait was so worth it. I ordered the Gyoza, which was delicious and I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen which was absolutely phenomenal! I would recommend this place to any and everyone and I plan to return soon! Best Ramen that I have ever had!

LEjtapIE2qDteYD738O0Fw.text: Great.  Three ramen choices, lots of add ons, and a big city feel to the very small restaurant.  I can't say enough good things about Monta.  You may find better ramen in town (like at Social House) but the setting and authenticity can't be beat.

SBX9Xs7iHsWQDvPvzVyAtA.text: I had the Tonkatsu ramen with extra chashu and a hard boiled egg. The broth is extremely rich in flavor and the chashu pork is the most tender chashu i've had in any ramen house. Monta is definitely #1 or #2 on my ramen list.   I would definitely eat here over any of the pho restaurants in vegas.

F-beontW3xKEBcKaPgxXEQ.text: So far my favorite ramen house in vegas.... And its close to home!

hWZsSEjE64D6UacCSaPcJw.text: Horrible, horrible service. They can't keep in order. Waited more than hour after we sat down. All the foods on the menus are greasy and salty. Not worth the wait and money.

TTxY0VlJGLSSJsp3PWh9Og.text: Went here last night for dinner and had a tasty, satisfying meal.   The restaurant is small and casual.  We ordered some gyoza, a tonkatsu ramen and a shoyu ramen with egg and kimchi and some cold green tea.  I loved that they offered kimchi as a side (I can't have ramen without it!) even though it was 'kimuchi' on the menu.  We tried to get the extra pork but they were out.  The gyoza was too greasy but tasted good.  The tonkatsu ramen was delish!  The broth was white, cloudy, flavorful and less greasy than the shoyu and the noodles were thinner.   The shoyu would be perfect for a  hangover.  The broth was darker, clearer, greasier, and saltier than the tonkatsu.  The ramens come with some green onions, and two pieces of tender pork.  The one thing that will keep me from going back is the temperature.  It is too hot in there, uncomfortably hot to really enjoy your meal especially if its a bowl of hot noodle soup.

HkqCWaiPNvrgXYv2Z-rqpQ.text: Destined to find yummy ramen where ever my travels takes me...lol. A little removed from the strip for the tourist but not too difficult to find.  Definitely a busy place at around 7ish on a weekday night. Lucked out for a table as there are only 5/6 depending how they're arranged for size. Wood benches, chairs, stools, tables and wainscoting lined the restaurant.   There's also L shaped seating for around 10, bar style, around the kitchen area.  The restaurant later filled up with people waiting outside, so be prepared to wait during the typical eat times.  Menu was simple as there was only 3 types of ramen you could order, Miso, Shoyu, Tonkotsu and a couple of rice dishes.  Decided to try the shoyu ramen ($6.95) with toppings (ranges from $0.50 - $1.50) corn, kimchi, and Kaedama (extra noodles).  The broth was tasty and not too salty and the pork was flavourful with the melt in your mouth taste.  The corn was not too buttery but the kimchi could of been better. I was expecting more taste from the kimchi, as it was toned down from other Ramen places I've tried in the past as well as Korean restaurants. The extra noodles was served on the side and was fist sized.  Do this if you're extra hungry...I was comatose after finishing this.  The noodle was a little skinnier than expected but had the right consistency and texture. The gyoza was not too my liking (didnt finish) and I can live off dumplings! The exterior was grilled too long aka burnt and the 'insides' was semi cold like another yelper had mentioned....hmmmm...im guessing store bought?  I imagine them being frozen and put on the grill not long enough but on extra high heat!!! (I know this how??? I make them when I'm home...lol)  Yes, I'd come here again for a quick bowl of noodles but thats about it.

spoevJxoiGBu7iMNNAfg6Q.text: Great hangover food. Awesome ramen broth. Must also get pork belly rice when you're here. It's tasty, fatty, and simply the best. Their pork belly rice is even better than Daikokuya's! Planning to try their kimchi fried rice next time I'm back in town.

rFt5puff3eJ6mE6xzxbl3w.text: Monta does Ramen well.  Nice to find a place like this in Vegas. These places are all over the place in Torrance so the 3 stars..  If this is the only Ramen place in LV, then I'll give them 4+

7F0rivb4jMwgeAXLeFm0Cw.text: Read about this place in December's las vegas magazine.  Arrived about 10:45 am and this place opens at 11:30 am.  Then people started arriving and standing in line, then we decided to join the line.  It is very small place with only 5 tables and a sushi counter.  We tried the tonkatsu shoyu ramen and gyoza.  Their broth is  just as good as those in Japan..  This is so far the best ramen I've eatten in all my travels.  We are planning to add this to our list for our next rip to vegas.  Definitely will recommend  this place to all of our friends.

hH8BF_HJ7J-CHEGbuAt0uA.text: Probably the best Ramen in Vegas, i got the tonkotsu Ramen and it was great, can't wait to try the rest of them. But the fried rice was the worst i ever had, then again why come to a Japanese Ramen house and order fried rice right. I will be back to try the rest of the ramen and the pork belly bowl.

hbnP6QnpsptHS6nU_v-gVA.text: So we were in Las Vegas and heard of this fantastic Ramen house.  We came, we tried, and it was ok.  The portions are small.  For me it's small and for anyone that's used to eatting in Los Angeles Ramen houses its small.  I was not full at all from eatting here.  The price was ok.  I guess if you are in LV and want Ramen you don't have much choice.  If you ever go to Los Angeles, go to Little Tokyo Ramen houses!  It's A LOT better.  Honestly I couldn't believe this place was so packed.  Makes me want to move out here and start a Ramen place.

LpluzmyAZ1I4Z6YB9bu7lw.text: Enjoyed the tonkatsu ramen. There were two pieces of melt in your mouth pork belly! Yummy! Also ordered a regular fried rice. We both finished our bowls of ramen and ended up finishing the fried rice. Feeling rather stuffed. I must say the broth was a bit fattier than other broths I've tasted, but still quite yummy!

Fp397FqnPlHig3zjRnYQng.text: The place is pack within few minutes from opening. Lucky us, we get here 5 minutes before opening.  Ramen are so-so...I've tried better ones. Not too much selections on the toppings.

oDHSaWUAPh4upAXVmGkQzQ.text: Monta delivered again with great ramen and gyoza. Still believe it to be some of the best ramen I've had outside of Japan.

PpnpF9Yv9q2tfLIXyQVSCA.text: Was visiting for a few days, why oh why did I wait until my last day  shere?  Tonkatsu ramen was creamy and savory at the same time, delicious!  Gyoza was also memorable.  What I wish were not so memorable were the waitresses yelling the orders to the kitchen.  Please don't yell over my head, why don't you actually start shouting out the order to the kitchen when you have completed your short walk over there instead?

GRjkD1Epyj6wLLbOW6mtgA.text: I've only been here a few times, and I enjoyed a lot eating the ramen, I always order the Tonkotsu since it's the best one, according to my friends. The ramen sure taste good, but the only bad thing is that it's too salty for me. The place is really small so it's really packed when it's busy. I like how I get to see the kitchen when eating :]  I think this is the best ramen place in Vegas, and I will always come here to eat ramen, but it's not the best in U.S. (I like the one in little tokyo more)

9vCf38yM9bLXzXl-wqqtHw.text: We were tired of fine dining and buffets so we decided to head to Chinatown for Monta. They have a very simple menu with 3 types of ramen: shoyu, tonkotsu, miso (typical selection) ranging from $6.95-7.50. You also have the option of adding more noodles and toppings for $0.75 -$1.50. They also had gyoza, pork rice bowls, and fried rice. Service was nice and speedy. You can tell the girls here were used to dealing with the crowds.  We tried the tonkotsu ramen and the kim chi fried rice.  Overall the ramen was quite flavorful but the flavors don't compare to our favorite ramen place in San Diego at Izakaya Masa. Monta noodles are much thinner but not mushy or al dente (the way we like). It's served with a couple slice of pork, Asian mushrooms, and bamboo shoots. But I do like that they have pickled ginger and minced garlic jars out for self service.  The fried rice was decent but unremarkable.($6.95)  Overall, a good dining experience with reasonable prices. However, the restaurant is really small. There are only 5 small tables plus a L-shaped bar area for 8, so I would return only with small groups to avoid a long wait.

DLqXFJb8RUrV23b1an1Jug.text: Tired of the busy and often pricey food on the strip, wife and I decided to venture out to the Chinatown area in search of some alternatives.  Based on the Yelp review we landed at Monta, and was pleasantly surprised!  The ramen noodle are the thin firm style which we loved, and the tonkosu broth was excellent!  The place is small but cozy, waitress are friendly.  My only gripe is they don't have one in So Cal area where I live.  Definitely heading back there again.

sELOh1jIrzACyeKv3_H3sg.text: Pretty freaking delicious! I had the spicy tonkotsu and it was perfect for this chilly winter we're  having in Vegas! The pork was ever so tender and if I knew the word for al dente in Japanese then I'd use it to describe their noodles! You will typically encounter a line as it is a small restaurant with only 5 tables and about 8 seats at their bar but well worth the wait! If you're thirsty for some Boba just go next door to Kung Fu while you wait! Enjoy everyone!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu @ Monta Ramen

B8Cj3AztlKm_m9z19HY6OQ.text: As soon as you walk in - sign in! Haha There's always a wait for this place.  (But if you're in a hurry to get back to work or wherever there are multiple of good restaurants you can go to in that same complex). So with that statement, it's the type of place you order--- eat--- and leave... You don't want to be the jerk holding up the wait :P   One thing that really caught my attention was how the chefs were dipping the bowl into hot boiling water before making your order to keep your food hot even longer.  I like to enjoy every bite of my food so by the end of my last bite my soup was still warm :P ( but I'll have to admit the last time I went they didn't dip my bowl )   I've tried all three fried rices on different occasions and all were good :) I think the kimchi is my favorite.  As for the  gyoza, it's pretty delicious and crispy.    I've tried all soups and I'll have to say I'll stick to the pork broth with thin noodles and of course adding some green onions and egg to that - call it my usual order :)

EWm3lD1QpO2chl6CsNaWiQ.text: As a New Yorker who is a ramen addict, I must inform you that this ramen is not only authentic but absolutely amazing in flavor profile and richness. The process is simple, order a base ramen (meat included) and then add desired toppings (minor extra charge). Then get ready to split those chopsticks, stir, and dig in. If you successfully eat all those tasty noodles too quickly, you can order more for $1.50. I had the Tonkotsu shoyu ramen, and I can happily say that the richness of the broth was very satisfying, the green onion topping cut through it very nicely, and I added nitamago because who doesn't like eggs? Can't wait to return and have more ramen!!!

1n4DWOutapRNIeYxbAA4MA.text: AMAZING!!! The food is delicious. Every time I go I get the spicy miso ramen & it's always made with perfection. I think the longest I've had to wait for my food was maybe 5 or 7 minutes, which is extremely short if you ask me. This is definitely my favorite place to eat in Vegas.

cE9WrDobSLYuOPFXUa4QDg.text: Place is excellent. Great food and decent beverage selection. Only problem is the restaurant itself is kinda small. Other than that great spot. Wouldn't recommend for large groups though.

zyDGcOK1p8RhDOTXSEZB9A.text: Went here for the second time, just as good as the last.  Sat at the counter again and could watch the cooks make each order.  The whole operation from the wait staff, cooks, and food were spot on!  Had miso ramen and gyoza, again, and was as good as it gets. Place is small and crowded also little warm, guess that's how the customer turnover is good. This place on our must go list whenever we visit Las Vegas.

lDtcH41eyrSsHe7_nohOCg.text: Alright Monta, after 2 reviews, I gotta give you guys the 5 stars. As mentioned in my previous reviews, this is by far the best ramen house in Vegas. That alone counts for a lot. They put a lot of care into their food, which I under appreciated in my previous reviews. Yes, I still think service is sometimes a hit or miss, but lately its been great the past few times I've been here. Hopefully, this is just consistent and not my amazing luck. Also, they listened to their customers and opened up a new location in Henderson. I really appreciate restaurant owners who lend an ear to their customers and act accordingly.  Not much else to say about Monta, if you are looking for ramen in Las Vegas, you've come to the right place.

__bsn-XF1Ui6nAyJA-uitw.text: This place is definitely worth checking out. The tonkotsu ramen had delicious broth and the chashu pork in it was amazing! The wait to get in was a bit long, however totally worth it! Once we were in the staff was friendly, service was quick and efficient! We will definitely come back next time we are in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

7Bh87PGGZ3QdpBjgxFyEEw.text: This place is AMAZING! Be prepared for a long wait if you come during peak hours because it's a small restaurant. We ordered Shoyu Ramen, Miso Ramen, Pork Bellly Bowl and Chashu bowl, and kimchi. My favorite was the Pork Belly bowl (~$3 for small, ~$6 for regular size), the ramen bowls were fine but they weren't the best I've had in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu and Miso ramen

vvuCrNZTyR9fVOycFcmasA.text: My first authentic Japanese ramen! SO happy we made the decision to visit on our trip to Vegas. Place was packed (and it's a tiny place) but we were seated quickly. You can tell the place is good because all the locals are eating here. We ordered gyoza and the miso ramen - both DELICIOUS. Service was awesome. I don't have enough good things to say about it, just don't let the small space deter you.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen

WcDxyX9iBq8yIJQxkOby2A.text: Off the beaten track and that certainly didn't affect the amount of people waiting to get in. They are waiting for a reason; it's damn good. We went hiking in Red Rock Canyon and stopped by here on our way back to the Strip. Yummy!

jydPb4mUoBuJFLh7RJfg7g.text: Monta Ramen was the first ramen place I had ever been to in Las Vegas and my first experience with ramen that did not come in a bag or cup. I have been here many times since then and it is still one of my favorites ones.   The restaurant itself is definitely small and often busy but it is always worth the wait. The tonkotsu is wonderfully porky and now you can get it spicy if that is your thing. My favorite part is the thin, dense noodles. There are days that I crave these noodles specifically and that is when I come to Monta.

80MDUXEdPsL0b9EAojEAAg.text: Ate like a king had a hard time leaving was so full of surprises I could even walk given 5 stars so very kind and wasn't expensive

mzfsOh4gXSWN6XVbwdfNig.text: This could be the "best" ramen in Vegas but it certainly is not the "best" ramen I've ever had.   The bowls are small, cheap, and filling.  Tonkotsu Ramen came with two slices of chashu pork. The broth was light and subtle. It wasn't as thick and flavorful as I wanted. The chashu pieces were thin and flimsy. They weren't intact and was cut up.  Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen was OK, too. Between the two, I prefer the tonkotsu broth.  Big or small, I always finish my entire bowl because I hate to waste the delicious broth but it just wasn't good for me to finish it here.   Lots of parking in the lot. There will most likely be a wait because it's a small restaurant. Hella cheap.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen

OEZBgwJ58v7aLuEURX5t3Q.text: If youre tired of the food on the strip and craving ramen this is the spot. From what the locals tell me the line can be insane at times. I came late night and to my surprise the restaurant was packed.  I didn't expect ramen in Vegas to be up par with LA and Bay Area. The ramen varieties were limited to only 4: Shio, Shoyu, Tonkatsu, and Tonkatsu Shoyu.  I've been spoiled by Ramen Parlor with variety.  Definitely worth checking out if you have a ramen craving and in try Las Vegas surrounding area.

8Ir3FboT1lFUb4VY7nHDNA.text: Great ramen, great prices, small location so you may have to wait for a table, but totally worth the wait

LveD-19LTC74UjlNi0wdtg.text: What a treat :-) I knew it was going to be good but I had no idea I would be doing my happy dance with every bite! :-D ohhhh...the pork....let me tell you about that little morsal of pure delight...the flavor was a beautiful thing :-) it melted in my mouth :-) I'm not a big meat eater but I'm ordering extra my next time around!  The service was just as wonderful as the food :-) I shall be back for sure...we came early a little before 5 and got right in other wise it's a small place and will fill quickly. Which is the reason why it took my so long to try this place. I have tried several times but failed since the wait was so long and my little girl has more energy than patients.

ZovkX2A0uxajAXDPfVoa8g.text: One of the best Ramen places in US. It definitely goes into top three of our Ramen list.  It's a bit crowded at dinner time and you might need to wait like 15 minutes. But once we had our food, all the waiting is worthwhile! It's a small place and we sat at counter. Once you got seated, the service is pretty fast. My bf ordered tonkotsu soyu and I got tonkotsu. The soup base if very thick and rich, very yummy, feels like a good stew from good pork. And the noodle is just right, not too soft and not too hard. Try eat noodle dipped in soup in one bite, it's heaven. :) I almost finished the whole bowl. The bowl is cheap like 6.95 - 8.95. You can add extra topping if you want. It only comes with chashu and a bit veggie for my meal but the good taste makes me happy enough. They don't have other sides or appetizers. As far as I remember, only gyozer and some fried rice. If I go LV later and want some Asian food, that'll probably be the first item popped into my mind.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu shoyu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

5NS_sYIY87VWtnYE4l4zQA.text: So I have had ramen twice before trying out this place and it is only because I like all the elements of ramen but the other two places just didn't quite cut it... And then I found this place and I am so happy with it! nothing else will suffice! Tonkotsu was my favorite

ZI1VxIKq5rz0j70Gp3IqaQ.text: Although the dining area is small, it is well worth the wait! I've been here several times and I always try to bring a different friend. The flavors of all of their dishes are spot on and the soups are an explosion of yumminess in and around your mouth. I'm forever a fan!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen

tqn4NdHobWXQ6ffz3l-7NQ.text: My go to place for ramen The staff is friendly, the only down side is that sometimes it does get extremely busy.

xfirlXL8qpi81nDUS4q_Ag.text: This place looked promising, but didn't deliver.  I guess I was feeling patient and generous that day.  The wait was almost an hour long at lunch on Wednesday since the kitchen was larger than the dining room.  Once seated in one of the limited tables or bar seats, the food comes out pretty quickly to keep customers moving.  Most customers oblige by eating quickly and not loitering with conversation after their meals.  Price is also very good at about $7 per bowl.    I thought the tonkotsu soup base was decent, but temperature was only lukewarm.  It wasn't even hot enough to warm up the toppings in the soup.  When recapping what our favorite and least favorite meals we had this past weekend, both of them cited Monta as the least satisfying.  That's very telling because both of them typically like ramen and are not terribly hard graders.

ilxXXE2mbzXp7PqSpNQlOg.text: The best ramen that we have had stateside.  I ordered the Tonkotsu and my husband had the black garlic oil. Both meals were phenomenal! The broth within my Tonkotsu was insanely flavorful ---The limit does not exist for how much of this broth I would eat. The only disappointment was the egg which was rather bland, but the pork was tender and not dry or chewy. We ate here on a Saturday around 2pm and we had just a 10 minute wait, but the place is very small. Try to come during off hours.  The best part is that the bill was only $30 for 2 ramens, gyoza, and 2 beers.. far cheaper than we usually pay now that ramen is trendy!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu + egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The menu

kfYnyYSutVFBM_xNG3xGmA.text: this place is a must go if you're craving authentic great ramen for an inexpensive price. Their service is great and you will not be disappointed!!!

r_dP3Y0c5vq8_yRW_mpZfQ.text: omnomnomnom!!  Sooo so good, just go.  Stop reading about it and do yourself a favor and go.  That being said like any good ramen shop, its tiny so either go on an off day, for lunch or be prepared for a wait.

nqoDgNz3a1No0oqH8Voy8g.text: The chasu pork bowl here is much better than their ramen. Maybe it was end of night, but the ramen broth was waaaay to salty for me to taste the tonkotsu flavoring. On the other hand the pork chasu at $5.75 is a steal!! Their price is ridiculous cheap for what you get!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2Kq9EDTwc2KgSMNIm6EDiw.text: QUICK & DIRTY: Before stuffing your face with silicone boobies and butts in Vegas, fuel-up with a bowl of deliciousness at Monta Ramen.  ***** My chubby, Filipino Uber driver -- transporting my friend and me from the airport to our hotel, -- tried selling us strippers to our room that night. So I decided to steer the conversation:  "My man, where does an Asian homie like me get down with some ramen up in Vegas?"   He replied, "Oh, Monta Ramen, dog. That's the spot."   I yelped it, of course, and corroborated his recommendation with the four-star average and overall glowing reviews.  Things to know: *****  I. LOCATION & PARKING: This small restaurant resides in a strip mall off of Spring Mountain Road. It sits adjacent to Kung-Fu Tea and Big Wong. Could this shopping area be any more Asian? haha.   The lot doesn't have a lot of room, and parking will be harder than ascending to the top of rope at the end of just about every Ninja Warrior course.   God speed.  II. FOOD & DRINK: Their simplified menu ensures speedy service. They serve six different kinds of ramen (your base), and each added topping, of course, costs extra. They also offer a cold noodle dish, appetizers ranging from gyoza to three different kinds of fried rice, Ashai or Budweiser beer. They carry tea and Coke products, too.   I tasted their Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil, which is a garlic flavored pork broth with thin noodles ($6.95). For toppings, I ordered a soft boil egg ($1.50) and chasu ($2.50)  The savory broth had a nice depth to it. Not like other ramen places where it just tastes watered with salt. It also had enough garlic.   This bowl also comes with thin noodles, so they're not as bouncy or chewy as one might receive in a traditional tonkotsu. However, I still enjoyed eating them.  The slices of chashu pork melted in my mouth. I regret not getting another order.   The soft boiled egg came out with the soup cold, so I'm assuming they cook them beforehand and then refrigerate in order to save time. (Maybe?) I don't know. Maybe pouring a ladle or two of broth over the egg before bringing it out would've helped. Not a big deal, though.   III. SERVICE: They have an efficient setup, so the food came out fast. Also, the host and server treated me nicely. No problems there.  IV. AMBIENCE & DECOR: The small shop seems like it can only fit up to 30 people if that. I wouldn't recommend Manta, though, for groups. Rather, I'd recommend this place, for those wanting to eat solo or up to a couple other people AT MOST. I'd also recommend it to Uber drivers trying to hook up their passengers with strippers, too. Haha.  V. PRICES: Affordable, especially when considering the other food options in Vegas. I'd eat there weekly if I lived close by, honestly.   VI. OVERALL: Will this ramen blow your mind? I don't think so. But if you're looking to get your fix with a more than above average bowl in Vegas, Monta will likely deliver.

EXST8kQTU2K4gtYgYNSZwQ.text: This was my first time having ramen. Before I chose which place to try, I took a poll on instagram: "what's the best ramen place to try" and most people recommended this place. I chose the spicy tonkotsu and gyoza. I loved the flavorful broth and the noodles were delicate and tasty. The gyoza was very delicious as well. It's obvious this place is popular when you arrive. The tiny inside is packed and there are people waiting outside. It looks like it only holds about 25 people. We were seated very quickly since we were only a party of 2 and there was room at the bar area. The food came out within minutes. One bowl and half of the gyoza is very filling. I left very satisfied and can't wait to try more.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen

puC9sxAabiVjtfJFae4lNQ.text: There is typically a long wait here.  We came here to check what the rave is all about.  We ate at the bar so that was much faster than the tables.   There were 9 of us in the party and we all thought is was average at best.  It wouldn't survive if it was in Los Angeles were the ren competition is much more stuff.  This plaza has amazing food.  We typically visit this plaza every time we come Vegas for a few other spots.  This won't be the place if I wanted ramen though.

LOoSrM4p63dVc6cDrotZiA.text: Small location and terrible parking but they are the original authentic ramen place owned and operated by Japanese people. The noodles are cooked perfectly and all the flavors are on point. The restaurant is very small and crowded and there is usually a line of people for lunch and dinner. Best to go between 2pm-5pm if you don't want to wait. If you don't want to add extras the price is less than $7 before tax and tip. Food comes out fast. I wish they would upgrade their throw away chopsticks. They use the old school rectangular splintered kind you have to break apart.  Each broth is distinctively different. The pork belly is a little too fatty though. Only real appetizer you can get is gyoza. Wish they had small side dishes.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

soFDPhBCmpaAC7eQVtooDQ.text: Monta is always consistent and you can't beat their prices!  Sometimes there is a wait, but the line moves pretty fast.  My go to is the Tonkatsu ramen with thick wavy noodles and add egg, corn, Takana and I put their chili oil in it as well . Their gyoza is good too, but be prepared as it does take a bit for them to cook, so you end up eating ramen with the gyoza which isn't bad either.  Delicious ramen and great value!  I've had ramen from other places in town and other cities and I still always crave Monta!

Kq8VQad_3qEaUmV9xb0Bkw.text: Location:   This little "Hole in the Wall Ramen" gem is located in an older small shopping center off of Spring Mtn Rd, west of Decatur.It is  approximately 7-10 minutes from the Palazzo.   Ambiance:  It's a standard  28-30 person little Asian restaurant with bar and table seating. The lighting is good , not too bright, but dim enough to have a cozy like feel. The tables are good with soft cushions and the corner table has a wooden bench sitting area. This is a clean restaurant.  Customer Service:  Very fluent in English and they do allow modifications  with the food. They are very friendly and attentive.  Food & Beverages:  The water is very clean ,without any metallic or mineral flavor. It's obvious they have a higher quality water filter, which means they care about quality. They may not have the greatest selection of beverages,  but the food is where their mastery lies. The broth is rich and not salty whatsoever.  They provide numerous additional ingredients on the table to add to your food,including  a crushed garlic sauce that is ,in my opinion ,the perfect ingredient. They also have very well made kimchi.   Thee noodles actually taste exactly how ramen should taste. There are many varieties of ramen out there, but this type is what grandma makes. The fried  rice is amazing . They also have the kimchi fried rice(favorite mix-add garlic ,touch of vinegar, chili oil , and soy ),the standard and another type I am unsure of.   Negative:  It is the local's favorite and the place every foodie expert goes when they have their ramen crave...which means the wait maybe long if you come during prime time.** Advice: if you come in, in  pairs and are willing to sit in "twos" in different spots, you will get seated faster, just sign in under different names.

3Q_9KelqzKBifK7Ov_EzkQ.text: Before embarking on our long drive home today, my girlfriend and I wanted to grab lunch. We figured we'd just go to a usual spot and head home, but she discovered Monta on yelp while I was driving.  The wait was reasonable when we arrived. It gave us time to look over the menu and plan out our action plan for lunch!  I ordered their kuro black garlic oil ramen and my gf ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen. In addition we ordered their pork belly bowl and fried rice. Yes. It was a lot of food for just two people, but we were famished and both slightly hungover from the night before.   The food came out really fast and you can see it all being freshly prepared and made from the counter.  Pork belly bowl: The regular size is definitely a meal on its own. If you're looking to share, regular is perfect for two people. It was 4345873490% amazing!! The pork belly was incredibly tender and flavorful. The meat to rice ratio was perfect. The issue with pork belly bowls at a lot of ramen shops is that they're usually really bomb, but also really oily. Like, a small pool of oil at the bottom of the bowl oily. I was glad to discover that Monta doesn't run into this issue with their pork belly bowl!  Kuro black garlic ramen: I've always seen this style of ramen at a lot of different ramen places, but this was the first time I had it. It was a little on the oily side, but full of garlicky goodness. If you love garlic, this is the bowl for you.  Spicy tonkotsu: Basically tonkotsu broth with a spicy paste that you mix in. Great, tasty hearty broth with a kick.  Fried rice: The fried rice was so good too! Their fried rice was hearty with lots of ingredients with a hint of wok-hei. Wok-hei is a subtle flavor that fried rice takes up when being cooked in a searing hot wok.  The portions here for the rice bowls are meals on their own, so if you plan on eating ramen, I'd recommend sizing down to a small unless you're sharing.  However, the ramen bowls aren't as large. It's perfect for an individual though, so you will definitely feel satisfied afterwards.  I'm really glad we avoided going to a usual spot and trying something new before we hit the road. We ate around 1 and finally got home not too long ago and I'm still feeling a bit full from lunch. I've got some rice leftover from lunch that I'm really looking forward to eating later!

ntmuB189mY-2mwNU-lFPmA.text: Most delicious ramen in Vegas! . Speedy service and amazing food. Have to have it at least once a week

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Absolutely amazing spicy tonkotsu ramen

tAUe2Sfra4pBrBpDikfvqQ.text: I've been here a couple of times. Ramen was good and priced reasonably. Nitamago is ALWAYS overcooked.

50W1LK_ZfbOxwTC8Kp6lQw.text: Yep, a line before they open! Lucky us we got a counter space! A line on a Monday way out in a Vegas suburb?    It's a small modest store with a few tables and counter space. A very darling homemade sign lists a few menu items.   The Kimchi fried rice was delicious. A little MSG won't hurt you. The Black Garlic ramen was smashing! Service was super! The prices a reasonable!  It was a $40 round trip ride share fare from The Strip, however I will be back!

LdanOlTtV9QFY5mpg5wxvg.text: Came around 2pm on Thursday and had to sign in and wait about 15 mins for bar seating. Got tonkotsu and the wife got spicy tonkotsu. Added egg and corn for me and egg and green onions for her.  Pork was fall apart tender, broth was rich and creamy and the noodles were cooked perfect.  Cheap, $6.50 - ~$10 depending on which version  you order.  Hot tea comes in a can, lol, but its hot...keep them in an oven or what??? ((:  I highly recommend trying the ramen here.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1fMeoMET0bhdRXsxRwRKxg.text: It was hot and just watched a video on cold ramen. Had heard good things about Monta and hoped for the best. They had a small crowd waiting outside but the wait wasn't long. They had cold ramen served with your choice of sesame or yuzu sauce. I tried the yuzu, my mom had the sesame. The sesame added a nice nutty, creamy taste- will go with that next time. The staff was efficient and friendly. The place is small, clean and packed. Their menu is relatively small, something I like, and there are several items I'd like to try. Definitely going back.

5WoVmuhTRYiosD3RY58aaw.text: You can't ever seem to find parking in the plaza. It's almost always full. I recommend that you park on the street or a neighboring plaza.  There's always a line for the restaurant. Waiting time varies from 10-40 minutes, maybe even longer depending on the time you go and the size of your party.    Try to get here before noon and late evening. Those are the times when the restaurant and parking lot will be PACKED.   In terms of their food, the ramen is amazing! The meat is SUPER tender. I highly recommend the Tonkotsu, which is their #1 ramen. The broth is REALLY creamy. I also recommend the Miso. If you're a sweet tooth, this is definitely the ramen to get. The broth has a little sweetness to it.

MnNGH3OHWKVX4OujX7uPtA.text: Not much of a review here but just needed to share that this is the best Ramen I've eaten. This being the spicy tonkatsu ramen. Amazing!  I will definately be returning to this place whenever I return to Vegas.  In the meantime, if anyone has any suggestions of where I can find something comparable to this in NYC please share.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu. Best Ramen ever!

ppQqd8f4hsSX9rbT-MjZew.text: The spicy Tonkotsu ramen is outstanding, spicy as advertised and very hearty. Also had a smallpork belly bowl, wasn't as blown away by it as i was by the ramen but it was good! Highly recommend this place for the yummy ramen!

0yJhg-6SEWKH0suFseC5Nw.text: What do you get when you get a super hangry Em B. and equally hangry co-habby, both of who can't decide where to eat at 11PM at night? Two irritably famished people who are ready to strangle each other in about 2.5 seconds and almost ready to just head to In-N-Out because everything else was closed. Enter Monta.   We were initially going to try and eat at JINYA ramen, but the wait time was one hour too short of us starving to death. By some miracle, we found ONE spot open in the parking lot and also ONE table that happened to be available right at the moment. Thank you baby jeezus!!   The co-habby devoured his Pork Belly bowl which was tender and full of flavor. I had the Kuro Ramen - Black Garlic Oil which featured Pork broth, roasted garlic flavor, thin noodles. This was damn tasty although the broth was a bit chalky for me. Still a bigger fan of the Raki Raki black garlic ramen however this was quite good. It's also only $7.95 but if you want a Nitamago egg, it's an extra $1.50. A bit skimpy on the pork too.  Service was friendly and lightning fast, which we appreciated since we were exhausted and just wanted to get some sleep after our long drive from SD. It's not a fancy place by any means and very tiny, but it's authentic and a great little hole in the wall in LV's Chinatown when you want a satisfying bowl of ramen or other Japanese fare. Will return!

zCnzuySOXrqSQh_pZ_GAdw.text: I can see why the lines are long here.. And it's not cause of the ramen! Prices are cheaper compared to Ramen Sora (best bowl of ramen in Vegas). The broth just didn't do it for me at monta.. That takana fried rice was tasty though

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0ADt5zZY0uDoAFELuLOXAw.text: Monta Ramen is one of the more popular ramen spots in Vegas. The choices are simple so I opted for the Miso Ramen and we all shared the Pork Belly Bowl and Gyoza.   The food came out quickly, which made up for the long wait outside. My Miso Ramen tasted off because of the miso. When I tasted my buddy's Tonkotsu, it was much better. The egg was nothing to write home about, but the noodles were pretty good.   On the other hand, the Gyoza and Pork Belly Bowl were good as well as the service. Overall, pretty good. Just not sure I'd wait about 1.5 hours for it though if I had a choice.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside the gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

g94kmx_4a_ts-OKghknVvw.text: Pretty small ramen place in Chinatown Las Vegas. We had a group of 8, and the wait was quite long for lunch on a Saturday. Service was good; the waiters checked up on us constantly. I got the Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil. The broth was rich but not too salty; the favors from the black garlic oil were wonderful. They had thin noodles, very standard. It was very oily, but that was expected for tonkotsu ramen. Their ramen bowls were cheap (~$7-$8), and it came with 2 pieces of chashu, bamboo shoots, and wood ear mushroom. I had to order the nitamago separately, and it was okay. I personally thought the chashu was too fatty, but I still liked the ramen overall.  Definitely a good option if you are craving some comforting rich ramen, but do expect to wait a bit. Boba and dessert places are conveniently located in the same plaza if you have room for that afterward!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro black garlic oil !

yM7U6e3rj-a5HGvy8wI-KA.text: There are some restaurants that might not have the best service, atmosphere or overall experience, but the food is so exceptional they deserve 5 starts regardless. To me, the core of a restaurant is the food, and if it is exceptional, I am willing to deal with some inconveniences to enjoy that food. Monta Ramen is one of those places. Their food is exceptional. Monta Ramen is not a place you go hang out, is not a place for a date, is not a place to have a nice dinner out. Monta Ramen is a place to go eat, period. It is a place for people in the search for outstanding food. You go there to eat, then you eat, then you leave, no frills.  Everything you order is outstanding, but the garlic broth is my favorite, their broth is so concentrated in pork flavor is thick. Almost gelatinous. Just heaven. Order the fried rice, it is perfectly cooked, perfectly season, fluffy and sticky at the same time.  Monta Ramen runs as a perfectly oiled machine, whose main purpose is to feed delicious food to as many people as possible. Hence, you will wait a long time to be seated, after you get seated you will be served quickly and expected to leave quickly. If you are into really good food go here if you are into having an experience first, then eat, don't go here. This restaurant is for food lovers, not experience seekers.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

j02nF9UbzNkHUZRS6zdSMQ.text: This place is a very small size restaurant in a supper busy plaza. The parking will be the headache if you come on the weekend. We were lucky to get sit in right away compare to another waiting time up to 1h. They have an open kitchen which is look neat & clean. The food come out without complain. They are perfect & delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best ramen in Vegas
