Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy pork belly rice bowl

wvANR_NmERIGP4zvHrFN8Q.text: Lovely place to eat! Food is fantastic and comes out quickly. The only gripe I really have with this place is the service, on occasion. I understand the restaurant itself is small and can get crowded pretty quickly, however, whenever I am sat down by my server (no matter who it is, I have come plenty of different times throughout the years) I feel like I'm being rushed through the whole service. They come to your table about 3 minutes after sitting you down and asking your drink order and make it almost painfully obvious they want you to order right at that moment so they can rush to get your order out. It's extremely rushed and makes me feel less valued as a customer and more as a dollar sign. As of now this is ok with me but I will definitely consider switching to another ramen spot if this goes on and I consistently feel rushed as a customer.

ea_sK6XsJ867FsIQiDVErA.text: Excellent food!!!  But very very very long wait!!!!  We were exhausted from standing while waiting for a long time.  Need a bigger place.  Now I know of a new place to go to when I'm in Vegas

YbANmqeUqocIWbn8cvte0A.text: This little hole in the wall place is clean,great service and good ramen the only downside is it's small but over all it's a great place to come for affordable good bowl of ramen.

7x_FfII0iul5BUrbqFFd0w.text: Delicious ramen & fried rice. Just expect to wait if you don't come right when they open because it does get really busy & the place is really small with limited seating.

cFiNpfKXz81LJ7sNKgAu-g.text: Just a good ramen place not the best but theres no reason it doesn't deserve 5 stars  Just a really long wait usually

uaCsWIqzbqeuwpwgFqe3Sg.text: Great service. Amazing dumplings and ramen! Good options of add-ons. Not much seating so it fills up quickly. Delicious ramen spot!

589__C9T1GCIFY_r-6wOkg.text: Ramen here is always delicious !! Got the butter added to the thin noodle it was so yummy !!!

YbeIDQzWO86fx8bgc43Npg.text: I huge lover of ramen I was excited to try out her favorite noodle house 'Monta'..   It's located on Spring Mountain in Chinatown and like every decent place will probably have a line.  We were lucky and fitted right away, we came around 430 p.m. Monta is another very quaint ramen joint that greets you when you arrive, and quickly serves their specialties. Their ramen options are well described and actually convinced me to try a broth I never had. Delicious!!! Though I am a huge pork fan and the broth made with pork is divine.  They don't have ramen that is specifically spicy, but they have a spicy option. They offer many sides for a nominal fee, including extras that were pretty tasty. The kimchi fried rice was very good, but the pork belly bowl was lacking meat...  The green onions are shredded, I wasn't a fan as it lost its flavor being so thin. Though I was very pleased with the creamy consistency of my soup. I enjoyed my lunch and the employees were very delightful. But, I would rate Monta on Spring Mountain 3***'s

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. So good
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bowl of ramen deliciousness

u6M9d5SCOp54B9jM6C48og.text: Shio broth was excellent, perfect, buttery, salty (not too salty) and not oily. Hubby had the shoyu broth which wasn't too salty. Ramen was cooked pretty good, not soft or too chewy. Spicy pork fired rice hit the spot when in need of rice! Kids had the mini chasu curry bowl. They killed it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

shB4iF1XbqGthqGQm_V3mw.text: One of my favorite ramen spots in town! Love how high pace they are, with food ordering and getting customers in and out! Seating is very limited so at times you have to wait 15-30mins for a table but it's sooooo worth it!  Their ramen bowls are full of flavor and the noodles are tender. Their gyozas are one of my favorites the only thing is that they don't have gyoza sauce for it so you have to 'make your own' using the different sauces on the table. (mine always come out different everytime :-/ ) Love their pork fried rice too! I can eat that rice everyday!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. YUMMY Gyoza

ypF4zgc5EidEl_DoBRVWTQ.text: Craving for some wholesome soup! This hit the spot! There was a line but it moved fast! This place dishes out some delicious broth soups! Gyoza and green mustard fried rice was bomb!

VmGNN2mOTqElmvg5hJ8lyg.text: For all the hype I was hearing about this place.... ew, is all I have to say. I LOVE Roman and if I had gone here for my first Roman House experience, I wouldn't have tried any where else because I would have thought Roman houses are gross. My whole family was disappointed and wouldn't eat here if this was the only place left to eat.

j63CH-oalEYTHSJmeCrv5g.text: 2.5** Good news first :) Yes the wait is long cuz the entire plaza where this is located is full of seemingly awesome restaurants. There's a sign in sheet to help keep orderly and seems to be the practice in Chinatown restaurants. The parking lot is packed during dinner time. People were walking in from parking across the street. But hooray for the selections of neighboring restaurants!  Yes service is quick and attentive. They clean off tables and seating areas as soon as guests are through. We got bar seats facing the kitchen and were able to watch their process. They wear gloves and hair bandanas. Saw how they keep their soup bowls hot. Saw how routine it was to put noodles, ingredients, and broth. Saw how busy the workers were. Our orders came out quickly after ordering.  Yes their ramen soup is totally delish! Hot, tasty, comfy, and a good amount of ingredients. Their awards and acknowledgments on the walls live up to the best value. Absolutely enjoyed the flavor! There was enough in our bowls for another soupy meal for later. Wish I could've finished it cuz I was having a needy moment. The rest of the soup to go - so it is so...  No there is not a lot of room for a popular place to eat. After a tiny bit of parking frustration, then there's the seating wait, and the standing, and the crowd. I wish they had better space; and perhaps that is what's in plans for such a successful place. Real awesome for them! Good luck on the bigger space.  No 3 whole stars or 3.5 - what's up Jo... Why're you jippin' on the stars?! Oh no see... Was looking forward to leftover soup for lunch the next day. Saddened me to gags that the broth was hard like butter! Eeeuuuw what! That doesn't happen to pho noodle broth! What was REALLY in this ramen broth?!?!?! (Grumpy cat face) I think I'll pass on next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu and Black Garlic Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

cr5yUS_EwYxflyDFT9YTFw.text: Tonkotsu Ramen ($6.95) - I typically like tonkotsu ramen, but this was oily and just too thick for my liking.  Without extra toppings, there's not a whole lot on the ramen as is.  Definitely not worth the wait...  Ambiance: Small establishment with tables tightly located next to each other, and a bar counter.  Minimal in decor, and kind of dark.  Long lines even on a weekday night and we waited around 30-40 minutes.  Service: Minimal but efficient as possible.  Price: It's cheaper than most other ramen places.  Parking: Small shared plaza parking.  Street parking around surrounding areas.  Location: Small plaza with bunch of other Asian establishments.  Lowlights: Long wait, thick oily soup.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

wx3IksUD8keL9JkVqlVgnQ.text: I had the Miso Ramen. It honestly did not meet my expectations. The bowl wasn't bad by any means but it did not have anything going for it as well. For these few reasons I have this give this a 3/5

UfQgsHBUoyPhQKxO0Hqr1w.text: Their gyozas were the best!! Wanted to impress my 11 yr old boy for his first Gyoza experience-

FlsI-z4oxy8So8Nq9vykgA.text: Small ramen shop but wonderful service! We had a large group and they were able to accommodate us with around 30 minutes wait. They also let us look at the menu and order while we were waiting so we could get our ramen soon after we got seated.   My personal favorite was the Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen, I've never had them mixed together and who knew they would be such a good combo! The Tonkatsu gave the broth the fatty rich taste, and the shoyu gave it a bit more kick in the flavor. For the marinated half-boiled egg (Ntamago), you have to order on the side, which is super worth it if you like them! The chashu was fatty and went well with the ramen.   Portion was okay, some of the guys in the group did wish they order extra noodle though. Overall a great ramen place, will be back again!

kzgdexKUArgFAFqGJAe01g.text: I came for the ramen, but I will remember the pork belly!    This little ramen shop was located in the China Town area of Vegas.  There are actually a few other asian things in this plaza.  I was happy we found this spot.  It's a legit Japanese Ramen place, we tried the Kuru ramen which was black and garlicy. I thought it was good, not amazing, but something different.  You don't get to select how firm you want your noodles, I felt they were on the firm side so if you like that.  Price is good, I think about $6.75 for a bowl of ramen and you can get refills on noodles if you wish.  You can also add additional toppings like egg, etc.    What was a must-do was getting a side of the pork belly bowl.  Think of it as an upgraded Yoshinoya beef bowl.  Instead, it's pork belly, the taste is strong juicy.  It is a little much to get ramen and a small side of pork belly bowl but I wouldn't have it any other way.  I want to come back and try fried rice with my ramen but I don't know if i'll be able to not get the pork belly again.  I would try a different ramen next time to see how they do on the traditional items.  Solid place for authentic Japanese Ramen and Sides.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

nM-_dNpPONXdoCAtN8ZxAQ.text: Always good.  Always consistent.  Always tasty.  What else can I say that hasn't already been said.  Yes the wait can be long.  But if Kana is there, she's awesome and makes the meager surroundings disappear.

GYDpPfuYQMdoWPosroANJw.text: I cannot complain about anything because the price and quality of the food is amazing considering it's in Las Vegas. At ~$7 a bowl for ramen, it's surprising that the food is so fresh and consistently good. I have yet to experience bad customer service here as everyone is really polite and welcoming. Hopefully they can reopen the Henderson location if they haven't already because it's a long ways away to drive to Spring Mountain anytime I want good ramen.

6Sm4nHpGExDF4P62mzMILA.text: OMG the spicy tonkotsu was so good, the pork gyoza was too! The best ramen I ever tasted in the US. They have not too many seating in the restaurant, but the queue line was still ok even during lunch time. Will surely come back when I come to Las Vegas again

rUK7OiONc4xuRrwB4hV-Wg.text: Yay yay yay for kimchi! This places kimchi alone is what keeps me coming back and it's only one dollar!   I have tried all of their ramen choices and I think they are all delicious. My favorite has got to be the tonkatsu ramen with thick wavy noodles instead of thin noodles. All very hearty and comforting, perfect for nights that you need a good fill. All add the add ons are very cheap as well.   I have also tried the gyoza and kimchi fried rice. Both very good, although I would prefer if they chopped the onions a tad bit smaller but I'm not complaining too much about it.   Although this location is very small and very busy they really know how to turn over the tables fast and I love it!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen and kimchi

VevmIkGxtDrekmGvpgerSg.text: Restaurants like these are the many reasons why I want to move to Vegas. My sorority sisters recommended this ramen joint, because it is their favorite. As for the atmosphere, the wait is INSANE. Fortunately we didn't have to wait too long because we went at a slow time. However, usually the wait can be hours. They have one small bar, and then a couple tables.  There is a long waiting list for dine in. Their prices are amazing, especially compared to Reno ramen prices. I ordered the spicy ramen for $7, and the pork belly bowl for $4. The ramen was amazing and tasty; toppings are extra, but even without toppings they are delicious. The pork belly bowl was to die for; it was so tasty and filling. I was very satisfied by the taste and flavor of the dishes. For great pricing and authentic taste, this place is worth the wait. But the downside is the wait. I would not recommend this place for people who want a quick bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy ramen! filling and great price

wPjrXw_2B87X0xc7WEhi1g.text: I know this is a violation of Yelp Law, but my visit to Monta was only the second time in my life that I've had ramen (Cup O'Noodles doesn't count, not that I eat it).    I may have been spoiled by the first time, which was in New Jersey.  At that place I was able to customize it to the skies: choice of the regular pork broth, or chicken, or even vegetable.  Too salty?  "No prob, we can do low sodium." And I was able to have chicken or shrimp (can't remember which) instead of some fatty pork.  It wasn't that way at Monta.  What you see is what you get, complete with photos.  And since even as a kid I was nauseated by even the tiniest bit of fat on any meat or poultry, I couldn't stand the pork that was in the bowl and had to remove it.  I'll take a nice, lean piece of pork loin any time, but not the stuff that makes up the choices at Monta.  The broth was pretty decent, and I'm a sucker for noodles of any kind, but the ramen here will never be my comfort food.  While service was quick, the tiny and cramped space does not lend itself to comfort or relaxation, so fast service was definitely welcome.    I don't disagree with all of those who love this place.  Different strokes for different folks, I guess.

7yzLwCb4mI_TYThkMjrs_w.text: The miso ramen is salty you can't stand! The pork on top is tasted not fresh

38q_-myzpKXBQUy6FjlEsw.text: I'll make this short and sweet. Hey, that's the perfect description of our waitress!  We arrived on Friday night, between 6-7PM to a full parking lot, but a slow night over at Monta Ramen. We found street parking, got our name on the list and probably sat around 7 minutes after that. The bar top was packed while the main area had a steady flow of patrons ordering, dining, enjoying then leaving. Seems like standard operating procedures, so let's do it.  I ordered the Spicy Tonkutsu Ramen and our table shared the Takana Rice. Literally, our ramen showed up within minutes.. Seems like they might have it sitting stove top somewhere. It took longer for our rice to show up, but it was definitely worth it. The rice was tasty, as are most fried foods. Fluffy and moist with bits and pieces of meat, egg and dashes of spice.   As far as the ramen goes, there was a taste I can't quite describe.. it wasn't necessarily bad nor was it good. What saved the bowl, in my opinion, was the fact that they include a little sriracha style chili sauce which blended well in the broth and masked that indescribable taste. That, along with garlic and a dab of soy totally turned this dish from a 3 to a 4. The spice level, out of 10, had to be in the 5 or 6 zone. ALMOST had me, but it was more of a flavor than the actual kick. The ramen noodles were a little thin making it truly easy to finish this bowl off, which I find hard to do in the SGV area due to the portion sizes.  This wasn't necessarily the best ramen I've had to date, but having the wind gust hard outside along with winter like temps and an empty stomach, it definitely did the job.. We didn't have to wait in a dreaded line, super-friendly service, decent prices, prompt ticket turnaround times and the meal was quite fulfilling.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. &#34;Spicy&#34; Tonkotsu

sJsCM7P-aFLkUOB7E80ctA.text: What can I say that hasn't already been mentioned in near 2000 reviews? This ramen is everything! The menu is so simple and small. They have picked a specialty and stuck to perfecting it. Expect a wait! When I think of a small hole-in-the-wall restaurant (which are my favorite kind), I think of what Monta Ramen looks like. It only holds maybe 20 people? I didn't count, but it's small. You owe it to yourself to try it at least once!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

vRH2LlsmTMwkQcTADDA7uA.text: We were really hungry and excited to try the ramen here, but we were a bit disappointed. The ramen was not bad, but it was not particularly good in any way.   I got the shoyu ramen. The soup was very salty, and the meat was very fatty and chewy. It was decently priced, but you have to add money for an egg. The toppings that came with the ramen weren't particularly great either.

q6ERtK-z5Li4YqeZPka50Q.text: The ramen here is absolutely amazing.It is very busy sometimes and has only small tables so not great for a large group. The prices are cheap about $6 to $10 and only $1 for more noodles.

sXwfVj2RbN_mJyBPRbIldA.text: I really enjoyed the Ramen and the ambiance of this small Japanese Noodle shop.  I love the open kitchen layout because it's fun to see the cooks at work making the food and creating the magic.  So let me back up. This little restaurant is located in a small strip mall off of Spring Mountain (Las Vegas' International District). Use Yelp Directions to help you find it. It's small, clean, and similar to a place you might visit in Tokoyo today (only it's missing the plastic food display at the front of the store). We walked in around 4'ish and the place was already packed.  Luckily, we only had to wait a couple of minutes before a place opened up at the bar.  A very nice server came over and took our orders down on her iPad (good modern touch).    The Shoyu Ramen (thick ramen, soy sauce & chicken broth w/ 2 slices of Pork) was only $6.95;  Tonkatsu (thin ramen, pork bone stew w/ 2 slices of Pork and a side of spicy sauce was $7.95; side of Kimchi $1; and rice $1. Oolong tea served nice and hot in a can was only $1.75.    Any Cons, you may ask? Well the restaurant is really small and really crowded because of it's popularity & tasty Ramen.  You have to eat fast or your Ramen will get cold. Also they want you out of there as quick as possible so they can make room for the poor customers waiting in line.  Think of this as an Express Ramen Noodle shop. We enjoyed this experience and definitely plan to visit again soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Better than Top Ramen. ;)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

V3V0o6ACKwHIGIFILM6ttw.text: Not being a Las Vegas native, I stumbled upon this spot and let me tell you, this was a really good Ramen restaurant. I had the Shayu Ramen, the noodles were thick and the base was really flavorful. This is a very small intimate hole in a wall place. It does get busy, and it is semi wheelchair accessible. My friends and I only waited for about 10 minutes before being seated. Our food arrived pretty quickly after being ordered. Fast service. Definitely would eat here again.

-9UFugJ6mj92qnrhA6xsXg.text: This place is very much... Alright.  Came here because a few friends raved about it and it looked like it had amazing reviews, came half an hour before opening time just to make sure we wouldn't have to wait too long. luckily my group of about 20 just barely fit behind a few other couples. very small place that seats less than 30?  The ramen wasn't bad but it definitely wasn't all that great. I'm from LA so I guess I probably am lucky to have much more options but you would figure Vegas has the best of all worlds. Compare to anything else I've ever had around LA, this was much more salty, portions were a tad bit smaller, other than the saltiness not that flavorful. Menu here is small but some Japanese restaurants tend to be so that wasn't too big of a surprise.  You definitely have to be a pork lover because that's pretty much all they have, if I remember right they have approximately four different ramen choices, and a few other side dishes like fried rice and gyoza.  If you are a local I'm sure this may be as good as it gets? But if you're from out of town only try this place if there is no wait. Totally not worth a wait.

1Ol6RMNTUHUwMfdTA0FzEA.text: Wow, this place is really good, and probably the most inexpensive ramen place I've been to.  I think the bowl of ramen I had was around $7, versus the $9 I spend at other joints.  But do not be deceived by the price, the noodles are good, and so is the broth.    After reading all the reviews we got here before it opened.  Since there was already a couple sitting on the bench, I decided to stand by the pillar near the door.  Within 10 minutes, a crowd began to form and they created their own impromptu line...which I was late to realize.  Still, I decided it would be ridiculous for me to get to the back of the line, which was beyond the front of the restaurant at that point, and so I stuck it out, and just got in line once the doors opened behind the first couple figuring those who came later had to have seen me standing there.  Luckily all went smoothly without any incident.  Food came out quickly, and service was good.  For big eaters, the offer extra noodles for a little more than a buck.  Everyone in my party enjoyed their meals.      With that said, my tip to you is that if you get there before the door opens, beware of the line that quickly forms, as I noticed that I would not have been able to get a seat, had I decided to conform to what everyone else decided to do.  Still I can't fault them for creating a line, as there were truly a lot of people that got there seemingly at the same time, and still more getting there as the restaurant finally opened.

c_weGUEAWAKZFQZSWWoxfg.text: Really nice place and worth it as long as you go there right when it opens of off hours.  This is my third visit to Monta but first time to review.    1.  The lines - The place is typical for a Ramen shop, with limited space to eat and to wait, but it is worth it.  My suggestion is to go when it opens and it will be all good.  2.  The food -  Have had: a.  Miso Ramen - Bean Paste Ramen, very tasty. noodles perfect. b.  Shoyu Ramen - Soy Sauce flavored broth and a nice stand by. c.  Tonkatsu Ramen - Pork Bone broth - my favorite.  All noodles are just right, al dente and the broth is not piping hot as I would expect, but tasty overall.  Perhaps they believe the western palate does not prefer the hot broth, but to me, it has to be piping hot to be perfect.  The soups have a perfect blend of roasted pork slices that are tender and tasty.  3.  Price - Very reasonable, approximately 7.00 depending if you put extra stuff in the noodles.  Check this place out.  you will not be disappointed.

-CNdLg3l-91UW2QTvUqUug.text: I get the biggest stomach boner just thinking about this place. More than sushi, more than even in n out, does this place make me want to commit suicide via ohm nom nom.  Some People b*tch about the service, but the servers aren't there to chit chat and entertain you (which is completely fine by me), they're there to (in order) get your drinks, food order, refill drinks, food delivery, accept payment, then shuffle you the f*ck out so I can stuff my face with shoyu with extra egg... And nori..... And extra pork chashu.... And.... and.....FAPFAPFAPFAP....

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. New Years day; hung over....
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. ... New Years day, hung over still, but significantly less miserable.

MhLaYxDgU_YEIAVHNUhhYw.text: We left this place our first attempted visit due to the wait.  This time we got sat right away. Service was good. Everyone talks this place up. To my disappointment, I was not impressed.  I have been known to get addicted to ramen.  My tonkotsu was too rich to finish.  The pork was very salty. I have had better ramen elsewhere.  However my boyfriend did enjoy his shoyu ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

EIn56_patIviJJ3exFlDfg.text: It only took me 3 years to finally get here. I'm glad I finally got to try it this year! It is pretty damn good. A thick hearty, flavorful broth with thick ramen noodles, and extra toppings (whichever are your favorite) and the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen really hits the spot. Next time I will try the black garlic broth, it looks so interesting! The service is very friendly and attentive. This is definitely the best ramen I've had in Vegas!

R4aIITMphAWkHkeh1BbgvA.text: Monta Ramen is a combination of things that works out just right to get 5 stars. I'll start with the little frustrations to get them out of the way.      The parking lot for the group of shops it's in is woefully undersized. You may have a hard time finding a spot right there. Next, there may be a bit of a wait. We went on a Monday with maybe a 20 minute wait, but I've heard from others it can get to be pretty long. Well... That's about it.      So the menu is small, but has the essentials. For three of us, we decided to have ramen, then split some extras. The pork belly rice bowl was great as were the gyoza. Everything we ordered was simple, but tasted great.      The ramen came out for the next part of the meal. We all went with the tonkotsu ramen. Limited add-ones included, but it wasn't lacking. The broth was amazingly creamy/milky and rich. The noodles had a great texture. Insanely hot, so many sure not to burn your mouth! I made sure to keep plenty of broth left for kaedama (extra serving of noodles).      Prices were super-affordable. If you stick with just ramen it's a steal. Even with extras you won't break the bank.

nN4A0VvdmrwHfqQAXL9i1w.text: 4 star for the food but because of the long wait I would give it 3.5 star.  The restaurant is extremely small.  We arrived half an early before it even opened and there was already a line at the door.  If you go around 2 or 3 pm there is no line! Not a busy time to eat.    We ordered the braised pork with egg on rice and two bowls of pork ramen.  We added an egg and extra meat to the ramen.  It was actually too much meat and we didn't finish it.  The broth was a little on the rich and oily side.  We thought they added butter to the broth but we asked the server and she said no butter.  It was still delicious and we would go again just not during peak hours.

fOfBJLv8S3LrEqhyHF090w.text: It was the first best ramen restaurant in Vegas before Jinya and sora. Those 3 can compete.  I love their cold noodle with miso dressing, can't get it anywhere else, the pork belly bowl and their fried rice is to die for.  Talk about service, it was ok, never special. Anyway, for me it just about food.

8vwXaGE4hjvEYB4CwjX2Rw.text: This is what Tonkatsu Ramen is all about. We got here about 20 minutes before opening and got in line. We ended up with primo spots at the bar. I've been on a kick looking for the best Ramen I can find. I'll continue looking for even better Ramen. I'm off to another place tonight. However, at this point, I have yet to find anything this good. The pork and egg were perfect. I'd like to see the egg marinated a little. The broth nearly perfect. The noodles truly excellent. I can see why there is a line here.  Broth - A- Noodles - A- Egg - A- Pork - A Additions - B

abSVCWyOPtXjni-Ys6p8-w.text: I am a HUGE RAMEN LOVER!  Living in Honolulu, we have really good Ramen restaurants here and after visiting New York City last year, my Ramen standards are a lot higher and whenever I'm in another city I always make it a point to have my Ramen fix. Last March I visited Ramen Sora and it was good but I think Ramen Monta beats it by far!  After a day of shopping at all the trader Joe's with my girlfriend Mochi we decided to have lunch at Ramen Monta because she knew how much I love my Ramen and it was a bit cold that day. The wait wasn't quit as long as she thought it would be because we beat the lunchtime rush so we were seated within a few minutes.   I got their new spicy Ramen and my girlfriend ordered the regular tonkatsu Ramen, we also ordered a side of the menchenko eggs with rice. The quality of noodle is good, very thin and soft and the broth is like buttery, not to salty, not to oily and so smooth and soothing. I think the broth is what makes a good quality Ramen. The price is also just right because for all 3 items I paid about $20 not including tip. Workers are very sweet and the food comes out quick...Be sure to go early because as we were eating and it got more towards lunch time, the line started forming.  I was raving about this place so much to my boyfriend who didn't come with us because he was sleeping back in the hotel room, so suxx for him. I will be sure to hit this place back up on the next Vegas trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy ramen

R64KyZyLSW6LzPETyyRERQ.text: My wife & I absolute love this place.The broths here must be made from the tears of angels! Its small & tight but is well worth the wait. In summer its a bit hot but hey you cant have it all. We love ramen and this is the go to spot. Highly recommend checking it out. the fried rice & pork belly bowl are also delish!!

siWz-lCK_vcKBI0rX3nKWQ.text: My wife and I stumbled upon Monta Ramen while visiting town. I love to get away from the Strip where the price of food is reasonable. The restaurant is small and busy so prepare to wait a little. I has the Miso Ramen which was excellent. My wife tried one of the fried rice dishes....superb.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen

OI9ynLUrEpGkHd6SxWuhFw.text: Needed a ramen fix at 10pm on a Sunday night before we were going to embark on our journey back to LA.  At 10pm there was no wait and a nice sized table for the 4 of us. We went with the Yelp highlights, and I'd hate to mention these here again since I don't think the system Yelp is built on filters out the negative comments for items mentioned a lot and it just keeps reinforcing the highlights even though I don't like em!  Tonkotsu Ramen - Got this and asked for extra spicy sauce since I didn't see the Spicy Tonkotsu on the chalkboard right away. It was good, but honestly way TOoOoOOo salty. I didn't realize it at first cause I was so hungry, but honestly it was very salty and I couldn't finish the soup  Gyoza - Nothing special whatsoever and no special sauces for this Kimchi Fried Rice - does NOT taste like a kimchi fried rice you'd expect after living in K town for some time Pork Belly Bowl - Also a MEH for me. I can see how it is taste so if you're into the crispy 'chadol'/yoshinoya type of meat then you should try this. A little saucey which ain't necessarily a bad thing. I also took this one home and ate it the next day and I didn't hate it.  Overall, unfortunately for the amount of reviews this place has, it was only worth 3 stars for me. I can confidently say I am a strong foodie and have my spots in the different cities I frequent and I was hoping to find a go-to ramen spot in Vegas. With that said, unfortunately I do not think it will be Monta.  I might come back for Kung Fu next door and if my ramen craving kicks, I might give it another go.

VTptWdZiLkxC1_8x0BAckA.text: Tonkatsu, Shoyu, Oh MY!  There is genuine reason why people line up on a daily basis before Monta opens. This restaurant is incredible. The food is sublime in its simplicity and authenticity. Ramen is such a wonderful and satisfying dish that when it is executed with the depth of flavor and consistency of Monta, it is something to celebrated.  Their Tonkatsu Ramen is absolutely incredible with regards to the depth of flavor and the value. Their ingredients taste fresh and appear to be well handled. It is very easy to go overboard with the additions of hard boiled egg, kim-chee, and more pork. The complimentary pickled ginger is so delicious. I know it is made in-house, I wish I could buy it and take it home!

7rUkkEkN5WfoN6J7VtPZFw.text: **3.5 Stars**  Located conveniently next to Raku on the outskirts of Las Vegas Chinatown, Monta is the latest darling in the Vegas foodie scene and follows the popular ramen trend that has already hit LA, NYC, and the Bay Area.    Authentically Japanese owned and frequented by many Japanese during our visit, Monta offers shoyu, tonkotsu, and miso broths.  Tonkotsu appears to be their most popular offering and bowls start at a reasonable $6.95.  Each bowl comes with two pieces of chashu, green onions, and some bamboo shoots.    Overall, the bowls are on the small side and toppings a bit sparse than other top places I've frequented.  Corn, butter, Kim Chee, and a hard boiled, not soft boiled, egg can be added.    Broth flavor was good though a tad salty and one noted compared to the more complex broths I love at Santouka.   The noodles are fresh but thin reminding me of the fresh made noodles at Maru Ichi in the Bay Area. I personally like thicker noodles like Orenchi in Sunnyvale.  Service, due to the small space and crowds, can feel a bit rushed and they initially forgot our drink orders.  No biggie and quickly fixed.    Monta is a nice addition to the ramen scene but with minimally topped bowls and solid broths, ramen aficionados will likely have tried more polished ramen parlors in SoCal and NorCal.    Monta doesn't accept credit cards and is cash only.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen

QwQi8vVOUevrUsaj3gdeFQ.text: I love me some ramen!  Put this on the favorite, and must eat at spots while in Vegas.  The place is small, so don't come in a group larger than 4.  Upon coming in, put your name on the clipboard and expect to wait, but well worth it!  Santouka (LA), Ippudo (NYC), Umaido (ATL) are my other favorites, and each one is different and good in their own way.  Be sure to add extra pork, egg, and butter!  Gyoza was delish as well!

W3M4HEpef00r91dz9aiJxQ.text: Tiny place. It is very cheap and nice ramen. But it is over creamy for the first ramen on the list. It is located in a plaza in Chinatown

UkLFpReSpLgXK7XIXvfZ3A.text: Ordered spicy ramen to go because of how busy the restaurant was. There were about 10 in front of us around 7:30pm. $6.95 for bowl plus $1 for spices. Took about 15 min to prepare for us. At first bite, I really liked the ramen, meat texture, and broth. However, after about 4 bites, the broth tasted a bit too salty and I'd had to stop and eat again.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Eating ramen in the back of my car, because the wait time is so long. Take out is only 15 minutes.

o4Dp2tDHOA7jMA9lcvFhRQ.text: Solid ramen shop. Broth was flavorful and the noodles were nice and chewy. The line is pretty long and the parking is terrible but it's worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

cj9RiqUrkM4d-m-7B_erVw.text: So this may be one of the better ramen places i've had in america (only have had in texas and vegas) but i've been to japan and had around 20 different bowls there. SInce japan, if i see ramen ill get it, only to relive that trip.  Monta, i probably the closest to authentic ramen that i've had outside of japan. Their broth is rich and has the body that a good tonkotsu broth is suppose to. The chashu is very tender and soft, but still holds its shape and doesnt fall apart. Monta just has everything spot on.  This is a definite visit when i visit Las Vegas again 5 stars!

7KD0Cvn5F0sjnWG3sI9oIg.text: And I still....LOVE Monta!   Cold noodles on a 110 degree day...perfect! I love their cold noodles! It is filled with yummy things like cucumbers, eggs, bamboo shoots, bean sprouts "mushroom/fungi" and of course the fatty pork. Since I tried it a couple of weeks ago, I haven't strayed from the cold to the hot. The mustard is a bit spicy for my taste so I always have them leave it off.  I've only tried the sesame sauce thus far, but I am pretty content with it. For the price you pay, you definitely get your money's worth. I've always had to take half of it home to eat it for later which works out for me since I love leftovers!   I also ordered the small pork belly bowl.... that sauce with rice is heaven! I love Monta and I love how efficient and fast the food comes out. If you are coming for lunch, it's packed at 11:30 when they first open, so come later if you can.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small pork belly bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold noodles with sesame sauce

easMbaC3FPLfGyLpio0IIQ.text: Got here a little before opening and already a line had formed (at least 15 people deep).  Pretty cramped inside, with about 6-7 tables and counter seating for 10.  Food took a while to come out, and a big reason why was there was only one person cooking the noodles, prepping the bowls, and plating/garnishing (with one person taking care of the rice items).  The waitstaff would just stand and wait for the food to be ready.  It could have been more efficient (and thus quicker), but maybe they were limited by the size of the kitchen.  Oh well...  The ramen itself was just okay, with average-tasting broth and average noodles.  I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with the wavy noodles, and some pork belly bowls and fried rice for the kids.  Not bad overall, and service was good, but I prefer Fukumimi Ramen to this place.  But mad props to that multi-tasking cook, he sure was fun to watch!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Noodles getting ready to swim in some broth!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen - switched out thin noodles for thick, wavy noodles

qQJUQDs7xCUZkt91VrbkJA.text: When a full meal isn't what you're craving, why not grab a bowl of ramen noodle soup! This ain't your college cup o noodle.

0w8VHacBayG2kecCYFSASg.text: A wonderfully delicious place to have a hot steaming bowl of ramen!!  I usually order the miso or tonkatsu ramen.... until I decided to order the "cold" ramen noodles on an extremely hot & sunny day.  The cold noodles have been the only disappointment I've experienced at Monta. Even my sister, who lived in Japan for 3 years, said the cold noodles were different from what she's had before.  However, she did say Monta was just like the traditional noodle houses in Japan!  I agree with some reviewers.... at times, the broth has been on the saltier side. But that hasn't stopped me from returning on a regular basis.  Monta is an excellent place to have a bowl of ramen and if you're really hungry, get a small side of the pork belly bowl, too. You won't be disappointed! Although a very small restaurant, the service has always been good and the dishes come out very quickly.

7PRsd5iEVtwTmMwiaqNwKg.text: Monta, according to one of my friends who lived in Japan, is as close to authentic Japanese ramen as you can get in Las Vegas. I'll take his word for it.  The small ramen joint does not fit many and there is often a wait. Your entire group has to be there in order to be seated as well. There is a $10 minimum for card.  The waitresses are obviously experienced and seemlessly work together and with the chefs to efficiently serve customers. They are friendly, but not overly so. Food comes quickly as well because their menu is pretty small.  My usual order is a miso ramen with corn. The main reason I get corn is because the broth is a little too salty. Many people complain about this but I never really felt the extent of Monta's salty broth until the past year or so. It just seems thicker and more unhealthy than it used to be. I'm not sure if their recipes changed or if my tastes changed.  You get nori, chashu, and bamboo. Condiments you can add include garlic puree, pickled ginger, sesame oil, soy sauce, sesame seeds, and chili powder. One thing that used to bother me when I first started coming here was that they only have green tea iced and in a can.   They also have a few other dishes besides the various ramen, including rice bowls, friend rice, cold noodles, and gyoza. For recent additions to the menu, they have the option to make your noodles spicy (+$1) or the kuro ramen, which is black garlic ramen. It's actually pretty tasty in my opinion, but I am an avid eater of garlic.  Regardless of the heavy mouthfeel of the ramen, the consistent service and food keeps regulars like me coming back.

7XiPaR4jdKHwkszNrV40IA.text: Delicious and flavorful ramen. It's very fast and cheap as well. I try and avoid rush hour times because their dining room is TINY! I do go twice a month at least and whenever I do try different places closer to my house they always come up short!

LDpDcokNpuEjO5-HZUPM4w.text: The ramen here is amazing. I like the tonkatsu shoyu which is porka and chicken broth mixed. The wait times can be outrageous at standard dinner times but do on weekday lunches and you'll be good. Definitely worth the wait

iERLFFV-jWu5IUMNWuYcpg.text: This ramen noodles house is legit! Not only their soups are great but their price is very reasonable. We will come back to this place!

zUzxigBoQ-kpEVKRmfEPgg.text: Terrible customer service!! We were waiting to be seated and the waitress began to seat the party after us on the waitlist. When my mom asked her why she was doing that, the waitress responded with a horrible attitude. She put the blame on us for questioning her! We left the restaurant right away because her reaction was so ridiculous.

VfFFNGHWLB1YCgGjnTf-Ug.text: I absolutely love this place, but nowadays to go is the way to, well, go. This being chinatown, lines are long and this place fills up FAST! However, I've never had to wait more than 10 minutes for food, and it's perfect for lazy/under the weather days (like today) when you want good food and a good nap right after ;) - *I'm sure the people who work here appreciate it even better if you knew your entire order and came in ready to place it*

arBRUqhvfIaXMWlKctczJQ.text: The ramen is off the hook. It is a very small location but even with a line they move you through quickly!  Be prepared to order and your food comes out quickly.

Ex3gomKjhuN5bbeGrqpI_A.text: Best Ramen Ever. I love.the taste of the ramen and the meat. I Love Monta Ramen! I will come and eat it more often. The ramen is like the taste of paradise.

UvMVqL25xvCWnSaGT8_mew.text: After accidentally stumbling upon Tonkotsu ramen and subsequently researching what makes the soup authentic a few months back, I've been searching for a place that can truly deliver an amazing Tonkotsu. THIS PLACE NAILS IT. Rich, creamy, thick broth that has a great flavor. I am more than happy with this place and will be frequenting.

pDRtA1hn8aTjhAs_JZSTLQ.text: Great find here in vegas, the noodles were a little aldente however you can get the wavy thick ones that are really soft. The broth was really good strong and flavorful. I added spicy paste, it really didn't change the ramen much, besides that good service and the gyoza was really good.

kz8cY0vtaej1YFB8WVfJJg.text: Really savory ramen soup, all the positive reviews about this place are True. You can choose any of the soups and you will be receiving nothing but the best delicious flavor.   I went during the late evening hours and it was busy, u could get lucky n just wait 5 min to be seated but could be a rare case.   Overall great Ramen Soup in town!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Side of steam rice $1.00
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Creamy smooth pork broth!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Really good chicken and pork broth!

YUHTjXfeuXLruVVZqBABPw.text: My favorite place here in town when I'm in the mood for ramen. This is a small place (seats less than 40 people) and there is usually a wait time of at least 30-45 minutes whenever I try to come in. Thus, the reason for 4 stars instead of 5. I have had to drive out to Monta Chaya out in Henderson a couple times because their place is bigger and I don't have to wait as long.  I usually have their Shoyu Ramen with an extra serving of noodles. Their fried rice and gyozu is what I will sometimes order and both are excellent. The staff is friendly and courteous, but very busy. Their prices are pretty reasonable. If you like Chinatown and don't mind possibly waiting outside for 30-45 minutes, then you should check out this place.

3_SbLtkY2VsL7ZmCf_yQMA.text: I like this place, but have come less over time because of the crowds you have to fight through to get a table here. If you come on a weekend, expect to wait 30-45 min to get a table since they don't have very many. Enjoyed it a lot more the 1st few times I came here but have been less impressed lately. Seems like as it's gotten more crowded, the food quality and service has gone downhill.  I've had the ramen, fried rice, and pork belly bowl here and nearly any choice you get is pretty decent. Sometimes you may get a bowl of ramen that's a little saltier than others...I'm sure this is directly related to how busy they've gotten. Hopefully they will look into expanding or adding another location to alleviate the crowd issue here.

baJvEM3vygJRH0HFAJafJg.text: This is a tiny place that seats maybe 20 people and then another 8 or so at the counter bar area.  If you think you're going to be clever by getting there right when they open for lunch, you really need to get there right when they open, not 10 minutes after they open!  We arrived at 11:32am on a Saturday as a party of 5 and were the first guests and thought "Hey, that was easy! Maybe this place doesn't get that busy for Saturday lunch?"  Suddenly, over the next 5 minutes, several other parties of 2 or 3 people came in one right after another and the place was suddenly full!  If you arrived at 11:40am, you were then looking at a wait of 30-45 minutes until the initial parties were served, ate and left.  So go early!  The ramen was good.  I do wish they would give you more than 2 thin slices of roasted pork.  I don't know that I'd go again if the wait was over 15 minutes though.  (I actually really like the ramen at the Bacchanal Buffet at Caesar's where you can request all you want roasted pork (since it's a buffet!).  The slow cooked broth there is unexpectedly and surprisingly really good too.)

0Te8CBuMsJ9pNH5Pc0_pOw.text: This is now one of my favorite places to eat at when I'm in Vegas!  A great place to eat at if you like ramen or want to eat something other than pho while you're in Chinatown.    I came here for dinner after spending some time at the pool before getting ready for a long night ahead.  I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen and added corn and a hard boiled egg.  The broth was very flavorful, I couldn't stop eating.  I added chili oil to my bowl for a kick because I like it spicy.    Good meal to have when you need to recover from partying, even in the heat!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with extra chasu, corn, and hardboiled egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

N-pfVMilUwQLjKTd-jh7JQ.text: Be patient there will be a wait here.  This is a small restaurant with a bar seating area.  Nothing too fancy for just getting a good wholesome bowl of Ramen   See below my lunch meal after a crazy night in Vegas.  Everything is an additional w/cost.     Miso Ramen 7.25  Pork Broth w/thin noodles (you can choose between chicken or pork broth, thin or wide noodles)   Special toppings for your Ramen: Chasu Pork $2.50 Spicy $1.50 Shreeded Green Onion $1.50 Seasoned hard boiled egg $1.50 Takana Mustard Leaf  $1.50 Corn .50  Other:  Gyoza $5.50  So this place is off the strip, you would need to take a cab here.  It is located in the Chinatown area of Vegas.  We waited for about 45mins, got seated and went straight into ordering our meal.  The service was fast.  Ingredients on the ramen are placed on top, but before I mixed everything altogether I tried the broth and it was very good.   Adding the ingredients of the spicy sauce, Mustard Leaf and Chasu in Pork broth made the soup just way too salty for me to eat it.  I really wish the server would had informed me that this would have happened.  Otherwise, the Chasu was really tender and the thin noodles were not too overwhelming.  Everything in the bowl was well portioned. Then I had the gyoza, it just tasted like any frozen gyoza purchased at a super market.  Overall, I would come back here and not make the same mistake by ordering too many salty add ons in my ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken broth ramen

ugfnXn9RJ5WJKQ6i5YpkNw.text: There was a long wait, but turned out to be shorter than we expected (yes we got skipped). I asked a server (Maki-San) if we have to write our name again, but she squeezed us into the next spot.   Their ramen and fried rice was pretty good. None of my friends were picky about ramen, and seemed they were pretty much satisfied with the dishes.   I'm deducting a star because toppings were bit overpriced (my friend was fussing over the price of seaweed). However, as an overall experience, I prefer here over Sora.

ylolamelhJ42uuSKui59bQ.text: I love the ramen here. Just wished the place was a little bigger. I'm not sure why they give you the option of sitting at the bar or table when they sit you where they want? It was a little upsetting when I circled table and they had two tables open and still sat us at the bar. Customer service is mediocre. The waitresses could be a little friendlier in my opinion.

FMhqHUGgFoL0cKboklXaJw.text: Soup is a little bit salty. The noodle is really good. Very good for a fast lunch or dinner

-a0MYhz3KK5jEWLvqI2WZQ.text: Service was quick and friendly, definitely 5 star there. Food was ok. Ordered ramen and the broth was just ok, not sure where all the 5 star review for the food come from. There are better tasting ramen out there.

su3OEZDxx8qP_4vo14io-A.text: The food was good,however, there is normally a wait between 10-30 min to get a seat. I liked this place but sadly some of their business practices made me give them a 1 star. With that being said I was very disappointed to find out that they added a 20% tip on to my check and that I paid without knowing. I was not given the option to tip instead it was just given to me as a part of my bill. I found this out when I was going through my checking account. Very dishearting guys. The concept of a tip is optional it is NOT mandatory. Overall food was good but they have some shady business practice.

fiEOcqOeUM3c_zsGa9QTgw.text: We got there before it opens for a weekday lunch, and there was already a lineup for it.  The ramen was pretty yummy; however, I'd probably won't come back for the next while since it was quite a wait.

ex75Swf05BbkatHkQH_PKQ.text: Pretty good chahan. Gyoza is definitely not as pungent as most versions, but decent nonetheless.   Now, the reason we came here was for the ramen. My shoyu ramen was only a slight step above your run of the mill Sapporo Ichiban packaged ramen, with a less than spectacular chasshu. The tonkotsu was a bit more flavorful, but both broths were left unfinished by me and my friend.   I hope to try Sora Ramen (Sapporo style ramen) down the street from Monta, and another joint close by. We were drawn in by the good reviews, but left with our own less than glowing opinion of those reviews.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Where the magic happens...

qtAzkP6y2U8YqOH-ARlj7w.text: This place has over 1k reviews so I was pretty stoked to try it out.  I have to say it's OK.    We pretty much ordered each type of ramen they have here.  The broth is fairly tasty and the noodles are pretty good but it was SALTY.  I drank 3 glasses of water while eating my food.  I don't know if they make fresh noodles here but I know I've had better noodles.  However that soft cooked tea egg, PERFECTION.  That really made my ramen so much better.  If you come here be prepared to wait since it's a tiny restaurant.  Luckily it moves pretty quickly but I would not come here with more than a party of 2.  *For Vegas standards, maybe this is the best out in the area.

0ww6mB3eRRXo-ByVt6Fmhg.text: Wow. Just wow, in the worst way possible. Was it an OFF night or something for them the night that I decided to enjoy my first meal in Vegas when I landed? I've heard only amazing things about Monta Ramen from fellow online Yelpers. But lemme tell ya, I should have listened to my actual Yelp foodie friends from the Bay Area. They told me, "Monta ain't all that." Don't get me wrong, service was pretty good actually. Maybe too good...cuz my ramen came out within minutes of ordering. How is that even possible? Do they have it pre-made in the back and it's just microwaved or something? I had very high hopes for Monta, sadly...I will never return. Here are my reasons: 1. TOO SALTY. And even if you ask for less salty...you're still gonna feel bloated as shizz from the sodium. 2. Noodles are NO BUENO. They're like thin vermicelli noodles. I like my ramen noodles thick and with the right kinda chew! 3. My soft boiled egg got cold within minutes. Hmmmm :-| 4. Spicy means weaksauce-American-spicy to them. 5. Oh yes, and there's always a wait here too. Why, I have no clue... Do yourself a favor. Go across the street to Ramen Sora and have a real bowl of delicious ramen. You can tell I was quite excited to sit down and enjoy my meal when I first got to Monta...check out my YouTube vlog for that weekend: youtube.com/watch?v=DhN4...

oqE7E8KehRnMxqye0ID8lQ.text: This is my ULTIMATE go-to for Miso Ramen! Actually, it's my go-to for any ramen, I'm just head over heels for miso ramen. Whenever a new ramen spot pops up in town, you can count on me to be there to slurp and sample the goods. Nothing, I repeat, nothing... compares to the depth of flavor and texture of the ramen at Monta. Their pork chasu is succulent and flavorful. I consistently order miso ramen with extra pork chasu, corn and nori (seaweed). Along with my ramen is a regular sized order of pork chasu fried rice. I've had their gyoza as well and am always satisfied with the taste and crunch of the wonton. I've never felt like anything was overly dry or extremely fattening, while eating. I hate going to places where the pork chasu is dry. I absolutely can't stand it. This visit around, my brother placed an order for a small pork chasu bowl and rice. I've never tried that before and it was tasty. BUT I will definitely be sticking to my one True love, miso ramen! Mind you, here we are in the dead heat of summer (112-117 degree Fahrenheit) eating soup.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My miso ramen with extra pork chasu, corn and nori
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen for the bro
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork chasu and rice bowl (small)

VDpIrkYx7PxcMBqF7Hlw9A.text: I loved Monta, past tense. It was my go to Ramen place, and I didn't care how long the wait is because the broth was worth it. I always ordered Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen with Thick Wavy Noodle since 2012. I know how that broth tastes like with my eyes closed, and tonight I was disappointed. I ordered my usual that I've been eating for about 6 years now, and it tasted different.  I told the waitress about it, and she insisted that it was Tonkatsu Shoyu. I told her that it wasnt what I'm used to, and I guess the waitress, Brenda, was offended. She argued and was rude, she stopped by at our table several times insisting what I received was Tonkatsu Shoyu, and she argued I was wrong. Long story short, the second bowl I received also tasted different. So I guess they changed the way they make their Tonkatsu Shoyu or changed chef or something. It was not the Monta I was used to. The environment was hostile, waitress was rude, and what made the restaurant worth it did not taste good anymore. What a loss. I loved Monta.

FKfozVixe16EAn0RaobARg.text: Don't tell my mom but my reasons for coming home for Christmas are as follows: 1. Getting my fix of Monta Ramen's Kuro Ramen after a year of being away from Vegas. 2. I love my family very much and I'm willing to put up with the stressors that come with family gatherings to spend time with them 3. I have literally been craving Monta Ramen since I moved and there are NO good ramen shops in the Cincinnati area that offer anything close to the stuff Monta's menu offers, especially for their prices.  This place is easily my top fav ramen shop I've ever been to.

L-aHiH0MhGHcEEt7Z5UV5g.text: Food is excellent & that's the reason why I gave them 3 stars..  Pros: food (that's about it) it's ahhh-mayyy-zing! Cons: waiting in line, staff is mediocre. It's a hit or miss, kind of thing. And when it's a hit, it's like. Average.   Wanna do togo? Forget it! We called in 15 mins to 20 mins before we get there and every single time, we had to wait for our to go's as if we were eating in. We place a call in to go for a reason! ..to skip the wait and make it on time to go to work or other responsibilities. They seriously need to fix that.. the excuse that they don't want noodles being saggy, well that's why I called it in at a certain time.. genius!

7zAJbnKFghWaE6aGFfdT_Q.text: Wow, definitely the BEST ramen I've had!!!!!! Ramen was great, so were the pork rice and basically everything we ordered. If you like ramen this is the place to go, don't miss it! I would eat this all day if they open up a branch in Houston!!!!! So jealous of Vegas people :(

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best ramen in Vegas!

mW0w9F47mmR7JafPPp-IIg.text: This place does get crowded because it is kind of like a hole in the wall. The ramen is pretty good. Service once seated is really fast. My husband loves this place. I personally find it comparable to other ramen places we have been. Plan to wait 15 to 30 min for a table depending on how big your party is. Plan to wait outside bc there is not enough seating in the inside to wait. Parking Can be tough. Wish they would open a bigger place. You are crammed in like sardenes. Menu is pretty basic. Wish they would add more choices like some ramen places in San Diego. Overall, it is pretty good.

f46xgCPUHPHFuICtFSWtbA.text: This place was so good! Food came out quick and was so fresh! The fried rice was on point

xTOMVN1Hus6LS5R4891V7Q.text: I absolutely adore this place. I'd tried a ramen place before this and wasn't at all impressed. I thought I wasn't a ramen person so I didn't try again. I got a new job and my boss took us out to eat to celebrate and we landed at Monta Ramen. OMGOODNESS. I LOVE IT. I've tried other ramen places since and though I've found good ramen I haven't found any that compare to Monta Ramen. The broth is super flavorful, almost creamy. The pork is delicious and tender. The price is super affordable. The place is small and you'll almost always have to wait at least 20-30 minutes but it's well worth it. The service has always been exemplary. When I crave ramen this is my go to.

S5HAcGh353k9Rk1c3x6D_Q.text: Wow. Just wow. One of my friends recommended this place. I was in the mood for something Asian/Spicy/Noodles since I'm a little under the weather.  When I walked in, I was shocked at how many people were crammed into this tiny tiny place. I opted to order takeout, so I would get it sooner, and I could use my waiting time to go next door for some milk tea(review for them will be next). They quoted me a 20 minute wait time, which was fine with me.   I went next door, for boba, waited for my milk tea, and hung out outside for maybe two minutes, and he comes outside looking for me, looking worried that I had forgotten about my food or something.   I get home, and am eating my Spicy Tonkatsu while writing this, and it is DELICIOUS. BY FAR BEST RAMEN EXPERIENCE I'VE HAD EVER!!!!   Hopefully it'll help me feel better.

9PsDe_RWOFQxnnB5lhQlIg.text: One of the best places to find ramen in this city. A small, subtlety-dimmed, intimate "ramen house," among the fast-paced hustle and bustle taking place within. This place was truly a joy. One can still have a quiet convo among the laughter and cling-clang of pots and pans and just...pure magic.  There's a small, simple menu with items that grace its pages. Food that will blow your mind! The food is mind-numbingly fantastic. The noodles in all the ramen dishes are perfectly cooked along some of the most divine broths I've ever tasted.  They have $1.00 a la carte menu items as well. The presentation of these divine bowls of heaven are wonderful and the tastiest out there! I must recommend a splash of their black garlic oil in your bowl of noodles. Kimchi is fantastic as well. Will definitely be visiting again...and again and again.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with black garlic oil. Extra bowl of noodles to the left. Devoured plate of kimchi in the right.

HV1CFcxzPGLLypdDjt8Jdw.text: Delicious ramen but there was quite a wait time. If you are hungover and starving, you won't be happy. I was hungry but not too bad because there is a boba place nearby. I tide myself over with a boba drink. We waited like 30-40 mins. Miso broth was not salty. Get the spicy sauce, its spicy. Kimchi was really good too.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. spicy miso ramen

JHD8iX87wvVPBGgBCuNofA.text: Hands down this is the best ramen place in vegas! Ramen sora would probably be next in line, but if you don't mind waiting for Monta, It is well worth it. I wish they had this in San Francisco. I would go here every time I am in vegas if I had a car. The soup was great and the noodles were nicely textured and tasted great. The pork belly melts in your mouth. What else can you ask for?!

An8k5Y9DMpjh19Y2q7OF-w.text: Tried the ramen here and it was amazing.  There isn't much seating room but I found a spot quickly.  Service was great.

Q_A6MiIcl-Sxofzy-EPY8A.text: Monta Ramen is a popular spot located in Chinatown. Their place isn't big at all, and this place can probably only seat around 25 people. I had to wait around 15 minutes for enough people to leave to seat four at the bar. If you have a party of more than four, you will definitely have to wait longer since there's only two tables that can seat that much.  First of all, I have to say I'm astonished by their prices. I'm typically used to $12+ bowls of ramen, and these were all around $7! I ordered the tonkotsu ramen, which has a creamy, pork broth. The other two popular bowls are the tonkotsu/shoyu and the spicy tonkotsu ramen. All bowls come with the basic green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage. Toppings are available for pretty cheap as well. I added an egg for $1.50.   Being seated at the bar let us watch what happened. The kitchen works super fast, and we all had our bowls within seven minutes. We ordered a gyoza appetizer, but it came out five minutes after our speedy ramen. For the price, the portion size was large and kept me full. The noodles were perfectly cooked and on the chewier side, which I liked. The noodles make up the majority of the bowl, but the toppings are a little lacking. The egg I ordered was cold. I would've liked it better if basic toppings included more vegetables. The broth was the perfect consistency, but it was too salty for me to enjoy. My mom and brother ordered extra noodles for $1.50, and they came out in two minutes. The extra noodles is literally the same amount as what you get in the beginning. It's a huge amount of food for such a small price!   The gyoza was a little overcooked and the bottom was slightly burnt. The filling lacked flavor and I wouldn't recommend it.  Definitely would recommend coming here for the ramen bowls! Their price is unbeatable.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with egg

b7bxqIYBIVcM2Wff6eqDjA.text: GET YOUR NAME ON THE LIST and get out!!  Expect to wait to eat here, but it's worth it.  Yeah we can sit and complain how the store needs to seat more people, but won't change the fact you'll be right back to wait in line again.   Vegas was raining so we were craving some ramen :) The service is quick and they are consistent!! Ate here 4 years ago & it was just as good. The prices are definitely fair and they don't skimp on serving sizes. Very straightforward menu, so if this is your first time, have a look while you're waiting.  Ordered the Tonkatsu. The pork belly is always tender and I love adding the red powder stuff (not entirely sure what it is, but it's great) thin noodles make it easier to devour quicker. The broth can be a bit on the greasier side, but that's just personal preference. Can't wait to try other menu items!!   ***$10 MINIMUM TO USE CARD

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. First page of menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Second page of menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu^^

GAYTb2-Q4b5f4KtBecTEvw.text: 5 stars!  Affordable AND excellent taste. The soup is rich and very flavorful.  The portions are smaller, but just order extra noodles for 1.50 and reuse the soup you never finish anyway.  I took mine home and had it for lunch the next day. Two very tasty meals for about 11 bucks after it is all said and done. Service is friendly, although they do get pretty busy.   I'm not super picky about attentive service, and not shy about just calling someone over or walking up to the register to get done what needs to get done. They do a great job here and I wouldn't have it any other way. Especially for the price.  The ramen price is a much better deal than their fried rice dishes.

ClCvSSCAZnqo61m2Oox0OA.text: We came here because of the yelp reviews and it lived up to the expectations. It's a very small, Japanese-style restaurant. There's about 10 bar seats and a handful of tables. Pro-tip: sit at the bar and watch the chef bust out a ton of bowls of ramen. I ordered Tonkatsu ramen with an egg and butter. It was so deliciously thick and creamy with a nice porky flavor. The pork itself was flavorful and delicious. We also got gyoza which was made to order and small plates of fried rice.

38C6g7zujczUdmsIf5sCaA.text: Delicious! Great place away from the strip, small hole in the wall, very tasty. We had the pot stickers as an appetizer and we each had a different ramen bowl. I got the spicy bowl with an added egg. Service was fast and punctual. Very pleased.

Oc71neNmXcflnvIAMpPx4w.text: You can never go wrong with a nice big bowl of Ramen. For months different friends have recommended this place to us. We finally made the time to stop in and see what all the talk was about. Like any ramen place, it's small and tight. Not recommended for big parties and families due to the space though (mainly those with babies and infants). We were seated right away which surprised us because everyone mentioned a wait. But since there was just two of us we didn't mind sitting at the bar. Right when we sat down people started pouring in. There was literally always a party waiting. The service was quick, like most ramen places. When our ramen came out we were so hungry I was surprised I took a photo. They have one size, which comes with a lot and of course you can add extra toppings for a fee. We loved their ramen. The noodles here were thinner than most ramen places but still so delicious. The 'spicy' wasn't so spicy.. but there's really only one ramen place we've been to where to spicy was actually spicy. I recommend ramen lovers to definitely try this place out. It did not disappoint.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen

g2NBj2-xHoZ07BdLHHvq1g.text: Oh I loved it... got the black garlic ramen . Very delicious will be coming back for sure

d71cYwFjz_0-geBY5TOgbw.text: Simplicity, flavorful and affordable rings into my mind while indulging in tasty ramen.  Presentation of ramen looks simple, but once you consume noodles, broth and toppings, all the flavors integrate and mesh nicely together.    My sister ordered Shoyu Ramen with corn since this is her favorite.  She said, "You have to try it!"  I'm one that can go without shoyu in my ramen.  One bite and I was very impressed with how well restaurant staff prepared and made this entree.  I fell in love with shoyu all over again.   I wanted to feast on an extraordinary entree and Kuro Ramen - Black Garlic Oil grabbed my attention.  This dish satisfied my palate 100%.  I'm amazed at how both dishes were light tasting and very delicious.   People will literally sign in and wait for their turn to dine here.  Customers will keep coming back for more.  That's what makes this place awesome!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen - Black Garlic Oil  &amp; Shoyu Ramen

8_kL9FDxXZhYCgChS2X12g.text: Monta Ramen is hands down the best ramen place in Vegas. I love everything about this place. The restaurant is small, but the food comes out so fast and everything is super delicious. The employees always try to make sure everything is fine with your food and are so nice. The only thing I would say I dislike about Monta is how packed it gets, but that just means that the food is good enough to wait for. Try getting there before 6-7pm-ish. Sometimes the wait can be 40 minutes-an hour if you come a couple minutes too late.

bvOep2XUry_Wv_1erFkQqA.text: Located in one of the many mini plazas, Monta is a very small place, fit for maybe 25 people max. Wait was about 15 minutes on Tuesday around 1pm. Make sure to put your name on the list. Service is nice, place is as clean as it could get. I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen without black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and green onions, (basically just leave me with soup, noodles, and 2 slabs of meat). I don't want to waste ingredients so don't give it to me, save it for the next person haha.  Ramen took about 10 minutes and it's a pretty big bowl. I really liked the broth. It was thick and full of flavor. The meat was marinated well with not a lot of fat. The noodles were cooked well. Definitely will come back here for ramen if I'm ever in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with no bamboo, green onions, and mushrooms LOL $6.95
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kitchenn
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu as of 12/13/16

liXrFE25j30Nbkew7jkICw.text: Coming from an area where a bowl of ramen can cost around $12, I was really surprised when I arrived here. My Vegas friend bought us here and told me I would enjoy it.   As soon as I opened the menu I saw ramen for around $7-8 I just couldn't believe my eyes.  On top of that the ramen actually had flavour and the meat was good! The fried rice was delicious as well.  Amazing place to go cure a hangover if you can find parking in the plaza.

o3g8fWAzBMaXJjeGkUbC9A.text: This ramen was.....good..... But not nearly as delicious as the ramen at fukumimi down the road.... I know this place has a lot of hype and I've been wanting to try their ramen for a long time. The people who work here were friendly and helpful. The gyoza were....not amazing. The ramen was tasty, but plain. The prices were average. Vegas has such amazing ramen options, and I don't think this is the best.

rg5J_Pp0HRjyxyWE1cxXAQ.text: Perfect food for this cold Vegas weather! Thank you to the staff at Monta. Beyond the amazing Tonkotsu and Pork Belly bowl the service was amazing. Kana and Yuri were so friendly! Thank you! It was popular this night but well worth the wait! If you're visiting Vegas, make this a necessary stop.

xSF9yVRvyNi4fN3-6EVnTg.text: Good ramen, the broth is rich, the black garlic oil added extra flavor to the ramen. Everything is good except the garlic puree on the table that didn't taste anything. Daikokuya in Los Angeles have the same garlic puree and it is so rich in garlic flavor. We also ordered fried rice, it is very tasty too.

rnA4pEBSyH4aqpJjXXmpWA.text: I love Monta Ramen, I have been coming here for couple of years now. I've tried most of the ramen, my favorite is the Tonkotsu but it's a heavy very flavorful ramen. If you like something lighter you should get the Tonkotsu-Shoyu, the black garlic is really good too. All of them are really good. The place is really small so most of the time there is a wait list, but it's not too long. The food comes out fast and they are able to do a quick turn around.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen

KCLTqiTjsUxRqZSPzQDaaA.text: I visited on a Wednesday 11:45am, seated immediately. Ordered quickly, food came out in 3 minutes, ate and left! I got the tonkatsu with black garlic oil on the side. The tonkatsu broth was flavorful, a little salty for my palate. Once I added the garlic oil, the flavor was on another level. Also had to get the egg and corn added! I saw other people getting sides of the rice bowls that seemed reasonable portion and delicious but I had so much noodle I barely finished. That's bang for your buck!  Found this place as recommended for somewhere to eat off the strip and I think it was worth the trek when there's no waiting involved.

rZPk2BBaNHCj0tYz89cVwg.text: There's many ramen places that try but none compare to this place! Finally found a place that has the creaminess and richness you've been wanting in a ramen. We're coming back for more!  Tonkatsu ramen- highly recommended! Very creamy! Very rich! Full of flavor!! Add chili oil and spices at the table for a spicier taste. Option available for more noodles.   Miso ramen- creamy too! Full of flavor too! Also delicious!   Gyoza- not recommended. Soggy. Didn't seem cooked all the way. Waitress said it'd take 10 mins to cook. Was probably thinking why would we order that.   Fried rice- typical but way better than fast food.   Customer service- nice people! Took orders immediately  Wait time- 30 mins for us on a Monday at 2 pm with 6 people. Had a group of 5 and 3 groups of 2 go before us but we were actually third on the list. Very difficult to get seating immediately anyways. Space has about 30 seats or so. Large groups not recommended. Couples are the easiest to get seats.

HLVq0GzgYiF2r3vAeQGDVA.text: Monta was my first love when Las Vegas had no ramen places open that compared to LA. They definitely serve a mean bowl of ramen but their broth is a little on the salty side.   I always order the tonkatsu shoyu because I feel like the mixture of the shoyu broth cuts the saltiness and richness of the tonkatsu alone. I always ask for the thicker noodle and add corn and egg for my perfect bowl. I've tried the miso but it's too salty for me.   Another must have is their pork belly bowl. Their chashu  and sauce is perfect on top of rice with some of that red ginger.   Make sure not to go at peak times cause there's always a line since seating is limited.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MMbxPX4D8hxbF22bgNTNpQ.text: Overrated, maybe I was expecting too much from the highest rated ramen shop in Vegas but my girlfriend and I left extremely disappointed. The pork bowl was more memorable than the ramen

mQbDgPN5VXZ-N1EE0yJyaA.text: If I live here, I would be so fat from eating tonkatsu ramen everyday.  Their tanaka fried rice was delicious!  The noodles was great, not over cooked.  The ingredients were great.  The service was courteous and prompt.  Their is usually a line, but well worth the wait.

1C59vIIWXKANkLPahu2b8A.text: Suffice to say Monta has become the next best thing to hit Vegas since fried rice, but WHY you may wonder did I only give it a 4 star? As you may all have read the rest of the 400+reviews & counting, everyone is raving about the food at Monta & the prices, and I definitely agree with all the positive reviews, I mean c'mon you have a Menu that would fit in one sheet of paper, how can you mess that one up? They have followed the In N Out Burger's mantra...KISSS (keep it simple st*p*d) Less is More, No Frills, No guess work, in fact I love everything on their menu so much it is so hard for me to pick just one item! The only disadvantage to the "If it ain't broke don't fix it" attitude is that it GETS BORING, and you might get Monta'd out (especially if you are eating there almost every week sometimes two) I guess some good things must come to an end, and as the Law of Gravity dictates, what comes up, must come down, even if it is THE BEST noodle & chiar su pork in town. With this popularity also comes one downfall....BE PREPARED TO WAIT FOR A TABLE! Especially during the peak hours of lunch & dinner. They open at 11 am and trust me there is a line already forming outside waiting for them to open. this is a sure way to tell that a place is sure to be good especially when it's packed, but what if you are really hungry already??? Hmmm bring some crackers with you. Keep in mind also that at Monta it is first come first serve, you can not make reservations, nor will they seat you if your whole party is not there yet (they FROWN upon this) Monta is suitable for parties of a maximum of 4 if your party is more than that you probably won't sit together or even eat at the same time. The waiting time is often discouraging, HUNGRY PEOPLE are ANGRY PEOPLE! It has happened on more than one occasion that we had to go somewhere else because we got discouraged by the slew of people waiting to be seated anplay how pressed for time we already are.
