So by now you probably figured out why it is missing that 1 more star, Me & Monta definitely have a Love-Hate relationship. Like in any other relationship, if you fall too quickly, you will fall out as quickly as you fell. So for now or until I crave you again, SAYUNARA Monta-san.

T9H3wtHRtSj9zaUbwaT3uQ.text: holy cow it's cold in Vegas! we can't believe it was snowing on the way up here but that's more reasons to come to Monta for a warm bowl of delicious Ramen.  Even though it's a small hole in the wall the wait wasn't more than 10 minutes.  We got the white broth with pork.  i like how there's mushroom and bamboo standard with every bowl.  Gyoza was pan fried to a crisp but was missing a dipping sauce? yah i guess soy sauce could do the trick.   I think the ramen and broth was really good but i still like the special pork in Mitsuwa (SD) much better.

Lh4x5MEaikkmm5JVkZQbPw.text: It was my 1st visit for authentic Japanese Ramen Noodles & it was so delicious. Special for the evening was tonkotsu mixed with the shoyu broth for $6.95. There was no need to add any additional extras to this as it was good just as it was (although I did add Mustard Greens based on a suggestion from a friend). The place is a small place holding @ max 25-30 people. There was a line waiting outside the door before we were done dining...that's a good sign of any restaurant. Will definitely try it again.

j--kuMae-79b20BAyIQXnQ.text: This place is tremendous.  Great ramen noodles and fried rice.  The best is the chase pork slices....oh my god, it melts in your mouth.  Absolutely awesome.  Away from the strip, in a tiny, almost deserted strip mall area.  I actually bumped into this place as i was headed to the Korean BBQ place next door, but once we arrived, my wife wanted to try ramen.  I'm glad she made that choice!  We've been back to Monta 3 times - and we don't live in Vegas - and still haven't gotten into the Korean BBQ place yet!

07tIlfbZ1lH8EjibTrwioA.text: The ramen in Japan is better, of course, but this is very close!!! Very good ramen. It's just WAYYY too small and I don't like how they charge extra for the egg and such. In Japan it came with it!

3JMERwGRaLg5lzT5AVyGiA.text: The family visited Monta tonight. It was "A-OK" experience.  Tonkatsu soup way too greasy, we are talking about 1/4 inch of floating fat on top.  I have an high tolerance of fat, but this is too much.

zQyeOQ3KuYlF3LS_j3izIQ.text: WE HEART YOU monta ramen!!!!' these noodles will change your life! Best new restaurant winner this year for shua!

MBetiL_i6-Bhb07ei-4ofQ.text: meh.  nothing too special about this ramen place.  it was good, just not that much different from all the other ramen spots in the valley.

qYnEhcoHcnHgbDw1GSd6RQ.text: We were looking forward to this place from reading the many high ratings, but we were a little disappointed.  Ramen and Fried rice were OK.  The portions were small, so we ordered extra noodles, which were still kinda small.  We've had better of course in Little Tokyo, & Los Angeles, so that is why it was just OK.  Service was excellent & the place was clean.  If you feel like Ramen in Vegas, this is the place to go, but don't expect high quality or low prices.

rHvsHMWwCgky4GOVlZzPFA.text: I've eaten in Japantown LA and Vancouver's best. Monta has the best Chashu pork by far and the tastiest and richest tonkatsu broth!!! I will come back again!

hMD8wjuRp_aphzFfOrlzWg.text: Fantastic food!  My favorite is the Ton Katsu Shoyu Ramen bowl.  You definitely need to be hungry to finish it as the bowl is huge.  The broth is a mix of the two styles of broth from Japan; a bit sour but with the miso taste in it.  Four stars as while I've no complaints on the food, and they also have a liquor liscence which is cool, the restaurant only seats about 24 so if you want to eat, be prepared to wait at least 30 minutes when the place is full (and it always is).  If you get there about 5 minutes before it opens you'll be able to get a seat; getting your bill is also a bit of a challenge but overall a great experience.  Lastly, the service has been dropping off as of late; for such a small place getting your bill shouldn't be so hard.

xHZa2djWWBKWpxkBLuBfkQ.text: I'm not huge on noodles and soup, and this place always seems to have a line out the door. It's so small here you're practically a sardine. The experience was really good and everyone is friendly I really liked the Ramen and will be coming back again to try all of the different options

zT98r09nfmOTep6BbAMYYA.text: It is NOT a vegetarian or pescetarian paradise, that's for sure.  This is all about pork. Anyway, it's a teeny tiny place located in Chinatown. We were lucky to only wait about 2 minutes. It was very crowded however there was one 2 seat table open.  I was suuuupppper psyched abut trying this place. I thought that there would be at least a shrimp item..maybe a fish?  Noooooooope. Not a one. Swing and a miss Vanessa. The miso soup is made withpork and chicken so that was out too. Oh well, my friend had been here before and really likes it, and I was staaaaarving, so I got the white rice and added corn, mustard greens and scallions.  Was ok.  I also got the cold noodle ramen with sesame. It was good however, this is not a place I will come back to. Honestly, there are no options and I would not want to get what I got again. The prices are ok, the staff was very nice. And my food was good, but not great for me to return.

rMhTqkGX1CRgC6GbV6hFtQ.text: Before my friends tricked me into going to Monta, I thought the only kind of ramen available were the packs for 19 cents, how naive. As I'm sure you've heard the place only seats about 20 people at a time and there is often times a wait, but it's very much worth it. Their menu is quite small but everything on there is a knock out. Feeling like you can't go wrong when you order is an awesome feeling. I personally order the Shoyu ramen with corn and fried rice, the first time i tired this I knew there was a heaven. It's so savory and authentic, if you ever go, take a spoonful of the fried rice dip it in the broth and I GUARANTEE your taste buds will be enraptured with a euphoric taste. The price is fairly cheap as well around $15 a person. The waitresses are very friendly as well and always take time to teach me some new Japanese every time I go. I definitely recommend this place for anyone looking for something different within a reasonable prince range.

iFYjueo_AmHZLfdsfEwdPg.text: It's small but they serve really quick and their noodle with soup is so awsome! Mostly crowded but you can have seats quickly.

QwJKYKNv5Pnw1-Es8949QA.text: One of the best ramen places in town. The wait is long at peak times but it's worth it. They use a pork-based broth, not dashi. If you hate dashi-based ramen, you'll like this place. It's a very hard-to-describe flavor. It's very flavorful and savory, and the noodles are perfect. The pork was also good to nibble on. I also tried the stir fried rice. Pretty decent but too many scallions for my liking. I liked it better than Hana Ichimonme in Los Angeles but I admit that could be also due to it being 5 months since I ate there.

yG0QK81d_pl-Lk2I5uEHsg.text: Small place and long wait.  salty ramen, we tried each of the three broths. Nothing spectacular but my first ramen place in Vegas. Have had much better in Bay Area, LA & Chicago.

07euxts4yUhLXK8oHWQiZA.text: I was boasting to my CSN students about a must try Raku, they said try Monta next door... and I say thank you very kindly! Prior to ordering while looking at the other tables fragrant dishes/bowls of fare, I'm thinking no way, to much food for me. BUT the deliciously flavored giant bowl Ramen & large dish of pork fried rice seemed to evaporate in to thin air. Lucky for me the portions weren't twice as big, or my next review would be on a Jenny Craig location or two.

Zpc0B98sWlhz7vLW8B2A7g.text: First sign a ramen shop is good is a long line and Monta won't dissapoint in wait and excellent ramen.  Ramen starts at the broth and the Shoyu based soup had excellent soy flavor without the overwhelming saltiness common in the more mediocre varieties.  The noodle is firm and doesn't get soggy absorbing the soup base.  Gyoza are prepared well, some crispy spots but still soft and moist.  The only bad thing is now my favorite ramen shop is 300 miles from my southern california home.

NB7vfm2-CKlegilcxTUq7Q.text: Never get tired of this place always good atmosphere ramen is always delicious fried rice or pork belly is a must dish to get to share with everyone small size is good to share

ehLdcUlXWOiC8ORLoozjew.text: I live on the complete opposite side of Vegas from this place. But I will ALWAYS choose this over any other Japanese noodle house. Monta is fantastic and I've NEVER had a bad experience here.   The food is delicious and it is most certainly the BEST ramen place in town.   Yes the restaurant is small, but it's definitely worth the wait.

BiJyOWmJjXBAo_nd4tYfug.text: My mom found out about this place through high ratings and praising reviews. But we were all honestly pretty disappointed with the hype.   The parking lot has decent amount of space for people to go in and out ok with possible short waits for spots. Coming in, this place is very tight and small. There's not much room for even 5 people to wait before getting seated. And seating itself barely has much room either. Just enough for people to get around ok.   The ramen (my family members and I all tried each ramen they offered) was all pretty salty and felt quite heavy. The fried rice dishes were good but not anything that stands out. Overall, everything seemed quite average or not to our personal liking.   The service here was alright as well. They seem busy so that may be why they could come off rude and rushed. They're not the most helpful either.   We're glad we gave it a try. It wasn't bad but we probably won't be thinking to come here.

kUFjRD9F5IVhpiJe4W9S-Q.text: We were driving around late night 10:49 pm and called, the nice guy said the last call was 10:55 and he was so sweet !!!! Everyone in there was. They accommodated to us and made sure we felt comfortable. The food was so yummy. I'm a big foodie but I don't really like noodles and stuff but this one was so amazing. The gyozas, the fried rice, the noodles ... so good for late night and such good price. Def recommend and would come back!!!!

lK2vCGkubcGTXqxXjLmybA.text: It took me several tries and having to turn around because the wait was too long, but I finally got in. I went in at about 11:35 A.M. - 5 minutes after they open - and the place was almost completely full. I got a seat at one of the stools, so got the heat in my face but a good view of the action happening in the kitchen. And, yes, the hostesses are Japanes  I ordered the Black Garlic 'Tonkotsu' (pork broth), with extra 'Chashu' (roast pork) and 'Nitamago' (half-boiled egg). (I also ordered a 'kaedama' (extra serving) after I finished the first bowl of noodles.) The wait was about 15 minutes, which is understandable considering the number of people already here when I arrived.  The broth was just the way I like it: not overly salty, thick, and not overpowering; the flavor was just right. The cuts of meat were about average and not very thick. Although it tasted good, it didn't really wow me.  I should've ordered gyoza or a small fried rice to see how they do with other dishes before just handing them a score. For now, definitely 4 stars at the very least, but I'm guessing could easily be 5 stars if their other plates are good.

m1G1AsLYAhsdLMuidYUHNA.text: Every time I visit Las Vegas, I find my way to swing by to grab a bowl of the best ramen. I've had ramen from numerous restaurants throughout the US and I really enjoy Monta. It's a small, crowded place in the Chinatown area of Las Vegas. It's always packed whenever I stop by, but you get seated fast. The food comes out immediately, so that's how there able to seat you so quickly. The food is delicious, great flavor. I typically stick to the Spicy Tonkotsu, but everything on the menu is good. Each bowl is priced well. Definitely a go to spot if you're craving some ramen.

PwQLJEJpMqONA2PFc-iHjw.text: This is probably the best ramen house in the US! The soup is so thick, flavorful & creamy - bursting with umami!  Came at 11.20am on a weekday and we were 3rd in line. If you come at 11.30, be prepared to wait.  We had the tonkotsu ramen (pork broth), tonkotsu shoyu ramen (pork chicken broth) & kuro tonkotsu ramen (black garlic oil pork ramen).  I like the noodles - they are on the thin side.  Just so comparable to the ones in Japan, you'll almost think you're in Japan!  TLDR; 10/10!

neZ7P_ZB56ENeF3E56MKZA.text: We were hungry for ramen, something that we can't get in Dayton.  As a result, we decided to check out Monta Ramen for lunch on Sunday.  Located in a small strip mall along Spring Mountain, Monta Ramen had zero curb appeal and would be easy to overlook had it not been for the line of people waiting outside.  The restaurant's dining area was small, cramped, and much like its exterior, no frills.  Basically, it actually did remind me somewhat of the noodle shops I experienced when I lived in Japan.  I had the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen ($6.95) with Chashu pork (+$2.50), and Nitamago, a seasoned hard-boiled egg (+$1.50).  I liked that the ramen broth possessed the expected umami notes and was perfectly seasoned and didn't overwhelm my taste buds with saltiness as some ramen broths will do.  I was very happy with my choice.  Apparently, many people felt that same as I did as the dining room was filled by the sounds of people slurping up noodles and people lined out the door on the list waiting to grab our table when we left.  Monta Ramen was just what the doctor ordered, solid ramen at a reasonable (to me) price.  I easily understand why it's a local favorite.  I'd gladly come back for more.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen with Chashu and Nitamago

X2n9LdGSdSIBk_T6x8UxkA.text: This place is WONDERFUL! First of all, it's open LATE on Friday and Saturday. So if you're flying into Vegas after work on a Friday, you will have a place to eat. Next, it is SOOOO AFFORDABLE! These days ramen is expensive and not affordable. Yes I understand making the broth and the other ingredients are costly. However, Monta manages to keep the bowls to under $10, that is a STEAL!   The tonkotsu broth is full of flavor and has depth. I personally prefer the wavy noodles so I sub out the thin for the wavy. Order an egg, and share with your partner. It is all enough to be full!   Oh yea parking at this lot is difficult.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I love this place. Basic Tonkotsu Ramen, but def not basic tasting!

c4PwZb6oykA3ZQbO1LjcsA.text: Very hidden little noodle house! It's tiny but they do a good job getting people in & out! Very easy to read menu. Everything is inexpensive. The fried rice is so good! The ramen dishes are great but the piece of pork that comes floating in your bowl you might want to avoid. It's purely fat and doesn't go down easily!!! Ew. I loved everything else!

ikmBzMb8FKiteTemtmansg.text: hella props to this place for being small and having staff that manage it well. They were so efficient and fair to the guests. I watched one particular waiter named Bryan just go from table to table, cleaning up, setting up, and calling the next party on the list. The other staff were very kind and did the most to satisfy your needs. Though the wait time was ridiculous i have mad respect for the staff here.   The food was also really good. I had the black garlic one but i actually kind of wished I got the tonkotsu because i tried my mum's and it was so good. The pork was so tender, it just melts in your mouth.   The venue was small but id say quite clean. I felt very comfortable there.  Sadly i'm only here on vacation but i loved coming here after eating burgers for the past 4 days.

e6Ac2wpPhy139eIbDyx9CA.text: The gyoza are alwase need for my gf and i. We usualy get the tonkotsu shou and i can never get ralen again without an egg :D

unHOMzyjjh-87hNdYd0Wkw.text: Best Ramen in Las Vegas!!!!!  If I go Vegas I go there, and u can hav kung fu tea after ramen

4wq2X6V8weaPye_KWIjD_Q.text: This is the best ramen I've ever had in my life!  The service was polite and efficient. My parents had never had ramen and the staff helped explain everything to them. My husband  loved the kuro ramen which we can't find where we live. If I ever move to Las Vegas this place will be one of the reasons!

5nEkMAejTPVr9r1TUHmpmg.text: It seems like the ramen joints in Vegas have all been well received and are quite popular. With over 2000 reviews on Yelp, I figured this place had to be pretty good.   Monta is located in a very busy plaza with limited parking spots - and since the storefront is pretty small itself, you can expect to either be cramped in the waiting area or standing outside waiting for a table. I came when the weather was still very cold, so a bunch of people were inside trying to avoid the frigid air. Even on a weekday night, the wait was around 45 minutes long. It seems like eating in parties of 2 or 4 are most convenient and larger parties will have to wait until everybody is here until they can be seated. There's a small bar section and several small tables that can be combined.  Menu is simple. They advertise which ramen bowls are their most popular; however, they have tonkotsu, shoyu, miso, and a black garlic oil ramen. Prices are actually on the very affordable side, with bowls costing around $7-8; however, there are very limited ingredients in the pre-set bowl. You can add additional toppings if you wish.   I was really curious about their kuro ramen with black garlic oil ($7.95). I added a flavored egg for $1.50 more but I was a little disappointed to see that the yolk was not as soft and yolky as I wanted it to be. But the bamboo shoots and pork chashu were on-point. I thought the broth was very flavorful and rich. Could actually taste the oil after several sips. I liked that the thin noodles were still kind of chewy, making each bite pleasant to eat. I would recommend this if you're not sure what to order and want to try something different.   Tonkotsu ramen ($6.95) did have a creamy and rich flavored broth. This was probably my favorite broth because of it was lighter than the black garlic oil. It was simple, but packed a punch in every bite. Thin noodles were also a part of this ramen.   Shoyu ramen ($6.95) was the least favorite among the three bowls. I don't think chicken broth is any good with ramen, and it reflected in this bowl. Very bland and lacked flavor; however, this bowl did have medium thick wavy noodles, which I liked.   We also ordered a regular pork belly bowl on the side to share. Very reminiscent of Yoshinoya's beef bowl, except this is made with pork belly. The pork belly was tasty and the sauce that the pork was cooked in seeped into the rice, giving it extra flavor. I can see why people recommended this appetizer. I would order this again if I could. Even eating the leftovers the next day, it was still tasty.   tl;dr - If you're a fan of ramen and like checking out new ramen joints, I suggest giving Monta a try. I don't think it was anything spectacular, but I can see why people like this place a lot. The bowls of ramen (besides the shoyu) were pretty solid. But because the area is so small and cramped, come early or be prepared for a wait.

XxIJFcOBWMAL_xOjQVmGeg.text: We came here just well about midnight after a show-  the place was full but we had a short wait and was seated almost right away at the counter bar.   Spicy Tonkatsu with a flavor egg ($9.45) - The broth was super milky and flavorful. It wasn't super fatty as you would think. The ramen noodles were cooked well and the chashu was super tender!  A little disappointed an egg isn't already included in the bowl and that it was extra.   Tonkatsu Shoyu with a flavor egg ($8.45) - my boyfriend ordered this and I only had a taste of the broth and I found it to be pretty good too. Its his favorite and it didn't seem too salty.   Small chashu bowl ($3.95) - it's a small order but honestly the bowl itself is a good size. The chashu is the same thing you get in the ramen bowl. Super tender and soft.   Overall - Great ramen. We cleaned our bowl ramen, soup and all! I've read people have had long waits. Glad I came here at the time i did. It definitely fixed my ramen craving and it's not too far away from the strip. Would definitely come back here!

o9Kpd1_Mfz0o67CRKGv1dw.text: Came looking for sushi, but my place was closed. Wandering around I found this little place. Friendly and fast. Pretty small menu but tasted homemade and good. Wasn't incredible but really good and comforting. I would stop by again if in the neighborhood and craving noodles.

IGKWiRrcJiyxj34Odfi8mg.text: Best Ramen I've had in Vegas yet! I got the black garlic oil  ramen added egg onion butter!!! Sooo good! Needed a bit of spice but I added some chili oil and it was perfect! Sooo flavorful! I also got Gyoza and kimchi fried rice. The gyoza... the fried rice was good Definitely an acquired taste. Next time I would probably just do the Ramen with some extra noodles and edamame. The place is a very very very small place. The earlier you can go the better or you will be waiting. I'm probably just going to get it to go next time because it's definitely worth it. I highly recommend it if you got the time to wait.

rlo6yDbj5_H6vyHXqw6Ajw.text: Oh. My. God. Just let me eat here breakfast, lunch and dinner every day of the week. Please.   I am a ramen fiend and Monta is easily my restaurant of choice. It's affordable, it's ridiculously delicious, and the pork slices are so ridiculously tender. Oh, the pork belly rice is also to die for.   Yes, there's almost always a wait but totally worth it.

TUwiKDedKnflkp3z7CS_YA.text: This place has some really good ramen. Make sure you go well before you're hungry because this place is almost always packed and it normally takes us a half hour to an hour to be seated. Totally worth the wait though!

There a plenty of options, and the ingredients were all delicious and well prepared.  Definitely give this place a try if you are in the mood for great ramen.

m6aYlbkfOVtyrpFex_MUfQ.text: I would give this place 5 stars if they got some decent air conditioning. The ramen was amazing but this place is so small there was a line out the door with one source of A/C. Don't come in the afternoon, especially with a large party,

p3JjQjUMcKIlozAo4t4SIg.text: Small ramen joint, so come early to avoid the long line!! I'm usually not a fan of ramen, but  enjoy eating it. IgCUTNjHtKLezPlHAU6sAQ.text: Great little ramen shop - cheap - convenient - small.  It's about 10 minutes from strip. I had the spicy tonkatsu ramen. The broth was slightly thick and creamy with just the right amount of heat. Service was fast and efficient.  I also had the potstickers which were OK. Stick with the ramen and you won't go wrong.

ry3-MqyCwl6LfNC0mKpTuQ.text: Incredible ramen and fried rice, plus good service! I went here last year on Halloween night with my boyfriend on our first date and I can't wait to do it all over again!

qoGHbcXqhDX1PrsH-8p59g.text: THE BEST RAMEN I'VE EVER HAD.  Portion sizes make sense also, you eat a small bowl of the best quality Ramen, and you go home without the usual, "OMG I'm going to hurl" feeling you get from most ramen places.

j8JpM7hPUVeIbQOQuL9LUg.text: Some of the best ramen I've ever had. Although the seating is very limited, it's worth the wait.

2hLRLHOUoJqIKESl6qSg2w.text: BIG DROP-OFF since the last time I dined here, which was probably a year ago when I came here with some friends and let me say that My friends and I  liked this place so much that we literally came here 3 days straight!!! I raved about this place so much to my girlfriend back home in Austin, so the expectations from us were pretty high coming in on a Monday evening around 7 o'clock. The wait time was about 20 min., so it wasn't too bad and the restaurant was pretty full. So I ordered 3 of my fav dishes I had last time to share with my girlfriend. We had miso ramen w/ ajitama (seasoned egg) and corn, Kim chi fried rice, and cold noodles with sesame sauce...so  Miso ramen- broth was a lil salty and luke  warm, cold corn (which prob made the broth luke warm), the noodles were stuck together in a ball shape, so that was obvious it wasn't boiled long enough.   Kim chi Fried rice- was very wet and was obvious drenched with a lot of oil  Cold noodles- were a bit sour and visibly covered with way too much sesame sauce.  I really don't understand the big drop off in the quality of taste and food and it saddens me to just give Monta 1 star ( star for good service) which seems harsh, but when you get food poisoning that causes your stomach to ache and many trips to the restrooms. How could you consider to go back...

Ssc0Ad9rfJ_WDzclzmU2hg.text: The food is amazing but the service isn't that great. I always love the food here, it's the best in Vegas. Their one in Henderson is better, but the service here depends on who's working. But other than that the food is great. Haven't had time to try the new soup yet, but I will pretty soon.

Xz5fzSizMncZmCICAQ34fQ.text: Craving ramen and deciding to be break-away from our normal habits, my boyfriend and I decided to try Monta, hearing so many good things about the place. We went on a Tuesday night and their small space was packed to the brim. We put our name on the waiting list and were seated in about 15-20 minutes of coming in.  I decided to get the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen. The food came out decently fast, even with how busy they were, so thats a plus. The food was absolutely delicious and I have nothing bad to say about it! But it kind of tasted like every other ramen I've had before so it wasn't anything special.  Overall, this place is a great place to go when you're craving a good bowl of ramen but don't go on a busy night. The space is insanely small so you most likely wouldn't get seated for over an hour. The ramen is good but it isn't worth the wait.

XbdUrEY_o2NBEp2UR6rL6w.text: This place is very busy on a weekday, so I waited for my lunch about 25 minutes. It's a very small place so if you want to have a sit you have to get there early. Tonkotsu ramen was pretty good bat a little salty. Actually not the best I've ever had. However it does have great flavors. But Pork belly rice bowl was really good. The service is quick enough. Though I am not a fan of Japanese food, I like this place...

5OKtAD6Gg0tDvfctKd3i4A.text: Food was good however there was too much salt on everything.   This place only has pork so if you don't like pork than you wont like this place.   They dont allow outside drinks, so if you happen to buy a boba drink next door while you're waiting for your table make sure you finish before going in. They made a huge fuss about it not sure why.   Food is ok.

AKhZ8MOFmDFuQ2PtWHRt4Q.text: Favorite ramen place in town. I got tonkotsu with nitamago. Broth and noodle were great. Exceptional food for its price! Also to-goed their fried rice. Fried rice was tasty as well.

hYCl16BCp3KJ8K56Z1qfxg.text: This was my second time here.  The first time, my cousin brought me here cuz it was his favorite place.  I trust him because he's eaten ramen in its motherland and he's just a picky mofo altogether.  Both times I partook of the kuro ramen.  It's rich, flavorful, and just perfection.  This place was crowded both times (and the strip mall parking is usually full).  But you go in, sign your name on the clipboard and wait for the goodness.  It's a small place that churns and burns.  I love that they have cold oolong tea in a can.  Once you order, food comes out fast.  If you're in Vegas and you happen to love ramen, get off the strip, and eat here.

-TbXjoBDJHqwHtkYgh7XWQ.text: Favorite Ramen spot! Quality food at a reallu good price and although the space is very small, the atmostphete is just perfect for a late night eat that hits the spot.

qjrp8SWzCBcj99s4_UxlrQ.text: For the price, it was pretty delicious. I also added a few more things on the side. Got the spicy miso and it was not bad. They use thinner ramen noodles here compared to the other ramen spots I've been to. Definitely NOT saying it's bad, it's different and I like it.

pB6fgM_BnFfZMcgHWHQ7FA.text: I always come in here with my boyfriend and have never been disappointed. Takes 10mins max to get the food in front of you. Its a small store so there's a wait sometimes but its never more than 10mins

v6feq7e56DfbwfjJm9GC2w.text: A Vegas trip without visiting Monta Ramen is not Vegas trip . Food consisting and very tasty.

ycf3xnRuB7iHXjngn89oJA.text: Literally love this place so much!! Im from San Diego so any ramen bowl is at least $10 but here every bowl started out at $7!! So affordable and worth every penny! Delicious creamy broth! It was pretty packed here the day we went but the servers were very fast and efficient. The ramen came out within 5 minutes of ordering.

iU09q1XF1JQxFa8It9BJBQ.text: Being from Bay Area and having so many good ramen joints to try really makes it hard to find "good" ones elsewhere. Monta has been on my "to-try" list for a very long time. But every time I try to go it's packed to the gills. Luckily this time I was out for an early dinner and was lucky to be seated within 15 minutes. This place is small, max cap at about 40.   Ordered the miso ramen, requested spicy which is just a chili paste added in that you mix into the soup yourself. The ramen was good. A little chewy, a little al dente. The broth was good. The chili paste gave it more flavor. Great food, just not worth any wait longer than 30 min.

6iOL-4wBp7PBvHGrrmcj1g.text: Once just a hole in the wall ramen spot, this place is consistently busy with a line out the door.  My go to is the tonkatsu shoyu ramen and an order of gyoza.  The shoyu ramen is also a great one to try the first time.  The pork belly melts like butter compared to other ramen places.  Pricing is very reasonable but be prepared to wait unless you go right before opening and in the middle afternoon.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu shoyu ramen

5nbgp-lKneoyTrwPRqSwNA.text: This is the first time that I'll thank a monsoon (Thank You!). If it wasn't for that freak storm that swept through the Chinatown area, my boyfriend and I probably wouldn't have found seating at Monta Ramen. Only those who are really serious about ramen will brave flooded intersections for a hot bowl of noodles -- that, or your Plan A for dinner fell through.   I almost didn't want to come here because of the issue I have with the lack of seating at this place, but we took the chance and dropped in anyway. We figured not many people would hit up Monta because the weather was lookin' ominous. Two open spots were free when we arrived at 7pm on a Friday night, but the tiny restaurant was almost filled to maximum occupancy. By the way, if you see seats available, don't forget to put your name down on the sign-in sheet by the doorway; it's still first come, first served.   I stuck with what I ordered on my last visit which was the Tonkotsu Ramen with nori and nitamago. I was pleased to learn that the ramen was still solid like the last time I had it several months ago. The broth was hearty and the pork was tender. I also shared an order of the Mini Pork Belly Bowl.  As much as I enjoyed my ramen, I almost want to say that the pork belly was my favorite part of dinner. It was flavorful and delicious, and I prefer it over the Mini Mentaiko Bowl that I ordered last time.  Unlike other ramen restaurants I've been to, Monta has about four ramen selections to choose from; however, you won't pay over $8.00 for a bowl. Overall, the food here is affordable. Two bowls of ramen and the pork belly came out to a little over $23.00 (without tip.)  Bumped up my rating for Monta from a 4 to a 5, all thanks to that Pork Belly Bowl and how the quality of the food has remained consistent.

nIEGM30I98JDeAS66kP2jA.text: First time eating "fancy" ramen as opposed to the top ramen I'm used to at home lol. When I went it was very busy so we had to put our name down and waited about 20 minutes or so.   We got seated at the bar and my friend recommended the tonkatsu ramen with nori and egg. The messed up on our order and thought we said corn instead of nori but it wasn't a big deal. The waitress brought our our nori in a separate bowl and only charged us for the corn which was 25 cents cheaper than the nori :)   The ramen was so good! Not too salty and not to watery, just perfect. Also when you eat the pork it literally melts in your mouth. Staff was great also. I will definitely be coming back here!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen

uw1N3uwYdv9Ntgw0QUt39Q.text: I did not like Montas ramen at all.   The service was great and attentive but the ramen was not doing it for me.   I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with medium waves noodles. The broth was fatty feeling which I love but with no flavor to match it, except salt. The noodles were cooked al dente except I didn't like the type of noodles they used.  The bowl is also very small. I finished the bowl and wanted more noodles but the calories weren't worth it if I didn't enjoy it.   Also, they need better AC. It was gross watching the guy make my ramen with a face full of sweat dripping.

lJ7_1MCuvwYkJT7krGcRxQ.text: This place was awesome good food fast service couldn't have asked for anything better

Ru0a55dRFC7ROdhNvC8bww.text: We had a 15-20 min wait and that's because like 5 names left.Anyways best ramen in Vegas hands down our bill was $40 plus dollars ordered kimchi's fried rice gyoza and a shout tonkatsu ramen with egg and nori which i added black garlic oil real bomb and then my bf ordered the black garlic ramen forgot the name but anyways it was a great lunch thanks

Ve0FSj-j2a87Bf_0Ccpweg.text: I was really excited to try this place when my wife said she heard about a new ramen joint that serves Hakata tonkotsu ramen.  The restaurant is minimalist with very little seating and is located next door to Raku. We generally don't sweat the decor, or lack thereof, as long as the food is good.  They offer shoyu, miso, and tonkotsu ramen and several other items on their menu. We ordered the tonkotsu, of course, which was $7 for a small-medium sized bowl. They used the thin white classic tonkotsu ramen noodles which were decent but lacked the elasticity or chewy "freshness factor" of other places we've tried. As my wife will attest to, I like my food salty and flavorful, but their broth was a bit too salty, even for me. It had an earthy shiitake mushroom flavor but was lacking in the porky flavor and richness of a good tonkotsu broth. Neither of us cared to slurp up any of the broth once we were done with the noodles. I found the two pieces of chashu were mediocre at best. They were somewhat tough and fatty and had this unusual ring of gelatin around the edges.  This place is arguably the best ramen place in Vegas that we have found so far. Unfortunately that also isn't saying very much. A mere year ago, both of us would probably have been more than satisfied with Monta. Damn you Ichiran for making ramen snobs out of us and forever raising our ramen bar! The search continues for better ramen in Vegas...

7HWXrdtX4Bec_arS-GHmbA.text: I was here during the Thanksgiving Holiday and it was great.  The Ramen had great flavor.  The noodles were cooked perfectly and the pork melted in my mouth.  Show up early as this place gets packed.  Definitely worth the wait!

-prDwB4vlWyXzt6eTyXovw.text: I love this place!! Have been going here for the past few years and love their staff and menu.  Yes it's very small and cramped but the food is so good that like many of the regulars who come here a few times a week I will be waiting even in 110 degree weather because the food is that good!! It's also really comforting to go someplace where the staff knows you and appreciates that you come back time and time again when there are so many other places to eat in LV. The food is made to order and I have never been disappointed!!

z70y5bhhPSxjigcLNDhejQ.text: Really good and authentic starting at the price of $6.95. You can add more ingredients to your ramen. I always get the tonkatsu ramen. I love their iced green tea. Their gyozas really good. The restaurant is cozy and and small. Their staff is really nice and attentive. An excellent hole in the wall gem.

Jd_loChpP6Ojqag6-KtRGQ.text: I've been to Raku a bunch of times, and a friend of mine mentioned that the noodle shop next door was worth a trip in its own right...  Boy, was he right!  This tiny little noodle shop (I think they might only seat like 25) has a counter and like 4 small tables.  The menu is limited to 3 types of noodle soup, a couple of entrees and some sides.    I ordered the miso noodle soup with an egg...  Perfectly done noodles in a rich, perfectly seasoned broth, served with a few slices of pork and some vegetables mixed in...  and the egg... AMAZING.  They have somehow figured out how to boil an egg so that the white is fully cooked, yet the center is slightly thinkened yet runny, and served it on top of my noodle soup, cut in half like a hard boiled egg.  Fascinating and delicious.  This place is definitely making it into my lunch rotation.  SOOO GOOD.

z0Z0_PQXG6nzIV3PWTKDhQ.text: Best Ramen in Vegas?  Only True Ramen House in Vegas?  Yes and Yes... Monta's Simple.  Hot.  Tasty.  Highly recommend to anyone in Vegas or visiting Vegas and wants to try something off the strip.    The mister and eldest son had the Miso and I had the Tonkatsu Shoyu (less salty than the Miso).  I had mine plain while extra chashu was added to one of the Miso's.  All of them were SO GOOD. The younger son had a small pork belly rice bowl but we had to spoon away all the vegetables that decorated it (green onions, pickled ginger shreds...).  He liked it.  I only gave 4 stars because I'm not much of a Ramen eater because of all the MSG.  And Unfortunately, I did end up with a migraine :(.  It's a super small joint and soda's are served in a can... I don't think they have hot drinks... yet.

Cy4XIV2kE6Ksk9ZuQZE_yw.text: If you're ever craving for ramen, this is the best ramen place in town! Awesome workers too!!

j6yRAb8cWaLb0dRqsJ85fg.text: I read about this restaurant on Yelp and was very excited to find a good ramen place.   As all the other Yelpers mentioned, it is VERY warm in the restaurant so be prepared! The whole restaurant only fits about 26 people but we were lucky we were the only customers.  I went with my boyfriend and I ordered the tonkatsu ramen w/ egg and he had the miso w/ corn, egg & extra chashu. Even in the heat I definitely enjoyed the ramen. The broth was very savory and delicious. The chashu was very soft and also very flavorful. I would definitely order the extra chashu next time we go there. I've never had corn in my ramen before (except for the american cuponoodles) but it added a nice crunch to the dish and sweetness.  The service was good but just be careful with your bill there. This was the first time we went there and they rang up 3 cokes instead of 2. After the transaction was completed she had corrected it by giving us cash back for the misrung item. After leaving the restaurant and being a day later, we came to realized the server charged his debit card TWICE for the meal as well. So not only did they rang up extra items on our tab but they charged the transaction TWICE.  Keep in mind that we were the only people in the restaurant as well so it wasn't like it was very busy.   Overall I was happy with the meal, just will keep in mind to pay cash and triple check the tab from now on.

vIJbm2lIknVEKpQgcvUgDA.text: Tried their Tonkotsu Ramen Noodles w/ shredded green onions, Kim Chee, and Calpico soft drink.  "OK USA!" - Bloodsport. aka Not bad.

WDBrnIt2bjQ5YbXKJbLG0A.text: I haven't had great ramen in Vegas since I was stationed in Japan and in finally found one.  "Oishi"

X74_DIIuJYxmQLtq0VFXew.text: Finally! A very good Ramen joint in Vegas. This place is much more the real Japanese ramen joint than the (now defunct) Togoshi Ramen.  Monta is in a small strip mall on Sprint Mountain Rd, just West of Decatur. It is very easy to miss as you go by. And the shop is very small, with only four 4 place table, 1 2 place table, and about 10 counter seats. They only accept cash so beware.  I recently learned of this place right here on yelp and had to give it a try. Like others on this forum, I grew up eating fantastic ramen all over Japan. And have long been searching... I was elated when Santouka came to the states and even more ecstatic when local joints like Orenchi (Cupertino, CA) that are very much like the ramen I used to know in Japan... started to pop up.  I'd like to preface this review with the fact that I like tonkotsu, thick chijirimen (wavy noodles) usually, so I am usually biased towards that. Monta has 4 basic types of ramen flavors: Tonkotsu, Shoyu, Miso, and new (at least it said new today) Tonkotsu Shoyu which is a combination of the Tonkotsu and Shoyu broths.  Tonkotsu, of course, is pork based broth. The Shoyu uses chicken broth (according to Monta), but I also detected some dashi (fish based) in there as well. Tonkotsu, and Tonkotsu Shoyu uses thin straight noodles. Shoyu and Miso uses the thick wavy noodles. Each ramen @  $6.95 comes with 2 slices of char shu, kikurage (woodear mushrooms), memma (seasoned bamboo shoots), and chopped green onions. There are other toppings available as mentioned in other reviews, along with kaedama (literally means "replacement ball") extra noodles.  Kaedama is usually ordered as you go, not in the beginning. This is because if get it at the same time as your ramen, then the noodles either go cold, or get overcooked. This is one of the reasons why I do not like places that have a "Large" size. By the time you're half way through, the noodles are too overcooked. I commend Monta for doing the kaedama the right way.  Anyway, I was @ Monta today, Thu, at 2 pm, and the place had a waiting list 8 deep! It took us abobut 20 minutes to get seated, and as we got seated, the wait line even got longer. OK... my expectations are way high... but be cautious... this, after all, is the only ramen only joint in Vegas....  I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu with nitamago and extra char shu. My wife had the Shoyu with nitamago. We also had gyoza. In the kitchen, there are basically 2 guys preparing the dishes. One guy that does the ramen, another that does the fried rice and others. And with the packed house, the service was slow.  But when the ramen finally came, I was not disappointed. Despite my doubts, the Tonkotsu Shoyu had a wonderful balance and marriage of pork and chicken broth. My wife's Shoyu, I believe due to the chicken stock, had a very mellow aspect to it which also gave the Tonkotsu a very mellow and non-overpowering flavor. I finished the broth to the last drop, including my wife's Shoyu/Chicken broth.  The noodles... My thin noodles were not overcooked, and about just right when my ramen came out. But because of its thinness, by the time I got half way through my ramen (and I'm a relatively quick ramen eater, beating my wife by a good 10 minutes :-)) was way overcooked and mushy soft. Next time, I will see if they will cook it less (katame, or as I do at Kyushu Jyangara in Tokyo, bari-kata... crispy as in ironed with starch). My wife's chijirimen was very good with good amount of al dente,a and the chewiness one expects in good ramen.  If I can't get them to cook the thin noodles to super al dente, then my backup plan is to have them use the thick noodles in the Tonkotsu ramen.  The boiled egg is soft boiled, but the yolk does not run. I like my soft boiled egg a with a bit more runny yolk. But nevertheless it was still good. The Char shu was one the the better ones I had in the states. very tender, melts in your mouth, with good flavor... not too over powering, not too bland. The slices were on the thin side, but I got a total of 8 slices by ordering the extra char shu topping ($2.50).   In summary both the Tonkotsu Shoyu and Shoyu ramens were done very well, with a good balance of broth, noodles, and toppings in a dish that came together very very well. Too many times, I have been to ramen places in the states where the broth may be good, but noodles lack, or vice versa, or even where all the individual ingredients are good, but the finished product just doesn't cut it.  The gyoza, unlike one reviewer here, I though were also very good. I would beg to differ that this is not like store bought gyoza as it is stuffed with pork whereas the store bought ones are more heavy on the nappa cabbage and not stuffed. The flavor is also very good, however, I like my gyoza wet...that is with a bit more juice as you bite into them.  In the end though, I give Monta 5 stars even with the few deficiencies. Monta, in my book, share the top honors with Orenchi in Cupertino,

nrjW4w7nqfUmdj5CSbjlHQ.text: Food: 4 stars Service: 3.5 stars Value: 4 stars  Our friend suggested this little ramen place because it has pretty good reviews on Yelp. The ramen with two thin slices of pork,and the broth were very tasty. The portion was decent and the price was very affordable. I was happy about this place and it definitely made it into my "must go in Vegas" list.

WPjs1mUEZJx65qBJqZvs-Q.text: Will NEVER come here again after waiting 40 mins in the freezing cold the manager or owner says he will not seat us only a party of 3 come on...no customer service why would you have us sign our name way before closing and wait 40 mins if your not going to seat us...been here once but will never come back came from LA to eat ramen and got turned away never again, if I could only give zero stars...my advice don't wait not worth it!!

KUex-ibh85CCdvYxI7jN3w.text: This is the best noodle house in las vegas! It's a small venue but the service and food is awesome!    They only have 4 different types of noodles but believe me you will be satisfied with selecting anyone of them.  If your still hungry, save your soup because they can add more noodles for you and make sure to always add the extra chashu pork.  It's soooooo goooooddd!

lpl6ct3fdOCalH2nXjYWUA.text: The Skinny: pretty good Hakata styled ramen (2.75), efficient service (3), value - really good... only $6.95 for a good ramen pick-me-up (4).  Tried this place because my hubby needed a big bowl of warm Japanese love after working all day and because of the Yelp reviews. We were super excited to see that this place specializes in Hakata-style pork broth ramen.  Hmmm... well... so far, it's one of the best bowl of ramen we've had in Vegas (but that doesn't necessarily say much). There is certainly a good amount of porky flavour in the broth... but not enough to make it really stand up  on its own (ie, make me want to drink the whole bowl and wonder if I can ask for more).  Also, there is a hint of the distinctive earthy shitake mushroom which does take away from the flavour of the pork.  The noodles are classic tonkotsu ramen noodles but they lacked the nice chew of others we've tried. The chashu was okay - a little on the fatty side, mildly tough but great flavour.  Overall, it's not bad, it's closer than LA (which has some really great ramen establishments), and pretty good value for your money.

CVMVX9o5tXy2a7fEFrXAOA.text: Absolutely the best ramen I have ever had! I ordered the Shoyu ramen and every bite was delicious. I will definitely be coming here every time I am in Vegas! Priced very reasonably. The noodles were perfect and just absolutely mouth watering! New favorite Ramen place!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen. A definite must try!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ate every bit of our meal!!!!! Too delicious.

aKKKAbjB4Zb53ZMmAqIq1Q.text: Monta Ramen is a very small restaurant.  It was busy and our wait was about 30 mins.  Hubby had the tonkotsu (pork bone) ramen with green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage and added nori. I shared with our daughter the tonkotsu-shoyu (pork bone & special shoyu base) ramen with green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage and added nori and a hard boiled egg.  We also had fried rice with pork, kimchi and extra chashu pork.  Our food was served fast, and the ramen and broth were tasty and the fried rice was delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu-shoyu ramen &amp; sides.

KjuYjeoyGzmyAd8_ZEBi2w.text: I love this place. It's small so there's is usually a wait but everyone goes in and out.  It's very affordable and all the items in the small menu are delicious.  Their fried rice is so tasty and gyozas are awesome. The ramen is creamy, tasteful, and their hot sauce is amazing.  My only suggestion is I wish they had other kinds of ramen like chicken or seafood. I do get tired of pork sometimes!

8tzqIPcoTjq2J8mn-Zse5w.text: This place was good enough that we came 2 nights in a row!  We were in Vegas for a friend's wedding and was scouting around for something Asian that didn't cost an arm and leg. While I was browsing reviews for another place (Fukumimi), the common thing locals were saying were that Monta was better, so why not! The plus side is they are open past 10PM, which baffles me that buffets on the strip close at 10PM.  I love the simplicity of the menu options. Was so glad that bean sprouts aren't even included in the ramen (except for their cold dish) because let's be real, bean sprouts are used for fillers most of the time.  The broth was awesome and probably the best tonkotsu I've had to date. It could get rich after awhile, so come hungry!  I also ordered mine with their nitamago (hard boiled eggs), and these were the good ones that have been soaking in broth goodness, not just sliced and added on top, so it was melty goodness.  This place is definitely going on my top ramen places and will be visited again next time I'm in Vegas.

jcbEiAZ7652oyRg_ub6LUQ.text: This is another go to lunch spot for us. Spring Mtn restaurants are close to his work so we frequent them every so often. This is one of our faves!!  They open at 1130AM. But don't wait to come then get there before! There is always a line by 1115-1120 when I usually am nonchalantly rushing to the line in fear I'll miss my window of opportunity to enjoy my oh so fabulous bowl of noodles. It is small and fills up fast and they don't seat you unless your whole party is there which sends me into another panic until The boyfriend shows up and I can breathe again. Also they only seat singles at the bar heads up, no table for you, no room for your laptop, this is not a working lunch spot. In and out. Once you're done you'll feel the eyes stating at you till you leave with your head down feeling like you might have taken just a little too long to enjoy your grub.   The service is always spot on and fast. Sometimes they ask if its ok sometimes not, I don't care though its always good! Sometimes being the first customers the wait for the food is sometimes sluggish with all the orders going in at once but I understand and gives us time to chat and admire the others. I always get my Ramen with corn and butter hold the shrooms. Yea I know they're not poisonous but these shrooms are just weird to me. The Boyfriend gets the Pork Belly Bowl and always shares generously, we'd have a fight on our hands if he didn't. This thing is to die for! Yummy baconey porky deliciousness! You won't regret it!

TLIZy7-aLIcab6WPbgjqhw.text: Came to Vegas for vacation and my friend kept telling me that I must try this place out.  I am from out of town so I cant really tell you where this place is at since I took a taxi but it seems like the Chinatown of Vegas.  It seems to be sorta hidden in the back of the shopping center but just look for the white sign.  Got here around 12pm and there was a slight wait (nothing compared the wait when we were leaving).  Sat down and the friendly waitress took my order: Shoyu Ramen with corn and also the small fried rice (my friend said i had to get it no matter what) and yes I know thats a lot of carbs.  Shoyu Ramen:  my ramen came out with extra chasu and with no corn.  the waitress quickly realized this and immediatly gave me some corn on the side and didnt charge me for the extra chasu (kudos to her to rectify the situation).  The broth was very good and not overly salty.  I consider this one of the better ramens that I have eaten.  But the thing that stood out the most to me are the noodles.  Wow! This has got to be one of the best noodles ive eaten at any ramen joint and I have been to many in NY, CA and Hawaii.  Many places forsake the noodles and focus too much on the broth and chasu but very very good noodles.  Fried Rice: this was the dish my friend kept raving about and keep telling me to order.  I am not a huge fried rice person but it was pretty darn good! I devoured it within minutes of it coming out and didnt even leave a spec for my friend.  Very good place I will definitely come again when I go to Vegas.

dsi62wBIsV8AedEMfbegBQ.text: Wow, this is the best ramen I have had in Vegas.  Keep in mind the place is super tiny, maybe seats 20 at most...and A/C doesn't really work so it is like sitting in a UPS truck(not that I've ever been in one but...u get the idea)  We were seated almost right away even though there were ppl waiting in front of us(perhaps they are in large groups).  The lady who seated us was really nice, later on there was another waitress who brought our ramen to us, cute and also nice(I think it is probably the owner and her daughter as they look alike), of course the 5 stars isn't based on the looks but honestly it does help a little(even without it, the ramen itself still deserves 5 stars).  We tried the #1 tonkotsu ramen with thin noodles, it was very rich in flavor, but our favorite was the Kuro ramen(the tonkotsu broth with black garlic oil), it was superb! and the chashu was not only buttery but also taste like it was grilled first!  There is also a shave ice place in same plaza which is also very good, and a foot massage place(make sure you yelp for the one with 4 stars, not the one with 1 star... :P)  I hope they open one in LA soon!

ttOwTgZZ8vxpivjSEsz6ag.text: YUM YUM YUM...YUMMY Alert!!!  Me and my fiance finally checked this place out and have eaten there two more times. When you finally find it in this strip mall the whole in the wall is a treasure. You can tell you are there because there is always people waiting out side and cars all around the one door.  This place is SMALL and HOT! There is a little wrap around bar that holds about 6-8 people and then maybe 5 tables. It is warm in there but no one seems to care. Everyone just eats there hot ramen noodles in the hot restaurant.  The ramen is so yummy! Get the egg added to your soup. That is the only add on I would recommend. I have had two of the broths and they are so rich and yummy.  You really cannot go wrong.   This place is NOODLEISH!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

KMh1QHRI4qmIuVPE3Mo-dg.text: Felt a mood for some ramen so I looked around on Yelp and saw that this was on the top of the list so I took a bus from the strip. Pretty small place. It was busy so it must be some legit ramen. I was greeted by a Japanese server and was seated at the bar. I noticed that the entire kitchen staff was not even close to being Japanese.  I dunno....I was getting skeptical about this place. I'd rather of had a non Japanese working front of house and seeing an actual Japanese preparing the food. Nothing against it but it just adds to the authenticity in my opinion.  Ordered the miso ramen and tried to take a pic but wouldn't you know it, the hot vegas sun had overheated my phone and I couldn't take any. Eh looks like ramen. Good broth. Good noodles. Good price Fast service. Eh, maybe Hisjapanic ramen isn't too bad. I'll return when I come back to Vegas.

j6hcxKNaEkAmvv9BwyQ6rQ.text: I was looking for some good eats in Vegas and Dru C recommended this place. THANK YOU DRU C!!!!!!!!  This was some amazingly delicious ramen!!! We had a short wait (party of 2), and I got to sit next to this sweet lady who eats there several times a week at the counter. If I remember correctly, I think they have purse hooks under the counter. =)  We got the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen with thick wavy noodles and Kumo Ramen. The pork just melts in your mouth!!! I LOVED the thick wavy noodles. They had a really great texture. The Kumo Ramen was just some garlicy goodness. YUMMMMM!!!  What a great first meal in Vegas =)

oxsJj7JqIQu45iM7ZH-Wpw.text: warning: this is not the place to go for a long meal, date, or to socialize. it is small, loud, and every part of the experience is very fast-paced. however, if you're looking for a quick and easy dining experience with incredible food, this is a must go!  service: extremely fast and efficient staff.  drink: although it tasted normal, i was put off by their hot green tea coming in a can. like what even?  appetizer: the pork belly bowl was delicious! not too salty which i really appreciated. try not to fill up on appetizers though, their ramen bowls are massive!  ramen: i ordered the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen with egg, nori, and corn, and it was amazing! this is only the second time i have ever had ramen and my expectations were blown away. simply delicious.

WFodoFR7jyJY-H8z-WzEPA.text: Everything used to be better. Now this place defines itself as more....adequately edible. The ramen was good. The gyoza was shit and the pork belly was shameful today. I felt our server seemed a little put out to take care of my party of three. I can understand why. This place is always packed and there are no signs of slowing down. But I believe this business lost that feeling of appreciation for every guest that walks through the door. If I'm just a number then I will take the number 7.6. Because that is the exact number of miles it is to Ramen Fukumimi.

8l-qho0h6QsviM7VWFQMbA.text: Went here on 9/24/11 with Lawrence T. for dinner. I'm always down to grab Asian food, and I've been to Pho Kim Long a bunch so I wanted to try something new. Raku was closed, and I know Monta has a following so we headed here.   To be honest, the second I was handed a menu, I wanted to leave. There are 3 main ramen choices and none sounded off the wall great. Lawrence said he was fine staying and he ordered tea. It was canned. I thought that was a little bizarre.   I ordered the Shoyu Ramen and a side of kimchi and he had the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen. When it came out it smelled like... pancakes! It was the weirdest thing. It smelled like a "bowl" of pancakes. The soup was actually pretty good, and I added a bunch of sesame oil and cayenne and garlic. It was good (even though I got cayenne pepper in my eye somehow.) Lawrence said he liked his soup too. The kimchi was the most bland I ever had and I wouldn't order it again. Regardless, the noodles were good.  If this place had more to choose from, I might come back, but as it stands, I'm still gonna make my way around the other restaurants in town.

XibgRxieYfxPs17UlogVTg.text: If you come here, I would recommend sticking with the tonkotsu ramen as that is what they're known for.   I ordered the spicy miso and was disappointed in how salty the broth was. Sad because my friend let me try some of her tonkotsu and it was so freakin' delicious. If I ever come back, I'm ordering my own bowl and not sharing!

muXqDyH-qYr-1wB3baSSYw.text: I give 2 stars for the food and one star for the service. Food is very average, not spicy... has no flavor. Service is way below average. I asked substitute fish for scullions in my salad. In the end I got no fish and no scullions. Also, I asked server to put a fork in my order to go. She said that she did that. When I opened my bad I found out I don't have any fork. Anyway I will not come back in this place.

C-1Tdl9Oxk6bvONsYisiZw.text: Amazing!  And I have to say some of the best pork I've ever had at a ramen restaurant.  It's unctuous and meltingly tender!  So hubby and I are sort of ramen fanatics and have had ramen all over the ramen hot spots in the US- Ippudo and Totto Ramen in NYC; Daikokuya, Tsujita, Ramen Jinya, Santouka, Hakata Ramen, Mottainai in LA.  And this place is probably the best ramen we've had, perhaps second to Totto ramen.  Their tonkotsu- shoyu ramen is awesome, I love the mix of the pork and chicken flavors.  They cook the noodles just right, and of course, the pork is to die for.  I also love how cheap the ramen is.    This place made me so happy after our 9 hour crazy traffic filled ride from LA!

VjUX6Gt1tztttc5_iJPGSA.text: Monta I'm disappointed. The one on Eastern isn't as bad as this. Your noodles were packaged tasting thick and hard, broth was not piping hot, condiments in a ramen bowl cold, and I could've fried my Gyoza better from my frozen packs I get at the Asian market. Shame on you. This is fest happens to most restaurants when they become popular they go down. Someone better will take your place even with your prime location.

mhDOcUtOmNWjEa5yG9T1Ww.text: Just went there today, long long line. Waited for 30 mins and had miso ramen. Not as good as I expected. Very salty.  Someone (Robert M) called me idiot coz my review or I just gave it two stars. Wonder, if he is related to this place.

v3k0A0ETxwrM8Lo2719gRw.text: I went to the one on Spring Mt & Decatur location and man.. that place is so small! So many people were lining up and I felt so clusterphobic! I still stayed and waited because I wanted to see why this place is so popular! Anyway, after 20 minutes of waiting, me and my party were finally sat. Customer service could be better. I understand its busy, but if you work there, that's just something you know you have to deal with especially if its a popular place. The food was good. Ramen.. delicious. Fried rice.. delicious as well!  Overall, it was a good experience!

-gFLsZCGarPMHWQlFsqhXg.text: Everything is great. Speedy and friendly staff.   Kimchi fried rice was a perfect appetizer. My spicy miso is one of the best I have ever have. I'm from CA, but whenever I am in Vegas I will for sure come back. If you want ramen come here!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Friends fun and good food!!

bdNz7YOBpGQ0xFu40j4hRg.text: They have a nice variety of broths. Their noodles are hand made but only one of them has any heat. None of the additions add any heat either. Their charsu is good but the amount is small. Sora trumps Monta!

fMm06I8Iv12Y9a8Qk8_l2w.text: Every time I hear MONTA, my mouth starts watering, my heart starts beating faster and I suddenly need to get that delicious miso broth in my mouth, a nitamago and some chasu pork. OH YEAH. Monta is simply delicious. Sadly it is very small and sometimes the wait time can be a little long and frustrating , specially when you are super hungry and that big o window lets u see people eating their awesome noodles  Now, let me say , that Ive tried ramen in various places and I keep coming back to monta. Their freshly made Gyoza and their pork belly bowl are amazing as well.  A must try if you are in vegas

t_m1a0KzG960Vh5wgHo9YQ.text: Tokatsu Ramen - It was ok for me, but my friend found the noodles inedible and way too soft. The soup was good but nothing special. Pork Belly Rice - So so. It was edible but again nothing special. I don't understand the high ratings for this place.. Yelp has let me down!

wlzOKc14ElL4XMQofkjUhg.text: My boyfriend is a big ramen lover and he said the tonkotsu ramen at Monta is the best he ever tried. I think the soap of the tonkotsu ramen is good and the chashu which comes with the ramen is VERY GOOD. Everytime we order the ramen, we will pay $2.5 for 4 more pieces of the chashu because it is just so good. For the chashu bowl, i think it's soso because the chashu is fried. Therefore it's not as good as those that are in the ramen. And i think the pork belly bowl is soso too, nothing special about it. For the fried rice, I think it tastes good and smells good. I had only tried the "fried rice". I didnt try the one with kimchi and veggie. And for the gyoza, I think it is okay. Nothing special about it too.  Overall, I would recommend you to try there ramen and fried rice. And for this price, it's really cheap and delicious !!! :D   And it's the best to go there at around 3pm so you do not have to wait for a long time. It's pretty crowded during noon and at night.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. gyoza (dumpling)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice (regular size)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. miso soup ramen with extra chashu

nMIXGy2Q-y6uzp5GUDn3GA.text: This is definitely not the ramen I had in college.  The place is small so if you come here late, I imagine the wait will be long.  I got here when they opened and there's already a small line.  I ordered the chicken and pork broth combo with thin noodles.  It is the best that I have eaten and will probably come back when I'm in town again.

Tsa3AxV40sqF_5pA7ePVrQ.text: Spicy ramen was pretty good. Noodles were on point. But the broth could have been more hot. Other than that, I give it a thumbs up! Will come back next time

slw0p6xTj6AI65ZH_QJNow.text: If I could rate each thing individually, I would.  Food flavor and quality-always was and will be 5 star. It's incredible and I crave it.   Wait time-average. 3.5 stars.  Quantity of food-5 star. You get tons of food. I usually get two meals out of one order that I take to go.  Parking-BLOWS. 1 star. Barely ever any room. You're better off parking on that side street.  Atmosphere/building- 2 stars. Cramped, tiny. They really need to expand and fast.  Service- 0 stars. I've only had to come in here once and I don't know if I'll be back based on this alone, no matter how damn good it is.  We walk in to a cramped/stuffed area full of people waiting- a patron is nice enough to tell me I have to "sign my name on the pedestal". I said "I just want it to go" and she didn't say anything, just kind of awkwardly looked at me. I didn't sign it. All those people got seated. After waiting about 10 more min of not being acknowledged, a waitress finally asked if I was waiting for a party of people, I said no, I just want to order to go. She came back 5 min later with a menu. I told her I already know what I wanted-she was already at a table next to me saying "yes, they were first". I'm aware, hence the reason they're at a table.   At that moment in time I was ready to explode "could someone just fvcking tell me what I'm supposed to do to order to go so I'm not standing here like an asssh*le??!?!?!" I was furious by the time I left. I couldn't be courteous anymore. If this is how noodle houses in Las Vegas go, they are all run sloppy and poorly organized, then white-girl-me can't deal with this, count me out. I sincerely hope other noodle-based places aren't like this, because now I really have motivation to try other ones.  Perhaps to avoid confusion, I should take an asian friend with me to break the barrier a little? I heard once that it's because Monta waitresses don't understand English well-this does not excuse the poor execution of guest-ferrying and certainly doesn't welcome new people to the establishment.

2FDo0qIoxe5fNgGb__c67Q.text: Tiny hole-in-the-wall joint in a strip mall featuring a variety of cheap, delicious Asian mom-and-pop eateries.  I'm not going to say anything that differs from what my other yelp colleagues have said; I will concur with the majority in that I found Monta Ramen's enormous bowls of steaming, savory goodness satisfying for the body and soul.  For less than $10 a bowl, anyone lucky enough and patient enough to snag a seat (no reservations; you sign your name on the queue list and temper your impatience) will be rewarded with yumminess that will live on for the rest of the night.

22zrtfPVRSzZga9578q0nw.text: Started off with the Gyoza and to me they were like a glorified pot sticker. Enjoyed some oolong tea, in a can, wish it was made in the building but i still liked it.  I had the Tonkotsu Ramen with Nitamago(Egg) and Chasu(Pork). It was was something I was not expecting, that's for sure. It has a very satisfying flavor that just made you "smile" after that first mouthfull . I added a little of the fresh garlic cuz i love me some garlic. I will definately be be back, looking forward to the colder months for that hit the spot meal

lr0BOGUPERQk4lMopMzPTw.text: A couple minutes off the strip. It's a small place, complete with bar seating to watch the chefs do their thang. Good broths and noodles, pork melts in your mouth! Cheap beer!

oRXi-hp8KrxYQx8etI60Vw.text: I love their ramen. It is to die for. Also, their beef belly fried rice taste like heaven. Get their tonkatsu ramen with the flavored egg topping. Trust me.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ZXwOg4xJWSw-ILepGQ9X6g.text: I started with the gyoza which were tasty and had a nicely crispy thin skins.  Next came the tonkatsu-shoyu ramen which I enhanced with extra pork and an egg.  The pork is awesome and I could eat lots more of it.    This place is small but has a cool vibe.  The only problem is the lack of space.  It was a bit uncomfortable to have people waiting and hovering so close.

gPQSqaqe8m_7ANOVrcuLrQ.text: Family of 9(everyone is practically adults) and they gave us a small table usually for 2 with a table regularly for 4. They told us to sit down and just by the first four sitting down we knew we couldn't fit ALL 9 of us in this setting and so there was a table of 4 empty so the parents sat there. The server said    something along the lines of "No." and so my parents decided to take this dilemma into their own hands and asked if they could just move the table of regularly 4 and the other 4 table together and just leave the table for 2 alone to the side for other guests and the server straight up said " NO WE DONT WANT TO." We had already been seated but the rest of us had to remain standing in the already crammed area trying to negotiate with the server. In the front there were multiple parties of 4 or more just watching this happen. We ended up just sitting down at both settings. What I'm trying to say is Monta staff on Spring Valley sucks.

hrsEHyKsS-jUO63kPPEZjA.text: My adult children pick this place to eat.  It was our best meal in Vegas. Great choice, Great service. Great food and Great prices

wuH9ivcWgF-3zyri47w09Q.text: You can tell food is good when people are willing to stand in line (which is often out the door) to wait through our blistering summers and biting winters.  Luckily, service and cook time are quick, so I have never had to wait more than fifteen minutes or so for a table or spot even when it's crowded.    Monta is a small, hole in the wall ramen place.  There are three kinds of seating: booth, table and bar stools.  If you're eating solo or you have a small party, you'll probably get seated more quickly because the individual bar stools will open up.  Additionally, so they can keep the flow going and keep wait times down, you'll have to sign in on a sheet, and they won't seat you until your entire party is present.  From the bar, you can see the crew in the kitchen cooking the meals.  On to the food.  I normally order the Tonkot-Shoyu (mixed broth of the Tonkotsu and Shoyu) with corn and nori (dried seaweed), and add in some chili oil and spices from the table set.  The soup itself comes with chashu pork, bamboo shoots, kikarage (black mushrooms) and green onion.  I've tried ramen at two other locations (one in the Galleria mall in Henderson, and the other was Anime Ramen) and this is definitely my favorite spot to go.  The noodles have just the right amount of chewiness, the broth is flavorful but not overpowering, and the chashu is tender, melt in your mouth goodness.    I have also tried the pork belly bowl and gyoza, and both are pretty good.  I wish they had a different sauce for the gyoza, but soy sauce mixed with vinegar and a little chili oil works just fine.  I've only discovered this place in the last year, but I can honestly say it's become one of my go-to restaurants and it's definitely a comfort food.  Prices are more expensive than your fifty cent package of Top Ramen, but it's still cheap for a restaurant at under ten dollars an entree.    My only bone to pick is that their green tea is only chilled and it comes in a can, though as far as canned green tea goes, it's not bad.

AUcIyFw7Hk0wOviZutUksg.text: best ramen in Vegas hands down. Tried their fusion of tonkatsu and shoyu ramen. Great broth, but wasn't a big fan of the thinner noodles, but they were very good. my friend got the shoyu one.. wished I had gotten that one. I like the fact is that they designed it to make you feel like you are in one of those hole in the wall ramen shops in Japan. Great experience and good food.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu shoyu ramen

qIMDkVnFs0rSCkjSE80bqA.text: Can tell by the broths that this Ramen shop takes their time to slowly get it right.  Best $7.95 you can possibly spend for meal in Vegas.  Excellent.

KCkLElaMCColVQ9JNbxfZQ.text: Tonkatsu Ramen was pretty good.  The broth and meat had a slightly different flavor then most ramen places that I've tried--in a positive way.  The broth was more creamy and the meat had a grilled taste to it.  My friend had the miso ramen, but I think the tonkatsu was better.  Price is usual for a ramen place.  The bowl comes standard with mushroom, 2 pieces of meat and bambo shoot.  I then added an egg and seaweed.  The place is super small and the wait is long.  But overall, I would come back if I craved ramen while I was in Vegas (only if I was craving it though).

psm8232zfNEn_QsmtOz48w.text: I went here on a monday for lunch.  The food is great.  My only complaint is that it is a small space and there is a wait, even on a Monday.  So you need to come right before it opens and get in line (there was a line of 15 people in front of the door at 11:15am, and the place opened at 11:30), otherwise, expect a wait to be seated.

qvrZJClrv6zHfNxhx1MgZA.text: There's love and hate relationship in this place. I love it cuz the food is good. I love the pork belly and the tonkostu ramen. The one thing I hate it it's the wait and small space. But everything else it good.

acT3zYnkP7UGoDL9GE2gWw.text: Too salty! I ordered tonkatsu ramen. Soup is very thick with extremely strong flavor. I don't think I will  come then.

x88Y30F7L7bdhMSOmm00EA.text: I scoped this place out before my husband and I went on vacation to Las Vegas and couldn't wait to try the ramen. I ordered the tonkontsu ramen and added the spicy sauce to the broth. I was a little disappointed that the sauce didn't make the broth super spicy, but it did add a little heat. My only complaint is that the broth was a little on the salty side, but it was still flavorful. The noodles were nice and chewy and the bamboo shoots were still crunchy, which I like! We also ordered the fried rice and it was delicious! I wish we would have ordered the kimchi fried rice because I'm sure that would have been yummy too! You have to sign in when you first get there, so they know who to serve next. We got there a little after they opened and they were packed! We didn't have to wait too long though and service was fast and friendly.

u5e7UD_rn-A7pL2bW5e-gw.text: Not that tasty. Minimal amount of noodles and a bit hard. The soup isn't savory. The servers were nice and courteous. Very small restaurant and noisy.

7XlIlj1npQs2RNa33btMow.text: Your not going to get any better unless you drive 5 hours to LA. Don't fear the line outside, it move quickly.  A must if you find yourself on Mountain Spring

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monta is worth the wait

5pOcTAf1hLUlebhzsOQmcg.text: We have been here twice and still think it's the best ramen place we've tried so far! The first time we went was on a Saturday at 4:30pm and didn't have to wait at all, but just went today and waited for 20 minutes on a Sunday at 2:30pm. The outside smell is awful, but you forget about the stench when inside the restaurant. The restaurant is small inside, but the food comes out quickly once you're in. The waitresses are always friendly and very quick to put in orders and bring drinks and refills. The miso and Kuro ramen were our favorites, but the pork belly and rice bowl is outstanding. The dish is flavorful and a decent size. Our 5 and 8 year old boys polished one bowl on their own. I love that they offer the option to add more noodles to your extra broth for only $1.50. We both added extra this last time. We will definitely be back to this place since we can't help but crave their ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly rice bowl ($5.95) regular size...a must try! The small is $3.95.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen (black garlic) $7.95

sB_Qh9VifFxSHcY5SMBgEw.text: YUCK!!!  Is ramen soup supposed to tast like greasy salt water???  The restaurant itself  was fine.  We got seated right away, the beer, dumplings and service were all very good (hence my 2 stars).  But the soup was digusting!  It did look pretty though.  We wanted to try this place becasue we had seen it on TV and read about it in a Vegas food book.  We were fooled.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dumplings were good.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gross, greasy, salty soup :-(

locEOA3ZfslE8TLyC41EDA.text: I'm going to go ahead an admit that although I know who David Chang and Tale Talde are, I'm not a pro at all when it comes to Asian food. Nonetheless, I visited Monta recently and must say I was impressed. I tried the shoyu ramen, although my friend recommended I try the tonkotsu. I thought it was pretty tasty though! I think it would be interesting to eat at the bar, like you were at a ramen place in Tokyo or Sapporo (David Chang's quarterly, Lucky Peach is all about different types of ramen, very interesting).   I can't say with certainty if the noodles are made in-house though.  BUT you get a lot of bang for a buck. i will be returning to try the tonkatsu and other items from the menu.

Me1OF8OSWYKChUJ220Ojcg.text: very pasty broth but delicious. the location is off the strip so not as convenient

mWrBYVpG85llBG77brb6rg.text: Amazing every time! Great ramen, quick, and friendly service. Chashu isn't the most buttery I've had, but the broth is dericious. Will be back!

MoyIifqasDgjtDn9wDEwMg.text: Honestly best hole on the wall place in Las Vegas. Not expensive at all. A little wait since the place is always packed. The Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen to die for!
