The broth is rightly season and the pork belly?! Orgasmic! $6.95 fo those noodles? Better than going to Asian Town in LA.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen wow!

0QKVDBrddNr8E1xHopzyfA.text: They're good at what they do, ramen.  I, personally, feel like this is a place you go to when you specifically are craving it.  You wouldn't come in not sure of what to order.   Options are limited since the menu is very small. The place itself is very small, but I think exclusivity is part of its charm. Every time I go there, it is busy and there is usually a little bit of a wait. There is a smal; bench outside for people to wait. Different hours of the day allow for different amounts of waits. There is a sign in sheet, so make sure to get your name on it ASAP. There is a drink that I get every time I am there called CALPICO. It's a non-carbonated soft drink. I know, I'm still trying to wrap my head around that idea as well. It's sweet and amazing. It's hard not to keep sipping on it while waiting for your food.

VIM4lK7iOagelwYpdjqaRQ.text: FOOD POISONING!! 1/04/2016. Wtf Monta?! We used to be such great friends. Why did you have to do me like this? Ordered my usual Miso Ramen bowl at 4 in the afternoon and I was in the bathroom by 7. I vomited no less than 8 times. This was my first incident of food poisoning ever (lucky me) but I don't think I will return after this, ever. This sort of carelessness is uncalled for.

lUC684pREH5ERLPRPyKHxg.text: This is usually my go-to ramen place, but today was just disappointing and caused me a lot of anger.  We went at the point when they were switching out their "sign-in" sheets, and we made the mistake of putting our name on the wrong sheet.  We noticed the mistake and corrected it, yet they continued to sit people who signed in after us.  Though they were aware that we had moved our name from the wrong sheet to the right sheet and had been waiting for 40 minutes, they sat a party of 6 that had only been waiting for ten minutes or so.  They then proceeded to tell us "oh well, we can't do anything for you, really, you should have put your name on the right sheet the first time."  Only when I told them we were going to leave and go somewhere else did they try to scramble to get a table together.  They're only in it for profit.  I just can't believe that they would treat people who visit them monthly like dirt.  It makes me sad, since I love their ramen, but I think this will dissuade me from visiting for quite a while...

RdB13YL_I1ycyxfO9Pxk4A.text: My first visit to Monta Noodle House was probably my last, at least for a while. I thought the food was ok, but the seating, prices and service was not what I had expected.  I went with several friends and one of them had suggested it. He is into food and so I thought to give it a shot. The restaurants in and around the area of this one, usually deliver, on what I mentioned above, that this one is lacking.  After waiting to get seated in the small restaurant, we were greeted quickly. What happened next was weird. We waited for almost 20 minutes before a member of the wait staff arrived to take our order. It took entirely too long for simple noodles in heated broth to arrive. It takes me two and a half minutes to make similar noodles and another two minutes to plate everything.  If you go during the Summer, which is always in Vegas, be ready for heat inside. Like another Yelper has mentioned, due to its size, this place stays hot and has little to no airflow.  For three people that ordered the standard fair and no beverages, the final bill should not have been anywhere near $40, but that's what I got.

6Q_GLiHOLr6xciPR1usXow.text: A friend from Los Angeles recommended this ramen joint to me.  "Not the same but good enough" were his exact words comparing it to Daikokuya.  Monta Ramen is literally in the midst of other small Asian food joints in a mini-strip mall in Las Vegas' Chinatown on Spring Mountain Road.  I honestly would have not known this place existed if my friend didn't tell me  about it.  Parking was, for one, a bit limited.    I walked in to a small, maybe 6 (or 7?)  tables and the counter bar, stuffy and unventilated ramen joint.  It had the same feel of Daikokuya:  cramped and rushed.  There were people standing, waiting and blocking the door.  I was offered to sit on the bar but there was no elbow room so I stood up and told the lady I would wait for a table instead.  The wait staff are Japanese, but noticed 2 Latinos working behind the bar/kitchen with an Asian guy.  Red flag I thought but then again I saw the framed accolades from different local papers and publications honoring and awarding Monta as the Best or one of the Best in Las Vegas.     I sat down in one of the small tables and ordered their tonkatsu ramen ($6.95).   The bowls are smaller, I noticed, and they're somewhat stingy with everything, including the broth and the toppings.  I had a couple small slices of chasu, bamboo shoots, mushrooms, and green onions.  Mine didn't come with marinated boiled egg.  I come to find out that you can order the toppings for extra charge.  Really? for an egg?   The broth was a bit salty to my liking, heavy and tasted like it was enriched with milk or cream, or maybe miso.  The wavy thinner noodles were somewhat seasoned too, but not overwhelmingly salty.  Their chasu, however, is to die for!  It's perfectly seasoned, cooked, caramelized and charred to my personal standards!  For that alone, I will come back and try their chasu rice bowl.  For their ramen soups?  I might try a different one the next time around, and maybe request thicker noodles.  Sidenote:  Monta Ramen was shut down by the Southern Nevada Health Department in mid March 2013 for 47 demerits, but have since re-inspected and reopened.

EauAuFIsZbtd8JGlTlDpiA.text: Delicious ramen!  I tried the Tonkotsu and the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen.  Both were good... but I liked the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen more.  The Tonkotsu is a very very rich fatty pork broth.  Probably  a little to rich for me.  The Tonkotsu Shoya was a little thinner, but had more flavor.  We also got the Kimchi Fried Rice which was amazing.  it's the best Kimchi friend rice I've every had.  (I think I enjoyed the fried rice more than the ramen).  The place is small, but the staff does an excellent job of turning over tables.

b9dVU57w034qualusDm_9w.text: This place does it oh so well. The menu is small and simple but oh so delicious. You can customize with a few different toppings but the base product is incredible. An excellent late night option worth checking out again and again that won't break the bank.

KUKQyaE-96Dj7PxrMhIJ9w.text: Worst customer service ever.. I liked the Monta on Henderson side better ... It's a small fried rice that we were waiting on for my daughter. we were nearly done eating our ramen and my daughter's small fried rice still hasn't come.. The server gave the fried rice to the wrong table.. I found out because the table next to us later then said I never ordered this fried rice... Pathetic! Just lame.. No sorry instead she blamed it on the Chef! Lol wow

LnlxRnBw1UXk1X_3zZxC6g.text: I love Ramen, but have no idea why its so expensive for a bowl of noddles compared to other bowl of noddles!   This place came highly recommended and boy was it good. It was probably one of the better bowls of ramen that I have had.   I truly feel that with any noodle soup, the soup is where it makes or breaks it. The broth here was excellent. It was flavorful, clean, and well balance. The one thing that threw me off were the noodles. I'm use to the regular ramen noodle size, but they appear to have given me the super fine ramen noodles. My friend who order the same broth as I did got the same noodles as I did, but everyone else got the regular noodles. Either way it was good, if I was to come back I would just ask for the regular noodles.   I added extra meat and an egg. I wish the egg was standard like most places.   Overall, great quality. One star off for the small portions.

LBgfyjEYFazGW5DjmdQ-Mg.text: A very simple and finely tuned establishment, I wish there was one like it at home.   The place is small and the service peeps very cheerfully chipper that it seems like something that came out of a Japanese Sailor Moon anime....can't complain, I love this atmosphere.  I ordered the Tontkotso/Miso broth with my ramen, the pork and noodles all complement the spices to expose umami flavor that is a joy for your tastebuds.  If you're ever in Las Vegas, you owe it to yourself to visit Chinatown and pay Monto Ramen a visit.

IDL-TNoaiMqD_yNQuamESQ.text: Quick, inexpensive, and delicious! The only reasons I took a star away:  One of the kitchen exhaust fans was broken so it was very smoky, warm, and loud inside.  Also, it would be great if they had some sort of non-pork offering. My husband does not eat pork so he got the Shoyu Ramen without the chashu, but we suspect something may have wound up in the broth somehow because he had had an upset stomach the following morning. We enjoyed it though!

qY5BLkx3QES0_D2kjPcWiA.text: This is the best ramen I've had since I moved to Vegas a few months ago. The wait could be a little long at certain hours but it's definitely worth it to me. I had the tonkatsu with black garlic oil. The oil compliments the pork nicely and the noodles are the nice and freshly made. A hot bowl of any of their soups hits the spot on a cold night in Vegas. You can't beat the price for the quality of food you receive. Add in an order of gyoza for the perfect meal!

r4V6ygU6wX9Zk_aTdd_f1g.text: A perfect bowl of noodles in a charming little hole-in-the-wall.  Service was welcoming, efficiently and friendly. When I read in some reviews that this wasn't the type of place you linger at, I was afraid that service might be a bit brusque. Nope! You get an enthusiastic greeting of "Irasshaimase!" from the couple of servers on the floor and the noodle chefs in the open kitchen behind the bar. Our server was courteous and we did not feel hurried. There's counter seating around the bar and maybe 5 four-tops in addition. It's not a big place, so there might be a wait if your party is larger than one or two. The AC was cranked up, which made for a very pleasant dining experience, considering you're eating hot soup in the desert.  I loved the concept of standard toppings and adding what you want on top of it. I added the seasoned egg to my bowl, which had a perfectly set, slightly gooey middle. The tonkotsu was thick and cloudy, with plenty of collagen dissolved in the soup to give you that lip-smacking sensation. Noodles were perfectly chewy, although you had to slurp fast so the hot soup didn't soften them too much. They also have Sapporo on tap in schooner sizes. Perfect, because my tummy can only hold so much liquid.   This is definitely worth a stop whether you are heading into or out of Las Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Selection of condiments

y1LosmeSGdYAWhNGyN3OCw.text: So, I was craving some pork belly all day! I was like an addict having withdraw symptoms! So, we decided to go to Monta, it was recommended to us! We had the Tonkotsu Ramen and added: Corn, Chashu Pork and Nitamago! Plus the Pork Belly Bowl! The ramen was rich and thick everything was amazing the pork was tender and fall off as soon as you picked it up melt in your mouth! You can never go wrong with a pork belly bowl its just amazing!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Ramen

eAgDUm7Ymn5BXNG5QrMv3A.text: We came here on a saturday afternoon around 1220 and it was super packed. We waited for an hourish but it's also because we had a party of 9. This place is right next to Raku and a korean restaurant.   We ordered a bowl of Tonkotsu shoyu ramen with an extra order of egg, kimchee fried rice, and gyoza. Let's actually start with the ramen which was the most disappointing dish of the 3....HOWEVER it was better than I expected. I have recently lost my hope for ramen so this place was actually better than I expected. The broth was a bit too salty for my taste but the chashu was really good. The noodles weren't bad.   The gyoza was really good. It was crispy and the inside of it was juicy and perfectly seasoned. The skin wasn't too thick so it had that perfect crispy to it when you bite into it.   The Kimchee Fried rice was the shiitttt. No joke. I think I'm gonna have dreams about the kimchee fried rice to be honest. It was moist and tasty. So much seasoning to it and there's little kick to it from the kimchee. There are restaurants that makes it super dry but Monta made it perfectly. Obviously it is oily, but it is seriously bomb-diggity good. It was sooooo good that we ordered a to-go right before we left and we ate it at midnight. We ate it cold cause there was no microwave in the hotel but it was still so damnnn good.  I would seriously come back only to get the fried rice...I'm really curious about the takana fried rice too. Service was actually really good and I actually gave Monta a 4 just because of the fried rice...or else I would probably give it a two stars.   The lesson is...you come early to avoid the wait, you get the fried rice, and be happy with life.

S6bS5_PfS4CfEzocQPYDAw.text: Monta Ramen is a very intimate, simple, and small ramen shop - they have a small menu as well, but that is good because it makes it easier to choose what to eat; they even scarcely have appetizers, as the only thing they really have is gyoza - other than that, it's either ramen or rice.  We've had the spicy tonkotsu ramen and tonkotsu shoyu ramen. They serve most of their ramen selection with thin noodles. I found it interesting that their broth offerings were differentiated by chicken, pork, or a combo or both. The spicy tonkotsu ramen comes with pork broth, spicy sauce, and thin noodles - the exact same as the tonkotsu ramen, but with a $1 spicy sauce extra fee. It was alright - a less creamy and oily than usual. The tonkotsu shoyu ramen is a mix of pork and chicken broth, and comes with thin noodles - the broth flavor was quite light, a lot less creamy than what I am used to (which I appreciated), had a slight syrupy consistency, and got pretty salty towards the end. The chashu pieces were extremely tender and fragile - so much that the pieces fell apart upon being picked, which was funny - I enjoyed them, but they were also thin and small slices. They also had an interesting dark brown jelly-like coating on the edges. The kikurage mushrooms and bamboo shoots were finely chopped and good and plentiful, and the amount of fresh green onions was generous. We also ordered kaedama, which was also a generous extra portion of noodles, and which basically used up the rest of the soup within the original bowl of ramen.  Overall, I prefer many other ramen places. However, you get great value at this place especially since you can currently grab a bowl of ramen for $7. The creaminess of tonkotsu broths I am used to is replaced by saltiness, which became too intense at the end. This experience can be easily skipped, but nowadays it's tough to find ramen at this good of a price. The best part of eating here was watching the chefs do cool soup and ladle movements with the ramen bowls.

VcvZtNF2YCaixB2KGP091g.text: This is my new favorite Ramen house, the tonkotsu ramen with chashu pork is spot on, the broth is so rich and flavorful you won't want it to end, the noodles are good, i wish they were fresh but still good, the pork is perfect and meaty. You will not regret coming to this place. I usually get the chashu pork bowl with my ramen and it's more then enough food. Don't pass this place and come early or you will wait in a long line but it's worth the wait.

KnhATFGXP1o1FoTGDhctgA.text: Oh lord, ramen at its best!  This is a must visit place for all my Vegas trips from now-on.  The place is small, but the service is quite quick.  Be prepared to wait for quite awhile to be seated if the restaurant is booming.  Due to limited seating and people seeming to socialize with their friends, the wait time may be ridiculous.  The food is great, but their should be a plan to keep the flow moving.  Other than that, and since that cannot yet be controlled without a proper setup in the restaurant layout, I still give this place a 5 for being as best as it could be.

mGiD9T2WR5OsuWw7xLfxxQ.text: I've given this place a few chances -- one of the worst ramen I've had. The venue is small and intimate, which is nice. The food is terrible. The noodles are very sub par (does not seem home made) and the broth is terrible. Too salty and only lukewarm, when in reality, should be very hot. It's cheap, which is probably the appeal to most people, but I would pay a dollar or two more for a much better experience.

-STaoZ_7KXTAhYslJbqxqA.text: Absolutely terrible location. Servers couldn't handle the rush. The lady trying to seat us was rude, & she even admitted to me and a couple of her guests that she was dazing off. Did not feel welcomed at all. Best off at the other locations

oTAdppDjJ2vEDqFkcjxQjA.text: We waited about an hr before getting seated and we arrived at 1140, 10 minutes after they opened. We both got the kuro ramen which isn't on the menu but it's the roasted garlic one as well as the gyoza n pork belly n rice bowl. Whoa, I gotta say the broth was waaaaay too porky and thick for me. It was very fatty n had consistency of porridge. Yes the pork slices were soft and melted in your mouth but I just couldn't get over the porky soup taste. The broth wasn't hot neither, it was lukewarm. Which just made it more gross tasting. Gyoza was good and the pork belly with rice was too fatty. The green onion n ginger relish helped disguise the taste a little. Yes the food came out lightning fast and service was good but this place is just too oink oink for me. I much prefer Santouka

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen with egg n corn added
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork bowl

iTgkAaGvbs4cIO4SYYUSMw.text: As i walked into the restaurant and saw the mass amount of people waiting, I knew it would be a long wait. As i approached the hostess and saw there were probably 25 tables still ahead of us, I asked how long is the wait? She replied with 20-40 minutes. HA ya right. But i really wanted ramen so I put our name in. We proceeded to go across the parking lot to a bar for a drink. 45 mins later we headed back, we got there to find that only 4 tables had been seated in that 45 min time frame. (NO SURPRISE) -- we waited another hour and gave up. She ended up calling us 2.5 hours later telling us our table was ready. HAHAHAHA. no thanks!

pHBVubSqcH19DgZKbLOYbQ.text: AMAZING. I don't even have words it's so good. And the service is amazing. They are quick and friendly! Basically everything on the menu is delicious. If you want ramen this is where you have to go.

Fnos4rLr4gQij6oqO2nMTw.text: Too good. Soup rich. Much flavor, esp the Kuro broth. Yummy thick noodles. Only $20 for 2 ppl. Gyozas were meh.

2jHWl7xPSFQYIEs58qdgDA.text: The ramen won't disappoint. The fried rice was surprisingly delicious.  Definitely worth the trip in.

Dr24O6aNhQ1m6oaTpb9CYg.text: This place was decent. I like the fatty tonkatsu broth with extra pork! But I have had better ramen before... The restaurant is very small so expect to wait a little... their side dishes are pretty good so get it as an appetizer to share with your friends

ExNwAilyDRLvyGUC1Q5rVA.text: BEST RAMEN EVERRRRRRRRRR  get the Tonkotsu Ramen (the middle picture) with THICK noodles, it will not disappoint you. I love the chili oil to give that extra spice. I wish they open a monta in OC because there's none here that can compare. I make sure I make time for monta when I'm in town. Don't go in big groups because this place is so small!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen with thick noodles. Best combo !

erVL04BmyFp2_dlVQzh4mQ.text: Definitely a great place for ramen. Had tried all of their ramen. My favorite would be the miso ramen. Place is small, but definitely has the Japanese ramen shop feel! Pork belly bowl is a must!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl

3H7na_PmpkHQPmlv7szAQQ.text: Full disclosure, i moved from Hawaii back to the mainland and have been to japan x4 and korea x2.  Very avg ramen and tonkotsu.  In addition, they bill this as Japanese, but it is totally a Korean ramen style.  Pretty disappointed on how high the reviews for this place are.  My two cents.

gLkdZunLbRC690TEkXdNXg.text: Best. Ramen. In. LV. My favorite restaurant!!! Everything is so delicious, and pretty good prices, even if you go by yourself.

gRcyB5iUeRyPBvwYtZQCQw.text: tight space but it adds character to place.   simple menu but it higlhly pleases my taste buds!  always have to visit this place when in vegas... cannot even find one in socal that can top this place off .

MQjqyZGElUkZ_nb-_MPAyQ.text: Second time eating here and my belly is happy and full. Great ramen, potstickers and cheap beer. Very limited seating, but short wait times.

9PouxjQkq_ugm-zqJjWewg.text: This review is long overdue, but from what I remember, the service was quick, the broth was tasty, and the food was fairly inexpensive.  It's a really small restaurant, so prepare to wait if coming during the meal rush.

r-PP8R7vUBBpXSJqJ_LoqA.text: This is the second time we're visiting this ramen house: first time, the ramen was really good and the pork bone based soup was simply good. I believe that a good food joint should always be consistent in the quality of its food. Monta ramen failed to deliver its goods the second time around: the miso ramen is extremely salty (I'm aware that miso is fermented soy based) but this miso ramen served will literally kill your kidneys and give you hypertension...beware those with high blood pressure issues! Imagine having to pay $1 extra for garlic oil.....this should be part of the kuro oil ramen one orders! I also don't believe one has to pay an additional $1.50 for an egg....hardboiled eggs should be part of the condiment for all ramen. Daikokuya in LA does it right : one standard excellent bowl of ramen with no extra cost for eggs! We're definitely not going back to Monta ramen!

o6nji8UFV8xnJcwV6QNldA.text: My wife and I finally got to try this restaurant last night.  From all the reviews, we were excited to try this place out.  Wow!!  We are fans.  The tonkotsu and shoyu ramen were excellent.  The thick noodle was cooked to perfection. The broth, in my opinion even tastes better than some of the restaurants in Tokyo.  Also the char siu is very flavourful, but a little too thinly sliced.  The fried rice was also very good.  I am so happy that we finally have an authentic ramen noodle house in my backyard.  Will definitely be back for more delicious ramen and broth.   I want to give 4.5 stars but I can't.  1/2 star off for those thin sliced char siu.

a2OpbUSOmOL3RoMW55atpw.text: Best Tonkatsu ramen in LV in my opinion.  Much better than Sora which was a disappointing experience.

M5KbfE_Dzu6WRNs-NaNPLg.text: Some of the best broth I've ever tasted. Slightly salty but worth it with The draft Beer and the mustard green fried rice is out o this world. Deep flavor and addicting to say the least. And in the Summer months the cold noodles with ponzu sauce is worth the trip alone!

NjfCC7Ms5dnv_3Xr5YfkUQ.text: The food was toooooo salty!!!!!! It is not bad but I couldnt finish it just simply because it is too salty!!!!!!!

k8dgj6fw6f5l6ICJJRtxsw.text: Ok its super small in there but the staff and chefs hustle, so you arent waiting forever for a table. Just expect a wait on a Friday night (esp First Fri) but its so worth it. Dont forget an order of the Kimchi Fried Rice to share!

vNutI96HbdbcSVfT612pvg.text: My friend and I first came to Monta via the public transportation bus and I do not regret waiting in the cold for 20 minutes and another 20 minutes at the restaurant for a table. I was soooooo relieved that Monta did not disappoint as I was also feeling a bit guilty for making my friend wait so long with me.  Their ramens are surprisingly good and the broth is flavorful, but not overly heavy. I ordered the tonkatsu broth with chashu and egg. The chashu was fork tender and I really appreciated that the yolk was not fully cooked. We also LOVED their Mentaiko bowl. The scallion, nori and touch of soy with the mentaiko was a match made in heaven. We went back on our last night in Vegas just to have it for the last time.   Making the trek to CT for Monta is so worthed it. The bill plus tip and RT taxi fare will be cheaper than any comparable restaurant you find on the strip.

pAyIz-y7OBsTPsek2D9d2w.text: I didn't even know gourmet ramen existed in Las Vegas. This was a small spot hidden on Spring Mountain Rd. It's really hot and ramen may not be the ideal food but it tasted great here. The chashu meat was really soft. The noodles were thin and the tonkatsu broth was very flavorful. Glad to have tried a place like this. It looks like they take pride and appreciate the craft of ramen here. It just makes the meal that much more satisfying.   Recommendation: Tonkatsu Ramen with extra chasu and hard boiled egg.

StD1xwLPQs1fTYhl1FpuSQ.text: I admit that Monta has the best ramen anywhere in Vegas.  The stuff they serve at Ichiza and Shuseki has nothing on them!  The noodles are fresh and the broth, whether tonkatsu, miso, or shoyu, is always steaming hot and extremely flavorful.  I appreciate that it's the real stuff and not the packaged, powder crap other places use.    Yes, Monta is a noodle house but their fried rice is just as good, if not better.  For someone who doesn't really like fried rice, I would come just for that.  Their gyoza was just okay.  I've had better.     Even though the place is (extremely) small, I like that it's cozy.  There was only one time when I actually had to wait for a table, but as always, the wait was worth it.    A basic bowl of ramen will cost you almost $8.  That's kind of steep, especially in the economy that we're in now.  An extra $1.50 for a hard boiled egg also seems a bit much, don't you think?  I guess it's really quality over quantity with this place.   Four out of five stars because food quality is good, service is good, but pricing isn't the best.  This place is always a pleasure though.  If you haven't been, you probably should soon.

kAXz2bBgE6oAvltIi8Ih7g.text: I'm all for authenticity and the like, so going into the Monta Noodle House is something of a nice nostalgia because it reminds me of a ramen shop in Japan; it's small and cozy yet with that "hole in the wall" charm.  The entire menu fits on one page, which for those that like variety I would suggest you search somewhere else to cure your soul for that variety of ramen. For entertainment purposes though, my group started out with an order of their gyoza, which was made from scratch, and was very tasty. The texture was a bit crispy-like on the outside, and that's all that it took (I think) to make it that much tastier. The inside had that "it's hot, but just right" feel to make it warm up the insides.  Though really now, it's all about the ramen. Monta prepares ramen in a Japanese fashion, the importance on the soup base. I had the tonkatsu (pork) base with extras of corn, egg, nori (seaweed for those who don't know), and some extra tonkatsu. The broth was a little bit saltier than I would have liked it, but all in all it was a very good blend of flavors that would make anybody want to come back for more. (b^^)b  In terms of drinks, you want to avoid pretty much everything on the menu besides water. It's a ramen shop, so you really want to focus more on the awesomeness of ramen, but I'm a bit sad that there isn't hot tea; my group ordered tea thinking it was hot, but it comes in a can that's been sitting in a fridge. Not a big letdown, but on a cold day in Las Vegas (those do exist) it would be nice to have a cup of hot tea to go with the ramen.  Atmosphere wise, everything resembles your typical Japanese ramen shop. The music adds a nice touch, but really it's the small, cramped family-like atmosphere that gives it that ramen shop touch. It's definitely good for those who want to catch up with one another or a small group of people looking for somewhere to eat; that's the atmosphere that was created.  All in all, a very good experience and if you want to eat some good legitimate Japanese style ramen, Monta is the place you want to go. (b^^)b

MMMAL0r2V0I4UVj98fmSWA.text: This place is amazing. The Ramen is always on point. The only reason why I didn't give it 5 stars is because the service isn't very good and there's ALWAYS a long wait. The place is very small and only seats about 25 people (give or take). But I'm not going for the service and never go when I'm starving since I know I'll probably be waiting for at least 30 mins. Overall one of the best Ramen spots in vegas

U9BbtOpA4zn6-Go8QPsL2g.text: I wanted so much to love this place based on the reviews. Surprisingly the best thing we had here was the char su rice bowl which was awesome. The ramen itself was just way too salty to the point it was barely edible. Friendly and great service otherwise but I hope there is better in vegas

1lQEl-U8ldS266jCx4MtXQ.text: the pork was delicately sliced and the broth was excellent. However, it was over an hour wait and we got there before it opened. it's comparable to the places I've tried in the SF Bay Area but I presume this is the best of Vegas so far.

XVwhZi4I8M1NG7OTd8Y0Xw.text: Yeah buddy -- this ain't Top Ramen for those rookies out there.  I've been eating ramen my entire life and made time to check this place out after a long day at a pool on the strip.  They have great options available for every taste -- hot/cold, meat/veggie.  I had the spicy Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen with egg and extra pork.  The kimchee side was perfect.  Although I don't look it, I'm half asian and when I walked up there were asians everywhere so I knew it was probably legit LOL.  Make time to leave the buffets and tourist traps on the strip and eat here once.  Plan accordingly because you may have to wait to eat since seating is very limited.  My group of three lucked out this day but the people after us had to wait.

s1jz5n4r0Bti29MimAaPtw.text: Finally!  A yelp hyped place I actually really loved.  Just when I was starting to give up on agreeing with my fellow yelpers, this place comes along and surprised me.  Let me note that I have never tried any sort of authentic ramen or have been to any ramen houses before, anywhere.  I know nothing about what is good and what isn't.  I also never come to the Spring Mountain area, as it is nowhere near where I live and my husband is not crazy about Asian cuisine.  So I came here alone before spending a few hours doing volunteer work in North Las Vegas, wanting something in my tummy before doing lifting and stuff.   I've complained in other reviews about some restaurants (mostly Asian-type food) that overwhelm you with egg smells when you walk in.  This one was one of those restaurants, but it was not bad enough to make me turn around and walk out.  It still grosses me out, as I really hate eggs.   I ordered the Tonkatsu, and only added some green onions.  Really nice flavorful broth, and I've never had such tender, nicely cooked pork in my life.  Very very good.  Next time I would add more pork to the dish.  My only beefs about this place was that they didn't brew their own iced green tea, they serve it from a can, meaning no refills.  And, the portion sizes were huge and I couldn't finish it all.  I wish they would serve a smaller bowl.  Oh and veggies!  Ramen needs a little vegetable action, and yes I know it is not authentic but I want it.  Other than that, I'll definitely be dragging my husband here whether he likes it or not.

avku1_o8t3zAP67DHZq46w.text: Yup, I went to Monta again....  This time I had 'Hiyashi Chuka(Cold Noodle)' & 'Small Bowl of Chashu'!  I loved it!! The ponzu sauce for the cold noodle was very citrus and just right. I'm wondering if they are making the homemade ponzu at their place instead of using the sauce from the bottle :) The hint of sesame oil was really blended into the dish and I was happy with the amount of the vegetables that they served with the noodle.   The chashu is a popular topping for the ramen, but I wanted to try with my rice this time. The chashu bowl comes with several piece of fried pork, chopped dried seaweed, and chopped green onion on top of rice. It was sooooo good!  I think I am sometimes very superstitions. Whenever I eat rice, I gobbled every grain in my bowl . My mom taught me to finish all the rice and eventually it will bring a good luck?! I still feel like that little girl :) Anyways, the dish was so tasty that I finished it all.   The server always welcoms customers with big smile :p  By the way, I happened to see the owner of Sushi Mon who was helping the kitchen staffs that day..,and the waitress said it's own by him.. What a great success! :-p

uTvAcyyCg_-xkBxomAG3Kg.text: Monta Ramen is simply the best. Excellent food and affordable prices are both a plus. Their pork ramen broth is killer good, and you can even order extra noodles if you are feeling hungry. They have additional ramen toppings for a little extra as well. The place is small so expect a wait if you come during peak hours. But overall, this place is killer.

iaGNa0gYGpxJZHJgtRQyZw.text: 3.5 star.  We ordered the shoyu and a tonutusku-shoyu ramen.  The mixed tonutusku-shoyu ramen tasted way better than the regular shoyu.  The shoyu tasted like soy sauce in water; I know shoyu means soy sauce, but every other place where I eat shoyu ramen, it didn't actually taste that way.  The tonuskutu-shoyu had at least some richness to it.  The noodles tasted ok, if I only ate the tonuskutu-shoyu, I would of given it 4 stars, but because of the shoyu broth, I am giving it a 3.5.

gUwlLYsNeh0P2DEPox9i-A.text: this place sits 24 people max (I think that's what the sign says) there's usually a line to get in but it's worth the wait. tonkatsu ramen, Kim Chee fried rice and gyoza is all you need...it's a lot of food so share :)

tWrjhy7YzthBjAiwqbGBZg.text: Great food, reasonable price. One of the best Ramen place in Vegas, but you always have to wait in line for a while due to very limited space.

2TVPK9FDisszMmmas3DoOg.text: We went there on a Monday around 12noon and had a 20 minutes wait.  The menu is simple.  I ordered the miso ramen, which is good, but too salty.  I did enjoy the sliced pork (very tender) and the noodle a lot, only wish it was not that salty.  My mother had the pork belly bowl, and we loved it.  We also ordered gyoza (pot sticker), and we love it very much too.  I will make it a regular eat out place for me and looking forward to try other items on the menu.

OGYu-2M_na-YKXJCW_pIbw.text: Best Ramen in Las Vegas. Then again there aren't many here. Love the miso ramen. I'm going to try the tonkatsu with the thicker noodles next time. I'm not a fine of the thinner ones.

pHLJLEIOiAQqdMBW6-SBCg.text: The broth they use is spot on. The noodles tasted packaged. And the gyoza were definitely frozen. But its all worth a trip to this tiny little noodle house.

U6tFy0Ae7gD5T3FBSfpcnw.text: i saw that there was a new Ramen shop in Las Vegas so I decided to check it out.  from the outside it doesnt look like much and the inside is no different.  You would say its just a hole in the wall place.  they have a very limited menu since the kitchen is so small and thats understandable.   I ordered the Shoyu Ramen, Gyoza and the small Fried Rice.  I was amazed by how delicious it was.  I am japanese so I like a good Ramen from time to time.  The Gyoza (potstickers) was home made.  Trust me I have eaten enough store bought Gyozas to know the difference.  Oh! and the Fried Rice was very tasty as well not mushy like other places.  Each grain of rice perfectly seperated from eachother..   With that being said the only 2 turn offs is the price.  althouggh a lot of the pricing is dead on correct.  there are few items on the menu that i feel is over priced for the amount they give.  another thing is the temperture inside the restaurant.  i guess they dont have any ac so they use a fan to cool down the room.  after eating hot soup i started sweating like a horse.   Overall I am satisfied with the product and i will be going back to eat again... That's for sure...

JQMNLMJmRUjzS_ETaIXJDQ.text: Food is good, price ok, bit cheaper than other restaurants I've eaten before. However one of the waitress, the asian girl with bangs give really bad service. I order ramen for me and my wife and gyoza for my son. I even make her repeat our orders. The ramen came pretty quickly, but the gyoza never came. I asked the waitress TWICE, if they're making the gyoza and she said yes, they're coming. 30 minutes later I see two plates of gyoza already done, but she give it to other tables. I asked where's the gyoza, she give me blank stare and she never apologize for her mistake. Seriously how hard can it be, especially with very limited menu, most people either order ramen or gyoza. She's either high or really stupid. I probably would come there agin, but I don't want her to serve us ever again.

wSUBN-5ezrOJdS3zyTKsJg.text: Best ramen in town hands down. The friend rice and the gyozas are also delicious. I lived in Japan for 9 years and I can tell you that this is as authentic as it gets. Very reasonably priced and fast service. One of the reasons I go there twice a week. You can be in and out in 25 minutes tops if you don't have to wait to be seated.

eh2beA_tcDxWqYo8huGJsg.text: Good service here, the girl is nice and speedy.  The miso ramen is toooooo salty, but still tastes good. The portions are OK as well, but the price is def a little higher than what I would want to pay for gourmet ramen. Will try again though

F8iCPS7qIxKPUVgyOy1uCQ.text: Came here two times during my four day stay! We ordered the Tokatsu ramen and the "Daily Special" Tonkatsu shoyu ramen and Japanese style fried rice. All were good but we enjoyed the Tonkatsu shoyu ramen more as the flavor was more balanced. This is another authentic ramen joint in Vegas. They serve only a few items which means they specialize in the few dishes they serve. Overall, a great place to go for ramen. The portion is a bit small for us but it sure was satisfying!

ekkhT913PLeYGsaRgSPLiQ.text: I have been looking for a great ramen place in LV, and found it! It's tiny and a small menu, but it's exactly what I wanted. Really nice staff. Go check it out.

HaaFXFvTet-HMOt7Np3JVA.text: The miso ramen broth was delicious.....yeah it was 110 degrees outside and the AC in the restaurant was not working, so as I'm eating my soup I was getting pretty sweaty, but despite of that the service was good and the soup was delicious...so I will be going back..!

el7XTdNqGtdE0VQUms-t2w.text: What a great place. The Tonkotsu was delicious and that boiled egg made it all work together. How they get the broth to have so much body and soul is beyond me but it make for so really delicious Ramen. Go at night as its not so hot AC seems to be broke but go because its delicious.

88vwNA-klOYgSBESTUMBAA.text: Just recently went to Monta Noodle House and I really enjoyed it. Coming down with a bit of a cold, this was the perfect place to begin the remedies!! Very quaint and cozy place, with very friendly staff. Great place for a cold/rainy evening, bowl of hot ramen noodles will make it all worth it! The Shoyu was really tasty, but I think next time I may try the Miso, sounded delicious. I'd definitely say a wonderful spot for any season!

beAxENDoy-mdvJarG5YVCQ.text: Best Japanese ramen I have had since returning to the states after 14 years in japan. Notice how they use different (and correct) noodles for each soup type!  Gochisousamadeshita

aU2_8rX2ZKzXjFvyaIhXAw.text: Highly over rated. First of all it was hotter than hell in there....too cheap to have AC!.   I do not like eating ramen when it is 90 degrees in the restaurant. Second the Asahi beer we ordered came out warm! The ramen was mediocre and lacked flavor...my son only ate one bite. extremely disappointed. Not anywhere near the caliber of lil Tokyo ramen houses in Los Angeles.

Z684WArNFFHQwZ1YJNGoQQ.text: Once you arrive at Monta and find a parking spot, you will instantly feel like your in Tokyo, Seoul, Beijing, Hong Kong, Manila, Taipei, Hanoi, Singapore and any of those Asian Capitals. This plaza is crazy busy so don't expect a quick stopover. However its one of the best Ramen place in Vegas. Everything my family and I ordered was delicious with a few hit and miss with the appetizers. As for their Ramen, simply delicious from the savory toppings and noodles. Our group really enjoyed the broth of all the Ramen we had last night 7.19.16. The service was friendly and helpful since it was every ones first time here.  FYI: We have been wanting to try this place for awhile now but its always busy so we never got around to it until last night. So expect to give yourself time and call ahead to check what is the wait time and make it a destination since you have Kung Fu Tea or Snowflake for dessert nearby!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen w/ Nitamago(Seasoned hard boiled egg) &amp; Nori(Dried Seaweed) toppings.

GiqWh7p_cnQuQsBRgFXtXQ.text: Important: 4 people from my party of 5 ate the Tonkatsu Ramen and had diarrhea afterwards. My mom's reaction was the worst; 45 minutes after we ate the ramen, she had a major stomach pain. Ramen was standard (i have high standards of ramen because I am asian and i've eaten a lot of different ramens). The gyoza however, was top notch!! It was very good definitely.

Bx61Mbyz3xZlf7xk1dbtGg.text: Simple small place with great Ramen. My fave. in Vegas cuz of the amazing flavor and topping choices.

FSseSyihzQancqxWpGLXug.text: Try to get there right when it opens. Located in a plaza with a parking lot. It gets packed really quick. The place is very small with a couple of tables and bar area.   Ordered: Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil (5/5) Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen (5/5) Kimchi friend rice (3.5/5)  When I took my first sip of the black garlic oil soup I was amazed! Omg the ramen is  The portion size is great. The soup is light and flavorful and not too oily. The noodles were cooked perfectly and have a good consistency. The fried rice is good as well but definitely try the ramen especially the black garlic oil!! The price is so reasonable! Definitely worth the drive off the strip! Will be back anytime im in Vegas !!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0XL8xVblef8pcq0QzQQFmw.text: Came here Saturday after EDC to recover and to get ready for round two. We got the black garlic ramen, tonkotsu ramen, mini chashu bowl, and the mini mentaiko bowl that was shared between two people. All of the dishes were great, especially the black garlic ramen and the chashu bowl .  The black garlic ramen and tonkotsu ramen were great. The broth was hearty and packs a big punch of flavor. It might be too salty for some, but it was salted perfectly for me. The noodles were cooked to my liking and the meat was soft and seasoned well. I personally love garlic and the black garlic ramen was right up my alley. It was packed with garlicky goodness and I drank some of the broth after finishing the noodles just to taste more of it.The mini mentaiko was good, but I wish had a little more fish roe.  The star out of all the dishes is the chashu bowl. The chashu was incredibly flavorful and had nice touch of charred flavor to it to give it a extra kick. The fatty parts of the meat melts in your mouth and coats it with juicy deliciousness. When I return to Monta, I will definitely be getting this again no matter what.   As a side note, be prepared to wait if you do come at a busy time and make sure your entire group is present when they call your name.

tbICjbZWd6kThnHTG662bg.text: The ramen at Monta Japanese Noodle House was extremely delicious and didn't disappoint by the slightest! However, with the wait-list system that the staff uses at the restaurant, our party of three was overlooked by the hostess for about forty five minutes. When I approached her to make sure that we were still on the list, she suggested that we hadn't been waiting here for an hour and even that we had lied about waiting outside the front door all this time. This definitely lessened what would have been the perfect ramen experience; however, in reviewing the restaurant, I must not only take into account the food, but also the service as a complete experience.

-iSPeqFcBxAbwBCEM4WnwA.text: This is definitely my favorite ramen spot. I've been ordering the same thing since 2011 and I've discovered a new side to add with my ramen. Grilled chashu on the side. I always order Shoyu ramen with egg and if I'm super hungry, I'll order gyoza too.

Lm0DCACMsbwJ2b9wPyJ9VA.text: Foodie approved. There's always a long wait (about 30 mins) and the parking is tough but the ramen is 100% worth it. Go inside and write your name and the number of people in your party on the waiting list. Your whole party has to be there to get seated.   I got the tonkatsu ramen and a side of kimchi and it's the perfect amount of food . The noodles are al dente because they keep cooking in the broth after they bring it out. Great quality, healthy, and delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen

h5EoSK1vmla9rJnOvTqZGQ.text: Amazing, this was one of the first ramen places I've tried and I was really good! Would definitely recommended to friends

uyQ9xIzQ53Q-Lss59M3YCQ.text: So happy we decided on doing lunch at this place right before we left Vegas! It was so delicious I would recommend anyone who is a ramen enthusiasts to try this place out! You won't be disappointed. Lucky we came at a time right before they got super busy so we didn't have to wait the place is really tiny so when there is a wait sometimes you might have to wait outside. We walked in and were immediately seated at the bar area. We ordered right away and were given our drinks right away The food came out within 5 or so min very fast. My friends ordered the spicy ramen  and I ordered the pork belly bowl over rice  and then we got an order of the kimchi rice to all share. Everything was amazing the kimchi rice was like nothing iv ever had before it was so delicious it had chunks of Napa kimchi cabbage in it! So good! the spicy ramen was perfect not to spicy and had amazing flavor! And the pork belly bowl was also delicious. I'll be revisiting this place for sure for that kimchi rice!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. This is a must try if you love kimchi!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wEqYcHzdwHnhVa0bSjfT-Q.text: I am giving Monta Ramen the 5 spot.  Why???  Because it deserves it!!!  Right here is where I would normally upload my keenly composed food porn, but I was so hungry and the food was soooo good, my phone didn't work fast enough to get it done...  What I can say is, we went with a party of 5, and we each order various foods to family style it.  Everything was SUGOI!!!   We ate, stomachs joyful, wallet happy, and vow to be back very soon.  Can't say anymore than that.  Well actually I prolly could, but do I really need to?

4IjSXiSx2JCW9Lo36FfbcA.text: Best ramen in Vegas! Nice and cozy inside- can't wait for this cold weather to come and eat. Food is unbeatable !

1TipDW1jKwA6ra74QuNSwQ.text: Worth the wait.  The different flavors are unique and masterfully done.  The garlic black oil sauce is amazing.  Have yet to have this anywhere else and it just works for me.   Only issue is parking, too many restaurants in same strip.  We had to park at an abandoned church parking to the West and our car was broken into.  Might go back for pick up, but not parking in those shady areas again.

sSn6Je9n2o3F4v87ch1m-w.text: Great ramen for really good price. The restaurant is really tiny and could only seat about a handful of customers. Be prepared to wait in line and come early if possible. We waited for 35-45 minutes for a table for 5.  Toppings could be added on the ramen and charged accordingly. They mentioned not accepting more than 2 credit cards per table, but luckily our server was nice to collect 3 of our credit card payments. Just ask nicely and if your order is above $15 they might allow it!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

4cmUK9eXfDdiXYcqOXmlfg.text: This place is awesome.  I moved here from the Bay Area where there is an abundance of great ramen and Monta competes with all of those.  Amazing food and it has that authentic Japanese ramen house feel with the tiny restaurant space.  There is always a line when you go here, usually a good sign for any restaraunt.  This review is making me hungry, I'm gonna go there right now.

irr5bZdmofWkKtcShoPqLA.text: The ramen here is good if you are a fan of "porky" fat flavor. I should had tried the chicken but the pork broth was recommended. I also have to point out that the place didn't have the A/C running, just ceiling fans. It's a small place, with the kitchen right beside the seating so the humidity from the broths and cooking was really making it feel hot and humid. I definitely won't bother coming back. It's Las Vegas in the summer, use the A/C if you have an open kitchen...

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BoDTUBU7VEd_BuyG4rCukQ.text: Love this place. Best ramen in Chinatown hands down. Also love the pork belly rice bowl and goyza. Definitely recommended. Also plan ahead as there will definitely be a line, usually 20-30 mins wait.

XUi4QMSx2a6hYhe1zKjq0A.text: Delicious ramen!  We came here in our search for the perfect bowl of ramen.  We were successful.  We started off with the gyoza and they were wonderful. I had the miso with pork, corn seaweed and butter and she had the pork broth with corn and seaweed.  The food was prepared very well and the service was great.  This was a successful Ramen field trip.  Looking forward to many more.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A bowl of love!

-2lgX7jteS3s64xaLQw-Zw.text: Spent 3 nights in Vegas, found this place the 2nd night and ate there both the 2nd and 3rd night it was that good!  Small place, had a wait both nights but there's a reason why, it's that good.  Fried rice was excellent and I got the spicy ramen and added extra pork, butter and corn and was hands down the best I've had, our ranked my go to place in NYC I've been going to for years.

n3QQ1iCd-4BMOfDYABXmEQ.text: Best ramen in the city. Period.   We also ordered the pork belly bowl which was simple but delicious. My only complaint was that the egg on my ramen was cold which was sort of weird to me and the yolk was a bit overdone despite this. Nonetheless, can't wait to go back!

k01F45vGoiZ-uDPCmaIj8A.text: So I live over at north, where I already have a favorite ramen spot. My friends told me try out Monta saying it's the best in town. At north we have ichi ramen, and that's hands down my favorite ramen place. The broth over there and the spicy sauce is fantastic. So I came with high expectations for Monta. I'm clearly judging on the ramen broth, and truthfully, I have no idea what people are talking about. The tonkotsu broth has a strong smell that is very off putting. I can't really describe it, maybe it's the pork broth or something, I'm not sure what it is. My friend who recommended Monta told me, it's the broth, that's how Monta Ramen usually smells. I really couldn't finish my ramen because the smell from the broth. The service was okay, and their fried rice was good. My rating is solely based on their ramen because it is their main product. It's really not as good as people describe. I just think people haven't been open to other ramen shops but broth wise. Ichi ramen is way better. Personally, the drive from north and the broth just doesn't do it for me. I swear there is a smell that is offputting. I hope other people can tell me what that is.

NwcM706Dh6vAJDlB51ZtzA.text: Monta Ramen is my second favorite ramen place. PROS: good ramen, lines are not too long, broth is not too fatty. CONS: they do not have freshly brewed green tea, only canned (yuck), they do not have fresh garlic as a topping option, which would add a lot of flavor.Overall a good place, but not nearly as good as Santouka Ramen in Costa Mesa, CA.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with added corn and spicy miso paste. The spicy miso paste is a must.

b90613C6BjvFHyoeYaamMA.text: Why are all ramen shops in Vegas small and cramped? That's besides the point because I am willing to wait for good ramen, but I was pretty disappointed by Monta on a recent visit. The toppings were too basic. It wasn't a surprise that the flavor was lacking when you only have a few components. You get two small slices of chashu and a few bamboo shoots. The tonkotsu-shoyu broth didn't have any depth of flavor. I had to ask for a second helping of noodles because the serving was so small. I didn't like the thin texture of the noodles. My friend asked for extra chili sauce for his spicy tonkotsu because it lacked the kick he was looking for. They said it was $1 extra. If your broth isn't spicy enough and you want to charge your customers extra, shame on you. Plus, 75 cents for nori? At least that's included at Sora. The best part of the ramen was the soft-boiled egg.

9wcYE9zO2ljVuVit38ELuA.text: This is a favorite spot to visit anytime we come to Vegas.  Always a line as the food is delicious and reasonable.  Japanese speaking staff friendly and efficient.  Pork Belly Bowl was delicious, but the Kuro Ramen was metcha oshiii!  My wife liked the Miso Ramen as well.  After living in Japan I've experienced some amazing ramen and Monta's is on par with the best I've ever had.

OxIB6mr83PfeOC9tp79yew.text: Amazing!! Best ramen in Vegas! i got the tonkatsu shoyu and it was amaze-balls!! definitely coming back to try the rest they have to offer!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6gDhJnqag5INiOZZqjgnXg.text: The broth was a bit salty for my palette but I thought the ramen was all around decent.  I would definitely recommend the shredded green  onion as a topping because it really added a nice chewy texture to the ramen.  Trust, it will not disappoint!  And the chashu is cooked perfectly.  It will melt in your mouth.  It gets really crowded during lunchtime and the place is pretty small so plan accordingly.  It's priced right under $7 so the price is definitely right.  I'm Korean so I love that they offer a side of kimchee.  It's a must.  They also had a mustard green side which was WAYYYY salty..  I definitely would not order that again.   Monta's legit.  It's run by all Japanese which also means excellent service..

dKUcR5yDUDXAPTQlZYUXSg.text: I'm pretty sure their ramen broth is made from the sweet nectar of the gods. Every slurp takes you to paradise. The tonkatsu and miso broth will make you want to slap your sister on the bum.    If you go during lunch get there before noon or after 1pm or you're in for a rude awakening. Pro tip: Sit at the bar and watch the art form that goes into creating each bowl of heaven.

0XFNnAooScPkZai4LMxeig.text: My go-to ramen spot!! Their broth is honestly my favorite because it's packed with flavor and it's not too salty for my preference with their bomb noodles!! The only downside is that this restaurant is packed like CRAZY during lunch/dinner times and such a small place. But because they have attentive waitresses who try to seat people ASAP and such heartwarming ramen, I really don't mind the wait for the speed my food comes out! I highly recommend this place, especially for people who haven't experienced passed package ramen!! My staple order is the ton Katsu shoyu ramen (idk if I even typed that correctly) BE AWARE: they will not seat you until your whole party is there

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_l3bxtobtrkT3C1Pb5j1dQ.text: What an incredible value.  I got the tonkotsu, it comes with two big pieces of melty pork belly, and I added an egg.  The broth is good, not great depth, but definitely  very good.  The noodles are the straight kind.  Service was excellent.  A woman chef was in charge of the kitchen, she totally commanded it.  That was cool.

LG6vdMkHcs-pt9mjSP68YQ.text: This place is legit. Seriously the best ramen I've ever had. I was worried about the wait so I came about 10-15 minutes before the restaurant opened. Once the doors opened, my group was the first to get seated. The menu is pretty simple, which I prefer. I love garlic ramen so I tried the kuro ramen (black garlic oil). Wow, it was delicious! The broth was super thick and flavorful! The meat was soft and tender, and the egg was cooked to perfection! Writing this review makes me crave another bowl of ramen. Sadly, I am not from the area. I can't wait til my next trip to Vegas so I can hit up this spot again! Solid 5 stars!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Heavenly bowl of ramen *o* (kuro ramen)

VZ3SnufGlH22DCTT7RK9bw.text: I had the Spicy tonkutsu ramen and it was okay, edible but I wouldn't rave about it. Broth was a little over salty and too thick for me, and they're pretty stingy with the broth. There was no option to choose how well you want the noodles to be cooked. Overall, while many said 20mins wait was worth it, I wouldn't agree. This place is overrated.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Open kitchen

wk-ajcopAggx0lbYUSB0UA.text: Probably the best Ramen in Vegas, but not the best EVER. Just the honest truth. I had the tonkatsu with extra chashu & egg. The sauce was VERY rich & creamy. A little too rich for my taste. The chashu is mostly fat but still good. Tasted very oily. I also got the kim chi ramen which was also very oily & salty! 4 stars because this is good for Vegas since there's not a ton of good asian food here, but like I said, I've had much better ramen elsewhere.

5Zhu10ZqiKp6o-qaGrXA3g.text: I really enjoy coming here when i can. Tonkotsu ramen with extra Tonkotsu. always leave with a very satisfied stomach.   Typical ramen prices, great ambience, despite how small the place is, but i still don't mind how busy and loud it can get. Simple, short review for a great ramen house.

3oDfJwyHkgUrU6GNjRiFJA.text: I probably come here about twice a month. This is one of the best ramen places in Vegas. I usually do take out but it's great place to come with a loved one. I always do the miso ramen with extra corn, butter, and chasu pork.

_Di-BoCwZ7NJUOp7E_2dOg.text: Pretty delicious.  Don't like the thin ramen noodles though.  It's not the normal chewy authentic ramen noodles.

lnKO6YNLTaKes5yyHVQIVA.text: So the fiancee and I were next door at Kung Fu Tea, and she said: "let's not go exactly at 11:30 AM when it opens".  So 5 minutes later we walked in and man the place was already packed. We got lucky and scored a corner table. A line had quickly formed after. It's a small establishment so be prepared to wait.  But the wait is worth it. Featuring a very easy to read menu (think, Shin-Sen Gumi in Fountain Valley/Gardena/Alhambra), we both ordered a regular bowl each featuring their pork broth.  Aside from the ingredients, which were tasty (the pork can be on the fatty side, which I love, but may vary for others), the broth itself was super rich and very very savory. Quite simply some (if not the) best ramen you can find in Vegas.  The servers take your orders down on iPads and are fast/friendly.  Parking seemed easy given the time we went, and this place does take credit cards. Major kudos to this place and I can't wait to come back.

9IC-Z3fkY9i6TDIxXlXJNA.text: Don't let the lines sway you this place is worth the wait!  The Tonkotsu Ramen was an eye opening gastronomic experience. After years of ordering various Phos and Miso soups this broth blew every other out of the park. It's ruined us forever. With a creamy consistency that rivals milk or melted butter this stock made from pork bones, fat, and collagen is heaven in a bowl. Add to that some amazing thin noodles (you can order thicker noodles if you desire) and throw in the basic toppings of green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage mushrooms. OMG it was to die for!  There are many additional toppings you can order to customize and make it perfect for your tastes.   We also ordered the Gyoza and the regular fried rice. After reading all the reviews we had to give them a try. The fried rice was good, but not fabulous. Perhaps there's a difference if you order the Takana Fried rice?  The gyoza were great. Thin pillows stuffed with vegatables and pork. Hot and delish!    Lucky for us, we're in town for a couple of weeks so we'll definitely be back!

7R2-_-IfqvqBWCudbzPq2w.text: Best ramen I've had since being in Japan in 2005! Their ramen is hyper-authentic and affordable (under $10), we also had gyoza and fried rice, and they even had vinegar and soy-sauce on the table (which is traditionally mixed together to make the gyoza dipping sauce.)   I love this place! The wait will be super long, because their are only about 20 seats, if that. Prepare to wait, or go early. Either way it is amazing.   Skip the plane ticket to japan, and get your ramen fix here!

z2027fUOdoxfoum9SSDKQA.text: We went on a sunday afternoon and it was packed. 30 min wait at least. No room to wait inside so we had to settle for the heat.  The place is small but the atmosphere is very "homey". Miso ramen was good. The broth was better than some. The meat was very fatty, yuck.   I'd give this place a 3.5 if i could... But a 4 will do

dpnOsOcO96G5xEAbRcKf9Q.text: Simple menu, but best ramen in town. The soup stock is very flavorous without tasting too MSG. Noodle is firm and chewy just like how ramen is supposed to be. Meat is marinated well.

72TRut0eSdM8OH7wNoGDpg.text: One of the factors in choosing a hotel when I come to Vegas is its proximity of C-town, where all the comfort foods and pretty decent ramen joints are. We tend to end up at Palms Place, just a couple of miles away.    Most recent trip, we came here for a quick bite. Dinner time on a Tuesday night resembles the weekend. People already waiting outside after signing in on the wait list.   It took about 10 min before we were called. Menus came quickly and our orders were taken just as fast. Fairly simple menu with decent choices.   We had Kuro ramen w black garlic oil. Rich broth w noticeable garlic flavor plus fatty slices of pork. Sprinkled their red pepper and it was delicious. Only $7.95  Also got a tonkatsu ramen. Like the other, this also had a rich broth w even fattier slices of pork than the first one. The red pepper did wonders for this bowl too. $6.95  Extra bowl of noodle to soak up that broth: $1.50.   The food came out super fast. And they came by quickly to clear up the table.  I get it, they need turnover. But they the staff were always nice and never pushy.    Our food was great. Simple and very satisfying. The  service was fast and efficient. We will definitely come back.   Notes:   *The parking lot is a decent size, but it will fill up. Circle around and even look at the side streets.   *The entire party needs to be present before being seated.  * It's a small place. Parties larger than 4 may expect a longer wait. Come in smaller numbers * Toppings are available ranges from nori to pork chashu at various prices.  *Eat quick and leave. They need turnover at these low prices. Go somewhere else to catch up

-dcMK91a1SwPi5k2uy6USw.text: I finally got the opportunity to check out this ramen place. We ended up going with 7 people and keep in mind this place is tiny. We got lucky that we did not have to wait long.   We ended up ordering gyozas,  kimchi rice, kuro garlic ramen with extra egg, pork belly rice bowl, and extra pork.   Food:  The quality of the food was amazing.  Great ramen noodles and amazing broth. It is very balanced and not too salty. Loved the garlic tasted behind it. We loved the kimchi rice as well.  The pork belly rice bowl was allright. They could added more pork belly but for the price, it was good. Overall For the price and quality, this is by far the best ramen place in Vegas 5/5  Service and atmosphere:  very fast service. We ordered really quickly. Then  less 15 minutes, our food arrived.  They paid attention to our water level and followed up to see if we want anymore items.  Atmosphere is very small and smelled like ramen broth every where!  It was such a good smell!  5/5  I will definitely come back for more ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

jI0G4VSPdXH4llaVybt1Yg.text: I love this place so much because they have Miso Ramen my favorite Ramen ever I had Fried Rice too and Kaedama (which is how to say extra noodles in Japanese) for my Ramen.   The atmosphere was very quiet I didn't hear a single person talk but the problem is that the bathrooms didn't smell like anything.   The service was great I like how they put the extra noodles in a small bowl so my baby brother can eat them.   I would like to come back here every once in a while for my birthday dinner.

fLv24oDTkV0A7PwBGPIVGA.text: This place is one of the best places ever for noodles. They are perfect and I mean every bite. The broth is so perfectly layered with flavors. This is a must try just be prepared to wait awhile to be seated. It's a very small spot......but dynamite comes in small packages.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Noodles are fantastic!!!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best Roman In Vegas

EwDN7B--zpMuZQ-eUthLcQ.text: My favorite Ramen place. Been coming here for years. The staff even knows me due to my frequency, that's not a joke. You know those movies where some dude walks into a bar and tells the barkeep "the usual"? That's me with Monta. I go in with my 1980 trench coat and hat, smoking a cigarette, sit down at the bar counter. The waitress comes up and I give a deep sigh before saying "I'll have the usual". She inputs my order in her iPad before she leaves me to sulk silently about a double homicide that I've been trying to solve for the past 5 years. The chief tells me that the case has gone cold... but I know, I know that the killer is still out there and one day I'll avenge little Suzy and Bobby, god rest their souls.  Thankfully the ramen comes before I played out the scene where I eat a .22 caliber after taking a shot of whiskey.

QHN7h7zbhWf4xc_zMBN0_Q.text: Still my favorite ramen place in Vegas.   I'm not a huge tonkotsu broth since it can be too thick for my own taste so I stick to my shoyu broth which I don't find too salty.   The gyoza and pork belly bowls are also a must for me. It usually ends up being too much food if I order all three but the gyoza and pork belly bowls are still great the next day if I can't finish it in one sitting.

nu_DNAg3zBaM16Ns0pDL-A.text: I am now a ramen believer! This restaurant completely changed my perspective on ramen. I have had it before but this is the first time I have truly enjoyed a bowl of ramen. Everything tasted fresh and the broth was very flavorful.   I visited a Friday at 6 pm with a large group. We were lucky enough to arrive early because otherwise I am not sure if we would have been seated. The place is small and sits very few people. There was no wait time at that time but by the time we left around 7 pm there was a long line.   I ordered the miso ramen and added green onions, egg and a side of kimchi. The portions are good and enough to satisfy. I am definitely visiting this establishment again.

8rloJHA4Yl49CQjk-E4itw.text: Wow surprised their ramen is so delicious!!! Dashi beautiful pork and eggs I will dream of this one in a lil storefront.  the gyoza perfect thin skin beautiful pork juicy inside luckily a local brought us here I will come back in the Chinatown area.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

8hLTFSB3QuaLd4vHSE9YvA.text: We went to 5 Ramen joints in Vegas this trip to try and find the best one according to our taste buds.  This place was the clear winner, there were some other places that were good but not quite as good as this place.  Not only do they have excellent Ramen broth and noodles with a perfect balance of flavor with neither side over powering the other. They also had Kimchi fried rice that was "WOW" so delicious and their Gyoza's were great. And loved the fact that they have crushed/minced garlic in a container next to our table. I love a lot of garlic in my food. :-)  Been to a bunch of places all over the US and this is one that is closest to real Japanese style Ramen that I have experienced in Japan. So happy Yelp is now being used in Japan.  This place sets the bar really high to compare to the real thing.  Can't wait to go back, my only complaint is that it is so small and you need to go 30 minutes before they open to get in.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu - Shoyu Ramen

ktaBGBjLEyD-eV5GFr2oIg.text: For $8 ramen the value is Montalisious. Small tables so not great for large groups. Parking is crazy because this square is food galore.   My advice is order to go. I actually like the Takana fried rice the best. Small portions so order two. Kung fu tea is next door while you wait.

P2NEVLr1eixNCE_gAeisBA.text: Right before getting my hair done at Chandelier Salon (you can see my review for their as well) I decided to get something to eat. I went thru the whole shopping center and at Monta I had the best feeling- I did not want to check reviews until I sat down. It is a small restaurant that can probably only seat about 25 people. I ordered the kimchi rice with pork belly on top and my girlfriend ordered the Spicy Ramen.   My kimchi rice with pork belly was delicious, the pork belly was soft and almost melted in your mouth. The kimchi rice was not red which thru me off but the flavor was amazing.   The ramen was amazing and so large- half way thru we decided to switch to both try what we each ordered.   We also ordered pot stickers and they were delicious.   For everything it ended up costing up about 26 dollars and it was well worth it. When we arrived (Saturday at 2pm) there was no wait but when I left the hair salon at almost 8pm there was a line wrapped around the door. For the next 24 hours, I craved and wanted Monta. I will be back and am so excited my food guides directed me here.

pYuZeXFWlhvHGvGdyPFQ6Q.text: It does not matter what time of the day, Monta Ramen is usually packed with a long line of hungry ramen enthusiasts waiting outside the door... for their turns to get a taste the popular Miso, Kuro (Black Garlic Oil), Tonkotsu, Shoyu or combination Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen. With over 2500+ reviews and 4-stars rating, something gotta be good here!   After waited for 30 minutes and finally got to try a variety of ramen... here's the verdict... well, all Tonkotsu, Spicy Tonkotsu and Kuro Black Garlic Oil Ramen turned out to be a bit too salty... although the quality of broth is considered somewhat standard... (NYC standards, of course) with creamy and thick broth... their Chashu is very thin and on the fatty side. Having used to getting lots of toppings as basics in NYC, you'll find that dried seaweed, seasoned egg and bamboo shoots are extras at Monta Ramen. Then again, this is Vegas Chinatown... and so, I say it's overall a good value ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen (Black Garlic Oil)

vG9KT44S2UoDgVQme32Tew.text: I came here with a fellow resident who was on the search for good ramen in Las Vegas.  Monta Ramen is quite small, so it can get crowded with a wait at times. Service however is decent.  As for the food, the ramen was okay, but I was not all that impressed with the flavor of the broth, and the noodles were not as chewy as I would have liked either.   Overall, did not meet my expectations but definitely not bad ramen either.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen.

_tDkVDFHo7U0fM-RSovEgA.text: WEI IS SIMPLY THE BEST TODAY (03/22/19)!!!! Tonight wait was so long about an hour by the time we were seated wei service was excellent!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. OUR WATER NEVER GOT REFILLED!!!

pcbScdZ2UiW-JTnmsq6zMw.text: This place really hits the spot. Especially after a day of drinking. It's not the best ramen I've ever had but it's still really good. We all got the shoyu ramen and it was light just the way we like it. If this place blew me away I would give it 5 stars, but today I was satisfied and not amazed.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7B-f2VoOizePvdfFa_HK4A.text: There is something to be said about small venues with a menu bursting with flavor. The wait want terrible but definitely plan ahead as seats are limited. That was my first sign this meal was going to be enjoyable. The staff greeted us with a smile. Started off with gyoza (pot stickers / dumplings). There was a seared side and a steamed side. Balancing the slight crunch while still remaining tender and moist. The Tonkotsu Ramen had a pork broth base with thin noodles, and slices of pork belly. I heard the pork is the best here so I went ahead and ordered extra pork for mine. The pork belly melts in your mouth. The fat was velvety, which you could only get from a slow cooking process. The portions were ideal. Not so much where I had to take some home but not so little where I would still be hungry. I walked out of there completely satisfied and my wallet was also happy as the process were very reasonable.  (thank you for the delicious food).

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen with extra pork
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

B66VaSA8qaBgngW9Nm3vIQ.text: This is most likely my favorite ramen place in Vegas. Off strip, hole in the wall, line out the door everyday of the week after 5:30pm. The ramen is affordable and credit cards are accepted for orders over $10. Their specialty ramen dishes will run u just under $8 while their more basic dishes will run you $6-$7. If you're feeling especially hungry place an order for some gyoza (pot stickers), or their fried rice. The pork is soft and thinly sliced, the broth is very flavorful, and the noodles are cooked just the way they should be (in my opinion).  I think it's also important to note, that parking in this shopping center can be ridiculous. It's small and can take quite a bit of circling to find a legitimate parking space.   Ultimately, if you are looking for your new go to ramen joint, this place should definitely be in the running. Don't take my word for it, check it out!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7_ewS4ZtDeoztoHL_z5D8w.text: First time here and I have to say it was pretty good. Better than I expected. Our server was really nice and let us switch tables because every time the door was opened we felt a cold wave coming in and we had our baby with us. The flavor of the ramen is good. They do need a better spicy sauce; may be like an oil based sauce.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7riL-piGK6KVGG4CbxvlPA.text: Monta Ramen was great!! We needed a quick ramen recovery after our long day exploring Vegas. It's definitely good to find an affordable and delicious restaurant since there are so many world class buffets in the casinos. The ramen portions were decent, but I ordered extra noodles just in case. The broth was also well made and was rich with flavor.   I'll definitely stop by on my next trip to Vegas!

UKw3b6eFror8NepgaSJ_ZA.text: The best shoyu ramen i've tasted so far.. we've been looking for a good ramen house off strip here in Las Vegas.. loo and behold we found this place.. the place is small and if you go probably on a busy time you're gonna wait a little bit.. we went around 11pm so we've waited a little bit.. the food is cheap.. not so much choices that's why you can tell that the food is good.. that is just my theory though.. but dude they're shoyu is the best.. its a must try here in vegas..

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. So far the best shoyu ramen that i&#39;ve tasted..

GyhWVqKNu6mYRNCykufvrg.text: Good ramen and cheap  -1 star bec we just sat and the girl is in a hurry to get our order. Mine was ready bec i saw the menu in the yelp but my husbnd is not, he ordered is ramen and looking on the menu but the girl is grabbing it already.lol

Ku-DKTaGkwkVqJuzldZNBA.text: This was my very first experience with ramen in a restaurant. I guess I was expecting a lot more. The flavor was okay, although very salty. You have to pay extra for every single thing, and there were several things I would expect that were not offered. Frankly, the flavor was not much better than a cup of noodles from the grocery store.  Except there were mushrooms. Lots and lots of mushrooms. Which would have been nice if they warned me on the menu, since I am allergic.   I don't know why this place is aso popular with the hipsters. It is cramped. It is tiny. It isn't that clean. It plays classic rock and has no particular decorating scheme. Seating is seriously uncomfortable. Parking sucks.  They sat me at the very first itty bitty wooden bar stool right by the kitchen and beverage machine (blowing hot air, adding insult to injury). Every time someone walked by, they hit me in the ass.
