I couldn't see more action as a pole dancer. Half way through my meal, I gave up.   The place was absolutely stoking hot. If the A.C. is out, warn people. I would have gone to the store, grabbed some Top Ramen, and gone home to add my own cilantro, lime, corn, and spicy seasonings, been cool, and not been groped.  I simply do not get the lines here. If this is what it's all about, perhaps ramen is not for me.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Had to pick out the millions of mushrooms. And, canned tea? Really?

7eFTnkaJJLK3H6mkdDjGfw.text: Got here about 15 minutes before opening so we waited in the car. There were some people waiting outside of the restaurant.  5 minutes before opening we decided to wait in line because more people came.  10 minutes after opening the place was packed!! I thought damn this place must be good!  I had the miso ramen and gyoza. Miso ramen was really good! Perfectly cooked ramen and a tasty broth. One of the best ramens I've had. On the table was pureed garlic and shredded ginger both not needed. Gyoza was slightly burnt and just okay.  Service was good. Prices are reasonable.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pureed garlic/ shredded ginger. Not needed.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza, just okay. Slightly burnt.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen, very good!

fJL9Un_qVj7S9GZor6EwxQ.text: Just came back from a very nice dinner. Price is extremely reasonable, food tasted great. What's not to like. Ah, yes the wait, can't blame them if they're good and reasonable. Love this place, will surely come back!

ujKNSDQrOeLz7avnLQicOA.text: Short wait time, quick service. Broth really tasty. No hot water, even green Tea came in a can.

FJgnH3dfDtp2jnhOuLXLkw.text: In the beginning, I was going to rate the place 4 stars. The restaurant itself is very small and compact; nothing really visually appealing. Although there isn't a lot on the menu, I still come back every time. It is always busy here so be prepared to wait in a small compacted space, as there is only 5 tables and a long bar. I used to think that the ramen here is the same at every ramen place, although after going to places like omoide and then coming back to Monta, I can conclude that Monta is the best ramen place here. The noodles are so flavorful, something you won't get at a place like omoide. Of course omoide as great other food, but for ramen, I highly recommend this place. The meat here is also very fatty (which, in my opinion, is the best part of the meat), thus making the meat something you would want to savor and eat slowly throughout eating the ramen. Typically, I order the tonkatsu which is 6.95, probably the cheapest ramen I've had. Typically I pay for tonkatsu for 7.50. Of course there are other ramen that are around 7.50 but I, being cheap, prefer my usual.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

tmxn4FQqIyDoEW-3rQGZbw.text: What ana amazing experience. You are also able to do takeout while keeping the noodles separate and cook them at home which is super easy. Delicious! Spicy tonkotsu is my favorite and i highly recommend to try it.

-uj0nL53uWjfltEHPSJ3kQ.text: I was craving something soupy homey post-a-usual-Vegas-night, ya know?! So Yelp to the rescue, I found this spot not too far from the strip, we headed out right away.   BEWARE, the place is so small and so popular. At 11:40 AM on a sunday morning, only a few minutes after they opened, the place was already FILLED. My bf and I snatched the last few seats at the bar. Ended up being a fun experience! We watched the nice chefs prepare our meals ;)  Don't even try to get a big party in here... I think the largest table fits 6 people?  Parking: good size shared lot  Service: good, quick? Gets a little busy and they might need more servers..  FOOD: come here for the RAMEN, I mean... why would you come to a ramen shop for... fried rice =.= I gotta admit the flavor here is a quite different from all the tonkotsu i've had in LA? But it's a worth-trying difference!  +Tonkotsu ramen (4/5) it was very very RICH , THICK and FLAVORFUL, maybe it's because i'm not Japanese and can't appreciate the ultra richness, it felt a bit over whelming at the end of the bowl. Maybe the tonkotsu-shoyu would be a good texture.  +the flavored egg (5/5) omg, please do add this to your bowl, it is soooooo gooood, im drooling a bit just writing this review. I wish they can just make this part of the bowl instead of an add-on  +pork belly rice bowl (4.5/5) it was really good! moist and flavorful, one of the better pork belly bowls i've had!!! Do order this instead of the fried rice  -why is the "spicy" upgrade costs extra?!?!??! RAWR  OVERALL, my bf and I had a solid lunch for a decent price tag. It gave us enough energy for the rest of the day exploring Vegas :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with added corn and flavored egg (a must)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. You can see your food being made!

P1yKZ5otAaJVXd49sNJESg.text: On my short trip to Las Vegas, I visited again on my last day here. For the first time in my ramen dining experiences, I got the tonkotsu + shoyu ramen and it was stellar. Very light compared to the tonkotsu alone but it was perfect for this 89 degrees and sunny lunch day. There was still a line at lunch but it went by pretty quick without the servers rushing the tables. I must say, you have something great here Monta - a rich tonkatsu broth, very light and clean tonkatsu shoyu broth that did not make me feel heavy at all, and fine servers who know how to do their job. Keep up the great work and food - I will visit on my next trip Vegas. Thanks!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 1st time having the green onion -added texture to Every bite but the flavor was not quite explosive or present as I thought. Great touch tho
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

9TgqhZoxzERKnVaccdYcSA.text: I wanted to try this the best ramen in vegas so I took a cab ride all the way to Monta in Chinatown. I'd say it's on par with with some of the better ramen places in Toronto but definitely not mindblowing. The tonkotsu broth is very creamy and the charsiu is thin but very flavourful and fatty. Definitely not a healthy meal. Also the broth was too salty to drink unfortunately. One more tip: they only take credit card if you spend over $10. I had to order extra charsiu and also 75 cent green onion to reach the $10 mark. Big mistake with the green onion. They put enough green onion on top to fit 4 meals probably. Yikes. A bit overkill.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. What happens when you order green onion to go with your ramen.

crugGwALOtFGbU43WgBldA.text: **** WORST SERVICE I HAVE EVER EXPERIENCED IN MY 23 YEARS ****   I wish I could give this place 0 stars for the service I experienced today. Two of the bowls of ramen had pork missing. One had no pieces of pork and one was missing one piece. We told the waiter this and he did not apologize. The first words out of his mouth were "are you sure?". You're in the service industry and this is how you speak to customers...   I also went up to the waiter to let him know how wrong he was that he did not apologize. He cut me off and said "can I talk first?". I was literally shocked. How can anyone be so rude. Obviously we didn't leave any tip.    Clearly we wanted to cheat you out of three paper thin slices of pork.

LMjEQ-yIkdcuutrHMuUZTg.text: Came to this location with a good friend for the first time. Never really saw this interior of the restaurant on Yelp but damn, it's pretty small if you ask me. I would always hear the hype about this place and how AMAZING the ramen is here. When I arrived, we had to wait 15 minutes, which is tolerable.   Parking can be a problem in this area but we Uber'd here this time so we didn't have to worry about that.   I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen. Starting prices were pretty cheap and there are extra toppings for you to add. I added extra tamago (egg) and extra pork. Long story short. These add ons can definitely add up the costs to your ramen.   We ordered the fried rice also which was really good and the pork belly which comes in small or large. In all honestly, food was good but the BROTH is a different story. The broth is too thick for my liking and it was too creamy that I couldn't even drink all of the broth. I feel like the broth was on the salty side and I asked my friend and he agreed.   Funny thing is, whenever my group of friends crave ramen, we would always separate and go to different ramen joints. Half of them would go to Monta and the other half would go to Ramen Sora. But in all honesty, it depends on the person because we all have our different takes on ramen. Monta, is good but the broth just ruins it for me.

mUiF3zD6tn6s7h78E8tkIg.text: Monta Ramen is a tiny shop sandwiched between  Kung Fu Tea and a sushi restaurant. While I understand the aim to look like an authentic Japanese ramen shop, they really ought to consider how impractical it is to have a large customer base with only a few seats. We waited in the cold outside for about half and hour, and then were able to squeeze our way inside the door to wait for another 20 minutes or so. There is a wait list that fills up very quickly.  I ordered the miso ramen with an egg, and a side of gyoza. The noodles were perfect but I found the miso broth to be incredibly salty and it overpowered everything. The egg was pre-boiled and probably stored in the fridge because it was cold in the middle. That was disappointing, as I paid over $1 extra for it and the yolk wasn't creamy at all. The gyoza were your typical run of the mill dumplings and tasted like they came from a frozen package rather than "handmade" as the menu stated.   Overall, this visit to Monta was a total letdown. I've heard such good things- perhaps we caught the cooks on a bad night?

-YYAXtHYezM0iUY9adCFUQ.text: Came in to a full restaurant but we only waited 10-15minutes before we were seated. We ordered the top 3 dishes and I have to say I like the Tonkotsu Shoyu broth the best. The Nitamago topping was a bit cold though, and they only gave two slices of chasu for each dish. A bit overpriced toppings, but overall okay for the price and taste.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My order: Tonkotsu Ramen

bMoq2FzWiB0rpj7i-Y1dbw.text: I always see a lot of people lined up here whenever I go to Kung Fu Tea next door so I finally made a point to go try it. Wasn't let down! I got there just before 11:30 when they open and there was already a line waiting. They are fast and efficient however as they seated everyone and started taking orders right away.   Ordering is easy as the menu is relatively simple with 4 types of broth to choose from, a few additional toppings you can get, and a few other dishes such as gyoza and rice dishes. I got the Tonktsu-Shoya ramen and it was superb. Very flavorful broth and the whole thing tasted excellent.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dudes in the kitchen

oT_2qmhCi_13GqaGuEwnDw.text: I expected this place to be much bigger, but I'm kinda glad that it was small. Cute. Cozy. We went on a rainy day, so ramen was perfect! Anyway, food was so good!!!! Ordered the shoyu ramen and the kimchi fried rice, both with no meat. Did not expect it to be so big for the price. Me and my daughter shared both dishes & was super full. Will def go back for more & try the other ramen.   Side note: I was kinda bummed they didn't have lemon slices for the water until I realized their water doesn't have that tappy taste like other restaurants. Extra points for sure!

nyQh5f9Sli_TX1xUb3F9MA.text: Love this place, 2nd time here, good ramen selections. Simple and delicious, must try the pork belly bowl.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wIqtafvKj14WSb78JpclGQ.text: I love the spicy tonkatsu with black garlic oil.  I will dream of this meal for many months in my far away mountain town in the snow. Why are all my favorite ramen houses in warm climates????

poOe8VQX4GvQdEifq7Qvrw.text: We stopped in on a Thursday evening around 6pm. I expected to wait as the seating is very limited, but we got lucky and were seated right away. There are only 5 tables and bar seating. So expect a wait on a busy night!  We ordered the tonkotsu ramen, fried rice, pork belly bowl and a side of kimchi. The ramen is very reasonably priced. $6.95-7.95 not including any add ins (seasoned egg, nori, corn, etc). The pork belly bowl was so good. The meat was tender and very flavorful. I absolutely loved the broth in the ramen. It was rich and not too salty.  The service was really quick. It was a bit warm inside but it's summer in Vegas and they have an open kitchen.  Next time I'm craving ramen, I will definitely be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with seasoned egg, pork belly bowl (right) and fried rice.

0t-4rkLEV43P0qgUBqY8OQ.text: The food and service deserves 5 stars. The only issues I had with Monta is the wait, waiting area, small parking lot, and tiny dining area. Otherwise, it was a great experience to sit right at the bar in front of the noodle chefs. What is unique with Monta Ramen is that the ramen noodles were a bit thinner that traditional ramen and had texture while eating. Broth was thicker than what I have experienced with ramen soups. The broth was almost like a gravy than soup but extremely tasty. What I discovered was that the locals will take the leftover broth home and purchase an extra side of ramen noodles to go with it. If you ever want to get your pork belly fat fix, the pork belly over rice bowl is a must have. It was well seasoned and the price is very reasonable. The pork belly didn't have any lean parts and basically all fat. If you don't mind that, it's all good.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RziaqhahyPN_LxypPAjcFA.text: I'm fairly new to the ramen world, but I really love this place. The only thing I don't like is how small the restaurant is, but if you with a small group (SMALL) it's perfect for an intimate dinner.   My friend and I were quickly seated at the bar and we both ordered the Miso Ramen. What I love about the bar is that you're able to see your ramen being made/prepared. I also love that the bar area has a super convenient cubby place to hold your bag while you eat =^.^= (i appreciate the little things). Dinner came out super fast and it was very hot and filling, so for the price (less than $10.00) and the amount, ya girl is def coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen, hot &amp; fresh

2O_fWJuAArLw-atONrwAzg.text: This hole in the wall place is always packed, and there's a very good reason for it.  No matter what, there will be a wait. Prepare for it. Even Tuesday at noon, there will be a wait. You can't avoid it, but it's a good land mark to find the spot.  Their food is simple, no over the top fancy shamancy ramen. You choose what toppings you want, otherwise nothing else fancy. This is your basic, wholesome ramen. But this amazing, it will be hands down the most amazing ramen you can get your hands on. The broth is so... I can't even describe it. It's perfected.  I will be coming back to eat more of thing ramen, this place is a keeper.

Jt-mkgtqYE3-OxZt68_1gA.text: This place was recommended to me by a friend because of their melt in your mouth chashu pork (which did not disappoint).   We already knew that the parking lot is tight and usually pretty crowded, so we parked in the lot across the street, and walked over. The restaurant is also very small, 9 seats at the bar and maybe 6 or so tables.   The menu is simple. Handful of different types of ramen soups, toppings, misc bowls, and appetizers. We ordered some gyoza to start which was good but nothing special.   My mom and I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen with nitamago egg and extra chashu pork. It came out quickly. The broth was a bit too thick for my liking and the noodles too thin. The chashu pork was definitely the highlight of the dish. It really does just melt in your mouth.   My little brother ordered the shoyu ramen which came with thicker noodles that I would've preferred. He said it was good but pretty salty.   Overall we enjoyed our meal but weren't blown away by any means. The two star rating is because later that evening my mom and I both got sick to our stomachs. My brother was fine, so we think it may have had something to do with our tonkotsu soups. I probably would pass on this place in the future or at least on the spicy tonkotsu ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu ramen with nitamago egg and extra chashu pork

ximxpZF76auYvFNgIngKeQ.text: Found this place on a wintery night with hubby while searching for a place with some "decent" ramen noodle soup. Though small in size and there appears to always be a line out the door, this place was definitely worth the wait. The broth of their soup is so rich in flavors -- a total " umami" experience for you "foodies!" We ended up ordering extra noodles to " stretch" our soup so we could take the rest home . My only 'complaint' is that parking is near impossible in the extremely small shared parking lot and street parking isn't much better.

lTq6ZN6B5a7KBnQkBJvZUw.text: A nice gem on the outskirts of Las Vegas  When we got here it was crowded! Man for small shop like this, there sure is a lot of folks waiting. Especially when we left--there was a huge crowd at the door and we couldn't even get out.  I got the spicy tonkotsu ramen which was amazing. Just the right amount of spiciness, and a rich broth paired with noodles that had a pleasant thickness and softness. The rice was ok, but not that great--definitely just go for the ramen.  Overall, a place that you have to visit at least once if you are in town

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly rice

WYLuDcQVPd00_HbhMfP6VA.text: I was recommended to this place by a friend who told me this ramen place was the best joint there is in Vegas. He sure was right! There was already a line before it even opened. On top of that, you know this place is bomb especially the fact that people are willing to wait in line outside in the blazing 109 degree sun.   I ordered the black garlic ramen which tasted amazing. I'm a huge garlic lover so having able to taste the garlic was a big deal for me since other places like to skimp on the garlic. The charsiu was crazy tender and the broth was oh so flavorful.   10/10 would come back if I'm ever in the area. Did I also forget to mention that the ramen here is stupid cheap. Deliciousness at such an affordable price I would say.   PS: if you're able to sit at the bar, do it. It's so cool to be able to see the chefs prepare the ramen bowls.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. black garlic ramen

oXBp4sN3TJ6vwgrHG7M_zA.text: Great prices, very good and friendly service. They made and served food quickly. Food was very tasty. Definitely would come back and recommend. Only tricky thing would be it's a little smaller for bigger groups.

lyf8syfLgsfuWicZQ5sQAA.text: Great place. We went the first night we were in town. About a $8 Uber ride from the strip in a Chinatown. Very small but we didn't want more then a half hour on a Thursday night around 6pm. After living in Japan for 10 years, I am constantly searching for Ramen that will transport me back to Japan and this did that.  Had the miso ramen, fried rice and gyoza. All were to the standards of a Japanese ramen house. I'll be coming back every single time I'm in town.

CKto398EMdNIfDNAkZuw0g.text: I've had this place bookmarked for months. My boyfriend and I finally flew out to Vegas to try this amazing place. In terms of flavor, Monta puts other ramen houses to shame. Very creamy, rich, and thick broth. I had never tasted anything like it before! The flavor really sticks to the noodles and creates quite an experience. Definitely get the tonkotsu for yourself. Pork belly melts in your mouth and the eggs aren't overcooked.   Would recommend to others if you're into thick, flavorful broth. Can be a wait during peak hours.

PhkrTi-TzVDM4bss0dIeFg.text: Probably personal taste but I didn't think their broth was that flavorful. I always get shoyu everywhere and theirs fell short. I will say that my husband loved the black ramen. The potstickers were pretty good. I really liked the fried rice, uniquely Japanese. Maybe bonito in there?

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

E3Ep48qDrBn32J3vvVuDeg.text: We ordered a Kuro Tonkotsu Ramen w/ Black Garlic Oil, Tonkotsu Ramen, and Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen.   I didn't try the Spicy Tonkotsu myself but I think the Kuro tastes better than the Tonkotsu. The addition of the garlic oil makes a big difference in my opinion. It makes it much more flavorful. The chashu was good but I didn't like the skin around it. The bamboo shoots weren't that good. Kinda bland.   The complaints I'd have is that the soup is actually a little thicker and saltier than I'm used to. Just a little. Also the noodles are on the slightly softer side.   I also tried their nitamago (flavored egg) which I think were very average. I'm very picky with my eggs so these eggs were too hard and cooked for my liking. Also a bit dry because of that.   By the way, be careful with the chopsticks. They don't break very cleanly so just watch out for splinters.   Price was pretty good. 3 bowls of ramen + 1 extra serving of noodle + 1 egg came out to be about $28 + tip.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Tonkotsu Ramen w/ Black Garlic Oil
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Really small ramen shop
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

lcB7f___Nqa20uyqf-NrgA.text: SUPER SAD they still have not opened the one in Henderson back up!   None the less this is still my kids FAVORITE Ramen spot.  We came here for my daughters birthday dinner (by request). We waiting for about an hour for a table, party of 3.   That is really the only downfall about this place is the wait. Unfortunately waiting outside for a hot soup, on a hot summer evening was NO fun. It smelled like sewer outside the doors.   Service is Usually pretty good here, everyone is nice, but very rushed as they only have  a few tables in the establishment. It's really a place to go for a quick bite, literally.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

BbVH4pySRWckx206z7YgfQ.text: If this is the best ramen place in Vegas, I'm glad I don't live here.  I've been spoiled by good ramen places in LA and OC area so this really didn't do it for me.  And the long wait was just annoying.  I really don't get why this place always has a long ass line.  I drove by here few different times during the day and there was always a line.  My wife and I got here about 20 minutes before it opened and there were already three people waiting in line.  In about another 10 minutes there were about 20 people in line.  This was on a Tuesday.   Ramen wasn't bad, it just wasn't my style.  The tonkotsu broth was too heavy for my taste.  It was so thick, it was almost like eating melted gelatin.  The chashu pieces were super thin and flimsy, and the flavored egg, which was an added option, just tasted like normal hard boiled egg.  Service was friendly but they try to rush you out (politely).  Can't blame them since there's always a line of people waiting outside.   Look at the board by the entrance area for extra menu items which are not in the main menu, such as spicy tonkotsu and kuro (black garlic oil) ramen.  If you live in Vegas, it's worth a try.  If you are from LA or OC like me, skip it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seems like there is always a line no matter what time or day
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ZkNPgne0gHNaSf6bP2L6VA.text: My friend brought us here saying it was the best ramen he's had in the US, and he's tried a fair number of places. The rest of us didn't think it was that special, but we enjoyed it. There were chunks of salt in the kimchi fried rice that I had to spit out, the gyoza filling was a bit mushy and looked suspiciously pink, and the spicy tonkatsu ramen was very salty. The black garlic oil ramen was very flavorful, almost earthy, but not overpowering like the spicy tonkatsu. The service was great, we got seated fast and food came right up after we ordered.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Kudo Ramen black garlic oil

AthwnG6VH0iZOsUYnz6DBQ.text: I've had a lot of ramen in my life time....  this is the BEST ramen I have had so far. Seriously incredible. Best flavor. Great soup and amazing noodles. There location is small but their service is fast. Would definitely come here again and again

YBg-NKjmNbdo83gOm-6tCg.text: This place was suggested by someone who was from Japan and was a big foodie. How could you not take the word of someone who should know what good ramen noodle taste like. Sure enough, I have now been to this place multiple times. I have tried the different ramen. My favorite ramen here is the black garlic tonkatsu ramen. You have the option to order extra noodle, chashu, eggs, and other options if you want. The service here is excellent, I always try to sit at the bar because you can see the chefs prepping the food. This is a small but quaint place so it's good for a date but not for a big party. They do have appetizers too such as gyoza. You can stuff yourself silly here without breaking the bank. I always leave satisfied and I promise that this would be my first place of chose when coming back to Las Vegas. I later learned that other people that I know who are ramen connoisseurs have also visited Monta. You should not hesitate about coming here.

OcOi2U_TVVOOmwH6Mc_-_A.text: My favorite Ramen place in town, flavor wise!! This review is solely based off of the food and service. I actually hate the location and the seating isn't very comfortable. But, they have the BEST spicy Tonkatsu in town..

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

u_yTG6FTs04L_xkEmbjWYw.text: Really good ramen, but really small place.  The restaurant only seats 27 people.  Luckily, the staff are really quick, and the wait time mostly depends on how fast people eat.  Prices are extremely reasonable for what you get.  And what you get is a well-crafted, carefully prepared ramen, with a complex broth that you will find nowhere else.  The tonkatsu (pork) soup base is wonderfully complex and rich, and quite frankly some of the best broth I have ever had.  You can tell they took great care in preparing this soup base.  By the way they even pre-warm the soup bowls before putting your ramen bowl together!  Mixed with strips of seaweed and bamboo shoots, and charsiu, this would be great on a cold winter day (or even a hot summer day like I had it).  The noodles were a little different from what I am used to.  They were a little thinner, light, and with a clean finish.  The gyoza was ok.  They definitely use a lot of ginger.  Very light, and not as dense as most others.  If you want a well-crafted bowl of ramen and reasonable prices... this is the place.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1BWsI-QdVQngOqINotdqlw.text: Love finding little gems like this in Vegas. Its totally off the strip in Chinatown, with just a few seats. You sign yourself in on the waiting list and wait to be seated. I got seated pretty quickly and ate at the bar.   Service was good and food came out quickly. Each bowl of ramen is $6.95 and comes with chashu already, but you can add more toppings if you want. I ordered the Tonkotsu, substituted the thin noodles for the medium thick wavy noodles and added a seasoned egg and corn. Pork broth was a little thick and salty for my liking, and I wish the chashu pieces were a little thicker but overall a good meal for less than $10.

CJWZ1tLT4lfo6DYioCQz1w.text: The ramen was super tasty & there was a good portion for the price! I feel like many good/popular ramen places are typically around 12/13 dollars, so to see that a bowl of ramen here was less than 10 dollars and the quality was good was nice. The inside of the restaurant was small & there was a wait, but the service was pretty quick and I was seated around 5 minutes from arriving. The food came pretty quickly as well. I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen and the broth was delicious & the noodles were very chewy and easy to eat. The slices of meat were a bit thin, and I ended up losing it in my soup a few times since there was so little and it kept breaking apart easily. However, they were very generous with their portion of noodles. For two bowls of ramen and a can of soda, our meal only came up to around $18, so it is very affordable. Definitely coming back here next visit!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

DMoHz1Noggni62nWULbGyw.text: Super small joint. I had the tonkotsu with thin noodles and the hub hub had the spicy ramen with thick, wavy noodles.  The tonkotsu noodles were pretty thick for being labeled "thin", which works out for the better because I prefer thick ramen noodles.  The first time we went here I thought it was one of the best ramen I have ever had but this time, though still good, it isn't the best.  With that said, for the price you can't beat it!

OmYe-i0X7Dq36eL-jWAIHw.text: We had the spicy miso ramen (spicy sauce on the side) with an additional order of tea egg. Great flavor all throughout! Almost up to par as Santouka! The pork was very tender and the egg was cooked to perfection. Nicely seasoned with mushrooms, scallions, and bamboo shoots. The place is small but we didn't wait for late lunch at 3pm, although tables were still filled. My kids got the shoyu ramen and that was great as well! Would def come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen. The pork was very flavorful and tender
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen and Shoyu Ramen behind it. Spicy sauce on the side ( = spicy miso ramen) Great flavors!

JyqaCAMeMoeostc-lPI6zA.text: My husband and I was in Vegas and had a craving for ramen. We were just going to look for something on the strip but decided to go off course and try something new. We found this place by looking for "best ramen in Vegas" and so we just had to try it. The ramen was really good! When we got there, it was a full house but we didn't have to wait long which was nice. I probably wouldn't recommend this for big groups since it's a fairly small restaurant, around 5 tables and then bar seating. The noodles were refreshing and the soup base wasn't too salty. The Spicy Miso Ramen isn't on the menu but since that what I always have, I asked if they were able to make it which they did to perfection. The pork was a little too fatty for my taste but my husband loved it! I've also never had hot green tea from a can before which was pretty interesting (in a good way). Overall, it was a good dining experience and I would definitely come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hot Green Tea in a can!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Miso Ramen

ENaxPVMsZ_39ui9Ub6CsHA.text: Best local japanese noodle house when my friends is visiting from out of town , i always bring them here  Noodle soup is very tasty and nice Most of noodle restaurants in las vegas is too salty here lol but here good

0m9VxbXhv5jjDjt_l85o8g.text: Came to Monta based upon word of mouth recommendations and was pleasantly relieved we made the right choice in coming to eat there. I had the Miso Ramen and the broth was a delivery of full body. It wasn't bland or too saltly or just average and so I was a happy camper. I had added the eggs and corn to my order. It was like a partyin my mouth. The pork was cooked perfectly and the portions were ideal. I will definitely come back the next time I'm in Vegas and a Ramen fix!

ZXd0CcB2W-OCyoX5dfxMcg.text: This is a review long overdue and mainly serves as a basis for comparison for ramen joints. I remember this place as being somewhat the Holy Grail of ramen for LV ramen. I can remember mostly the frustration of having to wait to be seated for about 30 minutes for lunch, my wife couldn't believe that we would have to wait (of course) because Yelp put these guys on map let alone because we were on vacation... I'm glad I take pictures cause I would not remember what we had otherwise. It makes sense to me that my son and I would get the Tonkotsu Ramen although I cannot remember why they distinguish between straight Tonkotsu Ramen yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... and Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen yelp.com/biz_photos/mont.... I must have ordered extra chasiu signaling the extra fatty pork belly as all of our bowl had some thin slices of regular pork already. The eggs we ordered extra look soft and slightly runny. It also makes sense to me that my wife would be the maverick and order the Shoyu Ramen yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... which is a chicken/vegetable based stock. It also makes sense to me that she would order a kimchi on the side to break up the heaviness of the soup yelp.com/biz_photos/mont...; that and the fact that I don't care for anything really spicy... Upon further review, it seems that the base bowl of noodles wasn't enough as we two porkers (the guys) ordered extra noodles for $1.50 more yelp.com/biz_photos/mont.... I also remember thinking that the wash basin was pretty trendy for an otherwise small ramen joint... yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... I think that Monta is going to be a one time deal, especially since we found another place that we like (Fukumimi) where the wait isn't nearly so bad...

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 091012:  fancy sink in the men&#39;s room...
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 091012:  Kaedama ($1.50)...
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 091012:  Tonkotsu Ramen, Nitamago and Chasiu extra...

-igKq7uQI6QpLb_V_1t_RQ.text: Great ramen. Quick Service. It's perfect for a chilly night and no hassle dinner. Make sure you sign yourself in right when you get there. Our wait was only about five minutes and the good was well worth it from the kim chi fiend rice to the shoyu ramen. Highly recommended

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

SJi2oXPT8DfJF1f5rRB0oA.text: Their Kuro Ramen was soooo good. The black garlic oil had a nice kick to it. The pork was so soft it melts in your mouth. Wish I had order a triple order of the pork had I known. One of the better ramen joints I've had in awhile.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. They were having a special Tonkotsu bowl w/ black garlic oil. The pork and noodles melted in your mouth. Should&#39;ve ordered two!

BA27AnxFeK6EgULe1g0Bdw.text: Best ramen I have had so far!  We ordered the Miso and Kuro (Tonkotsu with black garlic oil) ramen and they were both amazing.  The broth in the tonkotsu was thick and tasty.    Noodles and pork were both perfectly cooked.  Normally I try not to drink too much broth because it's so fatty and unhealthy, but the broth was so tasty I drank it all.    The restaurant is small and the line can get long so be prepared to wait if you come in during the lunch or dinner rush.  The service is fast but don't come here if you're expecting to hang out for hours.    Highlights:  Quick service.  Prices are very reasonable.  About $8 to $10 for ramen.  Kuro and Miso ramen are amazing!  Lowlights:   Lines can be long so be prepared to wait during rush hours.  Summary:  This off-the-strip gem is a definitely must eat if you're visiting Vegas.  Go with the Kuro and you will not be disappointed!

SIYXsHEQrN4dejtPVHgTlQ.text: Oh Monta..a place I can go to escape the craziness of Las Vegas and enjoy the delicious simplicity of ramen.    You can count on the place being busy.  Not the ideal place for big parties.    The broth is superb.  I usually have the cha-shu with an egg.  Perfect hangover cure.    When in Rome, eat Monta,

84uOBdSaSJmmwhUOCLPgjw.text: Read all the hype on this place and finally went to see what it was all about. Glad I did. Got there early and there was already a line building up. The line eventually got crazy. But the ramen here was fantastic! I've had ramen all over the world but this was one of the BEST ever. I realize waiting in line sucks but this place was worth the wait. I tried the black garlic oil Kuro ramen and it was hands down the best bowl of ramen I ever had. We also tried the spicy tonkotsu ramen and it had great flavor as well. Best to get here 30 mins early and just wait before the line becomes crazy but you will be glad you did.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic oil Kuro ramen

kXHZhyEJv7gZ70Yx74KOVw.text: This place is awesome!  Just discovered it thanks to other Yelp reviews. Finally got my noodle fix in LV!  They also have a larger newer Henderson location. But this one is the original....  Delicious!!!  Lots of pork options.  Vegetarians & Vegans can hold the pork and egg on many dishes.  Great find.  Hidden Gem!

aaqhXxqFpu2mf3iAvi_SKA.text: We actually took a cab to get to THIS place? My gf was raving about it because apparently it was suppose to be "really good". We decided to go because it was cold in Vegas anyway so ramen would warm us up!   Ehh I think where I am from, ramen is much better. There was quite a wait, the place was itty bitty! I didn't even end up getting ramen just because I didn't want to bloat and be all big before going out. I went with the Regular Fried Rice. I mean there wasn't anything amazing about it. It was like ordinary rice that I could've whipped up myself!   My gf got the ramen. The broth was okay. I've had better. The noodle on the other hand was super fresh. It had a crisp to it when you bit into it too.   The cool thing about our experience was we sat at the bar so we were able to see the chefs prepare all the ramen bowls and cook the meats and what not. What bothered me the most about this place is its efficiency and service. They are super slow and move like ants here! Nothing is speeding them up and I feel like I waited about 30 minutes for my food on top of the wait before being seated.   Too bad this joint was sort of far from Chinatown...because I wanted to check that place out but it wasn't walking distance!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen

GAloOaP7Do5c6RQy8krtJg.text: Best spicy shoyu ramen I've ever had! Kimchi fried rice is excellent also. Definitely worth a wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy shoyu ramen

oyCsrItq4OqiGydqtJZFHQ.text: Food here is amazing and tastes fresh. Their ramen is perfect for a cold night. The restaurant itself is very very small so there is usually a wait but it is worth it. Small selection of beers but it is available. If you're a fan of Ramen this place is a must try.

RtSVzLhA0QXEeHlKO_niGw.text: Awesome! Came here late at night (around 11pm) before heading to the strip to gamble!   It was perfect for what we were looking for...  The ramen was great - great broth and a nice portion. The fried rice was AWESOME - addictingly good. The roe on top of rice was great - even better with the chili oil. The only meh thing was the gyoza.   Overall, cheap + tasty - what can you ask for?

SlSyUw0SNtr8MkRuTc7ILQ.text: Here are my expectations for a good ramen place. Just like when I was in Japan, I want the ramen to taste good especially the broth. I'm a fan of tonkotsu so I want the milky white broth to taste good. The prices have to be reasonable and the ramen needs to arrive quickly after I place my order. Of course, cleanliness is a given.  Monta Ramen meets my criteria. The taste is comparable to those I had in Japan. Their tonkotsu is very good. The prices are reasonable and service is quick. When I worked on the Las Vegas Strip, this was one of my favorite stops during lunch or after work. I highly recommend this place.

5mrUeQ3wQ7P-9mXQnVDQRA.text: I've never had Ramen that didn't have a plastic wrapper. I wanted to see what all the hoopla was. I got the Tonkotsu which was good but not much different from when I bust out my package of Nissin Top Ramen and add a slice of american cheese to create a creamy broth. The slices of roasted pork made the dish better but my meat had a lot of fat on it, I was glad I got extra, 2 slices was not enough for that huge bowl of noodles. The price is good and I feel like the dish was a good size. But I doubt I'll go out of my to go here again.

GQS3IjJ5pe-CpC58wJBMng.text: I like this place , the ramen is really good and the staff is pretty quick and helpful if you have no idea what you want. It is a bit cramped but it works. weekends and evening its usually packed so dont go if you are ready to chew your arm off. actually the whole plaza is cramped and hard to find parking.

ijb70_eJL6WpY2tX7HUCZQ.text: I used to frequent this place during my Vegas trips from L.A. I finally tried it again today after several years and boy was I disappointed. What happened? Tbis place is still so popular, but the ramen was so bad today. The rame  became less than par, just like the  average ramen places in L.A. I don't think I will come here again. I always go back and forth between their Tonkotsu Shoyu and plain shoyu. I had the Shoyu today.  It tasted like my ramen sat in the soup for a while, almost like take-out ramen. If you cannot get the original shoyu right, you cannot get anything right. I used to love their broth by just smelling it. Their pork chashu looked miaerable, now so thin, dry, and no fat. Where did the Japanese chefs go? Did they just train the locals and go back to Japan? Maybe the busier restaurants get, the harder it is to maintain the original flavor. TRULY SAD. Publicity and overrated reviews messed this place up.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu rame  with Shiraga Negi topping. Negi should be thinner. My ramen looked like ramen with splash of soup.

oGNtpQuOneMkUWgL-H332Q.text: The noodles were definitely decent in Vegas. We tried the tonkatsu and miso ramen. Miso ramen was too salty for me. Miso is such a strong taste that you should not have that first before you tried the tonkatsu one. The noodles they used for this was perfect(it was the ramen noodles)!  Tonkatsu ramen was really tasty. The pork melted in your mouth. So good! The fungus gave the ramen a crunchy/texture to it! You always want to have some sort of bamboo in your ramen, which they did! The only thing I thought was missing was the noodles. They served mines with the thin noodles. I preferred to have my ramen with ramen noodles! I don't know if they are out of those ramen noodles or that's what they served but I'll have to request that next time. Yes, there will be a next time! :) Overall, it was pretty delish!

MDAEy6o2Rhti2Y9Dg976Ow.text: You must sign up on the wait list at the door - good thing another customer told me, I'd NEVER have guessed that! The food was amazing, although yes, salty, as some have stated, especially toward the end of the bowl. I had added mustard leaf, that's very salty and will make it worse. I almost ordered extra noodles ($1.50) to compensate but was so full I just couldn't. The menu is very simple and service is quick. I'd gladly come here again... but there are so many great places to try, even in this very plaza, I doubt I'll get the chance.

76K7SxPkdbVkmaPW3SL7WA.text: maybe it's because i've been spoiled by los angeles and all their great ramen places...this ramen place was just average...definitely was not worth the 1hour+ wait that my party did for....but hey...since its vegas, this is the most legit ramen place in the area....so we though to try it..  since their most popular item is the shoyu ramen...i opt'd for the shoyu tonkotsu ramen....idk about you but they really go crazy with the shoyu....it was salty...a bit too salty for me...and after just eating a night of salty food at wicked spoon..omg...more salty food....  probably wont come back again unless i really want ramen and i'm stuck in vegas

sCiFC2zbTyHmsiwlO-VmSw.text: im not sure but for me the ramen i ordered is really salty.. i also tried the porkbelly bowl which is really good. but the place is small and waiting time  is long.

0pqHZ_bJPDKO6bJbK7Rw2Q.text: Perfect on a chilly weather. Price not bad and they've added some stuff in their menu, which is good. Place small if volume of people is a lot, but since this is an in and out eatery, wait is not bad (unless if there's a group of people hanging out just cz). One of my faves.

XcVCSD4XAZj2W4gaZI4GsA.text: This is the first and only ramen place I have been in Vegas.  We all got some sort of ramen... as for other stuff on the menu, i haven't tried so not sure if it's good... my friend got this rice thing with fish eggs on it... he had a few bites and left it... apparently not good. I plan on taking my parents to this place for ramen when they visit vegas! Highly recommend the ramen.

wwApJSYaBNbVrymXe6AmjA.text: Have been here twice in past 4 months. Recommend arriving at least 15 minutes before opening for seating. Good service. Ordered today and ramen was brought over in 5 to 10 mins. Fried rice was also delicious. I have tried the spicy tonkstsu and it had just the right proportions. Eggs are cooked to be slightly runny still. Very delicious overall. My bf has tried the dark garlic broth. Very delicious, altho slight overwhelming in flavor towards the end. Over all highy recommend this place.

2BtwErFgjWZpY0Yb1q8AnQ.text: Everything was so good.  Fried rice, wow.  Regular and kim chee.  We had the garlic black oil tonkotsu as a special and it was awesome.

YmBflBe6DK3QO7zDnbQduw.text: Super love this place! It's a nice cozy place expect long line during the day but it's great to go at night specially when it's cold, it's always nice to have warm soup that taste sooo good and the meat that melts in your mouth. ;0)  I'm always craving for their ramen, my favorite is the tonkotsu shoyu ramen. My husband and my cousin literally gave the meaning to "good to the last drop". Their fried rice is good also. Very reasonable price.

W0j2EM5XGEdmVrDdTmwrXg.text: Very fast service.  It is worth it if you are in a hurry. The ramen is good. The texture of the noodles is great.

F-GwRf_8xLzH4uC8x8taDA.text: I've been waiting for a good ramen joint for a long time.  I love that they have 3  different soup base with different noodle combinations.  Portions are small. Having a hot bowl of ramen during summer is not pleasant but at least they got lots of fans blowing.

TOs-heE3WJS0O8a5dG_PHA.text: I miss living in Japan, and Monta takes me back. They have their own unique broths they have created for their ramen dishes, and each one of them is absolutely amazing. The side dishes like gyoza (pot stickers), special fried rice, and kimuhi (Japanese kimchi) are all amazing on their own as well. You can also get delicious Japanese imported draft beer at a great price. I am absolutely addicted to this place. Fun atmosphere, amazing food, and delicious beer. If you've been eating Cup Noodle your whole life... please... please go discover what real ramen was meant to taste like. Monta is where it's at.

1Lt28PRSef5r1mLsr5TRPw.text: My husband and I are ramen snobs for sure, and this place was amazing.  One star short of 5 because they didn't have a straight chicken ramen.  Yeah, I know it's not traditional, but we're from L.A. and my husband is spoiled.  The tonkotsu is fabulous, and pairing with an icy cold Asahi made it even more so.    A tiny joint in Chinatown that is way worth the trip off the Strip - you'll spend less for dinner for two here than you will for one lousy drink at a Strip casino!

1hdIGnAh5bRUueIJv3kEpg.text: This place has the best ramen in Vegas! The place is very tiny but I love sitting at the bar where you get a full view of what's going on in the kitchen. I like to order the miso ramen with golden corn. I'm no expert in miso but it's the most delicious I have ever had! The fried rice and gyoza are also really good too although sometimes the gyoza comes out stuck together and rip when you pull them apart. Otherwise the service has always been great and friendly, but winter time is the best to go because they have no air-conditioning!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Heaven!!

9vbj2xWJmhCILXieoZhONw.text: Love quick service and delicious ramen. We always get gyoza fried rice and ramen when we go. The only downside is the place is so small so there is always a wait! Best bet is to get there as soon as they open. One of our favorite parts of visiting Vegas every year!!

Vx9Y2khWTVhXEz-QUGABuQ.text: I love their ramen!! taste so fresh and something that you can't have in Las Vegas.

txrBkkSDh8L9UWmF6eudhg.text: This is a small ramen place, they open at 1130 and expect it to be full by 11:45 most days.  They have a small collection of broth options, but the pork bone based one is the best. Get an extra order of the Chasu Pork, because it's unbelievably good. Inexpensive, fast and delicious ramen.  Best in Las Vegas in my opinion.

rawAkWp_hktjezqJ0WTILg.text: Ramen was just so-so. Noodles were not handmade. However, rice bowl with pork belly was great! Service is good. Always in line.

O5MVgYKXzdMI1A4VRe6qrg.text: Ramen is probably one of my top foods, and I've had a LOT of ramen. This place is still top for me out of my 21 years of eating, and I'm staying True to that statement until I'm proven wrong. Even after my first time coming here, I'm still craving it all the way from California. The noodles are absolutely cooked to perfection. The broth is, of course, so tasteful and hot, but so good that even in the heat of Las Vegas, you couldn't care about it. The meat is THE best meat I've ever had in ramen, hands down. It's so tender and savory, it just falls apart with ease. The next time you're in North LV, you GOTTA stop by. You'll come out sweating from the heat inside the restaurant mixed with the heat from the soup and the weather, but you'll come out completely satisfied. If you're not satisfied, I don't know what to tell you.

bkfR0qCAOvmnYWILvPelsw.text: This is my favorite ramen shop.  I am so glad they're now in Henderson.

7ZdHxfwhjyEZvqQWelZMhw.text: Small hole in the wall place, worth searching for. Limited menu, awesome place if you're craving for ramen.  Small menu, very reasonable.  every time I've been there I had to wait about 15 min.worth the wait

vmjpUWR4BRT8wlaJxbOKVA.text: This place was fabulous. They sat our party of four immediately and the food was delicious and quick to arrive. The place got pretty crowded by the time we left, and I could understand why! It was delicious and great prices, everyone in my party ended up getting two entrees for less than $20 and enough to take home left overs. Great find.

jQi6SpJFAtofpt5fHrYFiw.text: Wow. Just wow. I wish I could give this place an even higher rating. The reviews and recommendations really show how wonderful this place really is. The first time I came here was also the first time I had ever had ramen. It was a Thursday afternoon around 3:30-4. I was looking for a good local place with ramen as I was with my family and it was my dads suggestion we try ramen. We went to a place on the same street about 3 blocks down. The place was EMPTY I mean not even a single car in the parking lot. After doing some research on yelp I see that monta ramen is just down the street and was high rated with lots of reviews. We checked it out and it was packed! On a Thursday afternoon that really says a lot about the place especially when another similar place so close was completely empty. We waited a moment for a table to be ready as this place is kinda small and does not have much seating space. But do not be deterred by this! It is worth the wait. The waitress was very nice and recommended the pork/chicken broth combo which she said was the most popular. I was sooooo impressed. I can't describe how delicious. I've gone back twice and it has only been 5 days. Mind you I also do not live close by.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

yTI5pUghI8LrRY5Y9CDAcg.text: I truly love this little gem of a Ramen House, with its limited seating and understated elegance.  Okay let be honest, there's only one dish, served three different ways, with a few small sides dishes and add-ons. But boy do they make that one dish well.  The place is usually pretty busy, and there are few seats to choose from. But a chair at the bar provides somewhat of a show as the cooks stack the bowls to warm them in preparation of the noodles which they shake free of their excess water with a particular flare.  You're in and out in no time and if you leave hungry, you probably didn't ask the waitresses for help in making your decision.  On a side note: it's not uncommon to find yourself sitting next to a beautiful and fascinating young woman - just don't blow it.

A3YCfxLbSdcr4cFzVhccNQ.text: Its official; I made my quest here today and I'm already craving round 2. It's gooooood!  For those not in the know, I've been a ramen-iac since I was 12 and first learned how to cook myself a cup o' noodles. I spent several summers as a gawky teenager watching cartoons and gobbling noodles like a fiend. Over the years, and through thousands of packets of freeze-dried noodles I slurped onward. Kimchi flavor, Maruchan, Nissan, yam-noodles, dandan mien and instant jjangmyun, my adoration for the comfort of a big steaming bowl of chewy noodles drenched in broth steadily growing. I've tried Ichiza's, Shuseki's and making it myself- this tops the list. Ichiza's was close, but this place will most likely be my number one noodle-spot this winter.   Coming up to the restaurant, I wouldn't have thought it was open if it weren't for the neon sign saying so. There's plenty of parking and it's right across the street from the shopping center with Shuseki.   I sat at the bar as I was having lunch alone and wanted to see the action. One chef would feel out the proper amount of fresh noodles per bowl, roughly a fistful, and drop them into the boiling cauldron of water. On the other side was a large kettle of broth steaming away, ready at a moment's notice. In the background several men worked on various other tasks involving the pork and other side dishes. At the front of the bar was the Vegas Weekly magazine that mentioned them, as well as a Good-luck Kitty, which I thought was cute.  Today, I opted for the miso. At first I couldn't decide- I'd tried the miso flavors at other establishments, so should I continue the trend for consistency of comparison, or deviate and expand my horizons further. I opted for the miso with nitamago, or egg. It didn't take long before my noodles were politely presented to me.  The broth: Super porky. No MSG taste at all. Rich miso flavor-seemed like it was all white [sweet] miso. Great depth of flavor, with an intense, buttery mouth feel. Hit all the right notes and was intensely satisfying. Tastes like homemade.  Noodles: Al dente egg noodles. Chewy and lots of them! Much better than anything instant with great slurpability.   The egg: Beautifully cooked, creamy and custardy, it added an entirely new level of complexity to the broth and had an exceptional texture. Ichiza's eggs are close, but the one I had here was supple and gelatinous, cooked slowly and well. It was easily the best egg I've had in a restaurant this year.   Pork: My bowl came with 2 slices of succulent, fall-apart tender pork. I could pull bite-size pieces off using my chopsticks. Thousands of times better than the terrifying piece of pork we were served at Shuseki. The pieces were thin, but I was satisfied with the amount I was given. You can always order more if you're willing to pay the additional charge.    Extras: The ramen comes with bamboo shoots, a few pieces of mushroom and a mountain of green onion. You can also add minced garlic paste, benishoga [red pickled ginger], sesame oil, furikake mix, sesame seeds, what looked like vinegar & a couple of other options are available either through the menu or asking your server.  I found the portion large enough for a late brunch, tiding me over for hours and powering me through a trip to the dog park with 3 rowdy puppies. I'm extremely satisfied and happy with the meal I had here, and I bragged to several of my friends. I'm looking forward to trying the shoyu flavor next, as well as trying the spicy greens with it.   I'll be back very soon!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with green onion, bamboo shoots, mushrooms and a [hidden] hardboiled egg.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The straight up miso ramen with an added egg.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Good luck kitty! =^u^=

tfu58M_-sk81LglkBGTN1g.text: This place is a japanese Ramen Noodle Bar. I have no idea what the hell kind of customer service people expect from a damn noodle bar. I expect food that is delicious, which this place is, a decent price, which Monta is a little on the pricer for it's product type, but not for it's quality, and food that is fast, which Monta is as well.  If you go get the fried rice, and the ramen, any kind. That's all I have to say. I'm pretty sure I've eaten more food than you, if anything at least more calories, so just trust me when I say go here and eat!

jGg2iWGEDuCZzjsS_ExbmA.text: If given the choice of going out to eat vs. staying in, I never even think about where I might want to go, I always go to Monta. A good friend introduced me to this wonderful place a long time ago, and it's been my favorite spot ever since.  The quality of food and service is top notch, and they never disappoint. I order the Tonkotsu-Shoyu with extra pork belly and an egg. For such delicious food, the prices are astoundingly good. I honestly could not say enough good things about this place.  I've taken numerous people to this place, and will continue to do so. I've told out of town friends, and anyone that has mentioned a hankering for ramen, or food in general, to come here, because they have not lived until they've eaten the best ramen in town.   I wish there were more space for seating, but it's not really a problem if I have to wait. The reason there is a wait is because everyone knows how amazing this place is, and their food is well worth the wait. Well worth it.

ZeUcvmBk9nTm81he8wh65Q.text: I took a stool at the bar and ordered the Shoyu Ramen, small Pork Belly side, and a Oolong Tea. The pork came out first. The delicious pork was nestled onto a bed of white rice and was topped with green onions and some pickled carrots. For 3.95 this dish was the winner of the day. The green onion and pickled ginger perfectly counterbalanced the savoryness of the pork belly.   This place never disappoints.

Acnge0xRkMapoaZJhSXkaw.text: Good ramen but I wouldn't wait 1 hour just to have ramen. I went there right when they opened and got seated right away.

uU-Gg_VnlsjCRZD1luDe0w.text: Being a pretty lucky teen, I've had the chance to travel, and try many ramen shops around Las Vegas area, California, as well as Japan and Hong Kong. Though it is not up to what I have tried in Japan, it is pretty close.   This is a small ramen shop at the back of a shopping centre. Max occupancy is probably give or take 25-30 people max with option to sit at the bar or table. Staff gives a very friendly welcome upon entry. A lot of times, this restaurant is quite busy. The restaurant has a nice warm feeling (not due to the heat from cooking) but it resembles some ramen shops i have tried and seen in Tokyo, Japan.   Upon sight of the menu, the front cover has a little story of origins of ramen. When you see the selection of foods they provide, it is not much. This is one of the few places, that i really like, that don't offer a wide variety of foods. Not only do they specialize in what they offer, it is also the only thing they need because of how well made it is.   They have three broth selections. Tonkotsu, which is a pork bone based broth (usually slowly boiled and simmered for many hours to create a white flavor-filled broth), Miso, and Shoyu (soy-sauce based). Being a fan of tonkotsu ramen, that was the first broth i had tried and loved. Price range for the different soup is i believe 6.95 - 7.95 with Shoyu and tonkotsu being $6.95 and Miso at 7.95 [don't quote me on the pricing but i do remember the miso being more expensive than tonkotsu for some reason... you'd think the one with more work (tonkotsu) would be more expensive]  They offer a variety of toppings ($1 - $2.50 each) you can choose to add to the ramen as well, ranging from extra pork, green onions, corn, butter, some green vegetable (forgot the name). Hearing great things about their pork, that was what i had ordered as an additional topping. There is also the option of getting extra noodles for a small fee of $2.   Take note, there are two types of noodles they use between the 3 broths. I believe Tonkotsu uses one, while miso and shoyu uses another. They also offer sides like gyoza, pork over rice, etc.   Upon arrival of food, i was amazed how well the ramen looked. The soup had a deep white color, pipping hot freshly made. The soup was not thin but not thick as well. Not sure how to explain, but it was a broth that looked to be filled of flavor. As most people, the first thing to try was the soup. Upon tasting of the soup, I was amazed. The flavor of the soup was rich, extremely flavorful, not too salty or sweet. It was like, perfection was reached. The noodles were a little over al dente which was perfect for ramen. The table has spices that you can add on top of your ramen like chili oil and this spicy spice mix.   The pork they used was a 1/2 fatty 1/2 meat type of cut formed in a circular shape. Being of Asian origin, it was exactly how I liked it. As said before, the option of extra noodles was available so some of the pork was saved. They amount of noodles you get is quite an amount (usually wont expect too much for "additional noodles" but if anything, it may have been a slightly larger serving then that was in the original bowl. The additional noodles is given in a bowl, heated and ready to be thrown into your original soup.   Lets just say, every single time, i order a bowl of ramen, additional noodles.. and never have soup left over =]   Service is great. Food is great. Price is reasonable. Recommend to many friends and family. One of the best ramen places i've ever been to

PvrT6DgJXHo2IRvZ3eRnug.text: The food is delicious and the staff is very friendly, you guys just won a regular customer.

ppQ8s3VhZi8DC6eb9IHjRQ.text: So I went to Monta twice last week due to them adding two new flavors and I had to try them.    Kuro Ramen:  Kuro means "black" for all you japanophiles.  The color comes from them adding Ma-yu (not to be confused with ra-yu), which is sesame oil with roasted garlic which gives it garlic flavor while adding blackish color.  To be quite honest, this ramen was not good at all.  I was expecting a punchy garlic flavor which it had very little of, and the broth....damn....what happened?  It was bland.  It taste as bland as Ramen Shoku's tonkotsu.  I had to believe that they were using a different broth for this ramen as I tasted my daughter's tonkotsu and it was totally different.  I would give it 2 stars.  Pretty crappy ramen if you ask me.  I would NOT recommend it.    Spicy Tokotsu Ramen:  This is somewhat similar to spicy miso at Ramen Sora in a way tha they just add spicy miso which you can mix to give it a little kick.  The base Tokotsu ramen is identical and I enjoyed the extra spicy kick to the regular rich tonkotsu broth.  It was also moderately spicy (for me), and I liked the fact that the spicy miso was viscous enough that I could adjust the amount of kick I wanted as I didn't want ALL of it.  I would give it solid 4+ stars for it.    With all that Monta has done to Las Vegas' ramen scene, I would still give them a 4, even though their new Kuro ramen was a complete failure.    I'm also finding that ramen chefs of recent has become noticeably hispanic, and ramen noodles seem to be a bit overcooked for my taste.  If I see that the noodle isn't as firm as I like it next time, I will drop them down to 3 stars....watch out Monta...there are some real competitions now.

TCsRVTQ8aaLh4KNds_uokg.text: Really good Ramen dishes. Now I know what it's SUPPOSED to be like! I got mine with the thicker noodles, extra pork and an egg. Bomb! I had enough broth that I could've ordered a refill of noodles, but we had a side of rice for the little guy, so I just dumped that in a slurped it all up! We got Gyoza as an appetizer. It wasn't bad, but I'll skip it next time.

A4saPXnUwXSRl9WtRS4e2w.text: Monta Ramen: The 411 and maybe something different than the 559 other Monta reviews...  Location: 1 block West of Decatur on Spring Mountain Road. It's tucked into the back of a small shopping center off the North side of Spring Mountain. Signage is minimal which means if you're not paying attention you will miss it.    Parking: Limited parking spaces if other businesses nearby are open. Can be tight to park if crowded.   Monta is small. Square footage wise they've taken a small space and maximized every square foot of it. Don't be surprised if there's a wait that you have to stand outside as there's room for maybe 2-3 people inside the front door.   Seating. They have a handful of tables and a counter with slightly uncomfortable stools you can sit on that looks into a fun to watch kitchen. If you are shy, claustrophobic, or don't like slurping noodles where anyone can watch this is not the place for you.   Food: I walked in here skeptical. 559 Yelp reviews. Lots of heated discussions, controversy abounds about Monta. I came to try it, and I came in a bad mood to boot. I ordered Miso Ramen with extra slices of charziu. And I had an OMG moment here that left me with a smile from ear to ear and I left the bowl totally empty. I will say that Ramen Sora has better charziu, hands down. But the overall experience I had at Monta was superior in every other aspect.    Special Notes: Monta's Miso Ramen has a bit more oil in the broth. It's not an oil that ruins the taste, it seems to enhance it somewhat. But it's also a small problem if you're sitting at the counter slurping a bowl of ramen and you get some splash back that lands on your shirt. If you've got to go back to work after eating at the counter, having some Shout wipes on hand is essential.   Overall Impression? I loved it. From the wide range of people I ate lunch beside to the overall awesomeness of the Miso Ramen to the friendly and fast staff, count me among those who understand why Monta inspires such a range of emotion. For me, this was an experience I won't soon forget, and I can't wait to go back and have more of it.

q2RjBceaOYZ25sa0vHXTzw.text: I wasn't that impressed by this ramen place. It's not bad. I like the thick noodles over thin noodles. The pork belly rice was so so too. Good but not great. I'll come back again but I'd try a few more places first if there is nothing better around Vegas

yWHH5PySEU9tZ8iU3Jut8A.text: Best Ramen Place.  The only reason it gets a four star is that it's impossible to go there without waiting in line which is a deal breaker when you don't have much time. They should definitely get a little larger place.  Other than that, again, best ramen I ever tasted :)

ls-DNfbwmajNA4FD_ZczXQ.text: Before I departed to Japan for a month, I was given an impromptu send-off party at Monta.  This came following a year of nonstop coworkers cheering about how wonderful Monta was and how it made other establishments in Vegas, particular Anime Ramen, look bad.  So needless to say, my expectations were really high.    It should be mentioned that Monta was incredibly authentic to the point where everything that I loved and hated about Japan was en-capsuled by this establishment:  Too small to fit a decent crowd so there was a 45 minute wait late night on a Friday?  Check. Hard benches? Check. Tiny waiting space? Check. Completely open mail slot in the middle of December with a door that didn't close so it was incredibly drafty and wet and miserable?   Check.  At some point I was actually convinced that this was their plot: Make you so hungry and cold and put-out that you would just find the food euphoric when you finally arrived.  Not to mention that they were OUT of miso so anything that had miso in it was not an option.  Seriously, my favorite thing on the menu?  You're out of it??  So finally managed to get to our food and the taste was great.  Broth was wonderful, noodles perfectly cooked.  Was it worth the wait?  Not reallyI just wanted to flee to Curry Zen whose attitude is blah but food is a staple for me.     I suppose that if I came a weekday afternoon and had a casual bowl I would had a different experience then it would have been fine.  But I shouldn't have to wait for a chance time to have a pleasant experience.

rG2AZM4SwS70veieu0thSw.text: Food: 8/10 - Authentic Chinese food.  Tasty  Cleanliness: 5/10 - Could be better  Ambiance: 3/10 - The place is super tiny and worn out.  Need's an overhaul.  Restrooms: Didn't visit  Service: 7/10 - Friendly and friendly but rushed because there is a wait.  Because the restaurant is small's the weight can be long.

LJmaBI6unYfRqzO9Q_HMaQ.text: I'm pretty sure the first thing you hear when you walk in are the waitresses yelling the order in Japanese and the chefs in the back confirming AND the slurping of noodles from patrons which is a strong first impression. (* + 1) I'm no ramen expert but I believe the best places have distinctive flavors for their broths. At Monta, you can definitely tell the Miso from the Tonkatsu, and the Shoyu from the Tonkatsu-Shoyu which earns a star. ( * + 1)   Location+Atmosphere: It's tucked away in a shady strip mall which I always seem to pass, but a good landmark is the bar at the beginning of the mall called Kilroy's (named after the famous Kilroy graffiti). I love the atmosphere which is an open kitchen where you see the chefs work. The bar seating has nice spinning bar stools and it's easy to get comfy/friendly with the strangers next to you. (* + 1)  Service: At the door they don't really care who you are or what you do (whether you have a party of one or a party of 10, no special treatment; no forgiveness for leaving/having incomplete party). Once seated, the service is quick and they get your stuff out as soon as possible to get another butt in your chair. With a small party (2-3) the wait shouldn't be too long. With a large (+4) party, at munch-time you're out of luck. Service does not earn a star.  Food: Ramen (why would you get anything else here?). Four different broths to choose from with their own noodle style. Tonkatsu shoyu ramen comes with wavy noodles and the Miso came with thin noodles. Extra noodles are $1.25. I don't get add-ons because there's no need, the amounts which are portioned should be rich enough to keep you from wanting for a couple hours. Which leads me to portion size. First time it came, I thought I could eat 3 bowls, but after the first tasty, rich bowl you find yourself satisfied. What you're looking for is the flavor of the broth and I think this place has one of the tastiest broths. I like to add the spicy powder, hot oil, and sesame seeds so maybe that's why it gets salty near the bottom, but it makes my noodles tastier. (* + 1) Got the gyoza, tasted the gyoza, enjoyed the gyoza, did not write home about the gyoza.  Strangest thing: I do not understand why they don't serve hot tea. Too much work to serve and too little space for the cups? They do have canned oolong and green tea though.

KXXJb33q-_IrNCd5WqSrlg.text: This is my favorite restaurant in Vegas. The ramen is incredible, the atmosphere is authentic and charming, and the people remember you (like Cheers, but saltier). Although the lines can get long, they turn over very quickly.

EVBUmQq68o_Rm-fmhqZqFw.text: Received a recommendation from the bartender at my hotel for ramen, this place is off the hook. The ramen was amazing, the atmosphere was perfect and the dumplings to die for

jPz4PhavJIDEyi3ZzIgdzQ.text: Came by for lunch the other day and it was a mediocre experience at best. Arrived at 11:35 am and had to wait for the first batch of folks to finish their ramen!  Started off with the Gyoza which was mediocre. It wasn't super fresh, although it was acceptable. ...nothing special.  The tonkotsu shoyu ramen w/ chashu and green onions was okay. Added in the nitamago, hard boiled egg, which made the ramen that much more tasty! As other Yelpers mentioned, they use skinny noodles here...so less substance to chew on. The chashu was tender, although it was on the fattier side.  The hard boiled egg was probably the highlight of the meal, cooked medium.  ~$15/person after tax and tip for lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen + Egg - $8.45
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza - $5.15

FGWQ4JQNp_KZBr1g-a7PXg.text: First time having black garlic aioli ramen ever! It wearing flavor. Broth was very savory and infused with the pork bone marrow flavor. I had the shredded green onions and that added another texture and flavor to the ramen. The egg was a little more hard boiled than I usually like it. The chashu pork melts in your mouth! Had a nice browned outer coating- delicious   The chashu bowl was good but I don't think I'd order again. Tastes similar to a fancy yoshinoya bowl

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic aioli ramen topped with shredded green onions

IbSV6l6hYyR8--YbdTAC8A.text: Hands down. Best. Ramen. Ever! I came here on a weekday for lunch. Actually, the reason why I even decided to check this place out is because the day before I was at the Japanese Curry spot just a couple hundred feet away (in the same plaza) and noticed a long line at Monta Ramen. I was curious. Why were so many people waiting outside to eat ramen? Well, I needed to found out! So the very next day, my friend and I arrived around 11:15am (the place opens at 11:30am for lunch). There were already a few people in line waiting for the doors to open. I peeked inside. It's very small! There's only about 6 tables and a few seats at the bar. We got seated at 11:30am and when I looked out the window, there was already a line.   We ordered their top two special daily ramens: Spicy Tonkatsu and Black garlic Oil Kuro ramen. Both are fantastic! Very flavorful and unique! I've never tasted anything like the Kuro ramen before. Truthfully it looks gross cuz it's black and oil, but damn the ramen tastes soooo ono (good)!!!! The noodles are perfectly cooked, al dente! The service is fast and friendly (they kind of want you out of there quick, though! lol).   If you're ever in Vegas and you love ramen, you def have to check out Monta Ramen. You won't regret it! The long line is worth the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Exterior of Monta
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic oil Kuro Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu

WDgkL_BuQI2D4bzK7evqhQ.text: Place is small so it always looks packed but Wait never ridiculously long. Food is fast with great presentation. A long time satisfied returning customer.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Add corn &amp; butter!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small fried rice. ALWAYS DELICIOUS

Hshl1KBHLHIoulPLIm80tw.text: I find that this ramen place is slightly more salty than Ramen Sora. It's a great place and the service is excellent.  I really enjoyed the Kimchi fried rice.  The ramen is more Korean-esque vs Japanese. I hope that analogy translates to you foodies out there! Its a great place to check out.

2PE9IPz-xovg7cIdeJBsDg.text: Best ramen in Vegas. Eating here for 6 years. Recommended to all my friends and out if towners.

DdeDtBfAfXtdtW1Y7WsIPg.text: This is my go-to ramen place in Vegas! The food is really cheap, under $10. Our food came out really fast and service was prompt. The restaurant tends to be busy so there's a wait but the food is worth it! There are other options aside from ramen.

DHqJYZcqliePXikt5H6Gnw.text: I love Monta. There's always a line but it's well worth it and the service is fast. It's some of the best ramen I've had in Las Vegas. The broth and egg are suoer delicious.

mmXTMS4H0A2aChh-xYgGWA.text: I am not a huge fan of wet food generally but I really enjoyed my black garlic ramen here on Tuesday on way home from Las Vegas. I have never had this version of ramen anywhere else. If I I lived nearby I'd be a regular. Dont let the dusty backwater strip mall fool you.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
