2wp6srK4T3UQIWe9V01V8A.text: My favorite ramen place in town! There is always a wait which in my opinion means they are doing something right. I go there for the ramen but I will always split a fried rice with whoever I'm with it is amazing!

Oex-XhMWK66K1IJ5KQEp9g.text: Facts:  1- very salty 2- very crowded 3- the wait is not bad because food comes out fairly quick 4- the fried rice is wet for those like your fried rice dry 5- friendly staff 6- open kitchen  I hope you this helps you making a decision where to eat and not just looking at how many stars they have.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Open kitchen

FSNPAf5qiOQwXcjncHrt6g.text: Called here on a Tuesday around 8p.m. and found out there's not wait. I was finally able to try this place that has lines every time I had passed by.   Tonkotsu ramen - 3 star. It was good, salty, but nothing super extraordinary. I didn't find it to be amazing, and have definitely had better ramen elsewhere...in Cali and Tokyo.   Kuro ramen- 3.5 star. This was richer in flavor and had depth that was different compared to the tonkotsu, but I sure wasn't raving about it either.   Kimchi fried rice- 2.5. I was looking forward to this since people had mentioned that it's quite amazing. Nah. I shoulda known better ordering kimchi fried rice at a ramen shop for one, and a Japanese restaurant.   Overall it's a 3 star. An A-OK for me. I don't think I'll be back here again. Oh, but I am proud that the food here got me to drink two big glasses of water.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice- ok

1IpJtkiJtTgQRda4oQ7tuw.text: The ONLY ramen place I go to when I'm in Vegas! I always want to try other ramen joints but I somehow always end up at Monta LOL There can be a long wait if you come during rush hour but it's definitely worth it! The reason why it can take a while to be seated is because the restaurant is small, with only a couple seats and bar seating. I usually get the spicy tonkotsu and it never disappoints my taste buds. Sometimes I add corn, egg or extra chasiu.. depending on how hungry I am. YUM! You can also also share a bowl and just add extra noodles. Each bowl is about $7.50(???) depending on which one you get and how many add ons you get! Not bad for the quality of food you get. MMM RAMEN!!

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Takana fried rice

hda5oyfj1f0Bduhsy9Btmg.text: Tonkatsu with garlic oil is absolutely delicious!! Highly recommend this place, but be ready to wait in line about 30+ minutes.

jP8-9hx7J-U5bGSK8ONEmA.text: My boyfriend loves this place! A lot of different options & service is usually quick.

eYXjdFtXANtCAE5Epsbd8w.text: Some of the best Ramen I have had.  Packed, quick, good service.  Don't go to Vegas much but will go back when I do.

wN9mYp_vuXTnnRxTM03mFg.text: I feel like I'm cheating on every ramen shop I go to because I always say this is the best ramen. But it's True! I love noodles, it's my favorite food. So I'm definitely picky (in everything). We waited about an hour, it's a small shop. Our waiter was very nice and our food didn't take long. But oh my, my mouth is watering just typing this. The fried rice was flavorful and oishii! I didn't try the kimichi fried rice I was scared it would be too spicy for me but I'll try it next time because it looked so good at other tables. The gyoza was soft boiled it was yummy too. Now the ramen, I've never had thin noodles before and it changed my world. It really complimented eveything. The broth was hearty but not super so I was able to finish everything. The egg was melting, oozing, you know good stuff. Chashu mmmmmmh. Yeah so go try it out, worth the wait, drive, everything :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

eGV1XXZYNsXe_my8ecCFPg.text: First time coming to a ramen joint closest to the West Coast and it did not disappoint. I guess it is True that Japanese foods is better in the West. Also this place is the cheapest I have seen/been to in my entire life starting at $7! So basically this place is cheap and delicious! The tonkatsu soup that i ordered was just as good or even better than the top ramen places I had been to but cheaper! Their tonkatsu broth is rich, thick and milky type but with just a tad salty than I would like. I actually substituted the thin noodles that normally comes with the tonkatsu choice with thick noodles. The noodles were cooked perfectly- chewy. Please note that the price of the ramen does not include an egg; just two slices of pork, scallions, bamboo shoots, and kikurage (wood ear). Service was friendly, attentive & the ramen came out quickly. I would definitely come back to Monta every time I am in the mood for ramen in LV.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Ramen with thick noodles
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kaedama (thin noodles)

GYGK9F2icvmPVG05h7T3kw.text: Definitely a great place to get a bowl of hot deliciousness when in Vegas!  On a recent trip, we were both craving ramen, so we came here to grub. The restaurant space is tiny with only a few tables, so be prepared to wait a bit as this place is extremely popular. We eventually got a seat at the bar area and was able to watch the chef's do their thing. This place is exactly like the ramen joints underneath metro stations in Tokyo, very authentic indeed.   Food was amazing, broth was super tasty, and the noodles cooked to perfection.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

72HOm_8GXEGiMRvF09liTA.text: I am Japanese from Japan. I can tell you that ramen here is probably the best ramen you can find in Vegas. Taste is pretty close to what you can find in Japan. Five star for me.

w1497foJmWpxALIMl6aOjQ.text: The place is really small, only has a few tables. but the open kitchen is given a big plus. $1.5 for extra noodles are perfect for noodle lovers.  The only thing is the soups is a little bit salty.

NR2k8EY0K3Di564xrfddJQ.text: Absolutely amazing Ramen, best I've ever had!

ZMVhzFUZZNiXk_H0V69xYg.text: By far, my second favorite Ramen place.  (First place is Ippudo). Came here for the first time and enjoyed my ramen! I highly recommend this place.  The price is reasonably cheap (compared to IPPUDO in New York City, where we would most likely spend at least $100+) I ordered the Miso Ramen, with egg. It was a bit salty, but overall it was yummy and tasty.   We got there around 5:30, so there was no waiting. The place is really small, so seating is very limited.   We've tried a couple of places in Vegas, and so far Monta is the best place I've been to.

4yOZOPy9doAQwx9WbOzojQ.text: yum yum yum! this place is a solid 3.5 star! i can't say that they were comparable to all the A+ ramen joints i've been to back home, but for vegas after a long tiring day ....?? it was godly!  we came in with a  party of 5 and were seated pretty much right away. we quickly ordered and our food came out immediately!  Piping hot with a nice flavorful broth! since it was all hot and humid outside, i wanted to take it down a notch with the richness of the broth, so i ordered my ramen with "less sodium/lighter broth" and it was still very delicious. it was also a nice change from the regular thick broth that my ramen usually comes in.   the place is pretty small but i dont think a whole lot of people know about it, especially visitors to vegas. definitely stop by when you're in the area if you want a good meal!

5RCOm15jlvb8zQSfF7kwRQ.text: Service is fast and Very good food. Worth the wait!

Q4n9j6qUMGeuYvxJpcj8pA.text: I love this place... the waiting sucks, the small seating area sucks, but once you sit down and start eating all those sucky parts melt away. You have to order their ramen. This time I got tonkatsu-shoyu - pork/soy sauce..? Extra order of noodles and added 1 egg, 3 extra orders of chashu (I absolutely do not regret this), half order of pork belly, gyoza and fried rice (mustard leaves). I loved everything, the gyoza and pork belly I can live without, but the ramen and chashu and fried rice was pure heaven for me. Regretting that I moved out of Vegas.

7ABeKlpcv1AoW76OUgszYQ.text: I like the ramen here ,they are the best in town!price is reasonable,food is yummy and the waitress is sweet. They are traditional japanese girls ,very gentle and quiet ,not like some other places waiter or waitress always yelling at chefs in the kitchen.you will feel comfortable when you are dinning there.a good place for couples and lovers .

lyJT1ExLNnBbsSdphyncug.text: Delicious ramen!! The noodles are the perfect texture and the broth is rich and creamy!

2ffhL0cP-kO4uB0si8fYYw.text: I had such high hopes for this place only to be let down. I ordered the black garlic oil tonkatsu ramen under the recommendation from the waitress. When my order came there was an obscene amount of black garlic oil resembling black sesame paste. This definitely did not look like the picture as advertised. The picture definitely did not have this much black garlic oil in the bowl.  In my bowl the tonkatsu broth was hiding under a layer of black oil. I was puzzled at why there was an excessive amount of garlic oil but I figured I should try it before I say anything else. Once I tried a spoonful of soup I wasn't sure what to think. To me the black garlic oil overwhelmed the tonkatsu flavor and was also quite salty. All I could taste was the garlic oil. Upon finishing my bowl I started feeling quite parched from the saltiness of the broth. Maybe I just went on an off day? If you do order the black garlic oil ramen proceed with caution as it may not turn out like the nice picture as advertised.

RFiZbAj1wRGWe5vRiJi1vw.text: Wow Wow Wow.   I have tried a few authentic places for Ramen before, but this place takes the cake :)  I had the Tonkotsu Ramen (which is pork for us Gaijins) and it was very tasty! The best part is that the broth wasn't overly salty, as most places that I have tried. The broth was delicious and the meat itself was very tender! I would definitely go here weekly if I lived close by. Prices are good too.   The space is a bit small and we did have a little wait before we were seated. This place gets busy! Don't worry though, because it's worth it!  I also heard that the Shoyo Ramen is very good as well!  I rarely give 5's. And the funny thing is that I had to get dragged to go here. Go figure. Apparently, this place has won a lot of awards in several big local magazines (how we found out about it, lol)  :)

eOJmm-UCmE1cZAuVByOklw.text: Best Ramen in Vegas.  I'd really want to rate this 4.5 stars, because the service is at times a bit rude, but the food is probably good enough that I can rate this 5 stars.  I come back frequently, always order the tonkotsu ramen with an egg and extra pork, delicious!

-lvQKEPc0TJh6mlxEv0NKQ.text: Miso soup was ok. The pork was kind of fatty. Service was ok. Small place and I felt crowdes while I was eating. Wasn't bad but I would probably go to Sora Ramen instead.

nmkxJPZdeGyxvNh2IaDVoA.text: I can't believe I've waited this long....simple, hearty, delicious.  This place is a winner.

TLE-dcF7TSkZBCIOdQ6S-w.text: Good.  Cheap.   Super small.  Reminds you of a side street big city diner.  Great character.  Limited menu but you go for one thing----great ramen.

QYwbkUvY4KmBlgP7tEvQ7A.text: Great Ramen and perfect food to warm you up ! Tonkatsu and shoyu are tasty !

jxqW3PI4TpjGLfuYvrhhPA.text: Great place to get a flavorful meal under $10. I got the tonkatsu ramen and a bottled water. Ramen was good, but I'll have to remember to get extra pork next time. Service was great. Food came out right away. It was another lunch for 1, and it wasn't so bad. I was in and out of there within 30 or so minutes (around 4pm on a Monday).

7t779yD21Gih-pZ1NZGskQ.text: Being a huge fan of noodles I consider myself somewhat of an expert on noodles.  Finding this place by searching on Yelp I really did not expect what I found.  The food here is absolutely awesome.  I could say all of the things that everyone else uses to describe the food here but for me it wouldn't be enough.  I have taken detours from cross country driving just to come here.  To me it is worth losing a day of travel time just to enjoy their food.  Recently my Dentist informed me that he had a 3 day conference in LV so I directed him to Monta.  When he came back he told me it was so good that he ate there 6 times in 3 days which means he had lunch and dinner there for 3 days in a row.  If that isn't proof of how totally awesome Monta is then nothing is.  For me it is as good as any I have had the pleasure of enjoying though I do personally consider it the best.  I have nothing against the Ramen in Japan as that is considered the mecca of ramen but Monta seems to have come from a back alley of Tokyo and shines much brighter.  At this very moment I am craving a bowl but just cannot run to Vegas right now but I would if I could because it is that good.

UV9NuBuaGMqXHld20F2GyQ.text: I chose this place base on the high ratings. I enjoyed the simplicity of the place. I liked their approach of keeping things simple.  I liked that they created a warm and friendly atmosphere.  The level of customer service is definitely high at Monta Ramen.  The wait staff is well trained and are very alert to what is taking place around the restaurant.  Unfortunately, the ramen is not up to par.  Instead of a slightly thicker and more al dente bowl of noodles, my was softer and more closely resembled the thinner egg noodles one might find in Cantonese soup noodle entrees. The noodles lacked "bite" and did not create much of the "slurping factor".  It is really too bad because the broth was decent.  The pork belly was good and the other ingredients were good.  The main attraction, however, was a bit "flat".  I did not feel going to the restaurant was worth the close to $30 round trip taxi fair I paid to/from my hotel.  I was going to rate Monta Ramen 2 stars, but the excellent service saved it from going to 2 stars.

JjVpZO6htmWpZra5IHA1pA.text: The gyoza and fried rice at this place is killer. The miso ramen a little salty for my liking and the noodles a little too soft. Besides that excellent ramen.  The service sometimes isnt that great, but its understandable because they are usually pretty busy

CfPteIAT34VGGYd8deTsnA.text: My first time here and I can say this:  I WILL BE BACK AGAIN.  The place is a little small, you have to wait get a spot to sit but:  The food is hot and fresh, it is coming out quick from the kitchen.  The two servers are making sure your drink is full.  All in all great food great time.  Come here :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonktsu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly little bowl :)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fresh sides tops

IqnzEBe944em4t_aQDO4_Q.text: I got here and I almost had to fight this one tiny asian chick for a spot. Worth it! There are 6 tables, it's a really tiny restaurant, but the ramen is probably one of the best ramen I've had. My friend is pregnant and this is all she craves. The chef and the servers are really quick and efficient. You will not be waiting long to eat once you are sat. This place isn't really a place to hang out and socialize. Just order, enjoy, and get out.

BclO64RiVOFFym4uK93dnQ.text: Yay for good little ramen shops! Monta opens at 11:30AM. My party and I arrived at Monta at precisely 11:10AM and there were already 7 parties waiting outside the door! There are only about I think 5 tables and some seats around the ramen bar in the shop. Just our luck, by the time we got to the front of the door, all of the tables and seats were filled. We then had to wait 45 minutes to be seated. Once we were seated, we ordered and our food and drinks came out quickly. There are two waitresses- both mid-age Japanese women.  I had the Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen with kimchi, nitamago (flavored egg), and nori on the side. The broth was really good- not too salty, so that's a plus. The noodles are handmade as well.   I would definitely come back. Sooooo gooooood.

DKsBvoe8NGbcBJ-FqnxXyQ.text: Quick service.  We got here at the right time where there was no line.  Woo hoo.  The ramen was pretty good.  Not the best I've had but it hit the ramen spot.  I would come back here.  It's a small place so I can see it getting pretty busy.

cmA3dP14V-TmS_OfFVihBw.text: Loooove the kuro ramen (black garlic oil)!! Went here for the first time this past summer. I know it's good because I went twice and both days it was 100+ degrees!if ur eating ramen in that kind of weather it must be good. I will definitely be back next time I'm in vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen

-fwHt33pVW0Re_LHs3zrUQ.text: In my top five places to get ramen but definitely not top three. They are always packed. The place is small and intimate. I suggest sitting at the counter. I usually get the shoyu ramen and add some kimchi, egg, moyashi, and extra pork. The size of the bowl is the right size, just filling enough. Overall a good place to get ramen but there are better places in my opinion.

FPXg-C_MnfzmVe5G-DHAdg.text: Don't go here if you are vegetarian! Totally my bad on this one. My husband wanted ramen, so I looked up this place and saw the reviews were great. Didn't think to check the menu to see if it was vegetarian friendly, just wanted to get him soup to help with his cold. He LOVED his food, and everyone else's looked amazing. They did have a cold noodle that was vegetarian. It didn't taste bad, but wasn't great. couldn't get past the "cold" part. Felt like I was eating cold leftovers out of the fridge. Meat eaters however, CHECK THIS PLACE OUT!

kQOuw0QGr_O-a0MYaC2vBA.text: We had the tonkotsu ramen with kaedama and a sm pork belly bowl for 15.  - noodles too mushy. not much meat or broth. broth needs to be a bit spicier. extra for green onions? too much hype for something not comparable to shin-sen-gumi.  - pork belly had more fat than meat. but in defense, pork belly is pretty much fat....  - friendly service. but no yelling japanese phrases when coming in?! i thought this is a ramen house!? lol - overall pleasant, but eh.

hVecxHFUj-CUL8FFFE20hA.text: Busy, but for a reason. Intimate, cozy and delicious. Pork belly is delicious. Shoyu and Tonkatsu Ramen are great. Cheap, too! I get it with an egg. And if you want more, you can add noodles for $1.50.

VLd82zyQSKWDvB0N96fFwQ.text: Arrived at 11:20, still had to wait, there were big parties of 7, 6 ahead of us,  I think max seating about 25. Got in after 30 minutes, Finished our food for 2 of us at 12:20 pm. I had the Kim-chi fried rice and the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen and wife have regular Ramen. Soup base taste was good, noodles were little over cooked for me. I been to a Ramen place in Orange County, Ca. that will carter to the hardness of the noodles.

_1TLKx2CUo0Ospah2Zpv3w.text: Do not order from Yuri. You can feel from her service that she hates her job. She is very rude. Zero customer service. ..

duxxI93o9eml7qMinxSwxQ.text: Chaysu with egg and corn!  That pork meat is so tender and fatty! Yes fatty! But it's delicious! Get your ramen, slurp it up, get out.   Super small restaurant.

xJbdJ5-2UWv0XopWzF8vrA.text: Affordable and delicious! Sat at the bar area. It was interesting to watch them make the ramen over the counter. Smaller location but that doesn't bother me. I had the spicy miso ramen and the broth was just right. The only thing I added was an egg because what's ramen without egg? Amiright? But the portion was perfect for me. I also tried the gyoza. A good appetizer if you just want gyoza, but nothing special. I would come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy miso ramen

OXF1IYKUn00n0XjYOghiOg.text: Yes ramen after a drunken night is always good, mainly wanted the broth. My friend who lives in Vegas recommended this place as one of the better ramen places in Vegas while also informing me that it still won't be like the ones in LA haha. So sure why not?  The establishment is rather small, they do have bar seats and do try their best to make the place look like an authentic ramen place. The pricing seemed fair but the bowl sizes were a bit smaller than I was use to, but whatever, because when it came out it, the broth was still delicious to me.   Like many other ramen places, the menu is simple, they have pictures and which broth you would like, I went with the miso and added an egg, it didn't take long to get here and it tasted great.

E05WnO1MrKCZOXkE5qqSPQ.text: I am a ramen fan but I never liked ramen growing up because It was in the form of Top Ramen.  Now I pay attention to the details that transform simple ingredients into a satisfying bowl of ramen.   I like Monta's version of soy sauce based ramen better than their tonkotsu.    The tonkotsu is definitely rich compared to other ramens I've had. The flavor of the bamboo and mushroom distracts me from the pork flavor.  Thin and firm noodles come with the tonkotsu and that is the way I would have done it.   The shoyu soy sauce ramen is great and the pairing with a thicker noodle is a good choice because it carries the favors of the broth better.  The flavor balance is right on.  I make this my preferred ramen when I visit.   Pork rice bowl was ok...a little too much fat and not enough flavor. Also it's sliced too thin to get a good grub-on.   Prices and toppings are very good.

Pv2UwByCjqA9JDo9w0FYog.text: Even it was packed, we did not wait too long for party of 4. Service was very quick! From order to serve was about 10 minutes. Ramen was excellent!

CJd3YEJqooWRxow5Dz8-8Q.text: It was quite the adventure finding this place since I am from out of town and this establishment is located in the depth of a strip mall in Chinatown.... but we found it! And I am SO glad that we did! They have the best ramen that I have had so far (in life). Oh my goodness!  So the restaurant itself would be best described as cozy... I wouldn't come strolling in 10+ people deep. Most of the seating appears to be surrounding the kitchen in a bar-like fashion. The menu is pretty basic and to the point - easy enough to order. You have a selection of noodles/ramen dishes to choose from... then you can add extras like egg, nori, etc. The basic ramen dishes are pretty filling themselves....but I added egg and nori for more flavor. Oh. My. God. It's like a flavor explosion. Maybe I'm not experienced enough in the ramen world.... but view become a bit obsessed trying it everywhere I go... and I'm not even exaggerating when I say that this is the best ramen I've had (so far). If you're a lover of ramen, STOP HERE!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

gvLnluhEg49XPqsZ872UdQ.text: First time trying Monta after hearing many good things about it. It is a fairly small place yet it's always busy when I see it. The waitresses were all very nice and always around to offer me more water or ask if everything was okay.  I had the tonkatsu shoyu ramen and it was delicious. However it was not the best I've had. The noodles they used seemed to be what threw me off. But overall it was good nonetheless!

217e0VVNqz-FkuDwJ4goBw.text: This was definitely a GREAT find!  If you like soup noodles, soups that takes hours to make, or melt in your mouth pork belly...then this is a must try.   This place is very small with minimum seating area and a limited menu.  Their main focus is their ramen and pork belly bowl, so if you do decide to make the trip out from the Strip of Las Vegas (about a 10 min taxi ride), then you have to try their Ramen and Pork Belly Bowl.  Tip:  Anticipate a wait due to the limited seating area.  Fortunately, we were in luck...no wait!  SCORE!!!  The prices here are very reasonable for the portion and the flavor you receive.  You are definitely getting your money worth.  We ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and a small Pork Belly Bowl.  The Pork Belly Bowl was a small size, but it was plenty for us since we totally devoured ourselves with tons of fantastic food on our trip to Vegas.  The bowl was pretty when it arrived!  The bowl was decorated with pickled ginger to cut the fattiness of the pork belly and an abundant amount of scallions to give the bowl a fresh green flavor.  Below the green and the red, was a pile of juicy, tender, and fatty pork belly gleaming at you.   Then our star...Tonkotsu Ramen.  We added extra Chashu Pork, corn, butter, and EGG (this is a definite MUST add...super soft and melt in your mouth!) to our bowl of ramen.  I have to say, this was a delight to the eye.  The portion was a good size, about the equivalent of a large bowl of Pho.  The flavor of the soup was deep and meaty, the noodles had a good bite to it and every bite had the yummy soup flavoring (we saw them cook the noodles in the slow cooked broth), the pork was drool worthy, the crisp sweet corn added an additional tastiness to the bowl, and the black fungus and bamboos added earthiness.  Overall a delicious experience...simple yet still makes us think about it all the time.  Of course not as good as the ramen you can get in Japan, but definitely pretty good for USA.  We would rate this place a 7 for flavor, price, and quality of ingredients.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly don
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen

UExYBbErWdmzjwEi5Ttj1g.text: By far my favorite ramen place in Vegas!  Get the combo pork/chicken broth with the seasoned egg and seaweed as extra toppings! Also check out the kimchi fried rice! DELISH!

xyna5oxn_6dSdjqTiGumNw.text: The decor is minimal, no music, and tiny shop, but the food was excellent.  I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen and was not disappointed.    The place was crowded, but we were seated extremely quickly on this visit.  The food took a while, but definitely worth the wait.  This is my go-to place for ramen in vegas now.

OR7L-_mgzLcKcuBJdEXvHw.text: Awesome Ramen place to eat. The Best Ramen in Las Vegas. Excellent Ramen noodles. I have tried every menu in each time I visit, so....delicious to the taste. The ingredients is fresh, for real...noodles, delicious soup base broth & large servings. Yes, truly recommend to everyone in Las Vegas. Add this to your bucket or check list when in Vegas. Till we meet again Monta Ramen.

P2JPGHI_cPVH7OwDiKoZDw.text: Monta is the real deal, go here.  The restaurant is pretty small and you can almost count that there will be a wait any time of day, in fact, when they open for lunch at 11 there is often a line already forming.  OK the food: -Miso Ramen is FANTASTIC,  it is my go to.The broth  is delicious and the noodles are chewy and plentiful, there is also the most tender sliced pork on top. You can also get extra items like more pork, butter, corn, sliced egg, all make your soup even better. - Pork  Belly Over Rice is a winner, just like it sounds, the pork belly will melt in your mouth. - Gyoza is the best I have ever had!!  The atmosphere is nice and the service is quick and friendly.

VScqOVf-5Do027LbDu1htg.text: Great black garlic ramen and I love it with the boiled eggs.

5WMjdnFp9V3o1phD2gyUlA.text: Great rich Tonkatsu Ramen. Lots of Umami. The chasu pork is very tender. Loved the kimchi fried rice. There is always a line or wait.

fLGgZOvi52edMFuZsbAiwA.text: Yumm! The Tonkatsu broth is definitely worth trying.   I recently relocated to Las Vegas from Northern California and the first craving I had to fulfill was for ramen. Monta Ramen definitely hit the spot!  BE WARNED: They're a bit inconsistent with their soup unfortunately. The first few times were delicious, but the last two times we have gone it was wayy too salty! I could feel the salt burning the back of my throat.

UrkjtIxr6Rmp8SD51Q5ElA.text: It's just OK ramen compared to what's available in LA.  Doesn't justify the really long lines outside.

cy3ZX8IVk-61fGFaB4ZGbA.text: I still think Monta is tasty, but it's just not as tasty as I used to think it was.  While Monta isn't my first choice anymore, I don't have any qualms on eating here. My best friend Tida C. is still a die-hard Monta lover so I'm sure they'll still be in my regular rotation of restaurants.  The Miso broth isn't as rich and a little more salty than I remembered. And the flavors are more subtle than comparable broths I've had at other ramen places. Between Shoyu, Tonkatsu, and Miso, I consider Miso to be the tastiest of all of them.  A couple of the reasons I still think Monta is awesome is their Togarashi (the red chili/pepper flakes on the table). I don't know how they make it or where they get it from, but no other togarashi is equal to that of Monta's. The blend of chili and other seasonings make it incredibly addicting and it has more spice (heat level) than others I've tried.  And of course, they still hold True to carrying the freshest mentaiko in town. That mini mentaiko bowl is still my favorite app / side dish to a hot bowl of noodles.

lvFLo-suiJfRP7q0Rl252A.text: I got the Miso Ramen. The ramen was good, the prices are great, the wait was only 10 minutes on a Friday. However, we were shocked that they had extremely limited options for our vegetarian friend. She ended up paying too much for a small portion of fried rice, for which they would not substitute the pork (expensive) for a side of corn (dirt cheap). This is a small place, not good for groups larger than 4. I wasn't blown away by the meal or experience.

G_UxL6nV9_H5lLlswndp0A.text: Monta is definitely one of the better ramen shops in Las Vegas. Its in the same strip mall as Raku on Decatur/ Spring Mtn.   Monta reminds us of Japan's ramen shops...its all about order your food, eat your food, and get out, so the next group can eat. It's not a posh restaurant, minimal tables/ seats. The restaurant holds at most 30 people (5 tables of 4 seats and about 10 seats on the counter), so if you go with a large party, just sit wherever you can and when you can or you might be waiting for awhile.  The menu is simple. Miso, Tonkatsu, or Shoyu ramen. My favorite is...all of them. Huge stock pots in the back have been boiling bones and veg for hours to create the backbone of their heavenly broth.  I seem to be on a tonkatsu ramen kick lately with its hearty broth... you could add some thickener to the broth and you would have a damn good gravy. They give you a good amount of ramen, a few slices of tender charsiu, bamboo, takenoko, green onions, half boiled egg, and kikurage. Its a solid meal for a cheap price, $7-8 and you can add other extras for a small price.  Another favorite is their pork belly bowl. Its cheap and filling...not to mention very tasty. You get the thinly sliced pork served over rice in a small bowl garnished with beni shoga. Its tasty, fatty, and better when you get eat a little beni shoga (red pickled ginger) with it.. We always get a small bowl and share it.  Their gyoza is good as is the kim chee fried rice. We need to try more of the items on their menu but we are creatures of habit and sometimes its hard to stray away from the  dishes that Monta is known for.  Its easy to over order food at Monta. Because the ramen bowls are big...resist ordering other dishes unless you have a big party and you want to share.   Monta is great on a hot day and better on a cold day!!   Arooha!!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu &amp; Miso Ramen with small pork belly bowl

C1DKqcWVIQBcQeACEuG7xw.text: I have tried pretty much all the ramen place in LA n this place is like the #1 ramen on my list (daikokuya in little Tokyo is #1 tooo!!!) The soup base for the ramen was incredible i've never tasted anything this good (not too salty, n rich in beef flavor, plus the soup is not like liquid, its a little bit thick n jelly-ish). I also order the fried rice.... holy mother of monkey balls.... it was so good I didn't know someone can cook fried rice to this level... this place is incredible.   A MUST TRY ramen if ur in vegas.

fGf905qc8lQlWyPf0EWYXw.text: As good as Ramen can be.  Simple menu.  The server was adorable.  Cool interior design.  A high end chef recommended we eat here when asked where to eat great food without spending a ton.  Fried rice surprisingly good.

tOit2dWDY8YiOZA27l2V9w.text: On a recent road trip from Denver to Portland, made it a point to check out ramen shops along the way.  I have to say this was our best ramen experience of the trip.  Seems to be a popular spot with the locals.  When we arrived there was a short wait (under 10 mins) and were seated at the bar once it opened up.  The service was friendly and efficient.  It was enjoyable to watch the action of kitchen right up close.  Everyone was moving with a sense of urgency and I appreciated the effort.  Ramen was definitely tasty but overall experience and ambiance is what pushed up to a 5 star experience.

LyaicxZrnM0VDbaSxYriIg.text: Good ramen in Las Vegas? Unheard of! Walking into Monta, I expected mediocre ramen compared to the ramen places I have grown to love in Los Angeles and eft feeling incredibly ignorant.   The Black Garlic Oil Ramen and Pork Belly Bowl was DELICIOUS. The only downside is the wait-be prepared and don't come when you are already starving unless you enjoy torturing yourself! Good things come to those who wait, don't miss out on my new go-to spot of Vegas!

nvv8o7RsPI0Bax04gUEnfg.text: Very surprised to find such authentic ramen in Vegas.  Very small dining room and waited only 15 mins for counter seat for party of 2 with wonderful view of the open kitchen.  We had  Kuru Ramen and Shoyu Ramen both excellent...I added corn and butter.  So good on a cold evening and can't wait to return again.

If_FztXAesxViME2o4U3RQ.text: This is my first time having ramen in Vegas. The location is off the strip and in Chinatown. The restaurant is small, with not too much seating. My boyfriend and I came on a Saturday afternoon at 2pm and we only waited 2 minutes and were seated. I ordered the tonkotsu shoyu ramen. Food came out pretty quick and service was also quick. The ramen was a bit bland, I think it needs more toppings. Overall not bad, but I don't know if I would come back if I was in the area.

OjqrXkZHNgo9AnbxFfxEtQ.text: I've heard very good things about Monta. The wait was pretty long because it's a pretty small place but it was worth it. I got the Miso ramen and it was pretty good but too salty for me. Next time I go I'll be sure to try a different one.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with flavored egg and corn

CF3-Du4m2jrloz1GaEd1Dg.text: I had the shoyu ramen with an egg and kimchi. Everything from the broth to the noodles to the toppings was perfectly seasoned. Highly recommended if you are in Vegas

2pSQpgz4J_WxgXFuVxE-IA.text: Had the tonkatsu ramen and Kimchi fried rice.  Felt that the salt overwhelmed any True flavors that could have been realized.  Noodles were pretty basic and flavor was pretty flat.  Normal issue I find with ramen places is uneven temperature of the dish and wishing it were hotter.  I've had better ramen before and look forward to that spot now.

mc7d8Yy7dOaQcvpoINcmHQ.text: I came in at around 5:40, and wait for 15 mins. I think it is a reason waiting Time. Ramen is very good, especially considering the pricing! Highly recommend!

hSuFTc8_YCHogGOQ3DhfYA.text: By far the best tasting and least expensive spot to get amazing ramen in Vegas. At least from my experience!! As I've been to all of the popular locations this place remains my favorite. The atmosphere reminds me alot of Japan as the entire staff speaks Japanese and the style of the place is tables and bar seating while you watch them prepare your dishes fresh. The ingredients are amazing and they have tons of selections - I always choose more vegetables and an extra egg. We usually buy 2 or 3 rounds of their draft beer. Especially because it's so cheap like a $2 for a pint.   The live atmosphere, delicious aroma and fast  service makes the experience feel truly authentic. Theres always a wait her to be sure to check in and sign your party up. The place is small and has limited seating so parties of 6 or less is advised. I usually get my ramen extra spicy and add the garlic oil. Dig in and try something new if it's your first second or 100th time you wont regret it!! Great for friends and small social gatherings.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VcIgqD-vkES_VW1epwgV9w.text: We have been coming to Monta for 4 years even though we live in SLC, UT. Hot or cold we always swing by, this place if nothing changes with their food will always be my favorite Ramen spot. The inside may be small and yes there can be a line at times but it is well worth the wait.   Tonkotsu - The broth reminds me of a silky smooth savory with soy bean after taste that is truly rememberable. Not to mention the pork is juicy as always and does not lack flavor.   Kuro Ramen - I chose to try this ramen because it seemed unique to me being brought out to other customers with how black the broth was. I forgot to snap a photo but the Kuro is my favorite cause of its rich flavor and with added shredded green onion complimented the broth very well.   Fried rice - Our littles ones love the rice here and so do I, it's probably the best fried rice I've ever had lol no joke. Idk what they do to it but it is ridiculously delicious.   Of course we will be back to eat two or more bowls of ramen in one sitting!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Takana Fried Rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu - Shoyu Ramen

V5d4h0xbJ2oLX6MW40q0HA.text: Monta Ramen is definitely my go to ramen spot when I visit Las Vegas. I've tried other places but seem to never enjoy it as much as Monta.   Their tonkotsu broth is so rich and flavorful and the pork literally melts in your mouth. I always get the spicy tonkotsu ramen, takana or kimchi fried rice and gyoza. This specific location on Spring Mountain Road is in Chinatown so it's a little off the strip. But soooo worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

5iQJgMKtv_dO7_JiP4mmFg.text: The place is small, so expect to wait a while if you come in a big group. I went in a group of four at around 10:30pm and didn't have to wait at all.   I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen. The meat was tender and delicious, but my broth was a little too salty. Food came out in a timely manner, and we didn't have to ask for water refills once, because they were great at keeping tabs on our water cups.

bSfzxCR2613CEbiBwe9a2A.text: When we first arrived in Vegas, we had a huge craving for Ramen! There are so many Ramen shops in Vegas, so we're glad Yelp helped us choose which one would best suit our taste/needs. The prices here for a bowl of Ramen is cheap compared to previous Ramen joints we've had. No complaints here! The restaurant itself reminds me of a True Ramen shop. You see the chefs preparing the Ramen right in front of you! This place is small and can get really packed during lunch time, so be prepared to wait. We got lucky and were seated within 5 minutes.  The wife and I shared the Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil ($7.95), the small Pork Belly Bowl ($3.95), and the small Chashu Bowl ($3.95). The broth for the Kuro Ramen was perfect. Very savory, garlicky, and not too salty. I love me some black garlic oil! The noodles were perfectly cooked. Perfect texture and absorbed the flavor of the broth like a sponge. The pork belly melts in your mouth and everything just pairs well together. The Chashu Bowl was basically the same pork belly they put in your Ramen, but on a bed of white rice. The pork was super tender and perfectly seasoned. The Pork Belly Bowl tasted like "Thit Kho" or "Thom Kem". Basically it's a lightly caramelized pork belly served over a bed of white rice. Pretty solid.  Overall, this place gets 5 stars from me because of the friendly staff, excellent service provided, atmosphere, cheap prices, and quality of the food! I will definitely be back whenever I'm in Vegas. This place is legit.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl and Chashu Bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kura Black Garlic Oil Ramen

HlLktneE5c-8es4bh3H-pg.text: My family and I throughly enjoyed our meals. We had the Tonkotsu and Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen, fried rice, and gyoza. All cooked to order and as authentic as you can get. As close to what I had in Okinawa since moving here.

_Gkm7itzea2pLbQQ08b2Cg.text: Was a little disappointed and truly saddened that I couldn't give this noodle joint a solid 5 star review after reading all the reviews and waiting to finally eat here.   My rating is about a 3.5, but I always like rounding up to be positive.  The pork belly rice bowl was very tasty and worth the squeeze, but the shoyu chashu noodles was only ok at best in my opinion.  It was bland and not very flavorful.   Wish it wasn't so, but that was just my experience.  Hopefully it was just an off day in the kitchen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

W5OpYVgXfpwQY6rgjXzUKA.text: Location - LV chinatown   Parking - avoid the rush hours or do what I do, park on the adjacent street not Spring Mountain though. Maybe I should have skipped that?  Service - extremely efficient, need to remind everyone that at a ramen bar...in and out, skip the chat outside or next door in the tea bar.  Food - so far one of the best ramen shops in Las Vegas. Noodles have the right texture. Broth has full of body and flavor.

Ug5oCFTLqFYznvFLDmiZuQ.text: Really great place in Vegas Chinatown, has an easily accessible parking lot and is in a plaza with other Asian food (boba next door!). Came here for lunch today before going to Life is Beautiful. It's a pretty small restaurant (just a few tables and the bar area), so the wait can be intense if you're going at a busy hour. We came around 12:30pm and waited maybe around 30 mins before being seated (our party of 5).   It's pretty cramped inside, but good ramen vibes all around. I know it says one dollar sign on yelp (the prices are actually very reasonable) but just know that you'll probably add toppings to your base ramen (if you don't add anything, the ramen is like $7-8, which is super cheap) so most likely your bill we be more than $10 (but again, still super cheap and totally worth).  I got the shoyu ramen with medium thickness noodles and added seaweed and egg. Pretty good! I don't have anything to complain about, and I tried my friend's thinner noodles and those were pretty good as well. The service was pretty prompt, they checked in often to keep our waters filled (this is something I comment on a lot in my reviews because I'm just a thirsty person, what can I say).  You can also decide to add more noodles halfway through your meal if you choose to. Overall, I can't really think of anything that I didn't like about this place besides the crowded setup of the interior. Solid ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. shoyu ramen with medium noodles, +egg and seaweed

Mq0kZZpMLCdi8-Zr3egMXQ.text: I'm a foodie and this is the best meal I've had this year.  Pork belly bowl with plenty of all the condiments.  Also tried some of the spicy pork loin ramen - the pork was completely rendered so that the fat was like butter, but the dish itself was not very spicy.  Service was fast and excellent, the pork belly bowl came out within 3 minutes of ordering it.  Fantastic.

EIG-NhCboVJ_rSufuqnokQ.text: I got the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with thick noodles. The broth was not bad but not excellent either. It was nice to have crushed garlic on the table since it absolutely elevates the broth a lot as do the chilies. The pork itself was nice, the noodles were ok.   Overall it is a solid place for a quick, cheap and hearty bowl; not outstanding but definitely great value for the cheap price.

atsXumOpCWnaPGVZ0Tmvdw.text: Fantastic. The food is amazing and the atmosphere is unique. I will definitely be back.   FYI- if you drive a large vehicle, park on the street in the west side of the restaurant. My Truck wouldn't fit in the super packed commercial center parking lot.

99QRDmzCnF8v1VTJGNxuKg.text: If you are looking for ramen, this restaurant is worth a Uber trip off the Vegas strip. The food is delicious, reasonable priced and the service is great!  My three friends and I came here this summer in search of some yummy noodles. The shopping center that it's located within has a variety of Asian restaurants and dessert places. There's also an excellent foot massage parlor here too. Monta Ramen has a pretty small restaurant space. There's maybe only a handful of tables located within. We got here a little after 5 pm so we were able to get a table instantly. I noticed a line out the door as the evening progressed.   Our table got a mix of the regular/spicy tonkotsu pork ramen. The broth has a nice fatty meat flavor and the char-su was thinly cut and tender. The ramen costs a tad under ten dollars but I thought the portion size is a bit small. If you got a big hearty appetite, I recommend you order extra ramen and meat and your bill will still be under $15 before tax.   I think this might be the best ramen place in Las Vegas and several Lyft drivers and other locals agree with me on this. Be sure to make this a stop in your next visit to Sin City!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. spicy
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkokatsu pork ramen

ePJXhpndYo52e7Uph6FcMQ.text: First impression when you go into this place is pike " hmm small busy place., wonder why??" Then you sit and place your order and you notice how this place is a well oiled machine that cranks one of the tastiest ramen around.   Their reputation in the neighborhood can be told by the locals that you see dining at this place. Limited seating so there is going to be a waiting list, so be prepared.  My biggest surprise is how efficient the crew are. Including he cooks behind the bar. These guys crank out orders within 10minutes of us ordering. Of course, the flavor is great but definitely the crew and customer service is what invites me back to go again.   Menu selection is pretty small and if you read my previous reviews is a good thing because they focus on perfecting their craft. Keep it simple.   Two thumbs up!

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0lVWc4wpOuetZiKRLoSZ3g.text: Good ramen alert!!! Small noodle house with real creamy pork bone broth. The Kuro ramen black garlic oil's broth is not greasy at all despite having garlic oil in it. It's really rich however, so adding extra green onion breaks up the richness in each bite and gives you a nice kick of raw onions. The chashu is on the thin side but cooked well and isn't chewy like many other places. The miso broth is also flavorful. Having a bowl on mentaiko don with ramen is always a perfect ending.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen black garlic oil, miso ramen and mini mentaiko bowl.

UJUDpzIwhTdCsjA3KgPSmg.text: The waitress was really impatient to waited customers. We waited for 10 minutes before they opened, and there suddenly came 20-30 ppl from the drink shop next door and got in the store before us. The waitress said they had been waiting for long, but the fact was there were only three of this group waiting in the line. I hated the cut lines and was very disappointed that the waitress couldn't give us satisfied response and blamed us for making nonsense arguments.

5YWU5q2LFrY2ETDdgkHBow.text: It is small. Long line to get in. Make sure you don't come on a whim when your super hungry. It's de worth it once you get to sit down and eat yummy rice and a big bowl of Ramen. I like everything on the menu.  The servers are courteous but firm about seating, to be fair to all the patrons. Most of the time seating time is between 30 min to about 2 hours.  Just here right before Halloween 2018, still yummy, still worth the wait.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

H-g_qM5uNHDC6Rl6_tbniQ.text: Even though ive been here only two times, and have had ramen from all over the LA area (lol) no lie this ramen is the REAL DEAL HOLY FIELD.  Winter is HERE! So expect long waiting periods. (pro tip: theres a boba spot next door make sure you get some if the wait is long!) Parking is abundant at times ive been there.   Once your'e seated youre food is pumped out quicker than   The broth is on another level here! So complex! a wonderful thick and hearty soup filled with all the love you can actually taste it!! Very smoke and really darn good! The broth is my favorite part of the bowl!  Noodles are amazing not as chewey as others Ive had before, thin and super yummmeh. Free Garlic and Ginger! FML give me 5 scoops of GARLIC PLEASE. ( im a garlic you know what! ha! )  Add an egg! ad some corn! some more broth! the list can go on!   Best thing about this place is that the menu is very original not a lot of extra stuff you would see at modern ramen joints. Very simple and thats why I appreciate this place! Fried rice, RAMEN, Gyoza (you have to order two) PORK BELLY RICE BOWL is so satisfying I wish I had another stomach for another bowl! Its that good. White rice topped with scallions, pickled ginger, pork belly! its a marriage in your mouth I promise you will not be let down!   Before I end this on the best note possible, their pricing is by far the most "BANG FOR YOUR BUCK" meal in Vegas and tops all of the noodle soups ive payed for anywhere else. I mean come on now, a monstrous ramen bowl made from love all under $8 bucks???? HELLO WAKE UP AND SMELL THE BROTH! Its amazing, I mean it. Thank you Monta, Love you all!

CKcGuqhVF9KtZSECyL_ziQ.text: For the sake of keeping things interesting (and different), I usually try to avoid writing about the same things in consecutive reviews. Yet, despite having just written about Momofuku's ramen at Cosmo, it seemed apt to write about Monta Ramen next! After all, I did end up visiting them for consecutive meals, so why not keep that going? Not to mention the fact that my perpetual writer's block is getting in the way of me completing my other Vegas reviews...ugh. Now, to be honest, us coming here was mostly a product of chance (like my luck at the tables...) - we were originally hoping to check out Raku next door, but Monta ended up calling our name first. Still, this wasn't the worst consolation prize, as my friend had highly recommended this place. Plus, the menu, while seemingly narrow, offered a lot of enticing choices - seven types of ramen, with a variety of toppings to add, and a slate of some tasty looking specials. -- GYOZA - Handmade Pan-fried Pork and Vegetable Dumplings (6 pcs)...$5.15 (yelp.com/biz_photos/mont...) Although the taste of them couldn't match their appearance (they looked great!), these gyoza were still pretty solid. The skins had just the right thickness and the filling, while not super juicy, were still rather meaty. -- PORK BELLY BOWL - Slices of Soy Marinated Pork Belly Served Over Rice with Green Onions...$3.95 (small) (yelp.com/biz_photos/mont...) Though not as amazing as I had hoped for, this was still pretty solid. The pork was a little dry (more sauce would've helped), but I liked the flavors/marinade and how the ginger and green onions complemented the pork belly. Plus, it was a sizable portion for the money! -- KURO RAMEN BLACK GARLIC OIL - Tonkotsu (Pork) Broth, Roasted Garlic Flavor, Thin Noodles, Two Slices of Chashu, Black Kikurage Mushrooms, Bamboo Shoots, Green Onions...$7.95 (yelp.com/biz_photos/mont...) Very...okay. Plus points for not skimping on the garlic oil, but the rest of this underwhelmed. While the chashu was fine, the noodles were kind of "meh" and the broth didn't stand out, other than the garlic oil. What's worse, their Nitamago/"flavored" egg (+$1.50) was just a regular egg. Even though the food may not have been worth the wait time (took about 45 mins to an hour to get a table?), the rest of our experience actually wasn't too shabby. Service is both friendly and prompt and I really liked how relaxing the vibe was. The best thing about Monta Ramen, though? Their prices! Maybe I'm just jaded by the Bay Area, but you get an impressively large bang for your buck here (like the pork belly bowl!). Despite how good of a value Monta Ramen may be, I can't say I'd make the effort to come back when there are so many alternatives out there (both ramen and otherwise). Certainly not a bad spot, but if I'm going to have to endure that sort of wait, I'd rather it be for something new and/or better.

CXXi5mMGR_De9SXqmopr6w.text: Monta is an absolute MUST every time we are in Vegas. Even during the summer months. The creamy broth never disappoints. There is limited seating so get here early with no more than a party of 6. Also note, they won't seat you until your entire party is there.

L9Jy1CyLePqW8HXPT4c-TA.text: The place is small but the noodles  are awesome! The staff is very friendly will definitely be back

ad2gReNOUjQc02lrRqNpiw.text: The restaurant only have like 6 tables, there's like 5 people waiting to sit down, and looking/staring at you while you eat. you will feel suffocated in such a small room. You can have a panic attack here. What a weird place, if people like to eat on top of one another  good for you. The food was not that good for all the hustle. Avoid this place.

6ZrW5WHH2C-AgF33HXVEow.text: What can I say. I've been back from Vegas for two months now and I don't think I can stop thinking about Monta Ramen. It's one of the best ramen places EVER. The fact that it's also $6 makes it a cheap eat and it's quality ramen.  I can still remember the taste of the broth--it's so damn savory and yummy ugh. Aside from that, the tonkotsu that was served wasn't too thin or too fat. It was literally the perfect size and perfect amount of fat. The texture of the noodle is pretty awesome too! It's not soggy nor is it hard. Perfect.  The service was pretty good, I mean--I would say it's normal. But I do have to say that this is a great place to come grab a bite for cheap eats and such. So gooooood.   I wish this exists in New York.. The next time I go back to Vegas, you will definitely find me in Monta Ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

qc_2ZZuXd-Ee48CHMADbDQ.text: This review is long overdue! I have been to many ramen spots in town and by far this is my favorite . They use to have another location in Henderson, but it looks like it closed down. I have been coming here for years, its just been a while since I have returned. Many of my family and friends from out of town  always want to come here when they visit Vegas.  Their hours are Sunday-Thursday 11:30am to 11pm. Friday-Saturday 11:30am-1am. The only reason I am giving them 4 stars is because there is always a wait to be seated, anywhere from 20mins and longer. I know its not their fault, people come because the food is bomb.  Their pork belly bowl is to die for! It just melts in your mouth. The texture of their ramen noodles are good, not too soft/hard. I tried the cold noodles for the first time today and it is super refreshing. Prices are cheap and I always leave happy n full!  The restaurant is small, holds about 30 people. There are 3 girls that run this place. Saori does such a good job with seating customers, taking/delivering orders, and making sure your your drinks are always refilled. Parking in this plaza sucks.

KWIZn6rlzXvhFnuj6SrPKA.text: One of the best ramen places in Vegas! Service was quick, we had our food in less than 10 minutes. Menu is simple. Ramen is flavorful and has good prices!

V5kNU95JgMcDp16I03zPtQ.text: This place has improved much since my first visit. I love monta ramen because it's fresh, savoring and delicious. Each time I want ramen, this is the place I want to go to. Also I love the area, very friendly staff and the restaurant is always neat and clean!

4e9jCh0tnEmqN0ULPdLqkA.text: Prime example of excellent ramen and service.  Got here around 1pm on a Sunday afternoon. The place is really small, like about 6 full sized tables and 10 individual stools. The wait was about 45 mintues but that didnt bother me since it was Vegas afterall.  The service was wonderful. The waiters were kind and made sure my water cup was always filled. Food came out after 5 minutes of ordering. Very hole in the wall feel.  I got the kuro ramen black garlic oil. Ive never had kuro ramen so i was excited to try this.  The both tasted flavorful, the noodles were the perfect texture, and the pork was nice and tender.  Best of all, it was only $8 for a filling meal. Keep in mind it does cost extra to add corn, seaweed, or eggs. I just didnt feel the need to.  Will definately try the tonkatsu when im back in Las Vegas.

tFmazxvfqXrP-fJAXMOl9A.text: This is actually really good Ramen, there is not much things to say about Ramen, if it's good, it's good, if it's bad it's horrible, fortunately this place was very good, I will keep coming back if Raku is busy ;)   Good job guys at Monta.

EeodYHQ8PvtQ35eiGq5d-Q.text: This is my first time and I love it.  Pros:  * Fast service * Friendly staff * Clean  * Cheap prices  Cons:  * The place is so tiny which it can only accommodate 25 - 30 people * Around 15-20 worth of items to choose from

9P27tvd9lzOQpxt-6faUZA.text: Came here on a Saturday afternoon around 4:30pm. I highly recommend getting here before 5 as the parking lot got busy and the restaurant got crowded just shortly after we arrived.  Service: We were greeted right away and seated at one of the few tables that were open. (You can sit at a table or at the bar) They knew this was our first time there so our waiter went over the menu with us and provided recommendations. (Thank U)  Food: I ordered the Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen and added the egg and corn. You can get the spice sauce on the side so you can keep adding spice to your liking. I also added a few sesame seeds which is just one of the options of fixins available right at your table. The broth was full of flavor. So good! If you want extra noodles you can get a side. I didn't need it.   We also ordered the Kimchee fried rice. I've had spicier Kimchee fried rice but it was still tasty.   We also ordered a small bowl of the pork belly which could be a great meal on its own. Yum!  Overall think this was a good choice and will definitely be adding this place as one of our new go to spots!

QDPc4HcICevWYjBDFyvpLg.text: Wow, LV! Didn't expect a good ramen in Nevada of all places~ Was I glad to have driven 3.3 miles from the strips to Chinatown. Visiters - go try their ramen if you love that noodle soup!! They have rather simple menu and selections - ramen, cold ramen (hiyashi chuka), & rice (fried kimchi rice, pork fried rice, mini mentaiko rice, chashu rice), They can pretty much customize your bowl (if you choose to). Soups they offer are; shoyu, tonkotsu, tonkotsu/shoyu, & miso.  Add the spicy paste to any soup base, pick the noodle (thin, thick, extra curly), & toppings. Spicy miso ramen was what I had! That first sip of the broth took my blues awat after a long sad losing day at the casino!! ;-)  Wait maybe long because this is a small ramen place. Definitely worth the drive out!

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy miso

dhAlj9kYtGIalpEmhXGP3g.text: Believe or not, "Monta Ramen house" is a must go restaurant whenever I'm in Las Vegas.  Unlike other ramen house, their soup is the Best!! It has super rich taste of flavor that goes perfectly with noodles! Try to drink the soup and eat the noodles at the same time, and also add a piece of Tonkatsu, they will take you into another level! The Tonkatsu will literally melted in your mouth!  Don't forget to order a pork belly bowl, if you can't stop yourself to order more.  It's so hard for me to write the review without eating the ramen right now!! In case you don't want to wait in line, get there before they open!

LI2ZAQpQr5fDClwpoM4ZAQ.text: Just wow! This place is amazing. Pretty small inside so the wait can get to be a bit long, but absolutely worth it. Between the three of us, we tried Miso, Tonkotsu, and Shoyu Ramen, Gyoza, and Fried Rice. The fried rice and ramen were very good, the gyoza was as well but we all said we would have rather had more rice. People are great, service was great, and food was AMAZING!

u9-ohuRRhX59IvCbMH_C_A.text: Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen w/ corn and butter. You won't regret it. Monta is a small place but the wait is always worth it! Kimchi Fried Rice and Gyoza hit the spot. Don't be intimidated by the crowd/wait, they do a great job of keeping it moving.

jIbGGPyp0ct4d1fT7r6G3A.text: My favorite ramen place on vegas i like every single dish in the menu sometimes thwre is wait time but it is worth it

N0j_pfso0pJXlYpTMyAd2A.text: A tiny place with a huge success of the almighty simple ramen noodles.  The base of the fillings are cha chu, black fungus, and green onion with a choice of black garlic, soy, miso, or spicy miso soup base.  For extra, you can add eggs, seaweed, extra cha chu, and corns.  Medium portion size and price is economical.  Noodle has a balance, not sure if it is hand made. My black garlic was heavy, first taste it reminiscing a familiar taste which took me awhile to figure out as abundance of sesame oil favors.  It was delicious.  The spicy miso wildly heated and it excited the taste goblets.  Wait can be long, but the turn around is quick. Absolutely a revisit.

LAJFOTI5wgOA4O6jQzakaw.text: Excellent food. Authentic. Great choices for soups and fried rices. Good for veg options as well.  Very friendly staff.

nvXBsIhtHaUg0nOcBH0MZQ.text: This is one of my top ramen places in the entire U.S. I try to come here every time I'm in Vegas, and for $7.50/bowl it's an unbeatable value! I like to get the Black Garlic ramen and share the Takana Rice plate. I've only been to one other place that offers black garlic ramen but Monta's has this dish down. My only complaint is I wish I didn't smell like black garlic afterwards, but I'm willing to make this sacrifice obviously.

uUrWG16LNzqfpWN9NgXvlg.text: 5 stars for the service. We were there on last sat night. The place was packed. The servers and chefs were moving as fast as they could, and with a smile (I didn't catch her name) 3 stars for the food since it was too salty even after adding a gallon of vinegar. ;)

YBLSAyPVZL1g3u8XpAbqmA.text: I came across this place and saw a small crowd waiting for tables out front and thought this place should be goof. Then I check Yelp and it looks legit, but this is the worst Ramen I've ever had, worse then the Tokyo airport Ramen I've had back in 2006. The broth is extremely salty and the pork has a foul smell.   This is review is purely based on the food, not the service.

TsTzWnQ0bhLfmUEfRo7Ufw.text: According to Yelp, Monta appears to be the most popular ramen joint in Vegas. If this place were relocated to Little Tokyo in DTLA, Sawtelle Blvd. or Gardena/Torrance, I doubt it would even make the mid-tier.  Hits: * Mildly impressed by the Tonkotsu ramen -- the broth was greasy and creamy, but not completely full-bodied... definitely not worth the half hour wait and hype * Ramen is cheap (~$7), since the portion sizes are small -- if you're still craving more noodles, add another serving for $1.50 * Order the overpriced hot green tea ($3) and you'll be amazed that the aluminum can is still hot... Apparently the Japanese vending machine keeps the can warm * The servers are good about splitting the check, and you can pay with card  Lessons Learned: * Why are all ramen restaurants so tiny?? This place can seat 20 at a time, and does not easily accommodate to parties larger than 4 (my party of 6 barely fit at the bar counter) * Prepare to wait -- we waited half an hour coming here at 5p on a Monday night * While the waitress was nice, she seemed really distracted -- In between taking my friend's order, she rushed into the kitchen and then came back 5 minutes later to resume taking down his order... weird * The ajitama ($1 for half an egg -.-) is not included and was slightly overcooked.. lame! * I think there was one Japanese chef in the show kitchen -- the rest were Latino/a ... reminded me of Tatsu Ramen  I think I'll stick to pho when I'm in Vegas from now on.
