hxD_hB7kV_eAVYy24oTcGw.text: BEST RAMEN IVE EVER HAD. It's been 3 days and I'm still dreaming about this ramen. The broth... The noodles... Just amazing. It was cooked to perfection. I got the tonkatsu ramen and loved it. The fried rice was delicious, and the gyoza were to die for. Will come back for sure when we're in Vegas next.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen, to die for!

2iNxAmdfd3JZE5me_w00kA.text: There have been a number of ramen places that have popped up in Vegas since Monta, and I've also had ramen in Cali, so my rating has definitely changed since. Ya know, when you don't really know better...  I'd still come back to this place, as it is the closest to me, and it's still pretty good, but the last time I was back here, I definitely noticed the taste difference in just everything.  Ramen is still decent enough for a visit. They are almost always busy (especially since their place is quite small) and service never really falls short. It's such a small place that it's quite hard for the servers to ignore you.  Still will be a regular to this particular ramen restaurant in Vegas, but 4 stars is the most I can give it now.  & I always get the TONKOTSU SHOYU ramen :)!

vy5aNUwJd2kasxDcVkpmvQ.text: Tried Jinya Ramen the other. It was good then tried Monta today. I'm glad I tried Jinya first because Monta's Tonkatsu Ramen is leagues better.  The menu is simpler than Jinya but taste wise Monta is better

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Ramen. Going with the simple dish you can see how good the place is

7v23_2SmG1C70Xlo8GPUyw.text: This is an above average ramen house in terms of food, but the one thing is that when we got our noodles, the soup and egg was lukewarm, which really bothered our party.  Other than that, parking is a little tight, the wait is a little long  and they're not good for large groups.

klob0Oth28dsIDSY4BiJAA.text: This is probably my favorite ramen spot in Vegas, and I've tried near all of them.  The line gets really long so be prepared to wait an hour in the hot sun. Run over across to one of the other spots in the plaza or over to the market across the street.   I get the Miso Ramen and ask for them to make it spicy. You can ask for the spicy ball on the side if you want.  The noodles are pretty firm and chewy. They don't leave a waxy feeling in your mouth. Kaedama (extra noodles) are only a buck fifty more too.  The broth is where it's at though. It's really thick and tasty. I normally get around 4 noodles (1 original and 3 extra) in before I need extra spicy sauce or something to thicken it up.   I'd say this is the number two spot, just can't eek out Ippudo, sorry!

xUCcURkPMsMGqxr5rKVqyg.text: Our last day in Las Vegas, We decided to go to Monta Ramen for lunch. Monta opened at  11:30am, and there is a line already!! We saw people lining up outside, after waiting for a little bit, my friend noticed there is a sign up sheet inside!!! Damn it!! They should leave the sign up outside! Oh, there is no sign saying Manto in front, but you can't miss it with the long line outside.  Anyways, after about almost 1 hour wait, we finally got seated at the bar ... which was fine, we get to look at the chefs.  Food! We ordered a Large Pork Belly Rice Bowl to share - the fatty pieces of pork were cooked perfectly, so tender, buttery, just goes perfect with rice! I really miss this!  Hubby ordered the basic Tonkotsu Ramen with egg added - broth is very bold and tense, and what I love the most is not overly salty!  I ordered the Kuro Ramen with egg added on the daily special board - black garlic oil ramen, I really love it. Egg was perfectly soft boiled, runny center. I do wish that it was thick noodles, this is just personal preference :)  My friend ordered Tonkotsu Ramen with egg and corn added - looks amazing!!  Very good and authentic Ramen place!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen with egg and corn added
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen with egg added
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen with egg added

BwBslvRz-MmqPQ6GUIBwwA.text: OMG, the Tonkatsu Ramen....this broth is what my dreams are made of!!! It's extra fatty and creamy and aromatic, and it goes with the ramen noodles perfectly. The balance in flavors here is phenomenal. The bowls come out piping hot and perfect!  If you don't like feeling your arteries clog as you eat, you can go for the Miso Ramen or a mixed broth ramen (which have a different flavor profile, but are also wonderfully paired with the ramen noodles).   Tip: get the extras! The pork is DELICIOUS, and if you like eggs with runny creamy yolks, order the flavored egg :)   Also, this is a tiny little ramen shop reminiscent of Daikokuya in downtown LA.....the wait/line can be super long....but the turn-around time is pretty fast because the little shop gets so hot you'll want to leave as soon as you're done eating!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen  + extra pork :)

PGM9IxL2f-HD3cXbjqFhGg.text: My favorite ramen is tonkotsu. Some people don't like the intense broth and find it salty. Me? I love the creamy, porky flavors.  Monta's broth is especially thick. Two of my dinner companions thought it was too salty but I loved it. I didn't think that was saltiness. It was intense umami from the greatly reduced broth. The broth was so rich that you can chew it.  The pork belly was tender and the eggs were good. Noodles could have been more springy.  Hope to RTE.

7pjIURaEjaJx-oBaFiW1sA.text: Upon recommendation by a friend and after reading the raving reviews, I gave this place a shot this evening.   I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen and small fried rice.  The soup doesn't blow me away like Santouka broth. Maybe it's the addition of the red spices.  But the fried rice is amazing. Much better than the ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice is amazing.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu ramen. Do not quite like it.

cZ5YjqZpYPYStDwKQcRH8A.text: Perhaps this is the best ramen that Las Vegas can produce, but it's definitely not the best ramen out there. It's not even "pretty good" ramen. It's simply decent. I came on a weekday for lunch and there were several people waiting outside for a table. This noodle shop is tiny. Luckily, it was only my boyfriend and me so we snatched two seats at the bar. I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen while he had the Tonkotsu Ramen with an egg.   Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen - pork and chicken broth with two slices of pork chashu, black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and a pile of green onions. The broth was extremely salty, especially compared to my boyfriend's broth. The noodles were rather springy but they were still acceptable. Half of the pork chashu was fat so there was actually very little meat.  Tonkotsu Ramen - pork broth with two slices of pork chashu, black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and a pile of green onions. My boyfriend added an egg which was soft-boiled so the white was cooked through, but the yolk remained molten. He thought his ramen was OK (and he's a ramen fanatic!). The broth fell flat (although not as salty as mine).  The flavors here aren't very compelling. The portions are generous considering a bowl is about $7 and the noodles come out pipin' hot. The restaurant is quite small so I was feeling a bit claustrophobic. That, coupled with the relentless Las Vegas heat, made me want to bolt outta there the second I was done slurping my noodles. Service was lackluster, not that I was expecting anything phenomenal. If you're in Chinatown and need a quick and warm bowl of ramen, Monta will suffice.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen

L9MHphzoDqZZnILnbvuRBA.text: This crowded place has super good deal for extremely authentic Japanese noodle. Always stop by here when we are in Vegas. They never let  down: creamly soup base, good texture of noodle. The fried rice threw us off: it has so much flavor and the chef did so much work in front of us. Yes, the chefs are not Japanese but dudes are so professional. The place rocks!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. We will come back for this
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. These guys are good
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UKKxXnUyEm-LrEim8pdnUg.text: Being from the bay area, I didn't expect much going to a ramen place in Vegas. But the ramen crave is real. We went at around 10 and the place was almost full. Luckily we got a table right away.  We got the black garlic oil ramen and the fried rice. The ramen was definitely up to the standards. The soup had such strong flavor without being too oily. The noodles were nice and chewy. The fried rice was good, but tasted much stronger compared to the ramen. The best part, the noodles were about $9 with added egg and the fried rice was only $5+. So worth the money.  The sitting through the terrible Vegas traffic is worth it.

8p0w5Tgcj8bzYhWl3-qO6w.text: Cheap and good. Like, really good! The tonkotsu was porky but still tasted clean, rich but not too gelatinous nor oily. Definitely order the black garlic ramen, the garlic adds a layer of earthy complexity. You would be hardpressed to find something similar at this price point outside of Japan.

UCArdFmyvkOye7Pzre8Zqg.text: This was my first neg experience here in the 5-6 years I've been patronizing Monta.  I don't come for the customer service, I come for their delicious food, but I haven't had a bad customer service experience until yesterday.   We were in a group of 6 and being waiting on by a waitress named Sanchi or Sachi, she quickly took our orders but didn't repeat or confirm the orders which is what I'm used to. When the food arrived at the table, two of our orders were incorrect. When we told her about it, she looked concerned and then curtly said something along the lines of "order it right next time". I was a little stunned by that, but because there is usually a language barrier with the staff there I brushed it off. I wanted to talk to the waitress again, to let her know if it was a problem, just add the two incorrect orders in our bill. I looked around and saw our waitress with another waitstaff named Archer looking at our table and talking/ laughing-- that didn't rub me the right way, and on top of that we didn't get checked in on until Archer came to the table to basically take over for Sanchi/Sachi, I'm guessing she asked him to take over. I explained our experience to Archer, and he was as kind as someone trying to mitigate a customer service complaint could be in that situation.   My take away was feeling insulted, but lesson learned, if you're in a big party or just in general, ask the waitress to repeat your order in there-- they usually do, but it happened yesterday that our waitress didn't, and it's loud and busy in that restaurant almost all the time. Again, the food is amazing, I don't go for the customer service. But I don't go to be insulted either, so make sure to protect your own experience there because customer service doesn't seem to be a priority.

VEjPQsz1UxckIY-LgcnjBA.text: Considering how popular this ramen place is, I thought it was weird that I didn't enjoy it all that much. I had the regular tonkatsu ramen with thick noodles. I usually like my noodles a bit firm but I thought their noodles were a bit undercooked.  Their broth was quite thick, but it just tasted too salty and fatty to me. I really needed an iced milk tea after that bowl of ramen. I enjoyed their guitars though. Tasted fresh with thin skin and juicy filling.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen with thick noodle

b1AypZIYU1HfnffR22LAig.text: Definitely worth the wait!  This place was a good choice to begin our vacation in Vegas. We ordered the spicy tonkotsu soup with rice noodles, pork, shredded green onions, corn, and kimchi. Delish!  The broth got better as I neared the bottom of the bowl.  I could have eaten it everyday I was in town. I have been searching for an equivalent since I left Vegas- it can't be beat.

91qiItHGZ6MdR8SZYFROBA.text: Great whole in a wall. I just wish there was something else other than just pork. My 2 teenagers really liked it and ordered noodle refill. The fried rice was very tasty but again, I wish they had shrimp or beef as an added option.

pf4Kd-EkCmQlogEJu6Q6lQ.text: This place is small but the food is amazing! Definitely will come back again. I actually bought extra soup to take home with me so that I can eat it for dinner.

t-kFvSCThgFmcMCE0AxRsw.text: Make sure to go over the specials.  I missed my chance to have spicy tonkatsu but it's okay, cause the regular tonkatsu was PERFECT.    The garlic oil ramen was amazing as well.  I kept stealing spoonfuls from my boyfriend's bowl.   Definitely going to come back here every time I'm in Vegas.  Def going at 5PM because we were able to get seats quick!

O-i6fZvlW0JPtqmXkSTuGg.text: I do not understand the hype about this place. It's cramped, hella dark, and their soup is SALTY. I am a fan of salt, but after eating here, I always get a sodium induced headache. I have tried this place THREE times (in hopes that maybe each time was just an 'off-night') but every time we have visited, same experience.   Pros- The service is great, the toppings to the ramen are delicious, and the food comes out fast.  .... But it's just not enough to keep me coming back.

uPlzQNsfqnbV7RJ1M6PhFQ.text: Once seated, the service is super fast! Tonkatsu and miso ramen were both excellent. Now I see why there is such a wait to eat here! Everything was great, I would definitely come back!

3V7HvjvUAOdZ1I_vh3D1xQ.text: Yes there IS a light at the end of the Spring Mountain Road Chinese/Vietnamese restaurant tunnel!  Tucked away in the back of a somewhat crowded strip mall (on your right hand side as you pass Decatur going up Spring Mountain) is Monta Ramen.  As with most Japanese Ramen houses, this place is tiny but I think that's what makes it feel so authentic.   What sets Monta apart from the others I've tried is the deliciously rich pork bone soup base that you know has been simmering for hours on end.  The noodles are perfect, not too firm but not soggy and the portions are just right.  And if you're crazy enough in thinking about adding that ridiculously priced $1.50 egg, do it.  Even though it costs the same as almost a dozen at the supermarket you won't regret it because it's semi runny/creamy texture blends perfectly with the soup.  Sitting at the bar, digging into my bowl of noodle heaven made me feel like I needed to start loudly slurping to show my appreciation.   If you're in the area Monta is definitely not to be missed...or actually don't go, it'll be a shorter wait for me.  :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza filling.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Handmade gyoza.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen with egg.

F1ZNtHobO9Zvzpi1Llx3Aw.text: What can I say about Monta. I used to like it. Unfortunately, "used to," is the key word. Today, I keep coming back expecting their classic ramen, best broth, and perfected simplicity. But I now must admit all I have come to expect is disappointment. I have been coming here for about 2-3 years. But now I can't help but second guess my decisions.   The service here has seemed to have gone down the drain. They give so much attitude and don't really care about the customers. You are rushed to order and if you have any problems or questions you are met with eye rolls and sighs. I'm not a picky eater, not at all, but service is key.   Now to the food. I remember the food they used to have was great. Unfortunately that didn't seem to translate over time. Like watching the slow death of a once great king, the food quality has seemed to die too.  Over salty broth, oily broth, boiled gyoza, and an appalling meat to rice ratio on their side dishes. What happened? WHAT HAPPENED?   To this I'm sorry Monta... You have lost me. I used to defend you feverishly against other ramen places but now... You have betrayed me. So to all you newbies that rave and praise this "new" monta. You can have it. I will leave this place in the past.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold noodles!

ZUHvQjYRFA2yb7H9zr4itw.text: I'm a regular at their Eastern & Serene location (I go AT LEAST once a week), however that location is temporary closed so I've been coming to this one. Their tonkotsu ramen is AMAZING. Never fails to satisfy me. Staff is always friendly & attentive. It gets busy & it's a small restaurant so don't be surprised if there's a wait outside! Yup, it's THAT good!

ZIQptvs90mRqrTJJCAGUKQ.text: My family loves this place. We stop here every time we come to Vegas.  The ramen is fantastic as well as the fried rice and pot stickers.  It is always crowded but they turn the tables quickly.  The service is always good as long as you don't try to stay too long and chat after your meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I can&#39;t come to Vegas without stopping by Monta Ramen for the best ramen I have ever had.

2ljGaYUz23grcZTZ_aCc9g.text: Once you eat a real home made ramen, there is no going back to the bagged stuff. The texture is so different and so is the flavor. Monta is the real deal - very delicious and on par with the best ramen places we've visited in Tokyo and Honolulu.

mj8ylR_ySzdzAUll_1M8XA.text: Yes, there's always usually a wait. Sometimes you'll get lucky and you'll just wait a few minutes and sometimes you'll wait till a group finishes their meal to get sat. It's a really small space. But oh man the ramen is delicious! I usually get the tonkotsu shoyu with additional egg and corn. Yesterday I tried the kuro ramen which had black garlic oil and it didn't disappoint. The fried rice here is also a must. The service is usually fast and friendly. My only complaint is that once in a while, the broth is too salty. Oh and yeah don't expect you're gonna sit around and chat with your group after your meal because you'll get some serious death stares from hungry customers waiting to get sat lol

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu shoyu!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen

h_6OY8Ju_4UcpvsltB5Prw.text: Loved it. The ingredients taste good. The broth is incredible. The service is really quick. It has a cool San Francisco like vibe.

1JaHKlFQwiPqhmIbsrF2vw.text: Good ramen is a warm hug from a beautiful friend!  I have ramen every 10 days religiously, but I frequent another ramen shop down the street a bit and had never been in Monta previously.  Monta is very good...they do you a solid here with their flavors.  The cramped little space and bustling turnover carries a positive energy with it... if you aren't waiting at rush hour.  That being said, Monta is not my favorite, and while I would happily come back, I probably won't too often since my favorite is so close.  I am all about the miso ramen, so I enjoyed that here as well.  I read Yuhi K.'s review before ordering so I also enjoyed the mentaiko and made sure to use togarashi.  These were excellent suggestions so I'll pass them on as well, but check out her review for more details.    The bottom line for me was that the broth lacked the deep, developed flavors you can get elsewhere, but they have some great options--especially for the kosher minded.  I have had a couple experiences where an individual I try to take to ramen isn't into the traditional pork broth.  Monta takes care of that by offering chicken base.  Monta also has some bar seating with an open kitchen...a great place to dine solo.

Kt-vuHla--xT2ytpjlIkyA.text: Las Vegas is blessed with these tiny gems but this is a standout. Amazing food, everyone is friendly. The best energy!

mVcKVKDANlaJox0RD9UCgQ.text: The wait at this place is insane (especially around the holidays).  Be ready to wait, I recommend the boba tea place next door.  Once inside the service was quick but friendly and the food was amazing and well priced.  Super good ramen and fried rice for about $8 each.   Oh, they have hot tea that is served in the can!? My old lady told me the heated cans is something from Shark Tank.  I kinda liked it. I prefer the steaming pot of tea but it was cool.

wPdcrxYNC3PSYsRZ1yMWsQ.text: Keep in mind, a 4.5 would probably be spot on. I went here on my last trip to Vegas in Fall of 2013 and hadn't had time to review it.  I just came back from a Vegas trip where I made 2 trips here it was that good.  Keep in mind, this little food shopping plaza is a gem in general if you have a car to drive off the strip.  My first time on this recent trip, I went with one of their specials, Kuro Black Garlic Oil Ramen.  There was this amazing, but not overly powerful garlic flavor. I somewhat wish it was more noticeable to be honest.  But everything else in terms of the noodles, chasu and broth was spot on.  I  have a soft spot for corn and an egg... and extra noodle of course =D  My second visit on this recent trip was... right before my flight actually.  I went with my sure bet, the delicious Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen.  Again, the broth was very tasty and flavorful.  The spice is OK, but not as spicy as I probably would have liked/tolerated.    Until I can find better, my go to ramen/hangover spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Black Garlic Ramen

PxSYX1wCJf_dvVgzrQSLfw.text: Dude good....    So many reviews out here....   I dont want to be redundant so I'll be short.      the good  Food....   Yum Yum Yum  the bad  so small...     if its busy you will have to wait...    i think it was 3 tables  also get the pork belly bowl...   do it now....    dont argue with me...     get it and thank me later  The unfortunate and uncomfortable  I liked it a lot and I rarely get sick from anything I eat but my wife does...    and did.   Had I eaten there alone it would have been 5 stars...   but my wife came home and was sick all night.      Bad Monta....     Bad Bad Monta

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Oh my god yum

_KRHgGDejEME3CtEgm_dDg.text: Really the best place and yet to find something better. Fast service but crazy lines. I was just super lucky that we didn't have to wait. The place is really small but worth every minute in line.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

rujvfpkDopI_2nuvCDFf0w.text: I love love love Monta Ramen.  Their food is so fresh, healthy,  and FAST!  The place is ALWAYS packed which means to me that I'M not the only one who  thinks so. This has to be the most popular ramen house in LAS Vegas.  I get the Miso Ramen often BUT there's on dish with lots of bean sprouts that I want to try.. looks so yummy! ! My lunch partner had Tonkotsu which of course I tasted... she put corn in it which was brilliant!  Can't wait to go back again.  A humble setting with wicked food!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic oil ramen.. yum!!

5EU5p71-Xiq9ra0O6vIflQ.text: This place is amazing!!! The pork belly melts in your mouth! The best ramen I've ever had. Straight Japanese style fresh made everyday. I've been to many high rated ramen shops in other cities as I love ramen, and this place takes ramen to a whole new level. For desert hit up the snowflake place next door, also bad a**!!!!

z4scIbFFo8BQ5oQ2uA85fQ.text: Please tell me what the fuss is all about.  The first time I went there was with my older Son, who acted like a Japanese Cultural officionado. He schooled me in the traditions and culture of Ramen.  It was just "ok".  The second time I went with my wife. We were both disappointed. She is Korean and particular about noodle. I tried her Ramen, and wasn't very good.   The waitress suggested a pork dish to me. I am pleased to tell you my dogs throughly enjoyed it, but I didn't it.  I have to say the servers are very nice, friendly, and quite frankly, easy on the eyes.   I won't go back there.   By the way, my son ended up in the US Navy and stationed in Japan for two years. When he returned, I asked him if he wanted to eat here. He informed me that it would be like a hamburger gourmet eating at Burger King.

AhTktrwrDdhz7xGAWvEipw.text: Great ramen place  Off the strip location - always busy and crowded - need to put your name on a list

AXkz_7e2C6rbEU846xz1aA.text: omggggggggg!!!!!!!! i got the black oil ramen sup with a hard boiled egg ...WOW WOW WOW WOOOOWWWWWWWWWWWW... the best soup pf my life. if i could get on a plane right now back to Vegas just for that soup i would. i DREAM about that soup!~! the wait is long but ABSOLUTELY worth the wait

zIneuc4WTzRrz3iSBHw9BQ.text: This gem of a place was so great I am still dreaming of the ramen I had there last Tuesday. My friend and I got a massage right next to the place and was ready for dinner when we saw the line outside Monta and got curious. Went inside and saw a small six table dive-ish kind of place so looked at Yelp for some guidance. Once I saw the reviews, I know its a match made in heaven. I signed in so we can get a table and waited 10 mins to get seated. We were lucky because there's only three parties ahead of us. We sat by the bar and ordered 2 gyoza, fried rice, pork belly bowl, a Kura Ramen for me and Shoyu ramen for my friend. The service was quick and efficient and it wasn't long till we feasted on this scrumptious food. First off, the bowls of ramen are huge!!! My black garlic ramen with extra egg was so good I am thinking about it until  now. The broth had depth of flavor and I relished every single spoonful. The noodles were al dente and tasted fresh and went well with the black garlic seasoning, I can eat it all day long. No regrets after I decided to be adventurous and try black garlic anything for the first time. Now on to the Gyoza - they were pillows of soft savory goodness with a slight crunch from being pan friend. The meat was lightly seasoned and was perfect with a lil bit of chili oil and soy sauce dipping sauce. The pork belly bowl was a good sized bowl (I ordered a small) and hit all the right spots with the tender pork belly coupled with the fragrant rice. It was the best $45 meal I have ever had in my entire life. I wish there was one in Houston. I am dreaming of coming back to Vegas just for this. And oh, don't even think about saving it for next day. Enjoy it while you can, and how it should be - fresh on the day of ordering and don't complain about it not being quite the same the following day. As a ramen enthusiast, Ramen is best enjoyed fresh and hot. I cannot wait to go back!!! Now on to dreaming about it again

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza wowzaaaa
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly bowl ohhhh sooooo good
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kura Ramen, Gyoza, Pork Belly Rice

6xJpbCybYksGc3PEZuvJNg.text: The woman is just so rude to the customer. Luckily, we changed our mind and ordered for picking up. and one more thing, I don't care if your restaurant gets too crowded. Customer service is the most important part in hospitality especially in Las Vegas.

HbFoIlOEdbIRYC5EHoxT5A.text: If you're craving for a steaming bowl of ramen, this place is IT!   Now I only gave them 4 stars as I wish they would expand even just a tad. Seating is so tight but I guess it also adds to highlight of when your name is finally called and you sit on their wooden chairs and get served almost immediately. The menu consists of 4 simple but very different ramen bowls and a few add ons and very minimal side dishes. But so much easier to choose from.  Love the Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen. I order mine with thick noodles instead which are seeped in pork AND chicken broth. DOUBLE the flavor. I make sure to always order extra chasyu (pork) although all ramen bowls come with 2 slices.  Love the slurp of the noodles and melt in your mouth pork. Slices of mushroom are added as a garnish but even that helps enhance the flavor.  This is only my second time here but I enjoy it immensely and even more so that I got to share it with 9 of my other friends...at the same time! :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen with extra pork chasyu

IZVc46mPKB7FvXD3NQpQ0A.text: Well a co worker and I decided to go here for lunch. ( she frequents this spot). The wait at lunch time was not horrible and the service was speedy. We got in and seated and ordered food within 5 minutes. After ordering the food was up about minutes later ( everything is already ready to go in the back it's just noodles and pork essentially). The food was pretty tasty and and at a good temperature.The texture was great and he serving was large for the price. The reason for the low rating. I am have never had such an upset stomach after eating any other food. I will try again, maybe a lighter dish and see if there is another reaction. However this did make me awfully ill.

TIK1DmQdI9Gc3a_p-wb3kQ.text: No other place serves better ramen in Las Vegas.  This isn't debatable.    Sometimes it may be a bit salty or whatnot, but I guarantee you, the other Japanese restaurants in the Chinatown area can never compare to their ramen.  Unless you've found a smaller, hole-in-the-wall place (doubt that's possible, considering how small this place is), then let me know.  Great ramen.  Great for the price, but it's $10 for the ramen plus a couple ingredients.  The service is ALWAYS fast.  I mean, how hard is it with less than 20 seats?  If something concerns you, the server is no more than 10 feet away- call for them when they pass by.  There are several kinds of soup base you can pick from- each explaining in good detail what they taste like.  They are never watery- very flavorful, and each side dish they give you to put into your soup is always fresh.  The ramen doesn't taste like cup noodle.  Someone earlier said that it's a typical, small Asian restaurant- get your food, eat, get the bill, get out.  Ok, that's True.  So what, you're going to knock them down a star for them not having a heart to heart connection with you and not letting you tell them your whole life story?  Please.    Good food, some waiting, good service, cozy interior.. nothing to complain about.

eEsPpocOmY7NimxWAUOjuQ.text: First timer based on a friends recommendation. Small, quaint place that runs like a well oiled machine. Food is fantastic! Don't think twice. Just go!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

5B5YBiXD7CkzPyPDz-vBgA.text: All the reviews are right!  WOW! So good. I had the Miso $7.25 for a bowl of delishesness

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

rsRA3E4P9yFmAzgMGPBg0Q.text: Honestly the BEST place for ramen in Vegas. Their restaurant is really small, given that it is basically a hole in the wall type of thing. So you're always looking at a wait time of atleast 10-20 minutes. But sometimes you'll get lucky and have no wait at all. Not gonna lie though. ITS TOTALLY WORTH THE WAIT. They're very inexpensive too.  I recommend their Miso Ramen with an add on of Nitamago, corn, and garlic. Sooooo good. And the pork that it comes with just melts in your mouth.  the only thing I hate about going to Monta, is the parking situation. Its such a popular and busy plaza because there are so many restaurants there, so everyone literally fights for parking.

REs8FnPr3yClZSPOATpgpQ.text: I've been in this place 5 times, It won't be the last. This a gem hidden and always who come to visit me this is one the place I take them. Is a must visit if you really are in to  Ramen. Beside the Ramen they have one of the best rice I ever had. You won't regret.  6 stars for me.

LJ-kPvvpRddC_QHZ8qw5CQ.text: I am a ramen lover. I live in California and I love to drive to Little Tokyo for their ramen. Well.. While visiting Vegas I have to say this place is a must! I ordered the Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen and it is delicious!! I ate everything that came in the bowl and also slurped up that broth.  The wait IS long but I won't deduct stars for the parking/wait line.   The food is well worth the wait.

SIoph7Y81-BtvEvPWjLiig.text: Great ramen. We went Monday exactly at 11:30 and took the last two spots available. There was a line before the place opened. Mostly locals too. Great place.

6toGGBhGgs6AuAKEXMBmig.text: Monta is quite the popular one! We got there right when it opened (11:30AM) and people were already lined up outside. We were lucky to even get a seat in their tinny space  (bar and tables).   We ordered a shoyu and tonkatsu ramen with a side of gyoza.  Everything is made to order and cooked fresh (though, ramen comes in  plastic packets -- probably shipped from somewhere else).  The gyoza was pretty forgettable as it had charring on the top. They're also not as delicate as the ones in Hakata (my forever ramen love!).   What I did like was their smooth ramen broth base.  Not too thick nor thin and also not too salty. Tonkatsu ramen comes with thinner noodles and shoyu comes with curly thicker noodles. Overall, tonkatsu is the winner between the two in terms of taste.  Pork was too fatty for my liking, but the overall verdict has a good return factor.

a83HLGM4dVF4veqUjaCNXQ.text: Yum yum. The best ramen we've had, we arrived at noon and had to wait about 25 minutes. The line was still long when we left after 1 pm  We had the spicy Tonkutsu pork, which next time I would just get regular, the broth is awesome by itself.  The ramen with chicken broth, shoyu  The pork belly rice bowl  Gyoza  All excellent. We stopped here after shopping at the (blah) north outlet mall.  The Terry Fator show tonight  at the Mirage was really fun.

ijS1ICxw1eZjtjCJpx3YuA.text: Best Ramen in Vegas  Ramen: small menu only 4 soup bases, My boyfriend loves Tonkotsu Ramen but I love the Miso Ramen. I get the Miso Ramen plus extra Chashu pork and extra egg. Which is more then enough for a small person like me. But for a guy who loves to eat my boyfriend usually orders with extra ramen. The soup is delicious, you would think the Miso ramen would be really salty but it's really well balanced. I love sprinkling the spices and drowning my soup with sesame oil. I like my soap red and spicy.   Line: The wait usually is 15-30 min the place is pretty small but the line moves quickly because people eat ramen pretty quick. They have small waiting area inside and a bench outside.  Customer Service: The waitresses who work there are super sweet, but once they mixed my order with another table and gave us free kimchi with no charged so I thought that was sweet. The cooks are funny, once I sat at the bar peeking up to see how the cooks make this delicious Ramen and a cook cracks a joke at me.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

c9fJHyI6y3EvwdcvPZ60tA.text: One of my favorite Asian restaurant overall. Specialized in Noodles Soup, they are just the best when I compare all the restaurants I've been to. I would definitely recommend anybody to go at this joint.  Atmosphere 5 / 5: Decorated in a japanese style, Monta is a little bit small with maximum 10 seating tables and a bar but it has a warm and friendly feeling as soon as you enter in the restaurant. Food 5 / 5: I chose the Chicken Ramen (or Shoyu Ramen ) with an addition of Kimchi, Onions, Eggs and if you're REALLY hungry, you can try to go with the addition of noodles. I want to meet you at the same time if you can finish your noodles soup with an addition of noodles, the basic soup is already huge! I also tried their saute fried rice that is excellent. This place is well recommended after a hangover. :-D Service 5 / 5: They're fast! The staff speaks japanese between them and you might see one of the waitress singing a Florida song with her japanese accent (Fun!).  Great finding, thank you YELP!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Rahmen

tebrJM5E90niJsspx8cX7g.text: Comfort food in a bowl of heaven!  We lucked out and got a seat at the counter within 5 minutes.  Which was fine with me! I love to watch chefs in action. I got the Tonkotsu Ramen with Chashu Pork and Nitamago.  The broth was smoky and out of this world!  The portions were huge!  Our server was a sweetheart!  Another great place for my late night cravings!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Late night comfort food!

Ejn3mwTe0KzamQ8bH6P-ZQ.text: Great range of ramen flavors and variations of noodle thickness. The kuro ramen features a rich tonkatsu base broth enhanced with a roasted garlic puree and black sesame seed oil. This broth was noticeably thicker in texture and more viscous than the plain tonkatsu or shoyu based broth.  I tasted three ramen broths and all had good flavor, none were over salted or heavy handed on the main flavor.   Gyoza was excellent, mine was juicy and had a great meat to veggie balance.    Small location so keep the party size 4 and under. Overall great quick service and quality food.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl (small)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen with egg

zj84Cr4tXU1gCm4UWglXTw.text: Huge portions, decent ramen.  There was no wait when I arrived around 4PM on a Friday afternoon. The place is small, so I understand why people say there's always a wait.  What I noticed is that there were signs posted for spicy options available for the ramen that weren't on the actual menu given to us. I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen with an added egg. The spicy ramen menu items are a little more expensive than the regular ramen, but only because they add a chili paste in the ramen that makes it spicy. I was not a fan of the chili paste that I mixed into my broth. The portion was very generous, but it's not the best ramen I've had. I don't recommend getting any of the ramen bowls spicy! Just order what's on the menu.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu ramen with added egg

j5UVHawxQZ0d6qwNnMNHIg.text: 4.5 stars for super rich and delicious ramen!  I LOVE fatty, rich broth - this was so good but actually a little overwhelming even for my standards. If I were to return, I would get the shio or soy broth instead.  Can't wait to come back. p.s. lines not too terrible on weekdays off-peak lunch hours.

osyE9b1VPdbH1EBhbjzbKQ.text: The broth here is different than ramen places in LA . . It is creamier and somewhat less saltier.  By far one of my favorites.  I thoroughly enjoyed half of the bowl I was capable of eating.    RICE WITH MASAGO isn't very impressive - it is literally just rice, seaweed, and fish roe.  KIM CHI FRIED RICE is really good.  Good mix of the kim chi and not too overpowering.  Drunk friends ate it later at night as said it was still good.

U_xX1y3I1b1VniOxjy4vNw.text: A very intimate ramen shop. First time in here, seats were very limited so guests were in and out very quick. Ordered the porkbelly bowl and a huge bowl of ramen with chashu. Very quick service but the taste and flavor was not MIA. Of course I added the five spice and some sesame seeds too.  Had a good time, food was awesome, definitely returning to have me some hot noodles and broth.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2OBUiUMid-leAsYkdADdow.text: I have been saying for years...I really want to try some ramen places.  Finally on a indecisive Sunday we made the leap and did it! It was 1115am when we arrived and there was already a line.  The place opened at 1130am on the dot and quickly it was full.  My husband and I sat at the counter which was exactly what we wanted.  We had the opportunity to watch the chefs prepare and cook our meals. Within 30 minutes we ate, paid and left with stuffed satisfied bellies along with a take out meal.   I had the miso ramen and my husband had the Tonkotsu Ramen spicy.  I did love mine but after I devoured mine I went for his and boy was he lucky my belly was full because it was euphoric for me!  I love spicy and will be ordering his next time. We also shared kimchi fried rice which did not make it to a to go bag. Lol. In addition we ordered pork belly bowl to go and had for dinner later that night. It was just as appetizing as our lunch and were very pleased with our decision to get an additional meal to go.  5/5 and will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice 5/5
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen 5/5 with added egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen 豚骨 spicy with added egg 5/5 amazing

5u2ujwIcl3zDznCC-LOhVw.text: Every time we've eaten here the noodles and meals are fantastic! they are usually always busy so we call in the order. Great prices and great food. been here many times and never a bad experience!

p2WOhAOXJvInIj5ghwu9Kg.text: So far I've tried 4 ramen places in vegas.. Fukumimi, sora ramen, ramen tatsu and monta ramen. Of these 4 I like monta ramen the best. This place is super small so come early or later if you want to avoid the long wait. Their menu is clear and concise.  They don't have dip ramen here.  The reason I liked this one the most was because their broth is super thick and flavorful. I ordered the regular tonkotsu ramen and it comes with chasu, and thin ramen noodles. I usually don't like the spice they add to make it spicy because it detracts from the broth flavor. They said that the spice they put in their spicy tonkotsu ramen is gochugang based ( the Korean spice paste) so it has a sweet note to it. Their ramen price is surprisingly also the cheapest amongst the 4 other places I've tried. My bowl was really satisfying!  If you're a big eater, they also had rice bowls you can order on the side. My friends got the pork belly bowl and the bowl that starts with a t that comes with pickled cabbage. The pork belly bowl was good. It was just fatty cooked meat and rice. The bowl with the pickled cabbage I didn't like. It was way too salty and it has a strange taste. I think that bowl is an acquired taste.

HIsq3-ohWnlDaKuWOSfbVg.text: We love heading to this place. The ramen has deep robust flavor. It IS on the salty side, so beware. It is also a very small place. If they open at noon, arriving at 11:30 will ensure that you sit in the second rotation. People line up! FYI, in case anyone was curious and didn't already know: Not vegetarian friendly. All the stock is meat based.

-ZAWCd250DtcxrS5LIMH1g.text: My boyfriend and I stop by here every time we visit Las Vegas. This place is amazing. Best ramen!!

zWb3uahzdCdgxnf5-UBkfw.text: Interesting surprise when we walked in there.  Small little place, small menu.  All their food has pork, no other options.  Noodles have gluten and they dont have options.  I got the rice and it was good.  Good flavor.  The service is what causes the stars to go down, they were in a hurry, rushing us and somewhat rude.  Disnt appreciate it.

Ba-rpRjjW1gwDt9EUQ7xAQ.text: Monta Ramen serves "KURUME" style Tonkotsu Ramen from Fukuoka. It's a broth made from selected pork bones and special soy sauce imported from Japan. Nice!! Small but clean ramen spot, Monta always seems like there is a long wait out the door.  The Kuro Ramen was black & impressive, the Tokotsu Ramen was creamy and deep. Both had thick and rich pork based broth with thin, unrisen noodles. The fried rice was well mannered with excellent seasoning & the gyoza was surprisingly crispy on the outside and fluffy on the inside.  Service was o-kay ....most likey because it was super busy with only two waitresses on the floor. The whole time, i felt rushed. The glares from the hungry customers waiting for a table to the right of us was piercing & hurting.  Other than that, yes! i'm a fan!!  Good For Kids: Yes Highchair: Yes

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen

ypuAP_Ryf9GVEQQ0YqEvFw.text: I'd rate this a happy 3 1/2 star joint.  We came here on a Friday afternoon during lunch hour. There was a 9 top wait in front of us, but the line moved quickly. There is a sign in system so be sure to get your name and number in your party written down on the clipboard by the hostess podium. They will call your name out when there's a table ready.   The place is TINY! Maybe 8 bar stools by the ramen bar, and 10 tables.   They blast top 40 which creates an odd ambiance, the waitresses are hurried and harried. Case in point: we tried to place our orders when the waitress brought us our water to which point she said she couldn't take our orders right now. She appears when she's ready to take our orders and when we ordered the gyoza appetizer, she screams it to the kitchen. She wrote down the rest of our ramen orders.  We ordered the Tonkatsu and Miso ramen. I made mine spicy ($1 extra). The Tonkatsu is pork broth based, while the Miso was pork and chicken soup base. They were both flavorful and contained green onions, roughly two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage. I say roughly because the chashu were very thin and mostly fat, therefore dissolving in our ramen. The spicy I added to my ramen was not mixed into the broth, instead it was a goop that sat on top of the ramen along with my toppings. It tasted like the Korean Gochujang chili pastes, and did not compliment the flavor of the ramen.   There were no service on the remainder of our dining experience, I'm not sure if this is because it's more of a casual counter service/semi-table service.   If you've ever had Santouka Ramen in Arlington Heights or any where else, I do believe they are the superior ramen shop.  All in all it was $25 with tip, so not bad for the experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen add spicy
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

kKvH3FifokoYxwbxoQheBg.text: Went on Sunday 9-20-15 around 12:45 PM.  This is located on the corner of spring mountain and decatur in the same shopping center as Raku, Kung-Fu tea, Big Wong, and Curry Zen.    You go inside and write your name on the list and they'll call you when a table's ready.  We put our name on the list and went over to Kung-Fu Tea to wait.  When we went back over, they had called us and crossed our name off the list so we had to put our name on the list again and wait all over again.  Oops.  But when they called my name they had a high chair ready for my boy and I thought that was pretty great.    $11.78 got me a bowl of tonkotsu ramen and a small order of fried rice.  The ramen was pretty great but DAT FRIED RICE THO....dang it was awesome.  I absolutely loved it. When I go back (and I definitely will) I will just ask for a trough full of that fried rice.  I only got 4-5 bites before my baby stole it and stuffed it all in his face.  It is a strange type of rice and I think it has pork belly in it.    Cheap, delicious, eats.  Woohoo! As good as it gets!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $3.95 small fried rice.  You want this in your belly right now, trust me.  9-20-15
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $6.95 Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen .  9-20-15

y5a_6WVgCLqX3FJOY2rGxg.text: I used to love it here. It's been a year since I've been here last so I was looking forward to a bowl of Spicy Tonkotsu. Noodles were a little chewy, broth was too salty for my taste and worse of all, not hot! And yes I know the heat is usually in the bottom of the bowl. But warm is as hot as it got. Lukewarm by the time the heat escaped the bowl.   It's as if they just poured broth over cold noodles!   Ramen Kobo near my side of town does so much better. Jinya Ramen is still my fave. They never disappoint.

lWrbGmQvr7kbOgQhXzt2SQ.text: First time trying ramen,and it was amazing. I know it looks really small but worth the wait. I got the spicy tonkatsu which was full of flavor. The service was fast and friendly. Will definitely be coming back!

nfISjRIvfywxDjlYcUDbGg.text: Have tried this several times by now, and still love the atmosphere and the selections. Just wish the ramen soups weren't quite so salty.   Next time I need to try the Shoyu Ramen. A friend said that one wasn't salty.  Will definitely be back!

vwDt3V2WgHSO7OdApx8LWA.text: I booked this spot a while ago.  Never had enough time to wait around for a table.  We got a chance to try it out today around 4:00 PM on a Sunday. The wait wasn't too bad.  We had about 3 tables before us.  I dropped my husband off to write our name down, while I drive around looking for a parking spot.  The parking situation in this plaza is VERY limited.  A lot of businesses and not enough space.  I was lucky to find a spot after third loop around.    Beware this place is super tiny, that's why usually the reason why the wait is so crazy during normal eating hours.  I would have to say the capacity would be 30-35 guests total.  I did feel it moves pretty quickly if there isn't a big group waiting.  A good thing to know is, you will need all your party there to be seated or they will skip to the next party.  We ordered some gyoza, it was ok.  Not one of the best I've had.  I had the Miso Ramen.  The broth was ok.  Nothing special.  The noodles so-so.    I wouldn't come back and wait in that line.  Not worth it.

xpHjAasvQdevbAEQBFXaTQ.text: After reading everyone's review I was so excited to try this place! The wait was about 15 mins and there was a long line outside. We order the spicy ramen with pork belly, egg and kim chi on the side. The ramen came out pretty fast. The flavor was ok a little bland for me. My soup was warm not piping hot so that was disappointing. Probably not gonna come back.

r4Ls5lfoe4EzElaShBkGAg.text: One of the best in town easy. City wide it's tied for first with Fukumimi but, this is the best ramen you can get west of the 15. No complaints. (have gone ~10 times) I got Miso ramen w/ gyoza

7IUfsHGHRG6IOJFw82ED1w.text: The building is small so sometimes the wait time is too long, I would not recommend bringing a big party here. The broth and noodles were tasty, but the pork was a bit dry. The service was adequate and they do take takeout orders. We sat at the bar, so it was a bit too warm in the room, I guess that's the price you pay for getting hot ramen in the summer

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

bxQTcQxK_Mw83g7DYf-G5A.text: The ramen here is very authentic, tasty. Small restaurant, quick service. Kind/attentive staff. Was suprised to see Takana on the menu..thats even rare to see in Japan. My Japanese gma also approved the ramen. Good quick eats.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen (chicken broth based) w/ egg

GYhFSrBe7adCPJfSlfRljA.text: Absolutely bomb. First time I've ever had "real" ramen before. Would definitely recommend coming here to check it out!  Try the Kimchi Fried Rice!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi Fried Rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu Soup

J30LNDSmkyO6j_DB7o3Pwg.text: Still the best ramen in vegas! cheap and really good!!! Expect to wait 20-30mins when you go there during lunch hours.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

pLWzqG-OaA45Xwx0C-6waQ.text: 3 1/2 stars. Came in for lunch during the week. I sat at the counter due to the full house and went with the Tonkotsu shoyu ramen with egg and extra chashu.  Sitting at the counter I was able to watch them prepare the ramen and noticed there was a chef in training. When I received my bowl all looked decent and tasted good with the exception that the ramen was overcooked and soggy. The patron next to me received his bowl and he ordered double meat and they only give him a single serving also which wasn't cool either.   Service was decent, but lets get it together in the kitchen!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkotsu shoyu ramen / egg and extra chashu.

nN-Ll8HYjE4WzdvoCHfZEg.text: After a half hour wait at this much-hyped ramen shop, I found the service to be excellent but the ramen just average. All in all, not worth the wait, though I am a visitor to Las Vegas and this might be the best there is. It's all relative.  Been fortunate to have had really excellent ramen in the past with a similar broth, though richer in texture from collagen derived from boiling the pork bones. The noodles were excellent, the location unpretentious and prices good.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu 09.25.2017
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. After a half hour wait, tried the tonkotsu ramen and found it to be just average.

u7vFLk0ZV3XOadhphruAYw.text: Salty two pork slices noodle soup fix and greasy gyoza. Made a quick stop here for a hot bowl of comfort. Downed a few glasses of water before leaving. I mean I rather have cup of noodle at the hotel room instead. If I didn't have taken photos I won't remember it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

LjynEAGQNrMA0ov2iKsNFQ.text: Delicious!! We ordered the tonkotsu ramen with a soft boiled egg and nori which was amazing! The broth was so rich and flavorful and the chashu pork was like butter! Hands down one of the best ramen I've ever had! Highly recommend!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen - broth was so good!!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen topped with Shredded Green Onion, soft boiled egg, and Nori. Side of kimchi. Mini Mentaiko

FUBajTAOg2ZqcmIdy4BUCg.text: One of the best ramen stops in Las Vegas. Also the prices are what ramen should be. There's a simple menu but every item is made well.

HOQ_cyqYoF2hLirlTnBfZA.text: Amazing ramen. I recommend the ramen Kuro ramen with black garlic oil and the Takana fried rice. Also, their gyoza is a big hit. Be prepared to wait in line. I arrive 10 minutes before they open on Sunday and am first in line.

feijajjOLGZhbypeuFVUyA.text: Best ramen taste/quality and price ratio I've ever tasted. Everything was great. Very delicious and rich broth. I wish the noodles were thicker though. The service was great! Also, ordered fried rice and it was very delicious as well. They also serve beer.

JtvNKFhhTlH27dJHKNdBdQ.text: I have attempted at coming here before but I have never been able to make it in because it's always so packed with people wanting to eat.  I finally came here at a good time around 6ish...and not packed but by the time I left, it was packed!  The miso ramen was delicious.  You can choose from add on's on your soup but they charge you, I dont think they should, they should just treat them as condiments.  At other ramen places that I have been too I get the egg, bamboo shoot, fire ball add on's free.  So I am not sure what their deal is.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xrxg10oV8an3tPfsQOVDtw.text: This is the best ramen in town, always have a lot of people are waiting outside. The price is reasonable($7-$9) for a medium size ramen

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

K15Symj3sRPb_7_RKwPjXA.text: I came here on a trip to Vegas in June, at the height of the summer heat. Ramen is just not a good idea in the summer. But the Black Garlic Ramen made it worth it.  The broth was my favorite part of this ramen, it was incredibly flavorful. It had the sort of taste that said, "Yes, I've been simmering for hours overnight, letting all my flavors marinate and get to know each other." The garlic flavor was really strong, but it was perfect with the broth.  The chashu and the egg were both really solid. The real kicker here is that the ramen was ridiculously cheap! It was under $10! I was blown away! Value wise, this was the best bowl I've ever had under $10.   Monta ramen is worth a trek away from the strip!

T4ViUZ9sBG-pXxLeWxlwUQ.text: Monta Ramen is another ramen joint on Spring Mountain Road, there seems to be a ramen battle in this area.  The dining area was small when compared with the other locations, I would limit to group size to 6 below to be comfortably seated.  I got their Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen.  The noodles was a bit disappointing, it tasted very mushy like they cooked them, but forgot to put them through a cold bath, and all the flour started to flaked off onto the broth.  Definitely did not look the same as some of the older pictures listed here.  The broth tasted ok in general.  Meat was tender.  Other than that, the ramen did not really had much in it, and having bad noodles pretty much ruined everything in the dish.  Service was decent even though they seemed very busy though.  Perhaps they have gone downhill since they first opened?  I might try this place again if they are still open for business during my next trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen

8lV4jqdv8MGhlE2bj9MMzw.text: Yeah, this place is small but so so worth it.   Their service is always so fast and the waitresses are quick to take your order when you sit down. The food is always delicious and fresh and the portion sizes are big for the price you pay. I normally share ramen with whoever I got with and it fills both of us up! I definitely recommend this location, just be prepared to wait.

lokKVrq2VYU7lugCyxxlFg.text: We were there at 5PM and restaurant was getting full.  For good reason, as there nothing bad to say about this place.    Ramen is extremely reasonably priced around $7 or $8, portions are not enormous but filling.  Low use of msg, as I'm not thirsty at all after the meal.  Noodles are cooked perfectly.  The star is the black sesame ramen, very rich flavor, one of the best ones I've tasted.  This small restaurant can be easily missed on Spring Mountain Road.  Best thing to do is use the GPS for first timers.  Highly recommended!

2K69sHf3paCZAZjBMIObTw.text: Bunch of patrons waiting outside.  Added my name to the bottom of a very long list!  Grinned wide on the inside each time the hostess barked out a name with no takers.  Scratch name, next!!  Finally...  Mark for two?!  That's meeh!  Hyped as the one of the best ramen spots in Vegas (are Monta ramen and Monta Chaya affiliated?).  Hope it's worth this 40 min wait on a Saturday afternoon!  Grinned wide on the inside again as Monta ramen met my lofty expectations!  At a base price of $6.95, my wallet was very happy!  Threw in a soft boiled egg and I'm set!  Good, deep flavor in the tonkotsu broth.  And very clean!  Clear consistency with no oil puddles or fat swimming around...    Slurping up the remaining broth means my meal is coming to an end--bittersweet...  Ordered fried rice as an app--savory with a smoky flavor.  Two big thumbs up for Monta Ramen!

3zjfxpwb-NwDqSOgzaD1Sw.text: I was craving for a soup today I came across a Japanese noodle house on spring mountain in Las Vegas Nevada this place is really small and if you don't mind sitting close to strangers this is a place for you then the food is great I would recommend Tonkotsu Black soup

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xu-5RshMbe57NK1WSLyp1Q.text: My background with ramen isn't the most robust, so take this review with a grain of salt.  I feel that the tonkotsu was a good choice to test out the restaurant so I ordered a bowl with egg and corn added.  The total cost was around $10.  The menu seems to range around there with extras for onion, corn, egg, etc. for an extra charge.  The ramen was great.  I don't have much comparison but it was tasty and filling.  Monta Ramen has that must-visit reputation so there's always lines.  It's located in probably the most renowned shopping plaza in Chinatown so add no parking on top of the wait time.  The restaurant only has a handful of table and counter space as well.  The service is really fast and good, but it just takes a while to sit.  Definitely give Monta a try.  It has such a high reputation that if you are a True ramen fan, then hopefully this will be your joint.  They also have a second location in Henderson that hardly ever has lines if you hate that hipster line disease.

5RMVRYdekWh5QHCOIboG2g.text: I've come here on and off through the years and can say that I've tried almost everything on the menu and have been very satisfied with everything.  The food is very customizable. If you see it on the menu, there's usually something they can do to make it to your liking. Just ask the them, they'll tell you what they can do and what they can't. BUT the only meat they have is PORK. If you don't like pork, this may not be your spot. This place is also NOT vegetarian/vegan or gluten free friendly.  Now, let me leave some tips on here to make your dining experience as painless as possible. This place is SMALL. Party of 4+? Prepare to either wait or not sit all together. Parties with younger children, plan accordingly cause half of the seats are bar seats, which small bodies and bar stools don't usually mix well.  Again, this place is small. Give everyone else a chance to enjoy their meal. This is not a hang out kind of spot. You sit, order, eat, pay and leave. You sit there too long, you'll probably feel angry glares from all the people waiting. This place can get crowded real quick.

W0mfnRBnpcCC3CVzVDcDNg.text: Everytime I'm in Las Vegas I always stop at Monta. It never fails to remind me why I keep coming back. The small plates are delicious especially the pork belly over rice. I always get a bowl of ramen. It could 120 degrees outside and I'll still get a bowl of ramen Tonkatsu is my favorite but I've enjoyed all the different broths and Noodle options. Small place in a busy strip mall is worth a stop. You'll keep coming back!

D6AHi5ve4yhujZ-QMoc9jA.text: Not bad after waiting almost an hour.. Ramen was good but a little salty. Overall great tasting.

xfaLMH1cAZhZyAujEd6lgQ.text: Very impressed and certainly will be back.  There are so many Asian restaurants in the area, if you aren't local or know someone here, you could easily overlook this place.  While it is small, it seats more than you'd expect and they also have an L-shaped counter with additional seating when you come in.  Always a good sign when you are greeted warmly, there's a sign-up sheet for waiting, there are kids with their folks, and regulars since the waitresses knew some of them by name.   We had the tonkatsu ramen and the shoyu ramen, with corn and shredded green onions.  The noodles were perfect, chewy, and the broth was top notch.  We also had the fried rice and the pork belly bowl.  Don't miss these!  And the food does come out fast from the kitchen.  Compared to the bay area, their prices are pretty reasonable and you get plenty to eat.  Service was excellent.  If you don't like to wait or are a True vegetarian, probably not the place for you.  We got there at 5:30pm on a Sunday and the place was just 1/2 full.  By 6:00pm, it was packed and they had more than a dozen people waiting.  I'm guessing if there's a line somewhere, it's usually a good bet the place is worth the wait.  It is located in a strip mall so there is parking, but there are also many restaurants as well.  They also called a taxi for us when we were done which was awesome.  I'll be back for sure.

osYIqp_Vssyc4FnIDJ4eVg.text: Went here based on other reviews and totally loved it! A very small place but the Shoyu Ramen was delicious! The Cold noodles we're good too! Definitely beats over paying for designer food on the strip!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shot Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold noodles

YfDJWsUjsdTyYczdl-KqrA.text: The food was absolutely delicious. The temperature was just right. The service was great. Anything on the menu is going to be tasty.

CgC9syPlFWA1cpC89I_S7A.text: It's fairly small and has a very quaint & authentic feel. We were seated right by the door and it was pretty cold. The restaurant itself isn't very big so as customers were coming in to put their name on the list we got hit with the breeze. The food was okay... we ordered the gyoza for appetizers and it was a little oily. The ramen was amazing. I like how they allow you custom pick your toppings. The experience was average but the ramen was really good. My son loves ramen so we are always in search of really good ramen and he was definitely satisfied.

ltkDLstGAYQOXQv-FWnMZg.text: Solidly good ramen spot in Vegas. It's small so expect a wait. My boyfriend and I waited for around 20 minutes for a table. We ordered two bowls of ramen and a small bowl of pork belly with rice to share. Pork belly rice was pretty underwhelming - I thought there was too much ginger. The ramen was definitely better - I wish the noodles had been a little chewier, but the flavor of the soup was very nice. Splurge for some corn and the egg! Prices are pretty good though - definitely cheaper than Chicago ramen.

UJSERd4ldfCUF3fs7EyBTw.text: Monta Ramen, you have yet to be dethroned as my number 1 ramen joint. If only you did not have 1-2 hours waiting time, you and I can get married. Check out my Monta Ramen (Hakata) vs Ramen Sora (Sapporo) review here: yelp.com/user_details?us... Want to see some food porn? yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... yelp.com/biz_photos/mont...

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu with nori/seaweed
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen (is da best!!!)

2frAQLDdphpnU5E0uCulxA.text: The wait wasn't too bad but I wish the portion size was just a little bit more. The food was delicious but portion size was fair.  The pricing was fair as well.

yJ_-ohUhkLghY0Z9roJpsg.text: So delicious!!!! Customer service was great & I was blown away @ how quick our order came out. Yes, it's Ramen so it should be quick but this other place we love too, takes about 30min to bring out our bowls. My Husband & I have waited til the right moment to try this place which was 10pm lol there was no wait what so ever & we will definitely come back!

74r_uaG_fpw8-n5Y6JHk2A.text: Went here on Sunday right when they just open, and there was already a line.  We only waited for 30 mins for a table of 4.  The line was moving fast.  The place was very small.  There are four different kinds of soup and we each had different one, and all were delicious.  Pay cash under $10.  The services are friendly and nice.  Highly recommend this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

SuOdhXSVJDWMI0F8L-lkPA.text: So after getting sweets from Ronald's to enjoy after dinner, we hit up Monta for some ramen action...My wife ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with egg, chashu, and corn. I ordered the Miso Ramen with egg and extra chashu. We also got a side of Gyoza and I tried the mini "Mentaiko"(Fish Eggs over rice with nori and sesame seeds  The Mentaiko was simple and good with a slight heat at the end, the gyoza was okay. Both the miso and Tonkotsu ramen were also good but these guys are pretty slick about jacking up the price of your order with the add on toppings just like some pizza joints do.  Monta is pretty decent but its nothing like spots in Cali or Back home in Hawaii.....Makes me miss Shiro's and Ezogiku even more...ALOHA!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso  Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mini Mentaiko

RU73i7OUdgBD2-0FvsVB9g.text: Cheap comfort ramen place! I don't think I've seen a smaller place in Vegas but it makes it special, seems like a chaos but it's always so quick! I hate places where you wait forever for your meal but this place got it! Broth is always delicious and makes the whole ramen

ziLFk0EmL0Njyul8wHQmVw.text: I can't believe it took us so long to find this place. If you like Ramen, this is the place to try. The menu is quite simple but the flavors or not. If there's one downside I have not been there yet when there's not a line waiting to enter. The restaurant only seats about 30 people, however the tables turn quickly. My favorite dish is the Ramen with black garlic.

qjL6DvsAu-dYiOQED_K20g.text: Components of a good bowl of ramen: 1) perfectly cooked noodles (some prefer slightly chewy, but I like mine a little softer) 2) well-balanced, flavored broth 3) attentiveness of toppings   Monta Ramen's Tonkotsu would have been THE PERFECT bowl, except it only passed 2 out of 3 of my criteria. Great noodles, good chashu, but the tonkotsu broth was waaaay too greasy and rich. It got to the point that I had to dump water from my cup to dilute it down-- [gasp!] I know, what blasphemy!   Had I known, I would've gone with the shoyu or miso.

1LVgU5FitdKW408iYv5JFg.text: Seating at Japanese Ramen joints are very similar. 3 -  6 tables and a bar, and a waiting list that you write your name on and wait to be called. At good Ramen places, a half hour to 45 minute wait is the norm. They aren't places to linger. They are places to eat and leave.  Early on a Saturday night, before the huge CES tradeshow, we hoped it would not have a line curling around the block as it did the year before during the trade show. With a little bit of parking "karma" we snagged a parking spot as someone else left, signed in and waited.  We were fortunate. After 20 minutes, we were in. Some Ramen places do a complete "meal" with broth, meat, egg, veggies, etc. for about $15 Monta does the "basic" with add-ons that comes up to the same price. But that meant you could get what you extras you wanted. More meat, maybe another egg or an extra helping of corn or nori.  I had the Tonkatsu Shoyo broth (pork bones and soy sauce) with extra charsui (fatty pork), stewed egg and nori. Seated at the bar meant we got a ring side view of the cooks: The huge pots of broth at a roiling boil, how they heated the bowls before using them, the finishing of the bowls.  Once they arrived, we slurped it down - like you are supposed to, before the Ramen sat in the broth too long and the texture changed. Excellent noodles, tasty - very tasty broth, fatty slices of pork and stewed egg with the yolk just a little "custardy" - very yum.  Definitely worth the usual wait - if we were to head back there again.

W6mcAhxAGxtdqNf0HI8B9A.text: Found Monta Ramen on Yelp and had to check it out for lunch based on the rave reviews.  The reviewers were correct.  Possibly the best ramen I've ever had.    Monta Ramen is pretty much a dump.  And it's impossibly small too.  There was a line at lunch, but it moves fast because they serve you quickly with their small menu, and you down the food fast because it's so good.  Service was friendly and efficient.    I went with the standard pork ramen with egg and dried seaweed.  Didn't need the seaweed.  The ramen was delicious.  I also tried some of the fried rice, which was just OK.    I can tell from the ramen how good the food is here.  I'd come back here in a heartbeat for more ramen.    Because of the line of hungry diners, go inside and sign up on the clipboard at the hostess station to get into line.

EUG1cRmdA1s5FRz9FoVDZw.text: Shoyu Ramen with extra pork is the best!!! pork belly bowl with rice is also amazing. I could eat here every day!! I prefer the eastern location better  seating arrangement. They gave me a flower for Mother's Day!

21uYxtdwjKjdjdFq6iVbhA.text: Super rich and delicious noodles, pork belly bowl very tasty

ARkUhjyY1QdLMQ41OWLXIQ.text: I love this place, great lunch spot and for dinner too.  For lunch you can keep it light with just a soup so you don't pass out later in the day.  For dinner you can get soup plus some gyoza or fried rice (which is the bomb, I love it here)  A new thing which is not on the menu is that you can get a mix of the Tonkatsu and the Shoyu broth, that's what I get.  In addition, I always add corn and chopped onion, and an egg if I'm in the mood.  Server's are very friendly, and they work very fast and efficient. It's not a place where you're gonna chill for 3 hours and hang out, the place is small so people are in and out pretty fast.  A little side note:  They have cans of Japanese iced tea which I had in Japan and never had in the US until coming here.  I love that!

5iuouMjdu9cCUNrIJczp2g.text: I never considered any other reason to visit Las Vegas aside from The Strip, but visitors rejoice! There is another reason..it's in the form of a little ramen restaurant called Monta! Fellow yelper Vicky L. recommended it to me and I made it my first stop in Vegas, right after picking up the rental car.  We arrived at around 11:45 and got extremely lucky with seats at the counter, because the place filled up quickly by noon with the lunch crowd.  I had the tonkotsu-shoyu and the husband had the tonkotsu. The broth for both were extremely creamy and delicious. If you like things with a bit more flavor, I suggest the tonkotsu-shoyu. The ramen noodles are the thin, angel-hair type which is a nice change from the usual ones we get in SF.   The egg..how could I forget to order the soft-boiled egg? I'm actually still bitter about that. So please do me (and yourself) a favor and add a soft-boiled egg to your ramen.   We also smelled the fried rice aroma from our neighbor and couldn't help but get a small order to share ourselves. It was the perfect portion and hit the spot.

vzZ9g3JJ84cXWjv9QdYr-Q.text: Kinda mediocre, not very deep flavor to the broth. I like that you can customize with various items such as corn, green onions (.75 cents), egg.. s3-media1.px.yelpcdn.com... I don't think I'd come here again.

jKw1VaKBkEqGViUhrw4h_Q.text: Small cozy place. It was busy when I came (maybe because it was lunch time). The waiting wasn't that bad, even the waitress skipped me twice since I was dining alone :(  everything was fast and nice. Love the food here :) will come back if I have chance

-wWzJgvevZ2Io6hBiGj-DA.text: Ordered the kim chi fried rice, green tea (did not expect it to be in a can), and a light brothed ramen noodle soup with pork belly, shredded mustard greens, bamboo shreds, and black mushroom strips. The pork belly was first class, the rest of the soup was too salty for my taste...I can imagine that it would have been perfect with 50% less salt. The kim chi fried rice was also a little salty. For the price, the overall quality was only soso.   Oh, I also ordered gyoza, which was just average at best.  I will say that the atmosphere seemed authentic and very Japanese with the cute waitresses screaming the orders to the kitchen in Japanese.  If the food were less salty, this place could easily get at least 4 stars.

p7NdCxzrs05is_uIHxmr8g.text: I love this place. I've dragged plenty of friends here. Although the wait is sometimes a pain, it's always worth it. Just the chicken broth with an egg and some fried rice... Delicious in every way. I only wish I could eat more!

LXmUHmQCOk35g-Ya8uHwig.text: This place was very busy at 4:00pm.  We ordered the miso ramen and fried rice.  Both were ok but, nothing special.   Prices were reasonable.

flssMdgGpV4pOHdOWwx0nQ.text: The menu only had a few items so you do not get overwhelmed. Ordered the standard Tonsuka Ramen. Broth was a little too salty. Prefer my broth to be hotter. They should rinse the noodles a bit more because I could taste the residual stuff that usually comes out of boiling noodles.   It was a relatively inexpensive meal, but I'd rather eat somewhere else next time.

tI6zDe7s2zZzcq_4WVbicA.text: Living in the Los Angeles area the past couple of years, there are tons of ramen noodle places, yet I was pleasantly surprised to find this little joint in the ol' LV.  Menu items of note:  Ramen - well of course, duh!  Lately, I've been getting the Tonkotsu-shoyu flavored broth.  The slices of pork are quite tender and soft, cooked to perfection.  Broth tends to be slightly on the thicker side, but tasty.  Always gotta get the add-on hard boiled egg with semi soft yolk.  The texture of the noodles always comes out right for me.  Service: The waitresses are always friendly to me and very polite.  I think most, if not all of them, are Japanese, which is a good thing, considering I'm eating ramen.  Reasons why I come here: The poker kitchen at the Rio is consistently lackluster every summer, and when I only have one hour for dinner, this is one of the best options.    Also, ramen is one of the hallmark foods of the modern day peasant.  I encourage all other like minded peasants to join me in celebration of......our peasantry? *Fist Pump*

vXCLKBUnhELBkApWJUH8bQ.text: Upon a friend's recommendation, I decided to head over to try Monta one night. It was 10 pm and dining options were starting to get scarce.
