Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ZryfddVAnMWLJCq39bPiTw.text: Good ramen and fried rice I got there late afternoon so the waited is bearable I can't imagine how busy they are on lunch hour but overall good experience will be there for more good ramen for sure

LrxljY1NhuyG4MCdzvPmUA.text: Love their chashu bowl! I've never dined in. I always call for pick up, but sometimes they take so long to answer.

xEuf3P0YF2lp9Q8udlP2EQ.text: I've never ventured outside ordering the regular Tonkotsu Ramen, but was feeling adventurous and tried their Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil based on a recommendation by a foodie friend and I'm glad I did. Though I love garlic, the garlic flavor was subtle and not overpowering. Highly recommended. And my kids loved the fried rice! And my husband liked the price- extremely reasonable! Oh, and always a must for me is a clean restaurant and great service so that was met as well. With kids always in tow, thankfully the waiting time was only 5-10 minutes (very late Vegas Thursday night).

Eedbaan1T5TCGxqHl-P23A.text: Hands down, the best Ramen restaurant in Vegas. I am a local and Japanese so I'm super picky with ramen. A must try for sure!!!!!

qBOLndwZ1DjyDOkT1Oc49A.text: It has been some time since I had good ramen.  San Francisco is one of the best foodie towns but it fails miserably in terms of ramen offerings.  We stopped by Monta on a recent trip to Vegas.  It is located on Spring Mountain road like most of the other popular nearby offstrip spots and is located in the same strip as Raku and Kung Fu Tea.  The parking lot is a bit tight and can fill up pretty quickly on busy nights but there is street parking and we have used the lot opposite of the strip (store was closed).  There was a short wait at Monta as expected but it was reasonable - only 3 other names on the clipboard.  The shop consisted of a long L shaped bar and 10 or so small tables.  Not a huge place but not small either.  We all ordered the Tonkatsu ramen and Tanaka fried rice as recommended.  The default toppings were a bit sparse (pork, bamboo, ginger, 'shrooms) but considering the price (under $7) I didn't mind.  I added a soft boiled egg to mine - other standard toppings were available (corn, more pork, butter, etc) We were pleasantly surprised at the turnaround for the ramen - within 5-10 minutes.  The broth carried plenty of flavor but was a bit thicker than the other ramen shops.  The noodles were thin and firm but not overly so.  The bowl only came with 2 slices of pork but it was expertly prepared - tender with a good combination of meat and fat.  There was a slight aftertaste (from MSG?) but easily queched from the Kung Fu milk tea from next door.  The fried rice was solid but a bit salty.  It was more than likely from the mustard leaves either being too abundant or just overly salty themselves.  Not bad but I may go with the potstickers or simply stick with the ramen next time.  A definite stop for me in Vegas the next time I am craving something soupy or noodles.

TZDSA7itBWIPTfAUBPVVXw.text: Talking about comfort food ??? This is the place ramen is very comforting. Waiting for seats is not fun because the place is not big enough. They need to expand the place so people don't have to wait too long.

1hHmATxP84xnhsD-Pz9azQ.text: Girlfriend brought me here and fell in love with the place!!! always been skeptical about ramen houses but not no more! Ramen was great definitely coming back!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1_sWovZFSINTP6o_ZYkJag.text: Pretty good ramen for Vegas. Soup base is solid, chashu is fatty, and 6 mins egg cooked perfectly. Reasonable price and quick service. Go during off hr to avoid line. Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

nFfDKFFImjnb0xoe0AzkNg.text: I had the shoyu ramen with egg. I didnt like the egg since it wasnt well done. But the soup was great especially on a cold day.  The pork belly bowl was delicious and the gyoza.   I gave it a 4 star cos of the place its too small and crowded. I feel crammed in the restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl. Delish!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen.. Taste good except for egg lol

e8HygGmPNd6Rby_piAdr3w.text: Came here for lunch and it was super packed! I wasn't aware there was a sign in sheet so I was kinda just standing there until someone came behind me and signed in. Thankfully he said I could go before him anyways! Wait was only about 5 minutes, but since there were no seats available I had to wait outside in the heat. Definitely not a place where you have an intimate meal, but I spent 45 minutes there without feeling They were rushing me out the door.  The food was pretty good. I got the tonkotsu shoyu, fried rice, and green tea. The ramen soup and noodles were very good, although I didn't like the meat. It says it's pork but it tasted like turkey and a mix of something else so I didn't eat it. The rice was good too with soy sauce but was a bit too eggy for my liking.   Service was good! Was asked twice if I needed refills, check came quickly, and just about everyone said thank you as I left! I would definitely come back just not get the pork or whatever that meat was.

zt855OAIuYhJGHLuOUny-g.text: Long wait time and on top of that the service is minimal compare to other places such as Fukumimi   Do not order the gyoza they served them almost frozen and they where stock together like if they were cooked in a rush !! On the ramen the chachu had a lot of fat and not well cooked. Noodles were good and the broth was uninspiring!!!! Will not come back

vdF3EszEBk8QAEQEoSozzQ.text: Authentic ramen noodle, not those milky buttery broth that is overwhelming after two sips. Their gyoza was Amazzzinggg, filling is pork+veggie. Does not smell or taste like old meat with tons of ingredients to mask it.  Kim chi fried rice was so flavorful , not too salty either. However, it is a tad bit oily for me, but what's fried rice without a little oil huh?  The place is small and have about five small tables and the rest of the seatings are located at the noodle bar( sits about 8 people)  We were so full and only paid 34 bucks!!(2 ramen noodles, fried rice, gyoza)  I strongly suggest trying out this place ASAP!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with extra bamboo shoot. Kimchi on the side

dWo6K6D3R00rAtPMbG9Lrg.text: Monta Ramen is delicious! I tried Monta Ramen at the SF Ramen Fest and when I came to Vegas last weekend - I just had to get another bowl!  Surprisingly it tasted almost exactly the same as it did at the festival! Except the portions were a little bit bigger.  I got the Spicy Tonkatsu ramen and added an extra egg for 50 cents.  I would also recommend the pork belly rice bowl (just get a small its plenty enough).  I came on a Friday at 11:45am - just 15 mins after they opened and they were completely full. This is not surprising since this place is super tiny. I had a party of 5 and we only waited about 15 mins, not bad of a wait at all..especially for Ramen!  Please try it! The prices are also super reasonable!

CUp_mN3RqMT_Ki7SF0835A.text: Ramen house. That's exactly what this place is, no frills just Ramen with a few sides (fried rice/gyoza items on the menu) Monta is truly a place that focuses on the Ramen.  Tonight I had the Shoyu basic ramen and didn't need to add anything to it.  I'm still a Ramen newb so hearing tables next to me adding extra pork, extra noodles etc made me realize you can customize your own Ramen bowls, but just the basic Ramen as is is just fine.  This is good comfort food and beats your top ramen like during your college years. *there will be a wait and this place is small, but definitely worth it! **the hot tea comes in cans cold or hot.

qP3LE3qini8iB5tjtDH8tw.text: Tasty ramen!  The air conditioner was broken when we went here to eat - it was a bit uncomfortable to eat my ramen bowl and kind of ruined the dining experience.

AHQq-IYhVuJdiL_I4E4GIQ.text: My schedule at work was changed for the weekend, and a coworker who was leaving a hour after I am off the clock suggested going to get ramen.  Then she said Monta Ramen.  I guess she has been reading the many positive reviews on Yelp.  So off we went to Monta Ramen.  The place was 85F with the fans (ceiling and the other portable ones) going full blast.  I suggested eating at the bar, since I know there is a fan blowing right next to the cashier area.  But the restaurant was still pretty packed (11 of us total) at around 4pm on a summer Saturday.  I tried the Shoyu Ramen this time, while my friend tried the Miso.  Shoyu was good and I didn't feel it was too salty like the other two ramen.  And my coworker enjoyed the Miso Ramen. Both of these options are prepared with the thick ramen noodle (just FYI), which I prefer anyway.  Overall, another satisfying dining experience at Monta Ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Plenty of broth left to enjoy the side of extra noodles.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen served with the thicker ramen noodles, which you can special request with other ramen orders.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chinese-Style Cold Noodle Salad.

sTUuUxyScXR4c1LMSiWqKA.text: Best ramen in Vegas.  Shoyu ramen w/fried rice and a side of potstickers.

kXxRbLIkSSHXCiuBfRdUjA.text: This place reminds me of Men-Oh in Little Tokyo in the settings.  Walk in to a small entry way, stools greet you at the bar table and you turn in to a small room with tight seating.  It's packed and you will be fortunate if you are seated right away.  At the same time, both times we were there we only waited 5-10 minutes so they do turn them pretty quickly.  Orders are taken promptly by pleasant wait staff, and your meal is turned around quickly as well, within 10 minutes.  Their ramen are overall the best I've had - not greasy, fresh, with nicely firm noodles - although from pure taste standpoint I probably prefer Hiromaru (RIP).  Their fried rice is really good, as is the chashu don.  These are more like side dishes from size standpoint, but probably too much for one person to have a ramen and one of these.  Maybe 2 ramen dishes and one will work for two... I say that because they're really good and you should really try them.  Great atmosphere, bustling crowd, and great food all equal to the best ramen joint I have been to yet.  It's probably more like 4.5 stars, but I want to differentiate between this and other 4-star places I've rated so I'm giving it a 5.  Table-for-1 Factor:  Yes, and there are many who partake.

sI0m-MttzauxhnbfYfcJmA.text: This was a bit removed from our "typical" restaurant routine, but was a good experience.  (It required getting over to the Chinatown area of Vegas).  The restaurant is Spartan and very small, which can result in waiting for a table at most times of the day or night.  There's limited room to wait inside, so you're on the sidewalk of a parking lot, which can be pretty hot at times.  Service was efficient and friendly, ramen bowls were delicious and served quickly, and food is inexpensive as is typical for this type of fare.  Overall, good food if you're just looking to chow down and move on, but not much to offer beyond that.

jBYMuer3HZGm3rv19z1eXA.text: This noodle-house is one of the hottest businesses in Las Vegas. (Yeah, like LV is not hot enough!)  But the thing is, "I'm definitely not a Ramen-guy!"   Because I'm not contented with just noodles, flavored broth, diced meat and/or vegetables in a bowl.   It's been a LONG while since I've had a bowl of Ramen....even before 9/11 to be exact (yeah, that long).    I met up with a bunch of friends in Las Vegas and each of us ordered one of the restaurant's tasty Ramen Noodle. I ordered the Chashu and Tonkatsu Ramen Noodle Bowl. For $6.95, it's not a bad price and had slices of Chashu and noodles in a flavorful Miso soup. The soup/meal was actually pretty good and comforting. This bowl of soup would definitely warm me up in a cold winter night in San Francisco.   I got my ramen soup very fast and the service was also good.  Friends used credit cards for their meals. But I paid my meal in cash.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CQXMIaYgXpnVPFv1qzWiyg.text: Went here with my dad and cousin. We waited 30 minutes outside. I thought to myself, "heck yeah, this wait is going to be worth it because I've heard a lot of good things about this place!" Tried the food. Wasn't impressed. I ordered a Shoyu Ramen and a mini mentaiko bowl. I expected the mentaiko bowl to be delicious, and it was--but trust me, after a few bites that sodium content will turn you off. A few minutes later, the shoyu ramen came. Too salty for my tastes.  My cousin ordered a Tonkotsu ramen and I tried it. I wish I ordered the Tonkotsu ramen instead because it wasn't AS salty, but still pretty salty. My dad ordered a miso ramen. Again, it was salty.  You get the gist.  Aside from the salty dishes, we ordered gyoza and fried rice. The fried rice was pretty standard and the gyoza was just a bit better from the frozen ones you can get at the store. Neato. Maybe I'll come back when I'm low on sodium intake.   The only good thing was the service. I wouldn't recommend this for big groups because the place is pretty small and it's usually packed whenever I'm around the area.

BLWw4_bG7eBLiaBTdp3kbw.text: There was a total of 6 in our group, short wait when we arrived. I got the Spicy Tonkotsu $7.95. It has thin noodles but there are other noodle dishes with thick noodles. Super cheap and yummy. :) a must try!

Zyta5lqa1Y0tvFoieGhi8A.text: A small store located in a decent plaza with plenty of parking! I think this is one of the best places I've had ramen at. Plus, this makes a great recovery meal off the strip of LV! If I'm ever back again this is the one place I'd visit!   Service: Friendly   Food:   Tonkatsu Ramen: Ramen was perfectly cooked and the soup wasn't too oily. The meat was very flavorful and wasn't tough at all!   Kimchi Fried Rice: Wasn't spicy but was an alright dish that you could order anywhere else.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

us8uZ6-0DCu3IcWSVHp0BQ.text: This is the best Ramen I've had. We were in Vegas for 3 days and ate at least once here daily! Dinner time is a bit of a wait (30 mins to 1 hr) but soooo worth it! Lunch we were seated right away.

dYR9tiENZVwyMsrttGp2CA.text: I went there two days ago with my brother. When I got there around 5pm, it was not busy yet. I really liked their pork belly don! The restaurant was clean, and services were great! Glad to find this place!!!

SrpM6RFnX2apzK36052kPg.text: I've been to other ramen joints in town and spent over $10 just for a bowl that wasn't even worth it. This place is so affordable and the portion sizes are very generous. The restaurant is small, only a handful of tables. But that doesn't stop people from waiting, this place is so popular! Every time I go, there's always a line, especially when they open, so be prepared to wait up to 15- 25 minutes. Plus they won't seat you unless your whole party is here, even if it's only for 2 people. My must-haves are the Tonkotsu or Miso ramen and the Takana fried rice. Their Chashu bowl is also very delicious. Once you get seated, the staff is pretty quick about taking your order and the food comes out fast, within 5-10 minutes. Monta's is definitely the place to go in Vegas for quality ramen.

Mq7oVVjucspxMfehzU5skg.text: Limited seating (6 tables that can sit parties of 4 and bar seating). 6 ramen style options, rice bowls, and appetizers. Around $7 per bowl. It's small! My family pretty much tried all the different styles and we all agreed it was SUPERRRRR SALTY. Eggs are add-ons. I don't understand why it's so popular here, we all had to drink water with every slurp. The spicy ramen wasn't spicy, just a spoonful of hot sauce. Tea is $3.  Yeah, won't be back. I wouldn't mind trying another place down closer to the strip. Private parking lot that's a tight squeeze with several other Asian cuisines around.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. #3 Ramen. The one with pork and chicken broth.

TYcQ-s_sEulKkQUdeFwQJA.text: Another great find with Ramen. Cute little place fantastic service good prices great food. They are always busy so prepare for a little bit of a wait

9JVROruATwkmwRqFyEbylA.text: After having ramen from the restaurant down the road,  I was quite disappointed in Monte Ramen.    It was relatively easy to find...on the right side of Spring Mountain Road as you drive east. The parking lot is shared with other busy restaurants.  I could feel a slight breeze from the air conditioning which was really helpful since it was 100 degrees outside!   The interior was small and dark. There were 5 tables and 9 counter seats. There were a few chairs for customers to wait for a table. Make sure you get your name on the clipboard!   The gyoza was shocking. ..it looked pale and undercooked,  like it was just fried on one of its 3 sides.  The inside was bland and flat tasting.   On the other hand,  the miso broth was really salty and the noodles were too soft. I didn't finish it.  The toppings of green onion, bamboo shoots & black fungus were room temperature as if they were hastily thrown on the top.   I would only go back if the competition down the road was full and if there was no line.  If there was a line,  go to the other restaurants right next door!  Sorry...

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen. ..meh.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Underdone,  pale &amp; bland gyoza.

B1x_4j4A-8qGogAEcI3WHA.text: This small ramen shop in the oriental portion of Vegas was amazing! They have tables for groups and a bar section, and they do first come first serve. When I arrived it was completely packed, but getting seated didn't take too long. They have around 5 different ramen bowls, with the most popular being the tonkotsu and shoyu ramen.  I tried the miso ramen with extra pork chashu and it was so rich! They also had kimchi fried rice so we decided to try that as well.   Was I was impressed with was the speediness of our orders. No more than 8 minutes pass by and we were served 4 different ramen bowls and a plate of fried rice. I believe we were in and out in less than an hour.   It'd be perfect if we had a restaurant this fast and efficient back in Orlando!

Q9zztoXCSTczN2D5Dtzf_g.text: We got there at 11:15 am on a Thursday and within minutes the line started to form behind us (we were 6th in line). Line forming before opening = legit ramen place. There's roughly enough tables/seats in the restaurant for 18-24 (off of memory). Then there's some bar stools for dining as well. It was our first time there, and being from the Bay Area, we've had some good Ramen back home, this place is comparable, if not better than most we've had. I like how you start out with your choice of "base ramen" and then do your add-ons from there. We tried the Miso and the Shoyu. Both were good, but I really liked the Shoyu flavor. We added the Pork Chashu, Flavored Egg, Corn, Nori, Fresh Shredded Green Onion, and when you add it all together and top with the pickled ginger -- you got some yummy ramen goodness. We also ordered a small bowl of the Pork Belly Bowl. This was really good as well, very tasty, comfort food (if you like a good bowl of rice and meat). We also had the Gyoza, which was fine. When we're back in Vegas, we may have to come back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso, Shoyu and Spicy Tonkatsu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl (small) -- Tasty!

IQhWEZXNs3l7Sxi4tS2mNQ.text: Amazing!! Best Ramen in my life! I had the black garlic. Great staff and fast service

iyON1wxXAmA6o0_L8VtHDQ.text: This ramen shop is authentic. Authentic in size and authentic in taste according to my friend who was born and raised in Japan.  With that being said, there aren't too many seats and it probably isn't a good idea to bring a party any larger than 6 here. There was a wait when we arrived on a Friday evening, but nothing insane (maybe ~15 mins) and completely worth it.  The gyoza was pan fried, and you could really tell they were made in-house. Yum.  I had the spicy tonkotsu ramen and it was simple, but delicious. Noodles are on the thinner side, but I liked it that way. Broth was flavorful and not oily.  Parking lot can get full. Service was fast and attentive though.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkatsu $7.50

tFp71iBjEVc4iM6rrkOCsw.text: My wife and I love this place. We have been there 3 times now and both love it. Even our 11 month old eats the noodles and broth. I've personally tried: The spicy tonkatsu ramen, tonkatsu ramen, miso ramen and tonkatsu-shoyu ramen. By far my favorite is the last one. As for the sides, I've tried the gyoza and kimchi fried rice. Both very good. Kimchi fried rice was the better of the two. Not authentic korean but that ok because this is a Japanese restaurant, not korean. When you come you have to do the kaedama, more noodles. I feel like they give you more noodles as the kaedama than what comes with the original bowl. Can't say enough good things about this place. Oh and it's cheap!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu-shoyu ramen. The best one imo
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Regular fried rice. Kimchi fried rice is better

RFXR6H8QmgwcnVibN_MMuQ.text: I honestly don't understand the hype.  A couple friends and I had gone here after hearing about how amazing this establishment is. Always seeing the long lines whenever eating in the neighboring establishments, we had always passed up on coming until now.  Monta Ramen is in the literal hub of Chinatown, as everything here boosts popularity. From Zen, Trattoria Nakamura-ya, Snowflake Shavery, and Raku, be warned that finding a parking spot during busier times can be almost impossible.  We were promptly seated as soon as a table was available for us. If there is a wait, I suggest figuring out what you want before being seated. The servers here work efficiently, so be prepared!  I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen. Prices were pretty cheap and there are extra toppings for you to add. Be warned as these add-ons are are lot more expensive than other ramen joints in town. As much as I wanted to like the food, I couldn't. The broth was thick, creamy, and filled with so much sodium I felt parched shortly after attempting to drink the broth. I couldn't taste much else from the ramen because of how heavy and salty the broth was. The other two in my group seemed to agree, as we all usually finished our ramen bowls from other restaurants, but suddenly had a hard time finishing half these bowls. We felt sick after leaving the restaurant.  As popular as this place is, I really cannot see why. Maybe it was a bad day and I will someday give this place another try. But for now, I'd rather go to a ramen place that doesn't make me feel nauseous.

7G3ECle_6uIYbrcaBzjUdA.text: A casual weekday lunch was met with a 20 minute wait. Was it worthy? YES!   We did not hesitate and immediately ordered upon seating. I had the spicy tonkotsu with special blend of hot spices. It was graced with cha siu, bamboo shoots, and scallions. The broth was thick and rich with grease. The cha siu came in huge slabs that covered a great portion of the bowl. The ratio of lean and fat was well balanced. My friend had the kuro with black garlic oil. The flavor was peculiar and memorable. It was also slightly heavier than my spicy tonkotsu.   Great food for a cheap price! This will definitely make it to my list for revisiting when I am in the area!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro with black garlic oil
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu with special spices

TY-iX3VJ1jPVbOr90dHnVg.text: Friendly no frills service, tasty and quick ramen.  We just got their normal ramen and was satisfying enough.  Small small place though so the wait was a bit much but I guess relatively speaking, wasn't too bad.

ugc11bBPryMOxpAj-43Csg.text: First time trying ramen and it was very good! This place has great service food comes quick you're in and out quickly and completely satisfied. This will be a place I make a point to stop at every time I'm in Vegas from now on.

gH-E77PHJwUajsxg80jSYA.text: Imagine trying one of the most authentic ramen's places in Las Vegas. This place is the place to go for ramen!

QcETFJJ2Y8tSBZYSzAHkgw.text: Solid - I wouldn't say the best I've had but good enough to want to keep coming back for a ramen fix. I will say the fried rice though ......yeh, I'll come for that everyday and twice on Sunday.  Only negative is the joint is super small and you need to establish dominance quickly to gain space...I recommend elbows and dropping a few love handles into people early to create "trust boundaries"....

_vFuDeSPNPBbll0ztjcb5Q.text: Had the ramen a while back, when they first open. It was very busy and we sat at the counter.   It was the same today, very busy for late lunch. I didn't expect a wait list but we put our name down and waited, no too long around 10 minutes. We sat at the counter!  We ordered the gyoza, the pork belly bowl, the chashu bowl, spicy tonkotsu ramen and the shoyu ramen. It was all very good, the broth was perfectly blended, warming the noodles through and the pork belly bowl is worth a repeat, it was top of my favorites list!   Service was great, food was great, now that cold weather is upon us, this may become a welcome spot!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Y1E5EmAq5Iwelo9gsOskcA.text: Best ramen in Vegas, hands down.  I have tried other ramen shops but I always find myself back here.  Monta has delicious broth and great noodles.  I like the wavy thick noodles that is offered in the miso ramen and shoyu ramen.  The thin straight noodles are good too but I like the thick kind.  You can choose from Tonkatsu (pork), Shoyu, Tonkatsu-Shoyu, or Miso broth.  You can make any broth spicy.  There is also a new broth that is the Tonkatsu broth with black garlic oil.  Sounds yummy.  The broths are all great and there are yummy add-ins.  I always add corn.  If you are feeling extra indulgent add some butter!  I like to wear a dark colored shirt so that you can't see all of the splash marks from the soup.   The sides are good to start off with.  The fried rice is actually pretty amazing.  The chunks of meat in the fried rice are delicious.  Gyoza is always a safe bet too.  Expect to wait.  That is the only reason I am not here more often.  I hate waiting to eat.  This restaurant is tiny and there are a lot of Monta fans out there.  You can try their other location Monta Chaya in Henderson if you are closer to that side of town.  Haven't been myself but it's owned by the same people.   Happy Ramen-ing :D

5TJLx_uHQUafnMa7WDs87Q.text: This Ramen spot has been my go to ever since I first heard about it in college. It's authentic, delicious, and comes out quickly after ordering. Can't go wrong there!   However, because this place has that good of ramen, everyone is bound to end up here. When you walk in there is normally a line or a couple groups ahead of you. Be sure to write your name on the list and include the number of people in your party. They may not get to you for a while so just be patient. When you are seated, whether it be at the bar or at the table, you'll see why there is such a wait!   PS. They have another location now on Eastern that serves the same ramen with a couple more appetizers than this Monta spot & the place is much larger. If you're not into waiting too much, I recommend heading to the Eastern location.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Side of Gyoza. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with pork chashu, egg, nori (seaweed) and corn.

S1jW7VNO-OSsyad9ciAhgQ.text: I seriously believe local Yelpers in Vegas has low food expectations. I'm not a foodie but I do love my food.  A transplant from California, many of the restaurants I've visited via Yelp reviews have been a disappointment.    Now this Ramen joint was just OK. Very basic noodles, soup, and it's ingredients.  For the 3 stars... service was fast and price was decent.  Would I return? Probably not.  I'd likely hit up other ramen places and see wha they have to offer.

Svk6Me0o7Cz917skH5teHg.text: Saw this place on multiple lists of where to eat in Vegas and my brother who really loves ramen recommended it as well. Very small place and that is the reason for a long wait time. I had 6 people in my group and we had to wait about 45 min. Groups of 2/3 were just going in and out. The menu is very simple and to the point with the different types of ramen they offer and the description of the broth and toppings. The first thing that stood out to me were the prices. Everything was less than $9. They also have other items like fried rice and gyozas. I ordered the Kuro Black Garlic Oil ramen and substituted the thin noodles for the medium thick noodles and added eggs, corn, and a sheet of seaweed. I'm not big on ramen but I really enjoyed my bowl. I even drank my broth from the bowl. The flavors were great and the noodles are hand made. For my table that ordered 6 bowls of ramen and an order of gyoza, our total was just under $75. That blew me away because I've always seen and spent at least $15 for a bowl ramen and most of them did not taste as good as here at Monta's. My only tip is expect a longer wait if you have a group of 4 or more because there are not many seats and the place is small. Definitely worth checking out especially for the prices and quality. Service was also great!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Black Garlic Oil Ramen

GttN50W7mniK_WrYDDiwhg.text: -Amazing ramen -so tasty  -satisfying -great size  -decent prize for ramen -super friendly service

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen menu price

QdkVqgo7b0bt6hb7JxUIhw.text: Monta is a solid 5 star Ramen spot! Killer service with excellent flavor. This place is a tucked in the back of a plaza in spring mountain I think every establishment in the place is at least four stars minimum! Started with braised pork belly and gyoza the pork belly is a Must Try! Went with the garlic ramen pork soup and added extra chili powder and oil for a little extra kick. The soup was enjoyable from start to finish with the perfect amount of each ingredient! **Favorite Ramen in Vegas

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Pork Belly Bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen

g00NocP8mFN2nK9F8lRoAA.text: Mmmmm...Monta.   The wait is always so damn long, but it is worth it.   It turns out that Monta and Marugame Monzo are run by the same group, which does not surprise me one bit.  Both have exceptionally delicious Japanese noodles.

v1xfnaFJL1eHRYv75ZI5ww.text: Best ramen spot in Las Vegas hands down. Orgasmic! And only $1 for more noodles. The lawd is great

tjlgKfZ4ar7_WoiljNx3Xg.text: Love Monta Ramen post night out clubbing. Perfect hangover food! It really depends on what you're feeling so you can't go wrong. I got the shoyu ramen but have had the hakkata spicy miso, both are really good.   Restaurant is small, you should get there when it opens or expect a wait.

0gOkz7vEG-fH_WRVNh58fA.text: I've been here twice and it's been really good!  The first time I came it was just two of us and we waited about 1/2 an hour. The second time it was a group of six and we waited probably an hour total (or at least one of our party waited an hour). This place is pretty small and I was hesitant with six people, but it worked out in the end. You probably shouldn't do more than six unless it's dead and both times I've been it was obviously busy (hence the wait).   However, once you get inside and order your food comes out relatively quickly and it's very tasty. The price is also quite nice because for being such a busy place they could probably charge a bit more (like lots of other ramen places) and still keep he crowds coming in.  Overall, I enjoy Monta and I'd probably go back, but maybe just as a group of 2-3.  Kimchi fried rice is so good.

TmaLHSeanwhVEPtSWuWwyA.text: Growing up in an Asian household, packaged ramen was pretty abundant in our cupboards. All sorts of flavors, brands, containers -- it was a staple. So when friends would rave about these ramen restaurants, I shrugged it off and remained widely uninterested.   It is just now that I am realizing how awesome and authentic this comfort food can be. Winter weather = ramen weather! Definitely slurping it up and making my rounds this season, and Monta was one of these. Lol, guess who's clearly late on the ramen train!  Parking is packed. Place is tiny. Sign yourself in and be prepared to wait. Make sure that your whole party is present, or they won't seat you. It happened to us. Makes sense though when your establishment is only about five tables and a limited bar area.  I had the shoyu ramen with nori (seaweed) added...I don't have any proper adjectives to describe it for you since I am nothing but a ramen amateur, but it was good. I do know I like thick noodles in my soup and it had that. My boyfriend had the miso and it was creamier compared to mine. We both shared the regular fried rice, which was a nice contrast. I drank their green tea, iced, and it came in a can. My other friend wanted hot tea, and it too, came in the same can, but heated. Strange. Overall, good ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. shoyu with added nori.

gpH38Mb4JTdtrKtVl0mZIA.text: Best ramen in Nevada, hands down. Authentic and ridiculously inexpensive for the quality. Don't forget The fried rice and handmade gyoza. Each ramen on the menu is perfect.

ravo4BaDwNKUsQTb0MdFeQ.text: This is my go to ramen spot I'm Chinatown! Always get the tonkatsu and add on more yummy stuff like the egg, and corn, and seaweed. The pork has a good flavor to it that is more than just the broth, but the broth itself is rich and very flavorful.   Downside for me but good for them: it's always busy. Also, I wish they delivered or partnered with uber eats. I haven't checked the other food delivery apps but they aren't on uber eats anymore.

RP9ZaHqS1wuu8FGMVT4-rQ.text: Monta is located on the outskirts of Chinatown. First impression, the parking lot is tight!  It can be difficult to find parking around lunch time. I heard a lot of good things about Monta Ramen and was eager to give it a try. Despite the 112 degree Las Vegas heat, good ramen is worth the wait and the sweat. My name was sixth on the list and it took about 15 minutes to be seated.  Not bad for a weekday lunch time and a highly rated restaurant.   The inside was pretty small but they've got the air condition kicking with a fan inside.  It was a definite relief from the heat outside. I wouldn't bring a party of more than six here because it may take longer to get seated.  The waitresses were polite and attentive. My friend and I ordered the tonkatsu ramen for $6.99 each which is a steal!  The order arrived quickly and first thing I notice is the broth is rich. You can see a lot of flavor packed into the bowl. It's a good mixture of saltiness, fat, and an overall creaminess that went well with the pork slices and egg. The noodles are thin and firm, perfect to slurp with the soup!  I quickly finished the bowl and drank all the soup before my long drive back home.  Great way to end my LV trip and can't wait to come back in the future to try something new on the menu!

Mop5ULHvNYoU4vMS63DvrA.text: Affordable, close to authentic ramen. What more can you ask for?  Monta Ramen is a fairly small ramen shop, seating maybe about 25-35 including the ramen bar area, but like most yelpers are keen to point out, they do try to move guests along. My family of 4 came right at the peak of dinner 7pm and only had to wait for 20 minutes, not too bad if you ask me.  We started our meal off with a pork belly bowl which was just savory goodness. The pork drippings from the fat coated the each grain of rice and made it all savory, buttery, and utterly delicious. The slivers of red ginger also helped to cut the fattiness/greasy factor of this dish.  Next came our orders. We each ordered some variety of ramen, but noticed that only the miso ramen came with "traditional" ramen noodles. Everyone else received these thinner noodles...still good, but not what we expected. I added a pad of butter and corn to my dish which made it more complete in my opinion....I also appreciated the fact that add-on's here ranged from $0.50 to $1.50 as opposed to my regular $1.50 to $3.00 in the Bay Area (for the same two spoonfuls of corn in most cases). My only complaint, outside of the noodle-snafu, was that our ramen was delivered lukewarm at best. It was a little off-putting.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoryu Ramen with extra corn and butter

q0lPutAOFVaQAO5Q9UQ7ew.text: I got the black ramen and my date got the spicy tonkotsu. The spicy tonkotsu initially comes as a normal tonkotsu and then you mix the spicy red stuff in the soup to make it spicy. My date really liked that the get to enjoy two flavors. He also said that the spicy thing is like spicy miso so it adds additional flavor/depth. The kuro ramen was really good, just the right amount of garlic so I didn't feel the need to add any(there's garlic on the table if you want to add it). We also got gyoza and fried rice. The gyoza was good but I was really really fascinated by the fried rice. That was like the perfect fried rice you would get at a Japanese ramen place. Wish I lived closer so I could go back.   We got there like ten minutes after opening on Sunday and the place was already filled.

51NCwpl-kzVDHX6p1LERAA.text: 5 stars for their ramen and cost! I always get their tonkotsu shoyu ramen sometimes with corn (50 cents extra) not bad at all considering I have paid $2 extra before, YIKES! Although their broth is a bit too salty for me, I love the noodles!  I feel like I'm the only one that doesn't drink the broth with my noodles whenever I come. Everyone I come with have close to empty bowls.  The chashu is just okay to me. I'm not a big fan of it and if I do eat it, I like mine a little on the leaner side than fatty.    More often than note this place is ALWAYS busy and not a great place for larger groups.  It is a tiny restaurant, requesting bar seats will get you seated faster typically if you don't have many in your party (i.e. 3 or less) and there is a clipboard to sign in on by the door.   3 stars due to the fact they allow non service animals in the restaurant. Story below.  Allows non service dogs in the restaurant which is a health code violation.  She got kicked out of Kungfu Tea two doors down before coming in to eat. Other than that the food was okay and wait was long as usual.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Holding her dog.

nAiHq3j-NHIuO8cCTDY1-Q.text: So I have tried nearly all of the ramen spots in Vegas and this is one of the few locations which I haven't visited yet. The seating is very limited so naturally there was a little bit of a wait.     After making it to the bar area me and my wife were extremely rushed to make a drink order as well as a food order right away. I ordered the spicy pork broth with nori and egg along with a hot tea. The hot tea came out right away inside a very hot can which was placed inside a cheap plastic cup. This is the first time in my life I was ever served a "hot tea" this way, and I unfortunately burnt my fingers quite badly picking it up. After pouring it in the cup which the can was inside I decided not to drink it, not only because of the awful taste, but I was attempting to be conscious of the potential health hazards.         My ramen came out almost instantly afterwards; but to my dismay, the broth was nearly ice cold, and there was no nori inside either. Other reviews have stated that the broth wasn't hot either, so my theory is that they make it that way to turn tables as fast as they can; as I felt extremely rushed by our server who was already making mistakes with my order. The noodles and eggs were the only two things in the bowl that tasted up to standard. I was able to get the nori off my check, and I had to deal with a slight stomach ache afterwards, but thankfully nothing too terrible.     I am very happy that I was finally able to eat here so I know very well that I should never come close to this place again. There are many great ramen spots in town, and this is absolutely not one of them!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The hot tea is in a piping hot can which is sealed. Watch out for your fingers if you didn&#39;t come prepared with gloves to handle it!

kfY8hJYcEySZfa5SKDL5-g.text: 1. Ramen is super salty  2. Super crowded restaurant   Although their ramen is super salty I did enjoy their beef and ramen. The wait wasn't too bad but I didn't like how cramped it was. The service was mediocre not bad or the best.

C-lMdj5NlohCgM37naEycg.text: I had high expectations for this place since our friends said it was the best ramen ever. Not the best, IMO, but still good.  SPICY TONKOTSU RAMEN $8 - The ramen noodles were pretty good, but the soup was way too fatty for me. I usually love fatty ramen soup but the soup here is ridiculously thick. Drinking the soup alone will fill you up. I also don't think the spicy version of the tonkotsu ramen is worth it, since it's $1 more than the regular version and not very spicy at all. I had to add extra spicy powder and oil.  Extra noodles are $1.50 and if you want to share, I suggest just getting 1 bowl and adding extra noodles to split. This way you basically get two bowls of ramen for $10.  FRIED RICE $6 - Pretty good, but not worth it for $6.  TAKANA FRIED RICE $7 - Expensive! Save your money and get ramen instead. This also tasted like mushrooms.  Be prepared to wait, because this place is really popular, even when it's hot outside. The restaurant itself is pretty tiny, with only a couple of tables and a bar area. The restaurant location is in a plaza with a bunch of other popular Asian food places, so be prepared to spend time looking for parking.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu ramen w/extra corn
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu shoyu ramen

60aUKdWrPD1lkgnX8NVjrQ.text: DELICIOUS. Although the wait was terrible EVEN on a Sunday afternoon at 3:30pm... Yes, you heard right... 3:30 pm and we still had to wait an hour to get seated. I am impressed with the fact that they stay True to their word that seating is first come, first serve. As in, if the next table open is can seat 4 people and you're next with a party of 2, you are still the ones to get that table. That was definitely what I wanted to hear after that long, terrible wait. But this means you will have to make sure you are present when they call your name, because I am almost certain they will also keep their word that you will be taken off the waiting list with no exceptions.  The food itself was fantastic. The broth was perfection, thick and flavorful. The noodles are the thin kind, which wasn't a problem for me. My friend got the spicy fish egg with rice side dish and unfortunately hated it. She took two small bites before leaving the rest untouched due to the fact that it was way too salty.   Overall, just don't get in line starving and expecting to get seated immediately, no matter what random hour you arrive. Thankfully the food came out fast after ordering!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Eggs not included!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Salty/spicy fish eggs with rice

rYJqUiCk4uZHAAKOUu2ljw.text: Not bad, Monta Ramen... not bad at all.   Three of my friends and I came here after a night dancing looking for some soup to appease our parched bodies. Here are some things you should expect:   1. Parking Easy peasy. There is a big lot, so no need to worry about that.  2. The wait Oh my goodness. We came to this place like 40 minutes before it opened, and there was ALREADY A LINE. This being said, I HIGHLY recommend coming early & waiting, unless you want to be in the hot Las Vegas sun, grumpy, hungry, hungover and sweaty.   3. The ramen I ordered the new spicy tonkatsu ramen with an egg. It was SO GOOD! The broth was very flavorful and not too salty (although, I've been told that I have a salty palette.. to each his own.). The pork in the ramen was soft and melted in my mouth! My only regret is not getting extra. My boyfriend got the tonkatsu shoyu ramen with fat noodles, which was good, but definitely not as good as mine... I think his was TOO salty for my taste (which again, has been known to be on the salty side). Even thought my ramen was overall really good, I couldn't finish it because it felt way too heavy/greasy in my stomach. I actually ended up with a small stomach ache after.   4. The service Okay, I guess I have to cut some slack here, because there were only 2 workers manning the floor, but it took FOREVER to order/flag someone down... it kind of felt like they were ignoring us on purpose at first. Nobody likes to have to compete for attention! #middlechildsyndrome #i'mnotevenamiddlechild #yelpdoesntevendohashtags  5. The value SUPER CHEAP! Also, a coke was only ONE DOLLAH! To me, that seems unheard of in a restaurant...   All in all, I recommend it. If you're like me and you easily get stomach aches from food that is too heavy, buttery or greasy, I'd recommend getting a coke or a sprite with your ramen so that you can burp all out alll dat ish.

N92lJfpfy_7If9kmehmGvw.text: have to try: its very small so expect to wait but the service is very quick. The menu is very simple but very good. Three to four ramens to choose from and a variety of extras to add into your ramen.  Recommend the Kimichi fried rice!!

BM-EGADRBax6MWemFaAkDw.text: You are not allowed to bring outside drink blah blah. Next thing you know, a bug crawling on my food. The server took the plate away without a word. No apologize. Never coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A BUG!? For real? Not again monta, health district shut you guys down not so long ago.

0sI8O-fxSKBiXJCXL9MOSA.text: The best ramen I ever had! Noodles were just the right consistency, broth was flavorful and it wasn't expensive. What a great find!

G17S9o_EH3I2gQtfsA5XSw.text: Food- 5 stars. I come here 2x, sometimes 3x a months because the tonkotsu ramen is the best ramen joint in vegas.. Pork broth on point same with the pork and the eggs and the corn that was on there...always get extra  noodles also..  2 stars. why??  My server YURI was a total disappointment. Didnt smile at all what soever and we felt rushed actually. she dropped off my check and said "here." Really? hmmm..  Never checked back on us to ask if everythinf was okay, if we needed anything. The only time she came back was when she was dropping off the check and asked "u want more water?" hmmm..  Im a server too, and it wasnt really that busy at the time. wait was dead already, no need to rush us and make us feel unwanted.  Since im a server of course i still left 20% despite of the poor service we received. When we come back next month, i will make sure not to be served by yuri.

bF726ob_9gkC6yrI4eSulg.text: So what happens when it's 105 degrees outside and you're hungry? You get a hot bowl of ramen, of course! I spent 3 days in Vegas eating all kinds of overpriced food, but none of it was as good as the fairly priced bowl of ramen at Monta Ramen. I really enjoyed everything about it! The noodles, the broth, the chashu... all good! I would have liked if they had a bit more air conditioning and a bit more space, but that won't stop me from coming back the next time I am in town!

_9dHw6jgIeHydzlwo14iow.text: Avoid the expensive touristy restaurants of the strip. Go to Monta and enjoy a great ramen. Try the black garlic oil ramen, super tasty.

wN38jwGJQkyTIITMlfQNyg.text: With just a limited menu this place nails it on the flavor! Hot Ramen soup on a cold night. Yum yummy. It is a very very small restaurant so be prepared to wait outside. But worth it. The service is quick and fast and very attentive.

PrrkOsLAfUIIPGd7HQV4vQ.text: Always amazing! I've come here multiple times and I don't mind the wait because the food is THAT good. The food always comes out fast as well. Even though they are a small establishment and always have people waiting, you never feel rushed. Overall, the food is great, the price is right,  and I will keep coming back. I tell all my friends about it.

OpKxxil6PCYGydUoyWj2Dw.text: Dear God, this was amazing. We waited for an hour in the afternoon heat and it was completely worth it. The ramen! It was eclipsed only by the fried rice! This was the best meal I ate in Vegas and it was totally affordable.

Y0_f0e4kBugA_NJsCo9MMQ.text: Delicious fried rice. Seems almost steamed not greasy and oily like some My friends love the Ramen. Price is great A cute and cozy joint

suAOM8JHKoWJJ5ISjwbQSw.text: One of the best ramen place to eat...cheap food and good service... cannot really complain about anything...as seen on travel channel!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yes that&#39;s for two people!!! Complete dinner...everybody wins in vegas!!!

VfX9ZRZVIvyHwZtqm6LqVw.text: I am new to the ramen eating trend but I am enjoying it. This place is great! It is tasty and wallet conscious. Although it is a little small it is worth the wait. We came in on a Sunday night and had about a 5 min wait which I know is rare! I had the shoyu ramen and added corn and butter. It came quick and tasted great. The portions are perfect. I will definitely be back.

-HRD5Cx9YGhTvEgc0HXGCw.text: Drools... Amazing ramen. I introduced two friends to this and they loved everything they tried.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkotsu with extra toppings

ykPg5KGFxkZXIp5PSrT68Q.text: First time here last night. The establishment is small, and there is a sign in sheet for seating. It was packed when I went in, and there were 3 parties waiting ahead of me in the tiny standing room waiting area.  It was hot and humid inside and understandably so. The cooks and front of the house staff were upbeat, energetic and friendly which made my evening enjoyable.  I ordered the Kuro ramen noodles with black garlic oil, and any concern of waiting in the heat subsided. I added in egg and butter, and the egg was an amazing addition.  I will definitely keep going back to explore the menu here.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen with egg

YSVW698VZw1xNN8CD7NdeA.text: Lines & wait is usually long considering the place is really small but totally worth it.  The kimchi friend rice tastes AMAZEbawls  All the different types of ramen are yum  The price is very affordable.  Literally the only downside to this place is the wait.

l2I3kzVIHqqXCV6UW9V4cA.text: Date & Time: Sunday, 2/15/15 @ 830pm  I came here after work with a few coworkers, expecting since it's still the weekend it would be pretty busy (said a co-worker who was raving about this place).  The wait was about 30 mins, then the line grew as we were waiting for our table. We ordered: - Soyu Ramen (extra chasiu) - 2 Tonkatsu Ramen (extra chasiu and egg) - 1 Pork belly bowl - 4 drinks total is around $50  Since this was the first time trying a Ramen spot besides my own mothers, I decided why not, since one of my co-workers have been asking all of us to go everyday at work. We entered the restaurant after the wait and the table are really packed close together (so it's like we're eating the table next to us). The people in line are watching other people eat, it's kind of awkward.  I tried my ramen, it was good but not the greatest (I told him, the hype he was giving this restaurant was not necessary anymore). The chasiu was weird, it was disintegrating in my soup. It was mostly melty, fatty, and I found it pointless to get extra.   My love got so sick from this place, he was perfectly fine, until that night. He was sweating and grabbing a fever, everything came out from both ends for a couple of days. He's afraid to try Ramen again :(

BuzrXyG_wqW_eepvkyDFCA.text: Very good ramen.   Didn't think ramen when it was 110f was a good idea at first but this place was definitely good.  The pork slices literally melt in your mouth.

c0PeLy8S1yr4ifdXRlPthQ.text: Best ramen I've ever had!! Plus awesome fry rice!! They could have sushi and I would be really happy! Very authentic food

YBgazwF0QL-LPP4hzi7-7Q.text: Although this is a ramen place, I've been looking for more places where I can get more flavorful fried rice and this is the place! I loved the fried rice, black garlic ramen, and potstickers! So worth the wait!

kozDReDhnTqoYzVvJaYcJQ.text: After arriving into town after a long road trip, I decided to try Monta Ramen out after observing during previous trips to Kabuto, Raku, and Sweet Raku (all in the same strip mall) that there was always a line congregated outside of Monta Ramen but I did not want to endure the torment of waiting with the summer heat.  Solid bowl of ramen, the tonkotsu broth is slightly more viscous than other broths I've had, but it was flavorful with a long complex finish.  The noodles were cooked right - not mushy at all nor undercooked.  It came with two slices of tender pork belly, and the add on option of seasoned egg had a good runny yolk.

LbGiXQgpmDqlY_eePlga9A.text: This is my favorite ramen place ever. My husband and I love Ramen and this by far is the best. We're from LA but every time we come to Vegas it's an absolute must before hitting the road. Perfect for the hangover too haha! Fried rice and gyoza's are good too. It's really small, so there's always usually a wait, but worth it.

UyHmuSQvSG0FITXrKRzo8Q.text: The wait was soooooooo long. 1 hour? 2 hours? It was ridiculous. But it was so highly yelped that we stuck it out through our hunger.  The ramen is very very salty. I have a salty palette and even for my taste buds, it was too high in sodium.  But what I loved were the small bowls of mentaiko and pork belly. We ordered 2 small bowls of mentaiko (fish eggs over rice, embellished with green onions etc) and 2 small bowls of pork belly over rice.   I also loved how they had kimchi on the menu. Most ramen places do not offer kimchi!   Loved everything about the place except the wait and the saltiness of the ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The bowls of mentaiko and pork belly over rice. My faves from the menu.

C1eerTBKg9I0T5Qw8BeuFA.text: I'm so sad to give them this rating. Monta has the best ramen in town, but not this monta. Their chasu was really chewy and I was surprised. The space is really small and it gets crowded. The chairs at the bar were really uncomfortable. And they seated like 3 parties before we sat down when we were there before all of them!!! I usually crave monta and love it, but it's the Eastern location that has my heart. I asked nicely if they had the chasu buns here and the lady was rude and said "no we don't." It was just a question. Anyway, probably won't be going back to this monta again. Sad because it used to be a favorite. Looks like I'll stick to the one in Henderson with nicer staff and better quality food. Ta ta for now!

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chasu buns

KzwEHJx6RUOxnFrRlBJemA.text: Their broth is out of this world. The food was amazing and the service it great. Hole in the wall everyone should try.

XParJdmm-S7F1LStCbcNDw.text: Absolutely Shitty service by two Asian female waitresses in 11/26 early afternoon.  "Bxtch" is probably a suitable terms to describe these two waitress/hostess.  Food is mediocre. Meat was too fatty and unhealthy.  I personally would not pick to come back to this restaurant because they hire very shitty and "rude" waitresses.  Do not go.

3dsXd1Fan2jNH7OHlw6SFg.text: I was craving ramen after going out in Downtown LV and found this place through Yelp. As an avid ramen eater, I would say this place was pretty good. I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen, and I must say, I have had more flavorful broth but the noodles were a nice texture and the ratio of noodles to pork was fairly equal.   I loved that this place was open late and although it was packed when I first arrived at 12:30am, I was seated within 15 minutes of arriving. I also enjoyed that they had all the condiments already on the table, including the fresh ginger. I always ask for ginger and I'm glad this time I didn't have to!   I am biased towards my ramen spot in Torrance, however I'm still a fan of this place. I would come back again!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork bowl and spicy tonkotsu ramen

EQEUUd-fX9BqsGKhfAXQ6A.text: A bit on the tiny side , so adequate seating may not be available for LARGE party's. Tables seat 4.  I really like sitting at the bar where I can look into the kitchen when they make my ramen . A bowl of ramen is perfect for my appetite. If u are feeling extra hungry you may want to order extra noodles. I had the spicy tonkotsu for $7.95 . Just spicy enough to make my nose run but not too spicy for me to eat. Friendly service and really fast service. I've waited longer for some meals at McDonalds. I will definitely be back here .

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu

XJopLYGZcu6CdSN_qOQM3g.text: Hands down the best tonkotsu ramen ever. I had the spicy tonkotsu ramen. It adds the taste to the broth, and it's not too spicy. Wife had shoyu ramen. Also taste great. The broth is not oily at all and the pork (chasu) melts in your mouth. Place is so small. We came about 5 minutes before they open for lunch on Friday and the line is already long outside. We had to wait for the next available table. It's definitely worth the wait. Service is great too. Definitely a pace to visit.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu

onLQcyS9Q3TZhVP52E3QDA.text: My boyfriend and I had to stop in again on our way to the airport.. Monta has awesome ramen. Also, I would recommend getting the spicy sauce on the side of you like a little extra flavor!!  Warning** you will leave full.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Green tea here is awesome.

du8Nevgoind7HFWBo99CWQ.text: I am honestly still dreaming about this place! I came here on a cold day and let me just say that this place is so small lol I really didn't expect how small the shop was going to be, but I really liked how cozy it was. There were only about 4-5 tables and a bar area, but people seemed to be really considerate by not camping out and most of the parties seated left shortly after finishing their meals, which I was very grateful for.   I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen and the boyfriend ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and we honestly just fell in love with our food. Both broths just have so much flavor that you just can't help but mindlessly sip on it long after the noodles and toppings are gone. We also had an order of the gyoza, which were tremendously tasty as well.   I never thought that I'd find a good ramen place in Vegas, but this place just really won me over. It's definitely my number one for ramen, which really sucks because I'm from LA and that is way too far from this place. I will definitely be back the next time I'm in the area.

_P9uK4AofwysjAqTkmiXNw.text: This small, bustling hole in the wall is serving up some of the best meals under $10 in Vegas.   There's only a handful of small tables here and limited bar seating, there is almost always a queue. It's well worth the usually short wait time.  The kitchen with steaming cauldrons and busy cooks can be seen over the bar and creates a fun atmosphere.   The menu is straightforward and uncomplicated. I love the simplicity.  The gyoza are crispy and delicious, the ramen is always cooked perfectly, the chashu pork is tender. They have some killer sides and rice bowls.  Everything is reasonably priced.  The pork belly rice bowl is phenomenal. The meat is slow braised into buttery, tender melt in your mouth goodness.  The waitresses are friendly and accommodating,  especially considering how busy this place is.   They could probably use a larger space with more tables to eliminate the wait times, but the small space is part of the charm. Enjoy it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Seasonings and sauces.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl. Amazingly tender. 5/5

IAZJ9WHTcoK_rR4fFO8bXg.text: First tried Monta at one of the Japanese Ramen festivals out in Torrance, CA. There were maybe several competitors but not one jazzed me. Except enter Monta. Small booth tucked in a corner. No heavy signage just three folks sweatin in the polstering heat serving up what unbeknowst to me the best ramen showcasing. Found out that they have a location out in Las Vegas and decided to take some family members out there to give it a try.  Got there 30 minutes before they opened. All of us hungover from the night before, only to see that there is a line about to form! We turned off our engines parked and snagged in front of the line. in 30 minutes I kid you not, at least 40 others joined. Luckily we were in front.   Starving and dehydrated. We ordered. I settled for the Spicy Tonkotsu with the added green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage. Added additionally the Nori + Nitamago. (dry seaweed and hard boiled egg, respectively) some corn, etc. My gal got the Tonkotsu BLACK. and whoa. I've never had a ramen to that degree ever in my 30 years of life. What is this? A smoky flavored broth? almost like a bbq tang? THIS was my highlight. It was unusual. It was weird. But in the most gnarliest of ways a ramen can be. I highly recommend that one.   fyi: their Chasu Bowl is one of the better ones I have experienced in all of CA. Definitely worth it as a side dish.   As a matter of fact. I am visiting MONTA again for MDW (Memorial Day Weekend) I am coming back. It wouldn't be a successful Vegas trip without a visit to Monta. Seriously best Ramen in town.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

v5Li9jyrUjGFCGdaN0KOFw.text: Great food and service. Would recommend this to anyone. Kinda of a small location and very popular so be prepared for a wait but it's well worth it!!!

Pd7Sq9_TTqlAx41nQ9Rhew.text: Cheap and tons of food. Delicious udon. Service extrmely fast and nice. Highly recommended, and definitely will come back.

A_B8bMxO5yDGfwLZeEmLIw.text: Had to wait in a long line.  Really small place. But it moved fast.  You don't linger here.   Ordered tonkotsu shoyu ramen and miso ramen. Small order of pork belly bowl. Thick wavy noodles are what you expect when you order ramen. The thin noodles are good too but the thicker ones are better.   One of my kids preferred the thinner noodle. They both thought it was the best ramen ever.

ZNSq_CpEDOu6Ybwt6XBVZw.text: Best ramen in town! Tonkotsu ramen broth is gravy thick and flavorful of pork bone essence, with slices of fragrant marinated pork belly. Add Nitamago egg $1.50 with delightful moist yolk to top off. Kuro ramen in delicious black garlic oil is good too, though slightly overpowering original tonkot broth character. Limited seating, Only 5 tables, 8 bar seats, good for small groups under 4. Come off peak hours to avoid long waits.

DAqpxp5klRH6VZODgMok3w.text: I usually eat at Orochon in LA but, figured I'd give this place a try - excellent! Better than Orochon. Ordered Miso Ramen with pork, green onions, egg. Flavor was awesome. Service was quick, place was clean. Only downside - it is small so get there early. Tomorrow, pork belly bowl on bed of rice. See pics.
