dfSWINuSvRcn5qU-L3LwiA.text: Best Tonkatsu ramen ever. I will come back here every time I'm in Las Vegas!  If you love Asian food, get away from the strip and in to Chinatown. Las Vegas has two food cultures - the tourist trap restaurants on the strip, and the amazing deals 1 to 2 miles away.

ZyzIbSYTGoV8cyK4vVkpmw.text: Some of the best ramen I've ever had. Seriously delicious. Their gozya was also outstanding and cooked to perfection.

kktlIvUxq1lA9EZxjEjmfA.text: Wow I thought Yamadaya Ramen was the best but now this place takes the crown. I had my doubts about trying ramen outside of SoCal since there is so much ramen competition and I'm glad I gave this place a shot. Their variation of the black garlic oil ramen was the best ramen broth I've ever had. The pork that comes with it was so tender as well. I added the flavor egg and it was cooked perfectly, the yolk was not fully cooked and had a tasty texture. I also loved the variety of add ons on the table such as adding as much ginger as you'd like. Definitely check this place out while in vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wow, best ramen I&#39;ve ever had
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

OCD_T9PhvNlBpbseKJKNBw.text: Horrible service. Rushed us to leave even though there were no one waiting to be seated. Rushed us to sign the check. All bad

56jqlPZg6oxfdZz6Mk9_xA.text: Monta Ramen is one of the best ramen spots in Las Vegas. Is it the best in town? Maybe...  My order I always get is the Tonkotsu Ramen + extra Chashu + Nitamago + Corn  Sometimes I order Gyoza, sometimes Fried Rice, sometimes both. Depends on how hungry I am.  Everything is done well and if you need more heat just add chili powder.  What sets Monta apart from the rest is their Chashu. I don't really fuck with pork but their Chashu just melts with good buttery & rich flavor. The broth can get heavy but their must be an egg in every Japanese hot noodle dish.  The spot is like how a ramen spot should be. Limited spacing with more seats at the bar than tables. You get in and get out (if no wait time) in 30 mins...  When it comes to Japanese food I'm a harsh critic because the times I've been to Tokyo and my mom's cooking  Overall it's maybe the best in town as I've converted non ramen lovers into lovers of ramen...if you haven't been go for sure!

uNffjQRoRnINpIp1_3lAag.text: Food: The broth was super tasty and creamy (I order the first one the menu), noodles amazing, I added the egg was delicious and the pork belly is to die for, Gyoza suuuper tasty and juicy.  Service: Super attentives servers Saori did a great job.  Price: $36 for 3 people which I think is not baad at all for the food quality.  Definitely coming back.

MFjZYGP__2FjLSPEFdgmSg.text: The secret is out. Best ramen in the state. The texture is great and portions are prefect. Love the soup and the Wood ear on top. The spicy power is good too. Wish there was one in other states. Price is great too.

MF3ERRAkz1qnTkmG6DjZcg.text: overrated. i'm not understanding the high ratings. middle of the road ramen with horrible service. now i understand why there's always a line outside, there's no where to sit inside. literally 4-5 tables and a bar counter. that's it. no appetizers. no hot drinks. the extra egg ordered was cold. the extra chashu ordered was cold. noodles were mushy. two stars for a reasonably good and hot broth. nothing to brag about. there's definitely a lot more ramen options out there where service and flavors easily top this.

9klhJzGHeLj_08AZL0FcVg.text: The best Japanese style ramen in town. You have the outside street bar feel when you walk in which makes the experience actually a little more authentic. The seating is very limited so be prepared to wait a bit.   The tonkotsu shoyu ramen is my absolute favorite. The portion size is great, especially considering you're only paying $7-8. The fried rice is my wife's favorite, and I have to say it's probably the best fried rice I've had in town.   I just wish they had refillable soda instead of only cans. The A/ unit isn't greatest either, so you can imagine how hot it can get when eating hot soup in a hot room. I always liked my food a little salty but sweating into my food isn't how I like it.

p68OK0EFMP-tWghKwj-wXw.text: Everyone around me loves Monta but believe it or not the first time I tried it was just a few months ago. It was quite a bit of an acquired taste to me. When I first tried it I got a tonkatsu ramen and I hated it! It was too rich and too porky for me and I found myself wanting pho instead HAHA but oddly enough I started craving it a couple weeks after!   Now I get the tonkatsu-shoyu with all the fixings except the greens with a side of kimchi! I always find myself thinking the noodle to soup ratio is off, I need more soup!!!! I always make sure to get the thinner noodles because they taste better! Sometimes the broth is way too salty and sometimes I leave feeling like I just drank a bunch of pork fat but I keep going back, it's strangely addicting LOL   The gyoza and kimchi fried rice are good but nothing too special~   The negative is that It's a really small restaurant and their AC is not the best. There's most likely always a wait. So in order to keep the flow going please be courteous and eat your ramen and leave! This is not a place to lolly-gag after you're done eating, quickly give up your table to the next hungry group or suffer the consequence of angry looks!!!!! LOL   Hot Tip: If you don't want to wait go at really odd times like 3:00-5:00; there's usually never a wait~

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Finally they have some good sour kimchi ~
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ask for the skinny noodles~

UMQnrGZJ4Wn4iQPwpHBM-Q.text: Never been to Japan to eat ramen but have had my fair share of ramen in the SF Bay area.   This was by far the best ramen I've ever had!  Perfectly cooked noodles served in their rich and flavorful stock.      Also tried their fried rice and pork belly rice which were just as good.     This was the only place we dined at twice during our visit to Vegas.   We'll be back next time we are in town.    Tip:   Avoid the long wait by getting there early or late.   Or enjoy boba tea next door while you wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly rice

ksYq3DU9ba2PD2L7CFcTgw.text: I am a True ramen foodie: lived in Japan for 16 years. The ramen at Monta is the same quality as the instant cup ramen I buy in Japan. The chashu is tender, but too fatty and the noodles are not of restaurant quality.  The last time I was here, I found a sign on the door asking customers to close the door behind them quickly for their AC system was not keeping up. On a hot 106 degree day in Vegas, the last thing I want to do is eat hot ramen in a hot restaurant. The place was definitely a little too warm. Beware!

i_eloaW5_Kh-YmDgxPNkGw.text: Stopped here as the midpoint of a road trip. Fast service and yummy broth. It's a small and popular place so try to hit it at non-peak times and you'll be happy.

1uIHJ44ZRA7JV_yKFuv2ag.text: Monta WOW!  I've read a ton of reviews about Monta Ramen, and have been wanting to try it for ages.   *confession* I've never had anything but instant ramen before.   We had to wait for about 30-40 minutes for a table...the place is tiny, and packed full of people happily enjoying the ramen and other deliciousness.  We had the shoyu (chicken broth with thick wavy noodles), tonkotsu shoyu (pork and chicken broth with thin noodles), and the kuro (pork broth with a garlic oil).    All three were good, although I think I like the shoyu better.  Mine (tonkotsu shoyo) was great at first, but the more I ate, the saltier it tasted.  Being on a limited sodium plan, it was a little much for me, but it was still delicious.  The kuro was good, but it was better with the thicker noodles.   Service was quick and polite.   I really enjoyed my first ramen bar, and look forward to going back again.

2oCth1oV7A1G_z6zNQJJJQ.text: The go to ramen shop in vegas. But the broth is very thick and salty so if you like that you wouldnt complain one bit. The service is good and quick. I go here with my boyfriend everytime we go to vegas. The other dishes are good as well. I have never been disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

4Wc6WskP5MtDeaEZriaYNQ.text: AMAZING RAMEN? IN VEGAS?  DID ELVIS KNOW ABOUT THIS!!????  We walked out of the Kung Fu Tea boba place next door and already a good line of hungry go-getters. I mean..if you're looking for delicious Asian food in the Chinatown area....get the Ramen.  So the advantage about being in this line was getting to order first when they opened. Everything good to go! Fresh Fresh!  It did not disappoint.   [Food] Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen. Hit the spot so good.The menu is actually really simple and has 2 main pages.   [Location] Ramen house. Bar side and few tables. Slightly tight inside but that's what I like. More authentic. I can see it getting packed in the heavier hours.  This is like Shinsingumi good. The broth is so rich....and the pork melted in my mouth! The egg noodles were firm and plump. Need to get more extras in your bowl!  YOU CAN BE A BALLER AT THE VEGAS BUFFETS BUT THIS RAMEN PLACE IS THE GAME-CHANGER TO GOOD MUST EAT ASIAN FOODS TO EAT IN SIN CITY.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen. Cleared the sinuses folks! Broth is outstanding!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside (bar area)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 2 of 2

OKeFmpcqThEbqutb2Eskqg.text: Amazing ramen! Can't get enough of it! Wish there was one in Henderson so I didn't have to drive!

SSZwVZ9ISDsh78AJaGwXIg.text: Great place in Vegas if you are craving ramen. I went here by myself when I was working out there and ordered the shoyu ramen. Never disappoints. It's a small place though, so the wait for big groups can be a little long. Also, if you come here at night around 9pm, parking gets really packed so I suggest to come 30mins early to scout out for parking. Nonetheless, it's a great spot to go to.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with a side of corn

IeomsWH9ceVVi_H_DBCC2Q.text: Food tastes good. Best ramen ever. Soup tastes so good, maybe lots of MSG, but definitely recommend because of the texture of the ramen. I would say unbeatable.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

XREmqJY3u7paybFSaydh8A.text: Had heard great things about Monta. I have to tell you, I felt it was below average. The broth was not that great, and we ordered two side bowls with pork and rice, one with pork belly and rice. The rice was inedible. I worked at a sushi bar for over four years so I know that sometimes the rice isn't cooked properly or something, but this rice was old! I'll be sticking to Sora Ramen from now on!

uoBAk_kG6supdODTI3zhLw.text: Came here on a friend's recommendation while I was in the Vegas area. It's off the strip which is where most of the better restaurants are. The ramen was better than expected, probably a combination of Monta's creamy broth and the fact that we hadn't eaten all day. I've tried other ramen restaurants in Vegas and I don't think I've eaten at a bad one. I don't know if this is better than any of the other ones I tried in Vegas but it sure beats the ones where I'm from.

8csr-_QQTDGcwJiMbgDAGA.text: We order regular pork belly bowl and tonkotsu ramen for supper...  The pork belly bowl is a bit too salty for me... however it does have great flavors and tender pork belly.  As for the tonkotsu ramen, the noodle was cooked accordingly. The rich broth is complementing the tender pork in the noodle. The taste of bamboo shoot was a bit too strong for me and it does not served with eggs which was diaappointing...  Anyway, it is a decent japanese restaurant...

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen... rich broth and good texture of noodle...
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl... a bit too salty for me but got a great mix of flavor

cZTG6kbwfbHSfDG5i-5SPA.text: On a super hot summer day in July, my nephew decided to eat ramen.  Its like over 100 degrees and he wanted soup? Eh? Oh well.. why not? We are in Vegas after all. So we hopped in an Uber ride from the strip, about 15 minutes away. When we got there, I guess we weren't the only ones that wanted ramen in 100 degree heat. There was a 15 minute wait in a small restaurant with AC. (OMG THANK YOU)  The menu itself isn't all that fancy. There's only a small selection of different types of food. My nephew and I both ordered ramen and shared a kimchi fried rice. The ramen was pretty good and it had a very clean and flavorful broth. We slurped away at it and just took bites at the kimchi fried rice. The fried rice was amazing and if I had the choice, I would probably just go back for that instead of the ramen.   Service was pretty good considering there were two servers working about 8-10 tables and a handful of bar seats. The prices are very reasonable, and happy to have spent that instead of paying an outrageous amount somewhere on the strip.   I guess for Vegas it's not that bad. I've definitely had better ramen in San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Seattle. Was it worth the trip from the strip? Sure why not.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

vunXIxuJGcnHNj1FeXbYZg.text: Well, korean ramen is one of the most popular noodle soup. But this report is about Japanese noodles, so for our vacation, we went to the noodle house. The line was long and it was "The blah-blah place".Their service was letting you go into the house, put your name and how many people are you going to eat with(including you), where you're going to sit and wait outside. But when I looked inside, the restraunt was really small. So there are two improvements so far: space; the line should be indoors.        The line now wasn't long, but still took a long time. I was groaning and couldn't urge to say a thing. When about 40 min later. My mom heard our names and we burst into the seating area and sat on our seats before the waiter made a sound. We got water, but the table was a bit unstable and spilled some of my water, I tried to clean it up. However, it spilled again and it was bigger this time. So I repeated my work. The waiter soon came back to us and got our order. While we waited, I investigate. There was a bar near us, and there was only one plant. The wall had decorations for Christmas. The only "upside" was music, but not asian music.       As quick as a bunny we got our meals. The Japanese ramen looks exactly like the Korean ones if you turn the soup into red. The soup tastes good. I ordered the Tonkotsu, so the meat obviously is the gift from God. The problem is, the noodles should be slick because the noodles were too chewy. We also got dumplings, which was a celebrity of nutrition(too many idioms!!!). I wasn't too pleased but it was worth it. We ate for 5 to 10 min and we walked off, thinking which restraunt to go next...

NW92087RS9x7xyelcRc5ow.text: This business is at a very busy center. The parking lot is always full and I usually end up parking on the side street. When going here, expect a little bit of a wait time because it's always packed which I understand and am okay with. However, I really dislike that it's way too crowded inside and there's not much space to move around. I hate that you're not even an arm's reach away from the next table.  What they lack in space though they make up for with food. I really like the base of their tonkasu ramen; it's not bland and it's not too salty, just the right amount for my taste. I also like getting their friend rice here as it taste very fresh, filling but not too heavy. Service is alright here, nothing too remarkable.  As far as ramen is concerned, I definitely recommend this place as one of my top 2.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

fAUinIVDul3KZcR7erZx9w.text: One of the best ramen places out here in vegas! Their ramen is to die for! Super delicious and reasonably priced. The food gets to you super quick as well. And the employees always make it a great experience. Very attentive and nice. I only wish this place was a tad bigger because there always seems to be a 20-30 minute wait, sometimes more! Definitely do recommend but come early!

Y2MxH16W72SQZE24sUwHUA.text: Best ramen I've ever had up until this point (by no means am I an expert but I've had Benten, Shin Sen Gumi, and Tatsu). Their broth is so flavorful and is the best recovery food after a weekend of partying. The tradition is eating this Sunday before heading back to reality lol.   I have always gotten their to spicy tonkotsu. I recommend getting additional shredded green onion and soft boiled egg. I've tasted my friends' broths and they're all really good too: spicy miso (can't go wrong, not heavy), black garlic (very garlicky! But so delicious. It's more rich than the other soups, just a warning), shoyu (simple yet fulfilling).  The last time we went (3 days ago) we ordered the pork bowl, and it was pretty bomb.    Just a warning as far as the actual space. It is small. There are only about 4 4-person tables (which of course they can split for a 2-person table if needed) and their counter. Sooo with that being said, sometimes they do have a line out the door and wait can vary. The last few times I have been, we've gotten 30 mins prior to opening and were seated right away. This is not a place you will enjoy waiting for if you're extremely hungry (unless you know the end result which is of course is DELICIOUSNESS IN A BOWL THAT IS ACTUALLY WAITING FOR YOU SO JUST KNOW THAT THE WAIT IS WORTH EVERY SECOND)  Special shout out to Kung Fu Tea next door. Go there after of you're craving something sweet!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. From top left, clockwise: shoyu, black garlic, spicy tonkotsu x 3. Middle is the pork bowl

9MW087RvLaX7yoqKFDLLaw.text: This is my favorite place to eat at! I love the ramen here. Super affordable for great quality food. If I could I would come here everyday. There might be a little wait when you go but it's super worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

k-5frfw_jtmiCx2DQ_fZ2Q.text: We tried Monta for the first time today.  We ordered take out, so we'll of course have to try it in house because I'm sure it will be better.   We ordered: tonkotsu + egg and corn Miso + egg and extra Chashu  Small pork belly bowl (based on yelp raves)  Everything was delicious and the restaurant didn't disappoint. The pork belly bowl was a hit and was polished off very quickly.  It comes with some kind of pickled vegetable that was a hit. Both broths were thick and flavorful. Not salty. The pork chashu was tender and tasty.  Our only issue was that the broth was in a separate container from the other ingredients, and it wasn't labeled. So we weren't exactly sure which broth was which.   Can't want to try this restaurant in house

EroFNbPeCaBt4UEUiEp0Qw.text: This is the go to place for Ramen! When you see lines of people waiting, it's a sign. There's others in LV but this place is the best! Very friendly crew and make sure your party is all present or they'll let you know, you know what I'm talking about.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

m_EoWztPiAgoJLSaCWKQmA.text: The wait on a Saturday morning was pretty insane. We ended up getting some tea next door and grabbing the food to go. The overall quality of the ramen is decent, though I find the shoyu ramen to be a bit on the saltier side. The extra toppings can be a bit expensive. The gyoza was okay.   The price is a bit more than what I expected of the quality. It may be attributed to the fact that we ate out of plastic containers. Compartively speaking, there are probably other food options that are just as good without the wait.

9-tLINw_1sCa81cZbeYXUg.text: 10 stars for ramen, best I've ever had! 1 Star for location/inside.  Why are ramen places always so small?? If you're good, you're gunna be busy!  Wait was 30 mins for 2 so we sat at the bar. Next to boxes and random bottles of who knows.

DZcCzKGNIB0cJFyNcxUVSg.text: I'm giving three because I need to visit another few Ramen stops before I say it's the tops.  It's a bit small, but the service is quick once seated and the food is AMAZING!  I had the spicy bowl with egg and Kimchi fried rice.  I will say..... I've been thinking about having some more noodles EVER SINCE. Not only are they delicious, but they are CHEAP! We only spent $27 on our bill.  Very impressed.   ** edit: I've now added a star because they really are the best ramen & price point in town.

Lq35CoebUOyNwHvyypzNWg.text: Very cozy, great service, excellent ramen and gyoza! Loved watching the chefs in action.

5E-jeI8eIWPQpS2bJ5jCVw.text: The staff is very quick and accommodating. I was able to get seated right away and order my food.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

KlAEt3eDL9_nNuF7w46Bpg.text: Thank the lord for Monta!! Since I gave up red meat, I also had to give up Ramen Sora. It was a sad transition because ramen is my favorite noodle dish ever. Luckily, I learned that Monta offered chicken broth (hallelujah!!), when the broth is usually pork based. Nice and salty- just the way I like it. I always ask for thick noodles and it's delicious and affordable. My boyfriend enjoys the charsiu (although insists that Sora's meat is better).  This is my go-to suggestion when someone is wanting ramen.  The unfortunate thing about Monta is that there's always a bit of a wait because there is a line. This is especially True when it is dinner time!  But you know it's good when there's a line. Inside is tightly packed and crowded. You eat and go. And parking may be a bit tricky since this whole shopping area is busy with awesome restaurants. Park across the street near to the church.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen is chicken-broth! :-)

bM6nSneZNYwAJ_biuRmw8g.text: This was our first stop after getting back to Vegas from a road trip through Arizona. I wish I had discovered all the restaurants in Vegas's Chinatown because I would have started coming here long ago when I first started partying in Vegas rather than spending exorbitant amounts to eat on the Strip.  Monta is a pretty decently sized restaurant, and while there was a waitlist when we arrived, we only had to wait about 5-10 minutes before being seated.  My friend and I were really hungry so we ordered gyoza and a small pork belly bowl to share. We also each ordered a bowl of ramen. All the food was really delicious, and you definitely can't beat the prices. I can't wait to come back to Vegas so I can eat here again!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UAn_8d8O7ZrzThmFiZgRXQ.text: We were on a vegas trip and on a whim decided to go off the strip. We chose Monta because we are huge ramen fans.  We tried the Tonkotsu Ramen and the Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil. It was the most flavorful ramen we have ever had and at about half the price.   Highly recommended!

SP7uw_Ht4hjODdMJSqqG7g.text: Bleh. How's this place one of the highest and most rated ramen spots? Ramen is mediocre- noodles feel like they've been sitting, broth has no depth and is just salty, and the pork smells too much to have been cooked for hours and of any quality. Pass!

ldDQDHhQ1hgKze8udZn1Pw.text: Best ramen place in all of Vegas.  OPEN late!  Let us order for you:  Get the pork belly and also the spicy tonkotsu ramen.   You will not be disappointed.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl - $5.75 - A must have!

QX4XP_outNfFpX3LcC1Mtg.text: I started coming here in 2009 or 2010, whenever they opened. I've never ever had a bad meal and I'm here about 25 times a year. I only go alone or with friends and after almost 10 years, they are always consistent. I suggest trying everything, lately I've been hooked on the pork belly /chasu bowl. Tonkatsu- the best in the country, Iv e stopped trying ramen at other places because there's no comparison.  I away find solace here, it makes bad days go away. I just wish they had bourbon.

3Rf_SvYHDWBSxdZP4Lzkwg.text: THE BEST RAMEN IN VEGAS!  As someone who's lived in Vegas for over 17 years, I've frequented many different ramen shops. Monta is by far the best. Super simple, super modern, fast, delicious, exquisite.   I've been visiting Monta for years now, and it's still just as good as ever. The broth that Monta concocts has such a deep, tremendous flavor, and this is really where they shine. Monta features Tonkatsu (pork), Shoyu (soy), Tonkatsu Shoyu, and Miso, but they also have specialty ramen like garlic Kuro ramen, as well as spicy Tonkatsu ramen. It's cheap and delicious. You can also load your ramen with toppings ranging from kimchi to corn for an up-charge. I personally prefer to add extra Kikurage (mushroom) to my Ramen. And it's only $1.50 for extra noodles!  If you're looking for more than just ramen, I'd highly recommend the fried rice and the gyoza. The fried rice is out of this world, and the gyoza are extremely addicting and some of the best I've had. It's not uncommon for my friends and I to order several servings of the gyoza in a single sitting.   With the Spring Mountain location being in the heart of Chinatown and not too far from The Strip, the peak hours can manifest massive wait times. Monta has a tiny footprint, only seating about 30 people at a time, so keep that in mind if you're planning on visiting on a Friday or Saturday evening. However, you can usually always get a seat of you visit during off-peak hours; afternoons in the middle of the week are usually best.   Overall, I'll be visiting Monta and slurping their delicious noodles until I die from ramen overload. This is some good f***ing ramen, and once you go Monta, you'll ALWAYS go back.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen w/ extra kikurage!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu!

n90o5CLJxRpHb9OBnB_RIA.text: So I was nursing a Las Vegas hangover (you know, still drunk at 9 am kinda hangover) by lying in fetal position in the back of the car, clutching a gigantic bottle of powerade, and damning myself for my excessive behavior (hey, only in Vegas!) My cousin said she that she had the perfect hang over cure. "Jamba Juice?" I groaned painfully. "No, we're going to Monta." The thought of food made my stomach churn. We walked in and were seated at one of the bigger tables. I made it a point to sit next to the wall so I can rest my head. I asked for a hot tea, and alas they serve no hot drinks. Sorry, one star off for that one. I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen. Even just the smell of the broth was oh so soothing - I felt my headache fade away with every slurp of the soup and ramen. From my understanding, they put great care into their broth by letting it boil down for hours. It is creamy, salty, and hot. Essentially, a perfect cap to a crazy night. The noodles were quite delicious too - it was slightly crispy and went very well with the soup. Tonkatsu comes with two pork pieces. You can order extra sides to put in your ramen (I felt like corn that day), but they do charge you. I also had a side order of fried rice, which I thought was very salty. It is good, but it needs something to offset the saltiness. The service was also prompt, and our server was quite cheery and polite.  The boys at our table kept mentioning how cute she was too.

NVdHLhrmenJl2vWuSX6rdQ.text: Outstanding food ! The fried rice was particularly amazing -- better than any typical "Chinese restaurant" fried rice. Outstanding flavor. I loved my shoyu ramen - very flavorful and not as salty as I feared. I spiced it up a bit with the spices on the table. Dining companions tried the gyoza (dumplings) and enjoyed them. Reasonable prices and excellent, speedy service. Small place with very few tables and counter service so arrive early or late,as you will probably have to wait otherwise.  I dined with two big eaters and they were full at the end of the meal, sharing a fried rice a gyoza and each having their own ramen. (Note that the regular-sized fried rice was not as big as expected, but not to be missed)  WARNING: Not many , if any, healthy options on the menu that I saw - so save some calorie real estate for a great dining experience at the casual Monta - well worth it!  I skipped the gyoza, had just a bite of the rice and gave one of my dining companions some of my noodles and still -- I was content!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gets busy! We were there early and had to wait a bit for a table, so suggest going at odd times
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tried the shoyu ramen. Gave away the pork; loved the mushrooms, broth, noodles
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Didn&#39;t try them but fellow diners said they were great

M79kc0pinn13c5um-DM_VA.text: My friend said this was like stepping into a noodle shop in Tokyo--so it turned out to be an adventure for us.  We got there around 10pm on a Friday night and the parking lot was jam packed, with some crazy drivers circling round and round for a space.  Friend got in sooner than I did and found two seats at the counter, but she was hassled a bit by the server she called the soup Nazi, who demanded to know how much longer before I showed up.  (I was parking for goodness sake.)  People were starting to line up outside the door, it's such a tiny place.  We both ordered to tonkatsu ramen, mine with butter and corn, which added to the rich broth.  I keep forgetting to tell them to hold the bamboo shoots.  The chashu was tasty, but just a bit on the chewy side and it's worthy of a youtube video to see me try to separate it with my hashi or do the bite and yank technique while slurping the noodles and broth.  Fun experience pretending we were in a Japan noodle house. We'll go back to try a different broth and see if the chashu is more tender earlier in the day.

nfBplQuFjlIyYVujovjpOw.text: Ordered the MisoShoyu ramen which was pretty good but pretty salty.  Flavor is good and meat is fatty.  Noodles aren't as "bouncy" as daikokuya or santouka but for $7 in vegas a few minutes from the strip...non c'e male!

51y3ILKSoRRElZKSEZIhzQ.text: five stars for their...        uMami   enjOyable distiNctive hearTy       sAvory  Noodles and both, ahh just gotta love this place. Its Japanese soul food!

NbeHjUqICQs3ZjQ0Q4ehDA.text: Tiny restaurant, but the food is really good!  Prices are affordable too.  I went with my BFF last night close to closing time.  She ordered the tonkatsu ramen and I ordered the chashu bowl.  The chashu bowl comes topped with nori, and the next day when I ordered takeout I definitely asked for it to be left off.  BUT the chashu is almost perfect - melty and tender on your tongue with the sweet soy-laced warm rice.  The only places I've had better chashu was in Japan and at a specific restaurant in the Bay Area, CA.  I tried the ramen, and it's good though too salty for my tastes.  The chashu bowl was worth driving out for though, and the next time we are in Vegas we will definitely stop by.

UAcB5_TLSbuDWx6qRnR-aA.text: Authentic ramen. Soup is good too. Meat and toppings are so so. My favorite dish at Monta is actually their Takana Fried Rice!! It's pretty unique. A bit spicy but not too spicy. I'd not drive out of the strip to come here unless I'm really craving for ramen... they usually have a wait.

Ccdxchd4yd5m-e4jUIf74Q.text: This is one of My Favorite Restaurants.  It is always a good place to have lunch.  There Fried Rice is Probably the best I have ever had.  All of the Ramen is Flavorful and has a ton of stuff to add to them.  Pink pickled ginger is amazing and makes all the food taste better.  One Bad thing its small so don't mind waiting

ZzjuLdewu99JSOrJrC6ZQw.text: Best ramen ever!!! I love it! No other comment or review needed lol they are good at what they do^^

dSZcK_gmtuCikC4zdxuncQ.text: This place is awesome. Super Japanese style. This place gets packed real fast but you know what it's worth the wait. I love the tonkotsu ramen with the nitamago and i add the grated garlic. Sooo good. The soup is thicker than the other ramens they have there. I had a thicker soup before @ tenkaippin in Oahu. But the tonkotsu is nice and salty, noodles are thin which I wish was a little bit fatter. I guess I like soggy noodles? But anyway they have toppings like chashu, green onion, bamboo, etc that's automatically on there. Omg chashu melts in your mouth! I always add the nitamago and sometimes corn. I've never had nitamago til I came to this place and I have to say that I love it!! I just love that first bite in to the noodles and then chashu and then nitamago. oh and their fried rice is awesome too! Service is fast and they are all so nice. I would actually rate this place 4.5

hVyrMfjJkaBMyO-hz1gO-Q.text: a very good place for japanese ramen noodles. this place can get busy as it is popular as well. prices are reasonable for the quantity and quality of the food. i would go back to this place.

9N_foClC3TC0Tn-gtXg9bQ.text: Just came back from here and I'm satisfied. We've ordered Tonkotsu Ramen, Mentaiko-Don, Cold Noodle (Hiyashi Chuka), Dumplings and Fried Rice. Place was so small, constantly packed and it's seems to be in-n-out kinda place. Definitely not the best place to relax and have a long conversation with friends over the meal. You eat, you get out. Service was ok. Nothing exceptional, but not rude either. Portion is kinda small but I usually eat noodles with something else anyways, so it worked out just fine. I really liked fried rice there... more than noodles. Noodles was great, not the best I've ever had, but I was certainly happy.

AZCQB45q3782PMf-OAxG8g.text: Although, the ramen shop at Mitsuwa in New Jersey is still my favorite, the Miso Ramen with the Roasted Pork comes pretty close.  I love the setting of the place and the open kitchen set-up.  It really makes the entire experience very authentic. The place was packed on a Friday afternoon, there isn't any space to wait inside (good thing its Vegas).  The service was very fast and friendly.

BRmbI7misgJW7PRUMeNMDA.text: Im in love! Tonkatsu ramen mmmmm and pork belly bowl! I'm sad when there's a wait!

STEDKG8LEjCfvHi9ns9B1Q.text: perhaps my expectations were too high.  i had the black garlic ramen. was not impressed. soup too salty. ramen noodles not chewy enough. sorry monta, wanted to love you but was disappointed.

-Jw2mvtIfZEFOToAlK0hhA.text: Wow!  And OMG!  Authentic and delicious! Totally satisfying - very tiny so be prepared to wait! But it's so worth it! And did I mention this one won't cost you a bundle- almost felt guilty it didn't cost a tad more- noodles and beer- less than $12!   Do not miss this place!!!

2zroskP08_yIkJsJZLCC4g.text: This is a tiny place that serves delicious ramen! Parking can be frustrating and waiting for a table can take a while. I especially dislike coming here on certain holidays, because there are so many people.

fNgq3KuJGe_xuqTRVJW0nw.text: Monta is amazing. Not only are the noodles killer but I love the idea of a tiny little restaurant that really only does a handful of items. You won't find desserts or even much for appetizers here. But what they do they do to perfection. Every couple of weeks I NEED my miso ramen fix. I plan on moving next year and I know Monta is one place I will miss.

Zhor2FHVcddZj38QGHi9gw.text: Raku was fully booked so ramen it is.  Good broth.  Tonkotsu much better than the shoyu combination broth.  Skimpy on the toppings.  Noodles are too soft.  Standard gyoza.  No fresh hot tea.

TeXYU59Jwq8xYz40AHGTxQ.text: With the exception of Daikokuya in L.A.,  Monta Noodle House has the best  Ramen I've ever had. It's a small, out of the way place with very friendly staff and great prices for the quality of food. I've added Monta to my mandatory stops whenever I'm in Las Vegas.

k4zBWrBGEL0X58qOR1HjIQ.text: ENVIRONMENT Off the strip in Chinatown. This place is quaint with only about five tables and a bar, which means there's a slight wait.   RAMEN Tonkotsu Shoyu - comes with noodles and basic toppings such as pork chad by, black mushrooms, bamboo shoots and green onions. MAKE IT SPICY.  Not the best ramen I've had. I almost want to say it's bland and this place needs to offer more toppings.

gg7YW31JR2przekzkHXMrw.text: This is the fricken' best ramen place I've ever been to.  I'm basing this statement on 1. Flavor. Incredible. Full. Not salty. Complex and deeelish! 2. Quick service.  3. Real Japanese waitresses.  4. Ice cold Sapporo on tap under $3! 5. You can refill your bowl with more Ramen for s couple of bucks!  I will come back every time I am in Vegas.   The place is a bit out of the way, but definitely worth the trip.   In the same little plaza is Big Wong, another must try for me.  Zen Japanese Curry. Gotta come try.  Kung Fu Tea.  SmowFlake Shavery. Hawsiian Shave Ice.   Look up Yelp Reviews!  All screaming!  Forget the Vegas Strip, THIS is where you eT  No frills, just good food.

erdlS4S8IBY8zG69ITSVAw.text: This place was such a good find. Never had been here before and we just searched up a Ramen place to try (since our favorite ramen joint closed down) and I would have to say that Monta Ramen is probably our new favorite. Their menu is small and simple, which I like because then I don't have to sit there forever trying to decide which one I want to order. I was able to see what they have and decide what I wanted quickly. We ordered the Tonkatu Shoyu and added an egg (extra $1.00-$1.50) and it was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO yummy! We also ordered their fried rice and gyoza. All was delicious.   The only downfall I have is that it is such a small restaurant that many people enjoy going to, so if you're there on a busy night.... most likely there will be a wait for a while and you'll be stuck waiting outside. (No inside seating area, hardly)  It was definitely worth the wait for us though. We enjoyed eating here and will be back again for sure.

jjd4bTnWVuGsfcOdQ-VwbQ.text: There isn't a whole lot left to be said that hasn't already been said.. This ramen joint is located in a little shopping center that is the mecca of fantastic quaint restaurants. Pretty much everything in this plaza is amazing. But Monta is The. Best. Ramen. In. Vegas.  I always get the half tonkatsu half shoyu ramen because I like a little more salt, and think the tonkatsu is just a tad too porky for me. I also get the thicker noodle because I like a little more chew. They offer various additional toppings here including green onion, butter (!), corn, nitamago, pickled mustard greens and the very very necessary extra order of chashu. Not necessary because the regular order comes with a stingy amount.. extra because you will never, ever have enough chashu.  At other ramen places I usually pick around the roasted pork, just not that into the flavor. But here, it melts away in your mouth. It's so tender it's hard to grab with your chopsticks sometimes because it'll just fall apart.  The kim chee fried rice here is solid, but nothing I'd go out of my way for. This version is just.. meh. Good but not great.  Monta is ALWAYS worth the wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Half tonkatsu half miso - just right. With nittamago and kim chee fried rice.

zRKNUrDY1pDwkIW1Vv_rKA.text: My favorite place for good Ramen! There is always a line but people don't mind waiting because the food is really good. Try the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen and the Fried Rice. It's really yummy. The staff is really friendly too. Take out is good too. You have to cook the soup yourself to maintain freshness so they give you everything separate and you would have to cook them together.

t0g7YmiSne18qntqzUuUWw.text: The best ramen in Vegas for fairly cheap price! Their food comes fast and is always super tasty. Not to salty. The only thing is that there's only like 4-5 tables and a bar area so the waiting time can reach an hour before you get seated, not the best if you're already starving! They're usually busy around 6 pm even on weekdays

YB8ZoTsGC_Wft5aeDfIhCw.text: Came here super early thinking  will be a long wait. There wasn't a line at all until probably 5 to 10 mins before they opened. We ordered the ramen, gyoza and pork rice. The pork rice was pretty good and different from the norm. The other two items were just okay.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

5buB9o_IL7KtAlgLjIuVKw.text: Our usual Ramen Sora was closed, so we decided to give their rival down the street a try.  We were there 5 minutes before opening, joined the throng of people waiting to get in, and happily we were able to get seats at the bar immediately.  I couldn't believe it when friends said that this place makes Ramen Sora look huge, but boy were they right!!  I think Monta Ramen seats maybe 35 people total and has a tiny waiting area.  I was very happy with the service!  Waitstaff was friendly, efficient, and checked on us regularly, even with a completely full house.  I loved being able to sit at the bar and watch the food being prepared.  This is one area they have a leg up on Ramen Sora.  I ordered miso ramen with corn, butter, and soft cooked egg and Hubs had tonkotsu ramen with shredded green onion.  At first, I thought my broth was completely lacking in flavor and was so disappointed.  Turns out that all the flavor had settled into the bottom of the bowl.  A good stirring fixed the problem.  Wish I had realized that earlier!  LOL!  Hubs and I both felt that the pork was extremely fatty and the texture was just not good.    I suppose that if I had never had Ramen Sora, this might have been fine.  But I HAVE had it and I will be going back to our usual from now on.  At least I can say that I've now made an informed decision between the two rivals.  :)

hVAeWhNo-4CKFiyZEgijSQ.text: I guess it's good for Vegas!  Thank goodness we didn't have to wait too long for ramen that is just ok!  My husband got the tonkatsu ramen, had no idea it didn't come with an egg (everywhere we eat at they give you an egg) so that's odd.  Then we tried the soup, wayy too salty.  My husband added water, about half a cup to dilute it, tasted so much better.  There really is no service.  We sat down, ordered and paid and that's pretty much it.  Don't expect to much.  We came in with high expectations because of the reviews, but left disappointed and hungry!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

rTWCzgv7EVExAGWH1q6xzA.text: By far the best Ramen place I've had! I ordered the tonkotsu shoyu ramen and the broth was very flavorful (a little salty for me, but a bit of hot water made it perfect), chashu was very tender, and the portion was good as well. Definitely coming back :)

UauqPFP97UC4v_BS1BDXiA.text: We came here on a Friday night at 6 pm, and had to wait for less than five minutes to get a seat. That said, the place is incredibly small, and we had to sit at the bar. There are maybe four tables total (besides the bar).   As far as food goes, the menu is very simple. I had the miso, and my fiance had the tonkatsu. We ate with another friend, an all ordered pretty different toppings, which the waitress all put down in front of the wrong people. Not a big deal, but the server didn't seem to know what she was serving. The ramen was good, but honestly I'd prefer Ramen Tatsu (especially because of the wait time and size of restaurant).

JElnrPPL7HiM-4FT7OLAqQ.text: This year, we've seen influx of new Ramen establishments in Las Vegas. Yet, Monta holds on to the throne. Sure, the long wait can be daunting, but it's for a reason.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small Fried Rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold Noodle.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen. Look! Twins in the egg!

NgEPRWzen9K95vPXJ81DcQ.text: I like to think I'm an average guy with an average guy appetite. My biggest gripe: portions wayyy too small ... with minimum protein. The two thin pork slices were yummy but about 1/3 fat and the size of a "dollar" pancake. Broth was very salty but I like salt. Heads up ... The thicker noodles were perfectly cooked (al dente). Veggies were yummy. Everyone around us was ordering extra-this or extra-that ... underscoring insufficient portion size. Taste was excellent. Tiny, noisy, cramped, long wait, rock music was totally unnecessary.

Rp9SSv2PyY0xvU1ZzqV4QQ.text: Monta, my favorite!  I love coming to Monta when hitting up Vegas.  My friend tells me that this is where the locals go.    Food is amazing.  AND AT CHEAP PRICES!  I usually go with the Tonkotsu Ramen.  Very tasty.  Also try to Kim Chi fried rice!  It's so good and goes great to compliment the ramen.    The last time I visited, I tried the cold noodles.  I forget what the name was on the menu but it was so tasty.  It was packed with flavor when you eat.  It also had that refreshing taste to it.  You leave the restaurant, not sluggish, but having a refreshed feeling, which isn't normal.  Well to me at least! Great restaurant and open pretty late!   Space is small, so try to get there early.  I heard that the wait times can be long if you go during prime times.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kim Chee Fried Rice. -Taken with an Apple iPhone 5
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen. -Taken with an Apple iPhone 5
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold Noodles. -Taken with an Apple iPhone 5

SeTYUQDbn9WTl-GEAAKUhA.text: Ambiance suck balls. Its too small. Just imagine 1 bedroom apartment made into the restaurant. The ambiance ruins this once an average tasting ramen. Its the cup o noodle 3/1$.

yek8g2KAB0NFvorGQ6fDOw.text: This is the Original Monta restaurant. Small, but sooooo good! I had the Tonkotsu Ramen, regular (not spicy) fried rice and Gyoza. Everything was great. Didn't think there would be a crowd for hot ramen with 110 degree days, but the locals love this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen and fried rice.

iu0aMixzyH6IDxc7s2ujGQ.text: Small gem about 10 minutes away from the stripe, this ramen place is amazing! I ordered the spicy shoyu ramen, it came in the different noodle that I've never tried before. The pot sticker was awesome too! But the downside is the small is too small and we felt rush but overall not too bad on the service but the food bested everything thing! The price are extremely cheap too!

Ww8kBRHPulYiMnzkBcBNag.text: I've heard a lot of good things about this place so I had to give it a try! I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with kimchi and the ramen definitely lived up to my expectations. However, I wasn't too crazy about the kimchi. Other than that everything was delicious :)

q8nuNAyyJ-MQhURplfqcfg.text: Everyone needs to be aware that this place is SMALL. I think even using the word small is inaccurate, but tiny. Absolutely no waiting area, so you have to wait inside, the place is crammed, and the parking lot itself isn't that big either. I had their miso ramen, which was yummy, but salty. The pork served in it....to die for! This place would be a lot better if they simply had more space! The good thing is that they are opening a new location next year in Green Valley! Yay.

paLg80k9bTwnP6XVm4CKkw.text: Oh my goodness. I was out here on vacation for a week and came back here twice because it was so good! Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen was my go-to both times.  It was my first time having authentic Ramen and it was delicious.  The pork, abundant in portion just melts in your mouth and the broth - my lord, the broth was creamy and rich and thick and so tasty.  The bowls were the perfect size too! My boyfriend and I joked that this is better than pho, but I put pho in a totally different category ;)   We came here around lunchtime during the weekday and on both occasions, there was about a 10-15 minute wait, but it's worth it guys! It's definitely easier if you're a single diner or just the two of you.  A party of 3 or more -- be prepared to wait.  The place was rather small so I got worried, but the staff are efficient and people are in and out.  We were seated at the counter closest to the kitchen, so it got pretty hot while waiting and eating our ramen, but it wasn't too bad.  For the amount you get and the absolute tastiness of everything -- it was worth every bit of wait and effort especially for being under $10 for a bowl.    I recently came back to DC and decided to try another ramen joint in the city and it didn't even come close.  Boyfriend and I were really disappointed because Monta Ramen has set the bar high for us and I cannot wait to come back to Vegas just for another bowl!   I definitely recommend this place if you're traveling or trying Ramen for the first time.  You will not regret it! The Spicy Tonkotsu wasn't even spicy for those who are hesitant  about the level of spice.  The dumplings were also delicious and fresh.  I miss you, Monta Ramen, and all the over delicious Asian eats in Vegas!

gqTzMlxg_SNXkaG4RaNDlA.text: My favorite ramen joint in Vegas. Go a little before they open because they get busy fast! Because they're just so good!   Broth (I usually get the tonkotsu shoyu $6.95) is not too fatty and it's super flavorful and beautiful.  Sides I usually get: kimchi fried rice and gyoza. Both perfection.   Noodles: amazing !!! Perfect to my preference. Not too soft or hard. Just right.  Ask for extra if you run out but be warned it's a hefty portion lol.   Price: so affordable y'all! Check out the picture of the menu I posted.   Parking: there's a lot !   Favorite Surroundings: Kung Fu Tea (boba spot), Curry Zen (Bomb Japanese curry spot), Hwaro (k bbq), And so much more in this amazing plaza lol

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ILYBMVVfZhnK8bGi8JUc4w.text: Wow, I've been trying new noodle places and this so far is my favorite!!! Most places the noodles are really soft. These are cooked the most perfect way, not too hard ,not to soft. Then you get to choose with broth. As well as the add ins so I didnt get that egg like other places. I dont always like everything in it so to add your favorites is nice. I thought the serivr was perfect.  The only flaw is the bar chairs at the bar were too small. Granted I'm not small but not 300 pound either I felt like I was the were wobbly and would have stayed longer but i felt i was going to crush the stool :-( next time I'll to a table with people

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Trying a new place

x7g-HnLQglX6Hj2xEFNJ-g.text: Vegas gem right here! The place is small but clean. The food is very reasonably priced and ramen came out quick. The food was absolutely delicious. The flavors are just wonderfully amazing. Love this place. I wish the place was a bit bigger to accommodate many customers. They are always busy because they are sooo good. This was the best bowl of ramen that I have had since I was in Japan! The flavor was amazing the noodles were also really well made. Our waitress was very friendly and efficient and we felt constantly taken care of even though it was busy. I would definitely recommend this place if you are looking for great service and amazing ramen! 100% recommend!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

HR6gGOR3oFs_vLlT_0e23g.text: Very nice and cost spot.   We had:  - black garlic ramen - $7.95 (plain with no meat nor egg, so you need to add) - gyoza ($5.95) - pork belly rice bowl (small at $3.49) - Anahi DRAFT FOR ONLY 2.95?!   Super value for money and would highly recommend if you're in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

P6_euzrPnfxrY1TtSFel_Q.text: For the quality and the price, this is my favorite tonkotsu in the entire country. This portion size easily averages $15 per bowl elsewhere. At Monta, it's under $10. I love everything about Monta. It's fast, it's casual, and it's so damn delicious.  I always make it a point to come here when I'm in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Black Garlic Oil Ramen // pork broth, roasted garlic flavor, and thin noodles

hoa5mqVV6tu1Qp5hGSgT0Q.text: Wow ramen for under $7?!? Well $6.95. I'm so down! As a visitor to Vegas I wanted to eat decently, with good value, and not break the bank. By venturing a short distance away from the Las Vegas strip you hit Chinatown; lots of great food and memories of home (LA 626).   I do have to warn you that wait time is over an hour long. People don't mind, they usually hop over to Kung Fu Tea to get their boba fix while waiting. Just know that if your name on the wait list is called and you're not there; they will skip you and move on to the next.  After waiting an hour we decided to change our dine in request to take out. Take out is 15 to 20 minutes. Much faster.  We get our food and head back to the strip to eat. The food was filling and delicious. For your classic ramen of just cha shu, seaweed, broth, and ramen it was a very good deal. FYI, you can order extra noodles if you're super hungry and want to eat more noodles.   Highly recommend checking out the Las Vegas Chinatown area (for good food and grocery shopping). The food here seems less expensive.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yummy take out ramen and gyoza!

o1lHLkO8kOQDiTqYQDGMqg.text: We came here due to high reviews and saw the pricing was decent price. However, I think they could do better. Do not get me wrong; service was good... but the ramen could use some work.   Ordered: Tonkotsu and Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen.  The first bite into the ramen; nothing special and the soup was nothing to rave about. We came, waited (there was a line), seated, ordered and booked out of there. This place was nothing to write home about. The pork chashu was fine- just fine, nothing more.   I have experienced better ramen. Place was cute, service was good. Expect a wait as the place is small.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen $6.95
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The menu as of 12/2018
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The menu as of 12/2018

IBx-eSe-XwdJKruiVdI7jQ.text: Quick recommendations: their fried rice is supah delicious and their eggs for the ramen is PERFECTLY cooked. Ramen is aight, the pork is super soft.  Summary: it's a pretty cute little ramen house. I wasn't rly hungry to begin with but my mom wanted to meet up so I was like aight that's fine. The wait for the ramen is SOOOOOOOOOOOOO short. Like it came out almost instantly. I kinda forgot what ramen I got, but it was good. Oh actually it might've been the miso and something ramen. Anyways, it wasn't too salty which is always good. The noodles were so yummy. They had different size noodles which is pretty epic if I do say so myself. And in conclusion you should definitely come here. It's a little cramped but the more the merrier I guess.

DHHCEdbRmmcusBckdjH6dA.text: This little tiny hole in the wall Ramen shop was LEGIT! My boss and his partner brought me here for lunch one day.   When we walked in, there was a tiny waiting area, a hostess stand to write your name down and about 15-20 seats (including the bar).   The menu was simple but to the point and I liked that, I have never been to a ramen shop before so this was cool. They had four or five different ramens to choose from and then about 10 things that you can add to it. I just did the basic ramen and added scallions to it. My boss also ordered a side of Kim Chi rice.   The food came less than ten minutes later nice and hot and smelling delicious! The rice.......I do not like kim chi but this rice was so flavorful and tasty that I went in for seconds.  My ramen was so good, the complexity of the broth was insane!   Throughout our meal the restaurant stayed busy and with people lining up outside. It is a popular place in China Town and I was finally able to find out why. I have told anyone that I can about my experience with Monta Ramen and can't wait to come back. I highly recommend this restaurant.

xyiTLWkaKPhl0W96jwky1A.text: It was just OK.    We arrived before it opened and there was a line of people out the door.  Luckily, we were able to get seated in the first wave.  I've heard about the horrible wait times and I can see why.  The restaurant is small!  We were seated at the counter by the door and that was the best seat because the AC unit was just above us.  I can't stand eating ramen while sweating.    I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and the broth was lukewarm and extremely salty.  The basic ramen comes with chashu, kikurage, bamboo shoots and green onions.  I added an egg and corn and they do not skimp on the corn.  Holy Moly!  I'm not complaining though!  I also tried the fried rice and that was good.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

c1S_eBJ_t-LGnLWxs61aoA.text: This place is something special, I miss it so much since moving! That miso ramen, gyoza, and fried rice... ugh! It is something out of a dream. The tiny space always had such a great vibe to it and the service is spectacular.

-oEvhd-3sj5kux1cvPZrDw.text: Let me start off by saying that there is nothing inherently wrong with the ramen at Monta but after eating at Ramen Sora and even Jinya, this place didn't really cut it for me.  I got exactly what I get at those two locations just so I could easily compare.  I got the shoyu ramen with extra noodles and the pork belly bowl.  Starting off with the pork belly bowl, this was really the star for me.  The pork was so tender and flavorful!  It was marinated in soy and had chopped pickled ginger on top which only added to the flavor.  I will say that this narrowly beats the chashu bowl and Ramen Sora.  I was a bit disappointed that I couldn't order an extra large bowl of ramen so I settled for an extra side of noodles.  The flavor of the broth was good but seemed to be lacking in flavor and didn't seem to have the same fat content as others I have tried.  Fat = Flavor!  The pork also seemed to be leaner and tougher than I would have liked.  The extra noodles were hard to add as they all stuck together in one mass so I decided to just dump them in but there wasn't extra broth added to compensate for the extra noodles.    Overall this wasn't a waste and I'm glad I tried it.  I now don't have to worry about what I was missing and if there was something better out there than my go to.  The food wasn't bad, it just wasn't great.  Let's just call this a learning experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with extra noodles.

ji1i9s50A4ntCYSw48oGvQ.text: Monta is probably one of the best available ramen places available in Vegas besides Momofuku but the wait is always horrendous.  My last visit my wife and I arrived on a Monday morning 10 minutes before the restaurant opened up and the line was already over the restaurants capacity.  My wife and I were pretty lucky to have only a party of two but for those with 4 or more had no choice but to wait for the 4 available quad seater tables.  The two types of ramen I usually choose between is the spicy miso ramen and the black garlic oil ramen.  Both ramen have a very thick and flavorful broth but my only gripe is that they don't always come out piping hot like it should, and I always feel like there is not enough broth.  The noodles have a good chew to them and the chashu is nice fatty and melts in your mouth delicious.    This is not a place for large parties more than 4, and if you are in a rush I would not even bother.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with corn
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic tonkotsu ramen with spicy sauce and extra corn

81KtOoAMY5Fy19dY73n7Hw.text: I've come here a couple of times. Both experiences have been good. This is supposed to be the best ramen place in my state and I wouldn't doubt it.   Service is speedy, food is flavorful, and the prices can't be beat. On this particular day I had the black garlic oil ramen.  I thought it was good. Nothing to go wild over.  Not sure if that's how it's supposed to taste, but it was like they overcooked the garlic that made it have a strong bitter flavor.  They've been at this location for a long time, which is small often making it have long waits. I did have their fried rice and that was delicious!  I think I may just not be a ramen person because I leave here without really wanting to come back and try more. It is definitely worth trying if you are indeed a ramen fan, however :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Outside. New name
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuru Ramen Black Garlic Oil

0y8xKpuMCF5Md3m8F6gXxw.text: The food is really good, and the prices are very fair. I love coming here   Yhhhhhhffhoigfjiiyfhiydd

IEDlglv1dZ1Nrx-swuUuKw.text: Monta is my staple ramen house and best ramen house in the US. All ramen restaurants I visit in my travels are all based off Monta. I have not found its equal except Monta's second location off Eastern.   For me I base broth, noodles, and overall experience based off either location. My favorite ramen is tonkatsu shoyu ramen. I love the broth and thin style noodles. Aside from the excellent ramen Monta offers great side dishes.   I invite others to find there staple and enjoy ramen restaurant hunting. Yes there will be ups and , "they called that ramen," you will come across in your travels. For me I enjoy it and love to return to Monta each time I'm back in town.

C6M9R5FfXWl7CXf_7brl7w.text: Always a favorite when I'm in the area.  Their ramen is as legit as can be and I've had ramen in Tokyo and Niseko Japan.    Location: Located in the Chinatown area of Las Vegas in a tiny mini mall-like complex.  Parking can be difficult if you come during peak hours as the small complex has a few other restaurants that are also very popular.  The restaurant is on the smaller side.  I think they might fit less than 30 people in the restaurant at any one time so be prepared to wait if you go during peak eating hours.  Also note that this place does NOT have AC so on really hot days in Vegas, it's WARM in the restaurant and eating a hot bowl of ramen on a hot day might not be for everyone.    Staff: The staff is quick but I'm guessing it's because they're trying to get people through their meals as efficiently as possible since there seems to always be a line waiting to be seated. Don't get me wrong, it's not like they rush you; I've never felt rushed when I eat here.   Food:  I love their ramen; I normally order shoyu ramen when I eat ramen.  The broth is rich and flavorful.  The char-siu is tender and also holds a lot of flavor.  I don't know if the noodles are handmade onsite or not; it didn't look like they were and I didn't ask.  The noodles had the perfect texture of chewiness.    Totally worth coming to if you are willing to be patient (especially in the heat of summer).

pDnvTk05RfM7bNCwrVg73g.text: The pork belly bowl is delicious, and the ramen is so good, yes the waiting time is outrageous but its totally worth it, when you take out is faster, but if you are a petient person is worth dinning in.

ybJouSoLz1lD_oBiyWbGwg.text: This tiny ramen joint is located in a busy plaza with limited parking. If you come during lunch or dinner prime times, it can get very challenging to find a parking spot. Wait time can be horrific too.   When you arrive, make sure to write your name on the wait list to get in their queue. Inside had only a few tables and the bar seating area. Not ideal for large groups.   Ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen  -Comes with a few slices of chasu pork in a thick creamy pork broth - The chasu slices were good and the thin ramen noodles was good but not mind blowing because it's NOT freshly made by them there  - This thick broth was too salty for my liking and so I had to ask for some hot water to dilute it   Note: The ramen does not come with any toppings so best to add an egg, corn, and seaweed. But DO NOT order the pickled mustard greens because it's way too salty and a waste of your money.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Wkgf1LCF_08gTJhqKCgukA.text: This place is always packed and busy! That's how you know it's good xD came here for Monday lunch and they were very accommodating to my party of 5 and asked if we wanted to get seated faster by squeezing or waiting for a more comfy table. The food was delicious! The soup for the ramen is super rich and tasty. The fried rice was yummy as well! Will be back whenever I come back to Vegas

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic ramen!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Regular sized Fried Rice

Wps8cZ4pJQW2b5cKsbjwug.text: Went in yesterday for the first time, and it was yummy!  I had fried rice and my boyfriend had the Tonkotsu ramen, we both left very satisfied! Only complaint is that its too small, so you might end up waiting a while for a table! Aside from that its cheap and delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi (almost gone) and Tonkotsu Ramen

NOJa0EccCFHB0OgqIhUmbw.text: Away from the strip but close to our hotel, Palms Place. Definitely worth the wait and nice break from the glitz and find a lot of locals dining.  Small place so be prepared to wait.

LSXwl_h7XT3BMufaxz1qzQ.text: Best Ramen broth and noodles in town! Reasonable prices and they don't charge you for hot sauce like itzy bitzy. Or give you half an egg when you add an egg to your ramen, you get a whole egg how it should be. Takana fried rice is to die for!

nvfKc_eSWm8ttYEGr62gag.text: The ramen here simply put is fantastic, I almost rated this place at 4 stars just because they're always busy because of the small seating space, but you can't blame them for that. The ramen is always filling and for an insanely cheap price, the place shuts any other noodle house down. Staff is usually fast also, never had a problem with my drink being refilled or my server asking if I needed anything.

XnNUEklhMVGvPC0WMBONZQ.text: We spent more time waiting to sit than waiting for our food to come - and that was only about 5 mins max... Even though this place is small, they are efficient and attentive. Food is amazing. We had tonkatsu shoyu ramen with flavored egg, pork belly bowl, and kimchi fried rice. The ramen was very traditional, well-flavored but not overpowering. The pork belly bowl was incredible. The pork is soft and bursting with flavor. Their rice is actually a nice texture, too - sticky without being mushy and not hard in the middle. The kimchi fried rice, while not spicy, had an irresistible taste. It was rich without feeling like too much. When we are in Vegas, we definitely expect to come back.

bQLy4On65t81W0p7MXstgg.text: The cure for a Las Vegas hangover is ramen. And with all the raves and reviews Monta Ramen was worth a visit. Upon arriving, there was already a crowd outside (it opens at 11:30). Luckily, the bar had two open seats for my friend and I.  Thinking with our appetites, we began the order:  2 Tonkotsu Ramen (this is what they're known for) 1 Gyoza (it's gyoza and I was hungover, so give me a break) 1 Kimchi fried rice (once again, we were hungover!)  After taking the last bite and having to unbutton my pants, I looked at my friend and gave him the approving nod, which summed up our experience.

e-k97rNv9gW6Q8HcN7FT7Q.text: we ate here twice in 3 days! the first time we actually came to eat at the snowflake shavery for dessert, but noticed the crowd milling around monta and decided to throw our name on the waiting list. since we had our baby in tow, we weren't exactly expecting to wait it out. however, the woman working at monta was so incredibly nice, she save us a table and made it as comfortable as possible for the baby, even helping us store the stroller in the back! now to be honest we weren't incredibly hungry after the wonderful shavery but we managed to still enjoy my tonkotsu and shoyu ramen with the egg and my wife the black garlic oil flavored kuro ramen. I've definitely had better egg in my time so next time I'd try some other add on.  while the food was good, the service was what stuck in our minds that first night. nicest wait staff ever! we also vowed to take my noodle loving 10 year old nephew and my sister when they rolled into town the next day.    so today we went around lunch time, and longer line so again we hit the snowflake shavery first! while waiting, we saw the flyer that they opened a monta in henderson! we'll definitely try that next. This time the wait was longer and we worked up our post-snow appetites...and score! the nephew and sister loved it! also i tried the takana fried rice this time which I thought was great. Just the right amount of spiciness and with the mustard green, unique from chinese fried rice. my better half had the shoyu ramen this time, which was indeed lighter than the tonkotsu broth. I think I preferred the tonkotsu but it was good to have tried them both.  next stop will definitely be the one near my parents house on eastern. thanks yelp for the recommendation!

9ZnH_vkZBVxZoYTUrog7Iw.text: One of my Vegas staples.  My friend took me here a few years ago, and I've been addicted ever since.  I usually order the Tonkatsu with corn and two eggs.  The broth is savory and the Gyoza is delightfully crispy!  The noodles are cooked to the perfect chewiness.  Monta is extremely small, so do not bring anymore than four people here.  If you're lucky, you'll get a table, but most of the time, you end up sitting at the counter (which is still cool because then you get to watch the chefs cook the noodles).    The food is yummy and the price tag is inexpensive = VALUE GALORE... Oh, and the service is always amazing.  The only catch? - Bring cash, because they don't take credit cards for bills under $10.00.    Go here. Just... Go.  I promise you will not regret it.  Slurrrrrrrrrp!

nyIc0cAOGQLBLisnChlDtA.text: I had the pork & chicken broth & my husband had the miso broth  The noodles were the perfect thickness the char siu was soft, the egg was more of a hard boiled instead of soft boiled. I like when the yolk is runny in the soup  The pork belly bowl is a must have full of flavor! Must get the large size!

7JAh6PjTMKd_UoYNqUoGqg.text: Ohh yelpers you have let me down..  I came here based on the high reviews and left disappointed (I didn't even finish my ramen).  This place is super tiny & was packed!  I came when they opened and there was already a line out the door so I had high expectations.  I had the: - Tonkotsu shoyu ramen (which has both pork and chicken broth). The broth was lacking.  It's salty but isn't rich.  The flavors are subtle compared to other places like Fukumimi, Daikokuya, and Men Oh Tokushima. ..and the egg in the ramen is a side option, so if you don't order it you won't get it.  The noodles were really different too.  They didn't seem like they were made from scratch.  Whatever it is, it's not what you typically have in ramen.  Also, the chaysu is pretty fatty so if you're looking to get some meat or protein in, you're almost forced to order something else.. or something else on the side! - Gyoza.  All 6 pieces were stuck together.  It really just looked like a whole bunch of frozen pieces were thrown in a pot so I wasn't too impressed - but they were YUMMY!    This place may be good, but maybe for things other than their ramen.

PQp_KEf7di-3ZCtb4H-DHA.text: Oh my Lord. This place is amazing. We made the mistake of eating a mid-afternoon meal here the same night we had a reservation at Gordon Ramsay Steak... that was dumb. So filling and very inexpensive. We will DEFINITELY go back next time we are in Vegas!

jIq-zV582hbgQg-w7Zeqhg.text: The ramen is pretty good, soup is pretty salty, but the fried rice is money!  The service is fast and friendly as it has that typical ramen house atmosphere.  I would definitely come back.

QrEPxm8_9txJ7ayKw1wiNw.text: unbelievable ramen. Just plain outrageously good.

Nr-dQxT75RV6NEIovs4BRA.text: I will admit - I am far from ramen noodle expert.  However, I will say that was a damn good bowl of soup!  This is a great place for a quick lunch.  I had the tonkotsu - shoyu with extra meat and an egg.  Also, an order of Goyza.  The pork was so good - it was tender and delish!  The broth was savory.  I would have liked to see more noodles in the soup, but hey...  Lotsa flavor and texture.  The goyza was good too.  It is a small place.  They have 28 seats jammed in there!  They turn some tables here, so don't go there thinking you are going to sit back and relax.    I guess semantically this is a fast food place because you get food fast and you even eat the food fast!  But it is not fast food that you normally think of.  I would say that this is real good fast food.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MD1iPZfuRr5oHc_ZrAJg1g.text: Great bargain! For fantastic Ramen.  Super happy and we will definitely recommend this little place. Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I caught the ramen chef before the next group sat down.

0tMxxa4SwTCy-J0bcutvPg.text: Love this place. I was craving some ramen and decided to yelp a place. I am so glad I did. Not only was the broth yummy, the prices were reasonable.  I got the miso ramen. Full of flavor and they have lots of noodles.  My hubby got the pork belly bowl. He really enjoyed it. The pork flavor was spot on.  We got an order of fried rice, that was ok.   Overall good food, good service. The place is small, but I can look past it because it was so good!

dkoO1chbgJupWWRKW85c9w.text: I don't get the hype or why there are people lining up for this. If this is the best ramen house in Vegas, than that's just sad. My broth was too thick and salty and the portion was small. There are better places out there for a couple bucks more.

fovG-xtXHGOL_OPlZ5J20A.text: I use Yelp often but I've never written a review before. However, I was so disappointed by my last visit at Monta that I feel like there needs to be some sort of review on the service. I have here many times because their food is good...not just good, but craveable. It's also a good value for the price and it never takes long to cook.   But that's not the problem at Monta. The problem is the service or lack of thereof. I visited today, April 28th, 2017 around 1pm. There were two cooks on, two servers, and all seats were filled. Everyone had their food and nothing was being cooked. I put my name on the list. A lady that was waiting before me kept looking around. After a few minutes she left, looking distraught. No one greeted us. I tried several times to catch the attention of the younger waitress but she kept looking away. I sat down. Stood up. Tried speaking to her when she was three inches away from me and refilling waters. She ignored me. I understand if this place is busy that she might not have the time, but she did. The cooks were cooking a thing. Everyone was eating. Not even a hello. All I wanted to do was order food to go. Finally I literally stared here straight across the room and said "excuse me." She came over with reluctance like I was going to ask her why I couldn't have a seat sooner. When I said I wanted to order to-do she immediately took my order. I was out of there in less than 5 minutes from this point.  Just remember, people come for the food but return for service.   On one of my last visits I witnessed another young waitress scream at a patron who had ordered over the phone. She confirmed her order with him but he said he ordered something different. He did seem very confused but she basically humiliated him in front of the whole restaurant. She changed his order for him but said that the price would not change. I understand that this is frustrating as someone who works both a job in customer service and a second job in the restaurant industry. But this is no way to handle a simply fixable mistake.  I am simply giving feedback as a customer on my experience. This place with continue to be successful because of it's delicious food. As for me, I will look elsewhere for my ramen. I will stop recommending this place to my friends. Las Vegas has countless restaurants, why should I go somewhere where I feel unwelcomed and hassled? To me, that is not worth one very good bowl of noodles.

nQ6gQjrIMbbTkjmju2daSg.text: It's worth the wait.. gotta try it out.. the tonkotsu ramen was just cooked right! The soup base is good..We also ordered the fried rice and gyoza.. with an ice cold green tea..will come back again!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Worth the wait...

OBCrampqUMxPNOzxMnaaZQ.text: i go here like twice a week with my sisters.. the only comment i wanna give is the place is too small. but in terms of food and service their actually good..

fqlyAJzxs9S0NsFhsEIiQw.text: Good flavor but needed add-ons. I guess that's why it's cheaper than the usual ramen places... the additional items adds to the cost.
