BPyhkXZVSvbspSXFb4Y6rA.text: I came here when we visit Las Vegas. This was 3rd time. First time I came here a few years ago, I thought this place serves best ramen! But this time, I didn't feel same way.. maybe they changed the recipe?? Not sure. We waited for one hour and exhausted. Is that the reason I didn't feel the same? Anyway, it's delicious but not special.

db1QeVQwu0XNmp84jctXDA.text: BEST. RAMEN. EVER. Seriously. Don't waste your time with any other Ramen place in town. Prices are amazing and you will crave this ramen for the rest of your life.

4JT_7GZ4iEYwVb6p-oMMAw.text: My bill was scrambled when I requested it be split. They split the payment just fine but charged my card twice and not my friends! Not cool!  The food was good and iI enjoyed watching the ramen be made. The service was pleasant as well. I like this place although I did not like having my money played around with.

-hk_AwhbjAjbYUAf9krvKQ.text: Service: excellent service, the staff always keep coming and ask if you need anything. They give you hot water in the cold weather even you don't ask for it. Last time I think the manager, she brought out 2 cup of hot tea in the Togo cup for us. I really appreciate this spirit :) Food: real Japanese ramen. I have been tried many places and the thing for you to recognize thats if they make a real ramen  just notice the egg. They have their special recipe to make the unique egg for the ramen. I always order extra eggs when I eat ramen, the soup of the ramen is ok compare to different places in this area ( Frisco ) this one should be recommend for this weather.

ZT-qc_C1CwKsFjtmCXmgaA.text: Visiting from CA and my cousin brought us to try their Ramen. I was the first to finish. That's how good it was. We're definitely coming back here when we visit again. My only complaint was the space of the restaurant, but it's worth the wait.

aJOHfDioFgUKMDdFPThQNg.text: This is probably my favorite ramen place in town. They specialise in tonkotsu ramen, but I personally prefer the slightly lighter, better balanced shoyu/tonkotsu mix. The noodles have a good bite, the chashu - flavorful without taking away from the broth, and the spice (I ask for it spicy) just adds to the whole experience.   The gyoza is pretty ok too!

OkBt97RauSuZ4HB-OggDRQ.text: Went there on the 4th to stop and have lunch before heading home... One of my favorite ramen place to come.  We come here everytime we visit Vegas.. Only to find out its closed no sign or nothing.. Very upset that I wasted my time driving here out of my way.

y13mRXQn8GfumwnBvc6clA.text: Super rich broth, very similar to ramen in J-town in LA.  Love that there's options of thin and medium thick noodles.  Definitely get a spicy one!  Also got the mustard fried rice - great concept, great flavor.  Place is small, so unless you go on off-hours, there will be a wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

CnRE_FXjYZvkO_HeOPFwcQ.text: My go to place for ramen in Las Vegas. Try the spicy Tonkatsu ramen. It has the right amount of richness and spiciness in the broth.  It's not just the ramen that is great. The kimchi fried rice is the best that I've had. Another favorite is the pork belly rice bowl. The pork belly is so tender, it melts in the mouth. The line seems long at times, but it goes fast. So don't get discouraged with the long lines.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Rice Bowl

fR2Jfex9iFMMJEG-JZVoNg.text: Absolutely loved the miso soup. Quite a wait but staff works very efficiently to get people in and out

jzvvUXTMdw-jnGDFwSPD2w.text: Been coming here for years ... but man the wait now. Therefore I'm encouraging counter-Ramenism.  They use pork in their Ramen ... They rush you and even serve cold noodles ... They make you remove your shoes at the door and go barefoot ... They serve imported Japanese beer from Canada ... They add so much flavor your tastebuds will shut down ... They add noodles to their soup to fill the bowl ... They make you put your name on a list ... then make you wait! They make you sit at a table with people you don't know ... They refuse to park your car ... And my favorite, their Tonkotsu broth is so thick & creamy you can't even drink it ...  10 reasons I hope not to see your there ...

blWpOayN1gAWfM9q0heYvw.text: Monta never fails!   Seating is limited but I've never had to wait longer than 20 minutes to be seated. You do have to write your name down on the wait list so just make sure you do that otherwise the hostess will never know you're there!   Miso ramen is my go to with corn as an extra topping. It adds a nice little crunch and sweetness to the savory broth.

PSEuQyLzEhXtSDU3Wnc6eQ.text: Despite the long waiting time since the place is relatively small, the tonkotsu ramen is great. The broth is better than any I've had before and the add on egg was made well too. Only two slices of cha shu though. But that's expected for the price as it's quite cheap!

ZLCfGnF7c7qFHSczX3LWfg.text: Came here right when they opened at 11:30am and the place was already PACKED. Our group of four grabbed the last available seats out of the 27 total they have.  We ordered a side of kimchi ($1!), kimchi fried rice (5/5), gyozas (3/5), Pork Belly Bowl (2/5), and Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen (3/5). The best thing here is the kimchi fried rice and if you like either kimchi or rice or both, you should definitely get this plate! It's flavorful without being overbearing and it adds a nice variety if you're ordering ramen.  The Pork Belly Bowl was sooo sooo bland. It looks much better than it tasted, and throughout eating my bowl, I kept having to add spice and soy sauce. The chef kept looking at me do so and I felt a bit guilty since I'd think it's pretty offensive that I'm altering his dish as much as I did, but I HAD to.   The ramen was mediocre and didn't meet its hype. We paid an extra $1 for spicy paste, but still felt like it was lacking. We do live in Los Angeles where there are many fine ramen establishments, so it gave this place a disadvantage as we were comparing what we had had in LA to what was available here the whole time.  Thankfully we didn't have to wait or else I would've docked another star off this review.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chefs making fresh noodles
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kim chi fried rice

LoYBIXad6im2I8EjfLsshA.text: We came here for lunch on Sunday and there was a 15 minute wait.   The restaurant is pretty dinky.  Service is really fast and efficient.   Kuro ramen (black garlic oil)- pork based broth that comes with chasu, bamboo, black mushrooms, and scallions.  I added an egg for $1.50.  The broth was good but the flavor isn't as rich as other ramen places.  I wasn't a fan of the straight ramen noodles.    Spicy Tonkotsu- the hubs got this and he said it was "pretty good".  Pork based broth and they give you a spoonful of some spicy paste on top of the ramen.  Relatively inexpensive meal but I didn't think the ramen was spectacular.  I'm probably spoiled by all the great ramen spots in LA!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic oil ramen

dU0WvoEGig_bGWCdheHlZA.text: On the recommendation of two of my daughter's customers, we tried this little hole in the wall in Las Vegas Chinatown.  No money was spent on decor.  There is a counter, giving the appearance of previously being a sushi bar along with a small amount of tables.  It was cramped.  By Hawaii standards, the food was cheap.  The tonkotsu soup was slightly oily and not as hearty or tasty as Tenkaippin kotteri ramen (#1 on my list).  Still, it is very good and I'm glad we stopped in.  I also had the mentaiko side dish, very good and very cheap.  Go check it out next time you're on the ninth island!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mentaiko bowl side dish

pdbt6RBRVsBtzOir8CsCSg.text: First ramen place I have ever been to and (biased, but still) my favorite! The prices are so reasonable and I feel like they cannot be beat. I'm obsessed with their miso ramen. Pro Tip: It is rather small. Be prepared to wait, but it doesn't even matter because once you've ordered, I swear your food is out in like...3 minutes. Go here.

g-OB1UdBqRZl1avjuslCEw.text: Love this ramen shop. It is small and theres always a wait list, but they get food out quickly and it is to Die for. Love the takana fried rice and the black seasame ramen. We always make sure to stop here when in Vegas

qRrQD5tVM1sHdydG99a9Iw.text: I lived in LA for 20 years and the best ramen I have ever had was here, in Vegas. What happens in Vegas stays in Vegas but ramen is a different story. Went with the pork broth and garlic. Rich as expected but the garlic took it to just a whole other level. Great ratio of noodles to pork belly. Easily two meals.

dASIDnvebmg61rrmfkJ7vg.text: Wow!  Excellent!  Best ramen in Vegas.  Seating is limited and you should expect to wait.  Parking is not great, but we always find a spot.  If your ramen experience is limited to the Walmart variety, then do yourself a favor and try this place.  The broth is more than an over salted packet and the noodles seem fresh made.  My favorite is the Tonkotsu Bowl.  The kimchi fried rice was okay and the pork belly bowl is amazing.

mMzGaT8M-rAb2wbwQHJH-g.text: Finnaly! an authentic Japanese ramen (I think or about as close to it as I can get) and I wasn't the slightest disappointed. ! awesome I'm in love.  The bowls goes for 7$ great price but can be very very plain untill you spice it up just a little with all the extras! and It can range anywhere from 8$+ my hunger has done me in with a 13$ bowl . . . damn them eggs ! lmao !

k9XTkWHA5SYhd-_oPnR92w.text: I love this place. Small spot, but worth the wait to get a seat and have a bowl of their yummy ramen. My favorite ramen spot in Vegas, hands down.

E9477_UGyZsc5jr3uRLLCQ.text: I am so full!  I had the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen with sliced pork.  I also ordered kaedama (extra noodles), the mini-mentaiko bowl with spicy cod row, green onion & chopped seaweed over rice.  Washed it all down with an Asahi draft.  Excellent and pretty inexpensive.  The place is tiny!  I saw 4 people walking for the door and run to beat them inside.  I had to sit at the bar close to the door and kept getting blasted by freezing winds from outside.  I will be back (maybe when it's warmer outside.)

BmdFqd_0Jjm2jcHjD4nFRQ.text: Affordable and fast place for Ramen. Probably not the best for a big group if coming while it's crowded- for a party of 3 we waited maybe 10 minutes. Plenty of parking too.

tkcSAvFB-tLiF9azSWnACQ.text: I thought it was tasty. You'll have to add toppings a la carte style. Good service. Check out my ramen pic. Enjoy!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

bvX51i7x9hrfKAcUQIUADg.text: Small place and prepare to wait. Lines can be quite long due to small number of tables.   The menu is on the small side.   I agree with others that they could use more toppings.  I split some potstickers with a friend and the miso ramen. The broth was good and the noodles were good. The potstickers were not anything to write home about andwould skip them.

3TwF65rIz6tVolAfm8e4Hg.text: My friends and I found this place in one of the Las Vegas magazines. We opted to try it out. I have been addicted ever since. I have not wanted to write this review because this place is like y secret treasure and very small. There is almost always await. The food comes out very fast it has a limited menu of Ramen noodles.  It is awesome. The fried rice is out of the park good.  The bowls of noodles are quite big and you pay like $7 bucks. You can't go wrong with that.  The wait staff is nice and fast.  I can eat here everyday since Ramen noodles are one of my favorite.  It is a bit out of the way for me plus its small and often packed. Definitely worth going and checking it out and even if you have never had Ramen (the pack for .25 cents in the grocery store does not count) for less then ten bucks its worth it try.

8e8bdtBYKdbeIzIwS7Zwig.text: Talk about ramen noodle supreme!  The first time I went to this place was on a Monday.  I ordered the Tonkatsu and got addicted!  They only provide 4 pieces of pork in the soup, so I had to order extra.  I was so hooked that I came back two days later.   The place and menu is really small (and lacked some a/c), but the food was well worth it.   Reasonable prices too.

vaq36O4zInDK0SodV2bhBg.text: Best ramen in the world!  it has become a monthly post-airport-pickup dinner when my boyfriend flies out from LA.  The chasu is melt-in-your-mouth and a good (we now order extra).  Quality of the broth is outstanding.

THkAzsWJvULSeehRiK5BoQ.text: YUM YUM YUM!   My friend's cousin recommended this place to me. She has family in Vegas and this is one of her favorite hole in the wall spots.  When I first walked in, I wasn't too sure about the place. No air conditioning, just a fan. The place is super tiny. We ordered the chashu bowl, fried rice, and tonkotsu ramen.   The pork in the chashu bowl and tonkotsu ramen melts in you mouth. It is THAT delicious. Both had very good flavor. The fried rice also was very good. All the food felt like it was home-made and in a very positive way. It brought back the comforts of home.  When I am back in town, I will for sure do my best to visit this place.   I really wish there was a place like this in San Diego.

qREZi4ZmlYpbXHj_GFv0Ww.text: So i should have made Monta my first yelp review. Lord knows I've prob eaten here more over the past year than anywhere else!   What can I say about Monta that the other 200 reviews haven't already said?          Hmm... well its sooo quick! If you need to do the 30 min lunch this is the place. Listen, its small, but there's a secret! If you come by yourself during lunch-hour you can usually find a single seat at the bar!    If you've never been to Monta, the tonkatsu ramen is like chicken noodle soup on steroids, except its pork noodle soup! It's literally the deepest, most intense pork flavor ever!   As good as this place is, its like 3 times better when its a little chilly outside, really makes it hit the spot.  PS. Get the egg. And when you get your ramen, flip the egg (which is cold) over, yolk down, for a few mins, soaking in the hot broth!

L3uywY5k0vZBkciCtkmliA.text: Overall, I'm giving this place 4 stars but the tonkotsu ramen deserves 5 stars by itself.  I loved the flavor of the soup and how the noodles were cooked just right.  My brother and bf were hesitant to go because they've had not so good ramen before but both of them loved the ramen they ordered (tonkotsu and shoyu).  My brother loved it so much, he went again 2 days later.  I'll definitely be going back again and again for the ramen!  And next time, I'll try the extra toppings..but it says a lot about the flavor of the soup when I loved it plain the way it came.  So why the 4 stars?  We also ordered kimchi fried rice and the dumplings.  The dumplings were ok, nothing special about it.  It came slightly burnt and were all stuck together.  The kimchi fried rice was ok too, but more sour than the normal ones I've had.    Stick to the ramen and you'll love this place!

iTTPWt4xohLGP8-V3staKA.text: Stopped by this place on a way back from Red Rock. It was full of middle-aged Japanese guys that were apparently refueling after Sunday golf.  I had a Miso ramen with some kind of a 'special roasted pork'. It was pretty good but I can hardly say that I was blown away (like quite a few reviewers of this place). It was just OK.

Fp7jrsaW3iVA2sGJNv2_Dw.text: Tonkatsu ramen is delish.  We come here every Vegas trip.

moBEegyaMgeRxu7G7cxULw.text: Very tasty Broth. I had the thin noodles, but should've gotten the thick ones. Service was a bit rushed, but still ok. Overall, very decent Ramen.

zeA7qQUna4pC4pBPvxkkfA.text: Went there tonight with hubby and friend.  We ordered two tonkotsu ramen, one miso ramen, a side of chashu, an order of gyoza, and three beers on tap, total came out to $31.14 not bad.    The gyoza was very tasty, chashu nice and tender, noodles were great, and the broth was alright nothing spectacular (better with the grated garlic they give you).   I like to put gyoza in my ramen (kinda like wonton mein or mandoo kook soo), there's something about dumplings in broth that makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside (my comfort food).    It is hot in there and eating hot ramen does not help, my husband couldn't wait to get out of there.   Service was fast and friendly.  So far best ramen in Vegas.

2xivgX3RFU2gKmcpYUbsKA.text: Best Ramen in Vegas IMO. The tonkatsu shoyu is mine and my wife's go to move each time. It's hard to order anything else. The porkbelly is so delicious and tender. If i'm feeling saucy i'll go with the tonkatsu shoyu with egg and extra pork. POW. The porkbelly rice bowl is delicious and a good appetizer. Their fried rice choices are also very good.

guqTFqWwF15nDCOERCjHHg.text: We ordered the shoyu ramen and fried rice.  I did enjoy the soup but I felt the noodles were a bit al dente.  I've had better fried rice, it just had tons of chunky onions in it.    A quick fix to my ramen craving in Vegas.

M5ZpMRxtXYIz1gB7CLbGvQ.text: This didn't turn out to be what i expected. Soup base was so salty, and the meat melted in the soup. I couldn't taste the meat at all. All in all...mehhhhhh

205VaCWLY3Au4E-2UX7u0w.text: OMG!!!! This place is out of this world!! The menu is short and to the point but wow!! I usually don't give a place 5 stars but this was worth the short wait outside in the cold. Try any of the soups and I added corn for a more comfort food feel! The beverages and food overall was cheap for the quality.  I will be back and I can't wait!

OBjOm5d7xD6Ix4EUmzc6tg.text: I have eaten here before and the food is good so we were excited to come for a friend's birthday dinner. My boyfriend and I got there first and put down for a table of 5. About 15 mins later they set a table for us but our entire party was not there so they refused to seat us. We told them that one person was in the lot trying to find a spot (another negative about this spot - no parking) and the other 2 were less than 5 minutes away. We asked if my boyfriend and I could be sat and order apps as we were starving. The waitress said she could not seat us until the whole party was there as it would be unfair to other ppl waiting?! She said if we wanted to eat we could sit separately (lovely - you see me with a gift bag but tell us we could sit separately). I asked what sense did that make when we're waiting for others. She said it didn't matter it's their policy. So we sat and stared at our table of 5 waiting for us as the waitress complained about us to the chefs and rolled her eyes at us every time she looked at us. As our friends were  still trying to find a spot we asked again if we could be sat and begin ordering. Verily nastily she said - are you going to order for 5?? My boyfriend said no why?? Everyone's more or less here. At this point I was just done with this place so I said let's leave and find somewhere else and walked out. My boyfriend asked the waitress are you really willing to let a table of 5 leave when ppl are ready to order and the others are trying to find parking in a lot that has no spots?? The waitress turned and walked away without saying anything.  We left and went to Ramen Sora (about a block away) where there's ample parking and better service.

T9Zx_TwxusQWNvt-yf4ALw.text: This place is great!!  One of my faves,  they keep it small to as the noodle places from Japan and even though it gets packed, service is quick enough, they are the pioneer of noodle houses in Vegas and they can't compare to any other.. Highly recommended

ykBc6QKq--GW_v0C-CwMxw.text: We took a chance on Monta after reading all the reviews and I'm glad we did.  The ramen was tasty, the fried rice was just ok, considering the price for what you get, but the rock star of the meal was def the pork belly rice!  I wish we would have not ordered the fried rice and just gotten the PBR!!  It reminded me of my childhood and it was sooooo good!  In fact, I want some now thinking of it! :)  I'll be back just for that!  The place is small tho and even tho we arrived around 4 it was still a 15 min. wait for a table.  The staff is friendly and the restaurant is clean.  But the  most important thing is order the PBR!! :)

YE1RjFnYUunxDrBODJxJ3A.text: We ordered 3 Shoyu and 1 Spicy Tonkotsu. The taste was not that bad and price is reasonable, but what we found in one of that Shoyu was a small round bug. We had a waitress take a look at it and we were told that it's just a mushroom. We asked to take a CLOSER look and they admitted that it was a bug. They asked us if we wanted replacement which was a little odd to us(who wants to keep the Ramen with the bug in it???). We were also told that it comes with food and on top of that, what we got after all this was 50% off on that Ramen and all they said to us was "Sorry about that". I was disappointed with their service even though their food is loved by lots of people..... Even though it wasn't only the server's fault, one's fault is everyone's fault as a team/restaurant member....

zsnDaATbWYn50ftx7WsaMg.text: Long wait at lunch but great food and reasonably priced.  Small menu with large portions.  Make sure you sign in when you get there they will call you outside when your table is ready.

4Tg7XTXDerozsnEpqExPAg.text: Monta is one of my favorite Japanese Ramen in town.   It's so tasty that it got famous and was featured on Travel Channel.  The chef claim you couldn't get the ingredient/recipe here and it came straight from Japan.  The noodle is very tasty.  Few things I don't like about the the Ramen is that the soup is got way too much oil in there which is not drinkable.  If you are looking for restaurant to socialize with your friends, this is definitely not the spot for you.  The turn over is very fast, people Eat and Go quick and you have people wait in line in a very small space and everyone will be staring at you waiting LOL...  Not a spot to hang out.  But Food is good.

TK-dPthSkPlFVrjJbbtguA.text: I've been coming to this place since they've opened.  I would give them 5 stars if I had reviewed them earlier, but as of late their broth has been overly salty.  However, I keep coming back for more since this is pretty much the only legitimate ramen shop that I know of in the Las Vegas Valley area.  I usually order the miso ramen with nitamago, shredded green onions, and corn (sometimes I go wild and order butter too).  The broth is on the fattier side, and is rich and nutty.  Overall, this is a good bowl of ramen.  Service is friendly and quick and their streamlined menu captures all the quintessential components of your basic ramen shop.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with nitamago
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with nitamago
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

vdI62sD0ef45zSgoTpGBew.text: Ramen as it should be. But seating is limited and crowds are large. What you need to know is that there will be a line out the door if you arrive after 11:30 for lunch. Walk in and write your name on the list asap and then wait patiently. Be sure your whole party is there for seating.

Tbw9xb4xKFdS_vEsGMdG8w.text: At Monta Ramen for lunch with my work partner. He warned me about the wait because this place is so popular. I didn't care because I had to get my ramen fix on, and this place is supposed to be the best in town! 1st impressions are good; as the wait list was organized and simple. While waiting, I checked out the menu. Straight forward, delicious sounding dishes/ bowls and sides. I also noticed that the menu is more limited than the Monta Ramen in Henderson (Eastern Ave/ Serene). Not full menu of appetizers... So at about 1 pm on a Tuesday afternoon, we waited 10 minutes.  Not bad, but I think we got lucky. I ordered the Tonkotsu...added the egg for a little over a buck...and it didn't disappoint!  The broth was flavorful (not just a sodium bomb) and the noodles were just what you'd expect a good noodle shop would produce.  Did I mention the price? $6.95 for bowl.  So good; and hit the spot for my craving. Check this place out if you yearn for good ramen. You won't be disappointed!!

8IJnzj5N6vOy9VM6neuiAg.text: To start off the place is small and cozy. They have classic pork broth. Amazing! The flavor is rich and creamy. There really isn't anything bad you could say about this place.

uFcWPEKntyJIP3_4DHmQbw.text: Finally got around to visiting the latest addition to ramen houses in Vegas - Monta Noodle House.  Conveniently located on Spring Mountain, right next to the super busy Raku.  (Smart business choice I would say.)  This place is bare bones - as in minimal tables and a bar, so don't come with a large group.  Their super simple menu gets you in and out fast!  (A couple who came in around the same time we did had ordered, gotten their food, finished, paid and left by the time we were eating ours.)  I went for their most popular dish - Tonkotsu Ramen ($6.95).  The main component is the broth, which is made up of boiling pork bones, fat, and collagen for hours.  This results in a cloudy white broth and would usually have the consistency of a thin gravy.  It automatically comes with two slices of char sui, takenoko (bamboo sprouts), kikurage (type of mushroom), and green onions.  Their char siu (barbecued pork) definitely isn't like the Chinese kind, but definitely tasty.  The Husband went for the Miso Ramen ($7.25), which is ultimately bean paste blended with the pork broth giving it a richer flavor.  This was also good, and quite filling.  We also shared a regular order of the Pork Belly Bowl ($5.75).  It sits on a bed of rice, with fresh scallions and pickled red ginger.  I adore pork belly and the next time I come here, I'm going to order a dish of this all to myself.  It's fatty and good.    A side dish we added on was the Takana Mustard Leaf ($1.50).  You can have this on the side or in your broth.  It's pickled mustard greens that may or may not be to your liking.  It's adds a different texture and taste to your ramen.  Other toppings you can add on included nitamago (seasoned hard boiled egg), corn, butter, kimchee, and more char siu or green onions.  There's only one other kind of ramen they offer here - Shoyu, which means soy sauce based.  You can also add extra noodles for $2 more if you save your soup and ask for "Kaedama."  Other dishes available are gyoza, fried rice, kim chee fried rice, takana fried rice, cha siu bowl, and mini mentaiko (marinated polluck roe).  Service was good.  With two waitresses, they keep the flow of business going great and refilled beverages as needed.  It's not the best place to loiter with the limited seating and all, but definitely a great place to grab a quick bite and go.  Update!   I returned the following month for my own bowl of the Pork Belly Bowl.  This time the pork belly was sliced thinner, which wasn't to my personal preference.  Guess it depends on who is working the kitchen that day.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Takana Mustard Leaf ($1.50)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl (regular $5.75)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen ($7.25)

HL_4fsfvDVtRORL67hG1Nw.text: Love this place!  One of my favorite restaurants!  Tastes like you're in Okinawa/Japan.

HIordy4gcUgHnGNLPDQ2Mw.text: Solid ramen joint. Small place away from the Vegas Strip (you'll need to cab it). Two kinds of noodles - if you're looking for the standard noodle, it's the bigger one. The chashu was really good, super tender. The nitamago was done really well. I had the tonkatsu-shoyu broth, which I liked a lot. My sister had the miso broth - SUPER SALTY!!

aOhubQCWlxw_dqWf9py2lw.text: Our favorite ramen place. Even if we have to wait for a while, it's worth it. Been coming to this place for more than 5 years, every winter time, this is the first place we come to for ramen. Would recommend it to anyone, you wont be disappointed.

NUfvxc45LYjUx6onYj5cFQ.text: Best ramen ever. Try the rice bowl too, it was delish. The service was awesome, the prices were good, can't get any better than this.

eb0TMHgKy9xLCRrgwmMDRQ.text: Now that I've come here enough to practically remember the whole menu, I think it's ready for a review.   When I found this place (through Yelp of course) I thought to myself, "Could it be? A True authentic ramen place that the city I originally resided in devastatingly lacked of? My own little NYC Momofuku only a 15 minute drive away?" OH, SWEET BABY JESUS IT COULD!   Before making the trip to your next lunch or dinner date here, you should probably consider what day you're going and at what time. This place is SMALL, like 5 tables (2 4-tops, 3 2-tops) small with a couple seats at the bar, and it gets crazy packed! The first time I came here I literally drove by and was like, "awh hailll noo," and drove away. HOWEVER I will say that if there's just a couple of people before you, just be patient and wait. The tables turn over rather quickly.  Which leads me to the menu. It's very simple and quick to prepare. If you're going with ramen, they have 4 different broth options: Shoyu (chicken), Tonkotsu (pork), Tonkotsu-shoyu (chicken & pork) and Miso. All are priced around 6.95 a bowl. Just forget the rest and go with the Tonkotsu-Shoyu. All ramens are prepared with two slices of pork, bamboo, and chopped green onion. Don't forget to add extra ingredients like an egg and mustard leaf! If you've never tried mustard leaf, it really compliments the broth and makes it extra delicious...order it on the side and try it out! Adding in the ingredients is what really gets the meal to be pricier than expected. Just 1 egg is an extra $1.75, but it's okay to indulge a little every now  and then, so just go all out with you bad ramen self!   They have other items as well such as fried rice, small plates, and cold ramen! I still have yet to try them.. will do an update after my next visit!   The only negative thing I'd have to say about the ramen is it can get pretty salty, of course you can mention to them less sodium, but I'm pretty sure all they're going to do is dilute it with hot water. To leave it on a positive note, aside from the saltiness the broth is PERFECTION. Extremely murky, so you know its packed with flavor and takes overnight cooking to prepare.

DCFGUj03ZRmZBfTCZSNCdQ.text: Small menu, but the three item I call were good.    But, since I come from SoCal to visit, this place's ramen doesn't seem any more special compare to the many we have from home, but still it's good!  The price make it's worth it compare to most places near the strip.  To sum it up, good food, decent price, but don't expect anything extraordinary if you had Japanese ramen before :-)

eXqdQQVR2AnxsfWSFLVzsQ.text: I love this place ! Great service, food, and price. I definitely recommend this place if you love Ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

8un06mMiKkxD9NVUP8-QvA.text: Pretty okay, a little in the bland side and they don't do as many mix-ins as other places (add separately). Not many side dishes either, just gyoza and rice. I personally like Ramen Sora down the street better.

HmzEVnhLRCt4Z0NLf3yb_A.text: **3.5 stars**  This place is really hoppin' especially around dinner time. There is always a line out the door if you go between 5-7pm. I've been here everytime I come to Vegas and I've always ordered the Miso Soup Ramen w. egg and seaweed. Each time I've had it, I feel like the soup has gotten saltier.. Don't get me wrong, the soup is still tasty, but once I got to the last bite, the soup was a little too much at the end. The kimchi tends to be sour, which is how some peope like it but I prefer my kimchi fresh.     This is a great place to get a quick ramen fix in Vegas but not nearly as comparable as the famous ramen places in New York!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen (miso soup?) w egg and seaweed as extras!

Tgln2r9Z3PSpYKu9Z4v5ZA.text: This is the most delicious Japanese food I have ever had. A little hole in the wall bustling with activity. The wait staff is great. Each person has a separate job and I love that. Servers aren't taking your dirty plates and waiters are just taking your order. We had the fried dumplings, ramen soup with pork and marinated eggs and the fried rice. The noodles were very fresh and the broth was perfectly seasoned. The dumplings were lightly fried and so delicious I couldn't stop eating them! I highly recommend monta. If you're looking for a place with great food, great prices and off the strip, this is the spot.

ZIveWVEQ767r3moRabzRIw.text: I used to think LA got one of the Best Ramen places in town.  Opinions changed!!  Monta Noodle House for now got the BEST Tonkotsu Ramen Soup in town!   I have tried the famous Ramen shop in LA, SF, and NYC.  This one is no doubt the  BEST.  Thick creamy soup with bald flavors.  Although I am not the fan of thin noodles but they managed to cook it right (Shinsengumi Hataka Ramen in Gardena can not get it right, so does the famous Ippudo in NYC).  I also LOVED their nitamago (soft broiled egg).  YUMMY (Look at the business photo that I placed)  This place is now on my official "Must Visit" place when coming to Sin City.  So Good!$!#$!$!  and they also accept credit cards :D

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yummy tonkotsu ramen in Vegas!

_tZjlaONGItGfe9x9P3-bA.text: Not sure what it is but I got a pretty upset stomach after eating at this place for dinner. The meat was really good but everything else wasn't. Perhaps I'm just not a big fan of their ramen. I've definitely had much better ramen compared to this.

jFFXpU4KmLFcFQWKg-yKyQ.text: This is probably the most popular ramen restaurant near Las Vegas area because we had to wait about 1 hour just to get in. Restaurant was pretty small and service was okay.    Miso ramen with extra chashu porks and nitamago ($7.25 + $2.5 + $1.5) - The miso broth was a bit salty, but at least there was some flavor. Nitamago (flavored egg) was actually pretty good. Chashu porks had a good texture, but tasted a bit salty. I do like their wavy noodle, pretty chewy.   This place probably won't be this popular if it opens up around the Los Angeles area because there are too many great ramen restaurants. Overall - noodle wasn't too bad, but broth was definitely a bit salty.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2QyiEFudmjLNbFGD_ycXng.text: We loved our first visit here; Had the chicken and pork broth, tonkotsu ramen ; Everything seemed just right; Definitely a change from the food on and near the strip; Definitely coming back; Quick service, delicious noodles;  Only drawback, very crowded; But it's to be expected;

JCZDc_Hn18AADVq8P09LgQ.text: This review is solely based on the wait staff last night. I ordered the Kuro ramen with black garlic oil asking for the garlic oil to be placed on the side. What came out to the table was tonkotsu ramen with garlic oil on the side. I immediately told the girl this is not what I ordered. She , in turn, went to get the original waitress who insisted this was what I ordered. Come on now , I know what I ordered and my friend heard me order it, too. Any establishment would have taken it back and replaced it with what i ordered. She refused. So now, my friends are halfway done with dinner so I said forget it and reluctantly ate the tonkotsu. So the bill comes and she charges me extra for the garlic oil. Wtf... So if you want to get your order right here have them repeat it before they take off.  I don't like tonkotsu ramen so I can't base my review on the food. Sorry

TAaodEqM8TK_mvmKi-O0oQ.text: Based on the reviews, thought we'd try Monta.  The place was packed during the lunch hour.  We were quickly greeted and offered seats at the counter.  We ordered the char siu rice bowl and shoyu ramen.  The food came quickly and smelled great.  Added the red ginger, sesame seeds, red pepper salt and crushed garlic.  It does add a boast.  The soup is tasty as were the noodles.  I don't eat pork so my hubby said it was very tender but sparse.  His bowl looked good with a small pile of seaweed on top of everything.  We enjoyed it but prefer pho to ramen so will visit Vietnamese places.

3mDTD5F-c2plrlBsKvpbZQ.text: It is a tradition...and a MUST to eat some sort of noodle and soup combo after a long inebriated weekend in Las Vegas. Monta Ramen is one of my go-to spots upon exiting the city of sin.  Very small location, but huge flavors!  Get here early or you will be getting blue-balled by the aroma and presence of the MONTA RAMEN.  *Oh yes...if you need a place to hang out or wait...I suggest the bar across the plaza...$4 beers and video casino games kept me entertained.  When we sat down, they had 2 specials: Kuro Ramen and Spicy Tonkatsu. Both sounded absolutely amazing...it took me a while to figure out which bowl I should get...but I finally came to a conclusion within minutes. I ORDERED BOTH!  In addition, I also ordered a bowl of Pork Belly with rice and a nice Sapporo to go with the meal. Oh yes, how could I forget...GETTING AN EGG IS A MUST!  The food came out...everything was heavenly. The noodle was firm to an appropriate al dente - ramen style. The broth wasnt too thick where it came off as a sauce. Hearty, packed with immense flavor, and delicious. So delicious that all the asians DID NOT want to waste the extra effort and time to publish their food on facebook or instagramn.   My experience was great. The only thing that sucked was the 4 hour drive home to OC + food coma + food baby.  HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!  UNTIL THEN!! ^-^

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

HF3PSLLzjbPQIurI43xYlg.text: Seriously one of the best ramen places I've been to in a long time! The service was great and the wait was manageable despite the small size of the restaurant. Also, even though it's a small place, it didn't feel cramped or stuffy. You had the choice of sitting at the bar or at a table - which made for a very chill eating experience.   I ordered the Gypza to start, set the stage for a wonderful meal. Then ordered the Shoyu Ramen which has both chicken and pork broth, thick noodles, pork belly, mushrooms and egg (extra). The ratio of noodle to broth was perfect and all ingredients complimented each other very well. The broth wasn't salty at all either - which was great!   My go to spot whenever I'm in town, hands down!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen with egg, pork belly, mushrooms, thick ramen noodles and pork and chicken broth - delicious!

sbg0hm7hpor8CfDB0tCzWw.text: Tonkotsu ramen had a very rich and tasty broth.  Thin noodles were cooked well. Liked the pork topping but cold corn caused soup to get cold. The pork belly rice was tasty too.  Place is small so expect a wait.

Ipd4AySNBrGEDF04QHUHWA.text: Never wrote a review on Monta before, and I certainly don't like writing bad reveiws unless I have a real personal bad rapport with the service, or, knowingly being "stiffed" out of more money for something not worthy or neccessary.  After "Togoshi Ramen" disappeared, Monta is probably the first real "Ramen-ya" (ramen house) opened in Las Vegas.  Not a sushi-ya or a restaurant serving ramen, or a ramen-ya being a full restaurant.  Monta's  Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen started good, and was good for awhile, and went to "a little too salty" on the ramen soup, but I know they can do better.   Went back today after more than a year, and it was back to normal. Still a small place, busy as usual, but, I was in and out in about 30 - 40min.  I ate pretty quick, too. I didn't order any extra toppings because I want it to taste it the way it is, plus, I ordered a side of pot stickers and a side of Kimchee Fried Rice.   It might be my imagination, but, I think their Kimchee Fried Rice got better.  I don't remember if it originally had any bits of shiitake mushrooms in it, but it had it, and it was delicious!   The gyoza (pot stickers)  I ordered (not in the photo) was a gyoza.  Nothing special.  Frankly, I've had better gyoza, and I can too, make a better one (with 30+ years of professional cooking and non-professional experience).  However, their specialy is ramen. Tonkotsu Shoyu is difficult to balance in the first place.  I can taste the pork broth with the shiitake mushrooms, and a hint of something... not Japanese.  May be Chinese, or perhaps that "hihachi" pepper from Okinawa?  Great job Monta!  Their other ramen like miso base and shoyu base have always been good. Ramen soups are always fascinating, because there are so many things you can do to it.  There is no "fixed" or "Orthodox" style, or, whatsoever.  It has to taste good at your first sip of the soup, hence, very challenging.  Furthermore, I've always loved the way their workers  are "up beat" and energetic, how a small and busy place like that should be.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monta Ramen&#39;s Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen and Kimchee Fried Rice.

53mcvAfVHO2GWZ69D3k_3Q.text: Soup had really good flavor. Service was excellent! Our order was made fast and tasted really fresh. They have a lot of options for soup base and toppings. The soup is a little on the heavy side for taste. Second best ramen shop in town in my opinion.

Pkyt-80qXGxRoks1mgHhDg.text: Great ramen in Las Vegas for under $10. Note- this place opens at 11:30am and by 11:33am it's hard to find a seat. Service was fast, staff was helpful and the ramen was very good.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miao ramen

0PKX248g8etyAvuRWxxd_Q.text: First Las Vegas Ramen I tried and I liked it.  Had their spicy tonkotsu ramen bowl and it was quite good. Also tried their fried rice and gyoza, both were not bad. No complaints. I actually the price was cheaper than bay area places.  Will go back to this place when craving ramen in Las Vegas. Maybe try their Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu $7.95
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

3f87yvthAQpuer2SCy0Ohg.text: Really Yummy Ramen joint.  They open at 11:30 and I highly recommend getting there 20 minutes early or you will wait in line.  If you don't mind the wait then you'll be very happy with your decision.

3FRvQJaVl5tJDXgJcy3lXw.text: The wait wasn't too bad , maybe because it was 11pm when we arrived. Had their famous Ramen black garlic , broth was so thick and tad bit salty. It was hard to eat and finish; they give so little meat. Added egg for $1.5 and ramen was around $8, which wasn't too bad .  Small little place and very nice severs

mQLMwuNWh5Q7iq9DAHrknA.text: I had tried ramen two times before this.  I did not like it. At all.  So when my bf asked me to go with him here I was to be honest not so excited about it.  So I ordered gyoza and shared the pork belly bowl and told my bf to just order his ramen and I would try it. Omg! The ramen was awesome I think he ordered the shoyu (spelling?) ramen! I actually liked it. Will definitely get my own bowl next time :))) And the pork belly bowl ahhhhh my good it was soooo delicious. The gyoza which are usually my favorite were just ok.  Go eat ramen at monta ramen even if u haven't liked it in the past.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

pCtxr2SxDrPGqO1tybMM6Q.text: YES! Finally got to try this place! Granted we came at an off peak hour for dinner around 4pm because that's when we got into town, wait was about 15 min. We were seated at a booth by the front door, which was a bench seat that spanned the length of the room and then 2 chairs on the other side. There was a bar and only a couple of other tables, so not great for big groups.  Noodles were chewy and on point! Black garlic ramen was amazing, the pork belly bowl definitely satisfied the kids. Since it was a hot hot day, full of driving, we ordered cold noodles with yuzu sauce!   Service was great! The servers were attentive and totally understanding with us, having 2 little ones, ie lots and lots of napkins, and water refills ;)

7YugrjlGeM6HULmSQvPI4Q.text: Mmm, ramen~  There's nothing like a bowl of steamy hot noodles that can cure any trace of a hangover.  I've only tried this place twice so far and every time they set my bowl of steamy hot miso/tonkatsu ramen with chashu and egg, a part of me rejoices.  Japanese chashu is normally tender, juicy, and melts in your mouth.  Monta's chashu doesn't disappoint.  Always get extra chashu!  The soup is full of flavor [although if you show up during the rush, it can become waaay too salty].  The over-cooked noodles is where they disappoint.  The establishment itself is very small and becomes packed fast.  Seating is limited and there always seems to be a line right when they open.  3.5 stars!

rttCblWCPi0N7NiChvBJhw.text: I try and come by every time I am in town.  It's one of my favorite Ramen places.  My boss and co-workers enjoy coming here too.  The service is quick and friendly.

fpHudJ3jdieQRBcFwbJrFw.text: First time eating Japanese food and is was great:) My friend from Japan came with me and my boyfriend. We loved it and will start being regulars:) The place only seats about  25-30 people if that:( It is defiantly my diamond in the ruff!!

INhlygkgr1m_PUVVOW2RRQ.text: You can easily tell by the groups of people standing outside Monta that it's the best ramen shop in Las Vegas or Hawaii! A frequent patron here, my boyfriend and I have dedicated a weekly lunch date there - Monta Mondays :D Their Sapporo style miso ramen is awesome - chewy noodles, rich miso broth, and the perfect amount of toppings. Oh how heavenly it would be if they were to add crab to the topping extras!  Be sure to order a side of handmade gyoza, as well.  *They don't open until 11:30am.

sDE6xVcoZyuCiA6MCkswHQ.text: Ramen here is reasonably price and the miso ramen is delicious! Definitely going to in here next time I'm in Las Vegas!

DKkQIldTSbaBg5n0PwEQ0Q.text: Finally got to go to Monta after hearing about it for so long and dying to go. It was good! Pretty much what you would expect from a ramen place... quick and easy. It is very small and you'll probably have to wait for sure.   I have to say I enjoy different ramen styles better, though, like what they have at Ramen Sora. Monta has thinner noodles, and their broth is very good but doesn't have the umami punch that makes ramen so delicious. I prefer thicker, chewier wavy noodles than thin noodles that they had. They also do not have curry like many ramen places unfortunately, but that is okay, because they make up for it with their variety of fried rices.   I sat at a stool at the bar, and it is pretty uncomfortable, but adds to the ramen-ya feel that they are going for. I wouldn't mind going back, it definitely satisfies the ramen craving, but I think if I had to pick one place it would be Ramen Sora for sure.   Check it out!

Bx7UHIdXHSYOF86UTppSzg.text: Before I finally tried this place, a couple people told me this was the best noodles in Vegas. I has the T. Shoyu noodles & Takana fried rice. Both were filling & okay, but I thought pho was more satisfying. Don't think I'll be back. I tried seeing if they had siracha hot sauce, but the server ignored me. These are only my opinions, perhaps many others think Monta is one of the best as well.

Btxp1yOBXq8hPCh9FEZ7vg.text: This Ramen is so good. definitely way better than the last two places i went.

BDfCbwhOuvWLpAimY4t2Ng.text: I was first introduced to this place when my friends had asked if I wanted to try out the best ramen in Las Vegas.  At first I was hesitant seeing as I have had plenty of ramen in Vegas.  They are good but not what  I was expecting.  When he had said the name Monta, I was relieved to know that this was not a place I had previously eaten at which is surprising seeing as I have eaten at plenty of ramen places.  When pulling up into the lot you would have to look for it seeing as Monta is a pretty tiny place.  This is definitely one of those places where you would have to hear about.  One of those hole in the wall places.  Once you walk in you are greeted warmly by the staff and the cozy environment.  You can see the kitchen and the workers all hard at work trying to fill the mouths of its many customers.  One thing I have to say about this place, and I have eaten here many times, prepare to wait a bit for there is usually a line because of how delicious this place is.  Once seated there will be a small menu with now four types of ramen you can choose from.  A tonkotsu base ramen which is pork based, shoyu which is soy based, tonkotsu-shoyu which is a mix of the two, and miso which is bean paste based.  They also have side items which you can put into your ramen like corn and eggs which are a pretty much a must.  The portions are also very generous and you will get that good fill feeling.  I have personally eaten them all and can vouch for them all.  They are all so good.  Monta is like the In-N-Out of ramen.  They specialize in ramen and boy, do they deliver.  This is now one of the only ramen places I will go to eat.  A very cheap and delicious way to spend with friends or even eat at by yourself.  There are few places where I will eat by myself and this is for sure one of them.

Ldu11EVuL-d-uJht6JN6GA.text: The first time I came to Monta, there was a huge line coming out of Big Wong because of their Grand opening free meal special, and this gave me a pretty easy entry into Monta that day.  Even though a bunch of cheap skates were at Big Wong, this tiny dining room at  Monta was still almost filled to capacity, but still; I found a seat the the counter area.   The waitress was very impressive, and had it down on helping almost everyone in the dining room, while still taking care of take outs orders.  On the down side, looking how Monta menu is set up,  they have a nickel and dime effect on how you make an order with them.   Never  in my life I would thought of a eating a 12.00 bowl of Ramen which happen that day.  The Tonsoku stock was pretty good, and ramen could have been cooked a little bit longer, but the thought of paying extra for the corn, nori, boiled egg, and extra noodles kind of got to me.    Don't get me wrong,  I thought  Monta had  the best Tonsoku ramen in Las Vegas, because there wasn't any real competitors at that time.   My only thought going through my mind was if Monta had to match up with Ezogeku in Hawaii (which is pretty good)   This comparison would be like Godzilla battling Pee Wee Herman, because Ezogeku would  waste this place in a heartbeat for quality and value.  That's pretty sad to say a ramen-ya in Hawaii has a better overall package than this so-called Las Vegas heavyweight..   I never understood why anyone would wait two hours in line to eat  here, because currently  in Las Vegas there more than a few Ramen-ya that recently opened recently and all of them can trade punches with Monta.  In fact, I don't think this place has the best ramen in the Chinatown area, and for sure Monta isn't the best Japanese establishment in this shopping complex.   Take my advice, walk fifty step to the east in the parking lot, and go there.   Sorry Monta,  in my opinion your product doesn't justify the price and the time wasted.  Also, please take a lesson from your neighbor next door, and keep everything clean in the back room.  Getting nailed with a MAJOR health violations from the Southern Nevada Health District is quite an embarrassment.    I"m Japanese, and know more than a thing or two about Ramen.   In my opinion, Monta is now just in a middle of the pack for Las Vegas ramen scene.  Don't believe in the hype.  .

tFNzm6EZzPYRS9G-_VrNCg.text: It was actually the wrong time of year to fully enjoy Ramen.  It is always best on a cold night, not a hot dry one.  Oh well, the journey must continue.    Ordered the tonkatsu Ramen and takana fried rice.  Tonkatsu broth was flavorful but not as rich and creamy as I've had at other place's Hawaii.  Noodles appeared similar to somen noodles.  Char siu tasted good but was cut VERY thin.    Takana fried rice was better than than the plain fried rice.  I wish there was a more pronounced takana flavor and (remember my low salt diet) it was a bit salty.  Overall a good experience, service was quick, food was good and of sufficient quantity, and prices were reasonable.  I would recommended going here, especially on a cold day/night.

mzy0CMQCs_rjNRfHbM9yhg.text: Pretty darn good ramen in a tiny little restaurant.  Not sure why everyone seems to be raving so much.  Great ramen, but I've had better.  Tonkatsu broth is excellent but the noodles were uninspiring.  Great prices though.  This sounds like a bad review, but I would definitely go again.

pNEv9gBJPAeYSf4HESOopQ.text: Delicious, inexpensive, and a ton of options to choose from. You can customize your broth, noodles, fixins(egg, seaweed, veggies, etc) and everything else quickly and easily. The only thing stopping me from giving this above 5 stars is the space itself. This restaurant might seat 20 people if you packed them in like sardines. There is no place to wait, and apparently the wait to even eat lunch here is a struggle. I felt like I could hear what the other diners were thinking when I was crammed in next to them. Aside from that, the food itself was absolutely delicious, and it tasted authentic. This certainly isn't your college ramen experience.

GZi05H92po8PhuLncDFCFw.text: I'm not big on ramen but this place is legit. There broths are flavorful, noodles are not over cooked, and there toppings are good too. You know its legit when there's ALWAYS a wait, then again this place is SUPER small. Every time I come here I have to wait at least 30 min but that's okay, its worth it. Prices are fairly average for a bowl of ramen. I'll def be back when i'm back in Vegas. :)

gEyTO31a8A1lEqn9uF3YnQ.text: Best Ramen in Vegas. This isn't your 25cent pack of Ramen from the grocery store. It's the real deal.  Cloudy broth with hot noodles and delicious slices of roasted pork.  Choice of 4 Ramen bowls. Tonkotsu, Shoyu, Tonkotsu-Shoyu (combination), and Miso. My favorite is the Tonkotsu-Shoyu, best of both worlds!  Full of flavor, not bland at all..I only added a little bit of spice to add some heat! I would definitely add a hard-boiled egg (minus a star because you have to pay extra, EGG should be included!) The bowl itself it well portioned and I was full after finished off last drips of broth and slurping my last noodle.   We also had the pork belly bowl.  To me this was flat.  As in, not what I was expecting with pork belly.  It was more gelatinous than crispy with fat on it.  Order the small bowl to try it I'd say.   Quick tips: Can be a long wait as the place is small so plan accordingly.  However the food comes quick, almost 5 minutes after you order! so the turnaround time isn't bad at all.  Get your noodle fix at MONTA! Man...after writing this I'm salivating for some Ramen..I'll see you there

0XA3amAIy9pxY2QC-nrsmw.text: This place is awesome., The Gyoza are delicious and the Shoyu Ramen was as good as noodle soup gets.

0-d4v82SbaFzIr8WvfkPJw.text: Really good ramen at cheap prices. It's worth the 5 minute drive away from the Strip to eat here. Just be warned they have limited seating. You may have to wait a while.

3auJ6uIMJHuQCH1Y-zpZlQ.text: After all the rave reviews, my husband and I decided to try it.  We got there early, and just in the nick of time, because 10 mins. later the place was packed with people waiting in line.  Husband and I ordered and it took a much longer time to prepare than should have been for the type of food we had.  I had Tonkatsu ramen with extra chasu (bad move) green onions and corn.  The green onions were finely shredded and placed on top like a haystack, and the corn just piled on top.  The chasu was thin and soft and fell apart when picked up.  The broth did not have much flavor.  I couldn't understand why this place did such a wonderful business when right across the street at Hue Thai you can get a wonderful bowl of pho for the same price, and don't have to pay for any extras.  They also have bahn mi (sandwiches) for which they bake their own wonderful bread.    Skip Monta Noodles and get your noodles at Hue Thai!  I don't work for either place. but am a regular at Hue Thai, and will continue to be.

OpNpxlB_Sx819wHxXNZ7Dg.text: Dinner 05/19/2016: Tonkotsu ramen broth was too salty.  I've eaten at their combined locations well over 20 times.  The Chinatown/Decatur location has a smaller menu selection compared to Monta Chaya.  I would recommend dining at their Eastern Ave location instead.

rZq8iiu1uqkMfDbLuLj1WA.text: Best hang over food. I would always come here when i'm about to leave Vegas. This place is small, but i'm not complaining. I remember I came here 15 minutes before it open and when they opened their door I saw people sprinting out of their cars trying to get a seat. When you see people do that, you know it's legit. They have multiple soup base and different add-ons. So it's line a customizable ramen shop. Build-a-ramen. The noodles are cooked well, they aren't bloated, the base is very flavorful, and the meat literally melts in your mouth. Service here is beyond excellent. This place is my absolute favorite ramen joint ... Ever...

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

a67UeFS04usraETJ9EWDTQ.text: After living in Japan for a year, I fell in love with ramen. I tried Pho and saimen as a substitute but it's NOT same. So when I heard about this place and read all the great reviews I couldn't wait to try it out. It definitely lives up to the hype!!   We got there at 12 on a Thursday and had to wait about 20-30 minutes. It was well worth the wait. We tried the goyza (I make this fresh at home and restaurants never beat my fresh ones but since it has such good reviews we tried it). If your a fan, definitely order them! So good!! I got the shoyu with boiled egg and cashu pork. The pork just melts in your mouth and the egg adds a nice texture to it. My Dad got the tonkastu with the cashu pork and loved that as well. Both types had amazing flavor, and we're just like the ones we fell in love with in Japan.   If I could give this place 6 stars I would!!!

eGGEwTDyjBay9R5LWX-E1Q.text: Amazing Raman!  They do not accept reservations so you have to get here during off peak hours or get your name on the list to wait! Make sure you have someone present to stand and wait because we walked away while they called our names :(. Theres also not a lot of space in the restaurant which gives reason to the long wait times.   I would try any of the ramen bowls they have available. They are all delicious and authentic!

Xzfiwi25NcXwqD-kcY3dMQ.text: Amazing!  Great Ramen! Great Prices! Great Service! A little on the small side but very comfortable.  Worth leaving the Strip!

hPBNtIxBAHzYSW0eDdc_0g.text: This place is frequently regarded as the "Best Ramen in Las Vegas", and when all the out of town friends visit, they would suggest a trip to Monta. But after their meal at Monta, not many positive reviews stem from their experience they had. Honestly, if you're going have that reputation as "Best of", people will hold you to a higher standard.  I would say the service here is good: the servers are friendly, the food comes out fast, generally a clean restaurant, and the wait is not too long (30 mins during busy times). The kitchen is open with a bar counter for customers to see their food being made.   Onto the food, and the reason why this is given only three stars. It is unfortunate to say that Monta's food is only standard. You can find this kind of quality ramen at any restaurant that is dedicated to making only ramen. The broth is good, but other ramen places in Vegas can and have achieved the same results. The toppings are what you'll find at other ramen shops: butter, nori, chasiu, canned corn, green onion etc etc.   I will say that i do stop by Monta frequently for a bowl of ramen, however I would not make this a destination restaurant. There are other ramen houses in Las Vegas that are producing at the same level.

PDHp-ahJ6UFLC0v3E07nXA.text: Awesome ramen in Vegas of all places. Had the tonkotsu and it was as good as I expect a tonkotsu to be, but I was still surprised mainly because it was in Vegas.  Definitely worth a visit if you're into proper tasting ramen.

YJKv0Rb_-6-R6g2FLnVPSA.text: I have to give this place 4 stars because it seemed not too far off in taste from my favorite ramen spot, Shoki Ramen in Sacramento.  I got my usual, shoyu ramen without meat, and was not disappointed.  Their noodles were not too cooked, which is just to my liking.  Also, I thought the broth was pretty tasty.  I had no idea, though, how tiny the place is!  We got there just a few minutes after opening, and all the tables were already taken.  We had to sit on bar stools which was a little bit uncomfortable, especially since I was wearing a short dress on the hot day we went.  Business was pretty steady at lunch time - tables/bar stools did not stay empty for very long at all.  And it seemed like everyone ordered their fried rice - maybe I missed out on something?

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen

uTecAqqgnGC1kysf5pXFNw.text: BEST RAMEN! The place is small but it is worth waiting and get seated. The broth is unexplainably delicious! This thus far is the best ramen place I've been to, comparable to the one we went to in Japan.

8HPO1nuiRUlAUxSlnIn2aw.text: Was super pumped to try a ramen place for the first time.   Guess I had different expectations.  The place was quaint and clean and service was fantastic.  Just was expecting more from the food.  It was ok, not spectacular, not bad but just ok.

kxdrR4fyLySTi2MKobp0cg.text: Long line up , but fast to get sitting at the table.    Food comes fast too!    Highly recommended in Vegas.     Very good value!

WlL_ZWTLJy1f4KhV5-S_AQ.text: Still the tastiest and most authentic ramen I've had in Vegas. I stick to tonkotsu usually, but they're all delicious. I wake up craving it!! If you show up to a long line, the wait is worth it.

lDdyaj5hjVazR0zFrD1xhA.text: Came on a Sunday night around 9pm waited about 20 min and there were 5 parties ahead of us on the list, it was a perfect end to a rainy day. We sat at the bar and watched them dish out the glorious bowls of ramen.  There were 2 waitresses and service was pretty fast. The food came out pretty quickly about 5 min.  Kuro ramen 7.95 Tonkatsu ramen 6.95 with egg 1.50 and corn 0.50 Small pork belly over rice 3.95  Asahi beer  Our total bill came out to about $24  The broth got a bit salty towards the end but that didn't stop me from cleaning out the bowl. Definitely get some asahi beer with your ramen!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small pork belly
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro ramen

3Xpv0mUNC9Vj2_u0akToig.text: I love this place! I've been here maybe four times and I've been to the other location in Henderson. I've NEVER been disappointed! Love the miso soup ramen!

p2DxfYzQIbn1aejBVCYrpA.text: Been here few times ... I fell like the quality went down considerably also the portions got smaller Servers are very attentive and the place always has a long line of people trying to get in ... They also have new items ... Spicy this , spicy that :-) I don't mean to sound crazy but the people in the kitchen are not japanese anymore :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sign in :-)

KBAP6d0ZaU3dv-p9X9ByNg.text: Tonkotsu shoyu ramen x2, pork belly bowl and gyozas.  We originally wanted pho to cure our slight hangovers but since we were nearby, we thought we'd give into hype. We came right when lunch started which was perfect timing. We had maybe 3 or 4 parties before us and only waited about 30-45 minutes. Not bad.  The inside of the restaurant is small and intimate. We ordered the above because 1) we were hungry and 2) when would we ever be back anyways? The gyozas were juicy and the pork belly was delish. Reminded me of a beef bowl from Yoshinoya, but 100x better! The ramen was definitely a winner. In my boyfriends words "the best ramen he's ever had." As for me, I don't know about it being the best I've ever had, but it's definitely ranked up high on my list.  If we're ever in the area again and there's not a long wait, we'll be back.

N7MrI3V_bDTO8oj6pjnsMA.text: Google maps will lead you past this tiny restaurant if you're heading West on Spring Mountain Road. The icon will show that you need to pass Hauck street. Don't make that mistake, Monta Ramen is actually in the plaza before that street. Google map takes you to this empty plaza with nothing but a sleazy looking massage parlor. Hmmm....?   This small hole in the wall restaurant interior reminds me of Daikokuya Jtown LA but even smaller! They had an L shaped bar which probably sits 10-12 people max. There were about 5-6 regular tables, some made for two people & some made for four. What happens in a place like this? A number of overflowing people waiting out the door. I recommend you coming early or during non-peaked hours. We got lucky because there was only one party ahead of us when we got in but that quickly changed. By the time we got out, there were at least 10 parties on that waiting list.  First thing I noticed was the array of condiments in front of us. Shredded pink ginger, purified garlic, white pepper, Japanese chili powder, SPICY a$$ hot chili oil, vinegar, soy sauce just to name a few. Love restaurants that aren't all hipster tight up the butt about their condiments.  Had the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen, a mixed blend of pork bone and soy sauce type soup based. The first one I've ever had actually since I'm typically accustomed to just Tonkotsu base. It was a little less rich and thick then the Tonkotsu base but still had that cloudy and strong taste. I added an egg and kimchi for a little more. For you carb lovers, you can add extra noodles for a minimal fee. I was quite satisfied with my ramen. My expectations were met even though they weren't that high since we were in Vegas and we know LA is crawling with bomb ramen houses. The chashu pork was quite fatty and the slices were on a smaller scale. The bowl of ramen itself was enough to make you full but not overly stuffed.  Also ordered the mini mentaiko bowl - cod fish row, seaweed, green onion, over rice. Nothing significant to report. The fried gyozas (pork and vegetable filling) were decent.  The ramen is nothing to die for but it really wasn't too bad. If you have a mad craving for ramen or just want to get something other than pho on Spring Mountain Road aka Chinatown, then Monta Ramen is there for you. Just be ready for a wait time. The ramen met my simple standards and the price was very affordable. The hard working staff are efficient and all "peace sign" fobby smiles.

The place is small so get there when they open (what I did) or be prepared to wait. Table turnover is pretty quick though, and the waitstaff is very attentive and pleasant. What a great find in Vegas. As a bonus, this is located in a strip center with several other seemingly great Asian restaurants! Will definitely be back.

yQoak4nJejiRyqyPVno_vw.text: Saw this restaurant featured on the travel channel. It featured chefs from upscale restaurants and it was this place that they liked to meet up, eat and socialize. It features fresh ramen. Yes, ramen. My dad loves those microwave noodles so I brought my wife and parents here to try it out. I was extremely surprised at how good it was. Everything is fresh and you chose your own ingredients. My family still talks about it. The actual location is tucked away on Spring Mountain Rd. Once you enter there is limited space. Come for lunch and be impressed with the taste.

ATlEFFv4xad9Ax6xY8m-yw.text: 9:20pm on a Sunday and there was still a waiting list! A sign of good food, for sure.   I was pretty impressed with their spicy tonkotsu. lSYCelhTjvbBVt_SsqIFgg.text: Visiting Las Vegas and read good reviews about Monta. It's a tiny place located in a crowded strip mall. Parking may be challenging. Went on a Tuesday evening and had to wait about 35 minutes, but happy we did. The ramen was fresh and I enjoyed the broth. I ordered the garlic and black sesame oil ramen and my boys agreed the regular one (7.95 each). We also tried the pork belly rice (small bowl $3.95). Tasty but too fatty for me. We ordered an extra bowl of noodles for $1.50 and left satisfied and stuffed.

-PYqvmC5RmkhUl-pUIhwyQ.text: Monta was the perfect end to our Vegas trip. We came in on a Sunday a little before 6pm and were seated right away. Shortly after there was a wait list. This is not the place to come with a large group, and there isn't a lot of seating.   We started with the Fried Rice. It comes in a regular or small size and since 3 of us were sharing, we ordered the regular. The portion isn't very big so if you want a lot I suggest ordering 2. It had tons of flavor and even chopped pieces of chashu. We all loved it and it was a nice compliment to our ramen.  My choice was the Miso Ramen. It consists of a pork and chicken broth with miso and medium-thick wavy noodles. I was determined to choose a ramen with those noodles instead of the thin ones, and I am glad I did. The noodles had just the right amount of chew, the chashu was tender, and the broth was packed with flavor. You must add the flavored egg. It was tasty, although it would be nice if they had the option for a poached egg.   A flavorful and unique choice is the Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil. It has tonsssss of roasted black garlic and a taste unlike anything I have tried before. Because of add-ons the total with tip for the 3 of us was $46 which I felt was fair. Next time we are craving ramen in Vegas, this will be our stop.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen with added corn and egg.

4Yn_8sWj0UFKuKxinf6JrA.text: I should preface that I am not a huge rice/noodle fan but I'll try and keep it fair.  This place is very small inside so you may not be able to fit a very large group and the wait times are always pretty long. However the bar section is usually open so you may be able to score those seats pretty quickly.  The menu consist of only a few items like different ramens, different fried rice, and a few little appetizers like gyoza.  I wasn't in the mood for ramen so I got the takana fried rice which was very flavorful and good. However my friend tried the kimchi fried rice and that was even better!   I did try some of my brother's ramen and it was really good as well. There was nothing there I didn't enjoy and according to a speaker on NPR radio it is one of the top ramen joints. I'm sure I'd agree if it was one of my go to foods.  The only thing I hate is that the sodas are served from cans so refills are not free. I'm so particular about my drinks - I'm terrible lol.

yRoBdxWvHPfORflNGUvgeg.text: Wasn't the biggest fan, giving them a 3 because my husband really enjoyed it.   The place is small and cozy, staff is very friendly and welcomes you as soon as you take a step into the door.   I went in with an opened mind, but not what I was expecting.   The soup I got was very milk! I can't remember the name, but it's the first one on their menu! Way to milky and had too many spices, the meat is very gooey, not how I like my meats!   The noodles were delicious!   The price is not bad at all for the amount of Ramen you get, each bowl is no more then $8 bucks.   My review might change after I go back and try their Miso Flavor soup. I'm a huge fan of miso soup, so we'll see!   Try it though, keep an opened mind. I might have just had a weird first time experience!

Aj3f2RLQs-l_NJZQRJL3xw.text: After more than a dozen trips to Las Vegas it took me going off the strip to find this little gem.   Let me start by saying that this is also my first time eating ramen that I did not purchase at a grocery store and wow what a difference.   We arrived before opening and there was already people waiting outside. We got in line and waited. The fully we were able to get a seat.  The place is fairly small and it gets packed quick. It is absolutely worth it because people waited up to 45 minutes to get seated.   I started with the cold ramen and moved on to the Tonkatsu Ramen. It was absolutely amazing. I can't even describe the taste or the experience. You just have to try it for yourself.   This little gem gets my stars and I will definitely be returning next time I am in Vegas.

trdNplz0PiI3z8ekEEn90A.text: Always the best ramen joint to go to in Vegas. Even tho they are always busy, people go in and out quick and satisfied. No one sits there to play on their phones and take up seats when the place is tiny and because of the long lines outside. I love that their service is fast paced. They immediately help you with the menu as you sit down to order which picks up the speed on dining. Water is already served when you wait for your order too. Even though the environment and setting is small, I like how they accommodate seating areas such as having a bar for the single people who come in alone. At the bar you can see the food being cooked in front of you.  Today I ordered Kimchi Fried Rice and Shoyu Tonkatsu with thick noodles. I also included add on topping such as egg, seaweed paper, and extra chashu pork. My bill was $20 even for that. Pay is moderate but worth the filling. I was stuffed.

Vriwg2KnZLtd3GZuiN8kmA.text: I've been going to Monta for a few years now.  It's such a nice place with delicious Ramen~ The staff are always nice and helpful even though the store gets busy almost all the time I'm there.  There is a waitlist since it's a popular place, but also has a small room.  It's worth the wait though. You can always get Boba next door called Kung Fu Tea while you wait or grab some afterwards.  You choose the type of Ramen you want and you can add topping for additional cost. I always add Nori(Dried Seaweed) and Nitamago(One egg split in half. Depending on the type of ramen you want the noodle will either be thick or thin. I enjoy either one in my opinion.
