GlRPYHtbZy6HlVUrjfQOog.text: Omg I hate that I love their ramen! Why? Because I've dragged my family here four times this summer alone and only twice were we able to successfully dine here!  The place is small! It is so frustratingly small and I hope and pray all the time that they are slow. But that prayer has only been answered 50% of the time so far.  I'm reviewing after my fifth time here. The very first time was almost ten years ago with a friend for dinner. I don't recall waiting too long, and all the details like what day etc. what I did recall was the ramen being delicious.  Almost ten years since our dinner here with a friend, we are now married with two more kids and now reside in Vegas...I remembered the ramen...so we called our friend that brought us here to help us remember what the restaurant was called, Monta. Boom! We visited for the first time since in early June this year. We were lucky that day, we waited for 10-15 minutes and, were able to wait inside. Oh yeah, FYI the waiting area consists of the entryway where you definitely feel out of place and in the way. Second and third attempts were both fails. The place would be packed with everyone and their grandma on the Waiting to eat yummy ramen list they have on the podium at the front of the restaurant. Finally! After a failed attempt to eat at ANOTHER busy restaurant, I said hey maybe we'll get lucky on Spring Mountain. I decided to call ahead because I was starving and the woman on the phone said, there was no wait at all! BINGO!  My family and I were minutes away from winning! We pulled up and I jumped out while the husby went to park (that's the strategy guys!) and ran in to the restaurant to secure our seats! There were 3 four seater tables available and I was seated right away. Seconds later, the other 2 tables were taken and by the time my husby joined me, there were already people awkwardly waiting for a table in the entryway! Boooyah!  It was a Friday afternoon around 130pm, I ordered the ramen with black garlic oil etc etc, the kids each had a shoyu ramen, and the man guy husby had a pork belly bowl and ramen, we all shared an order of gyoza. Gyoza is mediocre, but the ramen is delish, from the broth to the noodles, to the crunchy garnishes. I love green onions and love that they give out lots of green onions! I'm originally from HI, so this is the closest place I've found to Goma Tei back in HI.  The place is always dark, probably because it only has one window pane that's blacked out because of the Vegas sun, and it's small as hell, there's bar type seating and tables. Seems clean, but it's too small for me to even really take in and observe. I've never used the restroom here because I can just imagine how small it is. Oh and did I mention this place is freaking small?  Parking is always crazy here too. The "mall" or "plaza" that it's located in consists of mostly eateries similar to theirs, small and yummy, because it's always packed. We also visit the yakiniku place a couple doors down and we are always forever waiting there too.  I love these places because the food is so unique, that's why we keep coming back for more.

VxRgDBblPMew05HGahuiQA.text: For the price and the quality, Monta Ramen is definitely a 5/5! $7 RAMEN IS SO CHEAP.  Their broth is rich, flavorful, and thick, and I like that they have more options than the typical Tonkatsu and Shoyu ramen! I really liked their Kuro broth. Their ramen comes with basic toppings (green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage) and their extras range from $0.50 to $2.50. One bowl of ramen is definitely enough to fill you, but I split a chashu bowl with my boyfriend because everything was so cheap (so why not). It was delicious also!  Would recommend this place!

B_D4c-2jMWxwYVGHxMqS5g.text: This place never disappoints.  Our go to spot when craving ramen in Vegas.  I would put it up there as the best ramenIve ever had in SoCal or Vegas.    Don't hesitate to try this spot when in town.

OQahKLWyZZdg4u6WOrLt2w.text: Small hole in the wall Ramen joint. My family likes the Kim chee fried rice and the pork belly bowl. I'm not a big fan of Ramen but it was overall a good experience. I would recommend this place

lG6PLwX-pbKXlJAzSv2Yrg.text: This place was so all the rave, so I had to stop by when my friend was still living in Vegas and I happened to fly in for a weekend.   We went pretty late on a random night. Perhaps it was late night Thursday or something, but because of its off-strip location and its lengthy hours, there wasn't really much of a wait at all.   We were promptly seated and ordered their tonkatsu ramen. I just want to say this now ... if you're coming here to a specialty pork bone broth ramen joint that specializes in back fat of pork ... and you want a vegetarian ramen and you think it tastes bad ... I don't know what to say.  This isn't a vegetarian ramen spot.   Anyway, I think its decent for what you get but now that Jinya and other ramen joints are here, and LA has so much competition, I don't think its through the roof, but I would definitely come back again and get some extra fatty broth. MMM.

Dr-59sIXi3_8E1lm1xBANg.text: Delicious Food! I have only been to a few ramen places in Las Vegas but this place is the spot.  I had the Veggie Ramen and it was delicious, also the spicy tuna crispy rice was great.  Fast service, very friendly staff, the menu isn't too complicated. If you want a spot that's quick and easy this is it.  It's not too big of a place and the prices are affordable.  It's a cute ramen place, I will be back!

ZuS_UVPEUlXkHn38YQFlYQ.text: Monta is by far one of our favorite noodle spot in Las Vegas. It is a small restaurant but people wait to eat in here!   Simple menu that showcases their famous ramen and appetizers. Our go to ramen is the tonkutsu and garlic ramen. The broth is tasty but a little salty.  As for the fried rice it was a little oilier than what I remembered it to be.   This definitely hit the spot for my ramen craving today! Until the next time, Monta!

rYQTj-UbJUSWSsBBehw1kw.text: I have only been to a few ramen locations in Vegas so far, and I have to say Monta is my second fav ramen place here! Our friends love this place and wanted us to try it with them one night. Three of us all ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen and my husband ordered the chashu bowl.  Spicy Tonkotsu - 4/5: The broth is extremely rich and flavorful, which made for such a pleasant experience. The broth had such a good spice to it where I can feel it but it wasn't overbearing. I can still enjoy the flavor of the broth. The noodles were nice and chewy as well. I would definitely order this again.  Chashu Bowl - 3/5: Although absolutely great for the price, the quality of the meat and the overall taste weren't the greatest. The meat tasted like it didn't have enough sauce, and I felt like it needed it because the meat itself was dry. We wouldn't order this again.   Overall, this is a fantastic place for your ramen fix because it's delicious AND you can't beat the prices! Come check it out for yourself :)

Wb_1zeJdvSTc7JAAgtePCw.text: Very small location! They have table service and a quick service bar. The menu is small. We had ramen, fried rice and potstickers. It was very busy, but a nice atmosphere. I don't think I would bring a large party in because it feels a bit claustrophobic, but definitely worth trying them out.   They are allergy accommodating, which was great for my girlfriend because finding a ramen house without cross contamination with nuts or seafood. Very cost effective for a party of 3 and a great treat even in the 106 degree summer!

SpHmNgeBOHnvwbssRmL01w.text: Came here because I saw somewhere on tv it was one of the best ramens in vegas, obviously had to try it for myself! It did not disappoint. I got the spicy ramen. The soup was flavorful and so creamy. The spice could have been kicked up a couple notches but I understand the need to accommodate the average eater.  I also ordered the kimchi fried rice which was made quickly and it was good. Nothing too special about it, could have done with more protein in it, but it was a good contrast to the soup.   Service was friendly and quick. You come in and sign in, they will seat you asap if its full. We got there on a hot day so we only waited a couple minutes to be seated. There was bar seating as well as table seating. Plenty of parking as there was a full lot of spaces.  Will definitely be back to try the other ramens when I visit Las Vegas again. Happy Eating.

NmEuWMqzShR2pYpX0tRvaA.text: This is a nice place to get a decent bowl of ramen noodles.  This is a small restaurant so when visiting during peak hours expect a wait.  Luckily when I went it was just before the dinner rush so I was able to be seated right away.  The ramen is good and the service friendly and efficient.  It's just your typical ramen place nothing special.  I probably won't be back as there are just too many other places to try and this doesn't stand out.    2019 - 18/50

jQw-gj6CXIsmwx0cesRiFg.text: The fried rice was very good! We ordered an additional 2 portions for to-go.  The ramen broth was way too salty for me. I drank a lot of water trying to finish my bowl!  I asked for lemon or lime which they said they didn't have any. Weird! I'm sure there are better places for ramen

qNomn5wvoNgOdTctfGZ5kg.text: A lot of people have recommended this place to me.   First off, the environment is great, you get that  home feeling when you walk-in. Although, it's plain and simple, you're here for the food. It's a small location, so be prepare to wait. Best to go with less than 6-7 in your party. While sitting there eating at the bar area, I notice it was quite warm. They only had fans going, no A/C. Not sure, if their A/C was broken or what, so wear appropriate attire. Also, no outside food/drinks but they did put my Kung Fu tea drink in the fridge to give back to me after the meal, nice touch on their part.   Secondly, the customer service was good. The servers were attentive and provided a friendly smile to the place.   Lastly, the ramen proves to the best in Vegas or in Nevada in general. I had the Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen with the following add-ons, corn and nitamago (flavorful egg). In addition, I order a mini bowl of Spicy Mentaiko.   Speaking of the Spicy Mentaiko, which cost only $3, it's quite yummy. At first glance, you think simple, not many components. There's the bed of rice with cut green onions, sprinkled sesame seeds and shredded seaweed with the spicy fish eggs placed perfectly on top. Take one bite with all of the above and you get mixture of flavors that makes you come back and finish the bowl faster than reading this review.   Now, the main entree. The Spicy Tonkotsu was one of the best I've had. Not spicy by any means, if you can handle sriracha, you got this. The noodles were grade A ramen noodles, the broth was rich and flavorful, the corn was corn, the egg was so good but the pork chatsu is amazing. Literally, melts in your mouth.   In short, what are you waiting for???

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mini Mentaiko

z2OUkAf8gBLeZP6kLqXvow.text: Came to visit the girlfriend in Las Vegas and she recommended this ramen-ya called Monta. It's near one of my favorite sushi omakase joints in Vegas (Kabuto) so I was somewhat familiar with seeing it from previous trips.  They specialize in tonkotsu ramen. Several varieties like tonkotsu with black garlic oil, shoyu tonkotsu and spicy tonkotsu. They also have plain shoyu ramen for those not into tonkotsu. They also have several side dishes including some gyoza, fried rice options, and other pork belly items like char Siu bowls.  I'll tell you what, it's not Japan or Hawai'i but it wasn't bad considering it was Vegas. The prices here for a bowl of ramen reflect the prices in Japan versus how expensive Ramen is in Hawaii. Go with the shoyu tonkotsu, gyoza and Kimchi fried rice. Have a beer too while you're at it. You'll leave satisfied and happy.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice

ysfOYNzIwm8ncTl-3GfDjw.text: In my opinion, the best ramen in Las Vegas.  Monta has been my go-to ramen shop for years. So much so, that I had to force myself to try the competition just to see what they were up to. Yes, there are definitely other great ramen shop(s) in Las Vegas, but Monta consistently delivers an amazing product across their menu.  You have to start out with an order of Gyoza. Don't even think about skipping it!  Sometimes pork broth is a little too greasy for me, so I usually opt for the Shoyu Ramen. I always like to add egg, corn, and butter to round out the flavor.  If your not into ramen, or would like to switch it up, both the Chashu and Pork Belly Bowls are super flavorful and satisfying.  Wash it all down with an Asahi draft and you'll be enjoying some of the most authentic ramen experience outside of Japan.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UbbHYagwuc_5VO9O7l_ibA.text: Seriously, I don't know why any one spends money on eating on the strip especially, when places like this exists so close to it. Go to Vegas, grab and Uber and grab some Ramen!!!! This was great ramen and for about a fraction of the cost of anything on the strip. Plus I can guarantee that nothing on the strip taste this good. You should expect a line as this is not a large place. But you might get lucky and get a seat at the bar where you can watch your bowl of deliciousness come together. This place has awesome service and I really can't recommend it enough.

aRKcxbKj-2s4DzdeMvgAbA.text: This is definitely my go-to ramen place in Chinatown. You can almost always expect for a wait when coming here. I would recommend coming here on mid-afternoons or early evenings if you cannot wait.   So the faves are their spicy tonkatsu ramen and pork belly bowl. To be honest, I have not been here for months so I'm not quite certain if they actually changed the noodles as I thought it was way better before.   Prices are surprisingly on the cheaper side. A meal for 2 would probably costs around $20 only. I really don't mind paying extra as long as they don't sacrifice their standards.  Be warned though that parking can be a hassle as it is very limited compared to the number of restaurants in the area.   Overall, I would say this is my favorite ramen place in town!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

S8f3sMn4xiN3T1QR8_B-Sw.text: This place is small. It can get crowded and parking can be a challenge but the service and quality of the ramen and pork is outstanding especially considering the price  I would definitely  recommend this place on your next trip to Vegas

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ruko garlic ramen

YC52oCuqLRcTo_uVbdHKDg.text: This is the very first time trying Japanese Ramen, I had always wanted to but never knew where to go. A coworker of mine told me all about ramen and spiked my interest, I had to try it ASAP. I asked my friend to tag along with me and my wife and I'm very please we chose Monta Japanese Noodles House for our first time.  We arrived early and already there was a line, we started to get excited because that to me tells me this place is going to be delicious. And it was.  This place is very small makes getting in and out of the booths hard. And also means your seating super close to other people, which no one seems to mind.  As for the ramen , it come in a large bowl. It's very flavorful I added egg and my wife got it spicy. The portions are big but just Incase it's not enough you get an option to order more noodles. I couldn't even finish mines. Definitely recommend this place and look forward to returning

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

W12l5GTNZJjcw5FwE21zZg.text: Very solid restaurant. I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen. The spice warms up as you eat it, which was very pleasant. The pork was very tender, almost melting in your mouth. Great taste overall!   The service was also friendly and timely. They were very accommodating of my large group of 10 people, and the food came out pretty quickly.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen

tAgzmptuPcW9-LFxNS7Qew.text: Best ramen I've ever had hands down. And incredibly cheap. They are traditional ramens and not incredibly fancy but they're doing the staples that make ramen, ramen, justice. We were so glad to come here before leaving vegas. Absolutely worth leaving the strip for this authentic food!

KTLD-tknny0nItSV3yoXXg.text: I came here after intending to go to Big Wong, but after looking inside at an empty dining room, I decided to come here.  I was not disappointed.  You can't beat the ramen here for the bargain.  It's only $7 for a decent sized bowl!    Do I think it's really awesome ramen?  No.  It's definitely a 4/5 on the ramen -- the broth is a little lighter (maybe, watered down?) than I'd like. However, the price really makes up for it at $7 for a bowl.  To add on extra noodles, it's only $1.50.  You will be very, very full and satisfied with extra noodles.  I like that they have minced garlic, pickled ginger, sesame seeds, and chili flakes at the table.  There's even chili oil.  Pro tip: Make sure you add the minced garlic and chili flakes.  When you get extra noodles, put some of the chili oil and more minced garlic to up the flavor on your "second bowl"

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MucKYJjES8IgCOKll3tXjw.text: This place serves the best ramen compared to all the places I've been to! I ordered the Spicy Tonkotsu ramen, the broth is rich and flavorful and for the price you just can't beat! I've been to other ramen places that have comparable ramen but paid twice has much.  Word of advice, the place opens at 11:30am I would get there EARLY, maybe even before they open cause the place is small (about 6 tables with about 8 bar seating). We got there right at 11:30am and got the last bar seating, the line waiting to be seated went out the door. If you have a big party (4+) this might not be a place to go to for you.   Would definitely recommend stopping by if you're ever near the strip.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The spicy tonkotsu with flavored egg, corn, and extra char-sui

zCWCiJIcZxf5xtrEJQOqrA.text: During a recent trip to Vegas, I was surprised to discover that there are many options for ramen near the Strip. Unfortunately, after trying Monta, the most reviewed and the highest rated ramen spot in Vegas, I remain skeptical of the possibility of ramen excellence out here.  I tried the tonkotsu ramen, one of the six preparations available on the menu. I'm not a ramen expert. But I know from countless bowls in my lifetime that tonkotsu broth is usually creamy, salty, meaty, and fatty. The tonkotsu broth here is noticeably watered down and not particularly flavorful. If this is what they mean by "kurume style", I'm not a big fan.  The noodles were very thin. They smelled and tasted overly starchy like store bought noodles. The two small pieces of chashu were very thin too. I would say it was on the order of bacon thickness. I know that ramen is an assembled dish, but I wished that the chashu and the nitamago that I added were served at or near the temperature of the ramen broth. I found the cold temperatures off-putting.  While it's hard to argue against the extremely affordable prices you'll find here, the tonkotsu ramen at Monta was mediocre.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

feVOYr-H5VAYhez7ixDkMQ.text: A small establishment and it was crowded even for weekday lunch! Stopped in for 3 people and we waited for 5 minutes (we got lucky that a table had just left).  Two of us got ramen and one of us got the takana fried rice. I got the tonkotsu ramen and added extra chasu (pork) and soft boiled egg. The broth was pretty good - not too salty but filled with flavor. I really didn't need the extra chasu. I was so full (I had a snack before I came). The portions was definitely worth it for the price!! Without any additions, any bowl of ramen is less than $8 - insane value meal. My friends also liked their meals!   The service was quick - great place if you wanted to come by for a quick lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MvDdI-3hP6WAp2QEO3DbGg.text: Finally got to try this place!!!  Ive been wanting to try the ramen here for quite some time. Perfect hangover cure while in Vegas.  I got the spicy miso ramen. I broth was very rich and flavorful. Portions are very good. I loved it. All of my friends loved it as well. The egg is cooked to perfection and the pork was perfect. One of the top ramen places for sure  I will be back the next time I'm in Vegas. Place is very packed so expect to wait, but service is fast and efficient.

FfJsamE5tSD2mUdfy4Pazg.text: My ramen obsession that seems to never end.   I stumbled upon the best ramen place in Las Vegas called Monta Ramen. No, not really, I really yelped it. It was as if the ramen gods heard my cravings and made it rain (it's summer) to set the mood. It also cut the line short as people started leaving due to the heavy rain and well... long wait. We, obviously took advantage. T'was meant to be. I ordered miso ramen and added extra chashu pork, flavored egg & shredded green onions for that extra crisp. Mister ordered tonkotsu shoyu ramen with flavored egg. Thank goodness he did because I was very much torn and even thought about getting both for myself. Mine was hands down better than his. I'm sure he thought the same because he had my bowl for a good 10 minutes. On top of all that goodness, we ordered a pork belly bowl & we each had 2 glasses of Asahi beer. Best meal ever!  The only thing is, this place is quite small.

RLyPX751ouasob6DCgvv3A.text: I'm not a fan of ramen but this spot totally gets me craving for more! Whenever I am in vegas I usually go to this spot, it is small, crowded, and very busy though. Especially if you are going with a big party, the siting time takes long and usually ends up splitting the group per table which is understandable. I usually order the spicy tonkatsu ramen with eggs and extra onions. The broth is very thick and has a lot of flavor to it. The portion is okay, not too much and not too little. On the other hand, the portion for the Kim chi fried rice is very little. Another than that, this place is great! A must try for you ramen lovers.

7apBjrr6gCeKTI87nlfHzw.text: Why does everyone like this place?  I see everyone's check-ins on FB and ppl rave about this place.  But, seriously. 2 stars --- I've had better!  I think it didn't help that I was expecting a place to blow me away the way Honolulu's Goma Tei noodles blow me away.   To me the broth was too salty. I barely like soy sauce, I can't enjoy salty broth.  Meh.

-BOF8gWJS5SCwQm_SjF00A.text: We came here from Yelp's reviews on a cold, hungry night. The restaurant is pretty small. The wait wasn't too bad. The ramen itself was mediocre. They have thin and thick noodles. The thick noodles were almost exactly like what you would find in any ramen packet from the store. The thin noodles didn't work too well with the ramen broth. The broth was ok. I expected better noodles from a ramen shop with great reviews. Services was great though.

HhxpRjPuohbYeBtpxdaFWQ.text: Been to the restaurant area a few times but turned off by the wait. Well, the food must be good for people to get in lines, right? So I have my patience then finally put down my name once on the wait list. I was placed to the bar area pretty quickly. The ramen was below average. I don't see or taste anything special. Very lame, forgettable, salty ramen soup. Service was OK and even though it is not expensive, it's never worth the wait or the money.

508IRX00yiHc4tiS0-3-pQ.text: love this plaza! in this plaza there's foot massage, japanese curry, fluffy snow ice AND ramen!! it's basically your one stop shop to heaven! the ramen here is super flavorful and you can ask for thick or thin noodles. I also love the soft boiled egg. yummy. the fried rice and gyoza is good too!   Go during off meal times to avoid waits!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice side order

zOcLwVejoiIiyqYusVlETA.text: First time here with my family for my bday and it was the perfect choice! Fast service, not expensive and the food was delicious. Will definitely be coming back for date night and with my out of town family and friends

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice... Perfect!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen, delicious!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl, small. So creamy

jReqxU-j8xllE6mvK4OFtw.text: First night in town and we headed straight over to Monta House.  Of course, it was packed; we were already prepared for that and waited the 45 minutes to be seated.  This is a small joint that seats no more than 30 at a time I would estimate - I didn't sweep the room and take a head count, so that's my ballpark estimate.  It's probably the good-sized living room w/their kitchen incl'd for the whole place.  Their menu and selection is straightforward and simple:  3 types of noodle broth and you pick and add the extras you want in there.  Each of the 3 soups come with green onions, two slices of cha siu, bamboo shoots and kikurage.  You pay anywhere from 50 cents to two bucks for addt'l toppings.  They also have gyoza and varieties of fried rice & pork belly bowl - yummm!  I ordered the Tonkatsu-Shoyu Ramen with extra helpings of Cha Siu and Nori.  First sip of the broth and ohhh was I in my happy place!  The combination of the tonkatsu pork bone / fat with the Shoyu soy sauce made for a flavorful rich, creamy and salty soup.  I was quite happy that I ordered extra servings of the cha siu.  Let me tell you that was one of the best slices of pork I've ever had.  They simply just melted in my mouth and the taste with the broth made it simply superb for the entire experience.  Definite must return the next time we're back and I'd give my recommendation to anyone as well.  Expect the long wait and you'll also have to put up with some cramped seating arrangements and limited elbow room - you're not going to get anything more than 5 persons to a table.  Aside from that, not to forget at the verly least, service was very good and friendly.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu-Shoyo ramen w/xtra cha siu &amp; seaweed

Ns7bMcBUCFRSPxDeOCDT7g.text: Wow. Who knew a place like this existed in Sin CIty?!?!  I got the Shoyu and hubs got the pork ramen. They were both delicious. The pork broth was so thick and creamy.   Being the super Korean I am, i found myself wanting kimchi with my ramen.  If you drive to Vegas this is an awesome spot to cure your hangovers.

FdOB2swEyTaEjXqzLXQJ5g.text: I really loved this place. I had the miso ramen which was some of the best I've ever had! Place is small and cozy and the staff were very friendly. Definitely my new favorite spot!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen

fv8Oa37RZsOepzdJZabD4A.text: The ramen is good, but the selection is not. They only have fatty pork... Im a beef eater.

HXXhHMMoowO79bXFVddi9A.text: I love this place so much! It is pretty cheap for great tasting ramen. Customer service is great and food doesn't take long to prepare. One down side is that it is really small and it tends to get busy super fast but I don't mind. :)

e9964aQhvarnX9LW_JZc0Q.text: My favorite noodle place in Vegas so far.  I had the Miso Ramen. Make sure you ask for butter and corn in your order. I tried the egg in it and was not a fan. If you ask for green onion be prepared for a lot of green onion.  This is not a big place. We did not wait but it was mid afternoon on a Sunday. Most of the time there is a line.

VXfaXfol3EqOhcSfwwWtkQ.text: I was here to meet my friend and glad she did. This small place is known for their delicious ramen and for bargain. The ramen was so flavorful as well as the broth. My favorite part of the dish was the pork belly and egg.  We also ordered gyozas which I can't remember how it was like so it proves it wasn't anything special.

WBLkQcYYETsN6h-gNa54Cw.text: The ramen is good. Thin, thick, spicy, or not - all good. Very limited seating. Probably only good for party of 4 or fewer. Service is decent.

yZ9Zei-xg4RSJYkM8tdM2A.text: Its good for young people but its not good for the family. Waiting thirty five minutes outside and still not getting seat. It's very unorganized when they called the guests. They called whatever they like. People stands and comes inside also they don't have highchairs for your little one..Resto it's very small. It's like Motel 6 Hotel with tiny rooms and dirty. Pro: only tonkatsu delicious Cons: Waiting an hour to be from you write down your name until to have a food.            Serve very very slow...They make it very slow so looks like a lot of people a line but actually it's not like that if they serve fast. Their strategy made it this way. Won't comeback again. VERY DISAPPOINTING SERVICE!!!..

tfzPVMXSr237ARTFvfCJlA.text: This is seriously one of the best Ramen establishments I've been to and I've been to all the snooty LA ones :P I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and a small pork belly bowl. Both were amazing. The service was top notch too. Great place ! I definetly plan on making a visit every time I'm in the area.

OcAHJMpOq4oaJx2JU5tHLQ.text: Mentaiku bowl is a hell yes.  I'm not a huge fan of green onions, so I always ask for a light amount (which is still an awful lot).  Those gyoza's are also pretty tasty as well.  Did I mention that they are also hand-made in the restaurant?  I watched them make it on one of my previous visits where I forgot to check in.  Ramen wise, you can't go wrong.  Their tonkatsu shoryu ramen is my fave though :9

MVsuHfg3myJUwjlVRhPHcA.text: Chasu was good and the soup base had a bold flavor! A reasonable portion for the price.

GJy9fsqrEZyoEileiO6MhQ.text: Can't say enough good things about this place... I actually joined yelp  just to write a review.   I travel very frequently & always try to seek out the best Ramen / noodle houses in the cities I visit often as I'm a noodle junkie. I don't know why it took me so long to find Monta, though I'm really happy I did as I'm in Vegas every other week.   Firstly, the greeting and staff are extremely friendly - which really surprised me in a positive way considering Monta is located in Chinese town (an area I typically expect to be underwhelmed by service). Very attentive and happy - I left in such a better mood than I arrived!  I sat at the comfortable wooden bar & ordered the Miso Ramen with extra chashu. It was nice to watch the 2 cooks prepare the bowls ordered before mine as it was immediately clear that they were dedicated to the quality of preparation, ingredients and timing to ensure their guests received a perfect serving. In between orders I watched one cook prep and truss the pork for slow roasting & was impressed with the skill.  My bowl arrived as a perfect portion & nicely presented. I only added a dash or two of the toasted sesame seeds & a dash of the chili powder that were part of a good array of seasonings available to personalize the noodles to your taste. I like that.  The broth was truly wonderful: rich and creamy while carrying a fresh pork flavor. Noodles were nicely cooked, although a little thinner than I find my favorite to be (Santouka still purveys the finest noodle I have come across). The definite star of the bowl were the delicate and chashu slices that pinch perfectly into the grip of the chopsticks! The flavor, texture, and quality of this moist pork is truly superb.  Suffice to say that Monta has immediately become a favorite here in Vegas; a city where the experience usually fails to measure up to the hype.  Enjoy.

meI2CdLtdpTQ9fkLnNZbJQ.text: My first experience at Monta wasn't very good despite all the gleaming reviews I've read. The tonkatsu ramen tasted slightly gamy and was way too salty. I gave them another shot and it was a lot better. Gone was the gamy flavor of the broth. It was good but not amazing, in my opinion. Not the kind of broth you want to drink up. The chashu pork had a slightly smoky flavor and was OK. The nice wait staff and the cheap ramen help me see the attraction to this place. However, compared to other ramen places, I don't believe Monta's ramen stands out in presentation and flavor.

5FnyRTVu9SRcjenjTMeI2w.text: Okay, I can't stop coming back to this place.  I've tried to duplicate the broth at home and just can't!!!! They know me by face now... I come here with the hubby once a week.  It's just the best darn ramen ever!   The chashu is immoderate but I come here for the broth and the ramen.  The food is so simple yet so complex.  It's perfect!  I do wish they have agedashi tofu on the menu.  Monta read my review- add agedashi tofu to your menu, just use the shoyu broth.  It'll match well.  -M2

PMFxN_QExPLgfss7jCMSow.text: Always delicious. Usually a wait, but worth it. Ramen and a small order of Pork belly rice.always delicious ... We always take visitors here and they always love the ramen.

2W82CrE4Guq2NurQ-aP0jQ.text: Wow that was some good tonkatsu if u ask me, the pork was so tender. Probably the best noodles and soup i have ever tasted.  The service was great and the people were so helpful.  Will try and visit this place whenever i"m in Vegas.....

UdpjiUzO_20mPLxBbO664w.text: Pork Belly bowl will warm your belly. Ramen GOOD!

NIbw77J5EQUzzGAZPT6XHQ.text: Fast service and delicious ramen. I couldn't really ask for more. I got mine with the nitamago (egg), and the egg was so good I want to accelerate my next trip to Vegas just so I can get back here.

kKHtdMteI4qKzCY4jkdZlw.text: We stepped out of our comfort zone....  it was a very busy, hole in the wall restaurant.  Great food, great service!

h2PfPyhe_npl1NoTcRxNmQ.text: I took the advice of my fellow Yelpers and tried this place out.  I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen and I enjoyed the soup and the Char Siu pork in it but there was something missing when it came to the flavor of the Ramen.  The noodles had a pleasant texture but it got lost in the other flavors.  I'm used to having a Ramen that still reminded you it was still the reason you were eating Ramen in the first place, not a strong flavor but something.  Anyway, If I'm in the mood for Ramen, I'd still go here.  Haven't found any other Ramen places to try.

FnuZq6ZKEf8tWykbNycOuw.text: This is still my most favorite Japanese noodle house.  My only question is why don't they open up more of these -- perhaps one near Henderson where I work?

XUtiugSjzOnnFfRz1toFIA.text: Short menu. Great food. I will be back. If you are looking for a Ramen house that feels like you could have just walked in from a street in Dotonbori, Osaka, this is it.

8TTTrs9BPA5PQVQG_TM4pQ.text: This is the spot for Ramen. My family and I travel from the NW part of Vegas near Summerlin when we want our fix. We always order the tonkatsu shoyu with thin noodles and it is never a disappointment. The place is super small which sucks for a large size party or one with little ones (our case). That means you have no choice but to wait for one of the 4 tables to clear and you find yourself awkwardly staring at the people to see who will be done soon. This is not a place to sit and chat. Just eat and go. It gets packed ALL the time. We had to put a system in place where we drive up, someone hops out the car, puts the name on the list, THEN we look for parking, and sit in the car to wait LOL. We tried a Ramen place up the street and it just did not compare with Monta. It was more spacious with less of a wait time but that didn't make up for the Ramen. We'd rather wait and let claustrophobia kick in at Monta because it is so worth it :)

VYOpirNpXwr0zSLDrRsRhw.text: Shoyu RAmen  [ bomb ]   And especially pork bowl, I would forget the rAmen and just eAt the pork bowl instead [ bomb ] [ bomb ] [ bomb ] [ bomb ] . Why would you have a better dish then what you would normally serve? But it is the best in town [ bomb ]

VxhHf81RTpAo3-86Pzobtw.text: This place changed my idea of Ramen noodles. One word. Bangin!, the runny yolk egg in the soup is the shit.

02HYl58dxYQORxc9mtXweQ.text: the inside is very small, so if you have a big group i would think twice about coming during lunch/dinner hours, the ramen I had was really good & the service is really quick.

41QKEbZuCmvU0To6taG_5w.text: Fabulous noodles!!! The pork broth was sublime and the gyoza excellent. It's a small hole in the wall, but clean and pleasant.  As is usual for this town, it was located in a strip mall, which does diminish some of the charm.

zmoEQvy7biKykSwvRVy0eQ.text: Love the Ramen and Pork Belly at Monta. Great little place but don't be surprised if you have to wait to get a table. Yes its that good.

gSKikwOvbnNXsQ0KrxKniA.text: I have only had ramen at a few places but this is the best I have had.  I get the miso ramen and it is such a smooth yummy broth.  I love how you can choose what toppings you want on it and i love the condiments as well.  This place is not very big so if you go during a busy time you may have to wait a little bit but if ramen is what you want, i think its the best place in vegas.

MCqya4n2HDDeWYO6rans6Q.text: Went to monta noodle ... try it ...i think its decent but not supper impressing me ... lil cheap on meat aye ,,,, the broth is ok ... a touch more salt than it needed ... lack a lil nature sweetness ( maybe more bone and vegie to bring out sweetness) ... overall i would give it a 6 out of 10 ...

PO3X5mgdGg2KUcvl7R4dvw.text: If Naruto was a real person...then this place would be his number one stop in Vegas!

Y8oFxTsFenfwev8hV4lnkg.text: If you like Ramen, this is the place.  There's a few other ramen joints throughout the valley, but this has got to be one of my favorite spots.  Shoyu ramen for $6.95 with ability to customize it with a handful of toppings is a good deal to me =)  Pros:  *  All kinds of toppings to build your own ramen  *  Friendly service  *  Awesome Ramen... I can't explain this ,but the broth is a bowl of salty goodness.  Cons:  *  A bit on the crowded side.  It's a small place packed with tables and seating.  *  It's a hit or miss with the wait for this place... it's always busy so be prepared.  * Parking sucks...period!  Overall:   One of my favs in Vegas.  I'm giving it a four stars in comparison to other Ramen places I've been (not necessarily in Vegas).    Tips: *  A good place to come with a group of friends.. Very casual atmosphere *  Be eco-friendly and save yourself the hassle by trying to carpool if possible.

lXMMHGSOWdhZyuVtIGSrBQ.text: Been here a couple of times and it's so good.  I haven't tried the Miso Ramen yet so can't say much about that.  I've tried the Shoyu Ramen and Tonkatsu Ramen and both are AMAZING!!!  They give you a good amount of soup, not too little and not too much.  What makes it even better are the prices, they range from $6.95-$7.95...definitely affordable.  This place is small and only has a maximum occupancy of 26 but the wait is not long at all.  We came here on a busy night and only waited about 5 minutes.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

jelxScqsHpfoP5PxFQ39jw.text: Very delicious ramen and friendly service too!  Good value. Small location but they move people in and out quickly.  We had 6 in our party but they accommodated us. Had the miso ramen with egg along with the gyoza.  They fry the gyoza a bit so it is nice and crunchy.  Also tried the mini mentiko - very simple, but delicious with some green onion and seaweed garnishes.  Highly recommend this place!

6Ftrx0HqPOYTcgChnYq75w.text: We ordered the spicy tonkatsu, black garlic ramen and pork belly bowl. We came on a Friday around noon and there was only one group ahead of us. After ordering, we got our food in less than 5 mins! The thick noodles we're still a bit thin for my preference. The broth was thick and very flavorful. I really enjoyed the first half of the bowl but by the second half, it started to get so salty. The chashu was also a bit fatty.

1vaKl-Rs-29BjQhWPipsjQ.text: I eat low carb, so I don't eat noodles, but I crave ramen broth with all the meat and vegetables.    Service is no nonsense...they want to turn their tables over ASAP since it is small but popular place...even on a Monday around 6 PM it was fairly pack and by the time we were leaving there were 3 or 4 groups of diners waiting.  However, still, I guess they were nice.  When I asked for a soup without noodles, I confused the waitress and she brought me a bowl of just plain tonkatsu broth...no meat, no vegetables.  I was a little confused and thought is was additional broth for my husband's ramen. I ask the other waitress and in a few minutes she brought me the correct order, but mentioned what seemed obvious to me that it would be the same price with or without noodles.   The tonkatsu broth was rich in texture and deep with flavor and shows quality, time, and care in preparation. I loved it.  However, in comparison to Sora, I like Sora's broth just slightly better maybe because it was just a touch lighter in texture and flavor. Monta's didn't put nearly the amount of pork that Sora does. I do sample the noodles and I prefer Sora's noodles; they are sort of springy and light, Monta's were a little heavier.   My husband who eats ramen the normal way, also prefers Sora.  I guess, I like Sora's style of ramen soup better, but it is purely just a preference, and both are very good.

LxV-qmaYwD6-yUuY80tWkA.text: best ramen I've ever had. Not too fatty or salty, just perfect

oEPh8fraYQ4EOpQCIxgNxA.text: Simple menu. Amazing food. Chill atmosphere. There's normally a 10-20 minute wait but it is worth it!

MqEcuHukOszQ5buZ94kkEw.text: I have only been here once but overall I have to say it's okay. It's not bad, but it's not great either.  It is terribly cramped and when I went there I had to sit at the bar with my party so it was difficult talking to them when you're facing the kitchen rather than their faces.  The food was good. Tasty and simple. Great price too. It's a nice eat, but when I think of getting Ramen for dinner, Monta isn't the first restaurant that comes to mind.

aPavxueFdKCkADbzOmdY9w.text: We love ramen and this is our favorite ramen place in Vegas so far. The place is a little hole in the wall and it's always packed. We've never gone here without having to wait in line but the wait is not that bad and always worth it. The ramen is rich and hearty. We've tried to recreate it a few times at home but we never even come close. The price point is awesome, unbelievably low even for Chinatown.

pnn4rJKbMMgZFpgDNw62tg.text: Best ramen in Las Vegas!! very close to authentic ramen - Very cheap - Long line, but its worth the wait

4xZMdouAX5sMTCoRUlMxgA.text: I always have good dining experience here when I stop by. I am always prepared to wait a bit because the place is small, but I usually get lucky to snatch a bar seat. A and I are creatures of habit; so far we've ordered their pork belly bowl and tonkatsu ramen with all the trimmings. The pork belly bowl is delicious, perfect amount of meat for the rice, yet sometimes I find it a little bit on the greasy side. The tonkatsu ramen is good too. Fresh thin noodles with tasty broth. I think it's one of the best ramen houses in LV, but I've had better ramen when I used to live in the Bay area. I am still fan though, because the servers are quick and efficient. The prices are more than fair too so what's not to love?

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu shoyu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly regular size bowl

gCgQ3WfG8kBgZsEIWcN0eA.text: This is my favorite place to eat, with a cheap price you'll enjoy best ramen in town.

SfGphGoAG-pVNj4hYpNFAA.text: Love this place! Good food, no complaints. The noodle dishes are great and so are the rice dishes! So good :)

pKo0iMTrdF0amVC9OkdBDg.text: Will never come here again. Waitresses were rude, water was super dirty. They're cheap and cut corners. And wouldn't take a debit card for less than 10$. And told us after we ate because they didn't want to pay the fee to charge our card. Gross place go elsewhere.

ZQUGzl16uP9UIjJOGC-Qzg.text: Forget Pho - Ramen is Chinatown's best hangover cure (particularly perfect for the day after an Elite Event). This is a place that really does live up to the hype.   My coworker tried the gyoza and a pork belly bowl and was very pleased with both. I stuck with the tonkatsu ramen ($6.95) with extra pork added ($2.50). The broth was silky, creamy, and perfect! Pho broth seems so blah after eating this. The 6 slices of pork in my bowl were just fatty enough and so delicious!   A pleasant surprise was canned, cold oolong tea for $1.75. It was delicious and really hit the spot. When you're eating soup in 105 degree weather, a cold drink seems more appropriate than hot tea.   Service was friendly and accomodating and the broth can't be beat ! I'll be back - but next time I'll be going noodle-less. The noodles are a waste of space ! More yummy broth and meat please.

6UhrQfPHC86NMIOJf7AS-g.text: This is what I call GOOD RAMEN. This place is quaint and cute nestled away in a little shopping center off of Spring Mountain. It is SMALL so there may be a wait around peak times. That's probably the only downside. But it's definitely worth it.  They had four ramen to choose from: tonkatsu (pork bone), shoyu, miso, or tonkatsu-shoyu. All of which come with the basics: chashu (pork slices), bamboo shoots, green onions, and kikurage mushrooms. You have the option to add "extras" to personalize your ramen.  I had the tonkatsu-shoyu ramen with a boiled egg (as an extra). In retrospect, I should have ordered extra chashu -- which I recommend you do if you like pork. The meat was so tender and melt-in-your-mouth that the two slices the bowl comes with wasn't nearly enough! The broth was very tasty and not too salty like how some ramen can be.  They have other side dishes (gyoza, fried rice, etc) but I have a feeling those aren't the reason people come here. They're simply there as fillers. Stick to the star of the place: ramen of course!  This is definitely the place I will come to to satisfy my ramen cravings that I get once in a while. I have a feeling as soon as winter hits, I will definitely be frequenting this place for the warm deliciousness that is Monta Ramen :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen w/ extra chashu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu - shoyu ramen

7dWtqV2c1YSkdkuOPJILIw.text: Pork bowl was delicious. Their ramen is decent. It's worth what I paid for. Service is nice.

ZfAmgiyRd-iyp2_FdlTcQw.text: I am no connoisseur on Japanese food or ramen, but this place really has me addicted lately.  I found it while browsing reviews on Yelp, and Yelp was right on target!    The place is quite small, seating maybe 30 people, including the bar.  During lunch, there is a wait to get seated.  The cooks are out in the open, similar to the sushi bar trend.  I've always had good service, although sometimes there is a little bit of a communication problem... my English isn't so good sometimes! ;-)  But that's never annoyed me because I love the soups here.  So far I have only tried the Tonkatsu. I ordered with extra pork, egg, and (I know, shame on me), butter.  you can also order extra noodles if you aren't a big broth eater.  The Tonkatsu is, I believe, a pork based broth.  Its thick (for a broth), a little salty (but not too salty), and very flavorful.  The pork was cut very thinly, and was so juicy, almost buttery.  I barely had to chew it.  Now, I am no expert in homemade noodles or anything, but the noodles for me were quite good... filling and tasty.    I can't wait to try the other two main ramen dishes they have.  I know now isn't the perfect time for hot ramen, but I'll make an exception to that rule for this place any time!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu

OyvCv9eMcO6005DaRKTU8Q.text: Ode to Monta's Pork Belly Bowl  cue violin  Hey, I just ate you, and this is crazy... but here's my hunger , so feed me maybe?   All of the ramen bowls, try to tempt me, but here's my chopsticks, so feed me maybe?    Yeah this will probably be out of date by the time I hit submit review, but I'll deal with it.   I've been to Monta several times since it opened, and the first 8 or 9 times I stuck with getting various ramen.  Of those my favorite quickly became the Tonkotsu as I really enjoyed the creaminess of it.  I did like the other two as well, but always found myself going back to Tonkotsu.  As a quick aside, I actually found the Tonkotsu-Shoyu to be my least favorite.  The pork was always tender and tasty, and I would almost always get an egg added and I tried most of the other additions as well.   I personally didn't find many of them to be worth the extra cost to add, though I did like the Mustard Leaf on occasion.    For an appetizer I had the Gyoza a few times and found them to be very good examples, but not extraordinary at the same time.   Then one day I decided to split a pork belly bowl with a friend as an appetizer.  Game change.   It's seriously all I think about when I think of Monta now.  As much as I enjoyed the Ramen whenever I'd had it, it took a backseat to this dish in my heart and stomach.  Currently saving up for an engagement ring.  Pork Belly Bowl will make a lovely bride.  Service is always friendly if a little rushed, and I always thought the overall price was decent.  Still need to try Anime and Sora so no comparison on Ramens unfortunately, but unless they have Pork Belly Bowl on their menu, it might not matter.

u2_pY4X2dQaTOPMMM2xzPA.text: Seriously, Im getting addicted to this place. Noodles are perfect, broth is always creamy and perfectly seasoned, sides are delicious. Service is quick and friendly. What more can I ask!!??  So far my favorite is Miso Ramen with Nitamago and Nori. Last time, I ordered the  Mini Mentaiko (with spicy cod row) and was blown away by how great everything tasted.   One of the best meals under $10 in a city of great restaurants.

XlSP10HKtBS8deX445YEMA.text: I don't live in Vegas but found this place on Yelp.  Excellent Ramen place...if you're from California, you probably been to Shin-Sen-Gumi.  This place I think is better than Shin...the waitresses here are very friendly and service is excellent.  I would recommend you try their pork ramen...

RA8hFQ5saCw8L-DGH2uTwA.text: I was so happy when they opened this place. There are so many back in cali but i havent seen any here in vegas until monta.  the place is small and menu is simple. but simple usually means that everything should taste great.  all the stuff i order i really enjoy. you can add extras such as corn, extra meat, etc. to your ramen. they have this new flavor tonkasu-shoyu ramen and that is my favorite.  they make their gyoza fresh and they are really good but expensive considering i can buy a entire bag from the store for the same price.  if you are craving noodles and soup this is a nice change up from pho.

BDmBlUkeEQxq7JpPts83PA.text: Pretty nice place. Simple menu that isn't distracting or full of crazy dishes. The place gets busy often and to have quite a small establishment can be quite troublesome. This place is not for big dinners, more like lunch with a couple of friends to catch up or before heading out to a movie or something. Overall, this place is quite nice and I'm sure everyone will enjoy it :)

vGuHwylpN4gai2zuPCG_ow.text: Short on space. Long on taste. Well worth the wait. Order extra pork char siu with your bowl. You won't regret it.

VM2bNHzFuOIAf2rZG_PVdw.text: This place hits the spot if you want some good ole ramen!! Not the best I've had but the best in Vegas.

M2z_-gXV2EHZRDvWImwQ2A.text: we tried monta once. we won't ever go there again.  we went because several people we know were raving that there was FINALLY a good ramen joint here in vegas. see, where we come from, ramen joints are a dime a dozen where 90% of them are above average and super inexpensive.  i ordered the miso ramen. my broth was just slightly colder than lukewarm and tasted as though the chef ran out of salt for the rest of the day because he decided to put the restaurant's entire supply of it into my bowl of cold broth. the noodles are clearly dry, packaged noodles purchased in bulk. nothing special and certainly not al dente. if you know good ramen, you know that it should come to you so hot that it's almost impossible to eat for the first minute or so. the amount of steam that comes from a proper bowl of ramen should open up your pores and clear out your sinuses.  as for the service, well, i don't think i have enough expletives in my vocabulary to describe how miffed i was. i asked that my ramen be free of meat with extra veggies instead. that, apparently, was not allowed. i didn't argue and just decided that i'd remove the overcooked, thin pieces of pork from my bowl myself. i then asked if there were any additional non-meat toppings that i could add and, with a roll of the eyes, i was reluctantly directed with pen in hand to the section of the menu that said "toppings". so, in order to annoy the girl even more, i asked what takana was and, with another roll of the eyes and a severely frustrated tone, she said "it's a vegetable".  yeah, monta has plenty of misguided fans, i need not waste my time or hard earned dollar here.

YmaneSI7BRbJ11MsA1geQA.text: Cheap, delicious, and super fast service. I love the tonkatsu broth, so creamy. Really good kimchi too. Only downside is there is almost always a wait, though  it's never been more than 20 minutes. Wish the location was bigger; there's only like 5 tables.

3CFznG9MA3VwcsCVrGetGA.text: Japanese fried rice is delicious. But ramen is not my type. It's too salty. Gyoza can be a choice though the price is a little expensive with the portion.

iMtvAqL6bIPTnJDJ_B1eWA.text: Why am I rating this? Obviously it's a spit in the pool with all these other ratings. I want to right the wrong, four stars are not good enough for this place. Is the food five star? No, it's four star. The service, is it five star? No, it's three and a half stars. So why argue? Because for a lunch, you get something fantastic, delicious, full of umami and soooooo affordable. That, my friends, is a five star experience. I challenge you to find a better meal at double the price. And that's why there's a line out the door every lunch

-iOfjVAjTVYep95ANCn26g.text: I'll be honest - this was my first time ever having REAL ramen.  And, now my standards are very high.  The Tonkatsu broth was nothing less than a creamy cloud of comfort!!  The place reminds me of the tiny restaurants in Japan too.  Even with a line outside and the heat, I would happily wait for another bowl.

A6SCJqsgz-1yPKtzHBJdEA.text: Amazing noodles!!! Love the miso ramen ... Added seaweed and flavored egg! Yum!  Order the pork belly bowl too!

EEnDQZlUsLqVw08DsLOmsg.text: My family and I have been coming here for the last five years off and on. Sometimes once a month and there have been gaps as big as 9 months. We always have a pleasant experience and always have quality food. While there have been some slight inconsistencies over the years, we have almost always been happy with the food and service. This place is tiny and always busy. My favorites are the shoyu Ramen with corn, 2 eggs, and shredded green onion and also the fried rice. My kids adore this place and are always accommodated. The service is fast and the food is very reasonably priced. While I'm sure there are arguments for best Ramen in las vegas, monta is in the lead for me.

a0sAsKtAeESuNeeNQu7W_A.text: Good place for a satisfying tasty meal! Way worth it,  is a must stop when I come to Vegas!

wiYnptbcsnfnV--a7T3jDw.text: Went right after visiting the Grand Canyon. I was sun burnt and sweaty, i needed some comfort food. mmm... Ramen. I gave this place two stars because I had better, way better ramen in New York. Also the service was not all that. We stood at the entrance for a while then realize there was a book to put your name down. You would think the waitress that kept passing by would clue us in, Sheesh, i been to shittier ramen places service was never this bad. That made my experience there so much worst. Japanese people are usually so straightforward what is with this guessing game? The ramen is nothing to brag about, the broth is the same salty mess i complain about in most ramen places. One thing thats good though i have to say was their fried rice. That was delish. Yes go to a ramen place and get the fried rice.

qp5Klt7k16rfF-DjK4-uzQ.text: I've had the ramen here both eat in and take out and I love it. I've also had the gyoza. I think it's great. Is it like "Ippudo in NYC good"?  No. Is it "Some of the best ramen I've had"?  Yes.  As long as I'm in Vegas and looking for ramen, this will be the place I go... hands down, bar none.

HuP90rq4_BAX7zzPlgKVwQ.text: I have previously mentioned that I subconsciously have high ramen expectations.  But for some reason, this place just somehow managed to smash that.  I was first taken here on something of a whim.  We were going somewhere else, then the plans changed.  I'll admit, I was definitely not happy about it, as I know that any ramen place has a 90% chance of disappointing me.  But the second I walked in, I was taken aback to the tiny ramen shops back in Japan, with 1 long bar and a few tables.  Immediately my attitude changed for the good.  I looked at the menu, just 3 kinds of ramen, but you really don't need an exotic variety, just the ones you're really good at making.  Being kinda picky, I had ordered the Miso ramen, but with no mushroom or bamboo shoots, and added an egg and corn.  The soup came, and I did my usual broth test and was very surprised to find it was really good to me.  I added some sesame oil and went to town.  The egg was a nice addition, and the corn just reminded me of the food in Japan.    I was highly satisfied by the food and the place.  I will definitely be back again.

x2PHXcuualDaKlNmiEsx0Q.text: always a good time when i go here. i went at a time when it wasn't relatively busy where i had to wait, but they were still full inside. i ordered kimchi fried rice because i wasn't really hungry & i think it filled me up very well. it wasn't too spicy, but it was nice & hot & warmed me up. the ambiance is always nice, as they welcome each person individually. the orders came nice & fast.

uROfeK2sBYa9-jOQyIhSyQ.text: Best ramen I've had in Las Vegas. All the menu items are delicious, they're reasonably priced, and I like how you can request for extra noodles after your first bowl. Server's are friendly, but I remember I had a bad experience with one particular server. It wasn't bad enough for me to stop going though. All in all, almost all of the workers are friendly.

GRqXy-ayq0B4HDQPDDjwpQ.text: Alright, I came here with a party of 4 on a weeknight.  First impression, the parking lot was dark, the stores adjacent to the place was even darker and this place was open with nobody inside; couldn't even see the staff.   Instant O.o  Went inside, VERY simple interior kinda like a template style for restaurants with no outstanding unique traits for a ramen place.  I've eaten all over little tokyo in LA and cities around there so I know what good ramen taste like.  The food was slightly above par, but maybe it's cause what i'm used to. =/  However, i can say this place is up there as the top ramen places compared to the others I've tried, although to some, it may not mean much.

E7J1LDiclXf8kLZCmYPurQ.text: My experience with ramen is limited. There was a place near the Beverly Center in Los Angeles where I had some and liked it enough to return. The ramen at Monta is a whole other level of good. It's not only the best ramen I've ever had, it's the best Japanese food. My experience with Japanese food is that presentation is more important than flavor. That wasn't the case here.  We started with gyoza. These dumplings were tasty although maybe a tad too salty for me. Then our ramen soon arrived. I got the kontatsu with pork belly, green onions, egg and corn. The broth was tasty. A couple of different flavors going on. Quite savory. The noodles were perfect. Not overcooked and delicious. And all the toppings were good, too.  Janet got miso soup and was quite happy with her choice. She noted it was thicker than my soup. It seems like a winner. When we got there at 7 p.m. there were a couple of open tables and most of the bar was empty. By the time we left just after 8 p.m., every seat was taken, we had to push through a half dozen people standing at the door waiting to eat and another couple of cars pulled up with people going there to eat. It seems quite popular. Most of the people inside appeared to be of Japanese descent.
