Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Calpico
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu

HoWGW9B-uqAhjNQbR_4eVA.text: We were here just now trying to get a table waiting over 40 min. They kept telling us we cant get a table because all our party wasnt here. we were party of 3 and only 2 of us were here and out of nowhere she seats a group of 5 ppl who only 4 of their party member in the restaurant. If u have been telling us that we couldnt seat becauae not all our parties were there dont seat other ppl whose parties arent all there!! Wasted our time and ruin the night.

AH3R0BpdE8zOyTqvx7Lgmg.text: I don't know if it's because my palate has grown or if I've just learned to appreciate the finer bowl of ramen... But whatever it is, Monta is my go to spot for ramen when I'm feeling happy, sad, celebratory, or whatever. I've been to a bunch of other ramen spots around town, and they still have the best quality and prices by far!

nuzD4yToJ8BY--74wACNGA.text: This is probably the place for the most flavorful ramen you will find in Vegas. I chose the shoyu tonkatsu ramen here and it definitely beats out other places for ramen in Vegas that I've tried so far.  There are some drawbacks though. The portions are small and there is a lack of meat and ingredients in general. Luckily, there is at least the option to get extra noodles when all you have left is soup to help fill you up for an extra buck fifty. Definitely get the extra noodles if you aren't full.

zQKUKvq5HcSAo_ukVym4Rw.text: We were in vegas for the Sema show, looked up the best ramen and this ramen house came up.  All four of us agreed.....it is the best!  We had all the ramen options and loved them all.  You can order them hot or regular...both ways are totally yummy.  Fried rice if good but order it light oil.  Pork belly bowl is bomb.  We ate there 3days out of 5....it was that good.  Options get expensive though.  Enjoy!

mFUjLVDMJZZzJ-c3I_pBzg.text: Not a big fan of their noodles, but the broth is okay, and you get a plentiful amount of chasu and bamboo shoots. Their mini Chasu bowl is amazing though :)

jDqytVkbdfPBtlDE586wzw.text: Great food for a great price.  Fast excellent service.  It is almost always full but since service is fast you can just wait and seats become available quickly.  All parties must be present to be seated.

wdUHYZS1ZLW5AHLYTCPcdQ.text: Over-Hyped. Very small inside, about 22-24 seats with reportedly long lines in the evenings. On a Sunday afternoon we got in immediately, staff was all in a bad mood and rather unfriendly. Soup base was bland, chashu fatty and tasteless. There is much better Ramen to be had in Vegas!

ZNQl5c6yeZgLIA8cd6kbLA.text: Yummy!! The best rates place in town.  The gyoza is delicious.  The only downside is the place is small, so expect to wait for a table.

vT1HW2OW2FV6mj2bBJ_XEg.text: I love this place. I've been here several times but always forget to give a review. (Probably due to the food coma). Food is spot on and I always order the miso ramen, gyoza and Asahi beer. We're on our way tonight and I feel my mouth watering  already!  Oh and food is cheap too!

SGE3W6BAv6-j86Ds11qh6Q.text: Good ramen. Not great like it was a couple of years ago. Not sure if this is indicative of decline or better competition.   Great value, low prices. The gyoza were lame but the ramen still excellent.   Still crowded but not as bad as last year

-lD01mtBLi-TGuIO-YWx3w.text: I come here for the TONKOTSU RAMEN w/ a few orders of the KAIDAMA. In the summer time, I hit up the HIYASHICHUKA (my favorite).   Seating is very limited and depending on where you get seated, I have no room to get too comfy. A few times, I was elbow to elbow with my people sitting next to me.   Other than that all I have to say is: RAMEN DAISUKI!!!

xAAmQlFwv2y_Z_YstvK76A.text: Best ramen in Vegas! Soup was thick and flavorful, noodles were not soft..and the egg yolk was soft and wet..the kind of stuff u would get from an authentic ramen shop in japan..highly recommended

veQ6gEHJOHyIOrOhWCiNOQ.text: Hands down Monta has the best Japanese ramen in Las Vegas. I've tried my fair share of ramen places in Los Angeles and Vegas, and it's safe to say Monta beats everybody out of the park. The noodles are perfectly cooked every single time. The broth is perfectly filled with flavor but not too heavy at the same time. I love the thin noodles. I also love all their fried rice cooked to order and their gyoza appetizer. I'm not a huge fan of the 2 new ramen specials, but Monta never fails.

x5zktrxHawF15GZcNqpLLw.text: First time I've been to a Japanese Ramen shop and it was delicious.  My only point of reference is Vietnamese Pho and this was up there with the best Pho I've had.  Great, efficient service and very inexpensive as well!  Perfect for the day-after hangover that Vegas will give you!

IJtJmiiZ0yCeTtHa1de9Ww.text: Not really a big fan of noodle shops but this was the exception. I ordered the chicken and pork which was great. Very tender, melt in your mouth, pork and broth was perfectly seasoned. Small shop, clean, and service was super fast. Defiantly coming back.

SihQlMOQ_0D3Y_UYty3U6g.text: I have always come here since hearing about it years ago. The service isn't the best but damn it sure is consistently amazing food every time me we are here. Best time to go is around 2 - 3 pm. Expect a 10 - 30 min wait for a table.

3AdbQQFUA_LYBNntGbB03A.text: EXCELLENT! I can't seem to stay away from this place.. The food here is DELICIOUS! The menu selection is a bit limited and the location is very small which in turn usually has a waiting list but it is surely worth the wait!

H1yrYC9kzPqXQyjxohGqxA.text: This is probably the most FATTIEST, yet most flavorful and tender tonkatsu I've ever eaten.   Make sure you get the tonkatsu ramen with thick, aka "curly" noodles, nori, and some corn for that crunchy texture.  Yum-o.  And here's a tip: don't pack your leftovers and eat it cold on the way back to California in the car...this stuff turns into a fatty, thick, sludgy stew that's pretty unappetizing.

Fk3MU-m-kFcY31roPW3LDQ.text: I look forward to the kimchi fried rice every time I come here. Fast and friendly service. You may have to wait a bit before being seated although it is worth the wait every time. Just make sure your whole party is present or else they will not seat you.

Mqr8dgaabY6_b8Qv4iXeow.text: Solid place for good ramen. And the kimchi fried rice is delicious too!  There is usually a wait during lunch hours as the restaurant is very small. The service is always friendly and prompt. The prices are a little high for the portion sizes, but it is still a good lunch spot.

gZUFoySgjH7-9IoWV-AUcg.text: Great food, quick service and fantastic prices!

k9FhUWhecBzppvJt811uig.text: My husband and I went to NY and had the famous Ippudo Ramen Noodles (you have to wait approx two hours there).  So when we got back to Las Vegas, we were raving it and was looking for a place in Vegas that does handmade Ramen Noodles. And this isnt like the ramen that is .$50 for a box... these are great! I will not be able to eat noodles the same way again!  My husband and I have had their  Tonkotsu Ramen & their Shoyu ramen. You can also add extra noodles for $2 more... if you save your soup and ask for "Kaedama."  Be careful... it is a small place... so they don't do big parties or reservations... and there can be a long wait around the evening hours.

pfUnUvNeXlZY7OwqHrH0Vg.text: Love the noodles.  Best ramen I've had.  The pork belly is also excellent.  You can't really go wrong.  Yes, it is small and yes there will be a line, but it is worth it.

Moy9wzmkZEDRJAoC4rf3Vw.text: 3.5  Head off the strip into Chinatown for some good ramen.  We arrived at Monta only 30 minutes after it opened and were already facing a long line of hungry locals.  As with many ramen shops, it is very small and seating is limited to tables and the counter.  Our group of four were seated within 20 minutes and I ordered the standard Tonkotsu bowl.  I thought the noodles and pork slices were nicely cooked, but the pork broth was a touch saltier than what I prefer.  My husband's miso broth was smooth and savory, without the overwhelming saltiness.  There are also options for you to add in extra ingredients to customize your bowl, such as an egg, pork, corn, and extra noodles.  A great find that's different from the usual Vegas eateries.

efmOKWp8ZGK1lcgFVlIlRg.text: It took me a while to finally try Monta after reading about it in a couple local Vegas magazines, and damn was it worth the wait.  I have had a lot of ramen over the past couple of months, trying to find the holy grail of ramen, trying to find the bowl of bowls, trying to find the one bowl by which all other bowls are compared (I am not talking about weed sorry...).  Finally, after searching, I found it in Las Vegas of all place.  The first time I had Monta, I was hungover and it was damn good.  The second time I had it, I was dead sober and it was still damn damn good.    Honestly, if I could, I would give Monta 5+++ stars.  I have been here a couple of times and have tried all of the broths, and by far, the best broth is the tonkatsu-shoyu combo broth (rich, salty, melt in your mouth goodness).  The tonkatsu is a close second because wow, the broth is super-stick-to-your-ribs rich.  Make sure that no matter what you order, make sure to get extra pork and the amazingly, soft-boiled egg, with a slightly soft and runny center.  Go get your ramen on!

LMJNv1RRfHqxO1p1OSQ-vw.text: The only reason why Im giving this as 4 star due to the space it has. But I also realize japanese ramen houses are very similiar. But yes I love the tonkatsu and man let me tell you. This i feel is one of the authentic kinds of ramen places in Las Vegas. I love it so much i can wait over an hour for it. :) I have not tried other recipes.

OWLQNUJpD0MSi4uDbLYVyw.text: Their tonkotsu ramen was really good. The broth was perfect; the pork was melt-in-your-mouth fatty.  It was so good, that before we ended our Vegas trip we returned again.  We tried the tonkotsu shoyu ramen and pork belly.  Both visits we ordered kimchee on the side and it was good too...not spicy, just refreshing enough to accompany the richness of the pork and broth.

rgsS125JCPOBwMfcu-lKQw.text: Had the spicy tonkatsu ramen. Was awesome especially for the price! Best ramen in vegas

Vsu1i24Drc6c6Aof_J3fSQ.text: The fried rice is my favorite,  made with fried pork belly. How can you go wrong?  Actually, it is tied with the miso ramen.  I have been wanting to try the new ramen with black garlic oil but I just love my favorites so much I can't bear not ordering them.  Whenever im in Vegas I HAVE to eat here and now im a regular here even though my home is 2500 miles away.  That's how great this place is.

GKkmvhSRVPlGB-Hrkg9nig.text: Good, creamy tonkotsu broth.  Chashu was not too fatty and melted in my mouth.  The noodles were okay, they didn't have the eggy taste that I love.  The service is what deserved the 5-star.  I ordered a mentaiko bowl and stopped after the first bite, it was too fishy for me.  The waitress noticed this and took the charge off our check.  Thanks for the kind gesture Monta!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen.

C0nHNddxxwMneA8LxjXnFQ.text: Rick Moonen (Top Chef Master's contestant and owner of RM Seafood in Mandalay Bay) was spotted in this hole of a wall. Despite how low his restaurant ratings are, the fact that he chose to eat at this specific noodle house says a little something something about their food.   To keep this short and sweet:  - Friendly service - Was a wait around 12:30 (prime lunch time) but still got seated and served within 30 min - Tonkatsu ramen= perfect portions. I ended up slurping up more of the broth than the noodles which was very surprising (i never drink the broth) - Small fried rice seemed small at first for the four of us but was just the right amount with the ramen.  - Lots of ginger and garlic sauces for unlimited consumption - parking lot big in plaza   I want more!!!

lrm_eSE8xf-cGsZuDlFCFQ.text: We had lunch at Monta Ramen. If you are in Las Vegas, you've got to visit this place. The food quality is awesome, and the price is excellent. The ramens are less than $7 per order. I actually find the fried rice and pork belly bowl are my favorites. Make sure to get there early because the wait list can be long. But the serving speed is very fast so you won't end up waiting for long.

c7NqbYD1MSl6wmvvpmtG8A.text: So far this place has the best price for the minimum amount. Once you add in all the addition it will be around $11. Compare this place to Shoku Ramen which is down the street, it is very competitive. Again another ramen house with salty broth. Can I get a normal broth with just bone and vegetable taste then I add my own fish sauce and miso to my liking? The saltiness is still better than Shoku ramen, but then again it might be my bad luck at Shoku Ramen.   Monta Ramen is pretty closed to my house. The combination of garnish, slice of belly pork, and broth is not fully met to the famous tonkotsu. But overall it was good. The service is fast. I get to pick thick or thin noodle. The decoration was earth tone which is easy to the eyes but not vibing like Las Vegas strip interior design. The kitchen is huge compare to the seating space. If they were to do a remodel again, they might want to calculate out the total space and give more space to the seatings. The last time I counted, this has less than 45 seats. I think they can push to the 50-60 if they redo the kitchen. The menu do not have a long list of items. Just broth, noodle pot, fryer and a few pots to boil. How much are storage spaces? I think there is a huge space for storing food to the decade. Not just 6 months supplies. Starbuck have the same total items but look at the reasonable kitchen size.

rfeKRP5ZXLjxwQES3nWq6g.text: Absolutely delicious, probably the best ramen that I've ever had.  If you don't like to wait on line for a table, stop by during the off hours.  Every time I've gone, the line was out the door, but that's an indication of their food.

fU-KCTwF3GM9je_D4-gwnw.text: All I got say is YUMMY!!! Highly recommended for anyone wanting to their ramen fix.  I had their tonkotsu shoyu ramen topped with egg and extra Chasyu.  For some reason, their chasyu is more pork belly than "Char Siu" that I normally recognize, however, delicious is delicious...Lost a star, however, b/c eggs are not included and considered extra cost.    Beforeworn, for those who are coming with 4 or greater individuals.  The place is very small and only have ~four to five tables available for group seating.

Oed-np4buIndGdV6-hhgGA.text: Im not the biggest fan of asian style noodles, but the noodles and broth here are closer to what ive tasted to dishes made for me from people that are from japan or lived there than any other ramen spot in town. The layout and atmosphere is closest to what its like in Japan according to my friends from Japan.   Monta has the best fried rice, and the best gyoza of any style asian/japanese restaurant in town PERIOD. My only complain is the meat they put on top of the ramen bowls is small.

xjrQaiUfXkTJJt97sgkhrQ.text: Probably the best japanese ramen place in town. Its tucked in a little corner on Spring Mountain across SF market so you might actually miss it. The restaurant is actually quite small and if you come during peak lunch hours, you might have a 20-30 min (which is what happened to me).  You have 4 broth flavors to choose from:   Tonkotsu (very savory) - My favorite Shoyu (salty/soy sauce) Tonkotsu-Shoyu (combination of the first two which tastes funky to me) Miso   Each comes with 2 slices of chashu, some bamboo shoots and green onion. You have the option of adding more chashu, boiled egg, corn, kimch etc. Usually 2 slices of chashu isn't enough for me since its a GIGANTIC bowl of ramen and I can never finish it. They do have rice dishes and gyoza which is okay but not the best. Bill came out to be around $20 for two noodles so very reasonable.

N6HhFrlJAq3UkUNQHnNSxQ.text: This Vegas trip turned out great because I got the chance to try many different restaurants and Monta Ramen got me hooked on Ramen. Since I have been back to California I have tried 3 different places. I have compared them all to Monta Ramen and Monta Ramen blows everyone out of the water. There broth is so simple,yet very flavorful. There egg is cooked perfectly. Prices are very reasonable!

Ix19Qt11JFK-y95oxNC7mw.text: It's all about the pork belly. Doesn't matter if you get the ramen or the rice bowl. Get as much of that delicious, addictive pork belly as you can. While you sit at home, sloshing around to the realization that you ate way too much, the memories of the pork belly will come back, and suddenly you are blissfully at peace.

xF4ODD5UMKMwQVhOB9OSYQ.text: If you have lived here for more than a week and haven't been to Monta Ramen, you're already behind. The place seats like 20 people and it's freakin fantastic. Close your eyes and point at the menu. Whatever you pick, it's going to be delicious.

LkyTORMue2FyDU25DAtoRg.text: A bit of a hole in the wall, but had fantastic food. The miso ramen and fried rice was outstanding and service was great. Small place, but definitely a solid choice for some good noodles in Chinatown

hUQjRjGtOG5i4ZSxZ1jljQ.text: First time there and I loved it! I will definitely go there again. The food isn't spectacular, but it isn't supposed to be, it's RAMEN!

Zml3crkIkLTaISOX1P3mug.text: Waited for an hour since we didn't luckily get to the first round and had to wait for the entire first round (like 20 people) to finish eating and exiting...

tcxNuA90K-5CKHF1bsU_Cw.text: We arrived at 11:35am, 5 minutes after the restaurant theoretically opened.  But, in fact, they had opened about 20 minutes earlier and the place was already packed.  They have a clipboard near the entrance where you can add your name to the waiting list.  We were third, but because the first wave of customers had all been seated at about the same time, it took a while for them to start to finish.  I occupied myself watching the guy actually making the ramen, which was fun.  Once the first wave started to finish, a bunch of seats opened up in quick succession.  My wife and I both ordered the tonkatsu ramen with nitamago (a seasoned hard-boiled egg) and extra chashu pork.  It was fantastic, among the best I've ever had, and certainly much better than could reasonably be expected from a strip mall in Las Vegas.  I will certainly make it a priority to come back here every time I'm in town!

F0pP4PWwHFHeDYjosYnNxw.text: Okay so I have been on a crazy ramen kick these last few weeks.  I can't seem to get sick of it, which really needs to happen soon because all this sodium is not condusive to my eating clean and healthy.  I know I said in my Sora review that I probably would not go back to Monta after falling in deep and passionate love with my bowl of ramen at Sora, but I wanted to eat by myself today and I knew if I went to Monta, I could probably get a seat quicker than at Sora since Monta has the counter-top seating.  I used to go to Monta every Saturday for lunch by myself and noticed that there were a lot of people who like to eat there by themselves, which makes it easier and faster for me to get a seat.  Today was so busy!  So busy in fact, that I still had to wait about 15 minutes before getting seated. They only have a couple of servers who also double (triples?) as hostesses and bussers so these ladies are running around like crazy.  Like Sora, I just find myself exremely impressed at how quickly they turn tables over without making you feel rushed when you're eating.  I love to sit at the counter-top and watch them making the ramen.  The guys are super nice and will usually chat a little bit when I've been there on Saturdays, but today he was constantly running around getting those delicious bowls of steaming ramen out of the kitchen.     Anyway, I don't have anything against Monta.  I just think Sora is way better.  However, I did leave there today feeling extremely happy and satisfied.  I always get the Tonkatsu-Shoyu with chasyu and nitamago.  One bowl of ramen is usually more than enough for me.  If I'm with someone, we will usually also get the gyoza, which are good but nothing special.  Today, however, I decided to try something new and adventurously ordered the kimchi fried rice.  Not sure why regular fried rice comes in a small and large, but add some kimchi to it and you can only get one size, which is a large serving.  But I'm glad I got it because it was freakin' wonderful!  The seasoning is just perfect and the kim chi is just subtle enought that it doesn't overpower the fried rice taste.  I can't wait to eat the leftovers!  I still can't help but compare my ramen at Monta to my ramen at Sora, and though it falls short, I still really enjoy Monta as part of my ramen rotation and will continue to go there every once in a while.

o81t7fEhtilPVQlJmlhSCA.text: I had the noodles with chicken broth and the fried rice, the dishes came out quickly and well done despite the dining room being full. The menu is compact the service efficient  I would recommend it to anyone for an informal quick,  well cooked and presented  meal

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Noodles

brzytNV-C0w60iNdNi15ug.text: Best ramen house in town. But the waiting line in terrible. I hope they can expand to a bigger restaurant or have another location.

wbwm_RTPiMPYrFLX6Vje9g.text: Pretty dang good! Depending on what I eat I tend to be pretty picky. I enjoyed the Ramen at Monta. The thin noodles are yummy and the broth had lots of flavor. I have had Ramen at Sora before and I really noticed the difference. If I don't like the smell I don't eat the food. Monta's Ramen smelled great compared to Sora. Flavor wise as well. Good job on taking the time to make yummy Ramen!

1AcokEbnLYzszWovyFIfIw.text: Afraid I'm going to have to downgrade Monta.  :(  The broth in their tonkatsu just isn't the same as it used to be.  It used to have a really rich, almost meaty flavor.  It's still a really good broth but not the ridiculously tasty one it used to be.  Noodles also seem a bit limper than they used to be.  Maybe they're too busy to handle everything like they used to?

76L1Ass0dTY9lo6wCfXwqg.text: Mont Ramen-Best in VegasOne hour of hotwaiting line...the broth is flavorful~it's not just a sodium bombThe Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen is fantastic it hits the spot of my craving And the price is good too (10 Bucks only, it's already KO my stomach)

aPJfMgfacgAKd1-eiRYQkQ.text: Really no need for pics since yelpers have taken all the pics of every food item here. Nor is there a need for extensive reviews.    basically.... Small menu but very good food. That's all we want, right?    Shoyu Ramen, broth is much thinner than the Tonkatsu, but overall very good flavor for both entrees.    Not too thrilled over the mini Mentaiko that I thought was a must try. That side order was a doozy for us.  The ramen and gyoza was good enough to fill our lunch tummies....and then back to cali.    A great place to unwind the next morning after a long night being a fool at vegas strip and losing all your $. This place won't senselessly rob your wallet thinner than it already is.  Monta is kind of like a great cup of coffee the morning after a serious hang over.  Beware the wait could be long since the sitting area is very very small!

JdcFboPPONi4C0Alw-dcCg.text: The ramen was good, but not awesome. We came for dinner, but the line was supper long so we left. We came back the next day for lunch, waited about 5-10mins. Glad we didn't wait more than that. This restaurant is so small, with 15-20 people capacity, which explains why there is always a wait. Service was friendly.

xmTBfVC2e8CDbZFZ_Kcqmw.text: Really good ramen.  Good service.  I think it compares to the best places in Little Tokyo.

Z7amo6DEkUrq2IHJ3D9z0g.text: OMG!?!?!?!? Best Ramen you will ever have!?!? It is a VERY TINY restaurant and be prepared to wait at least 20 minutes, but it will be totally worth the wait!?!? It is amazing! The kimchi fried rice also amazing!?!?  this place!!!!

ph85XU9c4qIoMpPXcPzjNA.text: Surprisingly, there's an authentic JP ramen place in Vegas.  However, we found that the soup is a bit too salty.  I am very familiar with different JP regions ramen.  We found that it is not bad for ramen, but I won't say it's a "must try" one.  The fried rice is good there too.

mNQkGLWeSdj9_CJLWCTVSw.text: If you're sensitive to salt, then I would recommend you stay away from the ramen. I like salt, so the ramen was fine with me. It's very hearty and just hits the spot. Even if you can't enjoy the ramen, come here and try their rice dishes, they're pretty good.   All in all, it's a good spot to hit up the morning after a night of intense hardcore drinking.  Recommendation: Fried Rice

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Rice
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen

T55PV1KO1g0qO6e1O1fhLg.text: We went to Monta Noodle House for Japanese Ramen.  It's in Vegas Chinatown area, behind the Jack In the Box, in the Seoul Plaza.  They have good hours something like 11:30a-10p everyday.    I got:  Tonkotsu ramen $6.95 - it's a small bowl, 2 pcs fatty pork, small amount of noodles, some green onions, & the broth, no egg that's extra, no seaweed - that's extra.  Still liked it.  B. got Miso Ramen $7.25 w/ extra bamboo shoots .50 + nori .75  Our total 15.45 + $1.25 tax = $16.70 before tip.  Charged it.  Quick & fast dinner before our flight home.

o-LMZy2A5jzbxmIjUEfo5Q.text: Prepare to stand in a line. Great base to their soup. Gotta try the spicy version and their pork belly rice!!!

fuUMhPv4rr9CC5TDcuk-QQ.text: Head chef of the place sat and spoke with us during our meal he is a True Japanese ramen chef he explained they are a group of restaurants that start with mon thrus the name monta.   Ramen is bomb one of the best around and I will be coming back.

tItApwCwOEpFqrbUhbjT7g.text: The food is always amazing here and the staff extremely friendly ! The best tonkatsu shoyu in town !

eHIRPyAhrrFSdwT0utPB7Q.text: Delicious pork belly rice! So fattening yet so good. Was starving the whole day and the pork belly rice totally satisfied my craving.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

c_GlvGveqerSnEh3p5Jffw.text: Fucking awful. Service here is disgusting. The servers are very rude and keep persists you on leaving.

sz90SaOOQKniaRPa5Wjh9Q.text: Very good ramen spot in Vegas. The wait could be quite long (25 min wait) even on a weekday so just a heads up. I ordered the spicy shoyu ramen with egg and seaweed. I like the thin noodles and tasty broth that they had to offer. The portion is a bit small but the price is very reasonable. Might just have to order extra noodles next time.

Dud-5RuB9k-Tm6nPFrizTQ.text: The best....fast friendly service and awesome chef who is consistent....ramen is the best

Ii9IQz06qw-W79ECdUOoeg.text: Possibly the best bowl of ramen I've ever had! Friendly, prompt service. Melt-in-your-mouth pork. Heavenly broth. Perfect for a chilly Vegas evening. On those days, even on a weekday for a table of 2, you may expect a long wait. Prepare to get intimate, as it's a small resto that can get very crowded. If you do have to wait, I can confidently say that it will be worth it!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

j0_xK3BwNBaI31SjPCLvyA.text: Gotta love Yelp!! We found this hidden gem while in Vegas and we loved it!! We went back 2 more times, the place is small so of course you have to wait for a table, but the wait is worth it, the Ramen was delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious ramen

CixWiOlxKtBGQOJBzf6DpA.text: Me and my friends actually ended up here because the line at Oyster Bar was too long and we were starving. I personally am a ramen fan in general so I like trying new places, my other friend and her hubby are not big ramen fans, but luckily, after coming to Monta they have found a renewed interest in ramen.  We all started with a glass of beer, pretty cheap at about $3 but they are not pints, I think more like 10oz-ers? Still it was a refreshing way to start the meal.  Shared the pickled greens fried rice and the pork belly rice bowl. Fried rice was cooked well and flavorful, the pork belly bowl was even better. The fatty pieces of pork were cooked perfectly tender with their greasy goodness seaping into the rice underneath.   For ramen I got the half pork half chicken broth and added an egg. The chicken broth is supposed to be a little less rich but mine was still a pretty thick broth. Not that that's a bad thing, thick as in thick with flavor but sometimes I prefer a less rich broth because it can get very filling. So depending on what you like, the full tonkatsu broth would be richest and most flavorful and a the half and half would be a lighter version. Noodles were cooked perfectly.   The place is typical small Japanese style shop, they have a list for you to write your name on and wait. The waitresses do a nice job of clearing the tables and getting everyone seated as soon as possible so even though we had a few parties ahead of us the wait wasn't too bad for lunch hour. It does get a little hot inside though, so be warned for those coming in the summer months.

NZAVWOpOGd9Dra4cn9EGTA.text: There was no Pho hang over cure that I knew of when I was in Vegas. This Monta Ramen hit the spot and made me hungover for more!  After a two days of almost non-stop clubbing adventure and drinking for a bachlorette party we were seeking a hangover cure. The throbbing BUM BUM BUM and the dehydration headaches were kicking in from drinking close to 6 bottles of vodka. Of course split amongst 10 girls + the extra 3 bottles of "blow job shots" and "scooby snax shots" that resided in our hotel.   We came at 10:30am. They open at 11am and dafuq they had a line already waiting. Of course we were the second party that arrived. However the first party ahead of us only had 2. The total capacity in this small restaurant was probably... 28-32 seats. What I noticed in Las Vegas was... when the restaurant says it opens at a designated time... they sometimes open 10 minutes earlier. This goes to many of the restaurants outside of the strip. I never understood that. Also the patrons here are rude. Another party arrived and tried to CUT INFRONT OF US. To get in. WTF VEGAS? SCUMBAGS NO?  Anyways, the ramen here is comparable to some very phenomenal ramen joints in Japan. The Ramen mecca. It could go head to head to Santouka ramen and probably kick their ass easy.  Broth is rich, not too salty. Meat tender. Noodles perfect. I had opted for the Shoyu Tonkatsu ramen. Because I love soy sauce based ramens. With the combination with the Tonkatsu broth? F yea.  I also love my ramen SPICY. They had a special on that. It was every bit of heaven you could ask for.  NOT TOO SALTY YET RICH. CHECK. NOT TOO OILY YET STILL SAVORY. CHECK. CUSTOMER SERVICE? Awesome. The lady was lovely. The cooks focused.  Would I drive 4-5 hours to eat this again? Hell yea I would.

5mymy9tuNG6H2z8IRx7dfw.text: Service is good, but the Kuro with Black Garlic Oil that I had was so salty. I suspect that they also use MSG on their ramen because I felt nauseous after eating my ramen. I felt better after throwing up. My husband had the Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen and I tried a little bit of its soup...I can say it's better than the Kuro...I guess it's the oil that has extra sodium in it. My hubby and son liked the small pork belly bowl that we shared, just to taste it. I was expecting the belly to be crispy but it's the same meat that they put in the ramen. The gyoza is just average...nothing to talk about. We waited for an hour to be seated and I think it's not worth the wait. I won't be coming back to this place. There are other better ramen places in town, especially in that area.

yC0kQ9gheVRbiKX5e6kXAw.text: Despite my father's criticisms about this place (he's really picky when it comes to Japanese food), I decided to go here with my friends.   I've been here a good number of times and I think it's safe to say that this ramen house is good. And I mean GOOD.  I order the same thing every time: the shoyu ramen. The noodles are fantastic, the broth very flavorful, and the toppings, including the chashu, complete the bowl. Oh, and the fried rice is pretty good, too!  The place has a cozy and traditional feel to it. It's a very small establishment, but this is what you should expect from an authentic Japanese restaurant. This comes with a quick and friendly staff.  Need to go to this place more often since it's already getting really cold.

ixK5_DjTAIU9fPRxyN5ZeA.text: Everything is delicious here! Our visit wouldn't be complete without coming here. The ramen is out of this world. The fried rice is delicious!!!

gr84AsuEJiqwEYoLC_4igQ.text: My friend told me this was the best ramen she ever ate in her life... Well.. maybe I shouldve ordered something else because the Kuro Ramen was not good.  soup was bitter, my egg was still cold in the soup, and the temperature of the ramen when it came out was just WARM.  I hate that...I'll definitely give it another shit though.. maybe I should just order the regular tonkotsu that everyone gets..  BUT...the pork belly bowl... OMG.. let me tell you... I can probably eat 5 of those for sure... It had so much flavor and had my taste buds craving for it... So I definitely recommend that one.  It was not worth an hour wait for me at all..I'll give it another shot though.

g4MH1pjTV6m9hR73x3aUpA.text: We had to wait quite a while because this is a very small place, but it was worth it. We ordered Shoyu Ramen and Miso Ramen (x3), gyoza, and the kimchi fried rice. The kimchi fried rice was a total hit with our group, and everything else was good as well. The gyoza was nice and crispy. We will definitely be back but we will probably try to find out what their peak hours are so we don't have to wait as long next time.

AB9Pod2Fg_meBm-jvuidJg.text: Came here once and hated it, gave it another try and still hated it. Long wait times, got uncooked noodles one time, don't give you much meat, both times I got an upset stomach, one time they forgot to place our gyoza order so it came after we were already done with our ramen and they didn't offer to take off bill or anything. Jinya is the best for ramen in Vegas.

nkaqBCeMmdkt7Dyc7gxykw.text: Horrible service!  Rude waiter after waiting forever to be seated I asked for water and she said that I must first order food then she will bring me the water. WTF

jYmFjw9QUQk9Nt9FkjRYug.text: We came here at around 1:30pm last Friday - with the leftovers of the lunch crowd.   We had to wait for our party of 5 but the wait was not very long; I ordered the pork belly bowl for my young son and daughter - this was very rich and very flavorful; the pickled ginger complements the saltiness nicely.  I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen and it was full of flavor - very rich, filling and authentic - I ate the whole bowl (and they are very big bowls!).   This was my birthday lunch and we traveled 2 hours to eat here from Southern Utah. The staff were friendly and accommodating for our family with 2 adults and 3 kids even though the restaurant is very small and seating is limited. I was very happy with our meal.

Q0FV-i01sSJIAUq4gkcS0Q.text: Great ramen place!  Been here twice and have been thoroughly satisfied each time.  With how small this place is, I'm not surprised at the wait...even at 10pm at night.    The service, though brisk, is also very helpful and friendly.  No one has time to stand around to chat and explain things to you but they try very hard to seat everyone as quickly as possible and they manage to bring you your food quickly and correctly.  Hubby and I are purists...we stay with the tonkotsu broth.  The broth was rich and sticky...didn't taste like it was brewed only from pork bones but also from pork feet/hock.  Very tasty and comforting.  On our second visit, I got extra char siu.  When the fat from the char siu melted into my broth, it got even thicker and richer.  Hey, you say greasy, I say yummy!!  Other standouts - takana fried rice and pork belly bowl...all very good!!  Definitely going to be a staple for us when we're in LV.

XE2_jdH00jiytDv0JfDAqw.text: One of my favorite restaurants in Las Vegas, hands down, and I'm not alone. Every time I go to this place there is a line out the door because of all the people waiting to experience this culinary delight.   The noodles and toppings are all delicious, but there's something about the broth that makes this ramen to die for. Also, the pork. It's flavorful and fatty, and I would recommend getting extra if you feel like spoiling yourself.   Be careful though, this stuff is about as addicting as crack. After your first time, you'll keep going back until you realize it's gotten out of hand, and that you need to stop for the sake of your bank account and health. I put on about five pounds after first discovering this place, and I've gotten many friends addicted as well.   My personal favorites include the Spicy Tonkatsu with egg and shredded onion, and Kuro with butter and extra pork.

IowiEp7Inzo7RV7gRiQB0w.text: a must visit late night food spot in Vegas. You will love their ramen especially when you come here after drinking and party. But the ramen itself is pretty delicious, too.

mOJEcHYVNsEwHV9CE2hIlQ.text: Best Noodles House in Las Vegas for Ramen.

gjmeFf50nnD8ibz9s59sAw.text: (Very) good ramen place. Personally, I think Go!ku is a little better, but that doesn't take away from Monta Ramen being a very nice place to go have some ramen; it's also a fantastic bargain. Be forewarned though: if you come with a group, you may wait a long time to get a seat, because seating is somewhat scarce and in high demand. The broth is tasty, and the noodles taste fresh. The service is fast and efficient.

V1yIknFnZO_Tbg52VD3Y6A.text: Chinatown in Las Vegas is so cool. Hundreds of restaurant choices.  Monta Ramen was a top Yelp pick with over 2000 reviews.  Sublime ramen and well priced add-ons.  I chose the black garlic oil / tonkatsu style.  Kurobuta pork, bamboo shoots, They had a great array of seasonings to go with it: toasted sesame, pickled ginger, chili oil, vinegar, soy, pureed garlic.  A+.  Noodles were thin and delicious.  Didn't feel bloated.  Portion size was perfect.  I tipped the chefs directly.  What a great find !

nz7Bsr3TLk6MzT-f4318Og.text: First time eating here. We waited for a little bit but it was worth it. Sat down by the bar area. Which I think was the best seat cause you're able to see them cook the food that you ordered.  The service was excellent! Food was great!

i8wvM5wDXe2txKZEWcIG7Q.text: This place was super busy on a weekday. Obviously they must know their ramen. Thank goodness we only had to wait 30 minutes.   I ordered their tonkotsu ramen while my husband ordered the miso ramen. Verdict? The miso ramen was a lot taster and the noodles were better. The broth had a rich depth of flavor and the noodles were thicker and perfectly al dente in Japanese terms.   The place is very small so be prepared for a wait, but I think it was worth a drive from the strip. Cheap, good eats!

1D6bmXlKsjjzU8OseSO_gg.text: This is probably my favorite ramen place in Vegas!! It's a bit small but the food makes up for it!!! 10/10 would recommend!!!

YtOvvoHDm1zKjpQ4GT_vVA.text: Besides gallivanting on the Las Vegas strip for some great eats, my cousin and I decide to venture out. We wanted to get some curry, but the place we wanted to go to was closed during lunch hours. So with my trusty Yelp app, we decided to search what was popular around the vicinity. Monta Ramen was the first thing that popped up in our search, so we headed there.  As we arrived, there was a small line formed outside the building. Typical for a well known ramen spot. We added our name to the wait list and had about a fifteen minute wait. Once we were called, we sat around the prep area. Our server handed us our menus and gave my cousin some recommendations on their popular dishes. As for myself, I already knew what I was going to get.  I decided to the the miso based ramen, which includes some basic ingredients:  - Green onions  - Two slices of chashu - Bamboo shoots - Kikurage  There are extras you can add to your ramen, pricing varies. I got the following extras:    - Butter - Corn - Extra side of noodles - Nori - Soft boiled egg  Our ramens came out fairly quickly after placing our orders. As quickly as they were served, they remained piping hot! The presentation was nicely put together. I mixed all the ingredients in the bowl and took my first sip of the broth. The broth was very tasty. The addition of the butter gave the broth a creamy taste. The noodles were soft and easy to chew. The hard boiled egg was perfectly cooked to my liking with the runny yolk. The chashu seemed a little dry, but still tasted great.  Overall, a great experience and comparable to some of my favorite ramen spots in the Bay Area.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen with an extra side of noodles.

akI_bedKVXZx4t8Uk_qQRQ.text: The food is always amazing. I usually get the miso one. Sometimes, I would get the pork belly with rice. The meat is very tender, feels like it can melt in your mouth. I would give them 6 stars if I could, for their food.   Waiting is super long. One time I got here, the wait was almost an hour and I gave up. It's also very small inside, and I always have the pressure that people would hear me talking with my friends and the fact that a lot of people are waiting while I'm waiting keeps making me try to eat faster (I'm a slow eater, by the way). Since it's always packed, when you come here in the summer, even with the AC on, you can still be sweating bullets.   Parking is a pain. We usually have to park somewhere across the street, not in that shopping center.

zbvyepDvbbZ4trYdzC-UMQ.text: Through the years I have enjoyed Monta and never written a review. I'm sorry, Monta, please forgive me, you're absolutely wonderful and I love you and I recommend this place to anyone and everyone! Thanks for the best ramen in town. I've traveled the world and always prefer Monta. Now, I haven't been to Japan, so until then, this is THE BEST!

KA5451QUMIOlu3pyYITVPA.text: The ramen warrior in me is pleased. So delicious! Very small spot with great inexpensive food, so an average wait is normal.  Tonkatsu is the bomb and they serve Calpico! The kimchi fried rice is also a winner. I see why it's a fan favorite.  I'll be back again and again, especially on those rare cold, rainy days in LV.

7vJCVOvs9jU0U9nMeyiD0w.text: My colleagues and I had a three-day business conference in Vegas and at the end of day three, we were exhausted and hungry. We were staying in the north end of the Strip so I suggested ramen and everyone was game.  It was the PERFECT last meal of the trip. We went at 9:30 pm in our yoga pants to get our food to go. I got the Spicy Tonkatsu. My colleagues got the Miso and Shoyu. Our to-go containers had noodles in one container and the broth in another. Everything was tightly sealed - no spills on the way back to the hotel. They gave us spoons, forks and chopsticks.  And we all DEVOURED our bowls. The spicy had a little kick - I would call it a mild-medium. I haven't had much ramen in my life and I now understand why so many of my friends CRAVE it. Especially when it was as good as this was. We all had Ramen bellies in the morning.  Parking is a little tricky - it is a small lot with a lot of busy restaurants. Be patient! It's worth it! Next time I go - I want to get bubble tea from the tea shop two doors down, too.

nXDWulthescu7PMC4slhsw.text: The best ramen I've had so far. Worth the wait everytime It's my first stop everytime I come to Vegas.

iAH79rfoZNt8KTJzGjxB8Q.text: Normally, i never write a review. But this time i have to do it because we are so disappointed  I don't know how this restaurant got 4.5 star review. We are visiting from san diego for lunch during 4th of July weekend. The waitress is so rude and it seems she had a bad day. Never talk to anyone waiting the table then she split 7 of us to the table without even asking if that's what we want. By looking her bad attitude we just don't have appetite to eat there anymore. My suggestion is try go to near by Ramen restaurant. The food is better and their place is bigger and MUCH cleaner

NtOl1Uc30yA3BeC_MXNEGQ.text: Will not disappoint, as a broke college student finding something filling and for a cheap price and with everything tasting amazing, this place is the best. But know ahead of time that it does get busy especially around late hours so waiting could be about 20+ minutes but also as soon as 5 minutes. Either way the wait is worth it and everything is great.

3OHik5v9D73lfxDgnaYnzg.text: I still love Monta Ramen, especially Isako, not on the menu but the best "dish" there!

2T0Xfou7hyYw38z_I9P4EA.text: A great find near Las Vegas Strip.  There's nothing remarkable about the decor. It's all about the ramen. Half an hour wait on a Saturday evening was not bad at all, especially if this  tonkutsu-shoyu ramen was waiting for you..like a warm embrace. I added egg and nori. The ramen came only with a few,  but the tenderest charsu, so you might want to order extra. You might regret it, if you didn't.  The broth was really good. Honest.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I love dinner vacationlike this @ Monta Ramen

UlUaoorafO5USQRZrcAoBw.text: I give this place one star because of the fact that they gave less meet then even one star deserves if I could give them zero stars I would because they basically gave me zero meat. As far as the flavor goes not bad. I had the pork Ramen.   My best advice would be if you want more customers give more meat please thank you!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. No meat, skin only on the entire bowl of ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic oil ramen

KncdlzpJ3OkpkgoSrWlLOQ.text: We accidentally found this place while checking out Chinatown in Las Vegas. It's a small busy spot , very laid back and casual . The service was good we put our name on a list and were seated in about 20 minutes. Definitely worth every it . The ramen noodle bowls are outstanding we also had fried rice that was just as good . If your looking for a Japanese ramen noodle spot while in town I definitely recommend it . Plenty of foot spas in the area if you want to make an afternoon of it .

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hBMdkkBNeq8HkofyCH-VqA.text: Salt bombed is the best way to describe both of our ramen bowls. The thick and rich, gravy-like broth, was extremely salty and offended our taste buds. Although I preferred the spicy miso ramen over the tonkotsu shoyu, they were both incredibly heavy and beyond rich. The bowl and noodles were piping hot, but the broth was just warm.   We couldn't finish our bowls and left about 65% of it back (noodles and broth). After our dinner, our stomachs had a hard time digesting the richness and we felt a little nauseous. We could of shared one bowl of ramen, it was super filling and we had a ton of leftovers.   This is the first time I've ever regretted adding extra toppings on my ramen. The toppings didn't enhance or compliment our ramen. It all got lost in the thick salty broth. Plus the topping choices were rather boring, the best had to of been: corn, kimchi, and nitamago (flavored egg) - the kimchi was fresh and flavorful and they have perfected their soft-boiled egg!  Here's what we ordered:  Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with thin noodles (I didn't care for these noodles) and 2 slices of chashu (and with all of the extras): +dried seaweed - pretty boring +corn - I loved the corn's sweetness and texture  +nitamago (flavored soft boiled egg)- perfect!  +mustard leaf - mushy and flavorless +shredded green onion - adds nice texture and freshness +butter - this ramen doesn't need more richness!  $12.45   Spicy Miso Ramen with thick wavy noodles (the best noodles!) and 2 slices of thin chashu (and with all of the extras): +dried seaweed - boring +corn - great! +nitamago (flavored egg) - great!  +mustard leaf - boring and mushy +shredded green onion - adds freshness +butter - this ramen does not need more richness! :x $13.75  Side of extra chashu $2.50 - super fatty and buttery.   Side of Kimchi $1 - very fresh and flavorful.   Small pork belly bowl $3.95 - this was my favorite. The pork belly was tender, buttery, and rich in flavor. The rice was cooked perfectly and the green onion and sweet pickled ginger added perfect freshness to the rice bowl.  After eating here, it really made me miss Santouka Ramen in Costa Mesa, CA and Shin-Sen-Gumi Hakata Ramen in Fountain Valley, CA. :/

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Throwing in the white flag. So much food! Next time we&#39;re just ordering one bowl :p
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. One bowl would of been perfect for my bf and I to share. We had a ton of leftovers! It was souper filling!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Side of buttery chashu $2.50

EkP0eKCr5yUxYlYAPTux1Q.text: Tried this place on a friend recommendation, we found it packed, and had to wait for about 30 minutes, which I thought was a good sign. We ordered the Kimchi fried rice and Tonkotsu ramen soup. The rice was good, the soup was frankly ok. What makes a noodle soup is obviously the quality of the noodles and the spice flavors of the broth, and I found the flavors to be somewhat lacking. Many restaurants are riding the sudden wave of the Ramen fashion, and only few are truly deserving, I let everyone make their own judgement.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

XANwii0oW9unQ2qXaQce8A.text: Monta has always been a favorite of mine although today was not very memorable.  I took take out since waiting for a table is that of when the president arrives and stops all lanes of traffic, no one is ready and no one knows how to make it flow. Place is jam packed because of the tasty ramen provided but my personal opinion they have fallen off the tracks a bit due to such overwhelming success.  I took the tonkatsu soyu but was given just the soya offering. Discovered when I arrived to my home. The broth was what I wanted but it was too late and I felt it's from monta so it should taste good either way; I was not impressed. There were a few things wrong with the meal the tea egg was over cooked and just the overall wait inside the shop to pick up your Togo wasn't very pleasing.   This isn't a make or break for me with Monta just gave me a reason to find other ramen around town that do just ask great if not better

SYsWmome1N4qpknwvMEFMA.text: $6.95 for a bowl of tonkotsu ramen is pretty damn cheap. The ramen comes with two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots, and kirurage mushrooms and green onions. If you want a soft-boiled egg or corn it's extra. The ramen here is pretty good. The milky colored broth is full of pork flavor. I will definitely come back and try the other styles of ramen that they serve.

o6d2JWIY3xy_n7DC495Mfg.text: Be careful if you come here for lunch on a weekday.  Got here around 11:45. They open at 11:30. The place was already completely full with a 15 person (literally) waiting list. Insane. I got seated at 12:30.   The food:  I got my ramen within 6 minutes! That broth was on point!  Insanely flavorful. The pork was good too (it was cold, but still good). Also, the price was fair too. I added egg and seaweed, and mine was less than $10: Really delicious. Better than the ramen I've had in Reno, I need to try more places in Vegas to compare though.    Only come here if you have time to spare waiting for a bowl of soup. Otherwise, there are plenty of other food options in this area. Also, the place is so small that you'll smell like Asian food for the rest of the day.

0As6iGv-B5agTpDWjwg4nQ.text: I was recommended to this place.   4 stars for being the most amazing ramen I have ever tasted.  -1 star because there was an incident where a large group was waiting for a long time and the gentleman literally started yelling at the staff, 1 staff member was screaming at him back. It went on for a few minutes until the group left making everyone uncomfortable.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best ramen food

amHyYBE3aqlI74nMU116TA.text: Flashback to the first time I wanted to try this place... PACKED like no other that I couldn't even see through the windows. Looked like a major fire hazard so I did a 180 and got my ramen fill elsewhere.   This time, I came around 4pm, so with such an odd hour, I'm so glad I didn't have to wait! There's really not that many seats available but they do have pretty fast service. I had to try their tonkotsu ramen, adding the corn and the seasoned egg. The best part was definitely the chashu...melt-in-your-mouth delicious! The soup was a little thick/salty but still good. Overall, I would come back to maybe try the black garlic oil or add in other toppings and customize to my liking.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

bF04nXgtFDHtc_C-wWjydA.text: Great authentic restaurant. The fried rice and ramen are some of the best in town. I like the fresh ginger on the side. If you ask they will bring an extra bowl of ginger to your table. There is not a lot of tables available and there's a little bit of a wait to be seated. Walk in and put your name down as soon as you get there and be patient it's definitely worth it.

5tVwzyrbrNLIMQW5T8Kuqw.text: ((extreme salty)) if you want high blood pressure or heart stroke, come eat a bowl   bowls are small and salty that's all about this place

gMzCJJL9cqU3z3JBdaft8g.text: Trying the most hype ramen in LV ... Monta Ramen . The price is crazy cheap . $6.95 per order  u can't find that in LA. Taste wise hmmm LA's ramen still better  ... Expect long line because the place is so small . In the pictures : Spicy Tonkotsu ramen, Tonkotsu ramen , Tonkotsu and Shoyu ramen and Fried Rice .
