Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

e9ch_CN7hODHsey0tLB9bg.text: First off, I'm a huge ramen eater.  I came on a Saturday with two other people for dinner at around 6pm.  We had to wait about 20 minutes to get seated.  Once seated, I went for their Miso based ramen with added garlic oil, chili, egg, and corn.  It was delicious!  My only complaint was it was very salty.  Not overwhelmingly salty, but salty.  The ramen was the perfect texture.  The meat was good and everything went together really well.  My sister went for their Shoyu ramen, which is soy sauce based.  I had a sip of the broth and it was pretty good.  If you want a healthier choice, the Shoyu would be the one to go with.  We also ordered one Mini Mentaiko bowl but didn't even touch it because we were so full.  But later tried it and the eggs were way too salty.    For 3 bowls of ramen and the mentaiko, our total was about $24 without tip.  It was very reasonable.  The service was very fast.  Our food came out super fast.  The inside of this place is teeny tiny.  There's about 5 small tables and the bar that's it.  Prepare to wait on the weekends.  PS... if you have a crying baby/child, this is not the place to bring him or her.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $2.50 rice dish
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso with egg, corn, garlic oil, and chili

5UX9XiS-R7a6yScZ-9ByWQ.text: The soup was not bad but still not worth it. First of all when the soup came out it was not warm and noodle was soggy even though i told the server to get to extra hard noodles. The gyoza(dumplings) didnt taste that good and frice rice was very watery and was very disappointed about that. The server was not good at service as much either. They dont smile at all. Im a server in LA called shinsengumi as well so i know how customer service works but they dont know how to do customer service at all. They also collect dirty dish from our table instead of holding on there hands. They took away dishes when were still eating as well without asking .

0n_aNAEFV-O-eVhokKQ0ug.text: Still the standard bu which I judge Ramen and broths. Been to many around the country and this one is still my favorite.

r_2PC0P84sgfIjJt6Qvtkg.text: Me and my girlfriend went here and waited about an hour and a half to be seated at noon, so if you come here, be prepared for the long line. The ramen is at a really good price, we ordered a tonkotsu ramen and a black ramen. The tonkotsu broth is thick and delicious, black ramen is actually tonkotsu broth with some black garlic powder, was also delicious. I would say it's worth the wait.

V1ShPnVOb2ZLcD4JAbG3GQ.text: Delicious! We ordered 6 items (2 orders gyoza, 1 small mentaiko bowl, a pork belly bowl and 2 different ramens), and the total was only $40!!! The broth on the ramen is on point, and you could tell that the gyoza were homemade. I don't live in the area, but next time I pass by, this will definitely be my go-to stop!

0JtUq-g1l_ldGZMJLCFtiw.text: This place is good but I'm from LA where the Asian food scene is incredible. I got the spicy tonkatsu and pork belly bowl. For me, the ramen broth is too thick and salty and lacks depth. I prefer my noodles al dente and they are extremely soft here. Also I'm used to having an onsen egg included without extra charge, whereas here they don't include egg in your order, you have to order it as an add on. Lastly, the rice in the pork belly bowl was soggy. If you're from a city with amazing Asian food, I'd skip this location if you're in Vegas, you won't be super impressed.

P9EJ1fDn1OsIUbDPhF3W2Q.text: You will past literally hundreds of Oriental places to get here, before you arrive at this tiny 8 tables & a service counter Ramen Noodles place. I found to to be so fresh & hearty for a great price, you want to eat where the locals eat in this part of Chinatown. Self service, Sign in & wait for them to call your name, but  I recommend it you try the food, be carefully spicy was pretty Hot.

f-10k96CU_KyYYyXTiwKpw.text: Probably one of the best tonkotsu ramen I have ever had and I have a hate love (mostly hate) relationship with ramen LOL ANYWAY..... The broth was sooooo creamy just the way I like it. Super cheap for a nice meal. Don't forget to order the gyozas! Both boiled and fried for that perfect taste wuw.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

pKKBGFGco_4AAsDJNzxZLA.text: I have been a big fan of this place for several years, it's my no 1 ramen place in the town. Couple weeks ago I stopped by to pick up my phone order and they really disappointed me. Everyone was waiting outside at that time so I'm pretty sure they could notice me when I walked in. However, I waited for a long time before I got a greeting. The elder lady noticed me on her way to the bar area and she knew I was waiting for assistance but she tried to ignore me and just let me be there.      Ok, fine.      My bf and I went there for breakfast and the elder lady I met last time looked unhappy to serve, she served everyone because she have to. Also, I got an egg for my ramen and I have to rush to the restroom for the next couple hours. It's our first meal today and it almost ruined my day.  so..., plz plz plz make ur food fresh and ur waitresses look happy!!

j4mTmj1sekaLvhM4BcIGhg.text: When I found out this place was in one my favorite areas of town I was very excited to check it out.  There are several restaurants and even the snow shavery in this parking lot so sometimes parking can be a little difficult, but it's worth it.   Monta was smaller than expected inside...large parties may have a hard time here. There is bar seating much like a sushi bar and 4-5 tables. That's it! We came on a Friday evening at 6pm and were in and out by 7! Service was fast and easy.   The menu is simple, basically it's a choice of a Ramen noodle bowl or rice to include a pork belly bowl which is soooo fantastically good!   You can get a side of kimchi, flavored boiled egg, shredded green onion, butter, etc. they have plenty of table top items to add extra flavors to your meal which I loved...chili oil, soy sauce, garlic butter, vinegar and a blend of awesome seasonings.   Drinks come in a can (except water) and I think there was a choice of one beer (Asahi).   We had a great experience and will likely return for another round.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen, pork belly bowl so so good, and their black garlic oil ramen!!

0G3Ry9NZ7jHbfXaCdfZHiA.text: Ramen was a little on the cold side. My butter did not melt. If it had been warmer it would've been a 4/5. The broth is thick and the meat it tender. Added the corn and egg side (of course!). The wait on the weekend is at least 20 minutes so don't come too hungry. Limited seating.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

bww9F8hm-5NxOL7AzVEu4g.text: First time and we LOVE IT!!! It is a very small place and they few tables, but it is SO worth it. Their broths is delicious as well as their kimchi fried rice. Highly recommend it. Make sure your entire party is present at time of arrival. First full party come, first served.

EtekP4JkF-hJfprgWzavcA.text: We like eating there a lots but we have some bad experience there. We ate there a few times everything perfect. Me and my bf likes the ramen there but 1 time we decided to order to pick up. So we both get ramen and we didn't check what inside. Then we got home and get ready to eat. What we got is like plain noodles with broth. It's supposed to have pork chasu. And we ordered extra eggs and chasu. Nothing inside the box. We called and let them know we got plain noodles no meat nothing else beside noodle and the broth. The lady who picked the phone so rude. She said it's not right. Never happened like that. They always checked and she asked if I checked. I said no I didn't. Not even sorry and trying to say they are always right and I'm lying. And my bf there with me and he said we got nothing but noodles and broth. Then she said what is my name and phone number next time if we eat there they will give us extra. We haven't came back for very long bc we were so mad with their customer service. But decided to come back and give them another chance bc of they have good food. Guess what we both came back today and got upset stomach after couple hours. Didn't eat anything  after and we knew it from the restaurant what we ate. have to stay in the restroom for long time. Never come back again.

tj61KI6jlencF-iruNPklA.text: I'm a sucker for the pork belly bowl. I have eaten and enjoy the ramen dishes, but if I don't have the pork belly bowl, I am not satisfied with anything until I finally come back. I've tried pork belly dishes at other ramen and/or Asian food restaurants; this one has my heart.

sMJi-lmd5F0648ZB0VhSdw.text: Great noodles and prepare yourself to wait but other than that it's worth it. The only bad thing is that the girls that work there have attitude

2ampaAQtN2jd8OWMX4LkYQ.text: The food is absolutely amazing and the price is so affordable. You get a lot of ramen for a reasonable price. I have had numerous dates here and I have never had a bad meal. I only give it four stars due to the usual 20 minute wait to be seated.

ufXT6oMt3ZqRczKUWQRhHw.text: Amazing authentic taste ramen place. Best I've tried in US - highly recommended!!!! The tonkatsu ramen was great but the black garlic ramen is OUTSTANDING!!!! Everything comes quickly and service was quick and simple - a standard for ramen shop. You can't be disappointed for this place!!! Love love love!!!!

r_YD-zmeNztdb7sHz7Yslw.text: Monta set the bar for me when it comes to ramen. The chashu on the Tonkotsu ramen is melt is your mouth soft that I dont see in other places.

mEfkJH9suPcCSDAQjJCS9g.text: My go-to craving in all of Vegas. I crave this place at least once a week. It's far from where I live... but it's so good I usually go out of my way for it. Everything is always fresh and always tastes delicious. It's a very small place and only seats about 15-20 people. SO if your hungry, go early because there's always a long line for this awesome Ramen!

YkhOfURJwR8cbtJseHgY2g.text: Really yummy! For vegetarians, there is rice and a noodle dish. For meat foods, everyone loves the tonkastsu bowl. It's a classic with great flavor. I tried the black garlic ramen and it was really oily; I got a little sick after, I wonder if it was for the oils. The drinks come in cans. Service is attentive. Wait times can be long. They could use some more space somehow! It's tiny in there.

iLj50-2B4u7AlyaTZrO47g.text: I've been spoiled with really good ramen in the South Bay, and I was super excited to see this place get so many reviews. I had to come here twice, because the first time was so packed that I didn't have the patience to wait nor did I like waiting outside in 102 degree weather. So we came back the next day (15 min earlier) to avoid the line, and got seated right away. It's definitely average price for the bowl of noodles you get. I prefer a more favorable soup base and the noodles weren't freshly made, it's packaged noodles.   Overall, I might come here again when it's winter, but I cannot do hot noodle soup during a summer day.

Bd8TFZ1rcMP49FvvdLMczA.text: I'm no ramen guy. Actually, this is my first experience with True ramen from a restaurant. It definitely met my expectations. I got the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen on my friend's advice, and I also split some fried rice. Loved the rich broth, the texture of the noodles, and the way that the chashu (which isn't like what I'm used to) just melted away in my mouth. I can see how some people would complain of saltiness, but I liked it just fine. The fried rice was also delicious, although it did seem pricey for, you know, fried rice.  I was surprised at first by how small the place is, but after it became apparent that this is a spot for a quick meal, including rapid filling of orders, I saw how they could get away with it. You definitely shouldn't pick this place if you wanna linger around for an hour or more.

GaJwd2Bt-00ZDnOsRZKePg.text: This place was the second ramen place I've been to in town and I wanna say it was really good! I got the Tonkatsu shoyu with sea weed and egg. The broth was spectacular! And the pork was so tender....it melted in my mouth.  The only reason why I didn't give this place 4 stars instead of 5 is because they didn't have dessert:/ not even Mochi... Maybe next time:)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Dinner for 2..... I love this place!!!! And I&#39;m full!!!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl

9ZcFdXtLi4lvcbOETxvrYA.text: I wouldn't call myself a ramen snob, but I can appreciate a good bowl of ramen when I taste it. And I absolutely did with the Tonkotsu Ramen here- enjoyed it a lot!  The broth had hearty pork flavor and thick, creamy consistency, noodles were QQ- had the right amount of springy texture and chewiness to it, egg and Chashu Pork cooked perfectly. Everything blended really well together in flavor and texture. Anddd, what you get for the price makes it that much better! Super affordable and delicious always makes for a great meal!  The fried rice was one of my favorites as well. It's one of those dishes you will end up craving after you leave. Just get it when you go, trust me. I was hesitant when my friend ordered it because it's just fried rice- I could make that at home, right? I ended up eating most of it and left wanting more.   I've been patiently waiting for Monta to open in Richardson and when it does, I hope it's just as good as it was in Vegas. Can't wait!

G3PNoFqdiM6KX_H0v7h8oQ.text: Love some tasty ramen. The place is small and seating goes quickly but people eat fast so usually the wait isn't long. Service is good. The noodles are tasty and big portions! Parking kinda sucks if they're busy.

2qhIvya2FIyPmSyljnd5Yg.text: By FAR only place too go for Ramen! Growing up in Hawaii Ramen just about stable food as Spam musubi. So too finally find Ramen place same style food excited. It has all the same character small place holds less then fifty people, bar area (cool get see them make the ramen), and when the place gets packed line out the door. It SOO worth the wait. The timing is hit or miss. They first open in the morning for lunch that time always count on line. The whole small hole in the wall love because look where the restaurant located understand.  The food all the ramen is good. Shoyu Ramen I die for!! The flavor is spot on the depth nice light broth and depending if order additional topping can be hearty noodle dish. I prefer couple extras. Other thing find must really perfect compliment too big bowl of ramen is gyoza. It steamed perfectly then seared off on flat top too perfection and the filling is tasty. The gyoza sauce optional but must only way too have it combine together is divine.   They other sides I order the kim chee good but stand out is kim chee fried rice. It could ordered big bowl of that if they had it on the menu. =( It not over spicy but just the right amount of balance. They even have one beer offer on tap never think see small the place is never been good one too. I not remember name of it. Sorry.  The service is excellent. All the servers are very friendly and attentive. The prices are really reasonable. It light healthy tasty any time meal! =))) If never been say give it try!!!

6vwh18qmmIZhiHO-JMmxxA.text: despite the cold or hot weather that vegas gets whenever we are in vegas this place is a MUST on our list now! We stumbled upon this amazing place through yelp since we are from San Diego and we were unfamiliar with the area we usually mainly stay on the stripe when were in vegas but today was different we wanted to get away from the crazy scene and do something else and boy am I glad we did!   We came during a weird time around 230/300 so the place was pretty empty but I'm sure during lunch and dinner they are packed considering they only have a handful of tables. When you enter you instantly smell the delicious broth. We were welcomed and seated instantly. When we looked at the menu I was surprised to see that the Menu was small! It only had about 4 entrees and half Of them were ramen with the other half side dishes so instantly I knew that this place was going to be delicious since they only specialized on one type of dish! i got the miso ramen while my fiance got the tonkatsu (did I spell that right? Lol) ramen. Both were delicious it's ridiculous how much flavor the broth had! Hands down the best ramen place that I have tried so far!   As for service I have no complaints either everyone was friendly and greeted us when we entered and when we left! Like I said this place is a MUST now for us whenever we are in vegas and I can't wait till I go back again!   Side note: when we got back to our hotel room after eating here we turned on the food channel and they happened to be on tv! I thought it was a pretty funny coincidence but it just goes to show how yummy this place is! (:

lZ4SBrEQwN_AdoEdaqKiwQ.text: A-ma-zing! Best ramen I've had anywhere, in or out of Las Vegas. Came here after word-of-mouth rave reviews on my birthday (a Saturday) around 2pm. There was a little bit of a wait (maybe 3 minutes total) but there's a milk tea place next door and seats for waiting. Anywho, I ordered Shoyu ramen with no pork and added nori to it. My partner had miso ramen and added nori. We ordered white rice and kimchi to share. The napa cabbage kimchi is fresh and not overly fermented, and my ramen was flavorful and delicious. A pretty good sized bowl too! For all of this (2 bowls of ramen, rice, kimchi, one drink) it cost less than $20 before the tip. I've tried one other ramen place in Las Vegas' Chinatown and this one beats it by leaps and bounds. So good I came back the next day!! Same great experience with the spicy ramen.

kstLuOM5_uxt2mGr_LfA0w.text: I arrived at around 1pm for lunch after working a 12 hour graveyard shift. As I pulled into the parking lot a bum approached the front of my car and stopped me, he asked me to roll down my window, I could smell the alcohol coming off his breath mixed with the smell of unwashed body... after explaining to me that he "wasn't lying and telling the truth" and needed three dollars to get on a bus to take his "kid' (pointing at a wall where no one was) home I told him I had no cash... after staring at me for a moment deciding what to do about that I cut him off and told him to have a good day and good luck... and then proceeded to try to find a new parking spot as someone went around me and took the good parking spot that I was aiming for before I was approached by said bum!......  I have read reviews and you really don't understand how small this place is from reading them. the size of the bedroom... I mean... their dining area... is smaller then the size of my master bedroom.... You could not fit two king sized beds in the main dining room area. after getting over that shock, I signed in and proceeded to wait. after about 20 minutes four people from the bar area left and I was seated...  Now I'm a bigger dude. I push about 290 on a good day and the stool i was on was uncomfortable and flimsy but for some miracle it didn't break!  I ordered a mini Mentaiko and a Tonkotsu Ramen. The Mentaiko was actually very tasty, those eggs do give a good spicy kick, but once I mixed everything up with the rice and added some soy sauce it wasn't long before it was gone.  The Ramen was flavorful , I added more chashu pork, nitamago (hard boiled egg) and nori to the bowl when I ordered. The broth had a ton of flavor to it. I really did like it. however, I noticed that the noodles are pre-packaged and did not have any sustenance to them they were a little bit of a let down and I wasn't really into them but they didn't take away from, nor add anything of value to the soup broth itself.   The Chashu Pork was melt in your mouth good. I don't think it was worth the extra 2.95 for the extra two paper thin slices though. however, the extra cost for the 1.50 for the egg was definitely worth it and to be honest, the server I had was actually really nice and she worked really hard to make sure everyone was happy which I really liked to see. after paying in cash...  I ended up getting most of it to go and I just finished the last bit of it while writing this review... (for some reason after re-heating it actually tastes more flavorful! that's kinda odd)...  I would recommend giving Monta at least a try... it's not spectacularly good but it's good enough that I'd come back and try some of the other broths.. I have been to Ichiza for Ramen too. (just up the road from this place heading east) and if I had to compare the both I'd say that Monta comes out on top in terms of the quality of the broth... if I could get Monta Broth with Ichiza Noodles it'd probably be the perfect bowl of Ramen.  I've subtracted 1 star for just how small this place is and the fact that if you go by yourself you'll pretty much be forced to sit on the uncomfortable stools that promise either a fun trip to the ground if they break or a sore ass by the time you're done. I also subtracted 1 star because I didn't particularly care for their noodles.  When you go, hopefully you won't be accosted by the homeless in the area, seems to be a lot of them hanging out around popular places trying to find "bus fare"

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mini Mentaiko it was surprisingly good! I mixed everything up, added a little soy sauce and went to town!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Very tasty broth!

yIjCMTFli4DFxMwsyCRdNA.text: I love love love Monta Ramen! I always try to stop by here at least once during every trip to Las Vegas. Their broth is so good and the flavors of each of their ramen bowls are all savory and distinct from one another. I prefer the thick wavy noodles opposed to the thin ones, but they allow you to substitute any of the ramen with a different noodle type. The pork belly is my favorite and is definitely one of the reasons why I keep coming back to this place. Sometimes I'll add an egg or butter to my ramen bowl, which adds extra texture.   Their chasha bowl is also really good if you don't like ramen. The meat is really tender and juicy and they give you a perfect amount of rice to go with it.

EnqgIx6IWxah1n3dMeXe4A.text: Just ate here and it was seriously the best ramen I've ever had, definitely. And for a great price! Seriously, for a standard bowl of tonkatsu shoyu it was like $7.   It was very filling, might I add.   But, point is, the staff was incredibly kind, the service was incredibly speedy, like blow my mind speedy, and the food was impeccable. I will be coming back. 10/10

xxpGkfMkWDbo077KixPfwg.text: Hands down top three ramen spots on the west coast, right up there with Daikokuya, and the line can be just as long.

ylWqUVSDe_gZosYvTFWcyA.text: This is the best ramen I have ever tasted. They have a small dining room with awards all over the walls and once you taste the ramen you understand why. Their ramen is so delicious and flavorful, and reasonably priced. If you're in the area definitely check this place out.

h0dfmsmSB1jYm1O5BBk5gw.text: Was great the first time I went, but this last time was not ass good.  The tonkotsu ramen broth was so thick that it felt like I was eating a bowl of ramen with gravy...

solnlj2LNxARnm9BU_d6Ng.text: I used to wonder how people could get excited about Ramen.  To me it was a perfectly serviceable bowl of protein, carbs and veg.  Now that I've discovered Monta I know what I was missing.  We've been 3 times in the last month and it's turned into something I CRAVE.  I go for the Shoyu Ramen with corn (I like the extra crunch it brings) and a side of kimchi is a must.  I know they're just pulling it out of a big jar but whatever brand of kimchi is in that big jar it's darned delicious!  We've had to wait a couple of times but on this last visit at about 5pm on a Saturday we walked right in.  Love the vibe...small, bustling, feels like Tokyo!

5vid52ApN3Gehz9RM4LADg.text: Wow!!! I have tried several other ramen places in chinatown and this one definitely had the best miso ramen, ever! It was so inexpensive, too. I am definitely going back. Thank you for making my night, Monta Ramen!!

3vJ08wFA59VQnxbrr-hHpg.text: 6/5, got the pork belly bowl and my girlfriend got the ramen. best ramen she's had since japan and the pork belly bowl was delicious. also fast service and very reasonable, I could barely finish the pork belly bowl and it was less than $6, what a deal. you have to give this place a try

aT6xRx6ghVpyrqjzVmNvFQ.text: Great soup bases. It's a pleasant surprise that Vegas offers an authentic ramen place like this (in fact, this is not the only one). The basic bowl is not expensive, but it's easy to add additional options thinking they are cheap, but they add up; so be careful! The place is small, not recommend for a party large than four.

I4vkzrMgjN8_x9NhFtR9eQ.text: What a great find in Las Vegas! Initially, I didn't come here with much expectations because no other ramen places I've been to have impressed me as much as Ramen Dojo in NorCal. Knowing that the capacity of Monta Noodle House fit around 20 or so customers, I anticipated a wait so arrived 30 minutes before opening on a Friday afternoon. Arriving early got me a table right at opening...yay to that! so COME EARLY to avoid waiting.   Monta Noodle House offers three different kinds of broth but I got a recommendation from one of their regular customers to order the tonkatsu-shoyu combo broth! The standard bowl comes with noodles, bamboo shoots, onions, and two pieces of pork. I wanted the ultimate ramen experience so I added on some extra stuff to spice up my bowl - I added the soft boiled egg (a must for every ramen bowl!), sweet yellow corn and shredded green onions (MUST add - gives great flavoring to the whole bowl). I also garnished my ramen bowl with the togarashi chili powder and sesame seeds! The addition of sesame seeds in the bowl was just perfect =) I have to say the best part about this place is the ramen that they used - the noodles were so soft & the thickness was about the size of egg noodles but with a softer texture. I definitely enjoyed this.They also give you plenty of noodles to fill you up real GOOD!   If you're ever craving ramen in Las Vegas and can wake up early enough after a night of partying..remember to check this place out! It's located in Chinatown so having a rental car is convenient. Solid 4 stars for satisfaction and it's location in VEGAS!!  FYI: I also heard that the kimchee fried rice was also good to try.   Happy Eating =)

q7hkKTgxzqYRKc-AbCFF0Q.text: this is a local place and we were so glad we found it!    this place is located in the same plaza as raku (another local favorite) on spring mountain road which is known as chinatown (and you will find all different asian restaurants here).  their ramen was super duper delish.  i went with the tonkatsu broth which has a strong pork flavor, but kind of wished i went with the shoyu which is clean soy sauce, tangy, a bit sweet broth.    vegas is all about buffets and over the top fancy schmancy restaurants, but if you are in the mood for good ramen for around $8, i strongly recommend this place.  p.s. and it's great for hangovers -- i'm just sayyyin'.

7UnjPyC3mQxzlU_Tfj6M2g.text: I"m half Japanese and lived in Japan for 18 years so I know what good ramen taste like. Monta's Ramen is Good. I also enjoy their Chaahan (Fried Rice), looks greasy but it's very good, the gyoza is good too. Heard they're opening a second store off Eastern/Serene next to the Japan Creek Store and it's going to be much bigger space. Only 5 mins from home, can't wait.

2yzf_Y3LJDiVC0et03_f9g.text: My favorite Ramen Noodle place....well my 2nd one I ever been too and it is worth the wait. It's so dam small so be prepared to wait 30 min or more. Even out in the dessert heat. The soup broth is perfect...no to fatty and the ramen noodle is cooked perfect. Add Kim Chi and bam! cure for hangover or whatever.....

i9sVSi44Sy5gJCumMP8oVA.text: I wish we had one of these places in my city!  I had the Miso Ramen with the seaweed and the pork.  AMAZING! and for under $10. Unreal.

w6ZNGZKFhtStRNuKUsLYUw.text: This one of my favorites spots on Spring Mountain. Its a truly satisfying meal. I like the tonkatsushoyu because its the perfect balance; rich yet flavorful. the noodles are perfect every time and add what toppings you like, seaweed, egg, green onion, kim chee, PORK BELLY!!! MMMM PORK BELLY!!!!!

4uX3RQzoVN9H6J6Lja2guA.text: Way over-hyped.  From the Bay Area with tons of great ramen shops here, this joint is way below standards by comparison.  Nevertheless, this shop is in Las Vegas so you got to take what you have available here.  Their "basic" ramen choices are very bland unless you order a lot of the extras.  If you want something tasty, plan on layering all the extras, otherwise it is not worth it.  My family paid $40 for taxi rides to and from our hotel with this place and it definitely wasn't worth it.  Place is super small so not a lot of tables for their customers.  We went on a night that was not crowded.  Service was friendly.  If it wasn't for this, I would rate this a one star.

7YtPkr1jCXpcouenyNyIoQ.text: Great hole in the wall Ramen place! Great service and staff are very accommodating. We got our order right away which was awesome!  The wait for a table isn't too bad, if its cold just wait in your car or there are several massage places next to Monta :  ).

YbWLkq4EfANXnlKoxotMJg.text: Best food ever and the staff was so nice. I accidentally left my Invisalign on the table when I left and it was thrown away :( came back and the waitress dug through the trash for even though I told her I would. So super super nice staff!

Xi8N2PmUUkvU2NfNe5EEgQ.text: First review ever written and what a great place to rave about!  At first, Monta looks reliable, its not too big and is in a very small and overlooked spot, which most good eats usually are.  You walk in and it gives you a very homie feeling, despite its small size.    If you love ramen, this is the place to go!  The ramen is cooked to perfection and includes all the added ingredients that make any ramen craver beyond satisfied!  My personal favorite is the tonkotsu ramen with nitamago and a side of their gyoza!  Sooo Ono!  Definitely a must visit!

JcmmqaOH4-4NTSEtLd7TCg.text: Extremely good and authentic. I doubt the owners are chinese or korean. The workers are mostly japanese believe it or not and as far as the food itself is GREAT im definitely going back i love it it also feels like youre in japan by the way its set up

YR6yiZBa1ZHqQPkGfhQHFg.text: I want to start by subtracting the one star because the restaurant was uncomfortably hot - at least where I was seated, it was. I was at the end of the bar practically inside the kitchen. There was a wait, as usual, but as usual, the wait is worth it. I brought a ramen enthusiast friend from out of town. He ordered the tonkatsu shoyu ramen with egg and I ordered the tonkatsu ramen with mustard greens. We also split an order of the pork belly over rice. LET ME TELL YOU. This pork belly over rice was so silky and delicious that I didn't want my ramen anymore. I didn't even need the pork belly. The oils and the flavors of the pork just sinks into the rice and the rice alone is OUT OF THIS WORLD. The ramen is no joke either. The texture of the noodles stays perfect throughout the entire meal. They don't become so bloated with soup that they turn into mush. I hate mushy noodles. My friend ate his entire ramen bowl down to the last drop of soup! Now heed this warning: The portion sizes are not of America! If you think you are going to get this huge bowl of unfinishable noodles and broth, YOU'RE A GLUTTON. The portion size is just right and leaves you with JUST enough room for you to share an appetizer and have a cup of tea. This isn't the type of place for socializing. Eat your noodles and GTFO so that all of the other hopeful patrons can share a piece of the heaven that you have just experienced.

IulwpH7PfY_93x4QVcGtYA.text: I'm so glad my gf found this place on yelp for our final lunch at Vegas!  We ordered: - Tonkatsu Ramen: Absolutely wonderful smooth & milky pork-based broth. My favorite ramen is at shin sen gumi, and this bowl of ramen was very comparable, if not better. I also added toppings of a hard boiled egg and extra slices of pork - they gave 6 extra slices in addition to the two slices of pork that came with the bowl by default. I decided to avoid the kimchi because I didn't want the Korean toppings to dominate the Japanese broth. Noodles were cooked perfect, and you can order extra noodles for $1.50. - Shoyu Ramen: This is the darker one, I believe it's miso/soy based. My gf had this, and I tried the broth and it seemed equally as delicious. - Gyoza: It's like lightly grilled potstickers - Fried Rice: typical fried rice as expected - not something to die for, but good. - Kimchi Fried Rice: Pretty much exactly like the fried rice, except that it had a bit of the tangy flavor that the kimchi added - Pork bellow bowl: This was my favorite out of the fried rice bowls. Lightly cooked, tender, moist and juicy pork belly strips layered on top of white rice. Definitely worth getting along with the ramen.  Service was fantastic. Our group of 5 was sixth on the waitlist, but it moved pretty fast; we waited maybe about 20 or so minutes.  Cliff Notes: Tonkatsu Ramen with hardboiled egg and extra pork. Pork Belly bowl.

SsfnGT55FwcTJYzskn-iUg.text: Yummy.  The extra meat and boiled egg sides are a must.  I tried the pork ramen bowl.  Order the extra noodles if you're not full off the bowl.  Friendly staff.  Good portions.  Affordable.

_ejuKi4XhwLj_zgehrRaGQ.text: Great little and I do mean tiny restaurant. We had shoyu ramen bowls and it was delicious.  In and out in 30 min, but don't be surprised if you have to wait for a seat.  Place sits about 30. We will be back!

cbmtBPL8tM9AD50l6NCMhQ.text: I absolutely love this place. I have been to one other ramen place and I don't like pho so this is one of my favorite restaurants. I always get the tonkotsu ramen with extra pork and a side of gyoza. There is never a super long wait for the food. However, since they are a very small hole in the wall, the wait time is sometimes almost 40 minutes depending on if you want a bar or table seat. Sometimes it can be a bit stuffy. I think the price is great and the food is phenomenal.

DmgShgzZtzST8aJvGiYFYw.text: Rarely do I ever crave food but, this place is so good that I go across town just to bring it back home! Authentic Japanese ramen that is extremely cheap! I always get the tonkotsu ramen and it never disappoints. The pork melts in your mouth and the broth is so tasty! Not to mention the awesome decor in there as well with the mini action figures! I will frequently come back!

pOjCOZYx_fBJOhw-6OXsOQ.text: Made fresh to order all the time.  Miso ramen is great and the portions are plenty.  The soup base is so tasty and I love the corn added to it.  The pork is very tender and not too fatty.     The waitress is pleasant and to the point.  Usually always a line outside before they open so expect to wait a bit.    I will definitely be back for more good ramen after a fun night in Vegas.

USiwUmIpkbCN4JN7_5deBQ.text: Talk about authentic! I  am from Hawaii and we love our food! We have a substantial Japanese population that kept the old school style cooking and we also have the new generation dabbling with Fusion dishes. I can say I love both. A bit surprised at the comment made a couple back from mine. I would say maybe her taste buds need coaxing to enjoy a good meal.   As for the pork belly dish, my grandmother made the best and this is pretty comparable to hers. And that's a huge compliment.  Thumbs Up!!

CcW1V4m0KSvw3s-bNkWs3w.text: Outstanding traditional gyoza! Pork belly over rice was very good. Cha han was just ok. Kuro black garlic ramen was good. Spicy tonkatsu was thick but the non spicy one was better. Egg was good! We are from Bay area and I guess we are spoiled with best ramen.

mdXXiIzUewKza4wPrVQuTQ.text: This was my first visit for dinner.  There was only a short wait to be seated at a table.  The restaurant was located on Spring Mountain Rd/S Decatur Blvd in Las Vegas.  I ordered the Miso Ramen.  My friends ordered the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen and the Tonkotsu Ramen.  They all came with green onions, two slices of fatty chashu, thinly sliced bamboo shoots and kikurage.  Butter, corn, kimchee, extra chashu, nori, egg, etc were extra.  The portions were small for the price.  Luckily there was a plate of condiments:  soy sauce, sesame seed oil, sesame seeds, and chili powder to add flavor to the bland broth.  I probably won't be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen

S7gls0mdK5gMDAF85BpNHw.text: Absolutely hands down the worst Japanese Ramen from a restaurant I have ever tasted. The locals told me this is the best ramen place in town. Well that just adds another reason why Vegas sucks!   I have lived in Japan so I know what real quality Japanese ramen tastes like. I had their shoyu tonkatsu ramen and the noodles were half cooked and the broth was horrible.  They have instant ramen at mitsuwa or greenland for Vegas that tastes better than this crap! They put 2 small slices of meat and thats it. You have to pay for an egg and any other garnish. Theres only 4-5 small tables so just because theres a line outside doesn't mean its good. Will never go back to this dump!

mFi3H8rFkbKgm_W9N_4_ZQ.text: This is where I lost my ramen virginity so I can't say if it's the best but I truly enjoyed it.  There was a bit of a wait but I am told this is normal.  Its a small space and a bit noisy so don't expect a quit spot.  The food was great, cheap and served fast.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ramen with egg.

XddFU58FV8vo55OGPIe1OQ.text: Just tried Monta Ramen for the first time at the Ramen Yokocho Festival in Los Angeles.  As a SoCal native, I was blown away by how good Monta's product was.  They were easily the best bowl of ramen at the festival.  They took on Tsujita, Zagat rated and the best LA has to offer, and stood toe to toe.  I work in the Westside, so I eat at Tsujita a couple of times a month.  Monta gave them a run for their money with fine, al dente noodles, half a perfectly cooked onsen tamago, and an unctuous broth that was rich and flavorful without being too heavy.  Monta easily beat the two heavy hitters from Japan - Mattou Seimen, three time Tokyo Ramen Festival champion, and Tatsu No Ya, the #1 ramen shop in Kyushu.  Monta also took out a personal favorite, Shalala Ramen from my native NorCal, and a Googler staple.  (Shalala's Mountain View shop is 5 minutes from the Googleplex.)  Shinsengumi Hakata Ramen?  Not even a contender.  Monta Ramen is now on my short list of must-eat places in Las Vegas, along with Japanese Curry Zen.

qlUVWIp5pO3ksXgsiVUAHw.text: The best part about Monta Ramen is that it is completely customizable!  If you want to go with the bare essentials, then your bill is going to be the cheapest Ramen bill in Las Vegas.  Very good value!  But if you're like me and like a little (or sometimes a lot) more fixings, then you can add all that you'd like for additional prices!  Completely customizable and high quality ramen for a reasonable price!  The place is a little small, so I don't recommend big groups though.  Bring a friend or two and you should be just fine.

rf1onoxc3Tau_Kc8TPiPBw.text: Nom Nom. I heart ramen. I was a little nervous about a salt OD after reading the other reviews so I decided to go with the shoyu broth (chicken broth). It wasn't quite as rich or flavorful as pork broth, but I was pleased to note that salt was kept to a minimum without compromising flavor (I also begged them to lighten up on the salt). I love ramen as a meal. Its cheap, fast,  and totally filling, not to mention tasty.   We split a gyoza app, which was super greasy. Would probably skip that one. My husband felt like the 105 heat was too much for warm soup, so he opted for cold ramen noodles in a sesame dressing, which I also thought was absolutely delic. The menu is pretty limited so be prepared to eat ramen. So excited to find a good ramen place in Vegas. Skip the overpriced strip eateries and head to Chinatown for yummy, reasonably priced food.

B6F2s33_z5Pi6OzzzrKnhA.text: Not bad at all. Most people came for the Ramen. but their cold noodle w/ sesame souse is quite nice. My GF if vegetarian so this was the only thing she can eat here. A little disappointed in the beginning while found out this is the only vegetarian dish on the menu. However, after the first bite it turns out very good, refreshing and flavorful. People should try it! Highly recommend! Especially during the summer month while it is melting hot at Vegas...

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sesame souse over cold noodle - veggie style

tJpruBu317iHApeCSFtFug.text: Best meal by far of our entire trip to LV. Manta Ramen is worth any wait and is a great deal. The food is absolutely delicious.

uK6SgKmBs0tm157XRi71fA.text: Gah! I wish I read the reviews more carefully so I would have known that you need to order the egg as an add on. Everyone raved about the egg, so I assumed it was included, but it's not!   Oh well, the ramen is still excellent. I had the tonkotsu, but since my mom ordered the tonkotsu shoyu and my grandma had the shoyu, I was able to sample 3 out of the 4 available soups. The soup has a clean flavor and isn't as kotteri (fatty) as what you find at Santouka (my fave ramen joint). The noodles are also very thin - like angel hair pasta. The chasiu is definitely a standout and meltingly tender. I also ordered a small fried rice and it was delicious and quite literally glistening.  We came here around 1:30 on Saturday afternoon and scored the last 3 seats at the counter. As others have mentioned it is a very small restaurant, but most people eat their noodles and go so turnover is fast. Definitely a great place to check out in Vegas for some authentic ramen!

jFj9qGqFFANjpLaK7fSZEg.text: Whenever I have business in Vegas I make this a must do. I travel a lot and have determined that this is the best ramen in the country! I always do Tonkotsu since their broth is like no other. Rich and silky. I can never put down the whole bowl but I come close.  Dined there yesterday with a fussy eater. He downed the gyoza and the ramen. Love this place. Has been consistent and excellent for years.

kdA2u1UYATz8Mex7zcPT9A.text: Ramen seems like it would be a simple delicacy to create, but this place makes it such an exquisite dish and it is quite delightful to the taste buds.   I noticed a lot of bad reviews are due to the size and service of the restaurant as opposed to the food. But everytime I've came here I have never had that problem.   First of all, if you know this place is going to be small I wouldn't suggest bringing large groups. Everytime I've been here was with only one other person when I've had a craving for good ramen and some Japanese beer. With that said I've always been able to get a seat without having to wait too long and my food has always come out speedy, fresh, and fantastic.   The tonkatsu-shoyu ramen is awesome and if you'd rather opt out of the mixed broth they are both good stand alone too. There are a lot of toppings you can add to your soup which is pretty awesome also.   Great place for anyone to check out, but just remember the size capacity issue when trying out this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Delicious

XF-FmQ3gPCUYd8zBWbXhJw.text: Monta Ramen noodles are excellent!!! This is like my second kitchen.  Highly recommended.

I6ZwTrCYaa9xaarYL4O2Ng.text: We lucked out in that we got there around 9:15 on a Tuesday, but this place did NOT disappoint!  Didn't have to wait, which based on the reviews, I was worried about!  Never had ramen and this was sensational!  The broth is incredible and the service sensational!  Also, loved the pork belly bowl - which was another first.  I would go again and recommend to EVERYONE I know!

GWkE30xNURpxSWyFGHo9mQ.text: try their tonkotsu ramen, the soup base is kind of salty, I like ramen Sora better..it is a small place, not too comfortable for sitting with all the crowd, usually a long line

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

jv9endbt2uftppkNtrWJww.text: For a ramen shop in Las Vegas, it's pretty good. I ordered miso and it was on the salty side. But the soup was tasty with juicy piece of a pork and I love the thin ramen/noodle. The place is clean and you can see the ramen experts in action. It's a piece of an art.

lbpIrY9TfpL5zGYKbf2K4w.text: I have died and gone to Ramen Heaven. Enough said. Four stars only because they are in need of added square footage. Small and gets crowded. BUT worth every minute of the wait. Done yelping...back to grubbing. Mmmmmmmmmm

pxg2I6xsXfca9QIzYztdrQ.text: I've been here a couple times before hand, but lately it hasn't been what it was when it first opened. I went with my dad at my last visit. We both have the same taste in food so i thought he might be able to help me review this place. We ended up ordering 2 miso Ramen, as they contain the least amount of sodium, and we both were surprised at how they could end up making this one of the SALTEST broths we'd both ever tasted.. the worst part about it was it wasn't even ramen noodles.. it was the type of noodles they use in Chinese pan fried noodles..(thin egg noodles instead of wheat noodles)  which surprised both of us. I honestly wouldn't go back just because of this fact. The broths are just too darn salty...

4MKIQB1PBxD2THLttwMRlQ.text: If you love ramen, then you have to try this place. Easily comparable to authentic Downtown Los Angeles J-Town ramen. The menu is simple yet fulfilling and they have calpico soft drink too! Although a small place, its cozy and worth the wait in line. Ive been back twice in one day and its just as amazing as the first time. Highly recommended. I stop by every time I'm in Vegas..5 STARS!

PBjzDYmg2kngot9a9oqtkw.text: Two of us had lunch here today. I don't have enough ramen experience to go on in detail regarding the finer points of the meal. It was delicious and filling and at a fair price. We had the Tonkotsu Ramen, Miso Ramen, extra noodles on one and the regular size Pork Belly bowl.  The noodles had a fantastic texture and the broth was great. We both loved it and plan on eating there more. Service was friendly and efficient.

8S2uW3tYFIPUqraScsbbHQ.text: Monta is fantastic...a fantastic real Japanese Ramen house hidden in the middle of LV. Everything here is authentic, tasty, cheap, fun and fantastic. If you are looking for a small, real Japanese noodle house in LV, this is the place. enjoy!

YvuWVf5tYmRQhL_Kuv3OAQ.text: This rating is not for the food, which we didn't get a chance to eat, but for the smell.  Upon walking into this bustling little noodle shop to put our name on the list, the overwhelming smell of toilet turned us off and we selected a different restaurant to try within 5 minutes.  We've eaten at many ramen places and had not ever been to a place where the smell was so overwhelming and yet seemingly unrecognized by the patrons.

J76awBpY0w5A09CF5T_p1g.text: This is one of my favorite places to eat in town.  It's also the best ramen place I have found (I have tried several in town and several in LA).  I order the Miso ramen and add the seasoned egg!  They can get pretty busy, and they won't seat your party unless everyone is present.

VsCeRr5zZgFz9ruSMLGjzg.text: I went to Vegas recently for a mini-getaway, and being the crazy ramen aficionados that we are, my boyfriend and I HAD to come here and try this place during our trip.  We both ordered the Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen with extra chashu and hard-boiled (more like deliciously and perfectly soft-boiled!) egg.  The broth was absolutely delicious--just the right amount of flavor and rich pork fatty goodness to make it taste perfect!  Even though it was 103 degrees outside, I didn't care.  I ate and drank the entire bowl clean.  Gluttony at its finest.  Woo!  I was extremely impressed with the quality and texture of their chashu.  It was marinated just right and they really did cook it for hours to get it to really melt in my mouth!  The moment I bit into a piece, I didn't even really have to chew at all...it immediately disintegrated into orgasmic morsels of ecstasy and rocked a party in my mouth!  The egg was perfection...just the way all ramen "hard-boiled" (I still think they should call them "soft-boiled"...it just suits the texture better!) eggs should be.  The yolk was nice and and gooey and soft.  It complimented the ramen broth so well!  Needless to say, I wolfed down the entire bowl in about 10 minutes or less. hehe ^_^    We also got an order of the regular fried rice, and the only thing I can say is that it is THE BEST Japanese fried rice I have EVER had in my life thus far (in the States).  The rice was so extremely flavorful and light (because too much oil is a no-no).  Sprinkled with those little slices of heaven known as their chashu and plenty of pickled ginger, it tasted PHENOMENAL.  That was the 2nd party that rocked my mouth in one sitting!  Boy, what an awesomely dining experience!  Exquisite ramen.  Good price.  Great service.  Will most DEFINITELY have to visit again whenever we're in the area.  Oh, and my brother (who doesn't eat pork) also came with us.  He ordered the kimchi (or spicy?) fried rice without the pork and REALLY enjoyed his food.  He was even full off just that one single plate, so their portions are very reasonable, considering the elephant-sized appetite that he has.

1fXoSRV_rnevFzXsVgkOsQ.text: 3.5 stars. The ramen wasn't bad. The tonkatsu soyu broth was MUCH better than the tonkatsu broth version.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

J-FAUDaPCIzcYvYD0r7TDg.text: Best ramen house in Vegas...takes me away from Pho!!

hl3g5-VKVnbrna4rx_hjcw.text: This is one of my favorite ramen places!  The service is friendly and the food is very good and inexpensive. A lot of people complain that the broth is sometimes too salty, which I do agree with.  If you do think so, you can send it back and have them add some hot water to your dish.  I definitely recommend this place to all of my friends. A downside is it's a very small location, and seating is limited.  If you're heading there for dinner Fri-Sun, definitely expect seating delays.

gaBrTbzBGi2-MpdwTPjaYA.text: The ramen was good. We have been to Japan and the ramen is similar in taste. The place is busy and small like they are in Japan. I recommend getting here early and be prepared to wait if you have a big party. I like their Shoyu ramen, the gyoza was ok. I thought for $5.00 it was a bit steep. I will visit again although I am not a big fan of MSG which I know for sure they have in their broth.

XBtDdJXUyiKidBy9Or9auw.text: Very good ramen.  Not the best I've had, but absolutely solid and definitely hits the spot since I haven't had good ramen in several months.  I got the shoyu ramen and added nori, egg, and char sui.  Yes, I missed ramen.  The portion was completely decent.  The char sui was a waste of additional money I felt because the pork was way too fatty and broke apart too much in the soup.  Not worth the trouble, especially when there was no particularly special flavor to it.  They serve canned iced green tea which was delicious as well.

Q57VH8UA0G2CE4l-wmroWw.text: tonkatsu shoyu w/ soft egg! the broth is soo flavorful. sitting at the bar feels like i've been plopped in a japanese movie or anime. & i like watching the dude fling the noodle basket about.  fried rice is good too.

vd4r3bQN6PaAymDQCjYJQA.text: I am definitely a huge fan of this place! The ramen is amazing! I actually love everything on this menu! Just wish they have bigger parking lot! Or at least at a better location!

Pb4Hyl4nggLxIP1X66fWyA.text: One of my favorite places in Vegas. But their restaurant size has them always hosting a mammoth line out the door. As a former local I wouldn't wait for Monta. They do not have super fast service like ramen spots in Tokyo and westerners drag along and take their time. Love the noodles, but I wouldn't wait more than 10 minutes in line for them.

aFbBwawTmJ2eUE4vANzIOA.text: Tonkotsu might get four stars, the shio and miso/tonkotsu two or three.  Too salty, noodles were a little soft and I personally prefer the curly kind (rather than the round, straight kind at Monta). Pork was good, soft boiled egg was pretty good.  Personally I like the small, crowded restaurant.  It seems to somehow be the right ambiance for a ramen shop.

Cut6lbyj9XNB8QoKtOHSMg.text: Favorite Ramen noodle place!! Real Japanese style and flavor. Expect a wait but it's worth it!!

-hW5UchoPWuZDtodm2BWoQ.text: I went back to Monta today and I must say, it was different from the first time that I went! Maybe they just had an off day! Regardless, this place is always busy for a reason! Check it out! Fried rice ftw!

2scMGUgOvSvSrlS2avLVwg.text: One of the best ramen places I've been to. It starts off pretty cheap, and even with a few addons like the Chashu pork (must), corn, nori, etc, it was still really cheap.   Lots of flavor in the broth, and the Chashu is so tender. It literally just melts in your mouth and has really good flavor. This is definitely one spot I will always come to when in Vegas.

DEsqU8xyEjqCc0sjgJbGOQ.text: So we have been wanting to try Monta since moving to Vegas 2 years ago.  So we decided to give them a try after a movie premier.   It was way past normal dinner time but there was still a line to get in.  It took 40 minutes before we got our table.  There was a dust storm that evening so waiting outside was pretty special.      The inside is small and not very impressive and gives you the feel of eat and get out soon as possible.   The service was pretty good despite being busy.  We ordered our ramen and a pork belly bowl.  The pork belly bowl with rice was pretty good.  The marinated Tender and tasty marinated pork was a hit with all of us.      The Ramen arrived and I got the Spicy Tonkotsu which when I mixed in the red spicy paste  made the broth nice and thick.  I really enjoyed the taste and devoured my ramen as if my life depended on it.  The broth had a great taste and the added on egg made it even better.  The daughter got the black garlic ramen which I didn't care for.  So the Spicy Tonkotsu is my recommendation as I am craving it as I write this review.  I do think my next visit will be to pick up as the wait can be crazy at times.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kurobuta Ramen - Black Garlic Oulm
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with added Egg

WTZSVgemd9K0VYCJHjgCmA.text: Great ramen noodle. The place is small and cozy. When you arrive, you need to add your name to add your name to the waiting list yourself. The staff and service is A1. We did not have to ask for anything.They brought everything we needed without even asking. Parking is available. The washroom was clean and there is free WiFi, but I am not sure who was providing it.

pp-W7vGB-w0mc83ICcspXg.text: I love this place!!! Each dish has its unique flavor and i love adding all the extras!! Always a friendly staff!

iAOmNgHuWkQwLgkL0ve3xA.text: Not as good as comments. It's a popular restaurant ; very small you need to wait at least 30 minutes. The noodles, the soup, the price just about three stars.

Hlzgn8fb3NPLaqGJHvt6oQ.text: Yes, yes, and yes. This is definitely the best ramen I've had in Vegas, though it's still at an average quality compared to many places here in LA. It's a small restaurant so there is definitely waiting involved but luckily some of my friends went earlier and put our party down on the list so I myself did not have to wait too long.  I tried the tonkatsu shoyu ramen, but asked them to switch to thick chewy noodles since that's the way I like it. Hungover Aileen enjoyed the broth very much and it wasn't too salty, which is much appreciated. The noodles were the perfect texture. The chasu was also incredibly tender and just the right portion for me since I was able to get some in every bite of noodles.  The service by the older woman was so attentive and kind, while the younger waitress gave off the vibe that she was too cool for school. Regardless, the food was quick and good so I have no complaints.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkatsu shoyu with thick noodles

5nLC1VliwLjMaCI_5p6gSg.text: I was really disappointed when I visited Monta. It was the first ramen spot I visited in Vegas and the soup base was SO salty. I could barely finish my bowl of noodles. The seating was not comfortable and the restaurant was very crowded too.   Service was great, but I will not return to the restaurant simply because I didn't enjoy the food.

zEmrk2IT1TohBsyHY72F5A.text: Good size ramen bowl! Reasonably priced, well flavored. Ramen is well textured and broth is well balanced. Not too oily, but creamy. Recommend!

i9KuDJ-UelkREc2iegrAog.text: Best ramen I have had so far. The broth was very flavorful and everything went well together. I also tried their pork belly bowl. It was delicious. Expect a wait when you get here, but they get everyone in and out fast.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. My ramen :-)

vUb_Oxaz-WrL42soRsjCsw.text: Best ramen I've had! The place itself is really small. We had fun sitting up at the bar and watching the chef prepare the food. The prices are great and you get a huge bowl full, enough for 2 people to share if you're not too hungry.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

V2fj8QcQyUluyw-drHwobA.text: The ramen is delicious, but the place is a bit small and wait times can be ridiculous.  I would also recommend the fried rice.

QpIu2xeucppdhJVXBeYcgA.text: If you are in Vegas, it doesn't matter if you have a rental car or have to call for taxi/uber/lyft, you need to go here now. To be honest, this plaza is LOADED with SO many gems (Raku, Kabuto, etc!), it would be shameful if you do not come to this mini plaza. My goodness, I could go on a food tour just in this plaza alone. I only had time for one ramen shop visit, and I debated hard between Monta and another. In the end, I have absolutely no regrets and this was my favorite, albeit, shortest meal during my most recent Vegas visit.   Monta Ramen rivals among the best ramen joints in the US. For the locals who think that this place is just aiteeeee, I'm jealous of y'all! The black garlic tonkotsu is just dripping with richness and FLAVOR - one of the best bowls I've ever had. The spicy tonkotsu, while also great, is my second favorite - flavor wise, it is comparable to Ippudo's akamaru modern. My first bite into the perfectly firm al dente noodles put me on cloud nine. It's the little things in life, you know?   When you factor in the price of this place, the value is almost no comparison to most ramen joints in the US. Monta's prices are almost similar to ramen shops in Japan, that is to say that it is EXTREMELY affordable. It's a hole in the wall with fast, efficient service - the best kind of ramen joint if you ask me. Go have a bowl of ramen (or two), and with the extra money you've saved, go to Kung Fu Tea or Snowflake next door.

-goJo2WeScTFKnMX1oTrFA.text: Loved it! Checked it out Friday around 7:30pm.   Small place, very busy but was able to accommodate a part of 7. Long wait but totally worth it.  Tonkotsu Ramen was delicious. Pork broth was buttery, thin noodles were fresh and pork was tender. Added an egg and corn which made my bowl complete!  Pork belly bowl was yummy and great for sharing.   Although the place was packed and super busy, the 2 waitresses managed to get things done! They took our orders, refill drinks, take empty bowls and plates and clean up for the next party quickly and efficient.  Would love to come back next time we are in town!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen (added egg and corn)

SRMlD50sAHxYLxpIHbvx7g.text: I've probably been here about 20 times since I first found this place a few years ago. And I cannot seem to get enough. I've gotten all my friends to go. Some love it and some don't care for it as much. But if you like creamy bone broth Japanese style ramen this is the place to go!!! It's a small hole in the wall and in tends to be packed especially during lunch hours and on weekends but boy is it worth the wait!!! I know some people aren't willing to wait for "just a bowl of soup" but buddy this is no ordinary bowl of soup!!! If you like it spicy get the spicy tonkotsu and if you like it less creamy ask for the half chicken half pork. Oh and their pork belly fried rice is the fantabulous!!! Happy eating ^-^

O5X6mJ9aP2EdPZhW0hkZsA.text: Flavors are flawless. Place is tiny and too crowded most of the time, but services were as good as expected. Food always came out super quickly. I would come more often if there's no line to wait or bigger tables and bigger space.

6rjLphY5ASaWg2QWhZrGkw.text: The wait was long, and the place was small, but the food was worth the wait! The portions are generous for the price. You can add on many different things to your ramen. The kimchi fried rice was also yummy.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

rfsljgdQ-Yvsac1lkVBeUQ.text: Came across this place after searching "ramen" on yelp. After reading the reviews, we decided to give it a try.   Place is small. It can probably only sit 30 people. There's also a small waiting area by the door. We waited for about 30mins. Checked in at around 9:30pm, on a Friday.   I had the Tonkotsu Ramen and my husband had the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen. We both love eating Ramen, but we're unsure about this one.  We don't love it, but we don't hate it either. The noodles tasted hard and half-cooked; left a starchy taste in our mouth. Broth was ok.   Will think twice about coming back.

3uq1AieUKBjBIVdQwkPCpQ.text: Honestly, I don't see why people think this is good ramen. (Saying this from experience living in Japan, etc.)  The ramen noodles were bland and honestly, I think they might be using somen noodles rather than ramen noodles given how the koedama sticked together. There was no tare oil on top of the shoyu broth they delivered to me for the shoyu ramen, adding to the blandness. Also, the shoyu ramen was not translucent like it should be if they were using proper Shoyu broth. Also, seeing how the chefs appear to be cooking the noodles ahead of time rather than to order show me they do not care for their product like they need to.  Not returning.

D_cJAp5yII6xTeVE4CFq8w.text: Our go-to place in Vegas for a change of pace from the buffets or fancy dinners on the strip. Sometimes it's just nice to spend $20-25 for a meal for two vs. $100...  The ramen soup is great and very comforting during the winter months. The tonkatsu soup base is very rich. The shoyu is lighter if that is your preference. Place is really small so there was a short wait even at 4 pm and they usually have a line before opening.   Highly recommend.

sMsQAJASjdYjD476R5JJ8g.text: We drove into Vegas for our flight home the next day and as it was lunch time and our hotel room was not yet ready, we took a detour to Monta for lunch.  Sat at the counter again and we both ordered the Tonkotsu ramen. The noodles were a bit thinner this time.  I added an egg which I shared with Hubby and extra green onions.   Hubby also ordered the pork belly fried rice which was not as good as how it was prepared at their other branch which was chunks of pork. This was slices of pork belly and the dish didn't taste as good.   The food is served very fast so even 'tho there is a wait, even longer for larger groups 4 or more, the turn over is quick.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with added shreds of green onion and egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly slices fried rice. It&#39;s better at their Chaya Monta branch the last time we tried it.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Eating at the counter, looking at their business cards

JijLvlbFhq6DagJq7YTA3Q.text: This is the ramen place that the locals rave about. We showed up about 30 minutes prior to opening. There wasn't much of a line. 15 minutes later, there was a line of 50 people. We got lucky when they opened and we were seated with first group of patrons.  Staff was friendly and prompt to take orders to which they were seated thorough the ramen house. While waiting to order we had the seat next to the kitchen. It was artful to see the chef prepare the ramen bowls for the orders. A process to insure the bowls were clean. A process to make all bowls of an order. A process to continue the broth and insure each bowl is consistent irregardless of when made. Chef tasted the broths as being made so nothing would be off. Chef insured all ramen noodles were consisted from each bowl.   My order was the Tonkotsu shoyo ramen garlic pork added egg. Others in my group ordered the black ramen and one substituted their protein for chicken. The order didn't take long for the ramen master to artfully prepare and have wait staff deliver. The broth was made from pork or chicken.  The dishes arrived with the noodles, protein, broth, spices, vegetables, and spoons all fashionably placed in the bowl. With those who added egg, the egg was sitting on top. Tender noodles through. Broth was well layered and spicy in it's own. I still added some because I love the kick. Cha shu was not overly fatty. Egg was more cooked than I like. I enjoyed the bowl. I left no broth.  Aside from egg, I enjoyed the bowl and would love to visit again someday. Worth the drive out.

lLaAvYZHo2mdzV2mwsgsMg.text: This place was ok, but not great. Broth too thick, but maybe we should have ordered the mixed broth? I like Fukumimi better.

w3mcLs1NKrsQ4Kam-ascLQ.text: Ramen broth is very bland but then again it's not expensive either, you get what you pay for. The wait time is very long so if you have downtime to wait for not-so-great and cheap ramen then yes this is the place to be however note that the dining area is smaller than other  ramen places. I'm giving this place 3-stars for the fast service but quality of ramen is more likely a 2-star.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

FEvjgsNotI7YYWl2Jh4k4w.text: This place wee super yummy.  Food came out fast.  Great service. Very close to the strip in China town.  Tons of restaurants in China town.

dLqKhzklmE0kmdDWkdgbqg.text: I love Monta Ramen! Everyone needs to go. The flavor of the soup and pork and rice is soo yummy!! The portion is def enough to make you full.  The only downfall is the wait because the seating is limited. So try to go there as early so you won't be waiting to get seated.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

erVcwFE5naQFfoySS6VwIw.text: Ask anybody.. the best ramen place in Las Vegas! Cross streets are spring mountain and Decatur.. in Chinatown! It's located in a small lot so plan ahead for parking.. and definitely plan ahead for the wait! It's a small place. The shortest I have waited for a table was 20-30 mins, and that was at lunch time about 10 mins after it opened. The menu is pretty simple, you have a choice of the flavor of broth, it lists the ingredients in it, you can choose the thickness of the noodle or if you want it cold, you can have add-ons, and there are a few side plates which includes diff rice and meat for those who aren't fans of ramen. The waitresses move really fast and the wait time for your food to come out is very short. Definitely my go to place when I need ramen!

1vFVlf-JKl-7uc2mDgMoxA.text: Have been here several times over the past 3 years and every time I come the soup is always too salty. Decided to go again cuz my bf wanted to try it out and I thought I would give it another chance, since there is always a long wait. This time I asked for a less salty tonkotsu soup but guess what.... I got something close to water. I'm just quite shocked that ramen soup could taste like that considering it's stock is made from bones and veggies. The noodles had this residual flour taste as well. Overall I was just really shocked to get such a tasteless ramen soup which lacked umami. I don't know, if I go for the regular soup it's just too salty to taste anything, and if I ask for less salty it tastes like water. I guess the base is just... like that... It's sad considering their Sister shop ramen Kobo is REALLY GOOD and has nice flavours as well as salt levels. It just wasn't delicious and it made my entire dinner experience really disappointing.  Other than that, the gyoza was delicious and had a nice ginger flavour to it.

cgOchBvF3IPxFFtfY9EGag.text: Very similar taste of ramen like I'm back in Japan! My fave is their Tonkotsu shoyu ramen!

9wVz_iqPYu4LlkYjbsGVYg.text: Another delicious spot in Chinatown. Ramen was inexpensive but delicious and sure to hit the spot. Broth was perfectly balanced, not too salty. I also ordered the fish roe rice but I wasn't a big fan. Definitely coming back again when I'm in the mood for ramen.

7C-EI9fNz_1qkWdTZSvX3w.text: Black garlic ramen was delicious! Pork belly was so tender and melty it's to die for. Place is pretty small so might be a wait. But the wait wasn't bad goes by quickly .

aHmBQ9Jz0h0b5CRiGny83g.text: Tried the tonkotsu shoyu ramen, fried rice and gyoza.  Ramen was good, but I have tried better ones. The soup was a little thin but had a nice flavor.  Fried rice was GOOD. Had that smokey flavor to it.  Gyoza was ok. Nothing special. A little soggy and oily.
