Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

inlTPEjmsO1JJ0lmU8r1_w.text: I live  on the east coast and have been looking for an authentic ramen house to no avail. Until last night!! We sat at the bar and drooled the whole five minutes it took to get our bowl of heaven. I wish I lived here just for the ramen. Its not fair. Why can't I find one close to home!!!!????

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Fvevry9ppEpIVWEgcLuyww.text: The tonkotsu ramen is so yummy and fills you up, normally I don't get full from ramen and I was eyeing the noodle refill but once I was done withy noodles there was no more room. The service is really good too- order was taken promptly and food was brought out quickly. We never ran out of water. Prices are also very good. There is usually a line out the door but it's worth the wait. Hands down the best ramen in Vegas!

fSwp_SMrP4OFvHCytw-LRA.text: This place was alright to me. Not the best ramen but not the worst either. I've had better but this could work if you need a quick fix on a budget.

Km_F5Jtk-pAVlkd9js0rDw.text: Be warned: there's very often a wait in this tiny little slice of heaven. But it is absolutely worth it. Their ramen is actually divine, their fried rice is some of the best I've ever had. The tonkotsu ramen broth is thick and mouth-coating and everything a good broth should be. It's made to order, arrives at the table in under 5 minutes most times, portioned so huge that you'll have difficulty finishing a whole bowl, and priced at 8$ a pop.   Try and catch them when they have seasonal specials - the kuro (black garlic) ramen is absolutely fantastic.

OBhoEl7Q7CSwS0RaxJAq6Q.text: This place was pretty good but I feel like their pork slices were way fattier than at Ramen Sora.  It was so fatty that this overeater wasn't able to eat the entire bowl of noodles. Usually I have no trouble gobbling down an entire large bowl of noodles and slurping up all the broth but due to the high level of fat in the pork and broth, I was defeated. Both my sister and I preferred Ramen Sora's pork and broth over Monta. Their gyoza were decent. They did give us two extra because initially they only gave us five because the chef had dropped the sixth one on the floor so they had to only serve us five at first. If I had to pick, I would pick Ramen Sora over this place. Also, there were a lot of extra charges for toppings while at Ramen Sora they were included in the price. My sister and I also thought that the eggs at Ramen Sora were better.

RTHo7tjmxNv_rNQazt2mOQ.text: Yet another great place off the strip in las vegas.  It was super cold and windy this weekend in vegas so felt like some soup.  This ramen shop is great.   Its very small so you may have to wait a bit.  I went around 4pm on sunday and got the last 2 spots at the bar.  I was very happy with my noodles and the broth.  Also ordered some gyoza and fried rice.  Each were great.    The gyoza were cooked great.  Steamed first and then fried crispy on one side.  The fried rice was also well made.  Not oily at all and had very good spices.  The menu is not very big but it seems what is on it they do right.  I will be back again.  I just wish it was open 24x7.

Aww0t5PUA-cs9i4bbKJSeQ.text: One Word. SAIKOU! Tonkotsu ramen is damn good! I drove out to Vegas from L.A. just for the ramen. On my trip ,I had to go twice in one day. They need to bring the shop out to LA. please!

0QrXgGV6kdMJ1u3uIMy0bA.text: I was so excited to try this place because my friend had really talked it up and she was so excited to take me here. After spending 45 minutes waiting outside, we were sat at a very small, cramped bar. I ordered the miso ramen, I have to say I've had better tasting top ramen for 10 cents. The noodles had no flavor and the broth was very salty with barely any flavor and 3 small pieces of pork. Am I missing something?? Definitely not worth the wait. I will stick with Pho

k68jWAlXfdjFzmbbV6ZxMA.text: Delicious, great place to go if your a noodle lover. Although the location is very small, so most likely your going to be waiting. Better bring a cold bottle of water to keep you cool not much waiting room inside. My wife suggest adding the boiled egg and two extra slices of chashu to any bowl. My favorite is the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen it's delicious with a couple of teaspoons of soy sauce, vinegar and the red powder stuff. The place is pretty clean and so is the bathroom. Definitely will go back.

QD61rAyyPDwmqZZjFOGMzg.text: I. LOVED. IT.  It's always so hard to find authentic Japanese cuisine that's GOOD. This place was great! I went for my first time on Friday and I can't stop talking about how legit this place is. It feels like I'm in Japan. I definitely recommend hitting this place up if you're ever in the mood for ramen.  Service was great and having the option for kaedama rocks. The tonkotsu shoyu ramen was soo good and so was the gyoza and chahan.   5 STARS!   What are you doing still reading this, GO TRY IT!

FDGe8vSfaQCukQh4n9Hu4Q.text: I just have to review this place. I am a big fan of ramen and I have tried ramen from all the good places - norcal, socal and this place stands on its own!  The pork flavor ramen is so good, add a bit of garlic to it and you get the best tasting pork ramen you can get. I like it better than santa ramen @sanmateo.  The noodle itself is the thinner and softer kind you can find in socal and not the thicker kind you can find in norcal.

O74jNwc5XO-nhXZC2jzEcg.text: After stumbling through various Japanese restaurants that serve decent bowls of ramen, I've finally found a place that specializes at it. In fact, it's pretty much all they serve. Their menu reminded me of an In-N-Out menu: You either order a tonkotsu ramen or a miso ramen. If you don't want ramen, there's fried rice and some basic Japanese apps. Not much in terms of variety. But, if this is what you're in the mood for, they do it great.  I started off with an order of gyoza for an app. Simple stuff and what you'd expect. Nothing to write home about. Then, came the steamy bowl of tonkotsu ramen. The broth was a real winner here. A lot of places that I have tried never really got the broth quite right. This was one place where the flavor really hit the spot. Even though it's a scorching 100+ degrees outside, a routine stop for a bowl of ramen here is worth having. Next time I drop by, I will probably give their fried rice a shot.  Monta is a tiny, quaint little place, though not very crowded when I went. It started out empty when we walked in, but started filling up as we were slurping up our noodles. I wouldn't expect a wait for a table, but I could see it happening if this place picks up in popularity.

OVJyMIh4Kaujf18hZgza9g.text: A Vegas institution. Delighted that I discovered it early on, as it's tough to get in these days. Completely addicted to their miso ramen. I once went there straight from the airport after spending a month traveling in South America -- I didn't even drop my suitcase off at home first! This is not a place to linger over a meal, as they try to turn tables quite quickly, but there are plenty of other places nearby where you can get coffee and linger. Fantastic food and very consistent. Limited menu and just some beer and wine, so if you are looking for other items beside miso, some fried rice and some appetizers, I wouldn't choose Monta. However, for the best miso soup in town: Monta all the way. I am so hooked on their food that sometimes I go there twice a week. -- even if I happen to be on the other side of town. Highly recommended.

H3kio_MxKW07uGtGteYAHw.text: A nice little hole-in-the wall near Chinatown.  They serve really good ramen here.  I was a little doubtful when I first came, but this place is legit!  They have four different broths (Tonkotsu, shoyu, miso, and tonkotsu-shoyu)  I've tried three of the four, but I have to say that the tonkotsu is my favorite!  There's definitely a pork flavor, rich and soothing.  The soup is steaming when it comes out, but it makes it taste even better!  The pork they have is a little thinner than I would've preferred (due to the fragility when picking the meat up with chopsticks) but it's still so delicious.  I had my tonkotsu with the garlic mash that they have and a soft-boiled egg.  Perfect for a winter day!  The soup is great by itself, but every new topping that is added just gives more depth.  I found that the broth gets saltier the longer it sits.  =(  It kind of sucks because by the time I finish the noodles, the broth is too salty for me to drink.  Can't wait to go back!

Qvvc_2e_01Ktp62MsbWrgg.text: Monta Monta.. Do you want to Monta?.... F**k yeah I wanna Monta. A friend of mines mention to me about this place when she was in Vegas. So the next time I went to Vegas, I decided to try this place out cause I love good ramen. Line here sucks but it is well worth it. The first time I had this place I was blown away at how scrumdidilumpcious. I decided to go back to this place again the next day just so my friends can try it out also. Miso ramen was excellent. The pork was so tender that it melts in your mouth. Same with the egg. The only thing I would complain about is the gyoza. They tasted like the one you brought in the frozen good section at the store. Stay away from the gyoza and you would definitely give this place 5 stars.

hgKgHkscEHx01wOGRsYWwQ.text: Came here twice on our last trip. Love the tonkotsu shoyu with wavy noodles, corn, and egg. Tried the pork belly bowl, which was also delicious.

kd5IzAHlHhu-rE1b-cM_7A.text: one of the best ramen dishes i have ever had.  broth was flavorful but not too salty and noodles were toothsome.  place is crowded but worth the wait.  service is quick and wait is not bad at all.  would recommend for an off the strip meal.

iA8ZQlamzVyoowRpK7MXYg.text: I come here at least once a week.  Their menu is simple, but everything is cheap and delicious.  The food is authentic Japanese, and hey, most of the waitresses are too.  If you have the courage to practice your Japanese, this is probably the place to do it.  If you come here on the weekends, it will be packed, but they have very speedy service so people get in, eat, and go. This is a wonderful place.  P.S. as a side note, they do accept credit cards but the check has to have a minimum of $10.

z1QbJxrDADGUaTtdmz75og.text: We came here in the dead of summer last July for lunch and I'm happy to report that Monta serves up some pretty tasty ramen. A lot of the reviews warned against a queue but we were seated immediately and our food came just as quickly.  I quite enjoyed the tonkotsu ramen. The portions are on the smaller side and the broth was full of flavour but a wee bit too salty. I'll definitely be back here again!

w8JvqpM3hhbnOPjZt0J0AQ.text: We came at 9:45 and the place was pretty busy with 5 people ahead of us. My family tried the tonkotsu shoyu ramen, black garlic oil ramen, spicy tonkotsu ramen, and the miso ramen. The noodles taste like theyre from a package and they have no unique chewiness or texture which was a disappointment. The broth for the tonkotsu shoyu was decent but the miso had an overall better flavor. More importantly though the black garlic broth was extremely salty and when asking what it was made of we were told just garlic and oil. First off, that is extremely unhealthy considering they would have to burn the garlic in the oil and use all the remains as broth base. Also for those that write reviews saying that the charsiu melts in your mouth, news flash, it's all fat! So if you enjoy MSG, fatty meat, "meh" noodles, and burned garlic junk in your ramen, please come here! The only reason this could be a two is its pretty fast once you're seated, and the staff are nice, but I suggest you look somewhere else for a better meal.

OnjO3VtrUXHUmF7CXt-vEw.text: So amazing!  We happened to hit it just right and were seated quickly.  However, be prepared to wait - but the food is definitely worth it!  The broth is so flavorful and the noodles are cooked to perfection.  I felt like I was in Tokyo again!  A definite must try!

_nQU3u6zvuhA6U3QjFmDsQ.text: This place is to die for.  Everyone I bring here either finish their entire huge bowl of noodles or in my husband's case, eat my bowl as well.  Their choice of broths are all flavorful with varying degrees of heaviness/lightness.  The pork is to die for.  The non noodle dishes look great as well but I can't tear myself away from the noodles. Since it's cold out right now, nothing hits the spot more than a bowl of hot flavorful noodles.  Be sure to get there early, before 11:30 if you're going there for lunch because there's always a line out the door.

vNEhMhriHKLdrbhMHWvpcA.text: Ok Ramen... I've had better. But there's not a lot of Japanese selection in Vegas. I'd say Monta is mediocre, but awesome in Vegas. Personally, I give it a 3/5, but really it'd be a 4/5 in Vegas japanese ramen standards... So my honest opinion 3/5 because there is a queue typically and it's quite small. But ramen is pretty decent.

pBcKoUoTNCZ22FiLmSdgCA.text: Everytime I crave for Ramen I go here. Never disappointing. Tastes sooo good! I just hope they would expand and have a bigger dining area. This is definitely one of my favorites.

bMnNIuF57XbInwtUayCYSg.text: Small ramen house - max occupancy is 26 people. Thus there is going to be a wait for a table or a seat at the bar. As most people mention, it is worth the wait. The waitresses are friendly and efficient. We ordered ramen but also gyoza and fried rice. I liked the fact that everything came out at the same time, which is not the case at some restaurants.   The tonkatzu broth is richer and hearty, while the shoyu (soy sauce based) broth is clearer. Comes with basic toppings and if you want more (noodles, pork) or additions like corn and kim chee, it's an add-on.  Overall, great bowl of ramen with good texture noodles (not overcooked) with friendly, efficient service. I'll have to try the pork belly bowl next time.

uzEBVUYvmsVsNt1czaB2Qw.text: Best and cheapest meal I had during my trip to Vegas! I had the miso with egg, and it was cooked perfectly with a very flavorful broth. Pork was very tender. My friend got the Garlic Oil Ramen and was also impressed. You can't go wrong with $2 beers in Vegas either. I will definitely come back my next visit .

fD5VDMwqVXhPmN6Vq48TYw.text: Had the Tonkotsu Ramen and the broth was very rich and flavorful. Noodles were firm/chewy with great texture. Pork was soft and delicious. Stop by if your in Vegas, I'll be back for sure.

tUhnSgczWR97ZsR_SnO9wg.text: Top notch ramen shop...always busy. Expect to wait awhile, but it's worth it. My favorite is the Kuro Ramen w an order of fried rice. Try it and don't expect to leave any leftovers!  Open late too! 2 locations in Las Vegas add to the convenience of enjoying a quality ramen experience.

PYm9Xh1FJ3NCjT-IbPNacA.text: This place hands down is a much if your in Vegas. A little pass Chinatown you find yourself in a tiny hole in the wall but the wait is all worth it. Daily fresh noodles and broth to sip up.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yum

QnFC3raeVXtew4jt5PXE3Q.text: As an avid lover of all Asian styles of food I was excited to finally try Monta Ramen since I had heard good things. At first glance it looked like this little noodle shop was going to have a very long wait. However, we did not have to wait too long even with people waiting outside. There are not many seats, but this is not really the place to linger for long. Most people seem to leave fairly quickly once they are done. My friend and I sat at the counter and had fun watching the bustling kitchen while we waited for our ramen. The seating may feel cramped for some people, but I really liked the busy, controlled chaos feel of it.   On to the good stuff. I ordered the Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen with the regular house fixings and my friend had the Shoyu ramen with thin noodles. I was instantly impressed with my choice as soon as I tried it. The broth was slightly creamy and full of flavor, the thin noodles cooked to the perfect point so they were not mushy at all. I found the soup very flavorful, but I had to add a liberal amount of chili oil since I like my ramen spicy. The Shoyu ramen was also very tasty, the clear beef broth had just as deep a flavor as my selection. We both had a can of green tea to drink, which was a refreshing counter to my spicy soup. My only gripe was the fact that I was not completely full when I left, which is mostly my own fault. They offer the option of extra noodles, which I will surely do next time. The gyoza and fried rice are also on the list to try in the future.   Another great aspect is the price. The total bill for two bowls of ramen and two drinks was $18 and change. A great deal for any sit down place. Bottom line is that this place is a great option for a fun, cheap meal. I will definitely be going back.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6AuaEm5ebncEusZF1V_UzA.text: Since my mother is from Japan, I have eaten a lot of ramen in my life. I also admit that I am pretty picky when it comes to good ramen.   My husband and I finally decided to try Monta. We heard from a few friends that this was one of the best noodle houses in town. We stopped in on a Monday at around 12:30 pm. It was crowded, but we were able to get seated right away since a few parties left at the same time. The restaurant is really tiny. I saw the sign on the wall that said the seating capacity was only 26 people. We sat at the bar, which was kind of cool because I got to the see the employees preparing the ramen in their kitchen.   Sadly, I was disappointed. I ordered the Shoyu Ramen. I'm not sure if we just came in on a bad day, but I thought the noodles were too hard and the broth didn't have much flavor at all. Also thought the Chasu was weird. It was easy to eat because it was sliced very thin, but I did not like that slimy ring of fat around it. My husband felt the same way about his Tonkatsu Ramen.   Service was not the best either. The employees were slow with drink refills and they seemed to be more attentive to the larger parties in the restaurant. We waited a long time for our bill after eating.  Sorry, but this place just does not live up to all the hype. I would prefer having ramen across the street at Shuseki.

IynScp1sqnaVwXigb9dnuA.text: Got the Tonkotsu Ramen and the Pork Belly Bowl after looking at Yelp. Thank god I did. To reiterate a review I read, the pork belly was the highlight of the meal. I'm usually not the biggest fan of pork but this dish was insanely good. Salty, sweet, savory. It was absolutely delicious.   Ramen was good, the broth was a little too salty for me. But the noodles were the perfect consistency and the pickled radish on the side was a good garnish. The meat was really tender with the noodles.   Overall, wait was a little long but it's understood with the seating capacity, ramen was very good, but the PORK BELLY made this a 5 star for me.   tl;dr: Get the Pork Belly. That's all.

AlP2H2drFHy5m480MYp_9w.text: Went there three times while in Vegas this past week!  Delivered!  Good as advertised.  Had the spicy miso ramen, the pork rice bowl thingy and the gyoza!  I love the minced garlic that you can mix in with the gyoza sauce!  Everything was tasty and service was awesome!  Checkin in on a clipboard near the door and the wait can be long since it's a small place and there is always a line - but get there early :-)  Price: Reasonable Food: Yums Service: Solid  Thumbs up!

wW-xz4jOsyyC6Qk-cN378g.text: This place was recommended by a friend who had eaten here before.   It has a very small dining area and we understood why yelpers complained about the wait. Lucky for us, we went at the perfect time because the bar area opened up just in time for the 6 of us to chow down.   I got the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen with a side of Takana Mustard Leaf. Others enjoyed the other types of Ramen and the bf got the Pork Belly Bowl. Since I've been in SB for a while, I haven't had good ramen, so this was a special treat!   I must warn you though, the container of reddish spices was very salty and I personally don't recommend it unless you try your dish first and want more salty goodness. I love adding white pepper to kick it up a notch and the sesame seeds were a nice mild addition as well.  I took a bite of the pork belly bowl and it had a nice flavor. It's pretty much marinated bacon, how can you go wrong? The ramen was very tasty and I was finished before I knew it. The mustard leaf added additional flavor, but wasn't really needed.   This is a great find and a place that I'll definitely come back to.

NLEdoFTNVBuH2RDS8SHiNw.text: HOT! Not sure if their air conditioner is normally off, but it was 94 degrees inside! Hot room with hot ramen is not a good combination.   The noodles my husband got were salty. Mine were...ehh. I could have done better with a cheap pack of noodles at home and a few eggs.  For $42, not worth it- just for NOODLES!

kYTrbgdNpGRhTrHhDsOUeQ.text: I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen. The meat is really tender and melts in your mouth. The broth is really rich and creamy, but too salty! I asked for them to make it with less salt and it was still really salty.   I came on a Friday night and the wait wasn't bad. But I think I'll stick with Ramen Sora.

jttUKLvkqtoY_XXQGyd11w.text: My favorite type of place by concept. When the wait is SO worth it. But we waited 2 hours to find that they had called our name 30 min after we had listed ourselves... it didn't matter, we just wanted what we came for-- ramen.  By the time we sat, our large intestine had eaten our small intestines (or so it felt) so we had to order something to tide us over while waiting for ramen, and the fried rice and pork belly bowl were absolutely delicious and did the trick.   I ordered the special black garlic tonkatsu ramen and bear had the regular. The noodles were perfect, the bowl came out immaculate. I did learn that as much as I LOVE animal fat, I am not a tonkatsu broth fan. There was too much black garlic oil in my bowl as it over-encompassed every bite, and I feel like it should have been more of a nuance... so I could barely eat half the bowl.   But I could see the quality and consistency (otherwise) in their food. Service was prompt and friendly. Wish I was closer to give it another 5 shots, I'd wait 2 hours again.

PQ9jM1H_1Zq5jFSjb0yV_g.text: Monta is by far the most amazing ramen house in Las Vegas! I stumbled upon it and decided to take my wife and two kids (4 and 2) to give it a try. Last week we tried another Ramen house down the street from Monta and it was nowhere near as good. We've had ramen in Japan, Hawaii and California and Monta is the closest to what you can find on the streets of Tokyo.   We started out with Kimchee and the fried rice. They were both amazing! The Kimchee had an amazing taste and the fried rice was probably the best I have had! I had the spicy tonkotsu ramen, my wife had the miso ramen and my kids shared the cold noodles. All had amazing flavor with robust noodles and tender meat. The dishes were bursting with flavor! My kids pounded the cold noodles and the fried rice.  Overall, Monta is a MUST TRY when in Las Vegas. This is going to be a regular spot for us. Oh, the place is really small... So don't expect to have a big party and get in right away. You'll wait 20-30 minutes before you get in. Enjoy!

kweF-C7hkvnY-tdcndiAnw.text: A really great ramen place! Its a small place, lines can get really long during dinner time.

OV-gGEAfSr5M0YgVuWXVoA.text: So delicious, and I've had my share of tonkatsu ramen.  Perfect balance between the stock and that back fat :D. Served with thin noodles and cha shu.  The cha shu melts in your mouth however I think it competes with the fattiness of the soup. Personally I prefer a more meatier cha shu but this is pretty damn good.  The gyozas were delicious I definitely recommend them.  I would probably skip the pork belly bowl though. While it is still good, I've seriously had better.    Oh and if you're really hungry $2 will get u an extra portion of ramen. Good deal.  An all around solid choice!

sJP2L7Ydbmjt6wMagCC2ow.text: This tiny little hole in the wall, is one of Vegas's best kept secrets! It's a absolute MUST, especially during the cooler months. They not only have bomb-ass ramen, but make one of the best kimchi fried rice!!!! Mmmmm yum yum yum! One of my top 5 restaurants in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice! Nom nom nom
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

YEUBXDM-iREDVERarKAuAA.text: This is the ONLY place in Vegas that is close to what we have in San Diego, the infamous Tajima.  It's good, but I think it's because I have no other choices lol. The noodles taste like they came out of a bag that says "TOP RAMEN", no eggy taste at all and the broth could stand to see LESS salt. And I don't mean to be so negative but really, nothing compares to what we have back in SD.  I like Monta, it's perfect when you need a ramen fix.

OCHndLrMy2u57HGjH04A3w.text: Thankfully my husband was able to arrive before me and put our names down because the wait on a Wednesday night was lengthy. He did text me to tell me that if I didn't get there before they called our name our reservation would be forfeited. No pressure but I did get nervous trying to find parking in the strip mall. I guess the wait is long because the place is tiny! For some reason the ambience reminded me of my bar hopping days in Seattle. We waited for the only table capable of seating 7 and watched in agony as the current seated party socialized, giggled, and took selfies. Ugh...hurry up guys. The prices are incredibly competitive and the servings are huge. There isn't much selection on the menu but you really shouldn't be coming here to expect anything other than ramen. The one person who did not want ramen in our group had fried rice and said it was pretty good. The ramen itself is decent. It might be a personal preference but I had to tweak mine a bit with condiments to get the broth to my liking. I don't usually have to do this when I go for ramen. The broth was also slightly a bit thicker than I prefer.  The service was quick and efficient, bathrooms available and clean. I will be back and recommend you give it a try too.

bIagG0S6Q35_MZZu7ECXJA.text: I came out to Vegas with a seious Ramen craving this place fit the bill. Its a very traditional setting loved it

hOK4wdJgflD2E6S0BS4q5Q.text: I've eaten here once and though a bowl of Japanese soup noodles isn't usually my first choice for dinner, Monta has really good grub.  I was with 3 of my LA friends (who have plenty of eating experience in LA's Little Tokyo) and they also thought the food was excellent.

Ra7j4NGOUDLcLMMhs9A9ig.text: Great food, attentive staff, fast service. Expect a long wait Friday and Saturday nights to be seated.....especially if its a rainy day perfect for noodles.

OQSOOZsHAHO0NMeH41HPcQ.text: Oh man.  Real ramen.  This is the place to go if you're craving ramen in Vegas.  I got here around 7:30 on a Thursday night and it was crowded, but my friend and I got seated pretty quickly.  I got the tonkatsu ramen, the broth is so tasty!  One thing to note, the noodles they use for the tonkatsu isn't the same noodles for the other dishes.  The noodles for the shoyu and miso are more like egg noodles (which I prefer), and the ones for the tonkatsu ramen are more like noodles from a Cup 'O Noodles.  Don't get me wrong, they're still really good and I still killed my bowl.

e9HVIAjVbasi9b5jfKwT2Q.text: Attention: This is NOT the ramen you ate in college, it's about 1000x better.  The Tonkatsu I had tonight was delicious, and the pork they serve with it was flavorful, buttery, and fell about when you tried to pick it up, in other words, perfect.  The noodles were done perfectly, to what most would consider al dente, and held up really well to the broth.  I got a side of kim chi to go with it, and they paired really nicely.  It's a small restaurant in the back of a strip mall in Chinatown, but if you don't mind the drive and maybe missing it once or twice, I would say you need to go here at least once to try good ramen if you haven't had it before.

IKiliR3-bCjJXWEZBL2-Bw.text: Delicious but they really need to get a bigger place. It's way to small for how slammed they always are.

ITaKb4SwElS-9PQyK8qpqw.text: First time having ramen and this place was a great introduction!  I ordered the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen with the nitamago (seasoned hard-boiled egg) and double corn.  Delicious.  The broth was not salty, the noodles were perfectly cooked, and the corn and egg complimented the dish.  My companions ordered Kimchi and I've only had Kimchi once before and did not like it; however, the Kimchi at this place was quite yummy. We also ordered the Pork Belly Bowl - also wonderful.  The only complaint I have about Monta Ramen is that it's is a small restaurant.  I think there were only 7 tables and then the space at the bar.  We came at a decent time so we didn't have to wait too long to be seated. I'd definitely come again!

_FmyoH8WXOHaQv4-99FmwA.text: This charming restaurant offering the best ramen in Vegas is located two doors down from Raku in the Seoul Plaza on Spring Mountain, and could be one of the smallest restaurants in the city. Monta is actually so pea-sized that if you come during peak times you'll almost certainly have to wait before you can sit down. Don't let this be a deterrant, just keep it in mind before you go, and get there quickly before even more people find out about it.  Half of the restaurant is an open kitchen, so your dinner music consists of the clanking of woks and pans accompanied by the chatter of the waitresses, cooks, and other patrons. You can sit at the bar if you really want to be part of the action, or if none of the five tables are available. Though the vibe is nice and busy, the waitresses are sweet and won't rush you through your meal.  There are three types of ramen to choose from; Tonkatsu (rich, cloudy, almost creamy broth); Shoyu (light and delicate soy sauce based broth); and Miso (somewhere in the middle of the other consistencies and tastes like...miso). The Shoyu and Miso ramen come with chewy, thicker noodles which I much prefer in texture and taste to the thinner, less al dente noodles that come in the Tonkatsu (you can sub if you like). All three varieties of the ramen cost around $7 and also come with chasu (tender, roasted, fatty pork), scallions, kikurage (mushroom), takenoko (bamboo shoots), and scallions. You can then customize your ramen with little extras that include perfectly coddled egg, butter, more pork, and my personal favorite, Takana, or pickled mustard leaf. These don't cost a lot, so customize away. Also, be sure to add some of the fantastic accoutrement residing in your condiment tray such as pickled ginger strips and minced garlic.  You won't find much other than ramen on the menu, just a handful of appetizers and sides. Of these I've had the gyoza ($5.95), which were excellent one time but not cooked correctly another, and fried rice with takana. The fried rice is almost as good as the ramen, so if you aren't in the mood for soup get this instead. Another plus is cheap beer ($2.50 for domestic).  I can't think of any other meal I'd rather enjoy on a cold day than a steaming bowl of hearty home-made soup, so I plan on going to Monta frequently this winter. If it continues to get even busier, however, I may be taking it to go in a perfectly packed parcel. I brought ramen home for my husband once and was amazed at the care put into ensuring the soup would be just as good at home as it is in the restaurant. The noodles were wrapped in their own little pouch, waiting to be cooked until they reached our stove, and all the other ingredients were individually wrapped to keep them in their peak state. Attention to detail really separates the boys from the (ra)men.

Dx3HrB8OYMFDVw9_YVEBkw.text: A nice little hole-in-the-wall. I had the shoyu ramen without extra toppings and it was very good and filling.  I ended up taking the rest home.  The pork slices were very tasty and tender.  I'm not a fan of fat on meats but there wasn't much in the slices and the fat was very edible. When I get meat at some Vietnamese or Korean places, I get scared but this was great.  When you get there, you need to sign the guest list if the place is full (which it will be).  We had four parties in front of us but they were gone within 10-15 minutes.  We sat at the counter on hardwood stools which were not very comfortable.  The tables had padded chairs.  I'll be requesting a table next time.  I would definitely recommend Monta Noodle House.

Qua0-efSqvI8-VnYkFcSBw.text: While not the best ramen I've ever had, this place comes really close and my friends have told me they are the best in town.  So I have yet to try other ramen places in Vegas because this place is delicious.  Look no further.  The ramen was cooked perfectly both times I've been here, and the pork just melts in your mouth.  I've tried the shoyu and miso, and I prefer the miso.  This place is tiny and can get really busy, so I've eaten at the bar both times.  It doesn't bother me since I know not to go with a big group of people here.  If you sit at the bar, there is a litle shelf near your knees so you can tuck your purse away.  Brilliant!

atOSj7pBOHXMF7zh4CzYUg.text: Came here last night at about 10mins before closing. I noticed the waitress was upset that there were last minute customers but nevertheless, she still gave us great service plus the food came out faster because they wanted to close up. She kindly asked to pay ahead because they needed to close the register. Food was still good as last time and their gyoza is far by the tastiest.

HCr9c2nvBcSGXIvh5pkELA.text: This review is long overdue, as this is one of those places that I keep forgetting to review even though I eat there quite often.  Monta is my favorite Ramen house in town, and is the best that I have tried.  The broth is deep, full-bodied, creamy, and very meaty.  This broth is what is missing from many Ramen places.  The noodles have very nice texture, which is what I mainly look for in the noodles.    I usually get the Tonkastu Ramen with a little extra Roasted Pork, but I like the Miso Ramen, too.  The Miso is also very good, but just different.  I would characterize the Miso as sweeter, and I usually prefer the meatier broth to the sweet broth, but that's just me.  I also love that all the Ramen's are below $7, I believe.  I think I usually pay around 6.95 for the Ramen, so it's a great deal.   I have also tried the Pork Belly Bowl, which I really like.  I always try to order pork belly wherever I see it, and Monta's did not disappoint.   I also like to get their canned, chilled Oolong Tea.  I think they have a couple other types, but I usually just get the Oolong.    If you like Ramen, you should definitely check out Monta.  But if you don't like soup, noodles, or any combination of these, I wouldn't come because most of their menu is Ramen.

0mZ2md4xCYsNWBLrbFqGDw.text: Holy Ramen Batman!!!!! I gotta hit this place up at least once a week and I order the extra bowl of ramen. This place is small but intimate and very nice to watch them make it right in front of you. I absolutely suggest coming here either with friends, or heck take a date. Everyone likes ramen and if you don't you can't be a friend of mine!

DeBpI1k2qJrmBSkuNToRGw.text: great ramen. (i had the black garlic tonkotsu one). great fried rice. when i'm back in town, i'm coming back. this is the real thing. i shouldn't be surprised because it was recommended by someone i know to be a real food sophisticate.

yizlB-PxWVZtV3mfmvJycA.text: The ramen is okay (not as good as I thought it would be). The fried rice is better than the noodles.

MHny1SSm2OLFhDQXr7EvCA.text: I was told the cold noodles were awesome but they were just okay in my book.  I went up to use the restroom and the waiters thought I was done even though like half of my food was still left. By the time I went back they had cleared away my plate and I was still hungry =*(.

rlCHdHMVDryolAKvizBhPQ.text: this is the first ramen spot i've been to since i've moved to vegas.  keep in mind, i went home over the summer and had daikokuya [my absolute favorite ramen place back in l.a.], and my review may be slightly biased. but - the ramen was definitely yummy!  its a small place, but definitely cozy and gives a nice home kind of feel. service is great! although, my friend asked for an extra order of noodles [i guess there's somewhere on the menu that says if you order extra noodles, save some of your broth for the second batch of noodles] and towards the end he asked for them but he ate the broth with the noodles. that got a little confusing.   if im ever really craving ramen, and i'm not going home anytime soon, this will definitely be my spot!

lkOA36sF2_ioz2NcNCcxsQ.text: Every time I visit Vegas, I feel fortunate to know some locals that always take me to Chinatown or places nearby.  This place is tiny and packed...so there will most likely be a line.  But the wait is worth it.  I had the Miso Ramyum with Pork and Hard Boiled egg as add-ons.  I picked up the tab for a party of 5 and it was still half the price as my meal for two at Ippudo in NYC.  Great food and great value.

vDcejYAZY3rU-l3gcdX_xQ.text: Went back again- my expectations were too high the first time. On a second opinion, this is an excellent noodle house. Don't get the mustard greens, and everything will be not too salty.

CFisAJNzBX4jReExdtKnUQ.text: This is the best ramen I have had in any state.  I always get the Miso Ramen with extra chashyu.  The chashyu is melt in your mouth amazing.  Portions are huge the servers are nice... I really cant find anything wrong with this place.  To drink they even have calpico and some Japanese beer.  The gyoza is good as well.  Everything else on the menu looks delicious, but I also just end up ordering ramen since it is a noodle house.  Don't go here with more than 4 people though, because as is common in Japan ramen houses this place is very tiny and can get quite crowded.  I honestly recommend going right when they open.

m_vhkd0Vdz-TKDlv_6FvUQ.text: This place is very simple. The wait is kinda a bug. But if you didn't come to mess around, the Shoyu ramen is very tasty. Also had the Kimchi fried rice and the freshly made gyoza. It's a dive I would love to come back to.

FoybER4mWzIhEqRaDiAz8A.text: I got the miso soup added egg and corn. I think the noodles and egg are my favorite part!!! The broth is rich with pork flavors.   Waiting to get a table is usually 20-50 minute wait. It's less if the party is small and you don't mind sitting at the bar.  Give yourself extra time to park if your meeting friends because the spaces are limited.   The prices are affordable for the size given.  I'm a hearty eater and a soup here fills me to the max.   If it's too full and you can't wait. Get a boba next door first to sip and talk with friends.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dZJnNoU5FooZ3FGybDvhpw.text: We love monta! It's inexpensive and the portions are so huge. It's a very friendly and fast paced place. We wouldn't really recommend for large parties as it is literally a tight hole in the wall. It's perfect the way it is and the smallness of the restaurant makes it very intimate. Because the place is small there is usually a wait, but they do churn and burn through orders so the wait is never long. You can get apps but food comes out quickly and is very hot. We go all the time.

cRtcwzank7wtZud1fbHRhw.text: Small Japanese ramen joint with the best soup and noodles! I've been to several different ramen shops here in Las Vegas and this is my favorite! Not only is it good but it's way cheaper than other places. I ordered the spicy donkatsu ramen and have also tried the regular donkatsu ramen and they always satisfy my cravings. I recommend trying those out because the soup is pork broth based which makes it so much more flavorful.   Heads up: The restaurant is really small so don't be surprised to be put on a waitlist!

9jWqJHwH8fGDMkDc2Ij2gA.text: 4.5 stars. Best ramen I've had thus far! Worth the wait, worth the drive!   Their rice dishes are also quite delicious! I only wish I live closer.

MKHrDgdcksYVTiBGtkUHtQ.text: I think that the over 2 thousand reviews of this place must have been bought....  Sadly, this place was small and the good was mediocre at best  I had the chicken ramen and my friend had the pork  Both were not good....  Edible but poor   It saddens me that this place was bad as I always use Yelp as I travel quite a bit for work  The Uber driver informed us that he knew the place was mediocre. That according to him Las Vegas isn't very reliable as far as reviews are concerned. He stated that a lot of restaurants pay to get good reviews!!   I'm not sure if that's even a thing but I can say that this is not a 5 star review kind of restaurant and definitely wasn't worth the Uber ride to get there

6TGCboLD-b0LsSej1SdDlQ.text: Every trip I go to, I always make room for Ramen . My girlfriend and I found this place through Yelp and we gave it a try.   We ordered the Pork belly rice bowl, miso ramen, & spicy miso ramen. The pork was delicious, my Miso ramen was tasty. I'd give the ramen a 8.5/10, not bad at all.   If you never been to this place, it doesn't hurt to give it a try

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

k5BqWiFGhB6jsfBtewk22g.text: Cockroaches in the kitchen.   Used to be my favorite spot for ramen. Last time I went in the back door of the kitchen was open and it was insanely hot and muggy in the restaurant. Halfway through our meal we saw a cockroach crawling along the back wall of the kitchen. Brought it up to staff and they sighed like it was a common occurrence and gave us 15% off of our meal......We left right away.

eu4NdmWRUo-Fx_If-P1uKg.text: I've tried a lot of ramen places and I really like this one.  Too bad it's in Vegas.  I got the black garlic tonkotsu ramen.  It came with 2 super thinly sliced pork.  RECOMMEND:  get another 5 slices or so of pork chashu because they give u so littleee!!  The pork was super soft and fatty. I loved it!  I also liked the fact that their noodles were thin.  I also got cold noodles with yuzu sauce.  Refreshing but I'm not into cold noodles so I'll probably just stick to ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black garlic oil ramen. So good!
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Cold noodles with yuzu sauce. I&#39;m not a fan of cold noodles in general

fGRYc-htqV3PqjnhKZGXsA.text: This place is really good!! This review is coming from the girl who doesn't like Asian food lol!! They have a ramen called Tonkotsu and it's to die for!  Their prices are really good and reasonably priced. For the most part, their portion sizes are adequate except when it comes to the rice. The large fried rice is what a lot of us would consider a small. And their small plate of fried rice isn't enough to satisfy a person.  If I could recommend a plate on the menu, it would be the pork belly! I'm a picky eater and their pork belly left me speechless. It was amazing! It reminded me of Yoshinoya the restaurant.  As for wait times, they vary. The longest I've waited was 45 minutes. The place is very small. Nothing fancy. But they ALWAYS have a line out the door because it is just that freaking good.  Come check Monta out!  Ps, parking sucks lol

b5sFnn9hhHGIcIOR7XxsYA.text: I went at 11pm on a Friday night and was seated right away. The service was excellent and quick. The food was amazing as well. I'm going back again today with my wife because it was that good.

FkthCEwzyDWPwNb2iW2Fdw.text: I've had ramen from around the world and all over Japan. I was very skeptical walking in. We went on a Saturday morning and there was already a line queuing up before they were open.  The quality of the food was surprisingly good for the price. This is by no means the best ramen ever. But for Las Vegas I can comfortably say they are probably the best.  I would recommend wavy noodles over their thin noodles. I like both types by their thin noodles just doesn't have the proper texture. The broths are all good but lacks a slight depth. Their condiments though we're slightly lacking in quality. Fried rices are also acceptable.  Service was good. It is slightly cramped inside. Overall, while I'm living in Vegas, if I ever crave ramen I will return again.

4JHyaBv_fauMPV0HCHKFNQ.text: The waitress was very rude, totally not like Japanese culture at all. The food might be good, I don't know, but you might have to endure their arrogance to taste it.

I889q0qCmr_qm-TRIFZWZw.text: This place is a little hole in the wall off strip, and in a little strip mall.  We came here during a Saturday, around 12:30 pm, so there was a long wait.  To us, that is a good sign that this place is really good.  It was about 45 minutes before we were able to get a table. Overall all 3 of our ramens were pretty good.  We have had better but this place is worth coming back to.  The service was good, place is clean, and the food they pretty good.  One thing that we had here that we never had was hot tea in a can! The blew my mind!

FdIgblik-IilAxI3iFyUIA.text: The food is good. Quick service.  The only downfall is that it's so small haha. But the wait is never really outrageous  Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen with extra noodles!  My fave

gNsKy2coUor1df4peSDRDA.text: We love this place. Aunt was visiting from out of town and she went out on a limb for us and tried ramen and enjoyed it. The gyoza are flavorful We usually get the pork belly rice each time, delicious and shareable. I usually get the black garlic or spicy tonkotsu broths and the wife gets the miso. This is a small place so you may have to wait but the food comes fast so turnover is quick There are many as ons to the soup if there basic mushroom and pork is not enough

TbL5a-K3ayD-1X5S8ryFRg.text: I absolutely LOVE Monta! I've been going here for about a year, and every time I get the most AMAZING server, Wei. Wei is such a sweetheart and he's even memorized my order for faster service. Other than servers, you can't beat the price at around $8 a bowl and in my opinion Monta is the best ramen in Vegas. You absolutely CANNOT go wrong with the Tonkotsu ramen!  but seriously, make Wei a manager for how hard he works.

gyyw3fCsKZ5Ys4_XFGgRAQ.text: It was 114 degrees Fahrenheit with a dry hot wind blowing. Like a constant blowdryer to your face. And yet we still ended up at Monta ramen :P Yes, that good!  Love their tonkotsu ramen. Nice and rich pork broth along with a couple pieces of chashu, bamboo shoots and green onions. Add a nitamago (Japanese-style soft boiled egg) and you're set to go! Their noodles aren't as thick as Daikokuya. Win for me as I like my noodles thinner anyways. Overall, solid ramen place off the strip.  The joint is small, so there's usually a wait. Table and bar space available. Get the fried rice while you're at it!

KYDDp-u1_6e2kX383GVx0w.text: You can get a bowl of delicious ramen here at Monta Ramen. It's a little ways off the strip but worth the drive. The restaurant is small but they move very quickly through patrons so you're not waiting very long at all. Our ramen was prepped super fast. The flavors were all great especially the garlic ramen. Price is also reasonable.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

06RyOMy-Qvoj16_rxcFH_w.text: This is my favorite ramen place. Their tonkotsu ramen is soooo good and the price is very reasonable. One recommendation is I wish they had more locations in the valley

eu6QH5UdSv_39ypoVKVsqw.text: Didn't expect to find good ramen here in Vegas. But after seeing all the reviews certainly didn't disappoint.    Just like any other popular ramen place, you need to get here early or be prepared to wait.  Seatings are definitely limited.   Got to try the shoyu and tonkatsu ramen.  Very nicely flavored. Noodles were freshly made and tasty.  Soup with lots of depth.  Certainly if this restaurant were in LA it would rank near the top of my list.    Also tried the pork belly rice which was ok.  Didn't stand out as much as the ramen.  The chasu was much better in the ramen than with the rice.  Would definitely recommend this place if you are visiting LV.  Would not all give 4 stars but given the location I was definitely impressed to find this place around here.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

U-UHx9vtmBjmEMmoWP56zA.text: Born and raised in Japan, I've been eating ramen at more places than I can count, so I'm a big experienced fan of ramen. Stopped by here twice during the last week of 2015.   FIRST VISIT: Weekday lunch hour. 16 people ahead of me. Wait time 50 min. Had the Tonkotsu ramen ($6.95), Takana Fried Rice ($6.95), and hot green tea ($1.75). The ramen was not the best I've had, but pretty darn delicious. Good coloration and consistency of the broth, which was very savory and appetizing. I drank the whole thing! Good combination of toppings with adequate amounts. Comparable to traditional flavors found in Japan. If I had to be picky, I'd say the noodles itself were just okay. As for the Takana fried rice, it was as traditional as you can get. Reminded me of my childhood in Japan. If you've never had such flavors before, it will be a good experience. The savory flavor of the rice complemented the pickled mustard leaf which had a subtle spiciness to it. All this, including tax & tip, is a good deal for 20 bucks.  SECOND VISIT: Weekday around 9:30 pm. 8 people ahead of me. Wait time 35 min. Had the Kuro ramen ($8.95), mini Mentaiko ($2.95), kimchi side ($1.00) and hot oolong tea ($1.75). Kuro ramen has noticeable black garlic oil in the broth which is delicious. Thick rich savory taste. Again, if I had to nitpick, the noodles itself were average. The mentaiko was also very average. Straight forward and very traditional Japanese dish. No real wow factor but I enjoyed it. The marinated cod roe was spicy and complemented the dish well. Kimchi was not overbearing. It was tasty but seemed store bought. Total cost came out to be under $20 which is a great value. The hot teas served on both visits were provided in unopened cans which were heated.   Overall, this place has wonderful ramen and the monetary value is outstanding. The star of the show was the broth. Very complex flavors with depth. You won't be disappointed. As for the restaurant itself, the layout and setting was very Japanese. I will visit again the next time I visit Vegas which should be next month. If you've ever wondered what a typical ramen place in Japan is like, then this should be a good experience for you.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Takana Fried Rice

_xejVjFBJEn8aDl5i8RFpw.text: It is busy join. Comfortable atmosphere. Food come out 5 min after I ordered. Soup was rich and flavorful. Noodle was cooked just right. Miso ramen is different noodle from Tonkotzu ramen. Over all delicious

xv8v7YIAV3UzgyyDY31jEA.text: Appalling lack of customer service prompted this review. A small group of us entered this small hole in the wall ramen place and crowded by the tiny doorway to be helped or at least at greeted, but nope, 10min passed and we were not even acknowledged. The waitress with a long ponytail passed by us (within a ft of us..it is a tight place) several times completely ignoring us. After the the third time, we called out to ask how long the wait would be and was once again ignored (maybe she didn't hear us? Regardless, still unprofessional and inhospitable for a hostess/waitress). The fourth time she came by, I had to physically step out a bit to get her attention. She grudgingly provided instructions - I'm sorry, are we bothering you by having you do your job? Anyway fast forward to when we got seated - she did a complete 180 with her attitude, actually smiling and acting friendly...probably as real and believable as her glue-on lashes. Food was pretty good and came quickly but the way they treat their customers really took away from it all.

m1sRNiSJnxIlXgoJxSdswQ.text: Best cold ramen that I have ever had!  The tonkotsu ramen broth had such depth of flavor that I'm drooling just thinking about it. Great service!  In and  out in less than 45 minutes.

8bI4VpQ_hxhB9WjpJo22Zg.text: We were visiting Vegas for a weekend getaway and decided to venture off the main strip to eat some ramen! Had no idea Vegas had yummy ramen. If we lived there we would go back. The broth was tasty, the thin noodles were a bit on the softer size (maybe too soft) and the pork was good but slices quite thin. The service was friendly and quick. It was busy so we had to wait at least 15 minutes to be seated. We didn't wait long to get our food though :)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen - Black Garlic Oil

sc_DEpNT8YDLkuP9xfrunA.text: Very quick!! And perfect Ramen. Actually I started to love Ramen while I tried it for the first time in my life here in this restaurant.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

G04tIIOI0DuUMkXPHkFlNQ.text: I had a pork belly bowl and it was good. The staff and owner could spruce things up a bit outside and inside. The smell coming off the sidewalk/asphalt took away the beauty of a food establishment.

GGr9F8Pzbk2qOYm5lyO_YQ.text: The broth here is delish.  I've had stronger tonkotsu tasting broth elsewhere, but the service, reasonable price, and generous toppings makes this a good experience.  (Chashu was nice and fatty.  Sooooo good).  One thing to point out is that the soft boiled egg is not included and they use the thin noodles, which are easily overcooked.  So if it's important to you, ask for the noodles al dente.  We also got the mentaiko bowl for less than $3.  I really enjoyed it.  If we return, I want to try the spicy tonkotsu (I asked the waitress their top popular noodles and she said the original and the shoyu tonkotsu.  So we went with the latter).

IViuP6ER-7OdFFQNTlzkhw.text: Best ramen in Vegas. Just wish they weren't as busy.. maybe i should give them one star

yLXumrPb8urQYPAVCJv1Tg.text: The decor is minimal, there's no trendy music, it's all about good ramen.  Get there early and be prepared to wait. I counted six tables and there's a bar that seats 9. When you walk in the door there is a tiny waiting area with a couple chairs. There is not a hostess, you sign yourself in and wait for a seat to open up.   The food is delicious and it's really fun to sit at the bar and watch the chefs sling out bowls of hot ramen. I had the shoyu ramen which is a thick wavy noodle with a chicken and vegetable broth. Very tasty. Warning! Wear something cotton and east to clean. With all that noodle slurping you're sure to get some broth on you.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen with pork.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen with corn and shredded green onion.

aDhfC6zesgbMPbUHM6M8VA.text: Black Garlic Oil Tonkatsu Ramen - super SALTY, my tongue was slightly numb because of all the salt - broth was viscous and very fatty.  it was like liquid cholesterol. - pork slices was good  unfortunately due to my stomach cramps followed by greasy bowel movements, I cannot give this place more than 2 stars

UqACkStVSTCIMHEmiLtpNQ.text: Ohhhhh mannnnnn!!!! Delicioussssss!!! Small Ramen house seats about 30 ppl so expect a slight wait especially larger party. Broth was so hearty but a bit salty for my taste, but with a bit of water should help out. Ordered the black garlic broth one and absolutely enjoyed it very much. Pork belly rice bowl was good, but not as good as the hype I read. But portion was decent enough to to feed 2ppl or 3kids. Definitely a must revisit.

KkHRckspNkD12KI2HzYgIQ.text: Literally the best thing I've eaten in weeks. This is my first time experiencing authentic ramen and it was heavenly. I ordered the tonkatsu shoyu with nori and egg and the flavor combos were ah-mazing! We also got an order of the gyoza which were pretty tasty as well. I will definitely be back!  Note: it's pretty small inside and gets super crowded quickly so I suggest getting there early.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu with nori and egg

YDvRR1iYVcztRt_OaThH_A.text: Get there. Go now and slurp away. So good. Small. But good. Get there at eleven or expect to wait! The wait is worth it tho

HGzsX2qLW9XeYyIGOxhD8g.text: 3 stars for the food. 4 stars because it's pretty good for the price you pay; especially in Vegas where it's hard to find good, non-fast-food places that'll satisfy you for under $10.   Shoyu Ramen ($6.95) Tonkatsu Ramen (6.95) Pork Belly Bowl ($5.75 for regular)  Ramen was good, had a great bite to it and soup wasn't too bad. IMO, I wouldn't say it was anything special though. Pork belly bowl was really yummy. Simple: meat and rice. I loved this. Portion was actually huge and I probably could have done with just the small bowl.

mSTcczbdiISbmjDAy1B0bg.text: On a trip out to Vegas we decided to see what Vegas ramen was all about.  Wasn't too busy when we arrived so we only had to wait 5 minutes to be seated.  So the day we were the the AC was broken and it was hot as shit.  We both ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen.  I didn't really see if there was a spicy option but as much as I like my ramen spicy I don't think I would have gotten it with the place being an oven.    Since this style of ramen is what Hakata Shinsengumi serves I constantly found that I was comparing the two and it's almost unfair.  While the noodles were about the same the broth was only so so and after a while it started to get a little thick.  It was good but I don't think it was good enough to catch a Lyft out to again, at least not until we've been able to try the other ramen joints around Vegas.

GxMJ9hHUnSXNJXk-Z2h6TQ.text: Love this place during the cold nights. Best ramen in all of vegas by far. Im sure it takes them days to make the broth. It is packed with flavor. Do yourself the favor and go to raku sweets after.

O34txIiq50Dy6CeRd9lPNw.text: Good not great.  My family of 4 all tried a different ramen and shared a large pork belly bowl.  We all agreed the broth was a tad too salty.  My son and I had the miso.  I had mine spicy, regrettably.  I just didn't like the flavor of the spice, and it was overpowering.  The bowl was good and a large portion, but the meet was too shredded for me.  I prefer larger cuts and seared for some crispy ends.  Overall good but I've had much better back in LA.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso

qSVJCBmBJlIdy7_8o_ygkw.text: I really don't understand the hype about this place. It is a very tiny small place with ridiculous line.We came in at around 2pm hoping that it would be less wait but not really. We waited for around 30 minutes before getting a seat at a table.  We ordered 1 tonkotsu ramen, 2 kuro ramen with black garlic oil and 1 large fried rice.  Tonkotsu ramen tasted just like a regular bowl of tonkotsu and nothing else too special about it. Portion for fried rice was pretty small and tasted nothing special again.  The kuro ramen was very nasty. It came lukewarm and had a weird thick starchy texture to the soup and was very oily. It's also lacking on the garlic flavor and we're pretty disappointed by it because it seemed like a customer favorite at this place.  Overall I didn't enjoyed the meal and felt that we can definitely find better ramen elsewhere. I felt really rushed by the server throughout the meal.

V553W0nXe2UiLKoDm9VduQ.text: AWESOME food but be prepared for a LONG wait.   Came here based on the awesome reviews. Showed up a little after 1pm on a weekday. We waited easily more than an hour. This place is super tiny, but the turnover seemed as speedy as it could be. It was cold outside and there was no shelter from the cold. I would NEVER wait to eat at this place during the HEAT of summer!!! Impossible!!!   When we finally got seated, our orders were taken promptly. Surprised to find a little cubby to stash my stuff under the bar!!! Clever!!! I LOVED my Sapporo on tap. Sitting at the bar gave us a bird's eye view on how the food, especially the pork roasts were prepared. The logs of pork roasts were seared on something that looks like a huge George Forman grill. Oh!!!!! If you could only hear the sizzle of the hot grill & the smell the wonderful umami flavor of roast pork!!! The roasts are then placed into an oven and cooked until tender. This pork is then cut into nice generous slices to garnish the ramen or cut up into the fried rices. I take the time to mention what I witnessed because you feast not only with your palate but also with your other senses as well. I love that they roasted the pork & didn't just boil or steam them to oblivion. This is probably what makes this ramen house so yummy...the care in how the pork is prepared.   What we ordered...  Spicy Tonkotsu ramen...the most popular ramen on Yelp. Also highly recommended by those drooling to get in. I hear that corn & butter add-ons are a must!!  The broth was delicious, the ramen noodles were cooked perfectly, and the ramen was garnished with nice big round slices of roast pork. In most ramen houses, the chasu is often half fat... although there is nothing wrong with some good fat. These slices were mostly meaty. Yay!!!   Pork belly bowl...also popular on Yelp, but the pork in my bowl wasn't crispy at all. Good, but not as good as the....  Kimchee fried rice....surprisingly VERY GOOD!! I am usually skeptical to order "Korean" items at Japanese restaurants and vice versa, but it tasted SO GOOD!!! The big juicy pieces of pork made the rice so decadent!!! Yum!!!!  I didn't take off any stars for the wait...they can't help that they're a fabulous popular place!!! :D

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchee fried rice...surprisingly very good. Was skeptical Cuz this is a ramen house. Not spicy. Good flavor.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly bowl...also another top seller, but didn&#39;t have the &#34;crisp&#34; to my pork like other Yelpers shared.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sapporo on tap!!!

LvDk0boYouPD0S4PyFVR6w.text: Delicious ramen! Great service! Good place to try different ramen soups instead of the usual menu at ramen bars.  The small noodles really are tiny though but the soups are good. You can always add more noodles or soup to your order for just a small additional charge even after you've eaten which I like.

4sARCj9K-Wq-cDnIxaf6Ng.text: Asian people love noodles. I am asian, therefore i love noodles. I was saddened by our earlier trip to monta where the waitress told us the wait would be close to an hour. My growling stomach couldn't bear to wait so we settled for someplace else, cough swish shabu shabu cough, and was very unsatisfied. So we decided to give it one more try on my last night in Vegas. They won't seat you until your whole party is there and luckily the other two people made it just in time. This is a cozy restaurant which just adds to the ambiance a japanese noodle house. menu: yelp.com/biz_photos/UPIY... I ordered the Tonkotsu- shoyu ramen : yelp.com/biz_photos/UPIY... I thought the ramen was delicious. You could tell the noodles were "wendy's", fresh not frozen, and the garnish were all nicely cooked. The pork was so tender and fatty and delicious. You could eat that all day fa sho. We also tried the fried rice and the gyoza. Gyoza is top notch, some of the best i've ever had and I had some Godly ones in japan.. The fried rice was pretty delicious as well. I really liked my experience here. The waitresses seemed to be imported straight from Japan, very hospitable and nice. The food was excellent. And it didn't break our wallets either. So if you're asian or not, and you're craving ramen in Las Vegas, Monta is definitely a "SAFE BET".. VEGAS PUN INTENDED.
