QTNX9tFR6kqmdUAMuMGXJQ.text: Could've been 5 stars if they have a a bit bigger dining area, it was actually okay but could use up a little bigger space, diners are like half a foot away from each other and the temperature inside the restaurant was on 74deg. Could've at least made it a bit cooler coz we're eating your delicious hot noodles. Food was super great. Hands down. And the price, wasn't too bad at all. Would definitely come back for more. Waiting time though, we were there Sunday at around 6pm, they called our names after an hour. So yeah, if you are not the type who'd like to wait, this would just piss you. But the waiting was worth it for me.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen, love it

qnXxhmwSFL_yrRnaTDlgzA.text: Black garlic oil ramen is the only thing I want when I'm sick. It brings me back to life!

Kv0e7ClcxF8jopFXrUYvrA.text: I have been eating ramen since I was a child and I am not kidding when I say that I love this place. Although the restaurant itself is small, the atmosphere feels welcoming. I came on a Friday and it was busy, but the wait wasn't too long! Your entire party has to be there though before they can seat you. You have a choice between the bar vs. the table. The waitress was extremely friendly and the food came out quickly! Their Tonkotsu was super delicious! My boyfriend loved it too and it was his first time eating ramen! Price was super reasonable. Highly recommend!

aWcuDPIaxTDOQZp100CeQg.text: Monta has a certain charm about it. I love that's it's a small place. I love that it's so popular. The only thing keeping me from giving it 5 stars is the very inefficient and unmanaged wait list. While that part can be frustrating, once I'm seated at the bar or a table I forget all about it.   The service is extremely quick. I prefer to get the shoyu ramen with extra pork. Very filling but not too much. The pork adds that little extra something.

ex4iWecVI5w5W5RQmbzB4g.text: The place is small, but definitely a gem! I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with added butter, egg and corn. The pork&chicken broth was thick but not greasy. The chasiu edge was very flavorful with a sweet soy sauce and oyster mix type of taste. The bowl overall was super satisfying even on a hot summer day!

Mc7-7K5j7gx0nDj6QsUK8A.text: Excellent value! Ramen is top notch! Gyoza and Pork Belly bowls are good dishes as well. Very small place though so be wary of that. Pretty cheap meal. Been here nearly every time I visited Vegas the last four years (8 times).

53He9714oP4tPjRXiJKEPg.text: Ramen!!! Sooooo much better than the momofuku on the strip. Cheap, ridiculously fast and delicious. The broth is perfect and you can swap in the thicker more chewing noodles which I love. $20 and you'll be super full and happy. There's always a line but it goes by fast.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen with Corn

IjESiyWMkg3CCdRtNUmu7A.text: A must visit every time I am in Vegas. It's a small joint, maybe 8-10 tables and a small bar, but it's not lacking in flavor. The ramen is top notch and the service is fast. Just be prepared to wait because I have yet to visit and there not be a wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

oV8ktj5h8W4cRseSyFxtPQ.text: One of the most comforting meals of my life and one of only two places we repeated while in Vegas. I have never had creamy broth like what they have, but it will cure a hangover in five minutes flat. The noodles have just the right amount of chew. My fiance fell in love with their pork belly rice and I was lucky enough to receive the bright pink pickled ginger that he didn't want. It was the perfect accompaniment for that ultra-rich broth. And the gyozas are little pockets of steamed/crispy goodness. I just wish I hadn't been so full when I got them.   The wait can be long, but it is well worth it and your food comes quickly once you are inside. The portions and prices are deceptive and you will end up with way too much food if you aren't careful. Overall, I highly recommend this place and suggest the cab ride if you're visiting on the Strip.

52CRcKSG_aF6tMMPUQ055g.text: I cannot understand why anyone would rate Monta less than 5 stars! THIS local stop is the best one for Ramen- I have tried so many of them out of town and within Vegas, but no one compares to Monta. Their broth is outstanding, the noodles, the meat, etc. - I have no complaints about Monta. I still like the Spring Mt. location better than the Henderson location thought, because I find the broth "less salty" in China Town. This is my favorite place all around town, & I find an excuse not to eat, just to get a bite here. You need to try this place, BUT be ready to wait because everyone knows this little secret and lines are LONG!!

hNSCxutNL-1nQTlu4R65fQ.text: Delicious best ramen I have ever had.  Small place with excellent food and service!  We will be back!

eYXA4AVe-HLnATVn7Tz9nw.text: When I think of Ramen, I think of Instant Cup O Noodles or the Pre Packaged ones that you pay like 5 bucks for a big bulk box at Wal Mart.  Not until a friend of my wife mentioned this place that we stopped by to check it out. That's when I found out that this is not your ordinary dollar store ramen.   Their menu is pretty simple. You pick which noodle bowl you want, choose whatever you want to add to it (like a hard boiled egg for example) for an extra charge of course.  They also have other items like gyoza (pot stickers) and fried rice.  Service is above average and it should be because you can only fit so many people in this tiny place. So slow service with an excuse of "Sorry, we are really busy today"  will not fly with me. Memo to those that eat here: Once you're done eating, please pay and move on with your life! I have seen people finish their meal and proceed to just shoot the breeze for another 15 to 20 minutes while you have 6 to 10 people waiting for a spot.  Some random info. Make sure to sign in to your right as soon as you come in so they know who got next. Don't just stand there and expect for them to remember if you came in before somebody else. If you see lots of people outside just standing there, chances are you will be waiting for a bit before getting a table. For those that are chopstick challenged like me, they will not give you a fork unless you ask because you are already given chopsticks by default. All the condiments you need like sesame seeds, soy sauce, etc are right there on your table.  So you see their operation is simple. It's just that their space might seem constricting especially if you have claustrophobia.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkatsu with Egg.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork Belly Bowl.

rvcd_m7EZLMI3m9AMBuejw.text: I was hoping Monta would be a good replacement for my normal hangover pho craving but it was not. I think it was little overrated.  Parking lot is pretty big. Service was good. The restaurant itself is super duper small. Like 5 tables and a bar area.   Spicy Tonkotsu - $7.95 - Basicly the same thing as the tonkotsu but with a spoon full of a chili paste. I do not think that spoon full is worth the extra dollar they charge. The broth was clean and the spice was decent. Not to salty. I like the noodles. Had good bite. The chashu was over cooked, fell apart in the broth. I had to dig around for it.  Miso - $6.95 - Clean broth with good miso flavor. It was super salty. I did not like the noodles in this ramen. The texture reminded me of the dry bagged ramen.    Corn - $.50 - Plain sweet corn. I like corn in my ramen. Good price.  Seasoned Egg - $1.50 - Basicly an egg seasoned with soy sauce. The yolk was good. Not worth the price though.   BIG ISSUE. There was a hair in one of our ramens.GROSSS!!! Usually when there is a hair in your food, they replace it and do not charge you for it but they still charged us. That was a little annoying.  Overall, decent ramen mixed with bad gross luck. Still perfer pho.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu w/ Egg and Corn - $9.95
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso w/ Corn - $7.45

GMlU-AF-NOaBIp0eqOzc2Q.text: Did some research and found this little gem. It's rated the best Ramen place on a budget in the entire country. We were all blown away. HUGE bowls of Ramen for almost nothing, and the quality is NOT Sacrificed. I got the ton katsu Ramen and found it to be the best. Also, if you get the fried rice, get the large size. We got the small and it was so delicious, I really really wished we had ordered the large. I almost liked it more than the soup! Also, they do not take rez but we got seated almost immediately. Do yourself a favor and go here!

JWXH2_eWaoyheDv_1PJ2uw.text: I first tried Monta at the LA Ramen Festival in Torrance earlier this year. It was probably my favorite ramen from the festival! So for our last meal in Vegas before heading back to LA, I wanted to come here!  We arrived at 11:40 AM on a Sunday, the place was full and there were 4 groups ahead of us. Monta opens at 11:30!! Insane. We waited about 35-40minutes before getting seated at the counter.   FOOD: Ramen was yum as I remembered! Base price is pretty cheap $6.95 but when you add the egg, it brings it up to a regular bowl of ramen.  I had the tonkotsu ramen (my fave) Really rich and good flavor with a PERFECT soft boiled egg! Chasiu was also super tender and falling apart. HUGE portions!! I didn't finish my noodles :(   VENUE: Small, as usual and single unisex bathroom. Very cute and clean and I loved watching the chefs make the food.  SERVICE: Quick!! Food came out super fast after we ordered and they were always friendly and easy to flag down.  PARKING: Plenty!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with egg added
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

o8MyiV9FOGBb_I0sbb13wg.text: One of the best ramen stop at Las Vegas for the price and delicious soup. The Tonkatsu ramen is only 6.95$, and customers are keep coming for more. The shop opens late and it is the perfect destination for some warm food before clubbing. While we know there are cheaper option on the menu, we paid extra for the black garlic oil. It's the best flavor to be added onto a soup of ramen in my opinion. It intensifies the rich texture of the soup and stick onto the noodle very well. It's ten minutes from the strip, and plenty of parking. No reason to skip by for visiting Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black Garlic Tonkatsu Ramen

7jIBcoV9XILCIF6bWqluDQ.text: Try the Shoyu or Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen. Their Kimchi fried rice and gyoza are both great additions if you want to get something besides ramen.   This is a pretty small place so sometimes it takes a while to be seated. The ramen is alright, it's not my absolute favorite but it's good if you're in the area and craving it.

JeQtN_9q-mG8ZBbY3t5kFA.text: Used to be a weekly visit a few months back but the wait times and finding parking are always a hassle. Service is standard at best but food is good. Lots of competition in the area with strong up and comers right up the street.

EcXmKEEUYswxXE8uqaevJA.text: And my raving for the KURO RAMEN ($8.95) begins. It is hands down a genius creation! Think rich and thick tonkotsu broth with an added black garlic oil that is immaculately fragrant and savory. You know it's been simmering for hours the moment that soup touches your lips and coats your mouth like silk. I tell you, it's delicious beyond words. Give in to the urge of adding that flavored egg for an extra $1.50 and some corn for $.50 more. The option to add butter is there if you think this bowl could use more fat than it already contains. Go ahead, I won't judge. The noodles are chewy with a good bounce to it however, the next time I'm here, I'm asking if they can substitute the thin noodles to the thick wavy ones they use for the miso ramen. It's just something I prefer and definitely not a deal breaker.  I've heard good things about the PORK BELLY BOWL (sm $3.95) and I concur. It's slices of tender pork with a sweet and salty marinade over white rice, and then topped with ginger and green onions. Only, after having the KIMCHI FRIED RICE ($6.95), there was no looking back at that pork bowl. The latter won my heart and palate as soon as a heaping spoonful made it to my mouth. Oh how I wanted to come back that same weekend for more.   What's impressive too is the efficiency of the servers and kitchen. We sat, ordered, had our drinks, and before I could even say a word, our food trickled in just like that...boom, boom, boom! The long list of names on the clipboard can be a turn-off but don't be deceived, the turnover is quick as an energizer bunny.

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen - see the thick noodles
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi fried rice

rnNzpbDUqKWKvA3vueKN2w.text: It's yummy!  I found this place by accident and I'm so happy I did not once but twice.  Always a long line that moves like lightening.  I always order everything with extra meat.

lybPCNkghmoZNmslcFz7GA.text: I'm always on the hunt for a good ramen place and this place is awesome!  It's a small establishment but worth the wait. The menu is simple and you can add your choice of egg, seaweed, kimchi, etc into your ramen.   The serving size is plenty, enough to feed 1 hungry full sized man    We also had an appetizer- gyoza which were yummy too.   Service was friendly and quick. Plus they didn't try to kick us out even though we had a party of 4 and were gabbing quiet a bit after our meal was over.

eVj919zLSkixPMkmeInP3Q.text: Holy crap, what a small interior. I usually get away with finding a seat at the bar area for one, but no luck during this visit. My only gripe about the place. Small capacity and long wait times on a crowded day. The staff was friendly and are quick to get you seated. That means as soon as guests are finished and make their way towards the exit, staff is there immediately to clean up and prep the table for the next people to be seated.   Major upside to the ramen here. It's very good and still super affordable even after adding extra pieces chashu and an egg. As for my bowl of ramen? One of the best bowls I've had. Flavorful broth and the noodles were at that perfect thickness with good texture. Monta Ramen is worth a try.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkotsu shoyu ramen mixed up
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkotsu shoyu ramen with extra chashu and an added egg.

VM5XoEb1njYhpx4GXwEOqA.text: Yup! KURO (black garlic ramen) is made from the wings of angels and sprinkled with the joy of unicorns. Whatever euphoric experience you've had, this tops it. Not Coachella, EDC, or watching your ex die from furious shits in a porta potty can ever compare to the JOY you will experience from eating at Monta Ramen.   We had to take it to go because we had our pups with us. So we brought it to The Park near T-Mobile Arena where there are plenty of tables.   I had the Kuro ramen. The minute it hit my taste buds, I just bowed my head and thanked the immaculate baby Jesus for this amazing opportunity. You have to get it with an egg!! I added corn too.   Hubs had Tonkatsu and while his was good, mine was life changing.   Grabbed Kung Fu milk tea a few stores down while we waited for the to go order. It was a nice addition to our meal. Definitely will be back to both places!

2bF-In9NFWtjxHkZArjZmg.text: Ramen Noodle 101  1. Order a drink whether you drink it or not. Remember, they don't make much profits if you only get $7 noodles.   2. Order some tsumami (appetizers). Here I ordered gyoza and takana. Yes, you may order "toppings" as appetizers.   3. Prepare for food. Place your chopsticks on a chopstick rest. Make a holder out of paper chopstick case.  4. Juicy gyoza goes good with beer. A tiny bit of spicy Takana does a great job as well. (Think like if you are having cheese and wine)  5. Get a small Mentaiko rice bowl (or fried rice).   6. Put the rest of Takana on mentaiko bowl. (see picture).  7. Close your eyes and feel the texture of mentaiko mixing with spicy takana in your mouth. Get a second round of beer if you wish.   8. Here you finally order ramen noodles. Ask your server to make the broth (soup) hot (temperature wise). If you are eating Tonkotsu with thin noodle, try "katamen" (hard noodle). That's equivalent of "Al Dente" for pasta.  9. Once you have your noodle in front of you, close your eyes and focus on the smell of it. Open your eyes, check the color of broth. With your spoon, pick up some soup and taste it. You may close your eyes here again.   10. Pick noodles up high so it won't be too hot. Eat it up as soon as possible. Don't worry making noise. Slurp! (Be careful of the hot soup). Eat before noodle absorbs soup and gets fat and softy.   11. Shut up and eat.  12. If it's not enough, you have always an option to get extra noodles for only $1.50  13. Put some red ginger for different taste, if you like.   14. Finish up all the soup.   15. Raise your hand and ask for check.   16. Put cash on the table and say thank you (to the servers and also the food, Mother Earth), then leave right away. Ramen joint is not a place to chat and hangout forever.  17. For some desserts? There is a Raku Sweet nearby. Also, ChaMon, specialized in the ultra authentic green tea/matcha cafe is opening soon in the same shopping center.  18. If you are over 18 and into independent movies, find this Japanese 80s movie "Tampopo" on Netflix. It's a trippy film on ramen noodle.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Added &#34;kaedama&#34;(extra noodle) and put some red ginger.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu simply the best.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mentaiko bowl with takana

ylrCQnzFr3U2_mFduz5lwQ.text: If you're craving traditional, simplistic but exceptional ramen then Monta is the place to be! It's menu is very straight forward, no fancy fancy. It kinda brings out that get-in-get-out happy vibe like how ramen shops are like in Japan. They offer speedy service, adequate sitting/tables which is a plus!  You can never really go wrong with trying out this well established shop. The base of ramen isn't the noodles, its their soup. And Monta definitely hits the spot for that. They offer variations of noodles as well.   For first timers, this is a must try. As for the regulars such as myself, we will keep on coming!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen

cdC7psh8xk7cGEJ9US6-Ew.text: Best fried rice ever!  Wonderful soups, took home the leftovers and had 2 more servings. There was a wait, but well worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

sBM-MxsaxjwQs1rarIOwpg.text: The best thing about this spot is their prices. It's hard to find cheap ramen ($7) unless you're off the strip. But the food is pretty mediocre, I would suggest one of the other many spots in Chinatown, LV.

YzEAa8grmEPEYMZywFmOkQ.text: Probably top three ramens I've ever tried. (I've had a lot of ramen before.) We came here two times and left because of the wait. So then we came at 10:40ish to wait for it to open and were the first to be seated. I had the tonkotsu shoyu ramen with nori. It was so good! It was not too rich and not too light. I also had some of the Buddha bowl, which was very good, but not anything that special. The ramen is very filling so I don't think it was needed. The gyoza is also alright, good, but nothing special.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkotsu/shoyu ramen with nori. added chili oil and the spice thing lol

df3-A5IVe0vZV5cKZgVxcQ.text: My favorite Ramen place in Vegas!  Ramen is delicious, the service is good, and despite what I've heard about waiting in long lines that run out the door, I've never waited long for seating in the 4 or 5 times that I've been here.    The gyoza here is great too.  Ask them to show you how to mix the perfect make-it-yourself sauce for the gyoza.  It's pretty tasty.    Also, although not a staple, I actually think that the fried rice here is very good.  Check it out for yourself!

SOp997gA_dKMXH9-b4ubIQ.text: Ramen is always a good idea, especially if it's Monta!  I always get the miso ramen with corn. I love their flavorful yet light broth! Come by and check them out!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

4sISBOxt9UdDksb8A15EHA.text: First time visit to this restaurant, It was so outstanding we went back the very next day to have it again. I had the Tonkatsu,  it had a rich lite creamy flavor with tons of depth, my BF had the Black garlic oil ramen again full of flavor but not over done. The portion was generous and the price was unbeatable. The staff was very attentive and worked so well together, small intimate place there was a waiting list both times we visited (didn't wait long to be seated) but not surprised due to the quality and taste. We will definitely come back again when visiting LV.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. One of the best Ramen I&#39;ve had so far! Tonkotsu

xy2pGwR_zM8KUycc0JQ0Pw.text: This was the first ramen house I had been to, so I wasn't sure what to think. But after trying a few back home in the east, Monta was surely the best! If I ever come back to Vegas this will be on the list of places to go.

NGsVscqphv-n_vkhuEctCg.text: Ramen was excellent! I got the miso ramen and everything went so well together and wasn't too strong. The fried rice was okay, quite small but flavor was nice.

wIdNwgV_mlc07QD6bQmf9Q.text: Great ramen spot in China town. A bit hard to locate since it's tucked away in a small plaza. Parking lot is also smaller so if you go when it's busy beware parking maybe difficult.   Service was quick, very fast. Ramen broth is pretty flavorful and noodles are soft. Ramen seems to be the same at every place we go to, the broth and thrbsevice pretty much determine if it stands out. I would go back but unfortunately it didnt really stand out from any other of the 50 ramen houses in LV.

4BWZiMqusIwdqmYQcqSXPA.text: My partner and I come here on a regular bases. It's incredibly affordable and I'd say the best Ramen in Vegas. The restaurant is VERY small so don't come with a big group unless you are ready to wait. The staff is quick and accommodating and if you order Ramen it will come out within 5-7 minutes at most. Be aware that the dumplings are made to order and take a while so know you'll most likely be done with your ramen by the time the dumplings show up.   If you haven't been it's worth the trip!

FS0fzlQm3srx57zpxdl05w.text: We came here two times before and didn't even walk in because the line was out the door but of course, both of those times were during prime time for dinner.   Our schedules made us push dinner to a late one at around 9p almost 10p. I'm addicted to ramen right now and have wanted to try this place so bad due to all the stellar reviews. We wondered if it would be less busy at this late hour and it was! We were seated right away at the counter, all tables were full. Once we ordered and were eating the whole place was full, including the whole counter top and it even looked like a few people were even waiting when we left.   I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with thick noodles (it comes with thin) I added Corn and an egg. It is already topped with chashu, bamboo shoots, and green onions. Sadly, they didn't have bean sprouts :( I love bean sprouts in my ramen. I thought the broth was a little saltier and thicker than I like. The chashu was SO fatty, there was barely any meat, just fat. Not good. It wasn't my favorite bowl of ramen that I've ever had like I expected it was going to be.   My boyfriend ordered the Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen, it came with thin noodles but my boyfriend asked for thick. It wasn't super spicy but it definitely had a kick to it. He added Corn and an egg, as well. His chashu was also more fatty than meaty. It was less salty with the spice in it.  The Gyoza we ordered to share were soggy. They were all stuck together like they were frozen together before cooked and served :/ the insides weren't seasoned very well, either. I have had so much better elsewhere.  I was just extremely disappointed here. The service and kitchen was pretty quick but we did have to ask for our check because we hadn't been given one after quite some time of finishing our meal. Their menu is smaller than other ramen houses and so is the restaurant. There will always be a wait because there is barely any seating and if there was a wait, it is not worth it and I'd never do it. There are other places with ramen just as good, some that are even better, with less or no wait time.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

RIE0Q2WOnBEgQM0Nib8jJQ.text: I didn't realize how hard it would be to find a really good Ramen restaurant after moving out of Hawaii.  However, Monta comes close to filling the void.  Monta is a small Japanese noodle house in a strip mall in china town.  If you don't like waiting to sit down, get there early as the line usually begins to form before the restaurant opens at 11:30AM.  There are a few scattered tables, but I prefer to sit at the bar and watch the cooks prepare the dishes in the open kitchen.  Monta makes Tonkotsu ($6.95), Shoyu ($6.95) and Miso ($7.25) Ramen broths.  While all three of the broths are very good, the milky white colored Tonkotsu (stewed pork bone broth) has an especially savory meaty flavor.  My favorite is the combination Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen ($6.95) which tempers the intense meaty taste of the Tonkotsu with the salty Shoyu broth.  The thin yellow Ramen noodles have always been consistently cooked to the just right texture, neither too limp nor too firm and underdone.  The ramen comes with basic toppings (green onions, bamboo shoots, Kikurage mushrooms and two thin slices of marinated Chashu pork) however, like all good Ramen joints, they have a whole list of additional toppings you can add (for a little extra cash) to make the dish your own.  The combination of flavors and textures soaking in the hot broth goes down well on a cold day.  We also usually order the pan fried pork gyozas ($5.15 for 6) and a small Kimchi fried rice ($6.95).  The gyozas are excellent and the moist rice has a good flavor.  Each table has an array of sauces and condiments that you can add to your meal (rice vinegar, soy sauce, chili oil, sesame seeds, and chili pepper) as well as little jars of crushed garlic and red pickled ginger.  They also serve beer to wash it all down with.  The service is fast and the food comes out quickly.  So even if you do get stuck waiting in line, it usually moves fast.  And if you are in the mood for good Ramen, it is worth the wait.

GNT_K9VgXv70hpCQjNICeA.text: I love their ramen! Came with a couple of friends and my sister. I tried the Shoyu ramen for 6.95 and added a side of kimchee (because me loves some kimchee. yes i do!). I also ordered the kimchee fried rice as well for $6.95.   Awesome execution for both I may say! I loved the texture of the noodle. It was soft, but it still had that firm bite that you take into it. That's how I like my ramen! It also hd a very tender slice of pork in it and a few other garnishes. I loved the Shoyu broth. I don't know what else to say! It wasn't salty or overpowering. It was just right. Not too salty, and the broth was very nice with the mixture of the meat in it. YAY BROTHINESS!  Kimchee fried rice is also of A+ quality. You can taste that nice grill taste to it. The cut o the kimchee was small and so were the small bits of egg which is how I like it too be. So YAY KIMCHEE FRIED RICE!   It's such a good price too so I felt like I got more than what I payed for. The service was awesome. The server was very cheery and upbeat and attentive which I loved. So...YAY SERVICE! Thumbs up for such personal service in such a little place. I just love how authentic Japanese restaurants like to keep things small, simple, and intimate. YAY JAPAN!

ZSaNFqfpyHUTV2op6pdZbA.text: Oh my goodness.  I want more noodles now.  Yum.  We went on a Tuesday night at about 8;15 and there were people milling about outside, indicating a waiting list.  I had to be up early so we almost left and went elsewhere.  While we were thinking about it we put our names on the list, there were 3 other 2 tops ahead of us.  One of them had left I guess so we were sat in about 10 minutes.  I'm glad we stayed.    We were sat at the bar, with a perfect view of the noodles flinging about the kitchen.  Although I am a little short so I was standing most of the time :)  The place is small, probably no more than 24 seats, 10 of which are at the bar.  The service is quick and friendly.  The noodles come out quickly and it is fun to watch your order being made.  I got the Soy Ramen with extra scallions and extra pork.  Get the extra pork.  Each bowl comes with like 2 thin slices of pork.  It was my favorite part of the bowl, it is braised fatty pork that kind of melts in your soup and your mouth.  The flavor is wonderful and noodles are tender and slurpable (is that  a word?).    It was 20 bucks without tip and included two beers and two bowls.  It was quick and fun and tasty.  In the past I have had ramen bowls that were tasty, but they usually come with fish cakes and a few other things I don't love.  But this was pretty straight forward and no fish in any of these.  I guess it's a different type of ramen, but I like it way better.    Give this place a try, if there is a line, it goes quickly.  I will definitely go again, hopefully soon.

zrUihtJJ2j-ap0VYYYS68Q.text: Simply the best Ramen in Las Vegas and perhaps all the US.  Prices are still extremely reasonable even with all the demand.  Yes the place is tiny and waits can be long but well worth it.  I always come here everytime in Vegas and they never disappoint. The larger ramen restaurant on Spring Mountain Rd cant compete with this place.

EF3mmDlyRqAuzpMaM-FttA.text: Great food and service. Broth for soup was very flavorful. Meat is so tender that it literally melts in your mouth. There's always a line out the door, so plan ahead.

e-Kf2z0YXfcB3kkcoDrREw.text: My this would be my go-to ramen spot if it wasn't always so damn busy. It's small and popular. They really need to expand this location. But if you do get in, try the miso ramen and a few upgrades. Don't be afraid of the the butter. Trust me, it's worth the extra calories.

V6U_tCWv39j5GkPT9eoOvQ.text: This place always hits the spot for ramen cravings.  Clean and friendly.  Always over crowded.  The flavoring and tasting is good really good- but Ive aso had better in little tokyo in LA.  STill a great place and will be going again and again.

b_mYIbFmOjtRk3tfzGu5_A.text: Wow! Best real ramen since ive been to japan. Worth a trip even if it's tiny and not easy to find,in the back of a strip mall lot. Get there early, they have about 8 tables and not a lot of space to stand and wait.

jVMYj40DYB7qpl7X2wCDtg.text: For my first time here, it's been a lovely experience! The portions are quite large and the food is reasonably priced, as well as phenom-nom-nom-enal!!!!! Can be quite packed, but they're quick to solve the issue.

kiP5GTmJp6TkdYyV_QFy3Q.text: Delicious!! Never been here before today and the service was fast and great! The soup was so tasty and to my surprise I came out feeling full and satisfied after having a bowl of soup.   Definitely recommend to all my friends!

fnUBIcHCGjLzmAhKYofBWw.text: I was bummed when I moved to Nevada because I was certain I wouldn't find a Ramen spot that was as good as my old one in Chinatown back in L.A. But boy was I wrong! Monta exceeded my expectations!  Dare I say, even better than the spot back home? They're location isn't the flashiest and the decor is a little out of date but the food is quick, delicious hearty and cheap! Can't get any better than that.

VB7cuUO0inxaY9t5IEvHfA.text: Great pork broth ramen. Noodles, cooked perfect. Be willing to stand in line, but they turn the tables quickly. We were like 5th in line, but was seated in about 10 minutes. Great service and value.

QkoWBWQBiyw1CXL_nFnX9Q.text: I dont get it. Portions are WAY less than other places like Jinya and Sora. Tight and small. in the corner of massage parlors. I really love Ramen, I believe some of the best is right here in Las Vegas. I didnt feel that FLAVOR from either the food or staff, no hello or goodbye? More like: Next! Really left feeling Meh and I found myself not eating the rest. There is just nothing special about this place like Sora with its BROTH or Jinya with its NOODLES etc...Meh. I've experienced better.

FzOb8ev9wY-AFOT238e9yw.text: This was my introduction to ramen restaurant noodles.  Love it.  Very flavorful.  I recommend getting the flavored egg and seaweed with your noodles.  Also go next door and get yourself a boba tea at Kung Fu Tea!

CLCKLQQGOZG7XNlQ5Mw-fQ.text: We came with a party of 9, and they were very accommodating.  I got the Miso Ramen, which comes with the thick, curly noodles.  The regular Tonkotsu ramen comes with the thin noodles, which I don't really like, so read the descriptions carefully.  I added corn to my ramen, and it was perfect!  We also shared some gyoza and fried rice.  The gyoza is ok, but the fried rice had lots of green onions.    Yes, this place is small, but the crowd just shows how great the food and service is here.  We got to sit at the counter and watch the guys make all the food.  It was the best seat in the house!

6DVDcfOxVy82HkdAjz8Qbw.text: Best ramen in town, fried rice is off the chin chain, only thing is that it's a real small spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

DiPI2xA42hHTAJMnhiCRGw.text: All i can saw is AWESOME! The noodles were perfectly cooked, the spicy tonkatsu was perfect! This place is tiny... So I would limit your party to 4 or less. Will be visiting again soon!

HFHsjw4DSiUjIZS7CCQJmQ.text: A friend and I stopped by around 1:30 on a Saturday. We were about 5th down the waiting list but did not wait very long. The service was quick and efficient. We ordered the Miso Ramen and the Shoyu ramen. They were both delicious. The noodles were perfectly cooked. We ordered the flavored egg in our ramen and they were AMAZING. The egg white was amazingly tender while the yolk was perfectly runny and flavorful. The broth was a tad salty if you're just drinking it when you're done with the noodles. But other than that, it was a wonderful experience.

jfDUMCaWrxXMGA8M-2lfEg.text: Highly recommended, authentic. Love the Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen and Pork Belly Bowl. There seems to be a line but fast service makes up for it.

Sv8lBINK-iydC9Me2VjbFQ.text: When I was visiting my brother and his GF in Vegas, they took me here for dinner one night. I was surprised to see that this cozy ramen shop was next to another favorite Japanese place - Raku. What most people don't know is that you can find some of the best (and cheaper) eats off the strip when you're visiting Sin City.  There was a bit of a wait (15-20 mins) seeing that the place is pretty tiny but it was worth it.  I loved the Tonkotsu Ramen and the Fried Rice that I ordered and shared with my 1.5 year old. The pork broth was delicious and rich as one would hope for in a mom and pop style kind of place. The meat was tender enough to give to my son who loves pork. The Fried Rice wasn't overwhelmed with 100 ingredients like some places but it was so flavorful. I tried to hold back and not pig out but it's really hard when the food is so good!  I will definitely be stopping by Monta Ramen again on my next trip to Vegas!

Op8MS8h0jImLBb5phFDzJg.text: Will have to definitely check this place out again when in Vegas...that is all :)

bja_EPvZa3bgFjyR4FH0qQ.text: We ordered the shoyu tonkatsu ang Gyoza  Gyoza was super greasy I had to put napkins under it to suck the oil off.  Ramen soup was so-so as it was light on flavor and a bit too salty  Overall I think I was just okay. It's pretty affordable though

iPbRFySpGxzj_E8NizL8Og.text: Now I know why there is always a crowd waiting outside... It's amazingly delicious and fast and friendly service. I had the Shonkatsu Chashu noodles... Pork was super tender and the delicate flavor was out of this world!

ium2QPIKN0nI54iEZjL0rg.text: This is, hands down, the best ramen restaurant in Vegas, in my opinion.    The dining area itself is rather small, and more often than not you'll have to wait awhile for a table (especially during lunch on weekdays, and on weekends).  I think it would be super difficult for them to accommodate to a party of more than 4 people.    Their prices are very decent as well.  Everything is pretty much under $10.  Everything I have tried here tasted excellent.

GaZ2uDT5quw_IKwrvguWmg.text: I love this place! Been coming here for years and I just wanted to add to all the great reviews.

oqsnIlFJVD95GUwvyXak8g.text: Winter weather leaving you feeling cold? Me too!   My old staple for cold weather comfort, like many others, is Pho. In light of something new I decided to try Monta Ramen. This place is definitely worth a try!   Very cozy, small place, serves up a limited menu of fried rices and reman soups. I had the Kim chi fried rice -the egg and the flavors were amazing.   Also has the tonkotsu ramen and that was a very hearty filling soup.  The downfall from this place is the lack of a vegetarian option soup. This is usually a must for me. Feeling the cold disparity I opted for the chick and park broth tonkotsu ramen and gave the pork that came with my soup to my boyfriend (obviously this was a plus for him )   I neglected to notice the specials board, or rather the server neglected to tell me about it, but next time I'll be trying their Spicy Tonkotsu soup. Would have given this 4 stars, but sometimes the attitude of the servers is a bit shaky. Also, sitting at the counter near where the door opens isn't the greatest either.

C8AFIdjOCruxWixrmTV_fw.text: I arrived alone at this restaurant. Not a bad place for a party of one since they have bar seating. It's small inside but even the large party's waiting were seated quickly. I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with an egg. It was awesome. Very good service and quality ramen. I was impressed and will definitely go back.

g8sr-l79Bt5EZS6WBQjp9g.text: there was a line even at 9pm. But the noodle and the fried rice was goood and cheap. very satisfying late night food

3w1BkXcSuTBUxFbg5lBqGA.text: My buddy's been raving about Monta Ramen for as long as I can remember. Me, I just can't justify a soup as a meal, so I had never been before today. With only 4 hours of sleep and a 12nhour workday, a bowl of soup sounded like the perfect way to end my day. The spicy miso I ordered was delicious, and I ate every last drop of soup after finishing the noodles. I still will not change my stance of eating ramen as a meal, but if I have a craving for ramen I'm sure I'll come back in to Monta.

6n-NssnhHyCfgkhi1xhr1w.text: I really don't know what the hype is for this ramen place. This is my second time here because I thought I would give this place another try. Perhaps this is the best ramen place in Vegas, but if it is, I feel sad that people who live here haven't truly experienced good ramen.   The ramen noodles are overcooked and soggy. The broth does not taste like it has been cooked long enough with pork and chicken. If you like the type of broth that is not super thick though, this type of broth might be for you. Flavors seem to be added in after the fact rather than blended in. Something seems off about the whole ramen experience. I give it 2 stars because this place does try and has decent customer service.

RIv8Twhw5WmJEAEIqImPDg.text: While the ramen was decent, it definitely didn't warrant the wait we had to endure. Nothing incredibly unique about this place and I can say I've had better. They probably should expand thou if so many people want to keep trying it.

JneKvlPEK3TwAN1vtea06A.text: Our first experience at a noodle house, and it was great!!!  Very small atmosphere, but so delish!  Even being unfamiliar with the menu was not a deterrent.  The waitress was very helpful.  My husband had one type of ramen bowl and I had a different one and they were both awesome.  The dumplings are a must have!  Order those first, as it takes ten minutes to prepare them.  And to top off this awesome experience was the reasonable bill.  There might be a wait, but it is worth it.  That's why people are waiting!!!

aWEMGCMF7dzlNRF2hmdaJQ.text: One of my favorite Ramen places in town. They are consistent with their Ramen regardless the season or time of day. Fried rice and gyoza are made fresh and your food comes out hot. Don't be afraid to request they leave out any veggies you don't like, they are happy to oblige. When there is a long wait be sure to eat and go. This entire shopping center is like a treasure chest of treats.

KBpEsAalwNKGLGDAQob8Bw.text: There's always a line and it's a small restaurant but it's worth the wait. If you aren't Asian then you probably aren't used to a pork based broth, then that's what you should try. The sliced pork (Tonkotsu) is amazing. I go back every time I am in Vegas, TRY IT!!

c4Y-yhCZkgEMjdTQlnyysg.text: Went here to try their ramen since we are in Las Vegas for the weekend. This restaurant is in chinatown thoughm about 10-15 minutes from the strip depending on the traffic.    I ordered the Kuro Ramen and it was great! I had ordered extra chashu and corn but it was too much though.  It was very filling.  The broth is tasty but the black sesame oil got cold too fast and tasted like lard.  It wasnt suppose to taste like that since I had tried kuro ramen from other japanese restaurants around the world.  We also ordered sides of chashu rice bowl for 3.65 (approx.) and small bowl of pork belly bowl.  I like the chashu rice, chasu was a little bit crispy and tasty but the pork belly bowl is too sweet for my liking.  The noodles in the ramen are just right and had good chew in it.  i do recommend the place but to be honest, I had better.

JLyKRIeAhS6UkntdQRT3gg.text: I came here as a result of Yelp reviews. Totally worth it. I had the Tonkotsu ramen. So rich and creamy! Like savory, meat flavored buttery broth! I was worried that I would have a belly ache because it was so rich, but no, I was just fine! I didn't have any add-ins and I was so full!   My daughter had just had her wisdom teeth out a few days prior and was dying for some real food. She had the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen. By the time she was done, she looked like a whole new person. When she walked in, she was pale and tired, her eyes were glassy. By the time she was done eating her ramen, she had a rosy glow in her cheeks and she perked up 100%! It was like ambrosia.   We loved this place so much that when my friend came to visit from the San Francisco Bay Area the next day, we went again. My friend is a food snob and was leery that Monta would be anywhere near as good as her beloved Orenchi in Santa Clara (I've eaten there, it is heavenly). Monta definitely passed her high standards. I couldn't get her to admit that Monta was better, but she did agree that it was at least equal!  Very friendly and attentive staff. Small eating area, but just make sure you come before or after the normal busy times. We didn't have a wait either time when we went around 6:30pm, but worth the wait if you have to.   If you are looking for a good ramen place, this is it! If you think ramen comes in a package with a seasoning packet, go here and prepare to be schooled. SO ONO!

LFOBgfyoNT1_V-EgBnn-MQ.text: I always leave full and super happy with the food! The chefs work their butts off to service people quickly.  They definitely move fast. Ramen is always full of flavor! The kimchi fried rice is delicious! The location is tiny and small but honesty ramen isn't meant to be eaten in an hour, so people come in and leave fast. Expect a wait during rush hour and dinner time. Jot down your name on the list on the podium. Run next door for a boba if you'd like. The wait is worth it.

omQZC6nfg9_Iwtcri2cPuQ.text: Although my own House serves up a pretty bowl of Ramen (and NOT the prepackaged kind), Monta Noodle House is my "go to" place when I don't have the right ingredients on hand. The shoyu-tonkotsu broth with added corn, soft boiled egg, and nori perfectly warms my belly on those chilly Vegas nights.  With chili sesame oil, ginger, and garlic- I am in noodle soup heaven.   The bowl is just the right size for me (and I can eat), but my husband thinks it is just not enough.  Therefore, he must add 2 orders of pork slices and more noodles, and a  small order of pork belly and rice to fulfill his grumbling stomach.  Thus, what was supposed to be a cheap soup dinner because a lot pricier. It is a small restaurant with about 5 tables and seats at the counter, but the turn around is pretty quick since the menu is very simple.

_Mp1yT9pF-J9ZEySWyqQNA.text: Best japanese noodle shop i have ever eaten; however this restaurant is only my 5th one. Shoyo ramen: chicken broth only, minimal oil, great taste and quality ingredients. Fantastic cooked noodles. Gyoza dumplings were flavorful and tasty. Pork belly is the best i have tasted. Recommend this to anyone.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyo noodles

QlDrMPrpyMJJjtiEov3hmg.text: Went in during rush hour, which sucked because this place is super small and probably only sits about 30 or less people. We ended up waiting a really long time for our seats.  This place is supposedly the best ramen place in Las Vegas. Came out here and expected it to be awesome. However my opinion wouldn't matter because I'm not Japanese so how would I really know if this place is legit?   I ordered the spicy tonkotsu shoyu ramen with extra egg and pork. It was alright... Kinda meh. I expected more. This place is just an ordinary ramen place to me.   We came in as a group and asked for separate checks, but the worker didn't want to give us separate checks because apparently it was too complicated for her.

pGrRD3WNsRTl2ji3koyxAg.text: The wait is always really long but sooo worth it. The black garlic oil ramen is the best, in my opinion. I always try to stop by when I'm in Vegas.

eccRvKW4hBOAoP5MSf6BDQ.text: WHO KNEW Las Vegas had 5 star ramen?! I didn't!  Holy cow, Monta's Tonkatsu ramen was the one of the best I've ever had, rivaling Daikokuya in Little Tokyo. The tonkotsu LITERALLY melted in my mouth and the noodles were cooked perfectly. The broth was so stinkin' rich that I surrendered after eating only half of the bowl - the girls that I went with did the same. We were all in disbelief at how good it was - really, not being dramatic, though the fact that some of us were mildly hungover might have something to do with it...  Anyway, the ONLY downside is that the place is not suitable for groups larger than 4-5, but the waitresses were still accommodating when I went with a group of 10. Monta will definitely be on my list for my next Vegas trip if I'm not up for a Vegas buffet or I'm not feeling bad enough for some pho down the street.

0_PyXm6fdyIryW33ILqSbw.text: The ramen was good but service was kinda slow. Make sure to call first before you go there it's a small place and sometimes a wait.

ghxHiA3oOwa5HccFYzyI2w.text: Great place for ramen that is close driving distance to the strip.   This place seats about twenty people and you should be prepared to wait on a weekend.   The service was very fast and friendly.   This ramen place is run and owned by Japanese which is always more authentic.   I got a spicy tonkatsu ramen and the fried rice.  The portion was very large, extra noodles for $1.50 if you like.   Ramen: broth hot and spicy, on the saltier side, the hot sauce was right on target, pork was super tender and fell apart easily with my chopstick, veggies nice and firm.   Fried rice: good size portion, plenty of veggies mixed in, nice side of ginger slice.  Prices: very reasonable, all the ramen dishes were under $10 bucks. Fried rice portion was about $7. Japanese tea for $2 beer for $3  This is a solid ramen place in Vegas. Never impressed. Will return here again in the future.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkatsu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice

-QP9gmEstWBbWtiQOqC3uA.text: Really good ramen but this place gets hella busy. You also can't order over the phone to pick up, annoying. And if you come here expect to wait, for a while. But if you're craving ramen, this is probably the best place in town. I haven't tried anything better so far.

KLPRfnmyv4Poy9J4cMqL7w.text: Soooooo good. Las Vegas' best kept secret. Visited this restaurant on a recommendation and I was not disappointed.  The place is tiny and always packed but the wait time is average about 5-10 minutes.

EbGGzhOgTrdvuRoModELXg.text: This place has some of the best Ramen in town for a good price but it does get packed so your best bet is just get it to go.

u2Sw4Gcxilzastt8bL_UTA.text: Not those packaged noodles you eat on the poor or ate in college (isn't that all the same?).   Fresh noodles with tons of combinations of extra ingredients.  Pros:  Friendly staff Solid food - yes it's ramen, but it's GOOD ramen Reasonable pricing considering the portions are huge (bowl of ramen is the  size of a toddler's head and is absolutely full of food. Community style benched seating around the ramen bar is fun - you never  know who your neighbor will be and you can strike up some interesting  conversations - or not!   Cons:  Closet sized - there's always a wait and it feels hot as hell in there  Parking - it's in a strip mall that also houses the ever popular Raku Sweets so  parking can get interesting  Soda is only served in cans.  I'm a thirsty person and this gets to be an issue  after the first two.  I am well aware that most asian restaurants do this and I   understand that, but doesn't change my hope that I'll see something different.

PvPLFvYCZ34G9q3YnrUDYA.text: Great place if you need to get your ramen fix. Good food but be prepared to wait.

hAVGuAHRtAB8jA8kHPtIpA.text: Thank you, Vegas for sharing this amazing Ramen with us.  This ramen made our entire trip.  We walked two miles from the strip to get there, and it was WORTH EVERY STEP!  Blissful and stuffed, the 2 mile walk back was perfect to burn off all the magnificent calories.   It is in a little strip mall and is quite crowded no matter the time of day (we were there at 2:30 and waited about 20 minutes)  You write your name down on the clipboard right inside the doorway and when a table is ready they call you.  Most people wait outside, there are a few benches to sit on.  The interior is very clean, neat, and cute.  There is a counter and a few small tables.   It is not a place you want to come to if you have a large group.   The service was very pleasant.  The waitstaff was extremely kind, patient, and attentive.    We ordered some of the regular fried rice and it was the best we have ever tasted.  It was extremely fresh, well seasoned, and downright delicious.  We also ordered the gyoza which were cooked to order and impeccable.  Onto the ramen, I ordered the Tonkotsu which is a pork based broth where the bones are cooked in the broth to create a creamy, thick, almost buttery texture.  It was extremely flavorful and very rich.  My husband got the combo Shoyu Tonkotsu which is the same pork broth mixed with a soy/chicken based broth.  This was a little less rich and was also close to perfect.  The noodles were fresh and the perfect texture.  There are tons of add ons and extra seasonings at the table so you can make the broth exactly the way you want it!   I would recommend this establishment to anyone visiting the area.  It was amazing.

_YybEVp2GuRYR1GFw2CidQ.text: I tried ramen a handful of times, it's always good flavor and filling. But it is on the high sodium side. Cool spot, a little tight on seating but if you want 5 star seats go somewhere else. Overall, it's good and service was on point.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Rice bowl and ramen

6pU2BoEkwDO9h6ZzaaDRnw.text: There's a lot good ramen places especially in Chinatown and I've tried most of them, but Monta is the absolute best. I tried the location in Henderson first and then this one and they both are my favorite! The only downside is that they are always extremely packed and the wait is long since there aren't a lot of seats.

HAEgcSMwU0N2hhckspG_Kg.text: Came here to see what the hype was all about, so I came with high expectations.  I guess I set myself up for failure because the ramen was dissapointing. It doesnt even compare to the small ramen houses I grew accustomed to in Okinawa. Yet, it was still fairly busy, not worth the wait in my opinion.

bh32Y1mzr3NcLb4hKhuBLA.text: For the longest time i've heard this place was the go to place for some ramen. Well finally decided to give it a try instead of Ramen Sora where I usually went and had one of the best bowls of Ramen in my experience. I think Ramen in Vegas in general is just super cheap compared to northern Ca, so I definitely give this place a +1 on that ($8 ramen). One of the thing that surprised me most was having the minced pork over rice at a ramen shop. That I was not expecting.   Tonkotsu Ramen was what I ordered. It did come with some good flavors, but personally I think I liked the Minced Pork over rice more than I liked the ramen. The flavors were pretty good but they seemed like a flavor i'd get at any other ramen shop. Broth was buttery but felt like it was made me more thirsty than anything. I got this other noodle that I didn't like but my friends had the original type of ramen noodle. I didn't notice that they paired different noodles to different flavors or that you can request to have them changed, so that was a fail on my part. Add an egg and some butter corn and that makes anything close to good. Add some mouth melting tender pork and you should be good to go.   Place was kinda crowded and we had 9 people so our wait was a little long. There's a nice little boba joint next door, so get some boba and wait in the AC.   Tips:  1) Get the minced pork over rice 2) Add the egg and pork  3) Enjoy

VbiFkUBRmPeZtrsaeODidQ.text: Before I went to Monta I expected much because the comments said it is so good, maybe that's why I feel a little disappointed. However, it is still a good ramen restaurant, just not a "must go".  The space is a kind of small, like 9-12 tables and a bar. And there is always a line. People sign their name and the table size needed, then wait for calling. Servers are a little busy so they may not able to hear you in time, but it can be understood and they are still enthusiastic to each customer. The place looks clean, they clean the table immediately when someone leave. I think the furnitures are not new because the couple sit near me have to put something under the table to fix it. Maybe because the restaurant has a history.  I ordered the tonkutso ramen, and the food is another reason I feel a little disappointed. It tastes good, but not surprising delicious! The soup is a little salty and the nitamago tastes weird. Noodles are okay.  Anyway, in Vegas it is still can be considered as a good one. The price is very friendly, the environment is friendly, so I think if only want to enjoy a Japanese meal, you can try it. And as a local resident, I think I will go back to try other items sometime.

s64kKV2l1IHSF0BQcS9_GQ.text: I think besides there's just one other ramen place to compare this to in Vegas and I haven't been to the other one yet. Came here for a late lunch and waited for about 10 mins as the place is small. Not going to compare this to places in LA since I've had better. We ordered their fried rice with pork to start off and I'd have to say it's definitely one of the best I've had. Delicious and plenty of taste with this dish. I would have to order it again the next time I come.  I ordered their Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen which means "pork bone and special shoyu base" ramen. Bowl size and portion was just perfect but I could've easily ordered another set of ramen because I was that hungry that day but controlled myself. Soup based wise, it was kind of salty. Ramen though was perfect and the mix of chashu and egg was perfect since I usually have these at other ramen restaurants.   If you're in the mood for a good ramen place while you're in Vegas visiting, Monta Ramen is the place to check out. Though soup base can be a bit salty meaning it's probably because of too much MSG, taste wise of the noodles can't go wrong.

EHniMmm76LnI9wnUwln_Tw.text: I went here with a friend a couple of months ago on a Saturday night. The shop is small and very busy, but we got seated as soon as my friend arrived which was nice! The prices were great. I ordered the Kuro ramen and my friend ordered the Tonkatsu ramen. I think our bill was only $15 and we couldn't split it with our cards because there was a $10 minimum, no big deal though. My ramen was okay, but the broth was little too salty for me. I LOVE ramen, but this was just OK for me.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro (black garlic oil) ramen

HFhs6obPXB-c7Ampdof9ug.text: Went here twice. Sat by the bar. Place is smaller than Sora, but nicer. Service is good.   MISO RAMEN is way better than Tonkatsu Ramen. Get this one!!!  TONKATSU SHOYU RAMEN was good. Broth and noodles are nice. Only comment is there's not a lot of toppings that comes with the original order - 2 pieces of pork chashu and bamboo shoots, I think. We had to order extra topping of egg. I think next time, I'll also order extra pork chashu.   GYOZA is nice. It has a crunch that I like, but still meaty on the inside. Pretty good.   Monta and Sora are the only ramen places from Vegas featured on Ramen Festival in LA and Vegas. Rightfully so because both are awesome. (Didn't get to go to Ramen Fest though.) Contrary to other reviews here, my boyfriend and I think that Sora beats them by a tiny bit due to Sora's broth and toppings. I'd say come taste it yourself and you be the judge. It's very subjective after all. I'll probably go here if Sora is full since they're pretty close to each other.  Last note: I'll be bummed if I move back to San Diego because we don't have awesome ramen places like this. Tajima sucks! Will have to go to LA to get a good one.

I6P4n_2wAJHWzKXGci94fw.text: Love this place. Broth is made in house and is legit. If you're sick, come get some of this goodness to help you get better. If you come to this location in China Town get ready for a wait time. This place is popular for a reason, and this particular location is small. Their Henderson location **check to see if they're done with their renovations** is a little bigger, but I've still had to wait there as well.  If you understand that wait times = good food then enjoy this ramen house. I know I do!

mLJjWJ6grfX1GYUy8AztRA.text: Best ramen in vegas hands down.  The wait is well worth it. Highly recommended to anyone looking for good Japanese.

yGqf56GvD0E1duZ5kPDXWQ.text: Can we add more stars? This place waa delicious! Gyoza was perfectly crispy and of course the ramen was perf. Plus next door is The Foot Spa which was great too!  Totally coming back!

TUdzN74wqu9IWSvXoHjX6w.text: I figured I had to try Monta Ramen since it has been considered to be one of the best in Vegas. It wasn't too crowded when I came by, so my experience went by pretty quick as they were fast to bring out my ramen. Based on the waitress recommendation I went with their Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen -- bit.ly/ZgoKXE I went really simple with this and figured if they can get this right, then everything else should be good. It was pretty good ramen. Not really the best I've had though, but still good enough to be very comforting and filling. I'll have to pay another visit to Monta Ramen again in the future I'd love to try their rice dishes and all their other hot dishes. I'll be looking forward to it!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen

YL2HmILQglwey_gRAYt1cg.text: One of my favorite place to eat in Las Vegas, reasonable price, delicious, and great costumer service. They restaurant is kind of small and if you are sitting on the bar you kind of have to be shoulder to shoulder with another person.  If there are a lot of people and you find yourself have wait outside make sure you go in the restaurant first and search for the waiting list and put your name down, and then go back and wait outside. Once there are table open up they will call your name for sitting

DaT2S0m2wG56L3jzr7oeYQ.text: This place was pretty good. Going in during the fairly busy dinner time I wasn't sure if we were going to get in especially since they have a pretty small dining room. Their turn on tables was pretty swift so we were in after about a half hour wait.  To order we shared a small fried rice and I had the Spicy Ramen. Broth was on point and the noodles were pretty darn good. I tried the nori and flavored eggs as my toppings, the nori was nori and the egg was kind of meh. Over all we still had a pleasant experience. I would give it another try in the future.

BUuKlztcVE8Zqfsx17lhFA.text: It's always good to go back there. Best noodles ever. I taste good. I would order it without meat next time

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. It&#39;s yummy and rich. I would order it without meat next time.

4CDzLAjj9KmIL4SYkDkIfA.text: The best Ramen in Vegas! A must stop every time we come to Vegas. Ramen good, gyoza good, fried rice good!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_YIBleDyK0rnFG-E5X07pg.text: I think this place got LA ramen joints beat, some of the best hands down. I don't know if it'd traditional to have the booth so creamy and thick but the flavors are explosive. Funny thing is im from Dallas and they have a chain there. Its nothing like it what so ever.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

E82exGzEBHPDTvtY52W1wg.text: The best in town without question. My wife eats here at least once a week. There is a reason Anthony Bourdain comes here when in Vegas. You can order a few different kinds of ramen and a few sides if you so wish, as the menu is very small and focused on the main attraction. Still, the Gyoza are exceptional and I also enjoy the pork belly bowl. Forst and foremost however is the ramen, and of those choices I believe the tonkotsu shoyu ramen and miso ramen are the best options. Tonkotsu shoyu is a perfect blend of broths and flavor with thin noodles while the miso is even more complex and comes with slightly thicker, chewier noodles. If you are not full by the end, don't discard your broth and resist drinking it all up. Just ask for more noodles and you can keep the joy going.

uqzq1YYSlil40HCMfjYnTg.text: Absolutely love this place but it's so incredibly tiny that I usually always end up just going to ramen sora. The food here is amazing but expect like an 1-1/2 half wait and they don't take reservations. The ramen here is really good though so if you can stand waiting then it's worth it

QapyhXL1oHsiAdqhXvtovg.text: My husband and I came to Monta Ramen in August 2012 - so this review is way overdue, haha. We had just finished our meal at Raku (almost next door) and was still craving some ramen. Soo...we wandered into this restaurant, got seated immediately (it was already past 11:30 pm at night).  Even though it was so late already, this is one of the few ramen places that was open late at night.  My husband ordered a bowl of ramen, but I can't remember what he had. It was either Tonkotsu Ramen or Miso Ramen, although I think it's the former.   I ordered the pork belly rice bowl, and it was great! There was a good portion of marinated soy pork belly on top of a bed of rice, and I gobbled it up so quickly. It helps that I am a fan of pork belly :)  We both enjoyed our meal and wouldn't mind coming back again when we're visiting Las Vegas in the future.

X4Xq4-mzuxmppDAlzYcvtA.text: You guys should change your yelp times! Came all the way here for nothing! It says closes at 1am on here but they close at 11pm. Smh !

xfLa-3tv6SxT3eEyRuR8rw.text: Used to come here a lot because it was the number one ramen restaurant in town.but I'm just very disappointed about how the taste has changed. Fried rice is flavorless and the waitress had a bad attitude. Skip here and go to Tatsu.

2zTQbUTrcT7678ChzmawEg.text: O.M.G. The best ramen  I've ever had!  The pork melted in your mouth and the broth was to die for!  I think this is a spot mostly only locals go to so I'm glad I discovered it.  Small and cozy but the wait is well worth it!  I'll definitely be back!

WqCKd3MmYz2zKtnPrDND_g.text: Is it me or this place is overrated? I guess it's me since 700+ ppl seems to like it, and my friends thought the ramen are amazing too. Maybe there was something wrong with me or my pallet that day.   Good thing we got there early enough to avoid the long line during lunch hour on a Friday afternoon. Just got off the plane, I was super hungry and ready for some yummy ramen. I got the tonkotsu ramen and one of my friend got the miso ramen. I tried her and it's very similar to mines except for one thing, she added extra butter. This make the broth super rich and I can't see myself finishing it after a few bite if that was my noodle...too much. My ramen was super salty that it makes me super dehydrated. My favorite part of soup is always the broth, and if the broth is too much for me to handle, there's no point of eating it. The pork though, on the other hand was very tender and delicious.   I'll give it another try when I go back to Vegas, just because I love ramen that much.   Ramen: around $7/bowl (not too bad). It's a pretty good size too.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

4Sg6WG5BvHwU_fmlvprD2Q.text: Hey Monta, you make some good Ramen, just saying.  It took me some time to finally try this place. For one, I didn't know of its existence until after it was open for some time, and I had a hard time finding it. It is inside of a plaza where I had a hard time locating it, but you just have to make sure you make the turn into the plaza or the little street next to the plaza.  My friends that have tried Monta beforehand liked it enough where I had some expectations for this place. It didn't have to be rated G-A-F, but it had to be tasty. The first time I came, I just got a bowl of their tonkatsu ramen and I must say, I was one happy guy afterwards. The noodles were pretty good, their egg made me happy, their pork melted in my mouth, but the broth is what impressed me. The broth was probably my favorite part about the meal. Needless to say, I finished the whole bowl, soup and all! I was really happy.   The next few times I came, I started customizing and ordering different things on the menu. I added more noodles the next few times, got some of their fried rice, gyoza, added some corn to my soup, just customizing things to the point where I was happy! Their fried rice was pretty tasty. The kimchi fried rice may not be for everyone, because unless you like kimchi, you may not like it. Adding various things to your ramen makes it takes a lot better and funner to eat since it has more color and just the feeling of being able to customize your food just makes it that much better.   If you want to try some ramen and you're in the area, I highly recommend Monta. The only downside is that the restaurant is fairly small and during peak hours, you should expect a wait. People get turned away from places that have waits, but if you think about it, why do they have waits? It is small, but people keep going back because the food is delicious, it's as simple as that.

1K8S-VB8NzCXpcVy_GZU8w.text: Eating Ramen while it's 106 degree heat? Yup, it definitely was the first experience of that. For some weird reason I was craving for some ramen in the middle of night, so decided to give it a shot before leaving Vegas. Ordered: 1 Shoyu Ramen (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) - for those who don't eat pork, this bowl is the way to go! Chicken based soup that's not too salty and not greasy. The noodles were cooked perfectly, which is always a +. The only tiny thing they could probably improve on is to have the egg yolk more runny. 2. Fried Rice (yelp.com/user_local_phot...) - very good fried rice, yummy tasting, delicious, fatty, but not sure if it's one of the best I've ever had like other review said. Would definitely return again on a non-summer day! Tip: Be prepare to wait cause the long can be long!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso with egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu with egg
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small fried rice!

Hp9r2ji93hizyG2xIyeLqQ.text: Monta ramen has to be one of the best ramen spot in Vegas. You can't beat the price and quality. Only less then $8 for a large bowl of ramen is amazing! I always come to monta ramen whenever I am craving ramen, I've tried other places and this by far is my favorite. I always get the black sesame oil ramen (Kuro ramen) with thick noodles, You must try!! Times when I don't get ramen, I order the pork belly bowl, super good too! The wait to receive your food after you order is very quick, probably a 5-10 min wait. The only reason why I couldn't give this place a 5 Star is because of how small the place is which results in a long wait to get seated and how small the parking lot is.

bSnpDCLMFaz1P1gNvOHgJw.text: Hands down the best and most enjoyable Ramen Japanese noodle house! Thank you to the staff all your hard work in keeping us all nice and full and more than happy. We will  keep coming back again and again.  We like that the restaurant is small and only accepts a small amount of people at one time. the cooks are on point and the staff is super friendly. ARIGATO!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. MONTA JAPANESE NOODLE HOUSE  #1 in vegas

5nYHBBvrxrN6EEzCCTgdSw.text: I can't believe I hadn't written a review for this place yet. I've eaten here at least 6 times, and stopped by another 6-8 times only to be turned away by the line waiting. Its very small, maybe 3 4-top tables, 3 2-tops, and counter seats. There is always a line. This visit was on a Saturday, 2pm, and we waited for about 15 minutes for a table.  I had the miso ramen, with added egg, and a pork belly bowl. So delicious. The pork belly bowl is a new order for me and I really enjoyed the flavors. The miso ramen is good, not as salty as Ramen Sora, but still a bit salty. But its really good ramen, and will be my first choice for ramen in Vegas.  Try it, you will like it.

DLbhPS6K0LRyxVazS3SyVw.text: This is my favorite Ramen place. You usually have to wait, and the parking is a huge pain in the ass... But it's all worth it when you get your food. Simply the best. Take your patience with you, for sure, but go.

aP1AoAZ4aWTRgYKuqL88bQ.text: Ok so we went to Monta on a recommendation from a friend that is would absolutely re-define ramen for me, so me and the Fiancee go to monta and check it out (also forgot to metion that i brought other friends to try it out from the bay area so our party was a total of 9) when we got there we had to wait, the capacity of that place is 26 @_@ wow.  needless to say we were going to take up almost half the restaurant, we waited about 45 minutes and then we were sat. The menu is very simple...pick your broth (tonkotsu, shoyu or miso) and then you are off. The food made it to the table fast, but was not impressed by the flavor nor having to pay per item to make my bowl complete.  so needles to say i would recommend you try it and put your comments up to let people know what to expect before going there. NO one in my party was floored by the flavor and the wait staff was very slow at refilling

gGTXvp-6j3PYgbbDUcetjQ.text: Simply Japan and Good(^w^)  When I walked in, I was instantly happy because how much it reminded me of small Japanese ramen shop in Osaka.   They play Japanese music from 70's to present, which adds good touch to the resutrant.  I ordered tonkotsu ramen, their broth is excellent, rich creamy and yummy =D Their noodle is straight skinny type, which is good match for tonkotsu broth.   I had their Gyoza, witch is homemade and delicious.   Their chashu tastes like real chashu you can get in Japan (^w^) mmmMM I would definitely go back their when i goto Vegas next time =D

Fvpn9S9OGKAaH87Y7DhBcw.text: I usually go to the new location on Eastern/Serene, though I have gone to other one a well.  Consistent quality of the food.  The best ramen in town!  I love everything from the calamari, fried rice, karaage (fried chicken) and that crunchy spicy tuna appetizer.  Of course the ramen, don't forget to add extra chashu (pork). Yummy!  Prices are affordable too.

OZuWMAksD8JdweMdb1cxHw.text: I'm not a big fan of ramen and this place didn't help change my opinion about it.. Monta is a tiny restaurant tucked in a strip mall that seats about 25-30 people.. They serve ramen with a choice between 4 different broths and every bowl comes with char-su, mushroom, and green onion.. There are other options that you can add to your noodles for an additional cost too.. The broth was thick and a yellow-milky color which wasn't the best for drinking and the noodles didn't have any distinction that would make them "the best" ramen.. We also tried their regular fried rice and that was probably the only thing everyone enjoyed and would come back for again.. But as for the ramen I think I'll pass!

yzVOfj2oP0uAhhjTl4qx9A.text: Gone are the days of associating ramen with my poor college days. Sad to admit but I have only had the processed packaged type of ramen until my friend turned me on to Monta Noodle House. To even mention Monta's ramen in the same sentence as Top Ramen or Cup O' Noodles is blasphemous.   I ordered the Tonkatsu Ramen which I believe is their most popular dish. The broth is thick, cloudy, and jam packed with flavor. The noodles were perfectly cooked and tasted like they were made fresh onsite. There were a few slivers of pork and I added a soft boiled egg. My husband got the combination Tonkatsu and Shoya and it was just as yummy as my dish. It is interesting how many variations there are of ramen and how adding one ingredient changes the whole dish.   Monta really is a hole in the wall restaurant because it could easily be missed in the shopping center. The restaurant is tiny so it is not recommended for large groups. This is a sit down, order, slurp up, and leave type of joint. I'm not sure if I'd frequent this place in the hot summer months but it definitely hits the spot when you want some warmth in your tummy.

E1P4yy1K1c0KRE_uwrggLg.text: THE best Ramen in Las Vegas!!! I never really cared fkr ramen until I has Monta. There may be a bit of a wait to get in but I find lunch is very easy to get into....but it is definitely worth the wait!!! I get the spicy tonkatsu shoyu ramen with a side if kimchi and egg. The kimchi fried rice is out of this world. The staff is so nice and the food flys out if the kitchen. I eat Monta at least once a week it's so addicting!

FCLVh28VJlM1vciNf75-bA.text: So far the best ramen I've tasted in las Vegas.  Shoyu-tonk ramen is my favorite.  I've tried all four broth flavors and I always order the shoyu-tonk.  The fried rice is good too.

4wq84l_Wl5BcVcRGPuzRkw.text: This place is great, smaller restaurant but it too has a very Japanese feel.  Not by a bunch of bought Japanese decor just by atmosphere, steaming pots of broth and cooks in plan sight getting your order ready.  Simple condiments, no extra American or generic Asian stuff but authentic to a noodle house.    Reminds me of living in Japan.

cRw3mdz6xcJMGpRqjKsB1w.text: I have been going to a lot of ramen places lately, looking for the best ones.  Some have been amazing, some not so much.  This place was sort of in the middle.  It's very small, which is appropriate for a ramen shop.  Our party of three waited for about half an hour for a table on a Friday around noon, which was to be expected.  We were seated at the bar, which has a nice little shelf underneath to put your purses on.  =)  I ordered the miso ramen and added boiled egg (nitamago).  The first few bites I thought were delicious.  Then the saltiness became a little too much for me.  I couldn't eat it all, and took about half of it home in a to-go container.  I had the rest the next day, and again, it was tasty but way too salty.  And I usually love salt.  I still ate it though.  Someone else in my party ordered the kuro ramen and loved it.  I'd go back, but maybe try a different flavor.

TOPqzgFD9M3QjFu1CLeAmw.text: Yep, visited only a couple of days later for lunch with co-workers.   We all had to be there before it opened at 11:30 or else we'd never have enough to eat.  There was a line before it opened and there were always at least a few people who had to wait either at the entrance way or outside at all times.  Also important, your whole party has to be there or you won't be seated.  And yes, yet again the tonkotsu impressed.  I love it!  And this time I ordered the extra chashu.  That meat in that delicious broth is just perfect.  Maybe one day I'll be compelled enough to order at refill for less than two bucks, but trust me when I say that one bowl is perfect and hits me in the right spot.  This might become a regular stop for lunch, of course provided I get there early enough.

YPssjBDBmQ7EihCRjNgkqw.text: It's on my monthly must have menu.   Tonkotsu Ramen is the best out of the 3 ramen selections on the menu imo.   Creamy savory broth, perfectly cooked noodle and the tender Chashu (Pork) make it very addictive.  This is not something you can cook at home.  The pork has the perfect amount of fat makes the Ramen rich and flavorful without being greasy.  You can tell it takes a lot of time and effort to prepare the pork.
