Their other side dishes (Fried Rice, Gyoza, Pork belly...) are all very delicious as well.  Service was ok and bareable as most of the small scale Asian restaurants.   The downside of the restaurant: --The broth is a bit saltier than I'd prefer. --I'd prefer more Chashu (pork) pieces per Ramen order for the price they're charging --Sometimes they run out of extra Chashu. --It's always hot in there.  They need to invest some money in AC. --I felt like I was being ripped off a little when I went there the first time because it seems a little overpriced for the portion and the ingredients.  However, now I'm totally addicted and have no choice cause it's very yummy and they don't have many competitions.

Gj1VLwZk_hOb-1hRvmQONA.text: This is a great little place for noodles at their best. I love the fact that they are small in menu, size and price. I always make sure to order my noodles with a nice glass of beer to bring out all the great flavors out. This noodle house is the best in town and I will recommend this place over and over again. Enjoy

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

rjwKuyH5XR_8qfdgUY9Qmg.text: I've now had all three types of ramen and the shoyu is my favorite.  I tried this one last because I was expecting it to be very salty; that was not the case.  It's a bit saltier than the miso and tonkotsu versions, but at the same time it also had the most pork flavor, making for a delicious combo with the chashu.  I really want to give this place five stars because I'm now a Monta Ramen addict, but like I said in my earlier review I'm not very experienced with ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Special Menu item added in November 2010; not sure if it&#39;s permanent.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen

T6oVChKUmIlPeym3eiYLeA.text: Best Japanese Ramen I've ever had! The pork is perfectly marinated.   Try the pork flavored ramen with hard boiled eggs (must) and corn. I like to have a side dish of kim-chi on the side also.

WjQp7m6rDnNCJjJgfPFa9Q.text: The ramen here is just 5 star perfect, flavors are delicate and unique, Gyoza is perfect too. Usually packed to the max, waitress is super rude with some BS attitude, wonder where it came from. Wish they were friendlier, would make this place a 5 star.

SfT7m-PYHWfEr4pnoHEJlg.text: "Got Ramen?"  My life has never been the same ever since I became lactose-intolerant. I've tried to substitute with soy milk to no avail. Now thanks to Monta, I can drink Tonkatsu broth all-day to get my nutrients! Yes, Tonkatsu broth, rich, creamy pork marrow. Served with slow roasted pork in pork fat. Topped with green onions. I wish I drank this growing up, I would have been 6 foot-tall and playing in the NBA. Instead, I'm short and pull people's teeth for a living.   My one complaint, turn up the AC yo! It is HOT! I was sweating more than the pig I just ate. I was sweating like a hooker in church. Like junkie in withdrawal. Like Clinton next to an intern. Like a blonde reading a math book. Seriously Chuck Norris would complain that it's hot in there..

hgw6Rj5sTYup_az5dNwTig.text: I have been hearing great things about this place. So finally my boyfriend and I decided to try it. The weather wasn't too hot and I was craving ramen. I had seen other reviews about there being no AC and that got me worried. But it turned out to not be too bad.  I like how the restaurant is very simple and the menu isn't extensive. That's a good sign that the few things on the menu are done well.  We both ordered the tonkotsu ramen and an extra order of chashu (4 more pieces). The broth was deeelish. And I was so glad we ordered the extra chashu. It was flavorful and so tender. And the noodles were just right.  We will be coming back here again and again, to try the different broths and toppings. I can't wait!

7A6934ZKqGbQIzDI7p_srQ.text: Man, oh man!  The Tonkatsu ramen was sooooo goood!  It was a cool day in Las Vegas and what better way to warm up than with a big bowl of ramen.  Very tasty rich broth.  The ramen noodles was cooked al dente.  The pork slices were actually slices of belly pork and when you touched it, it kind of melts into the broth!  Oooooh, delicious!  I had my ramen with the boiled egg.  There were condiments on the table and I put some of that pureed garlic into my soup to give it an extra garlic kick!    We also ordered one fried rice and a gyoza appetizer.  Yummy!  All items gold stars!    The restaurant is tiny with 4 tables of 4 and 1 table of 2 and a L-shaped  bar counter, facing the open kitchen.  You can watch the cooks make the ramen in front of you.  The wait staff are all very polite.  Turnover is fast as people come and go all the time we were at the restaurant for lunch today.  Definitely will come back to Monta Noodle House!

9YkKlJCPIN6cgk1rnmifBg.text: On my first visit to the Monta (Ellis) Noodle House I had an inclination that it was worthy of four sexy stars. After eating here, I'm quite certain of that.  Your not going to drive past it on Spring Mountain in case you think you missed it because it's all the way in the back of the plaza.    If your a Rameniac like myself.  This place is the new kid on the block and a must-try.  We know Las Vegas isn't exactly a hot-bed for ramen but Monta meets my needs.  The Miso Ramen was delicious, it's probably one of the best in town. we waited 15 minutes, but definitely worth the wait. although many have first timers have said it wasn't worth.  Monta wouldn't stand a chance vs. some ramen spots I frequent in the Bay Area. But all of my friends and they were all asian said it couldn't be better.  The kikurage was yummy as well.  But stay away from the specials like the Kim-Chi Fried Rice.  But who the hell goes to a ramen house for fried rice?  Duh!

K1I19JVCLoXnQYldiZRMSw.text: This place is not too hard to find and there are plenty of parking spaces with other restaurants around. If you're feeling ramen, this is (so far), the best place. Growing up in Japan, ramen has been the comfort food for me whenever I'm out and about with family, friends, or by myself. I only knew of 2 other locations here in Vegas when I used to live here and since I left and came back, this popped out of nowhere and it blew me away. Their ramen is perfect. From the texture of the noodles, the amount they serve and the flavor of the broth, it's just perfect. It's also the first time I've been to a ramen shop where you can choose exactly what type of toppings you want. I chose eggs, nori, and pork. The pork and the egg definitely is the perfect toppings I've ever tasted on ramen. The amount of fat and the flavor of the pork was magnificent. The egg was just perfect where the yolk had a creamy texture in the center and the whites had a slight salty flavor to it that just blew me away and mixed very well with the broth (I had the Tonkatsu broth). As for the restaurant itself, It's clean inside. It has a mom and pop feel so it didn't feel fully sterile like an apple store would which I don't mind. It felt very home-e. I felt like I was really in Japan, minus the radio blasting in the background. I think I heard One Direction and some other pop music play. It shouldn't bother you though if you love/hate it because trust me, the ramen will be so good you're not gonna care. Customer service was really fast. I walked in and was greeted and seated right away. I ordered and I'd say 3 or 4 minutes later, I get my bowl. Once I finished my water, (BAM!) refilled. Portions I'd say is just right. They give you enough where you don't end up wasting anything, but I'm just so used to getting gigantic bowls of ramen that I was actually bummed how perfectly proportioned it was! Is that weird? Over all, I give this place a 5 out of 5, I can't wait to eat here again (for ramen that is). I haven't tried the others stuff they offer on the menu, but if ramen is what you're looking for, then look no farther. This. Is. THE. Place.   Location: 4/5 Cleanliness: 4/5 Customer Service: 5/5 Time: 5/5 Portions: 4/5 Taste: 5/5 27/30 =90%

6yObwKvP7MyKe_9SQ3v-kQ.text: A great spot and my favorite ramen of all, I consider my self a ramen connoisseur ish And I've tried a number of spots but this place gotta be the top.

4eUofgMD87Uwp5X-oLYNSA.text: Amazing food, it does get busy but it is super worth it. I had the miso which I loved. Service was prompt and friendly.

Ukqzhpj8Uy3NCdIW-g1oIQ.text: I found out about Monta ramen at a ramen festival in Torrance but the line was so dang long that I wasn't able to check out. Fast forward a few years and I'm finally able to experience their Kura Ramen at the real Las Vegas location,which is very tiny so large groups aren't recommended. The intimate restaurant reminded me of some ramen places in Japan except they didn't have the vending machine to place your ramen order here.   I really enjoyed their Kura Black Ramen. The broth was very silky and light which I prefer over the thicker broth unless it's cold as hell outside. The garlic chili oil was a very nice touch. The pork was one of the most tender pieces that I've tried in ramen. The pork broke apart so quickly. I was a bit surprised.   I also have to go with my usual pairing of ramen with Gyoza. The wrapping was very thin and the inside was very juicy. What's not to like?

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kurt Black Ramen

gAJNu8154ifRwvH3tbg7SA.text: Delicious!!!! Very quaint and intimate but busy on a Friday night. The Kuro Black Garlic Oil ramen is the best!  Make it spicy. Our server, Brenda took care of that for me!  Great atmosphere.

3DPy7uElPIMvep5laQsi5Q.text: I've came here many times before with my family, and I did enjoy the times before here. Only this time, I came with my little sister, and my boyfriend (All of us are under 18) and we wanted to take a bite of some ramen. I put my name under the waiting list, and the hostess was SUPER unprofessional and didn't even greet us or announce our party group, and we had to seat ourselves. After that, we ordered our food and they took MORE time than average. Knowing this restaurant from past visits, it does NOT take more than 5 minutes for them to prepare food. And we didn't even order a lot! We all watched older adults getting their food that were there after us, and received their food BEFORE us. From my experience with this restaurant, me and my family never had to wait 30 MINUTES TO RECEIVE FOOD. It was absolutely ridiculous. Our waiter kept coming back to us if we needed any help. Yeah, we're absolutely starving and we barely had any updates. I get that the waiters were doing their jobs, but informing us that our food is almost ready and that takes another 15 minutes, I lost it completely. The absolute worst part was the end when we finished. I was charged from my card MORE than I should have paid. They took $7 extra when I didn't authorize it. These guys are CROOKS. They took advantage of us and didn't treat us as average customers. I don't know if it's because we're under than 18? They should not back down. I'm SUPER disappointed as this place was my favorite restaurant before.

PA_tT_hVJ9c8jRMIFVBMcw.text: First night in LV and my first meal had to be at one of my favorites, Monta Ramen. Worth the 30 min wait for a steaming bowl of Tonkatsu ramen. The broth is decadent and savory and the noodles were nice and chewy. I love the textures; the crunch from bamboo and wood ear mushrooms, soft chewy noodles, and pork that melts in your mouth. There's a variety of sauces and spices to jazz it up: sesame seeds,  garlic, chili seasoning, vinegar, and soy sauce.  It's a quick Uber ride from the Strip. It's a local's favorite that is a must stop for a foodie experience. Definitely add to your list if you're ever in Vegas!

HQ3QsAmizma-FTECCqe_2Q.text: It was cheap, it was too salty, and they forgot my fried rice order. We had already finished our ramen and the fried rice still hadn't come so we cancelled it. Table next to us got their fried rice the same time their ramen got to the table. Waiter made up some B.S. excuse about the kitchen being backed up. If that was True, then why did the ramen come out so fast and why did the table next to us (who sat down AFTER us) get their fried rice before we did. Aside from the fact that it was cheap and decent ramen, there isn't much to this place.

Gg0SPa0wReccCbuCTs8T5Q.text: Delicious ramen all the time.. High wait time.. Space is soo tiny you feel like your sitting on top of the next person.. Service is okay.. I come just for my ramen!! Yummy!!

jcQbaKh1bqTsfd2YfwV8Xg.text: Amazing Ramen, service is super quick!  Write your name and guest count when you arrive and they will get you a seat, food comes fast, hot and delicious, servers are super quick, bill came before we even asked!

mEnJxW0vEPmMzLJSWyFU_Q.text: I love this place!! Best Tonkatsu ramen Ever!!! I go here as often as possible!!! Definitely worth trying and very reasonably priced.

ua2s9pDLchnY0rJCZnkswg.text: Looking for authentic ramen??? This is the place!!! They serve some bomb ramen that I've been looking for here in Nevada.  The location is near my favorite Korean BBQ place Hwaro so parking is limited.  I did come here on a Wednesday night at around 9pm so there was some parking. The wait for 2 was about 10 minutes.    The restaurant is really small which you know it's authentic because Japanese ramen bars are very small.  Its usually a eat and go kind of thing.  The menu is very simple.  There's a few ramen choices, add on toppings, and sides such as fried rice or gyoza.  Average price for a bowl of ramen is about $8.  I got the black garlic ramen because garlic is my favorite.  The broth is more on the rich and creamy side compared to a shoyu broth.  I switched my noodles to the thick noodles because I had thin the night before.  I also got the fried rice which would probably taste better with meat.  I had to remove the chashu because I don't eat meat.  Food wait was about 5 minutes.  I was not mad at all.  There are condiments you c ask for such as sesame seeds, vinegar, etc... I wanted to go here tonight but sadly I have no one to go with.  I recommend this place to anyone who loves ramen.  Tip: not great for big parties.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

92x4wxZF1lNXaHew7mOPfw.text: I solely came here because this place had great Yelp reviews. I wasn't as impressed as I expected to be. The majority of the reviews state this is one of the best spots for ramen, but I found the ramen to be mediocre.   We got there about 15 minutes before they opened and there was already a line of about eight people waiting outside. When we got in, I realized the long wait times everyone was talking about was due to the fact that the restaurant is tiny. There is very limited seating.   I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen and my boyfriend ordered the Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen. Both were okay. It wasn't bad but it just wasn't the best ramen I've ever had, considering we have many options in LA. We also ordered the Gyoza, which was actually good. She allowed us to order it extra crispy which was nice. The price for the ramen was decent. You pay about $6.95 for the basic ramen that includes a small amount of pork chashu. You can add extra toppings, such as more pork chashu, egg, corn, nori, and kimchi for a little bit more.   Overall, the ramen was average. I'm glad we didn't have to wait long for table because it would not have been worth a long wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu - Shoyu Ramen

bxnsRKYA9nK7_qtw0u0uOQ.text: Awesome food, the soup is really close to ones I've had in Japan! Service is awesome too. The only thing is that you've gotta really hang in there while waiting for your turn to seat down as the wait can take as long as almost 45mins on peak timing. It's about 15 to 20mins on off peaks timings. Despite the long waiting time, you'll never have to wait for more than 10mins for your ramen to be in your table! Worth it babes!

xGVfABTQICh7enf7fy9Y6A.text: Okay, so here's the skinny:  Monta ramen is not only some of the cheapest ramen (in price), but it is the quickest too! They have superior service, that's quite lightning fast! Usually I order the extra noodles because most ramen restaurants give you very little noodle, so me and my bf paid the extra 1.50 for more noodles. Well, they give you an extra POUND of noodles just to put in your already full ramen! That's almost 2 pounds of noodles. geeze!  The taste is quite good, and the basic order gives you two pieces of pork, which are delicious.   I HIGHLY suggest going out there and giving it a shot! Great place :)

T1ZoDsNEk4jQ8gwF46P9xw.text: Forget the Strip. The good food with great deals is off the Strip. That's where all the foodies should go! My bf and I were super hungry and we were really pleased with the variety and prices of the items on the menu. You have the option of eating at the bar or at the table, but we opted to sit at the tables instead.  We ordered:  1) Gyoza - Yummy and delicious! Dip it in some vinegar and soy sauce and you're good to go! (5/5)  2) Pork Belly Bowl - We got a small bowl to share and OHMYGERD IT'S SO GOOD. Definitely try this. You'll have a hard time sharing it so just get a bowl for yourself haha (5/5)  3) Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen - Broth was flavorful and noodles were good too. Just be aware that basic toppings come with just mushroom, bamboo and pork chashu with green onions. If you want an egg, you'll need to pay extra. (5/5)  4) Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil - I love the broth! The black garlic was oh so yummy. The noodles were cooked perfectly, texture was great. What I especially like about both our ramen bowls was the quality of the chashu. It literally MELTS IN YOUR MOUTH. (5/5)  Overall, we were really surprised with the amount of food we ate and what a great deal it was! Service is great too, credit cards accepted. Parking can be okay. Would definitely come here again!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1a9V1BM_8qdPOloQrYD2wQ.text: Super savory  Attentive servers Fast service  Clean Loved it! :) Excellent price  But music Too loud :/

bRJcVTEUy3JP4mpkgZLPwA.text: Had high hopes for this place after having friends recommend it as the closest thing to LA ramen in LV... not quite.  Drive off strip just for the Tonkotsu and although it was good, Jinya beats it which is a above average ramen place. Definitely not as good as the ramen I had in LA but the hole in the wall look of the place had its appeal. Food was good and a nice break from high prices on the strip.   I noticed they had oolong tea so I assumed it may be Chinese owned and so I asked for a Tsingtao (one of my favorite beers) and the waitress said "This a Japanese restaurant, no Chinese beer . " To which I replied "...but you have oolong tea on the menu ..." She couldn't help but smirk and smile

9SB1B216GGvTIg8Cfz4ssg.text: Best priced beers, amazing ramen,  fast and awesome service.  You couldn't ask for better!

FtfnBDf5_R8cJ8qDSr39ow.text: This place is small but the chef knows how to make the ramen taste delicious. It gets packed from time to time but it is worth the wait. Craving for some ramen? This is the place to go.

a3ufXqeaDwR_Iasv6dIHCQ.text: Best Ramen I've had in a long time. When a couple of my friends heard that I was going to Las Vegas, the first thing they told me to visit was Monta Ramen... not a club or some fancy restaurant, this place... and I see why.   The place is small simple and quaint. Went here for a late lunch (about 2:30pm) on a weekday so it wasn't busy and were promptly served. I ordered the Black Garlic Oil Ramen and not even 10 minutes later, got my food. The ramen and the pork in it had the perfect balance of richness, fattiness and saltiness and was definitely the best I've had in years.   It does get busy in the evening, especially because the place is small (I tried coming back later in the week). So I do suggest coming early. Other than that the only disappointing thing is that it's in Vegas. Definitely going to come back next time I'm in town.  Favorite: Black Garlic Oil Ramen

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black Garlic Oil Ramen! So good.

JZnkuvdAZFyOFamRCU9Q-A.text: I've been Tokyo and had ramen there. This place is definitely authentic. I had the Tonkostu Ramen, which was fatty and rich in flavor like a ramen broth is supposed to be. I added NiTamago (2 eggs) and Seaweed... absolute perfection! The eggs were golden brown with a creamy yolk (shut up!!!), I definitely recommend this place. Worth leaving the strip for a night and you bet it's worth your dollars!

yztiPp67h1zwQowMv7pXnA.text: Decent ramen! Definitely better from the ones we have at home but doesn't quite beat the ramen we've had around LA. I got the spicy miso ramen and the mister got the regular miso ramen. We ordered the pork belly bowl to go along with our meal.  The pork belly bowl had a lot of flavor but the rice wasn't really great. I'm very picky with my rice so I found the rice to be a bit too hard for my liking. The spicy miso ramen was good!! It had lots of flavor and the spicy gave it a nice kick. The cha SJ was tastyy.  Even as a packed house, we got to be seated in less than 5 minutes. Got our order taken, our food out in about another 5 minutes, and were in and out of the restaurant in las than 30 minutes!! That's what I call efficient and delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dcgIO7q8u6Am6gJUxPx1XQ.text: Fast friendly staff. Great Ramen. I've tried them all and you'd be happy with whatever you choose. A must go if in Vegas.

f2iV66rwDgNJc20e380VaQ.text: The ramen here is absolutely amazing. This was my first ramen place when I first moved to Las Vegas. Its a very small place but the wait is worth it. You simply write your name down and wait (just like most places). Be sure to stick around so you can hear your name be called.  Upon sitting down, we were served our waters at least within 1-2min; that's always a great sign! I tried their fried rice as a small appetizer. Even their fried rice was delicious.   The prices here are very fair. Theres a variety of flavors to choose from. Miso, tonkotsu, shoyu  and even cold noodles.  You can add shredded onions, seaweed, egg, kimchi on the side and a multitude of other add ons. I ordered the tonkotsu with shredded onions, the seaweed and an egg!   The broth was creamy, milky, the right flavors blended together. It was slightly salty but just add more toppings to soak up all that flavor! The noodles itself were a fine consistency. It wasnt soggy nor was it too chewy.   The only thing missing is a bigger space! It gets quite crammed in there. Sometimes sitting two people in an area you'd typically sit one. Ill be coming back over and over again.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

6BWzsoA9oPvBFXbxmpCw_Q.text: I really enjoyed my Tonkatsu Ramen!  It's a small ramen place and everytime I'll stop by to check them out there's always a line and I'm so glad that day it wasn't that crowded.  I always get Tonkatsu Ramen in every Ramen places I go to. That way I can be able to compare the broth, noodles, chatsu and eggs.   I really like their tonkatsu broth and noodles. I was just a little disappointed on how my eggs turned out---it's close to being a hard boiled egg. I really like mine, soft boiled egg! Maybe, I just assume that all ramen egg is soft boiled.   But overall, it was a treat to try out Monta Noodle House. Service was great, and if you are craving for some Ramen---it will definitely it that spot!

1kjsujT2QF-wLYdeJXLwYw.text: The BEST RAMEN I HAVE EVER HAD!!! Perfect for a cold day and to just eat something warm is great. The food is really good and the Miso ramen is very good. It's my personal favorite. The staff is really nice and the food is super quick and delicious.

gkNV6jhzuN7PKiewpT1SBw.text: We were the first customers, and when we went in, we were welcomed and greeted. The waiters and waitresses were very nice!!  I ordered the Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen ($6.95) which was sooo good, especially at such a low price! I think this is one of the best ramen places I've eaten at!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen ($6.95)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

0YBvIWaLthId0PaZygR4_w.text: Been here 3 times- first two visits, ramen were spot on. My go-to is the black garlic oil ramen. Third time eating here, the broth was too salty for some reason.

qjcM2mzGS5u05S-Zal3GOA.text: We went here right after we got to Vegas and also it was lunch time. The wait for a table took like 15 minutes or so. This place is located in Chinatown in a plaza. The restaurant is very small like restaurant in Japan. I ordered spicy miso ramen and added eggs and corn. I also ordered Kim chi fried rice while my friends ordered ramen and gyoza. The ramen I had was delicious and tasty. I wish it was more spicer since I like eating spicy. The Kimchi fried rice was good and flavorful. Also the fried rice is not oily at all and well cooked. The gyoza was good and taste good when it dipped with soy sauce. The services was great and attentive. They often checked on us and refilled our water. The parking can be packed so you might have to wait for parking. This place is an option if you don't want to eat on the strip. I would come back here if I'm in the area.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

J-s5WghjOdpP1LJLoafv-g.text: So, I decided to come back and give this place another change to live up to the hype but it just did not do it for me.   Again, we got lucky and did not have to wait a ridiculous long line . Our server lacked customer service and had no personality. I knew what I wanted so we ordered right away. I had their Spicy Tonkotsu with corn. Broth was not as thick as last time but it was not spicy at all. When I asked for hot sauce, they said they did not have any besides the chilly powder on the table and if I wanted chilly paste I would have to pay extra for it (wow). We got two sides, one was the Pork Belly bowl and Gyoza (pot stickers). Pork belly was delicious and the pot stickers were okay.   My overall experience was nothing special. I honestly like Sora better than this place. Unless I am craving the Pork belly bowl or drunk, I will not be returning.

6VfgPg1jObivv3pVG-65pg.text: Wow, I'm really sad that I have to update my review of Monta to a one star, but I think that this drastic difference is a testament to how horrible our experience was. I'm majoring in English at school right now so I hate having to write anything longer than a paragraph, but this experience was horrible enough that I'm taking my break off school to document this.   We were waited by someone named Brenda who was both incredibly rude and unhelpful - her service tainted our entire experience. I'm a huge believer in tipping, but our entire party was so disappointed with her service that many of us did not want to tip; the only reason why we did was because of Wei, another waiter.  While Monta as a ramen shop is still pretty good, there are so many other places with way better service that I don't think I'll be coming back ever again, which sucks because Monta was always my go-to spot to bring my few friends (ok I don't have a lot of friends so i guess my service won't hurt them that badly but whatever i'm still not going there ever again).   First of all, we put our name down at around 5PM, and like usual, it was incredibly busy. We didn't hear our name get called because it around 30 degrees outside, and there were no places to wait indoors so we were waiting somewhere else. Finally, when we went back to check, she said, "Sorry, I called your name TWO times outside, and ONCE inside and you didn't come so. It's not fair to the other people who have been waiting (??? ok it's not like we weren't waiting either) so idk, let me know what you want to do." The "what" was very ambiguous as she did not inform us "what" our options were, so eventually I asked if our new place on the list was at the bottom of the line, in which case we would go somewhere else. She said no, that our party would follow after a few more parties because "it wasn't fair" (honestly I'm not sure if fair was used correctly in this interaction because i don't believe that this was in line with the "rules" of Monta and waiting in 30 degree weather) but I was mad hungry so we were like okay whatever and decided to just wait.   We waited around ten more minutes, and finally, she called my name and led us to the bar area. I asked her if we could wait for a table (this was a party of five, and we were so looking forward to talking to each other and catching up), and she said, "No, it's not fair to the other people who have been waiting (again confused because it's not like we weren't waiting and it was dumb cold outside), so you will have to sit here." Which I mean I GUESS I could see her reasoning, but also, she should have told us that we would all be forced to sit at the bar esp because there were FIVE of us trying to have a conversation and we had been waiting an hour at that point. If she had told us that we would be forced to sit at the bar, we definitely would have gone someplace else. SO I don't think it was "FAIR" that she wasn't forthcoming about our seating.   And then secondly, while I was eating, one of the workers knocked over a bunch of the plates into my table and splashed me with the water and soup. And I would have been more whatever with it except for the fact that no one apologized or cleared the plates. So i ... cleared the plates ... for the workers .... who tipped and splashed me with dirty water .... That doesn't seem very FAIR either!  And then to wrap it all up, after I asked for the check (this part is important keep reading and keep this in mind) after no one was really attending to our bar area, Brenda came over and asked if we were done because "as you can see, there are a lot of people waiting so," (the other part was important because yes there were a lot of people but if there were then why weren't you trying to wait on our table more instead of rushing us out of the bar area after I had to ask for the check), my friends and I all left very unhappy and annoyed.  So overall, wouldn't recommend Monta; there are so many other places you can go with a better waiting system and way better service.

BKTKg0kIcVgtrQXk_PHquA.text: First off, this place was _crowded_! It's in the Chinatown area with tons of other places that look the same from the outside, yet everyone was huddled around Monta Ramen. My girlfriend and I figured that that meant something, so we gave it a go.  I thought it was good. To be honest, I don't think I have the most distinguishing tongue when it comes to ramen. I've eaten at probably five or six ramen places in my life, and each one has tasted similarly good to me. Monta didn't necessarily stand out as particularly good. But it was still good.  Prices were normal. Ramens started at $7 and then a few bucks more for add ons of your choice.  Portions were a bit on the large side. Service was a bit friendlier than average.  One gripe: I really hate walking in to a place and seeing a huge "WE RESERVE THE RIGHT TO REFUSE SERVICE..." sign as my welcoming. Kind of a put-off.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Long wait! (About 20 minutes; the place is really small though, seats maybe 15-20 people)
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Add ons
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu Ramen

Qx7Cahn6p-XiD9xUJBRFAw.text: Yes! Some really good ramen. I counted the number of seats and end number was 27. This explains why the wait can be long but that didn't stop me. Parking was a pain, had to circle a couple of times to finally find a spot. I walked in and wrote my name on the piece of paper (party of ONE!).  I saw a stool by it's lonesome at the bar top area but didn't want to intrude since there we're 15ish ppl ahead of me (but I was a party of one?!)  anywho once the server came to her senses, I was seated at the aforementioned stool and I ordered the Tokontsu ramen and added egg. It comes with two pieces of pork which was just enough with the egg.   The temp of the broth was Luke warm, the noodles were what made the dish warm:so pretty much the perfect temp for you to slurp down the bowl as fast as possible so they can get you in and out. The egg was pre-cooked or prepped because the yoke was actually cold as if they cooked it before and kept it in the chiller before adding it to the dish.  Overall the ramen was delicious. Not too rich, noodles were a good texture and the pork was tasty! From writing my name down till paying for my check it was about 30mins. Talk about a quick dinner! Don't be a butt and take up a table conversing for a long amount of time.  It's a minimum of $10 to use a credit card so bring cash if you're dining alone. My total was like $9something after tax!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen

7j18N89nPY1zXGKS098mjg.text: Had a good bowl of miso ramen, great value. One thing to knock is I ordered green onions. As a topping and there was too much. Other negative is I got hot tea in a can. Give them a try

si_g2Q2WtqSo4ounog8Xxg.text: BEST RAMEN IN VEGAS. Service is fast and friendly! It's a small seating space and usually packed out the door but is definitely worth the wait!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu - Shoyu Ramen

6zp-nBimi4MDUtQmIvSNzA.text: Don't be deterred by the packed parking lot or tiny restaurant.  All members of your party must be there to be seated.  We went with a party of 8 on a Sunday night.  The place was crowded but after about 15 minutes a table large enough for us opened up just as our second half arrived.  The service is super quick.  Not a lot of options but enough you can satisfy all your cravings.  I opted for the spicy noodles with extra pork, egg and kimchi.  For 4 orders it only took about 10 minutes.  The portions are huge and so tasty.  Everyone gave it a big thumbs up.  I left full to the brink and warmth in my belly.  Oh and the price is killer.

kfsalh2u0Bq6889saBNMuw.text: My daughter and I enjoyed their ramen here.  I didn't want any pork on our ramen so when I asked if we can substitute the pork for more veggies, they said no, we can only order an extra side of veggies.    We got there on a Saturday around 2pm and we waited for about 15 minutes.  The place was small, clean and the waiters just want to serve and turn the tables over.  My daughter ordered the following:  Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen ($7) - The portion was not very big but for $7, it's not bad.  The broth was flavorful and the veggies were cooked perfectly.    I will go again but since there are lots of other ramen places in Las Vegas, I'll try others first.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A little green onion heart my daughter found.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen.  No meat.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen.  No meat.

GUznpSTcUKQfwBkH5iBwXQ.text: As you've probably seen in a lot of the reviews here, Monta Ramen is located in a tiny, heavy-trafficked complex in the Chinatown area in Las Vegas. Parking is almost always a pain, and this location can probably seat a max of 25-30 people at once (hence, the looong lines). With that said, if you are looking for quality, good ramen, I think this one is worth a try.  The most recent time I went, I got the tonkotsu ramen with an egg (had to order this as extra because it's not included in the standard order), and gyoza for an appetizer to share. The pork broth is delicious! Definitely hits the spot. I do wish the bowl came with more meat. You can order extra pork so I may try that next time. The gyoza was honestly just pretty standard and nothing too memorable.  The customer service has been good every time I've gone, and they really try to be efficient and quick to get the lines moving.

e1LWAv0Pr67O_ioi41Upkw.text: Very authentic tasting.... and cheap! Their green tea ice tea is very good. I like the Tomtaksu bowl.  Its a very small restaurant so their is usually a wait but very well worth it.

873AZ8e1pt5tHgv5-DpF6A.text: Monta Ramen is a tiny place that gets very busy so dine here at off hours if you can. Their Spicy Tonkatsu Ramen was absolutely delicious. The broth was rich and flavorful. My only complaint is that the broth needs to be served hotter. My friend and I shared the Kimchee fried rice and it was pleasant. My friend got the Shoyu Ramen and loved it.
