Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork gyosa
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Best ramen in Vegas !

cOEJ33C1YBSOQGfU8-7DCA.text: This place is the best.  Highest quality Ramen at great prices.  It is a small location and it is always packed.  This is a Vegas gem.

1Q5BnGtVNcFWGudhdWb6Kw.text: Get there early, there is always a line and it is well worth the wait. Place is warm and cozy, seats about 20 people like a traditional noodle house. Food is very well priced and you get a lot! Can't go wrong with anything in the menu, rice bowl, noodle bowls or just ramen.

fF6xNhOiojyUpXrv8JPg0w.text: Very good ramen.  I had canned green tea.  There's still no hot green tea but this latest visit I was able to come in and sit.  Last time there were more people waiting outside than actually sitting inside eating.  I had the miso ramen, it was good.  I had extra meat with mine since the last time the two pieces melted in my mouth quickly.  I ordered extra ramen to pour in my bowl.  The broth in the miso ramen isn't as drinkable or downable as the others but I love the flavors of this compared to the shoyu ramen.    Even though the menu is limited, the ramen here is very good.

7C5XpPRvweFKRwA4UsT-Jw.text: I've been to some premium ramen joints in North America (Kintaro in Vancouver BC and Ippudo in NYC), so I definitely came in here with tempered expectations.  In addition to the traditional Japanese greeting by the staff as you come in and an open kitchen view of the chefs preparing the food, what struck me was the significant number of older Japanese business men who had come in with their suits folded against their shoulders on a blistering hot summer day to order a steaming bowl of noodles!  That clued me in this was perhaps the real deal.  Being my first time here, I went with the Tonkatsu ramen, which is ramen in pork broth stewed for several hours.  Bonus points for speed since I could have sworn my entree arrived within 2 minutes from the time I ordered.  Step one is tasting the broth:  the broth was at once unctuous and velvety smooth with intense flavors of marrow and porkified goodness without seeming overtly greasy/oily.    Moving onto the noodles, there should definitely be some spring when you chew on the noodles and these were definitely on par with the other places I've visited with just the right amount of "al dente" and some umami embedded within the noodles themselves.    Finally there's the pork which is marinated in soy and cut paper thin with a thin lining of fat that has condensed into a perfect strip of pork belly perfection that is just right for the creamy broth it is bathed in since any more would cause the pork to loose it's distinct note.  The basic order also includes some bamboo shoots and kikurage (japanese seaweed) and it is a steal of a deal at 6.99, but I think what would have completed my experience was the addition of a few toppings such spring onions or mustard greens (for a few bucks more) to cut through the richness of the broth and add some additional textures and color.  There is also the option to add a hard-boiled egg or to get an extra serving of noodles if you're needing something more substantial.  All in all, definitely an authentic joint that measures up to the greats and will be somewhere I will frequent again and again especially during the colder months.

Ozpexl8-vgR-PMRUlKsS0g.text: WONDERFUL Ramen and Gyoza! Just like in Japan. What can I say. They are the best. Try the Chashu Ramen and the Chahan with Gyoza too if you are hungry! A+A+

K5EfV2o878WXDOGw-Q_QaQ.text: So delicious!  We lived overseas for a few years. My hubby is very particular about his ramen. I'm a picky eater, so I am slightly hard to please.  OMG! This place reminded us of our time overseas. It's tucked away, but once you find it - you've found a gem. The service is amazing! It's quick and friendly. The portions are good and price is budget friendly. This is a must stop when in Vegas.

dom1umJ25t3UuuM02xsoTA.text: Compared to Sora Ramen, I like this much better.  We had the thin noodles and they were al dente. The broth was also thicker and tastier. Try the takana fried rice (with mustard greens). It was also very tasty!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hqzSq6HoLMlvLaVKIMOSCw.text: Great food that is cheap! Only down side is the restaurant itself is so small there's always a really long wait. Worth it though!

-BevmVvidPrY2FqhSBMidw.text: Thank you Yelp!!! After a disasterous meal at Ichiza the night before, Monta was a refreshing change.  The ramen bowls aren't super huge but the food is delicious! I ordered the hiyashi chuka special on the board (cold noodles) with ponzu sauce and no mustard. The noodles were deliciously chewy and the dressing hit the spot. It came with a large portion of shredded egg omelette, cucumbers, tomatoes, and their awesome chasu.  We also had the pork belly bowl to share and it was awesome! The pork was tender and juicy.   Tonkotsu ramen had broth that had good depth.  Come here early or you'll have to wait since the tables and seats are very limited!

rm2T4oVarAJKW5LYQHfOsQ.text: Pretty good! Prices are reasonable and the quantity given is also good. Fast service, nice servers and food comes fast. This place is always crowded so you eat and you go. I come here often and I always enjoy it. I hope they expand their joint so more people can go and eat. Overall, its a must-try!

lxQTihoFTwkPkGFjPyBk_g.text: 1-5 scale  Service: 4 Cleaningness: 3.5 Food Quality: 3.5  I've tried a lot of ramen places and I'm simply comparing to the places we have available in Vancouver (which has a lot of good ramen joints).  The staff is very friendly and service was fast.  We had to come back a second time because the wait was so long the first time and lucked out with no wait the second time.  Despite the 3 star rating, the food is good, but based on my past experiences is certainly not worth an hour wait.  The portions are good and the soup is rich (almost too salty for me) -- had the miso ramen.  Overall, would recommend if there is a 15min or less wait.

ywc9JFWD_O_-eP1Zab53Hw.text: We always come here for the best ramen when in Vegas, never disappoints and always satisfied. This place is totally worth the wait. Thanks again Monta Ramen!

UbZUXDcOmZPzM6DFNKKJ1A.text: I always come here for their delicious Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen & their pork belly bowl! Affordable pricing, great quality food, & the place is quite clean. Also, it can be quite busy during the weekends so if you plan to go, expect somewhat of a wait (15-30 min.) My boyfriend & I usually try to head there around 7pm to beat the foot traffic! Also, once your seated they quickly grab what you want to drink and take your order once your drinks arrive. Quick, efficient and you leave with a full belly! Lastly, they do take out!

9hMCAshg3oTDkCIW9D7SOQ.text: I had the opportunity to try out Monta Ramen based on a recomendation from a co-worker.  This place is very small and tucked away in a strip mall on Spring Mt Chinatown.  I think there is table seating for 16 inside, plus another 8 or so at the bar.  I tried to time it so I wouldn't have to wait as I've heard there can be a long line to get in.  Got here at about 6:30 pm and was able to get a seat right away at the bar.  Ordered a Shoyu ramen with extra pork and egg.  Even though my friend recommended the kimchee fried rice I was here to sample the ramen.    The ramen came out pretty quick, noodles were nice and crisp and the broth was clean and not too salty as others have said.  The pork was sliced very thing, but it was very flavorful and melt in your mouth delicious.  The egg was also very good, rivaling the egg here in San Diego at Yakiyudori.    Overall a very good bowl of ramen in Sin City.  4 Stars!

hShdsfJKMhdANaHukB_I5A.text: Coming from Japan, I can attest to the authenticity of the ramen served here.  The flavor of the soup was so rich and delicious, it was truly a treat to get to eat here.  Probably one of the best ramen I've ever ate!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The tonkotsu ramen is a winner!

7hQorjZB6_PFLuPZcPJ9QA.text: Was visiting Vegas and always on the lookout for good food.  That's why I'm on yelp, duh.  Was in the mood to try something different.  Saw the write up for Monta and checked yelp to confirm and it was one of my first spots.    I flew in on Wednesday and decided that this was the night.  Got here a little early and luckily was seated right away at the counter.  Service was good they quickly took my order and I had a front row seat watching them prepare all of the goodness that they do.    Started off with the Goyza and it was pretty good. The filling could have had a little more spice to it but it did the trick.  For the main I had the Tonkotsu Ramen with extra pork.  The portion was a good size and the extra pork was a nice addition.  I added some spicy sauce to give it a little more of a kick but it was quality.   One thing that I thought was odd was the green ice tea came in a can. Never seen that before but it was good.  I prefer fresh brewed but that would be the only downside to the visit.   Great place to go for good Ramen. Enjoy

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Green tea
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Gyoza

45xUZr-zDekgP0M7a8JUBA.text: First ramen experience here in LV and it already beats the average ramen in the bay. And to add insult to injury, their ramen are only $8!! Can you believe this??  Spicy Tonkatsu: I wasnt expecting much from the broth, but oh my goodness did it have some depth to it. I was diving 20,000 leagues under the broth. It wasnt heavy, but it had so much flavor. The noodles were okay and the chashu held its own, but the broth was clearly the star of the show. I only wish I didnt get it spicy because the spice wasnt doing the broth justice and just made the soup too salty. 4/5.  Black Garlic: Broth was a bit too salty for my liking. Flavor was good overall. 3/5.  Fried Rice: Very standard fried rice. The chashu needed more flavor to carry the dish though. 3.5/5.  Pork Belly Bowl: Okay, this was probably my favorite thing here. The bork was so soft, but had just the right amount of flavor to it and wasnt tough whatsoever. Make sure to add some hot oil or some of you broth to the bowl (you're welcome). 5/5.  2 ramens and 2 mini rice bowls only came out to $30 after tax and tip. You're paying that much for almost one bowl at stupid ass ramen dojo in the bay area.   You definitely get your money's worth here. If you are from the bay, give this place a try. You will understand what I mean.

Z2ccjAxKIBPYcMMm_I836A.text: The food was good (: the place itself is very small, tooo crowded. Service was fast and friendly

fgqNumfbMbO3HHN48qDNpQ.text: I wanted so bad to give this spot 5 stars but in my eyes they committed a sin.  My Egg and my Chashu were cold .   OTHER THAN THAT . God damn the ramen was delicious. I had miso broth, increible. My wife had the tonkotsu broth and she loved it.  The noodles were some of my favorite noodles I've ever had.   A humble spot far away from the glitz and glamour and facade far away from Las Vegas. A great experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_GEadVwtlK_--fXomuZXQQ.text: The tonkostu base was excellent. All the noodles my family and I had ordered were delicious and made with the right texture. The only this I have to complain about is gyozas. Not only were they way burnt, but they were also all stuck together. They were also placed with the burnt bottom facing up as if they were just thrown on the plate.

lZQsratBzhAc2erodh9rNg.text: Excellent ramen. Tonkatsu is the dish I always aim to order but EVERYTHING is good. Best to Uber/Lyft because parking is a PITA. If you crave authentic Japanese, this is the place. One of my top ramen spots.  The place is tiny! Bring a date here but don't roll up in a huge group. This place is popular and be prepared to wait an hour at least. The shopping center is small and they're many other popular spots within. Parking is a PITA and it's probably best to park on the street to avoid door dings. Parking and waiting are the worst things about this place and there have been a number of times where I changed my mind because it wasn't worth the trouble. I highly suggest using ride-share and arriving early to avoid crowds.  Enjoy

aBqLPwk7zcWSo8PnYusaDg.text: This is the first time my family and I eat lunch here. I feel compelled to write my feedback and to say customer service here is excellent. As the matter of fact, because of good customer service, the food just taste better. I wouldn't say that the ramen is a big WOW compared to a lot of other places we have been to. But it wasn't salty or bland, just right. The place is small so expect a wait time to be longer than 15 to 30 minutes and make sure your party is ALLL there. It is only fair to other people who's waiting. My family and I would come back here again if we're in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1P8Ip6OnttJKIKiYIEt5Tw.text: If you do plan on coming here, try your best to avoid dinner time. My boyfriend and I came around 7pm and waited about an hour to be seated.   It's a super small restaurant with literally 5 tables and a booth that fits about 8 people. There were people waiting inside and outside, which sucks especially when it's cold and people are hungry. You have to fill out a sheet with the number of people in your party and where you'd like to be seated, then they call people out to seat them accordingly.   Once we got seated we were immediately served with drinks and the waitress took our orders. The staff works quickly to get people seated and fed. We sat for about 5 minutes and our food was already made and set in front of us. That's a bonus!  I got the spicy tonkotsu ramen with corn and flavored egg, my boyfriend got the regular tonkotsu ramen with nori and extra noodles. The broth was thicker than i expected but the meat and noodles were delicious. They really fill up your bowl to the max.  We also ordered the regular fried rice, just like everyone else in the restaurant. We could see why it was popular, it's freaking delicious and I would definitely order the fried rice to go!   Four stars because they should expand the place to make it bigger especially since they have such a huge crowd of customers coming in.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

7c6Ts16m8BLPKsA0MZiW-w.text: OMG. If this place wasn't a state away, I'd be here all the time.   I was seated almost immediately, and service was pretty efficient. I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen with an egg. It was delicious! Not too salty but FULL of flavor. The level of spice was just right. The pork literally melted in my mouth - I wish they included a little bit more! The firmness of the noodles was to my liking!  From now on, I'm making a stop here before visiting Vegas.   100% recommend to ramen lovers who can't travel to Japan! :P  (Picture is of the regular tonkotsu)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen

JCprEmArXRDrpEHptiQcRg.text: Oyshineeee...  Monta's is by far the BEST ramen joint I've ever experienced.    The tonkotsu broth is amazing and as you can see by the before and after pics I finish it all!!!  Highly recommend ordering they're gyoza and pork belly bowl over fried rice (special order).   Montas is a must every time we're in Vegas.  The place is super small and can only accommodate a few parties at a time.  If you can get on the counter, do it, cause you won't be talking much while devouring your meal anyway.  Wait times can be long but it'll be well with it.  P2P is outstanding   You'd be a fool to skip this place... but if you do that's ok so we can get in faster.  Arigato Montas!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

sx44DEriJw4xA48Q6ABoHw.text: Very fast service and very delicious! One of the best shoyu ramen I've had here in vegas. The broth was the perfect amount of salty and savory for me. I added corn and some chili oil to my ramen and it was like heaven for my soul. My boyfriend got the spicy ramen, he added a lot of garlic and other side sauces to try to make it spicer. It wasn't as spicy as he would've liked but we both still enjoyed it.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

GHIHvPQ3mWLtXtLJKH8PWw.text: Very good place food is very good quality will come back in the future this place is ver recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

EEZP1hRN20Y4ixenW0TUrA.text: Came here to get the miso and spicy tonkatsu ramen. Both broths and noodles were great.   The spicy tonkatsu ramen had some skinnier noodles slurping up the noodles was so satisfying. As you slurped it up the spice came with the noodles and it's quite rich (not that thick tho).  The miso ramen had a much more wholesome broth that you could drink and the noodles were a bit thicker. In that ramen, I feel like you wanted to eat noodles with the broth ( like one bite after another) to really enjoy it.  One thing was that the egg didn't seem to be marinated with sake, soy sauce, or anything. It just tasted like a soft boiled egg. Also the chasu just seemed soft and fatty and not very flavorful. Perhaps they just expect the broth to flavor it, but I prefer a little marination.  Coming from sf, this was extremely cheap. 10 bucks a person with toppings.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NWs0u8m6TiezdbCX1gNItA.text: Found this one on Yelp a looooong time ago and been stuck with going here ever since. The restaurant is super tiny with limited seats, but the food here is pretty amazing.   I always get the tonkotsu ramen when the half boiled egg with the spicy paste. It's a bit on the heavy/greasy side, but overall the taste is excellent. Gyoza is nothing special, so I wouldn't put too much hope in them in my opinion.   Avoid this place during lunch and dinner! It's in a plaza that consists of good restaurants and boba shop. The parking spots are limited and can be hard to find/park. This place opens at 11:30 but people start lining up even before that. But the service is pretty quick so the wait is doable.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

8nm7vbTQZeZdLtjvfsTOzQ.text: Delicious and affordable ramen for your belly. I arrived at 11:30 am and waited 20 minutes to be seated. While I was waiting I had a boba tea from the place next door.   Service at Monta was fast and friendly. We'll be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

YGLGbzik40oKir6ovhkKMg.text: Hands down best ramen spot in town! It's so delicious, portions are good, and the price is unbeatable! So the next time you're around, make sure to give this place a try!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Ramen with corn

HiN8oP00jlDjuDUS4ZB3eg.text: Wanted some Ramen while in town so I pulled up my trusted Yelp app and looked for the closest ramen spots that were rated the highest. Monta Ramen was the closest one in proximity to where we were staying so we decided to give it a try.   Pulling into the parking lot, I immediately noticed the crowd of asian people waiting outside so you know this place is legit lol. There were about 5 groups ahead of us so I put our name down and waited patiently.   The wait lasted about 30 minutes until we got seated. The place is pretty tiny, but cozy nonetheless. The waitress was very friendly and attentive even though they were so busy.   The first thing i noticed when i looked at the menu were the prices... they were super cheap compared to what I'm used to for Ramen in the bay area. $7 for a bowl of ramen??!!  I was floored.... and in seeing that I was thinking ok.. their portions must be tiny.   I ordered the Spicy Miso Ramen. When the bowl came out (which was very fast), I was pleasantly surprised.. it was a pretty decent portion!  The taste was excellent too!   Great food, great service, will be back! Also, there's a boba spot right next door, Kung Fu Tea if you need something sweet after dinner!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy miso
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The wait

lyg3uQM1fv26Bm4OIH1w2Q.text: Been coming here for at least five years & it's always consistent.  Polite, fast working employees & chefs.  The line may look long by the list you sign in on, but don't leave.  The Ramen is worth it & they've always seated us quickly.    I love the Miso Ramen!  I add hard boiled eggs, shredded green onion, corn, seaweed, then the chili oil, powder, & lots of garlic.  The spicier & more orange it is the better to me.  Make your own soup how you like it w/ all of the choices.    The Gyoza are good too.  I always sit at the bar, but if there's more than two of you, sit at the table.  No full bar, only beer.  We ordered a hot tea & a cold tea.  Both came in a can!  The hot tea was hot too, which I've never had in a can.      My fav ramen is only exclusive to Nobu Hotel room service so when I crave that, Monta is the spot for my Ramen fix.  All of the soups are delish.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen my way.
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen my cousins way

zSrNtAGmjtAJNuBu97oX7Q.text: Gotta love your foodie friends!!  A friend of mine recommended this place and who would have thought i would eat the best ramen in the planet in Vegas?!!  Here the reviews:  -Ambience: place is tiny but cute inside.  -Service: waitress was nice and friendly. There is always a line outside. I went 2:30pm so it wasn't that busy. (Smart move)  *Miso ramen ($7.25) One of the best ramens ever!!  The broth has something i cant express in words and the char siu!! Mmmm!! Just by typing this i want to go back again!!!  Overall, every time i am in Vegas, this will be my MUST stop!  #happybelly #iaminlovewiththisplace

c9PRRx4o0zSxe7xHaw-olA.text: MONTA, you are the best Ramen I have ever had!  This place is small, unpretentious, but really, really good. Seriously good!  Tonkotsu Ramen with extra chashu pork, nitamago (egg), and pickled ginger is the best thing you will eat in Vegas, 20 mins outside of the strip. Add a side of Kaedama for the extra broth (if you have any). Broth is so rich and creamy, full of flavour. Noodles soak up that "juice" and become life changing upon consumption.   Finally, wash it all down with an Asahi.   Life is good. Life is really good.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

xTxh4P9dqtrtpzUh6f_PQQ.text: I read a review down below that kinda summed up this experience for me: Southern California Ramen restaraunts have spoiled me and jaded my taste buds.  The pork they put in their soup is a little on the fatty side and the broth seems to have to not been skimmed enough since it is also oily and fatty.  Interesting atmosphere though.  However I would say that if you want better Ramen go down the street to Ichiza.  Monta has a limited menu of just oily soup while Ichiza is an explosion of variety AND they have better Ramen soup.

3UDgl1intOgg8m_Lh4E0ug.text: Huh.  This is a twist.  I actually enjoyed the shoyu ramen here more than the tonkatsu (shio/salt ramen).  My family were in Vegas and my sister knew of a tasty ramen place so we decided to truck on down to Monta Noodle House.  Over all, the experience was pretty good.  I have to say this stacks up pretty well compared to some of the ramen places in California like Santouka or Shin Sen Gumi.  I think the defining factor is the broth itself.  Whether you're down for thick hearty broth or straight up thin broth, that's up to you.  I personally dig the heartiness of this place and definitely wouldn't mind going here again.  Ten points to Monta.

w7GfemIQGoDmS4nEXQ46Bw.text: Easily on par with the best ramen houses LA has to offer.  Distance from my house (5 hrs if the CHP are being assholes) is just about the only thing stopping me from getting fat here (Oh wait, I'm already fat).  And as someone who up until recently had only eaten inside the hotels, the prices are HELL FREAKING AWESOME! (As in reasonably cheap :)

tsa9M4PB6M4eKFCrsh4NjA.text: Delicious!!  I have been meaning to try Monta forever since I keep hearing great things.  Well, I finally made it and can't wait to come back.  I am already dreaming of that tasty broth again!!  I ordered the Shoyu ramen and added an egg (and no pork).  Although at first it seemed like it might be a little basic and not enough, when I received my bowl it was more food than I thought it would be.  The noodles tasted great and the egg was cooked perfectly, not too runny which I don't care for.  The broth was the best, there's something about it that has left me with a craving for it.  Just one bowl left me completely full and satisfied and all for about $8.00!  I must mention that I had gone to an expensive strip restaurant the night before and spent about 15-times that and was so unsatisfied with my food.  The price here for delicious food cannot be beat!  Also worth noting - we arrived exactly at 5pm and there were only 2 parties in front of us.  But within 5-7 minutes of arriving, there was a huge line after us.  The place is small so you might have a wait.

jUJJfmOkiOMJnchj6JmDOg.text: My best friend introduced me to traditional ramen when I went to visit him in California.  I fell in love after the first steaming mouthful.  Since then, I've been trying to find somewhere that can match California's quality, and so far, Monta is the closest I've come in Las Vegas.  I judge a ramen place by their tonkatsu ramen; its the most basic and traditional type.  If they can make tonkatsu, the shoyu and miso are bound to be good.  Such is the case with Monta.  The tonkatsu is creamy and savory, with just the right amount of salt.  Make sure to get a nitamago in there as well; it definitely adds to the texture and flavour.  Considering the flavour and the price, this place is the best in town.

zaQt1IXhJWnR243mFvvfMQ.text: The broth was too salty.  You can't drink that stuff.  Noodles was okay.  Charsui pork was 90 fat.  Great staff and service but I was not impressed with the ramen noodle soup.

aYYQ_Tz0mHQCiCuPiSm7kg.text: Best ramen in Vegas. The broth is flavorful and the sides are great as well. If you're not in the mood for hot noodles, give the cold noodles with the yuzu dipping sauce a try. I'm always amazed by how cheap our bill is with everything we order!

Dbalp56drmK-KUZVR1526w.text: Dining in experience, soup is delicious.. To go experience not so good.. at work super hungry so I ordered ramen at Monta, picked up order and drove back to work. Open my lunch and to my amazement the noodles are not cook.. Called back asking why wasn't it cook they replied that they don't serve it cook but will only if ask. Told me next time you know to ask to cook noodle. lol WTF are you kidding me?!. never heard of ordering take out raw!!.

oSTcmAQivC3LbFykjxMeVg.text: This place is extremely satisfying, especially after a day of hiking. We were able to split a pork belly bowl and potstickers between 3 people. The pork belly was soft but not chewy and very flavorful and the shoyu flavor did not overpower the pork. We added goma to the bowl which gave the pork and rice a rosted, nutty flavor. The potsickers were delicious. The wrapper was thin and crispy and the filling had a slight kick to it, so if you don't enjoy spicy food in anyway I wouldn't recommend ordering these. I ordered the tonkatsu shoyu ramen with an egg and was very satisfied with my choice. The broth was creamy without being too fatty and the chashu pork was soft and melted in my mouth. The egg could have used more seasoning or marinated a bit longer as it was rather flavorless.  The noodles were the right consistency and were neither too chewy or starchy. The service was on par with the food. The wait staff was friendly and came back to check on us often.

LIKcZQdaHWvk2ti72PiC5w.text: I'm writing this review from Oakland, Ca. I was living in Las Vegas a few years back and I remember eating here. The ramen was so delicious. I still think about it. Here in the San Francisco Bay Area I have yet to find as good a ramen, even though there's a Japantown in SF. I am constantly disappointed.  The only other ramen that compares is in Torrance, Ca. I heard about on in Berkeley,  but it's $16 a bowl. I miss your ramen. :(

SyhKr6Fc4Ral7SkdgzmLqA.text: This place was sooo hard to find because they had no sign.  If my friend didn't tell me it was right next to Raku I wouldn't have found it.  It was worth it though.  Much like In-n-Out there is a very small menu but the quality and simplicity made up for it.  I am a fan!

8EpD68sZgnJuokCA_iaJbw.text: Not the biggest Ramen fan but this place is really good! My son had a pork belly bowl he loved it!

Vu6SHygYM3bo2V6V40HG7A.text: The best I've had outside of my home state of Hawaii. Ultra authentic, clean and delicious.

EM26bKvzPOZ0oyiiwXge5g.text: Monta is an authentic Japanese ramen restaurant. From the moment you enter its cramped, busy little space with a cheerful greeting from the staff to the satisfied feeling of a bellyful of delicious ramen it's a wonderful experience. The ramen is on-par with the real stuff in Japan, and the Tonkotsu and Miso varieties are especially good. The gyoza and fried rice leave a bit to be desired but as this is primarily a ramen restaurant that can be forgiven. The beer is cheap too, with Asahi on tap for about $2.95 a glass. All in all it's a wonderful experience and if you are looking for authentic ramen in Las Vegas this is your best bet.

UlOjXaBCxNQPZLWrvZqq8g.text: Service here is hit or miss. Sometimes excellent, sometimes not so attentive. I've eaten here about 9 or 10 times, and I noticed that it is server dependent. There are 2 servers that seem to consistently let me down, where as the other 2 are always great and work together well to make sure they always check up on us.  The Chasu (bbq pork) here is quite good, IMO it is better than the chasu at the well known Daikokuya in Los Angeles. Oddly, they have 2 different types of ramen noodles here that are ASSIGNED to the type of broth you choose and they will NOT let you choose the other noodles with a different broth. I prefer the noodles they use in the miso ramen, but normally prefer a combination of tonkatsu and shoyu broth. The lack of flexibility is a bit upsetting and leaves the foodie in me yearning for food MY WAY.   Fortunately, I tried all of their fried rices and rice bowls and have been pretty happy with all of them. My favorite is the pork belly bowl. YUM!!! I add a bit of the crushed garlic, chili oil, and japanese chili flakes to make it absolutely scrumptious. If you like pork (who doesn't), you MUST try this.

zAoamEIi6LX5QxRZiZW_SQ.text: Delicious broth, fresh noodles and affordable. Don't know of any ramen place in Vegas so this is a must try if you are a ramen fan! The pork belly rice bowl was also super yummy!

k_HW6M6DK_0sWbE7AGLsyQ.text: Best Ramen in Town IMHO... The Miso ramen broth is savory and quite rich, but a bit too salty for me. I tend to lean more towards the Tonkatsu Shoyu ramen where for me the broth is to my liking. All ramens are delicious though and I would recommend trying them all. My favorite adds are extra chashu pork, egg, shreaded green onion. I alway leave enough broth to order Kaedama (extra noodles).

_iKaFRP2A1pWa0p3kGxEbQ.text: One of my favorite places to eat! I'd never turn down and invite to eat here. Their spicy powder really does it for me cause I'm a fan of spicy! The only downside is there's not many places to sit so you have to wait awhile to be seated sometimes. Also wish they would get rid of the $10 minimum card charge. Sometimes I just don't have cash and don't want to have to order extra stuff just to meet it. Other than that I will forever be coming here!

ezPOfas3j4tVrM0Ii3VVqg.text: I first read about this place in Vegas weekly. I love ramen especially in the winter. i think it's a great little place. The menu is small but the things they make are done extremely well. It can get crowded on weekends so I suggest going during week days if you can. It's also great because I can go by myself and sit at the bar area and not feel weird haha Simple and reasonable= me likey!

zs120_Hx1lNo2z82KoNuAw.text: I don't have a lot of Ramen expertise but this place far exceeded my expectations, which were high before I walked through the door. An outstanding meal for right around $10.

xWH-FeMkuqnvyUfs61d0ng.text: Really good, affordable Ramen served quickly in a no frills atmosphere.  The broth in my bowl of ramen was so good. The noodles were perfect. And the meat was so tender. They don't have a lot of extras you can add to your bowl, but that really doesn't matter because it was so delicious. I will be back

VEYNypeFAU_hxBhV6xWNPA.text: After eating here three times (and already planning to come here forever), I feel I can finally give a thorough review of this ramen shop. Let me just state a few obvious things when you arrive (or before you arrive): 1. This shopping center is almost always packed on the weekends and if you're lucky, you'll get a semi-empty parking lot on the weekdays. It has a ton of other amazing restaurants so it is usually busy.  2. This place is one of the best reviewed ramen shops in Vegas; therefore, expect a line if you go during lunch hours, dinner hours, or any time during the weekends. Luckily, they get people in and out fast and provide really efficient service. 3. It's a small ramen shop in terms of square footage, and smaller parties get priority only because there are more single/double seats (bar seats/small tables) than there are full tables (for 3 or more).   Technical stuff aside, the ramen here is delicious. I have gotten a different one each time: tonkotsu, shoyu, and tonkotsu shoyu.  My boyfriend has ordered the kuro ramen with black garlic oil a few times now as well.  Their broths are flavorful and very rich.  The tonkotsu ramen really coats your mouth with a delicious layer of fat- their chashu will reflect the same. I couldn't believe the flavor and sensation of the chashu melting in my mouth.  If you want something still very rich but not "coat your mouth" rich, go for the happy medium with the tonkotsu shoyu ramen.  If you're looking for a very (almost) familiar flavor of ramen, I'd recommend the shoyu ramen. My partner says the kuro ramen with black garlic oil has similar fatty flavors to the tonkotsu, but with (obviously) black garlic oil. I love garlic, and have yet to try this one- so I will update my review once I have!  I definitely recommend corn, nitamago, and kimchi as your toppings. Obviously, if you're into it, extra pork chashu is a must. Their kimchi is very light- not too spicy, and delicious when you eat it with the broth of any bowl; we've gotten it every time and have even shared it with strangers so they can have the delicious experience themselves.  I can't normally convince my boyfriend to go eat ramen with me, it's just not high priority on his list of foods he would rather go eat (sushi, KBBQ, etc.), but he loves Monta Ramen.   We'll each get a bowl of ramen with toppings and drinks, and our bill never comes out to be more than ~$20 before tip! The employees there are quick, efficient, courteous, and hard working.  You definitely get the bang for your buck here, and I can see why they are so well loved in the community. We'll definitely be coming here for our ramen needs forever.

vyaCOF_UYhTRdfub4fdnsA.text: Absolutely delicious!! I have been craving for it again since I left. The wait time is so worth it!!

O-TyvwKMg0ooKTc6axtmpw.text: This may be one of the best ramen joints this side of the Pacific.   Be advised, the place is tiny and the wait can be pretty long, so get there early and out your name in the waitlist.   The tonkotsu is milky goodness and the noodles are perfection. You can't go wrong with the pork belly bowl on the side with your ramen.   I never miss an opportunity to hit up Monta whenever I'm in Vegas. I've tried a ton of ramen places in the area and none have what Monta can offer.

wc0Q4DmInPSLrdds8GOKlA.text: Food was ok service was ok. Got a seat really quick and my Luke warm Soup was delivered quickly. I ordered the spicy soup and it wasn't spicy at all. I had to pay 1.00 dollar for spicy paste that was just like ketchup. That was a bust. Don't think I'll be going back again.

LtWL_XtnhAm7eblSTid0ig.text: PROS:  -BEST RAMEN IN TOWN. For the price this place asks for, HANDS DOWN is the best for being affordable AND delicious! -Fast & friendly service -Pork belly bowl  FOOD 5/5: -I've been eating Monta for years, and I recommend all the soups, seriously. They all have a great broth, which is like the foundation of the whole soup. SUPER creamy and SUPER tasty! -I'm just going to list the prices for the soups because all of them are sublime! -Tonkotsu Ramen ($6.95): Pork broth  -Shoyu Ramen ($6.95): Chicken broth -Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen ($6.95): Pork & Chicken broth + thin noodles -Miso Ramen ($7.25): Pork & chicken broth + thick noodles = PERSONAL FAVORITE ;) -Pork Belly Bowl (sm $2.95 // reg $5.75): Sliced pork with green onions, so amazing. Must have for an appetizer  CONS: -Always busy + usually a line -Tight space

Qe5J0skluiYMhUDPwplxYA.text: Not sure what the hype was all about, I ordered the spicy tonkotsu ramen and my brother was luke warm, and the flavors were not really all that great. I'm sticking to Ramen Sora the next time I come back to Las Vegas. The only reason I gave another star is because the service wasn't too bad. But overall a disappointing trip to a mediocre ramen shop at best.

orRieGHK4lbidLD9245hmw.text: Service was okay. Food could have been better. It was a bit too salty for my taste. I expected the soup to be hot, but it was more of a warm temperature.

BJZC1L12IG0tKblNEHmpXQ.text: Monta is my favorite ramen in vegas.. i came here mostly every 2 weeks and always order Black garlic ramen. And today i was really disappointed with the service. Server asked anything to drink? My friend asked hot water and i asked regular water. She said sorry we dont have hot water. Water no ice its ok? And i was like ok.  Came here today on Wednesday arround 7pm with my friend and both of us order black garlic. The broth really really salty then usual. Told the server about my issue and i asked her can you give me little more broth? She told me broth cost 2$. And i was like...?? Are u serious?? Instead she give me more broth she give me hot water.. well earlier when she take our drink and we asked hot water , server said they dont have hot water..  We really disappointed with service..

8W7EPVyX7AhwcxHtWTNVEA.text: Solid ramen place in Vegas!  The wait can be long, we came on a Friday night and the wait was about 30-40 minutes at 10pm!  The ramen is VERY affordable and reasonably priced.  The ramen here would be at least 10 bucks in LA!  You have options to add other stuff in your ramen if you want to.  I got the shoyu cause I love the soy based broth, it was alright for me.  My gf got the miso and I loved the broth! A much thicker and tastier broth! Parking can be hard in the plaza, but there should be available spaces on the street!

DD3Hn8A7qceJqZJe5DEsJA.text: Like many people who come here, I am very picky about the quality of my ramen restaurant choices. When I'm in Vegas, Monta is my go-to place. I come here especially for the chashu bowl; the cut of pork that they have is unlike any other, so much so that when I'm away from Sin City, I'm dreaming about this chashu. Of course, the ramen here is also very good, worthy of top Nom-nom awards; I'm a fan of the Tonkotsu and Tonkotsu Shoyu broths. Expect to wait awhile, but it's totally worth it. Itadakimasu!

4yl9wlUfyi6uX0dHz7MrpA.text: Went today for takeout. Just what the doctor ordered. Wow! The service was super quick! I took everything home to eat, totally delicious. I got the miso ramen with an egg and extra noodles. Price was $11 total. Tons of food! Location was easy to find too.

LOyrdXCQKjlGCKd00JgrGg.text: Second time coming here. Last year came here looking a cheap and good ramen place, was glad we came across this place. As a ramen chef this was better than the ramen we had. As well every time coming to Las Vegas this is the first place we think of when we want ramen. Would be coming back every year when in Vegas.

aNOKXHCEDq5dqd6N2pyiCQ.text: If you're looking for affordably delicious Ramen this place is it! The Tonkotsu is wonderfully creamy and hearty. Perfect for cold nights. If you're hungry like I was you can get extras: noodles, chashu, eggs, etc.  The place is cozy and doesn't have a lot of seating so expect a wait. One suggestion is to always have a person present in case the waitress calls your name or they will skip you and you will need to start over again.

AVTWS1pUz8wQ3m3BBqanmg.text: Super yummy Ramen! Service was super nice!  We didn't have to wait very long and although they're were tons waiting.  Small little restaurant but people go in and out pretty fast so the 30 minute i was told was like 10 minutes.  Now about the food.  I had the spicy tonkotsu ramen and it was very filling :) the broth was very flavorful! We also ordered the beef bowl but i wouldn't recommend it because the beef to rice ratio was no bueno.  Stick to the ramen :)

Rn-Oe88kWgoYiWnRNLQ_aQ.text: Best ramen in Vegas! The noodles are silky and taste wonderful. We ordered the Kuro Ramen Black Garlic Oil +corn +seaweed and Tonkotsu Ramen +extra pork chashu. The broth and the included ingredients of the ramen was tasty. We added the red ginger from the jar to give a little zing. We also ordered the Pan-fried pork and veggie Gyoza that was perfectly crisp on one side. It is a small restaurant that looks to seat a guesstimate of 30 people. There's usually a wait that doesn't is usually 15-30 minutes, but we got lucky and there wasn't a wait. It was a fair price for 2. $25 together. We will be returning!

WpYtoZhknUq1aYq002W1IQ.text: Best ramen and fried rice in vegas!!! Great prices and great service. Be ready to wait if its dinner time, they are always super busy ( great food ) but the wait is always worth it! If you dont feel like ramen their fried rice and pork belly bowls are delicious!

3A7wPkN_2IbTGxMwyU4jSg.text: Only have been here once and I really was in love with this ramen. The soup base was very flavorful, and I like that there are different ramen options in terms of thin or wide noodles. I also like the cold yuzu ramen that is good for a hot summer day. It's refreshing and acidic with plenty of vegetables for when your'e not feeling a warm umami broth. I don't like the fact that the parking complex is extremely difficult to find any space and is often crowded with the wait. This would be my 'go to' if I wanted ramen takeout, but I wouldn't go here for the ambience and experience.

g22B_Wi7caf_IqPHfB9v9w.text: Las Vegas, NV: I hate giving low ratings but this place doesn't deserve anything else. I came here with friends and didn't choose the place so I didn't know it was not vegetarian friendly. Sadly that meant I couldn't partake in the ramen but I settled for fried rice (not the restaurant's fault I'm vegetarian after all).   I ended paying about $6.00 for a tiny serving of rice. Mind you, I got a size that was supposedly a full meal. When I asked the waitress to substitute the ham for egg, corn, or anything vegetarian friendly, she refused. Instead, she insisted I pay extra for each of those items.   I have never been to a place less accommodating to dietary restrictions in my entire life. I've also never been to a place that would charge me extra for a substitute that would be cheaper than the meat that comes with the meal. For the rudeness and inflexibility combined with a tiny and expensive portion of rice that was ordinary at best, I can't give this place any more stars.   Ps My friends said the ramen was good so I recommend the ramen to the carnivorous people out there.

OKXOM2FlFUr2NKxLbuHeXg.text: I've had all types of ramen--and i still love this place.  The broth is light yet filling and the noodles are fresh. It's worth the wait. Definitely get the tonkotsu broth and I always get extra meat, seaweed, and egg~  Just keep in mind that its a tiny place, hard to find parking, and you'll be in line, depending on what time, for at least 30+ minutes

TAKjXm7cvIhcE4RgRXbNAA.text: Authentic "hole in the wall" ramen spot. Came here New Year's Day. There was 20 people in the list but worth the wait. Service was great and fast. Best part was inexpensive and delicious!

dCT0CoXoPc5p16DorPj3tg.text: Veey good ramen. Very recomanded. Good prices basic and not complicated menu. Sometimes get busy

1OS0tr-ws5NkffMjEq_jMQ.text: Ever seen the movie Ratatouille? Just like the food critic, I ordered a bowl of pork belly with rice and it took me way back to my first job at 14 years of age. Japanese restaurant. One of my favorite dishes and I haven't had it since 1993. So good! Brings back awesome memories.

5X_q1il_ifY181CfkCzgpQ.text: Seriously loved this place. Wasn't so sure at the beginning but was proved wrong!!! Loved the ramen and the broth. I honestly can't say enough good things about this place!

OKEJum2qp-jQvW-iP_sz0A.text: This was my first time going to this place with my two other friend and we order three ramen noodles and it was terrible the soup was too salty and the customer service wasn't very good , as most others restaurant they will come by and ask for any need , even thought the ramen was cheap but we would never come back again .

9xO7StpGmt23RzkmvFEvGg.text: Of all things Ramen,Japanese, and delicious, Monta Ramen on Spring Mountain Blvd falls right in the middle. It's nothing mind blowing, nor is it terrible, hence the 3stars.   First off... Place is SUPER TINY. So expect a wait and make sure to write your name down. Even when it's not packed, it get packed pretty quickly... And because it's so tiny, it tends to get uncomfortable when it's packed... And that's uncomfortable on both the eating and waiting end. Eating coz all the tables are close, even the bar area is hardly comfortable elbow room for the seats next to each other. And also when it's a long wait and you're eating, you seriously feel like EVERYONE waiting is watching you eat to see how much longer you will be sitting down. Uncomfortable on the waiting end coz there's not much of a waiting area at all. If you have issue with confined spaces... Not the place for you my friend.   The decor and seating does follow the more traditional Japanese ramen house with it being a small narrow restaurant, with wood tables and seatings. I noticed most if not all servers are Japanese so it keeps to the authenticity. Minus the Hispanic cooks lol   The food is good. Price is definitely what keeps me coming back and dealing with the wait and tight space tho. The taste and flavors aren't mind blowing and it's nothing to rave about to your friends.  But it's definitely somewhere I can easily say "I got the bill tonight" without regretting it and feeling like I broke my wallet over a filling meal. I will say the portions are great for the cheap prices.   My favorite actually is not the ramen here but the pork belly bowl. The pork belly is cooked just right; not over or under cooked and just the right amount of sauce in the right to compliment the flavors of the pork belly. For me... That's the ticket item that has me returning. Plus another good point is service is fairly quick... BUT they have to be... They need their customers revolving in and out to accommodate for lack of space.   Tbh the location in Henderson is better. Just this area is closer to my house than Henderson. The ramen can tend to be too salty for my palate... But again like I said it's not amazing but it's not terrible. But definitely worth going for the prices and the pork belly bowl! Nom nom nom

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Pork belly bowl

DyMv3Xp_WmJ538ADLnkuxw.text: Nothing special, other than the fact that in addition to pork broth they also have chicken broth (Halal friendly!!) Though I've had better ramen, this will do the job when you're hungover. Prices are normal.   Get there early, as the line is LONG. We got there 10 mins before it opened and still has to wait 30 minutes to be seated--the line was THAT long.

AagQmgNh0gvYHprJt2bJAw.text: We ordered the Taka Fried rice which was absolutely amazing. I got the Miso Ramen and loved the broth and noodles. I think I went over board with the sides. I ordered everything but butter and Chashu in it. I would leave out corn and Taka next time.   All in all its a quant and bustling restaurant. The foods great.

x020I2gaEJtXV-bJEEm_4w.text: Food was average, I got the spicy ramen bowl and kimchi fried rice. Service was definitely terrible. After being sat for about a min or so the server asked us for our order so didn't really get to see what else they got. After our order was put in, we had to ask if we can get something to drink then had to ask another person for straws. Service could of improved this entire experience. The kimchi fried rice didn't really have much kimchi in it. Tasted the soy sauce more then the kimchi. Maybe if I added an egg or something else to my ramen bowl next time I'd like it better.

NcKJzbdJk-ZV_j_s309ljA.text: 2 of my coworkers including me had our credit cards skimmed here!   We went here for dinner and the food was as good as everyone says, but it definitely is not worth the trouble of the fraudulent activities. They were smart about it too. They only started charging stuff after a week or two from our visit. I honestly didn't want to believe it at first, but 3 people out of our 5 group party which one of us paid cash is not just a coincidence. We all didn't go anywhere else out of the norm between our dinner at Monta and when the fraudulent charges occurred.   This disappoints me because the Ramen is so good. You might say "why don't you just use cash next time" but it's just my stance that if a place can allow that to happen I will not spend my hard earned money there. So with that being said if you choose to eat here be careful. As for me my search for a new Ramen place begins.

bGPvzmrfgcjze6M-APBaFw.text: My friend and I had a rough morning at the dayclubs on a Saturday, we were starving and figured we grab some ramen before heading back to our hotel. I love their simple menu, just exactly what we needed that afternoon. I went with the Miso Ramen and added Chashu Pork, Green Onion, and Nitamago (soft boiled egg). The broth was delicious, savory and well seasoned, toppings all hit the spot as well. The service was great and since we came at an off hour there was no wait at all. This was the perfect afternoon pick-me-up and a great spot for some quality ramen in Vegas.

ndUgBHgkCO0I-NZVkJIQ1w.text: Mmm, monta! Get in mah belly!  +Authentic Japanese ramen shop off the strip. I mean who would have thought?! The waitresses and head chef are Japanese and speak it fluently. Always a good sign!  +Monta has 4 soup broth to choose from: Tonkotsu, tonkotsu-shoyu, shoyu, and miso. Always nice to have varieties since I'm sick of just eating tonkotsu at every single ramen shop. My boyfriend and I both ordered Tonkotsu-Shoyu but I opted for chijire men (thick, wavy noodles) and it was awesome! The noodles had great consistency and the soup was spot on.  +Their 6 piece gyoza tasted like legit ramen shop gyozas. Yum!  -Limited seatings. There are four desks that seats four people, one desk that seats two people, and 9 seats available at the counter.  -Line forms even before opening! My boyfriend and I got to Monta a little too early around 11AM. We were waiting in the car and people started trickling in around 11:15AM and there was mini line formed already before opening! Since it's limited seating, the people in line will fill up the restaurant and there will be constant flow of customers/wait time during lunch peak hours.  -I read someone's review that they had great fried rice so I ordered it but it was a-okay. I've had better ramen shop fried rice before so I will not order it again if I visit Monta.  Monta needs to definitely open a shop in LA. Cannot wait to eat Monta until my next visit to Vegas!

Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried rice was a let down :/ will not order again

u60_9l3n9-0JTscj49QieQ.text: I think this ramen place is okay nothing special. The wait was long when I went and it took a while for our food to come out. I got the spicy tonkatsu ramen and it was kinda light in flavor for my taste. Also tried their fried rice and i felt the rice was kinda mushy as well and the flavor again was light. Over all this place isn't too bad the price is very reasonable but I'd still prefer other ramen places.

yJkPCXIQsz3nyllJ0ZRHRQ.text: Had the pork belly over rice and the garlic oil ramen.   Yuum!  Really small seated area but reasonably priced.

45RIEFon5I_yeH2Eu78LLw.text: For a quick fix of ramen noodle cravings I highly recommend trying this place. Getting seated and order was fast for such a tiny place that was packed, we got the kuro ramen which is the black bean garlic noddles. Taste similar to Tiger Den in Houston but not as good, I would come back for this if in town. Service wise it was good, only two waitress for a busy place and they checked in on us to see if everything was okay.   Overall my belly was happy and satisfied, if you want noodles after a massage then try this place then hit up Kung Fu for milk tea (just right next door to each other). Location is super convenient, not too far from the Vegas strip.

wt5PF5tRmchX8SHs0Q56jQ.text: Went here tonight and it was cold outside.  Ramen was the solution tonight and Monta Ramen did the trick.  Miso Ramen was excellent, noodles cooked perfectly and key to a success ramen experience.  Toppings of your choice is optional to further enhance your palette.   Note: this place is small so waiting during peak hours is normal.  It's what I call a hole in the wall place and better than any ramen places in the casinos.

kZfYwPNMooAaQz2xRihA9A.text: Quick, tasty...a gem!  We always stop here at least once when we're in town.  I forget what it's called but the black garlic ramen is a "must try."

hUXFIFF1Czt73VOIQFCG-Q.text: Place is very good but have had better in NY.  I would still recommend it tho. It's a small restaurant tho and wait is long.  If I really have a craving and am in the neighborhood I would come back.

eN1CogklDT1-ZgKLSEAaIA.text: Food: 4 Service: 4 Atmosphere: 3. Cramped in a strip mall (which is of course typical in LV.). It is located in the same strip mall as another popular Japanese place, Raku.  FIRST IMPRESSION and ORDERING As we stood waiting for about maybe 15-20 min, we peeked over to the table of 4 who were eating on a table smack right next to the entry door where everyone was standing & waiting. We saw that the fried rice looked a tad greasy and so did the ramen broth. My dinner companion gave me that look of "hmmm" and I said "I guess we'll just try it since we're already here". We were curious to compare this to our usual Ramen Dojo (San Mateo, CA).  We ordered one tonkotsu $6.95 (+egg $1.50  and corn $0.50), one shoyu ramen $6.95 with extra chasu (+4 pieces, $2.50) and one kimchi fried rice $6.95 (hoping this would be less greasy than the regular fried rice and it was slightly less common in the Ramen place).  Having not eaten lunch that day, we were huuungry and ready to devour our order as soon as it arrived. First impression: noodles presentation looked neat and mouthwatering; the ingredients were neatly arranged on top and the bowl of ramen looked quite appetizing. Especially with 2 hungry stomachs impatiently waiting to devour them. LOL.   The broth didn't appear as greasy as my earlier glance at the previous table.  There was a curious black ring around each of the chasu (more about this later) that's usually not present in the other ramen's place chasu piece.  Interesting, we thought.  The fried rice still looked a tad on the greasy side by the shines it showed. But in all fairness, I haven't ordered Japanese fried rice in a ramen place for some time. Maybe they all look like that.  Now on to the fun part.  FOOD The broth on the tonkotsu ramen was delish. Slightly on the lighter side compared to Ramen Dojo, but it was still good. One big difference that made Ramen Dojo's broth more 'hearty' and tasty was the addition of chicken bits in their broths. If you like a lighter version of Tonkotsu broth, you will like Monta's version better.  The shoyu broth was light yet had a lot of flavor.   The tonkotsu bowl came with thin noodles. We both were very curious how good (smooth) this thin noodle would be. While not as 'smooth' as some of the other thin ramen noodles we've tried in Japan, we were pleasantly surprised at how smooth and tasty it was. So, thumbs up here.  The noodles in the shoyu bowl was also pretty good. It is the yellow, thicker, curly kind; of course heavier than the one in the tonkotsu bowl, yet not super-heavy.  As for the curious black ring around the chasu, as you probably have guessed, it is the pork skin. The skin itself was a real thin strip with a very thin layer of fat underneath it.  Including this skin gave the soup broth an extra flavor and aroma that distinguished it from other ramen's place broth. It was probably also why the half-finished ramen bowl we peeked earlier looked slightly greasier. I don't typically see this pork skin included in other ramen shop. This is a plus for the broth. The slightly greasier broth didn't quite happen as much in my bowl. 'cause I like to scrape off the fat under the pork skin. LOL. Another thumbs up!  The last dish which was the kimchee fried rice ($6.95) was yum, though I still think it could be done with slightly less oil.  Unlike the rice bowl-sized portion that it often comes in, this fried rice came in a rounded square plate of the size that could've been a meal by itself.  SERVICE Service was friendly, efficient and brisk without making us feel rushed. But we did devoured our meal super fast and left quickly as a courtesy to the long lines of people waiting.  Two thumbs up for this place.  ANECDOTAL COMMENTS & OBSERVATIONS (mostly rhetorical) Why is it that most ramen house has the most 'house rules' posted on their outside window? No outside food. No outside drink. No tacos? (seriously, this place has a picture of tacos with a cross on it and Japanese writing).

UYwf-LvQv6KEc79vWkl1aw.text: OMG! The Tonkotsu ramen is mouth-watering! I will be dreaming about it for some time! In fact, I'm seriously thinking of coming back to Vegas every year just for this ramen! The broth is delicious! For the meat lovers, get extra pork belly bc they don't give you much meat. The miso ramen was not as good, too heavy and salty for our taste. The regular fried rice was very tasty, but it's small bc it's a appetizer serving.

WsvZd1FeuOaZy3AipOaIfA.text: Love love love this place! Add butter, green onions, and some spicy sesame oil to the Tonkatsu ramen....and Voila!

o6mokAoa5euVqfAl1GtcXQ.text: I've looked far and wide for a good Ramen shop that would satisfy my appetite for real Japanese style Ramen.  Oh how I've shed many tears over the prepackaged Ramen that I was forced to eat, because I just couldn't get the real deal.  Well my days of sadness are over since Monta Ramen has come into my life.  Now the world is good again....   I usually go for the the tonkotsu Ramen, but have been known to dip my chopsticks into the tonkotsu-shoyu broth as well.  Both flavors are deep and rich, and each has a creamy texture that can only come from long, slow simmering.  The main difference between these two types of broths comes in the form of a lil more salty punch that the tonkotsu-shoyu has.   The noodles are firm (but not too firm) and thin and have a great mellow flavor that balances out the saltiness of the broths.  On their menu it states that you can get an extra helping of these noodles for a very small fee.  I've tried to finish an extra helping of the noodles twice, and have failed both times.  It is a really huge a portion of food, and in my version of man vs. food, food most defiantly won.  Along with the noodles you get a selection of side items you can add to your Ramen.   I would recommend adding the egg and corn they taste great in the Ramen, and turn it into a really substantial meal.    The last thing I'm going to say about this great Las Vegas Ramen shop is that the staff is, and has always been friendly and attentive (I never go more two minutes without having my water glass filled).

xzoY3B4wCkI4oLt3WlVrWw.text: A decent ramen place.  The miso base I got was just too salty for me, and they charge for eggs to be put in the soup.  You can get a tastier and cheaper ramen at Ramen Sora down the street.  Don't really see the huge hype about this place.  It won't be my first choice for ramen.

P8gvCZC9xgijaRI_8dV8Dg.text: A little different from the Pho style, this is Japanese, very good, many topping choices. Only the service and friendliness can use some work. I felt like there was no time allowed to relax and enjoy,..it was eat and Go....

i8pS3cFsN94za36GXY4BMg.text: This place is great. You can tell by the line. You're blessed if you get there and sit right down. But if you have to wait in a 30 minute line it's worth it. The noodles are great. I prefer the thick noddles and my SO prefers the thin noodles. We both like to add corn.

pNhjDp2K5r3aE2_MLU3bpw.text: Having lived in OKinawa AND in mainland Japan, in Yokosuka... i'd like to think that I know a thing or two when in comes to Japanese Ramen.   Before there was Monta, there were only two real places to get Ramen here in Vegas. One was Togoshi (which sadly had closed) and Kaigenro (which still has some pretty excellent ramen, BTW). Enter Monta...a fresh new take on a small niche market here in sin city.   And let me tell you, after that first sip of the soup and the first snap of the fresh noodles, I was instantly transported back to Japan. Even for just a fleeting moment, I forgot all about the hustle and bustle of day to day life here and was "home" for the duration of a bowl or ramen.   Their chashu is out of this world!  the menu is kept simple with three main variations of ramen: shoyu, miso, and tonkotsu...all of which are absolute trips back in time, like being back in Japan.   Now only if they served beer...........

cCD6oD8rVCb0vh2mDPdgfA.text: Mmmmm, thank you Yelp, this place is good, I love Ramen and this place reminds me of Orochon Ramen in Los Angeles. Not necessarily better but for Las Vegas this might be one of the best.   Pros: The Shoyu Ramen and Tonkatsu were so good with extra green onion and chashu. My friend didn't like the chashu (pork) so much because she felt it was a weird texture thing but I loved it, put extra in mine and took hers, so my gain! Tonkatsu noodles were good, and the egg was good but you had to let it sit in the hot broth for awhile, otherwise you'd realize that they tossed a cold egg in there. Service was good, very friendly and nice.  The biggest cons were the size and the temperature. I got there early so I was able to secure a spot at the bar but outside of that, there were three small table for maybe four, and a group of eight sitting together and that's all there was room for. I couldn't imagine what this place is like during lunch hour or dinner. When I first arrived I didn't think the temperature was that bad since they have fans everywhere. But after eating hot ramen, having a couple Asahis, and being right next to the busy kitchen, the sweat started coming (felt like I was cutting weight for a fight) but it's manageable. All in all, I will definitely be coming back here

08PfraU0swQHNBaQqhxprg.text: We LOVE this place.  My new favorite is miso ramen with a side of the "spicy" paste.  It comes very close to the chili pepper ramen I used to have all the time in Narita.  Gyoza are done perfectly! It's worth the wait!

4QyduTcbe0jheYApEZKDgg.text: Their ramen and fried rice are yummy! Price are reasonable! I love coming here whenever I'm at Vegas!

q_dqaRnwcQ2uN06fSdvu6w.text: Best ramen I've had. Kimchi is awesome too. This place is small and loud just as it should be. Do not come here with large group. I walked from city center, about 45 min. Worth it.

lo9xn32ewtpagckdyxzWgA.text: I was extremely excited to find out that there was a new ramen restaurant in town.  I finally got the chance to try it today.  I was a little apprehensive after reading all the reviews about the heat inside and the rude service.  Well, as usual, I was only customer at 3 pm.  The first thing I noticed was the temperature.  Sure it was hot and humid, but they have large vats of soup and hot water boiling away, so it was to be expected.  I think they had the A/C on full because it was definitely tolerable.  Next was the waitress.  The one that helped me was very friendly and helpful.  She checked up on me regularly.  So good news, maybe the owner read the reviews and critiques on Yelp and decided to do something.  As for the food, I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with egg and extra premium green onion.  Since I was the only person in there, my order came quickly.  The size of the bowl was a bit on the small size.  Two, nice, fatty, pieces of pork floated underneath a mound of slivered green onions.  I quickly tried a piece of the char-su.  The meat was extremely tender, as tender as the fat and their was a nice ring of flavor on the outside.  Made me wish they gave me more.  The broth was nice an rich, not too salty and the noodles were cooked to a nice al dente, so they were chewy and adsorbed some of the broth.  After sampling everything, I added some minced garlic and chili powder to my bowl.  They also had the pickled ginger, toasted sesame seeds, white pepper, sesame seed oil, and some other condiments so I could season my noodles just the way I wanted.  That was a big plus.    Overall, I was very happy with the flavor of my tonkotsu ramen, the service, and the A/C.  I would have given this place 4 stars, but the price was a little too steep for the smaller than average sized bowl.  I would definitely go back to take care of any future ramen cravings and try the miso ramen!

xG5xOfSZJFy4pYLQyqpasQ.text: Kinda stumbled into this place after a massage. Super packed when we walked in, but we were seated right away at the bar. Service was quick and prompt. Menu was small which allows you to make a quick choice. Husband and I both ordered fried rice. His was the Kimchi, mine was the T-something fried rice (with mustard greens, yum!). We both enjoyed our food very much and it came out pretty quick. I definitely recommend if you are looking for noodles...if you are low carb, there aren't many options for you. Wish we could have tried the Ramen, too. It looked delicious!

vOcpHHDQNKIZzJ0FwpEJQA.text: Just gotta say, my favorite ramen place in town!  Always the miso ramen but I have tried all their other stuff and I have not any complains

PqW9pPfMC8Jx3CdhVse2Uw.text: Excellent service.  Tonkotsu shoyu ramen is my favorite.  Love this place I know it's super busy but its worth the wait. I've never had a bad experience there and I at least go there twice a month. I love it when the manager is the cook she is best!!!

97W-HZdapjn0DI7D7rnlFw.text: I tried this place out because my friends frequent this place especially during Saturday mornings after pick up basketball. Anyway, I had the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen and the Chasu Pork Bowl.   I'm not a food critic in any way but comparing it to Sora, I can notice a lot of differences. One is well Sora doesn't have Tonkotsu Shoyu in the menu. But with Monta's serving I was quite disappointed. The broth felt greasy and almost instantly left a line of fat/grease on my lips. Although it is good, certain people don't like that feeling when eating. It is creamy and rich but Minus points on the grease. The pork on the Ramen Bowl is only one slice hidden behind bamboo shoots and mushrooms. If I didn't dig through the bowl I wouldn't have even found it. The noodles were okay, but it felt like as if they were just about cooked when the chef took it out from the pot. It felt as if it needed about a minute more in cooking. The server was very nice, refilling our water glasses almost every time we downed a glass. So fast it felt like she was on a mission. The Chasu Bowl was very good however, the shredded Nori on top was surprising and the meat was tender and tasty. It was sweet on the outside part of the cut just how Chasu should taste like. I wasn't blown away by the food but it was a good meal for a hungry man like me. I'd give Monta a second try but probably would not be my go-to Ramen joint.

6hEIvWXrhisJAOBDmiri2Q.text: This place is ok. The venue is small and the wait is long. You literally have to be there when they open which is around 1100 to not wait in line. Anime Ramen is a better choice than Monta Ramen. They have more food choices.

oKo8IrXUktS_KETHKhqECQ.text: This place is awesome! Ive always seen there has been lines out the door soni decided to check out the popularity. The food here is spectacular! Cant wait to eat here again!  Saori is always my sever and she is awesome! Her hospitality is the best. She is super beautiful too! I love you....I mean youre awesome hahaha ;)

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dgAV8rT7AaqmKkC-9MAT4g.text: Monta never fails!  Great service and the food is always consistent. Being selfish, I only wish they had more side dishes... Eating at your favorite place there's only so much gyoza and fried rice you can eat!!

VX3AVG84-1LA-HvImTr86Q.text: Omg, what a great idea to come after a night of hard partying at EDC. My friend found Monta Ramen on Yelp, and once our whole crew woke up from drunken slumber, we hopped in our car and headed straight for ramen!!  I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen which is the most popular and also the Takana friend rice. The soup for the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen was a little bit salty, but the pork was the best thing ever. Wow, it is so tender and tasty, totally worth it- just don't finish the soup. I wish there were more pieces in my ramen, but you can always add more! Also, as recommended by our waitress, the Takana friend rice is a must. It was really delicious and I wish my stomach would have let me eat more.   Overall, Monta Ramen is a cute little ramen place in the Chinatown/ asia food area off the strip. The food is decent, great for hangovers and the service is also really friendly. Although where we sat is spacious, this place gets super packed. Prepare yourself for a wait because the restaurant is small and can only accommodate a few tables / seating at the bar at a time.

uFRT9W1bx1iG1gDVYGg7ew.text: The ramen is tasty, served quickly. Depending on what time you go you'll probably have to wait, seeting is very limited but worth the wait. Seems to be pretty common with most Ramen restaurants around the area.

VZZLMVw8DMl4OYeFPnFsJw.text: Ok, gave this place another try and I still have to say I'm not a devotee.   I did enjoy the ramen quite a bit, I daresay a little more than on my first visit. I got the tonkatsu and this time I avoided the mustard greens hoping to reduce the salty taste. Pretty good, but the broth is still a little too salty for me. My fella loved it and he'd probably give it a higher rating, so maybe it's just me.  It'll still be my go-to place for ramen in town though.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2bVTXJip-KQ-WrJ0ZyueMA.text: Yummy! Ramen noodles! The broth is sup@ delicious. If you like Minchin, the have an awesome dish of Kmchi fried rice! If you have small children they welcome the challenge to win them over with their house specialties. Ask the wait svc for the winning dishes...some clippings of news articles are hung up by the door which also informs you of what's good! One important tip...if you see that it's packed you must go to the podium and sign in.  And FYI it is a very quaint place (small) Seats are limited. And prepare to be face down in a bowl of Something Wonderful!

tKi_7W0RqYgXdd0WDSMHEw.text: Always delicious ramen here. The food is amazing. Place is super tiny which stinks when it's busy but otherwise no complaints. I love everything I've eaten here.

fBTR8no5Q4wqRXj6hQNY6Q.text: Absolutely love this joint! Besides the heavy wait this places is one of the best Ramen I've had in a while. You can choose from a few different Ramen broth and each with its own unique flavor. I personally enjoy shoyu Ramen it's light on the broth and not heavy. Give this place a try. I do recommend getting in early and putting your name on the list. Otherwise, be aware that you may not get in for a long time.

ouULDUPkrG9i8FLJgODR7g.text: I guess I had rather high expectations for this place, but it was just average for me. There was a waitlist for a table when we got there. The restaurant is rather tiny so the tables fill up fast. I saw several people come in just for a to go order. Every one in our group got the tonkotsu ramen. Hubs got extra chasu for his. The chasu was really fatty, which some people like but it isn't my cup of tea. The noodles were good but overall nothing spectacular.

XN9Aa1NXJPjhArgnl9Xxvw.text: On my last trip to Vegas, I finally got to eat at the legendary Monta Ramen. This place has been on my "to do" list since I lived here 3 yrs ago. I've tried at least a dozen times to go, but because this place is so small, the wait is usually very long and I'm not patient enough to wait in a long line for Ramen. However, this past trip we went at a great time in-between lunch/dinner when there was no wait list. I ordered: Small Fried Rice, $3.95 yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen, $7.25 yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... Miso Ramen (no meat), $7.25 yelp.com/biz_photos/mont... The portions here are much smaller than other Ramen places I've been to. If you're accustomed to the large portions in So Cal Ramen joints, be warned that the portions here is about 3/4 those portions. The Fried Rice was very good and hit the spot. The Ramen was very good, full of flavor. I had the Veggie Miso Ramen and it was awesome. The Better Half had the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen and she thoroughly enjoyed it as well. Other notes: They make the Ramen fresh to order, so it's a bit of a wait. There's also counter seating available for convenience. We sat at the counter and watched them make the dishes....pretty cool. Did it live up to the hype? It met my expectations and was definitely 4 Stars in my opinion. Return Factor - 80%

Tg6Owm7DSODsUBQcYHS4RA.text: Great hole in the wall ramen place. Had the shoyu ramen which was fantastic.  Service was great and I would return.  Great service.

_PYU_TDBaOmGWzh8gymX0Q.text: Always pack no matter what time of day. It's a good spot great quality broth. I enjoy the food plaza they are in. I always get the spicy miso ramen with an egg and nori with gyoza. Oishii

nuWohRtjBcET7KawCywTpg.text: So good! The noodles have the right amount of firmness and the broth is savory and rich. Not salty at all. This place is very small and tight so if you're out with a lot of friends, be ready to wait for a table. Service is fast and food is affordable. Best ramen I have had so far in Las Vegas.

nG0H6LPUpru7Q_FyR8GvEQ.text: I was really looking forward because this ramen place has a lot of reviews and remain 4 stars. However, I'm disappointed with ramen here. Noodle is too salty. It's not supposed to be this salty in balck garlic oil soup base ramen. Chyashu are too fatty. Spicy sauce in spicy ramen is Korean chili sauce????? I'm really confused. Definitely a "not coming back" restaurant.

hWr7JTBkMqaH8Kuu25u_-g.text: The food here is good, but I was surprisingly more satisfied with the kimchi fried rice than the ramen! The kimchi fried rice was so good that we ordered some to-go to eat as a snack. The ramen: noodles were good, chashu was good, broth was average. Gyoza was also a nice starter to share.  Don't come with a lot of people.... unless you are willing to wait... almost 2 hours....

JjF6Pj1E6_ZA_jeYr3ujRA.text: Amazing Ramen, the spicy tonkatsu was on point. Fast and efficient service. Staff is very friendly!

DYt_k1uSp-7hkiONYi6_gw.text: Very delicious Kyushu Ramen in America! Like I eat in Japan. You can go by ride or 203 RTC

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy tonkutsu ramen

1A3rSJguZibNDLex0ZY5aQ.text: Delicious!! The place was so small. I think it has about 20 seats includes bar table. So we expected to wait during weekends. Ramen was cooked perfectly, and the soup was good. We all like the tonkotsu, shoyu and miso ramen. Also tried the black garlic oil ramen but not as good as we thought.  Other dishes like fried rice, mentaiko and gyoza were good too. If a bowl of ramen can't fill you up, you can order extra ramen with just $1.5.

97IZ0A1LYIYQYwJHJ6Q1ig.text: What else can I say that hasn't been said yet? Yes, the wait is usually long. Yes, it is a small restaurant. And mostly yes, the amazing food makes up for all of that!!!!!   First timers DO NOT be turned off by the first impression. It is worth it all I it!!!!!
