0lXuo-ziUchRDhmX4bL3vQ.text: super nom. this was my intro to real Ramen now I feel like a real man. don't know where I'd be without this place. probs eating Top Ramen with msg like a little boy.

gXR6oDG_VU8U9xevDkLNDQ.text: Unfortunately, a place I used to think was near 5 stars and a reference standard for ramen in the US, was entirely disappointing today - quite embarrassing actually. For some reason, the soup was bland, extremely salty and not hot, the noodles seemed so so, the bamboo shoots were coarse, and the pork slices were extremely fatty. This extreme inconsistency from prior experiences leaves me wondering whether to ever bring guests to this place ever again. Perhaps there has been a change in chef?

O059WWwVfrc5had3ZYXDSw.text: How do you NEGATIVE rate this place?  "Monta Japanese Noodle House was shut down by the Southern Nevada Health District after a routine inspection found 47 demerits on March 12.  Violations included spoiled food, potentially hazardous food stored at improper temperatures and staff not properly washing their hands. Also among the citations, an inadequate number of hand washing sinks and ineffective pest control measures."   I went here once.. And some days later they shut the place down.. HECKA gross!

9gMwJRrI8f8H-d4w03wa6A.text: Best ramen my wife and I have had in the US. Amazing. Super cheap so get the add-ons

JyXnJ50EgWvzZlxNR6ebqw.text: Definitely yummy ramen and it comes out really fast, which is good because they only have 5 tables and maybe 10 seats at the bar, so they need to rotate people quickly. We went around 1pm on a Saturday and had to wait about 15 minutes for a seat.   Ordered the Miso Ramen and the broth was really good, but a bit too salty for my taste, but still really good. The pork was really good, and the noodles were best towards the end of the meal because they had gotten softer after soaking in the juices. Initially they were more Al dente.   Since this is my first visit to a ramen restaurant in las vegas, I'll probably try a different one the next time around so I have something to compare it to.

m_mbS3aTSNGccuebJ-mesQ.text: Great affordable ramen. Wait time is long during dinner time but that's a good sign I guess. Once you order, the food comes fast. The staff is friendly and you can see them making the food if you sit at the bar. Restaurant is on the small side.

zcytieFsb0Cq-haTHnVcLw.text: Awesome little place off the overpriced strip. Thanks to yelp we took a short cab ride and it was worth it. Had the Miso Ramen. Dont need to order extra noodles. Big portions to begin with and so tasty.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Miso Ramen

npEMPKx5RD52g6APcEl1mg.text: So G.O.O.D!!!   I wish we had a Monta Noodle House in my city!  I'm really jealous because I've been looking for a good Japanese Noodle place for YEARS and BOOM!  I found it.  However, it's in Vegas and not in the East Los Angeles County area :o(  I had the Tonkostsu with a Chicken/beef broth.  It was perfect!  The combination of a heavy beef broth with the lighter chicken broth was absolutely delightful.  The best part is the price.  It's a fair price for what you get and if you're in Vegas and don't want to pay all that money for a 'fancy' meal or get crappy buffet food.  Take a trip off the strip to try out this place.  It's well worth the trip and believe me, every time I come to Vegas this is going to be a must stop for me!  Cheers and Eat Responsibly!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

SaHqbYlPRuZz3gkUU1n1mw.text: Came to Vegas, cousin suggest that I come here .  Ummm ummm good ..the soup was thick full of flavor,, pork melts in your mouth and oh that kimchie fried rice , say no more just chow!

vQ-f9L3WzeLH_rHiIatpPQ.text: Have been coming here for 2 years. Place hasn't changed a bit. Still the best Ramen in town.

Z_LJ5STC_70nrJmOErrmhg.text: I found this place in the Vegas Weekly Magazine and knew i had to try it out after seeing great Yelp reviews.  Were my expectations met? YES! As soon as you walk in, you are immediately greeted by a very cute Japanese girl worker and are seated right away. The restaurant is small, but very cozy. We ordered the tonkotsu ramen with a boiled egg on the side and were very impressed at how delicious the bowl of soup was. Although the bowl only comes with two thin slices of pork, the pork itself is very tender and is soaked in that delicious broth making you savor each bite! The broth is cloudy like it should be and wasn't too salty or too bland for my taste. What really impressed me was the poached egg. The article talked about how perfectly poached the eggs were there and boy was he right! The egg was not too runny nor too cooked. The combination of the runny yolk and broth tasted like heaven in my mouth!   Overall, the food and service were excellent. It was also a very authentic experience for me since the worker's demeanor reminded me of my time in Japan. Very perky, always smiling and had a cute high pitched voice! Come here to enjoy a delicious bowl of ramen and experience a little taste of Japan!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen

EO5ctn6m_oCKNkO0XvgyvA.text: I blame Monta Ramen for my random cravings of ramen. A dish I thought people were insane to desire and stand in line for. I'm not one of those people I once judged. :( DAMN YOU Monta!  The vibe here is clean and chill. Describe this place in one word is impossible. There is always a wait here. The place packs the crowd and flavors. This isn't somewhere you want to go if your party exceeds more than 5-6 people.   The ramen is tasty and reasonable priced. The Kim Chee fried rice is delish! The gyoza is pretty tasty too.   If you plan on headed here for some dinner and casual conversation...don't. Enjoy the dinner but take your casual conversation elsewhere because sitting their too long and not eating is just being selfish to people who also want to indulge in the warmth and tastiness of Monta Ramen!

IWk6n0e6iXdc4LCbyFjIww.text: First things first. 1. I've never had ramen til now. 2. This is my first review as an Elite woohoo!  Maybe I had higher expectations of this place, even though I had nothing to compare it to other than the ramen you get for .20 at the local grocery store. It was good. Very good even. I ordered the pork/chicken broth ramen add corn and butter. I ate the entire bowl and would order it again. I personally chose to add a little chile oil and whatever that mixed seasoning at the table was. It def improved my broth which needed the extra umph. The pork in the soup was not my style. The fatty skin reminded me of duck, which I don't like the skin of. Everything else in the soup was yummy and ill consider adding extra mushrooms and maybe an egg next time.  Good prices, I'd much rather go order a $7 bowl of ramen, versus buying all those ingredients and doing it myself. However, how often do I eat ramen is really the question here, maybe that's why I expected it to be something more than basic. Ill consider ramen again, as long as I don't have to wait (which you usually do considering they have like 6 tables) or possibly order it Togo. I did notice that was an option. Next time ill try Sora or Fukumimi.

R8pFu57-J8y9EAp7m9ilEg.text: I liked it! Some people might find it salty and broth a little too thick. But I lived in Japan for a year, this is authentic Japanese Ramen to me! And they can always add a little hot water if it's too thick, just like in Japan.

Xrh9kd-mM108_wukhaLrRQ.text: I dream of Ramen!! What can I say, if you're hankering for good ramen then go here and get your fix. I prefer the thicker noodles because it reminds me of the saimin I grew up eating. Broth is tasty with just the right amount of salt. Omg mouth watering while writing this review.

7QWToiW9fs9CVGVT994Tfg.text: Good f**kin tonkotsu ramen, nuff said. Go try!!!

zpLJVogoEcIvGu6PlBI4gg.text: I moved to Las Vegas from LA last year. This is easily the BEST restaurant I have been to!

fkQDQxxEZ4rfsuufYb4prw.text: Definitely had to find a Japanese Ramen place in my new locale.   Luckily, some friends were in town and wanted to come back to their ramen house of choice.   Simple menu options and great appetizers selection.   I had the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen and had a few spoonfuls of the Takana rice, which were both flavorful and delicious.   They request that your full party is there before you're seated, even had a bar to sit at which was quite nice for the smaller parties.   Will come back to this place when I need my ramen fix.

nfi7OSgyKFW4ZrHqzRBNyA.text: Great food, friendly staff, decent atmosphere. Only bad comment is that it is really small space.

Gw6TF0QTyujXchvmZ23E_g.text: With all the five-star reviews, I had high expectations for this joint's fabled tonkotsu.  And it was an epic fail.  Traditional tonkotsu has a thick soup base made of pork bones that takes more than 24 hours to make. This version is watery.  Traditional tonkotsu has this mix of flavors that leaves you feeling satisfied, and wanting for more. This version is too salty, and I left with a stomach discomfort.  I'd like the next set of yelp reviewers to be honest with themselves when I say that there is a FECAL aftertaste to this place's pork topping.  In short, I would have been better off buying the 50 cent Nissin instant noodles, top it with some meat, and feel happier.  For a comparison of a good tonkotsu, if you can't travel to Japan, try Daikokuya in Los Angeles' Little Tokyo, and your taste buds will be blown by the difference.  I will not eat here again.

UqG0YgcFiOzrreS0z86PZA.text: While visiting Las Vegas I was doing research on Ramen restaurants on yelp and kept reading about everyone who had a positive and delicious experience at Monta Ramen.  Today I made the trip with my brother.  We got here about 10 minutes after they opened and found the last remaining table.  The place was already packed.  After looking at the menu I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen which is a rich pork broth with two slices of melt in your mouth pork with wood-ear mushrooms and scallions.  I added the Nitamago which is a seasoned hard-boiled egg.  This meal did not disappoint.  It came to the table within 10 minutes and was a great looking bowl of ramen.  Very savory and fresh.  We also had the Gyoza  which is a pan-fried pork and vegetable dumpling.  My brother ordered the Takana pork-fried rice.  This rice was a nice addition to our ramen bowls.    Just a note:  As our ramen bowls were delivered I looked up and noticed that Monta Ramen must have a lot of fans because the little doorway was filled with people waiting to eat but the line also went out the door.   Knowing what I do now about how delicious this ramen is I would have gladly waited outside for my turn to enjoy this bowl.    Monta Ramen will definitely be on my list to visit the next time I come to Las Vegas.  Can't wait to bring my wife here.  Very affordable.  I recommend.

cx7qK-FbOx9sG2ijVhfCsw.text: Excellent ramen. Best Ive ever had!  Tiny place, busy and very warm. But excellent food! Q

pzh1qx6PhNjc24z_Mq1W0g.text: A small, simple place with extraordinarily good noodles. The menu is limited, but oh so full of goodness. If you add an egg to your ramen, it makes the richness even more so. One bowl is more than enough to fill even a large eater. Sooo good!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Most excellent ramen!

syvEXJ3tYfk2bvSTDKwTQw.text: Ramen was cooked to perfection, broth was rich and flavorful. Noodles were perfect size and cooked perfect. 10/10 would recommend, my eyes rolled back as I took the first sip

lJGvnr3590wQmCk4gfIing.text: Everything we ordered was excellent. The Kuro Ramen was garlic heaven. Tonkotsu Ramen was  excellent. The kids loved the Chashu Pork Bowl and the Pork Belly Bowl.  Will be back here definitely. The price is very affordable as well.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Kkz7A-GpumxFUagT_43AlA.text: I used to love this place. But, i guess not anymore. I always dont mind to wait to eat here in very long line during the dinner time. But, from today I won't come back this place never. I just went to eat my favorite ramen like 10 mins ago. They were busy as always even they just opened. My party was the last seated table before they got so busy. Since they just opened, people were waiting to order or to get their food. It was understandable to wait to order food to server until one of the server just yelled at us "it's first come first serves, so wait please" I was like okay..? I didn't even ask you anything all i did is just had some eye contact but okay I'm cool. But, when she finally take our order, she didn't even wait until i finished my order. And, when i asked her for two iced water with lemon, she answered " no lemon" while she was walking away from our table. That was such a disrespectful manner as a server. I would understand if she just said the same answer while she was standing side to us. After that, again they were busy, so we waited for the food not too long, but a just little bit. But, even she delivered wrong food to our table and we asked her if she is sure it's ours. And, as before, she just answered "yes" while she walking away from table. I was okay with that. But, i was sure that it was not mine. And guess what. She just came back to our table saying sorry it's not mine and grabbed the bowl to give to the other customer. Finally, we got our food. Food was delicious as always. But, all the servers, they never come to us to make sure if we are okay with everything except when we are paying the bill. Like i said, it is understandable that i cannot expect such an amazing customer service. But, it's different and such a disrespectful to customer when it's repeated on same day. I did not want to tip to server. But, food was good. So, i tipped to the chefs who worked so hard in the kitchen.

B-J0PZh85foTZ41td3is8g.text: This place is by far my absolute favorite place to eat! They are cheap and tasty! Try the Kim chi! Or the spicy tonkatsu!

fbxhfmxRcUK7SJSWx0YoOg.text: I've probably been to Monta Ramen about 20+ times now, and in my opinion it's the best ramen noodle shop in town (Fukumimi does come close in my opinion....more on that in another review.   The Food (5 out of 5): I usually order either the Tonkotsu Shoyu or the Miso Ramen and then add an egg. I absolutely love their broth (I am a big fan of salt after all). At times, we will order gyoza and/or fried rice to go along with our orders of ramen, and that is usually a good way to round out the meal.  The Service (4 out of 5): I love how fast the turnover of tables is after a patron as left because there is usually a line of people waiting to get in. This is my only True gripe about Monta; I just wish that they had just a little more seating room. HINT: If you go here for lunch, they open at 11:30am......just make sure that you are a couple of minutes early otherwise you will be waiting about 20-30 mins to get seated.  The Price (5 out of 5):  Ok, I guess that this could be better if it were FREE, but come on, that's not going to happen! But, you shouldn't be paying any more than $20 pp here (more like $10-12 pp if you're not getting any extras and/or having water as your drink).   OVERALL: Monta Ramen is at the top of the pack for Japanese ramen noodle shops in Las Vegas in my opinion!

K91DIOGEJpc9mieDg5P3NQ.text: Don't come here for the tonkotsu ramen.   We came here for lunch and the wait was about 40 minutes.  The service was quick and friendly but the place felt a bit dirty, was a bit dark, and the seating was very cramped together.    I ordered the tonkotsu ramen with flavored eggs and seaweed.  Do Not Order this.   The broth was disappointingly salty and thick.   Seriously salty!  I had to go through 2 full cups of water and I still felt that wasn't enough.   After 1/3 of the way, I had to eat the ramen without the broth, which was unfortunate because the broth is what makes the ramen.  On the upper side, the noodles and eggs were perfectly cooked!  Would I come back?  Probably not.   Again, don't order the tonkotsu ramen unless you want to be on a sodium high.

zMij1MPcPgK4y4TLdT_bew.text: Small ramen restaurant but can definitely hit the spot. Be sure to account for the wait but if you want to sit at the bar you might get lucky. Would recommend going during off peak hours so you can get seated quick. The ramen isn't as salty as others but it is still pretty tasty. I didn't leave this place thirsty like I normally do for other ramen places.

3YfB7VEQZh7YRpyB9bzSdQ.text: Had heard really great things about this place and had eaten at Ramen Tatsu the weekend before. I have to say, this place did not live up to the review hype. Don't get me wrong, the soup here is good, but not amazing. The broth is much fattier than the broth at Ramen Tatsu and I did not like that. It's also much more crowded and noisy, neither of which I like. I'm not sure id go out of my way to go back.

QLKHnoTJISFPcsEm78GQ3A.text: Soooo good! Tiny little ramen shop. About 7 parties on the list in front of us but the wait wasn't too bad. Tried the Tonkotsu shoyu ramen and the miso ramen. The pork in the ramen was melt in your mouth good! Gyozas were generously filled & delicious. Tried their calamari-best I've ever had! Presentation was good. Efficient, friendly service. Huge parking lot and a good value. Loved this place!

dZ8sGElimutv5AhE6pFeFA.text: HANDS DOWN MY FAVORITE RAMEN PLACE IN VEGAS!  I keep coming back for either the Pork Belly bowls or the Tonksu Shoyu! The taste and flavor always amazes me, I've tried soo many other ramen places but this one takes the cake! And adding extra sides is not the bad on price!

XZPJkwTVIzt1EGXat8IC4Q.text: We were able to be seated when it opened and were very excited to try the food. We didn't realize the place was sooo small and it was so stuffy upon arrival.   The pork belly bowl was good, melts in your mouth, but that was where it ended.  Ordered the Tonkotsu, Tonkotsu Shuyo and Kuro Black Garlic Oil Ramen. I have had ramen before, so I am not sure what all the hype is about.  The noodles were ok but the soup was so thick and salty. Isn't it supposed to be a light broth? Mine sure wasn't.   After we left, my husband started get tummy aches and cold sweats, sounds like a bought of food poisoning to me.  We won't be back.

Scy05TOJHt1mlsXsSOO3Tg.text: Best Tonkotsu ramen I've had on the west coast.  The broth was unbelievable... Thick but not overwhelming.  The noodles were perfectly done.  Unfortunate that the egg I've included but the prices were very friendly.  Would repeat.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu ramen.

RiJUhHHAdUrkzOYvKr6vOA.text: Ramen is good. Pork Belly bowl is best! If ur rolling ten deep go mid afternoon - only way u'll get in! Broth rocks -  Tonkatsu shoyu is my fave. Spicy Tonkatsu is decent.  I suggest switching to the thicker noodles - much better in my view.  The fried rice and gyoza is notable as well. This review is a lil' late as I hadn't realized it was still in my draft pile.  Monta is amazing - I'll def be back the next time I'm in Vegas!

OLY5h_XD_88l3d3YjDgvVQ.text: When I walked into this place I suspected it was run by Koreans. How did I guess? They served dogs. I don't mean that the flesh of canine is declared an option on the menu, but that they served Koreans, and owner, those surreptitious eyes, the stink of deceit that crowns his air of pretense, that's what I mean.  The noodles were stringy, the broth blooming with oil vessels and the char-siu portions niggardly (I can say that word only because I'm black and East Coast educated).  I would recommend Fukumimi for the woody ambience and specials, or I could recommend Misoya-Tomi for their customer loyalty program, but this place is a crowded dump with teak wood benches that need a massage of Old English and customers that haven't evolved away from being too familiar and conspecific with the species of c. lupus.   Anyways. Come if you like lines and mediocre ramen.

vFy3260Dh9GA_ysKxktvMA.text: Best ramen in vegas, hands down, don't care what ppl say, i always recommend this place, especially after a bad hangover from the night before.  I always order the same thing:  Gyoza = perfectly cooked add a little soy sauce w/ chili oil and its a perfect match  Tonkotsu-shoyu ramen and add an egg and nori and it could not be any better. Service is always friendly, and wait is never too long usually. worth the wait if you have to wait though. Not a good place for parties of more than 4, more of a place for 2 ppl so you can do the bar if need be.   Best thing is food always comes out quick and never disappointed. Small place, when you are inside you don't feel like your in vegas at all. And that is a great feeling, especially for someone who has been here for 8 years already.

2R7jmX0Ob26_SxEzMX-rQQ.text: Ramen and waiting in line seem to come hand in hand anywhere but his place is definitely worth the wait.  Menu-  On different occasions I had the shoyu ramen and tonkotsu ramen. I definitely prefer the tonkotsu ramen. So much more flavor!!! Kaedama is a plus. Service -  Once you are seated, they get you in and out pretty quickly. They are really good about filling your water glass, I've noticed a lot of ramen places tend to forget about the water. Ambiance- Small with very little tables. The counter space tends to have quicker turn around so if you are going there solo or as a couple you will get seated a lot quicker.  Other-  Parking is easy and this lot has quite a bit of restaurants. While waiting for your table, walk about the area and plan your next meal.

yo2dZNtIVgw71TwdPrBozw.text: I'm not a big fan of Monta, maybe it's because I get sick every time I come here and eat something with the charsui (which I figured out after I was about to give up). Everyone else claims it's the best ramen in Las Vegas, maybe, but I haven't been to enough places around to say for certain just yet. So far it's a no for me, because of the way I get sick.  Growing up in Japan with a Chinese family, I know what good ramen tastes like and they're decent but when they're busy the noodles are hard (not cooked long enough) which I hate, they have to be consistant! And on top of that I can't eat the charsui without getting sick which then it's game over for me for the day, so it usually ends with me giving it away to someone.   So like I said, when it's busy they're not that consistant because they're trying to keep up with the demand and not be slow, but it shows in their cooking. I always get gyoza with my ramen and would feel weird if I didn't! Something I've done since I was a little child, besides the pair together taste great!   The soup base itself is light as it should be, though sometimes I feel it's a bit salty (maybe my Asian taste buds were a little too active then, but it's good. Also depends on the one you want, I'm pretty traditional and don't stray from the shoyu (soy sauce base). The noodles is a hit and miss, since they're usually busy and rarely not, though I like going when most people aren't eating, the noodle can be either perfect or too hard for me. People like their noodles differently and not many places give you an option (very few in Japan do), but like I said hit and miss usually it's okay.   Outside of their regular toppings you can add extra stuff like corn, butter, green onions, etc for some extra costs which isn't much at all! They also have kaedame which is a second helping of noodles, but you need to leave some soup base and not drink it if you're going to do that.  Overall the price for what you get is decent and not too bad especially comparing it to places in Japan. My only complaint is that the charsui gets me sick every time I've eaten it and since I've stopped it's been okay.

P0PzS9uGgAcPyQ0pzV-YYw.text: Amazing ramen. We go here again and again and again. If you're in Chinatown or across the highway on the strip looking for a ramen fix this place definitely hits the spot. Sometimes a bit of a wait, and you can't call ahead. But worth it. The ayce Korean BBQ right next door is also extremely good but sometimes has an equally long wait.

k-c9TYGBpsgi6TsgEbh5GA.text: Very good ramens here and this restaurant is so busy. But it's good. When you wait you can have some snacks near by. But you not wait for long time.

WNvAr-MDPup-8RcEkm1QLw.text: MY MUST GO PLACE in Vegas. I have to come here every time I go to Vegas no matter how out of the way it is off the strip. I always get the spicy ramen which never disappoints. The broth was kind of on a thicker side than other place but was not super heavy, definitely so well seasoned. The meat obviously had a lot of fat on it but you can always take out the fat if you don't want to eat it. The ramen overall was not full of toppings but I did not mind it. The noodles itself was nice and chewy, went so well with the broth. The service was super fast per usual since there are always so many people in line.   Overall Taste 5/5 Service 5/5 super fast but I never felt like we were rushed to get out Parking 4/5 kind of small lot for the amount of business there Price 5/5 so worth it!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

vo8eaYsF69BiW5HlacktLg.text: It's such a pleasure to come here while I'm visiting family in Vegas. It's usually a bit of a wait to get in but it's well worth it. The quality of the ramen and broth is AMAZING, and they have some of the most delicious fried rice I've ever had. I will continue to come here time after time.

DJGqlK4_VSbwMDyrCUyVKw.text: Monta probably deserves a good rating by default just for the novelty of having a kurume ramen spot in Las Vegas, but it's also a very good one. Kurume style ramen is a product of Fukuoka prefecture, so there are many similarities to other Fukuoka styles like Hakata, such as the thin, dense noodles (think Ippudo) - but a defining characteristic of Kurume is that the tonkotsu tends to be less oily/fatty than Hakata tonokotsu. Kurume style is still creamy and rich, but the mouth feel of less oil/fat allows for more of the meat flavor to come through. Monta definitely gets this right.  Unfortunately, Monta is a small shop and quite popular, so it's often busy and crowded. Even on weekdays I'll often find that there's a line by noon - so I'd definitely get there right at opening if you don't want to wait (as long).  Now if only the owners/management can get their act together and relocate Monta Chaya (and keep us updated about it), if nothing else than to reduce the crowds at this Monta...

hye-LdbDS3-fM_JkD4jJDA.text: Our first meal in Vegas. I had high expectations for this place due to the ratings. It's a small, hole in the wall place. We camre pretty late, and they were busy but the wait for a party of three wasn't too long. I order the Tonkatsu ramen with corn and I have to say, there was nothing that wowed me. I've had better. I did like how cheap and fast it was but other than that, meh.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_qs4AWai23p4bwrzQtBJAQ.text: This by far is the best ramen in town. Based on the most recent reviews, I was kind of concerned by the quality of ramen here, but nevertheless I gave it a go. Starting off, the chasu bowl was amazing, fall apart  tender. Next, the ramen broth was very creamy and rich. The noodles had perfect chewiness to it and the toppings complimented the dish well. One problem was that the black garlic ramen had too much of a garlic flavor which made it very overpowering and there was too little chasu on the bowl.  Overall this place deserves a go!

fPzZ9u9U-YBwAyYAHJGhzQ.text: 2018-03-23 Friday at 11:10pm. I gave 2 stars for quality on ramen and their bad service. When I was just finished my ramen and taking my beer for finishing, the waitress came and took my bowl that was annoying and she wanted to push me to check out. However, no one was sitting at any tables and I was sitting at bar with some customers. There was no need to push me out while the restaurant was not busy.   I had Tonkotsu Ramen as my late night dinner at Monta Ramen. Mmm........ the soup didn't taste so Japanese Tonkotsu (as I know Japanese food for 29 years). As usual, all people inside kitchen were Hispanics. Although the reviews for this ramen shop were good, their quality of ramen was not that good to me. Not authentic. The only good thing that I thought  was the prices on ramen and beer. The basic ramen with 2 slices of pork Cha-Shiu, Black kikurage bamboo shoots, and green onions was only $6.95 + Tax & Tips. I added flavored egg  $1.50, corn  $0.50, and Nori (dried seaweed) $0.75.  The about 12 oz Asahi Draft beer  was only $2.95 + Tax & Tips. If I had both ramen and beer in New York City, I would need to pay about $24 including Tax & Tips. But today I only paid $15.59 including Tax&Tips. The quality against the low prices was acceptable but please don't expect too much. I would like to pay more for real authentic ramen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

g4G61iGZNAFZ-RGszcEDtg.text: Little ramen shop, BIG flavor. I ordered the Kuro Ramen (tonkotsu with black garlic oil I believe) and it was A1! My food came out super quick and service was excellent. Broth wasn't too heavy and was very hot upon being served, which is crucial to me. Chashu was thin and and flavorful, noodles perfect. I'm shaking my head at how good the ramen was. A+. Will be back!  EDIT: I forgot to mention how much lower the prices are here compared to other ramen shops in general. Cherry on top of the whole dining experience.

cAV00D8GZSjslLwO9lLzJg.text: Authentic, busy, quick, off the strip but so worth it! Awesome prices for some ch flavorful ramen and rice
