21cngDU2xNYWvGsX5_FRVQ.text: Been coming here for a few years, they never disappoint, expect long waits during prime eating hours.  Best fried rice in town, amazing ramen.

jUd5X1EvcIgezRmMajul0A.text: Came in here for a late business lunch, wasn't even super busy like usual. Just as I sit down the waiter literally plays the role of hero and CONFRONTS me about having a 1/4 full can of monster energy with me.  He told me straight up I either need to "down it" or throw it out. I was so taken back that I thought I was on the show Punk'd. I wouldn't mind tossing it but first of all the rule is dumb. I'm a 32 year old businessman with plenty of money, I can afford (and even offered) to buy a drink from their restaurant if it was going to be a real problem.  They weren't accepting of that and continued to harass me about having any outside drink. The waiter said that there's a sign as I was in, but the sign is barely visible as it's off to the left and looks like it was drawn by a kindergartener.  I must have eaten here over 100 times since living in Vegas for the past 10 years, but no more will I patronize this establishment. I'm a strong believer in the notion that I vote with my dollar and I'm not voting for this place ever again unless they change their predatory rule.

gcSyh_28CMKUjQOti9_ofw.text: I honestly junk there's nothing special about the ramen. I ordered the spicy ramen and a mini Mentaiko bowl. The broth is very salty and the ramen texture is rather rubbery. The mini meitako rice is better ham the ramen (although some of the rice is kind of hard and dry).

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mentaiko bowl

L2x-G4fi5C_pELTI3nK24A.text: There is so much to love about Monta, the only downside is the wait. But this is obviously due to popularity and the size of the restaurant.  I have had Noodles and ramen all over Vegas and this is by far in the top three for Noodle choices here in town for you Noodle junkies out there like me.  I believe in sticking with what works so I normally order the same thing but I have tried everything on their menu.  My normal order consists of the Mini Mentaiko Bowl which is amazing, the Takana Fried Rice (quite possibly the best fried rice in Las Vegas), and the Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen (I cannot put into words how excellent this Bowl of Noodles is.) Though a little tricky to find, make sure you check this place out, I promise you that you will go back again and again!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. What the bowl looks like after a night out at Monta! The Tonkatsu Shoyu Ramen is epically delectable!

keIR6_2FukfI8toN7VK2Uw.text: Food: 6/10 Service: 7/10 Value: 6/10 Ambience: 6/10  TL;DR - Small place with average ramen with overpriced toppings  Very small and cozy restaurant. Be prepared to wait a long time if you go with a party of 3 or more. We came with 4 and had to wait for one of the four-seat tables to vacate. It was kind of awkward standing in a cramped entrance staring down folks who are eating in your to-be seats.  I ordered the black ramen just to try something new, but it was unflavorful. By the time I finished adding condiments, it pretty much became a Thai noodle soup.  The overall service was nice and quick, though none of the servers were smiling.  I probably won't be back on my next Vegas trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Inside
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tasteless kuro ramen was tasteless

ClD9oQawBY9ur3BUFRUvPA.text: My review is a little bit biased because I've been spoiled by all the great ramen restaurants in the bay area and socal.   Honestly, the ramen here is good. It's not great though. Nothing really stands out.   Be ready to wait to get seated as the place isn't huge.   Customer service was good. However, they definitely try to get everyone in and out.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Black Garlic Ramen

WcmtXtTNgHLCpmrorXzCuQ.text: Alright, this place is strictly ramen and fried rice. And the occasion beer. There are no desserts, although, this place is located in the wonderful haven of food places all right next to each other. And there are dessert places within the complex.   To me, their Tonkostu broth is very think and heavy. If you prefer your broths on the heavier side, this place is for you.   I prefer their Shoyu ramen where the broth is chicken stock. It's not to heavy.   Mind you, this place is usually packed so you have to be a little patience, but overall, this place isn't to bad.   I'd still prefer other ramen places though. When I get the chance, I'll share my other ramen experiences.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

UhoGfD0RK2XpgHa3CUGeZg.text: Heard so much about ramen in Las Vegas, I had to try while I was in town. I bookmarked 3 ramen shops for what it seemed like high rating while I was in a conference. Due to limited time on Yelp search, I didn't read anyone's reviews, just quickly bookmarked highest rated 3.  I picked this one as it was closest from the hotel I was staying. After I ordered my food, the person who sat next to me at the counter said so much good thing about this place over other places I bookmarked.  Gyoza was good.  I gave a piece to a stranger sat next to me as he gave me this look that he wanted to try.  Ramen..... Well broth was nice and hot... I ate ramen as soon as I took one picture but noodle was soft. It's Hakata thin noodle, perhaps I should have requested barikata (very hard) for my noodle. If their noodle was al dente, I would have given this place 4 stars.  After I was done eating I finally saw some reviews from some of my favorite yelpers. They all rated 3... Ah of course.  I looked at the stranger next to me, he ate so slow, his noodle looked soggy.  Either he doesn't know how to eat ramen in Japanese way or too busy talking to me.   If you like ramen in Japanese way, may want t ask to cook noodle al dente to fully enjoy it's texture.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Open kitchen. Limited seating inside
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hakata ramen with thin noodles

paGTvH9WELgoR1B5DzLrCg.text: Excellent ramen. Great service and the food comes out fast. They have to cause this place gets crowded but the turnover is fast. Definitely worth the wait.

68s20X6N5IlAHGr0ELvSRg.text: What do three people exhausted do after a whole day walking on the strip? Yelp good places to eat that is...  This place did not disappoint! The ramen was delicious and with prices staring at $6.95 you really can't go wrong with that!  My friend ordered the shoyu ramen and said it was a perfect balance of soy sauce...not too salty which sometimes tend to be the case for other ramen places.  We all loved the chasu pork. Tender, melt-in-your-mouth delicious.  We thought of going back again but of course we had to head back home to the Bay. When we're back in the area, we will definitely go back to Monta!

U5UW_P5ObnrxeO6_w6UgxQ.text: !!! Oishi (Delicious) Been coming here for 3-4 years now, mostly for lunch. The tonkotsu is my go to dish, with a hearty broth, & tender slices of pork. I add the shredded onions for a buck extra. Their fried rice is top notch, Prices are very reasonable, it's hard to spend more than $10 unless you're drinking beer. Get there at 1130am right when they open, or after 2 pm. It's a small spot with limited seating, but they run things efficiently & I've never waited more than 25 minutes at their busiest times.

-UfbVfcnE2j2D5hkmPW4AA.text: Get ready to wait a while for a table (we waited almost an hour for two people). The place was packed, and tiny. However, the food was fantastic. I got the Tonkotsu-Shoyu Ramen, and the ramen broth is incredibly rich, thick, and tasty. It's creamy, which isn't a texture I normally associate with ramen broth. The noodles are delicious and the toppings are on point. My friend got the Kuro Ramen - Black Garlic Oil which was even better than mine. It was well worth the wait!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Time to eat some ramen!

kbdD7SmLCKfW7ajTiRwZjg.text: Legit! All I need to say. Thin noodle fans go hurr. I like the broth here better than Sora. Sora has the curly thick noodles but I'm overall the broth and flavor is better here.

6e-nJfKFVV0PSj_vjV9bog.text: Food is fantastic, but it is definitely a hole in the wall. This location is tiny and you will most likely have to wait 20-30 minutes just to be seated. Staff is friendly most of the time, but due to the high pace, they are extremely busy. Also wish they had more variety within the menu, but if you'd prefer to wait, the food is worth it.

MxKAKwzMI7tys7VX2gG0sg.text: How have I never heard of Chinatown in Vegas or never knew how close it was to The Strip?! I mean it's not walking distance, but it's a short cab ride about 2-3 miles away.  Thanks to one of my friends' extended knowledge, we decided to grab ramen in Chinatown at her favorite place, Monta. The shop isn't particularly big and I guess people heard about the hype so there can be a 20-40 minute wait a lot of the time.   I got the tonkatsu ramen and the base price is such a great deal at just $6.75. I added corn for $1 extra and my friend and I also shared the fried rice. You also have to purchase green tea and it comes hot in a can (so interesting). Still, after all that, our total was $32 after tax which is such a great deal!   If there's a long wait, there's a boba place next door thats really good so you can kill time there. Since we only waited about 20 minutes, we left the boba for after dinner :)

-XMP7hQDAul4BWy2AqkeeQ.text: Monta was an unexpected delight!  We were in the area for Kung Fu Tea and were in the mood for dinner and stumbled upon this Ramen spot, conveniently 2 stores over.  It's a small restaurant which makes for a more intimate setting but we were seated within 15 min wait.  The ramen comes out super fast, I think maybe 5 minutes of ordering, so you can definitely have a quick dinner here.  I ordered the Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen and was very happy with my choice.  Flavor of the broth was light/tasty and the thin noodles were a great texture.  Service was great, they checked in on us often and refilled our waters when necessary.  All in all a good eats in the Las Vegas area.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu

YcFvbT8flsbq3AHF82slIg.text: The broth is A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! Best I've had so far.   It's like I can taste the bone marrow.  Hole in the wall. Go early.

y32fBipTnVv-WaMe2cmENw.text: Best ramen in town. After trying other ramen bars in Las Vegas, I'm sure this is my favorite one. The flavor is so authentic and the service is really fast and effective. Also, the price is so reasonable! Go and check it out, you won't be disappointed! The place is pretty small so you'll probably have to wait between 15 and 30 minutes to get a seat, so keep that in mind.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu shoyu with corn and nori

3vCKGOGszNLootpQofNBZQ.text: Very delicious ramen and cheap! I liked it here. I had the spicy ramen with extra pork, seaweed and egg. The broth was really good and consistent. Pork was well seasoned and cooked. No complaints about the food at all, I want to try more ramen from this place.  The only thing was that it is a small restaurant and kind of crowded. Also very busy... But that's not really a bad thing. It means business is good, and that's probably because the food is great and prices are cheap

9My6-UX3zP5k6v5Y7yUwzA.text: So many visitors to Las Vegas rarely leave the strip to find the True treasures that please the soul (no not adult clubs). The Spring Mountain Road strip mall location where Monta Ramen is located is seemingly blessed because it features two authentic and amazing food locales that I was lucky enough to bet on two food-tastic nights with my friends.    Monta Ramen is the real deal! So amazing is the Kuro (tonkatsu with black garlic oil) that you will definitely want to add a Kenadama (extra noodles) to help you get as much of that magical elixir that is perfect after a night out partying or before a night out. The broth is creamy and smooth and made with great effect to give it surprising "I can't stop eating" umami flavor. I would have loved it if the noodles which should almost always be the star of the ramen experience were slightly larger but so strong was the broth's performance that I didn't care.  The other great thing about this place is that this bowl only cost about $8 at the time that I am writing this. Add a 5 spice cured soft boiled egg for even more creamy richness.  Thanks Monta Ramen - Domo Arigato! *bow low*

wWiPTMZ3s9drA1g8FGDSDw.text: I would happily rate this place higher but the fact that they don't have hot tea (they said they could heat up their canned tea. What?!) and especially, consistently the ramen is never hot. Health code obviously dictates that the toppings/ingredients must be kept cool to avoid foodborne illness, so to compensate for that, why not heat up that wonderful broth more??! Once it is added, within a few minutes you're dealing with an indulgent bowl of noodles that's barely above lukewarm. Ramen, unlike Pho, is heavy on fat and salt and starch, so to really enjoy it, it's gotta be hot hot hot!

VfigVD0K18BiQiXibQ5y_g.text: Our last day in Vegas, Wifey wanted something different from The Strip and away from The Strip.   I was in the mood for some good Mexican, but I was overruled as Wifey wanted Ramen. I scoffed at the notion of a good Ramen joint existing in Vegas. I crave for good Ramen, and so far the best I've had to date was from Santouka Ramen in LA. The Ramen joints in The City are a joke, but thank god for San Mateo as my only salvation for good Ramen.   So when Wifey found this place, I was very skeptical; but I had no choice since she won all the money in Vegas that pretty much paid for our trip and then some.   So we drove to Vegas' Chinatown district and one thing I noticed is that the blocks are like a frigging mile long. Damn...the blocks are so far apart I felt like I was in the desert.   So we arrived and it's in a small strip mall similar to those found all over California (looks promising) and definitely qualifies as a Hole-In-The-Wall joint. The place is small...more tiny than small with a seating of about 20 + at a time. It was around lunch and the place was packed. I also observed a squad car illegally parked and had me worried for a second thinking it was a crime-ridden area and had an incident in progress. My guard subsided when I saw two of Vegas' finest slurping the Ramen inside.   We waited for approximately 20-25 minutes before we got called and I was famished. I was already eyeing the 'Daily Special" board of Kuro Ramen and Spicy Tonkutso Ramen (both $7.95). Sold! Wifey also ordered a side of Tonkutso Pork over a bowl of rice.   The side order arrived first and what we got was a pile of pork meat on top of rice topped with Nori strips. Ummmm....Anthony Bourdain would approve of this.   Then our Ramen arrived and all my skepticism disappeared and what I felt next was envy. I was envious that Vegas can have a better Ramen joint than San Francisco. Then envy turned into sadness, which turned into me slurping the noodles to comfort my emotional needs at that time.   The broth was amazing. Unlike the broths in The City that are overly salty, this one was creamy, thick, rich but also tasted light. How could that be? It wasn't rich, thick and heavy as one would expect. All I can say is wow. It truly made a believer out of me. I also tasted the Wifey's broth and the roller coaster of emotion began again.   This one really surprised me in a good way.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Tonkotsu Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kuro Ramen
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Bowl over Rice

2Dne2327tqpcPurz7MJDlg.text: Amazing! First time having Ramen and it was amazing. Not to mention the prices are great and the atmosphere is too. 3 of us had ramen and a beer and the bill was under $40. The place is super tiny and packed but we were seated quickly and service was great too. This is my new favorite Vegas food spot.

lxu9JOzaWQyqLGP3v1L7bg.text: The food was good, service was fast... but the seating is very limited.   HIS & HERS: We both ordered the same thing -- SHOYU RAMEN. The soup is very flavorful & topped with green onions, two slices of chashu, bamboo shoots and kikurage. Added EGG, NORI SEAWEED & CORN. So good!   Most likely my favorite ramen place in Vegas! Can't wait to go back again!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Monta Ramen!

MlkhITJe1RSS0_9vSSzL2Q.text: Due to the cold weather, we knew we wanted to have something warm for dinner... like ramen and ended up Yelp-ing Monta Ramen. You're not going to find anything else in comaprison on The Strip anyways. (Thanks fellow Yelpers for the recommendations too!)  It was already packed on a Monday night around 7pm but the wait did die down around 7:30pm. It's a very small restaurant with 5 or so tables plus seating along the L-shaped counter area.   Since I'm a fan of thick chewy noodles, I ordered the Shoyu Ramen. The only other ramen with thick wavy noodes was the Miso Ramen. The Tonkatsu and tonkatsu shoyu came with thin noodles. Basic toppings include two slices of pork chashu, black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, and green onions.   We also split the Kimchi friend rice but you can pass on this. It was so-so in my opinion. The ramen, however, hit the spot. The broth was very flavorful and the noodles were perfect! Who knew we would find such a great ramen place in Las Vegas in the Chinatown area.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Shoyu ramen (chicken broth) with thick chewy ramen noodles

OKjxn3v5tZJnV9DdZXeM_Q.text: come for their RAMEN and make sure when you order you ask for the squiggly noodles, made that mistake today.  I ate the cold noodles two years ago and they def hit the spot on a HOT day in vegas.   This time I went for the spicy tonkatsu....the flavor was so balanced and then to make it spicy they put some of that korean hot pepper paste that sets it on fire from the inside of the bowl and out.  I cannot wait for Monta to come to Texas!!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. spicy tonkotsu!

e5Ngsl6dvCo7GWwbkr7Y7g.text: One of the better ramen places and it's located in Las Vegas! This place is a must if you love Japanese-style ramen and happen to be in Vegas.  I am a big fan and there's a real science about making that perfect bowl of ramen. The broth is essentially 70% of the main ingredients that either can make or break a bowl of ramen.  Monta is well-known for their pork and chicken broth or the combination of the two. Had the tonkotsu ramen with thin noodles in pork broth included two slices of pork chashu, black mushrooms, bamboo shoots, green onions and an addition of nitamago (marinated soft boiled egg).  The ramen was really delicious. Even our Japanese colleagues thought the ramen was pretty good being in the US.  This place is not very big so it can get rather crowded so expect to wait during lunch hours.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. menu
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. tonkotsu ramen with an added soft-boiled egg

S7EMeg7Q1U8efYvapRKOuA.text: Could this be my favorite ramen spot in Las Vegas? Absolutely! It's good, affordable and fast from when you order. The wait time can be ridiculous at times but it's worth the wait. Tip: make sure your entire party is with you or you will have to wait to be seated.

JHBxpqSLK_YqazyXQAUYsQ.text: This place has it all: great service, intimate dining room, quick food and delicious menu items, and it is affordable! Monta is always a must visit when I come to Vegas... Go late, around 11pm or midnight to get right in. Otherwise, the wait could be forever. There are only about 30 seats.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu Shoyu Ramen with thick noodles (instead of the menu recommended thin).

-LskB2EF9uEguCIpVyWDSQ.text: People always rant and rave about this place. I think this is the third time I've had it and I'm just not impressed. The noodles seemed too hard/thick and the pork just wasn't as melt in your mouth as I like it!  The flavor isn't even all that... I prefer Ramen Sora by far!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi

iR7JjAw8KGHk3UITEOKnpA.text: I'm so glad I found Monta ramen during my trip to Vegas ! Their ramen was one of the best ramen I ever had and at a very reasonable price about 6-8$ a bowl. My bf and I also ordered a side order of their fried rice, it was indeed delicious also! I recommend the spicy tonkatsu ramen! Service was great too, but a very small spot so might have to wait.

PegRYrraCQynU6nTVnRwLA.text: I have wanted to try Monta for a good few years now & somehow had never made it. Lol, that's what I get for not having foodie friends. My friends have gutter palates & they're not adventurous @ all.  Fortunately, I have made new friends & that was how I ended up here. Thanks to Cresta I., I finally got to try Monta. I had accompanied her on a Mommy & me day. I, being the, me in the equation :P  We arrived a little before 6 pm on a Tuesday. We had actually tried to come around lunch time, which was silly of us, because it was way too packed. However, when we returned, it was less crowded & we were seated immediately at the counter.   I ordered the Tonkatsu-Shoyu Ramen with Nitamago & some chicken fried rice. The rice came out first & it was really good. Then, the moment I had been waiting for, and cue the angels...AHHHH...my ramen. It just looked so beautiful & smelled wonderful. As I write this now, my mouth is watering & I can just taste it. It really was so comforting & delicious, the epitome of Umami, in the general sense. I just wanted to dive in and backstroke in there! I was totally reminded of the movie Ramen Girl, and I could just feel the love, and heart & soul that went into this bowl of ramen. Unfortunately, I have nothing else to compare it to. I have been to Japan, but sadly I never had the pleasure of having ramen while I was there :(  Overall, I really love this place & I will definitely be back. The staff is wonderful & gracious. It was a lot of fun sitting @ the counter & watching the cooking going on back there. Lol, I did find it amusing to see some of my fellow Hispanics back there doing big things ;) I'm pretty sure they were trying to pass them off as Japanese by tying their headbands a little tighter than normal though. Well, they do it @ Benihana, so why not here. Ha Ha! I will totally recommend this place to any and everyone who will listen.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. I know you&#39;re all jealous!

1KcXnx-a3RYEC9lEJdNkpA.text: I always come here when I'm in Vegas and we always wait it out because the ramen is that good. The only time I haven't had to wait more than half an hour was coming on a weekday after 8pm, but I like to come during the day because it makes for amazing hangover lunch. From experience, either the morning batch tastes better or the ramen tastes better after a night out.  The ramen is cheaper than any place I've been to. My favorite is the kuro (black) ramen which is fried garlic with tonkotsu ($7.99) The regular tonkotsu ($6.99) is good too. Toppings aren't expensive either. I always add a soft boiled egg ($1). I like to get the mentaiko bowl and eat whatever rice is leftover with my remaining broth.  There's a wait for a reason and it's well worth it.

-cm43-CmF-YVBsJehSf2Eg.text: Finally got a chance to try this place..we came here a few weeks back and never for a chance to write my review.. So here I am, playing catch up!   Anyway.. We've been hearing so many good things about this place.. So of course, it's bookmarked! I'm glad to say.. I tried it..& ehhh.. Well.. I've had better. Sorry fellow yelpers.. I took everyone's opinion and tried it when it came to my turn.. Just wasn't pleased.. The soup was weak.. Their pork was really soft though! Like melts in your mouth soft! So that's good.. I got their thick noodles.. & it was ok..my bf got thin noodles and he liked the thin ones better, my bf is crazy about this place though.. Then again he's crazy about every ramen place! Lol we also got the fried dumplings.. (Gyzo)? I forgot, but it tastes like any other friend dumplings I had.. I don't think it's anything special... Specially for that price.. Nope..   All in all, glad I got to try it.. Two bowls and one dumpling order came out to be $40 including tip and all add-on's in our ramen.. If you're ever in town.. Give it a try!   The wait is pretty long though! Come in small groups! The place is tiny!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Could do without..
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Thick noodles...
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

nNYTYDa0QGQ1MuN9caLOow.text: Cute spot for a quick bite. Service was friendly, food came out quick and it was very tasty. Enjoyed a plate of kimchi fried rice and the little one had the medium size ramen bowl, would go back for both!

-0KYRFNwGQ9oPIvY3Szm8Q.text: A little more disappointed. I've been coming here for 2 years. It was my ultimate favorite. The portioning sizes are way smaller and the broth isn't as flavorful.. Still good but I can say that this isn't my favorite anymore. Sad.

gD-AlfYb5jtTOJJeE1dKxw.text: This is the best Ramen I've had in the US. I lived in Japan for 4 years and this place takes me back, just like the ramen I got when I was overseas. Highly recommend. It is a small space so you will have to wait for a table or a seat at the bar. It's always crowded but it's worth the wait.

PbiUExvsH5OVm3C1RAgZXg.text: Best ramen place outside of West Los Angeles!!! Always crowded which is a good indication of how good this place is. The price is right and the ramen is delicious!!  Now we don't have to go back to LA when we are craving some ramen.

meKKQhZZ6hANTarO9VwjEw.text: Very small busy ramen noodles. Got seated right the way at opened spots for sushi bar. Food came out very fast. I meant ramen even came out before appetizer gyoza. We went there for ramen and it was just ok. Fast service. Will be back again.

55R7uYqW1gGIW_-8SU8Vew.text: Best Roman and fried rice I've ever had!!! Sooo good. This place knows how to make the broth. The flavors in the ramen broth are on point! If you're visiting Vegas this is a must eat! You will not be disappointed. If you're not into ramen, give this place a try, they will change your mind.

ugL8fjDqLELX0IAyQf0xFQ.text: Tonkatsu is amazing. Go to ramen place for sure.   They have pork belly that can get addicting   I would go all the time if I could. So I do

oyLHaLxlLNcyWzmSugI-UQ.text: This is the best Ramen I have ever had. I have had ramen other places which is usually just ok, but Monta's Tonkotsu is the best! The venue is small/cozy and your entire party has to be there for them to seat you so they can keep the line moving, but its a great experience, great food and pretty good service.

4WcbeCgbsJa8O6JA5MgAcg.text: I'm not sure what the hype is all about at Monta Ramen.  Don't get me wrong, this place has good Ramen but I've definitely had better elsewhere.  I ordered the Tonkatsu-Shoyu Ramen with nori and corn.  Personally my broth was a little bit on the salty side and my best friend felt the same way.  We also ordered gyoza, which I liked very much but that's about it.  We did arrive about 12:30 A.M. and I'm assuming we got the last batch since all the workers seemed to be cleaning up the place as we finished up our Ramen.  They also forgot to give us the red ginger you usually get on the side.  My boyfriend and I didn't realize this until we headed out the door after seeing the Ramen add-ons were compiled together at the bar ready to be stored for the next business day.  If you plan to go maybe try and go during normal/peak hours.  The way I see it, it's like ordering french fries in the wee hours of the night, when they are usually sitting out too long and become stale and soggy.  Basically, you might not get the best batch of broth...   Yeah, sorry Monta Ramen, there's just no chemistry between you and me.  Good try though.  Lina Chen

SMNiG56GP7RhnRzzA79bog.text: My favorite Ramen restaurant in Las Vegas! Small place but they manage everything well. I love Tonkatsu Ramen and Gyoza. And the service was good.

YveUAInuXFoq0fmrXLB74g.text: I was really excited to see this ramen place in Vegas! As a ramen maniac I loved the pork chashu and the bamboo shoot. Must try ramen place in Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkutsu ramen

EraSf14eJD8cP4cL2VQsUQ.text: Expect a line, fast almost abrupt service keeps the room moving. Not a huge menu but the offerings are consistently "good". Chilled noodle salad with yuzu is refreshing and delicious, Ramen is done well just a little on the ubiquitous side. Still a good value and worth a try for sure.

rrwXwElMYJQ1w689rJjErg.text: When I think of Ramen in Vegas, I think of Monta Ramen. It's always packed to the brim with people and there's even more people huddled outside the door waiting to get in. You would think this is the only Ramen game in town.   I'm a fan of the Kuro Ramen which features black garlic oil in the tonkotsu-shoya broth. The restaurant is small and I would not recommend coming with a big group.

91KSbRkvvIUizxsaMSO--A.text: 1/2014 We tried Many Japanese ramen noodle places in Southern California , this one is called: ton lotus with pork, wild mushrooms and thin noodles, and it's by far the best. That's it, nothing else to add.   2/27/2015 Still the best ramen I EVER had. No further comments.  7/17/2015 Alert !  Monta Ramen fell to 2-nd place in a taste test, crowned by Santouka Ramen in Mission Viejo, California. Who would have thought of that ?!!  2/17/2016 Monta ramen still stands second to Santouka Ramen in Mission Viejo, BUT don't be deceived, it blows out of the water most ramen joints around Orange County , CA, and the ramen noodle joints on the strip in Vegas don't stand a chance. Way to go Yelp :)  9/22/2017 Their spicy miso soup is still dope - if not better than last time....

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States

ZRtRywdS8I7IPv1ktADSvg.text: Good flavor and very amazing quick service. The noodles were over cook and mushy. The rice was overcooked as well

1kGUwDIaqCxAt64U6sGm1A.text: First time there - we had a lot of first times on this trip.  The ramen in the pork and chicken broth is to die for. Service was excellent. Highly recommend. Oh and also the post stickers! Yum yum yum!

HtqKHqxSdirEdjy_h7cE2Q.text: I've been to ramen places all over from LA, SF, Hawaii and more, and I am a fan of Monta. It definitely has similar quality of ramen compared to many of the other places that I frequent in LA and SF. I ordered the basic staple of Tonkatsu ramen. The broth was very good, not too greasy or salty, but a great combination of pork flavors. The noodles were also well cooked, not too soft or al dente. Then comes the best part, the large pork pieces that are placed in the ramen. They are thinly sliced with a portion of fat that just makes it taste so good. I always want more, and often do order extra pork for my ramen, since they usually only give you about 2-3 pieces and after you have them, you want more. The ramen also comes with some other ingredients and if you start adding some extra ingredients, the cost of your bowl of ramen will add up (including a soft-boiled egg, extra noodles, some vegetables, and more). Overall, this is a quality ramen joint that I will definitely go back to again.

sRKTc93Rn250Kmen1DBsMw.text: Stopped here after eating at Raku because my fiance was still hungry.  The ambience is not fancy but the noodles are SUPERB.  The ramen noodles were excellent - cooked perfectly.  The chashu was delish, practically melted in our mouths and the broth was super tasty. Their service was very nice and friendly unlike Ippudo in NYC which claims to have the best ramen noodles.  Personally, I don't think they deserve a 1 minute wait, never mind the craziness of 2 hours - and rude on top of that.  I can only hope that Monta opens up a spot in NYC.  If you even remotely like ramen - you have to go there when you are in Las Vegas.

QDklFJP0MBYOiK6xywhotQ.text: I have already posted my review, but those people who do not understand the difference between  tonkOtsu              and            tonkAtsu  should not be writing a review on Ramen or Japanese restaurant, period.

oNWJrkvSA_JQCHkeWE3YRA.text: Love the simplicity of the menu and the broth was yum (a bit too much msg but definite yum).  I'll definitely be back on every visit to vegas!

AN1YerW3y1lk-I6UO6GoNQ.text: Great small ramen shop!  small oasis, close to the strip. Tonkatsu ramen is dope, their draft beer is also very good.  Very friendly people, great food for  the money!!!

XdyXD8A26oHtd6pZbYrHBQ.text: We tried the Miso ramen and Tonkatsu ramen, both were delicious! I'd say it is comparable to some delicious ramens at San Diego (i.e Santouka ramen). A bowl of ramen is around $7, and extra sides (corn, extra meat, etc) are around $0.5. It's a small restaurant - probably only fits 25 people. Great food and great service!

6UKXqGdo10uX-EQehXiGBg.text: Another great find through YELP!  Arrived at Monta around 9:30 and were lucky enough to get seated!  Every spot was taken.  I counted 23 seats in the house.  Mom and I had the Shoyu Ramen. The flavor was delicious! Dad had the Tonkotsu/Shoyu Ramen.  The noodles were thinner, and the broth was a little thicker. My husband had the Tonkotsu Ramen with corn and a side order of kimchi.  He ate every bit and said we would be back again.  Great place for ramen!

DJNQvPjb4tkP2xW_GYUrCg.text: The tonkotsu ramen and the tonkotsu-shoyu ramen were both excellent.  The noodles were definitely the standout, and the 45 minute wait was worth it.  We'll be back in the future!

iUnX0o7acjgdPdQuGX_vAA.text: Mmmm monta, i want to go to there. I always leave satisfied.  Most delicious pork ever.  Actually it's so rich that I don't usually order extras, 2 pieces is enough for me.   Some reviewers have said that it's too salty and sometimes I agree, but then I just pour more water in it to balance it out.  My go-to ramen:  Miso ramen with shredded green onion, egg, and kimchee.

X-_UPplcjAffYuYSOXnCOA.text: it was so crowded i ordered take out. it was one of the best and one and only japanese ramen place i found in Vegas coming from Hawaii which have ramen houses all over the island. the tonkotsu broth was so creamy and good and the mentaiko rice bowl was delicious. i would definetly go back everytim i crave ramen or a nice soup broth to warm you up

4TiJOYrI6HJuLsuMf-lW9g.text: Great ramen.  Simple with a full body broth.  Probably one of my favorite ramen shops, period.

H8CpepKdkjm2xbDM8Un2eg.text: Nice place!  They are always eager to please their customers.  The food is tasty.  I love the hiyashi chuka, kimchee fried rice, and an iced green tea.    I feel like such a fatty after walking away each time, but it's damn good food.  Will visit again and again.

mkwQfSDFilcswmsKOifQCw.text: Thursday 1:30pm and the wait is over half an hour for a party of two. -_- really? But seriously this place is pretty darn good. The wait is lame but it's worth it! I've only had samples of the ramen and it's good but I have had WAY better ramen elsewhere. the broth is super rich and pretty good but the noodles are too thin! I come here for the pork belly rice! It trumps all other rice bowls I have had in the area. So hmm.... LV's monta pork belly rice bowl vs LA's daikokuya shredded pork rice bowl. Let the showdown begin!

_mWCUrUZf_ytJj2N87On2Q.text: How they make ramen so damn creamy? Better not be lard..

aJV_JPI2SPkf6Dcr6ulsaA.text: Ever since I saw a movie called Ramen Girl, trying out a properly prepared ramen has been one of my goals. Now I can say that I've finally accomplished that. This is not the ramen you were forced to eat in college to save money. I had tonkatsu ramen which had a full bodied pork broth with thin slices of barbequed pork belly. It was such a revelation of what well made noodles should be. I will regret having to go back home where we don't have any Japanese restaurants that put the care into creating this spectacular comfort food.

pHwSba0hFepT4E8aRmiafQ.text: I really appreciate a place that has a small menu of things that are very well executed. Monta is just such a place. The service is efficient and food is affordable.It only suits small parties and there is often a wait. I would love to see more vegetables available for the soups but overall a great spot!

dVLN5-LLARNd3VL55tDytQ.text: Best ramen I've ever tried. Dishes are fresh and made to order. The place seems as authentic as it gets and is downright legit. If you are not interested in having pork, then don't bother. Definitely wish there some chicken options. The price is great and the flavor is just right. It gets packed, so expect to wait, especially if you are more than two diners. On a warm Vegas night, you can't go wrong with some cold noodles and an ice cold Japanese beer. The gyoza is also pretty delicious and comes out exactly as pictured in the menu...every time! One of my favorite things about this place is the spicy horse radish mustard that comes on the side. It is made in house and unreal. Was not a fan of the pork belly bowl, a little too fatty and more rice than anything, but it looks like a crowd pleaser. They also have some typical Japanese canned beverages. Place is super clean, kitchen is open for all to see, and service is both prompt and courteous.

DHioIF6dU-19yhlD6Xhf0A.text: i love ramen! i finally got a chance to come check this place out when my co-worker and i had an extra long lunch break. i love that they have a really simple menu. i had the tonkotsu ramen and it was delicious. i wish they served hot tea though. quick service at lunch time. the place is really small and crowded when we went...however, it was peak lunch hour. pretty quick turnover though. i'll be back. =)

lB2YD7LwHKT2pESYCqow0A.text: Still going here every week if not more often. They finally have a sign up so they're a bit easier to spot. Anyway, I'm glad everyone else is liking this place.  I don't know why the bad reviews on the gyoza, because it's right up my alley.  And yes, they do use different noodles for the Tonkotsu ramen versus the others.  The tonkotsu ramen is Hakata style, and is known for the very thin, very delicious noodles.  They cook theirs a little more here than they do in Hakata, but it's still great. Anyway, having tried the miso ramen, I'd say give this one a shot too.  It's their tonkotsu soup with miso added to give it a rich nutty flavor that really sticks to your ribs. I also have to recommend the chahan (fried rice), it is super peppery and delicious.  Just the way I remember it from my highschool days in Japan. A second note.  Anything you don't like on your ramen, let them know.  I keep going with picky eaters (1 vegan, others just picky), and they've made a vegan kimchi chahan, as well as bowls of ramen with extra this, no that, whatever you ask for. As always, they're eager to please, and definitely worth seeing, so help Monta stay busy, and maybe even expand.  I would love to see more of these guys.

hGsqmmW6tnxr0H_K5J5NmQ.text: Always stop by Monta for ramen when we are in town.  They serve up some tasty ramen.  I usually order the miso although the tonkatsu is tasty as well.  The gyoza is good too.  I ordered a small rice bowl one time but the ramen is enough and I struggled to finish both.

LV0SAhaLbUtH2QK8piK9Aw.text: I miss you sooooo much Monta.  The ramen here in Florida is like well...terrible.  I would do just about anything to sip your broth, slurp your noodles, the pork, the egg, the everything.....me sad.

wd34QVVGCSiDJ-fpYICvTg.text: I had the tonkotsu ramen. The broth is on the salty side but that's the way it should be. It should be salty and silky. The noodles were perfectly cooked and the chashu was heavenly! It's the best chashu I've had!  If people want a less salty broth, then I would suggest trying the shoyu ramen or the combo (tonkotsu shoyu).  Btw, it's tonkOtsu not tonkAtsu. Tonkatsu is breaded, deep-fried pork cutlet. Get it straight people!

VyOMm7EJAnnFU0oD0JyiBA.text: Purpose of visit: light lunch in anticipation of a big dinner later that night. Ordered a bowl of TonkoTsu ramen with Gyoza And an egg omelette. Service was quick and efficient. We got lucky and were seated before the crowd showed up.usually a wait to sit down in the small restaurant. Ramen flavor was good. Portion was just right for a light lunch. Solid place and very reasonably priced.

i_wMKJDkeI2-glXEXdTzqA.text: Interested what a bowl of ramen taste like instead of a cup O noodle soup . The best ramen in all of Las Vegas . Only 4 stars though because if your the waitress and you see ten people with bowed heads saying grace before the meal wait till we're done dont yell out " ramen ramen ramen" have some respect.

cvvf00unheHXwR8SOLd04g.text: Yelp helped me find this place, and I was not disappointed. Waited maybe 15 minutes to get in. When I was seated, a waitress orbiting came by with menus. We had the shoyu (chicken based) ramen with thicker noodles and the shoyu tonkatsu (blend of the shoyu chicken broth and the creamy pork tonkatsu broth). We didn't add extra toppings, and while they might have been nice, they were unnecessary. But bowls were brought quickly and consumed in near silence. The food was so good angels might have passed over our table. I loved the chewiness of the thicker noodles, but my lunch companion thought his thinner noodles were also good, though less chewy and not of a traditional soup noodle than the chewy egg based and thicker ramen noodles that I love. The waitress even checked in to see how our food was. Great service. I have nothing bad to say about this place. If I'm ever in Vegas again, I will make an effort to stop by this restaurant.

zsqXFZe4h4ied5SEJMKnwA.text: Went with friend and his wife for dinner. Very small shop in a lot near the end of chinatown. I did notice it was the only place that seemed busy besides the bar. Might be worried on wait during peak times, but wasn't too long for us, 15-20min. Ordered the miso ramen. Noodles were good texture and bite, broth was decent. Service was good too. Overall pretty decent.

FcyxApZa3eANPif2_Nmsow.text: love their soup noodle, the soup taste so good. Price is very good. But bad customer service + long waiting time.

1cdT1pHozcOpzRX_mD66NA.text: Great food! The people are nice but u have to get there as early as possible. It opens around 11:30, we got there at 11:32 and five min after there was a line waiting.

8CMtm8XX1FKx_48Ccw-n4Q.text: Monta Noodle House is an exceptional rarity, especially in a desert locale like Las Vegas. This place is popular with both locals and tourists (in my case, I am simply an out of towner).   Although not nearly as amazing as Shinsengumi or Daikokuya in my hometown of LA, Monta is a great alternative if you find yourself hankering for a satisfying bowl of ramen after a long drive to Vegas. I opted for a classic bowl of ramen with slices of pork char siu, and it totally hit the spot for me.   If you ever decide to skip out on the numerous fast food chains in Barstow, be sure to pay Monta Noodle House a visit. You'd be glad you did!

lIAoNLD8n4qx0suQ8qKmVA.text: I always have great Ramen here.  Their fried rice tastes incredible.  It is a small restaurant so you often have to wait quite a while for a seat.  Food is consistently great.  Service is ok unless you have a problem and then they are terrible at handling even small issues like when they forgot ingredients in my Ramen.  One thing I don't care for is that since there is always people waiting I feel rushed to chow down and get out of there fast to make room for others.

zM9biY5gXQB2fT3LnKX2uw.text: Extremely friendly service like a sushi restaurant. But you have to really like Ramen because that's about all they have. And it just didn't seem like the food was easy to get excited about.

KTn_q5ePe1SrAXIq25pyoA.text: Excellent place for noodles. I mean, really really good. It was hot as heck in Vegas and we still went to go get noodles for lunch. Place gets packed pretty early on, but well worth the wait.   Vegas has Monta, LA has Hakata Ramen Shin-Sen-Gumi.

i7hBhLSx27PSl01rDn0bCg.text: Simple amazing.  The noodles here were fantastic with a nice variety of different sauces to completely customize your meal.   I had the Shoyu Ramen and it was wonderful.  The noodles and pork were fantastic.  The broth was also incredibly flavorful with a smoother, milder taste.  I tried the tonkatsu broth too which is equally wonderful but in a more milky, slightly heavier way.  The gyoza was also great especially paired with some of the sauces.  This was definitely one of the best things I have eaten in a long time.  The fact that I was hungover and had spent the morning in the desert only added to the greatness.  The place had a very nice, and subtle ambiance.  The place was clean, the decorations were very simple but had personality and the place drew a nice crowd that was more than just the tourists that clog the Strip.  The wait staff was also incredibly helpful, efficient, and friendly.  I liked that when my table ordered the gyoza they said it would be ready in seven minutes.  Now that's service!  Oh, and they have A/C now. so your desert heat fears can be alleviated.  If you're in Vegas and want to get away from the hustle and bustle of the Strip and also want some great Ramen this is the place to go.  I definitely recommend going.  Also, great hangover food.

nEBx5650q2gCpx9XwSDRFQ.text: Still my favorite ramen place in town after many years. Miso ramen and the new Kuro (black garlic oil) ramen are both unbelievably great. Just took a newbie there today and he was amazed at the taste of his Miso ramen. A word of advice--this place gets packed during regular meal times (11am-3pm and 5pm-9pm), so expect a 30 minute wait. Or if you are a eat anytime guy like me, then go eat at 4pm and you would not have to wait in line!

qOMClxJsbIeVvlcyUYeQyQ.text: Amazing food.  Amazing service.  Cheap.  Large portions.  Sesame seeds(!) on the table, with other condiments.  I'll the other Yelpers to the work with the details.    When my roommate said she wanted Roman Noodles instead of sushi, I thought she was nuts, but wow....I will definitely be returning!

P-i7PxVfb8N6pKP7b_p4aA.text: Love the ramen. It was just what I needed after a long week in Vegas. Had the spicy tonkatsu with egg and was delicious. Adding to places that I will be back to while in Vegas.

S71vM-_hQcYyW4638I37Eg.text: Simply yummy! Very rich n flavorful :) I have tried everything on the menu. Never had a disappointed meal. Love everything on the menu. Always busy, there is waiting line most of the time. Love their Asahi beer draft.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Try their asahi beer!!!!

oflCsT0hsMecDM9xnExSKA.text: Holy upgrade!   It's been a while since we've been back to Monta.  It's not because it's not delicious.  Believe me it is the very delicious!  We finally came back for ramen last night and the entire experience was such an upgrade!  Two air conditioning units added in and no wait on a Tuesday night.  Hooray!  Now onto the food.  Move over Bun Thit Nuong, Taiwanese cold noodles, and Naeng Myun.  Summer cold noodles got a new MVP!  Cold ramen noodles at Monta Ramen.  What better dish to eat than cold al dente ramen noodles mixed in with a tangy light yuzu soy sauce and crunchy toss-in's of fungus, cucumber, bean sprouts, egg, pop of mustard and of course, you can't forget the FATTY FATTY cha-shu!  Conclusion:  Monta Ramen cold noodles during summer time.  Monta Ramen hot noodles during the winter time.  FTW.

pCoyJ-41urzEZHy99jGFkw.text: I love ramen, but their food has enough oil to fuel your car on your way back home. Their noodles are so gooood. They don't have that "instant" noodle flavor like some restaurants do. I will always come back, but why does it have to be so fattening!?! -_-

L2TUZ2FDPF1QrTc4BYQmOg.text: When we woke up today it was and my wife had a cold. So we figured it would be a good day for soup and headed off to Monta for some ramen.  We both ordered green tea hoping for a soothing, warm start to the meal. The waiter brought out two cans of cold green tea. We explained we were expecting hot tea and were told they don't have any hot tea. So we asked for water with lemon but were told they don't have lemon. I ended up ordering a diet coke and my wife stuck with plain water  Things went smoother from there.  I ordered the Tonkatsu ramen with egg, nori, and mustard greens. It was good, salty.  My wife ordered the Tonkatsu shoyu ramen with egg and green onion. It was also good and less salty than mine.  I highly recommend getting the eggs. It was a great addition to both. Beyond that, choose what you like.  Overall, I preferred my wife's ramen and she preferred mine. We switched midway through though I was only halfway done and she'd finished two-thirds of hers. I got ripped off.  We also ordered kimchee and gyoza. The kimchee was good but nothing special. The gyoza never arrived. However, the kimchee and ramen were plenty, so we didn't make a big deal of it. (I did check the receipt and verified we weren't charged for the gyoza.)  Great place for a rainy day, some of the best ramen I've ever had.

EE8JPInd6_oPKZ4ld11pyA.text: It's been quite a while since I wrote my first review for this place.  UPDATE TIME!  I've been back to Monta several times.. and by several I mean, ever since I had my first taste.. I've been back at least 4-5 times in a month.  Since my first time, nothing about the food has changed but there have been some additions to the menu such as the Tonkotsu Shoyu ramen and the Cold noodles (which I have yet to try). The food is still the same and I STILL LOVE IT.  The only thing that's changed is the prices for toppings and such has gone up a little bit and now my meal averages to about $12-$14 a trip for just one bowl. A little bit pricey sometimes but hey, you get what you pay for!  My old review still holds truth! GO FORTH AND EAT MONTA!

Ytpw1485I1dE-kK0LLSsWw.text: This is my first review so be gentle! I would like to say I came in here at a very good time! From what I hear, it's a densely crowded place with a bit of a wait, but I didn't wait and had a nice seat with my friends! This took place on a Saturday night as well, mind you.  Service was so-so, but goes well with a small shabby place such as Monta. Shabby, but CLEAN. It reminded me very well of the corner noodles houses they have in Japan. Stepping into Monta reminded me of the times I stayed in Japan during hot summers and cold autumns.   I ordered the Tonkotsu-Shoyu ramen. Dericious aromatic smell, and served hot. I could say I enjoyed every bite and every piece of pork in this ramen! (Mind you, I am not a pork fan.) I believe Monta deserves a first-timers graced visit, so check em out! :)

Ar6bMlD3wjmxpNcvsvq75g.text: Great food, great service I really recomended!

Q3LV9Sd-pOL0xkyGlMNrPg.text: My Girlfriend asked me one day to try a ramen house. My initial thought was something you get for lunch in your college days. I was blown away by the depth of flavor they have in their broth and the authenticity they deliver. The menu is simple and short. Four different broths, a few additional toppings and a couple of rice and pork options for appetizers. There is usually a line but great food always has one, so be prepared to wait 20-30 minutes as the place isn't very big. What they don't have in square feet they make up for in exception service and great authentic ramen flavor.

1Ql1MtwwVXn33vQwXdwjtA.text: Pro: yum! I like the thin noodles, but I usually focus on the broth. I got the tonkatsu miso and it was an delicious blend of pork and chicken.  Con: the wait. Also, there is no spicy version of ramen

uylfhpyggVJgwOYTmE24gg.text: This place may be small in size but big in value. Their soups are great and the pork belly with rice was amazing! The menu may not be very deep but what they make is top notch.  Reasonable hours with reasonable pricing and excellent service. A great place to go to get something in your belly after a night of drinking with friends.

zaF2NJQBtEnBAdg7qINu8Q.text: Kuro ramen (black garlic oil). Extra nori. Nitamago. Delicious!

vSHswaUIfHoykolb7gOy5A.text: I only wish they have one in So Cal.  I had the Kuro and the broth is so rich and nothing I've tasted here. We have a lot of great ramen places here but nothing like Monta. The manager was also super nice and called us a cab. The wait was long but totally worth it.  The fried rice was also yummy! My new go to ramen spot when I'm in town.

CA3dWVMJcEBVU4RrAiFDcw.text: I had the miso ramen. It was good. Nothing holy sh#t about it. I would not have it again though too salty for me.  TB had the cold noodles. I don't remember the exact name of the dish but it was good as well. Decently priced and fast service. Unfortunately, I eat some of the best ramen in the world on a regular basis (Yelp: Shoki) so this place doesn't really compare.

r7MaPN2UXsMY3bOFR-UagA.text: I did like the food as it was very good. The only thing that I really didn't like was that there wasn't much of a variety at all. I would give it a 5 if there was a lot of variety and Soba as well.

ZBvysCGWKs6jnBjlhivGVQ.text: Go to place along with Sora for a ramen fix. Also like to go to Sushi House Goyemon after 11pm to get some AYCE ramen.

AztAFlwOMHvK6U67-oVGqA.text: To date, my favorite ramen spot in Vegas. Small location so there are always wait times. But the flavor and quality of the ramen is stellar! Very reasonably priced. Everything you order is prepared fresh as your order is taken. Go here! Trust the fat kid

0fPtm8vj_WUrw9NmxMFAWA.text: Ordered the tonkatsu and the shoyu Ramen. Well, this is a place u either extremely love it or hate it never coming back. The tonkatsu soup base is way too salty, as almost the chef dumped the entire jaw in the salt.Its very very creamy and thick. It's how Japanese noodle base should be like.  And it has a very strong taste of the pork fat. Many might love the thickness, but I am not a pork fan, so is a no for me. Shoyu base is just chicken soup with soy sauce, just soso. Neither the thick wavy noodle or the thin noodle did the magic for me. I don't think I'm coming back, it's a good noodle place, just not for me.

Szw68-XfyWAJUx0kZnELNw.text: My Monta review has been delayed to its full capacity. Monta I say is easily the best ramen spot in my opinion. I was super addicted to this stuff at one point, shoyu ramen with corn and butter with a sh*t ton of spicy powder on top. Stuff is crack. I am even surprised how I used to be able to finish a whole bowl with extra chashu even! no soup leftover to the last drop! Why am I missing a star? I guess consistensy is questionable in recent times. There are some days where the broth is a bit in the salty or bland side, some days where the noodles are a bit undercooked. Either days, I would still pick Monta over any other ramen place (I've been to 5 other) in town, that's it!

R-QshilYu4X3e-aNYPkj8Q.text: This place is realy good,I understand now why people hype it up so much.I came in today for lunch and it was pretty packed i had to sit on the stool where you can see the chelfs wich i didnt mind i like watching them cook.And it wasnt hot even by the kitchen so thats good.I got the soy sause ramen and water.  Soy sause ramen-The noodles were aldentay and very good!The pork in it was pretty good but I didnt eat it all it had a sweetness to it it was good.And the broth was yummy as well it was salty and tasted like soy sause very flavorful though,I put extra soy sause and the red chilly flake things in for spicyness it was hella good.

DTRcsZtFAs14NwFji92OXA.text: I have been try to get to this place after reading some reviews on Yelp by my hero Yuki K. So I arrange to pick up Wifee from work on a pretence of tile shopping for the new kitchen , quick detour and we're at Monta.   I get the Miso Ramen, fab broth with huge pieces of pork and big fat noodles. Wifee got the Shoyu, it was simply splendid. Washed down with some Green Tea (in a can) and we were out the door for less than $20 before a tip.  It's a tiny place with super friendly staff, food is cooked right in front of you. Really good.

7feIGssb-fBT0K6Oyy4r5A.text: Definitely worth the wait! They are very quick and food is always really good. I always make a trip here when my friends and family are in town! On a hot day, the cold noodle dish is so refreshing.

VHexNtWfZldvvBq7XEQ1hw.text: WOW this place has nothing on the ramen places in Southern California! The broth is perfection- not salty, thick and flavorful. I only got 3 slices of pork (on the fattier side) however it was tasty and marinated well. The restaurant is small so be prepared to wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Monta Japanese Noodle House - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Tonkotsu ramen with boiled egg topping

_-Z70KkEsISOiBqo_6gCqw.text: My friend invited me to Monta Ramen for lunch. Our food was very delicious. I had chicken noodles and gyoza. The service was very good! I will definitely be coming back here again!

i458cACucWCOj8OPkgfzXw.text: the BEST ramen house in town.  their menu is simple, not bombarded with so many choices.   oh yeah, their pork belly fried rice is pretty amazing too.    during the winter, good luck with getting a table.  wait times can span to an hour or so.  it is a small restaurant and it's always packed.  but quality ramen at such a cheap price...I'd wait around for a table.
